headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Episode 5 Recap: Bursting the Bubble
abstract: The Doctor saves a rich wannabe vlogger from being eaten by a giant slug, but a final twist leaves him reeling.
lead_paragraph: We’ve passed the midway point in this season of “Doctor Who,” and the show’s ambition shows no sign of subsiding. After playing with themes of religion and politics, it’s artificial intelligence, already touched on in the earlier episode “Boom,” that’s the topic du jour in “Dot and Bubble.”

headline: Ohio Legislature Passes Bill Ensuring Biden’s Spot on the Ballot
abstract: The bill, which Gov. Mike DeWine, a Republican, is expected to sign this weekend, appeared to end the possibility that President Biden would not be on the state’s ballot in November.
lead_paragraph: The Ohio General Assembly has passed a legislative fix that ensures President Biden will be on the state’s ballot in November, averting a crisis that had been brewing for weeks over what is typically a minor procedural issue.

headline: Florida Deputy Who Fatally Shot Airman Is Fired
abstract: The Okaloosa County Sheriff’s Office said that the use of deadly force during the May 3 encounter at the airman’s apartment was unreasonable.
lead_paragraph: The Florida sheriff’s deputy who fatally shot a U.S. Air Force senior airman in the airman’s home this month has been fired, the sheriff’s office said on Friday, describing the deputy’s use of deadly force, which was captured on body camera, as “not objectively reasonable.”

headline: Trump and Allies Assail Conviction With Faulty Claims
abstract: After former President Donald J. Trump was found guilty, he and a number of conservative figures in the news media and lawmakers on the right have spread false and misleading claims about the Manhattan case.
lead_paragraph: After former President Donald J. Trump was found guilty of all 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, he instantly rejected the verdict and assailed the judge and criminal justice system.

headline: How Trump’s Most Loyal Supporters Are Responding to the Verdict
abstract: Many saw in the jury’s finding a rejection of themselves, of their values and even of democracy itself.
lead_paragraph: The sense of grievance erupted as powerfully as the verdict itself.

headline: Biden Dons Kansas City Helmet to Celebrate Its Super Bowl Victory
abstract: Taylor Swift was not at the White House to celebrate with her boyfriend, Travis Kelce, but kicker Harrison Butker, who recently drew controversy for a commencement speech, attended.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, President Biden urgently called for an end to the war in Gaza. He solemnly discussed the rule of law after former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal conviction. And he donned a shiny red helmet to the whoops and cheers of a pack of football players and fans.

headline: Cram In
abstract: Eric Warren’s Saturday debut fits a lot of fun into tight spaces.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Eric Warren’s second puzzle for The New York Times after his Friday debut in March 2023, and I think the two grids are at about the same level of difficulty. They have a similarly low word count, which is challenging for both the creator and the solver. Today we have only 66 clues, most of which lead to longer entries presented in stacks and stairs. This configuration looks imposing, but there are mild entries that made it solve quite smoothly for me.

headline: ‘2,000 Mules’ Producer Apologizes to Man Depicted Committing Election Fraud
abstract: Salem Media Group, which co-produced the 2022 film, issued the apology to a Georgia man who was falsely depicted as stuffing a ballot box near Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: The conservative media company Salem Media Group has apologized to a Georgia man who was falsely depicted as having committed election fraud in the film “2,000 Mules,” which Salem co-produced and released in 2022.

headline: Quote of the Day: Fresh From a Title, Hayes Takes Over the National Team
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I’m lucky to be born in England, but made in America.”

headline: Corrections: June 1, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 1, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the new president of Yale University misstated the number of  votes cast against a Stony Brook faculty senate motion to censure Maurie McInnis. It was 55, not 54.

headline: German Soccer Team’s Deal With a Weapons Maker Prompts Some Boos
abstract: For some fans of Borussia Dortmund, an advertising deal with Rheinmetall, a major arms manufacturer, has overshadowed the run-up to the Champions League final on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Borussia Dortmund, one of Germany’s most successful soccer clubs, is rooted in the industrial Ruhr region and prides itself on retaining its working-class roots, community engagement and anti-establishment mentality.

headline: A Small Army Combating a Flood of Deepfakes in India’s Election
abstract: Social media is awash with A.I.-altered audio, clipped video and manipulated images. Fact-checkers want to save the public from deception.
lead_paragraph: Through the middle of a high-stakes election being held during a mind-melting heat wave, a blizzard of confusing deepfakes blows across India. The variety seems endless: A.I.-powered mimicry, ventriloquy and deceptive editing effects. Some of it is crude, some jokey, some so obviously fake that it could never be expected to be seen as real.

headline: How Rhubarb Conquered Germany, Then the World
abstract: A tongue-twisting rap by a Berlin duo has spotlighted Germans’ love of their springtime produce. Now if only they could find a rhyme for asparagus.
lead_paragraph: In the past month, millions of people have found themselves stumbling through the contorted and catchy syllables of a song about, of all things, a woman named Barbara and some rhubarb-loving barbarians who drink beer while getting their beards barbered. In German.

headline: Scandals and Missteps Slow Momentum of Germany’s Far Right
abstract: The Alternative for Germany party remains strong, but a growing pushback at home and abroad may be blunting its surge.
lead_paragraph: The far-right Alternative for Germany party was poised for a banner year.

headline: The Champions League’s Most Bitter Rivalry May Be Off the Field
abstract: No club has won European soccer’s richest prize more than Real Madrid, but its recent dominance has been accompanied by a bruising fight over the tournament’s future.
lead_paragraph: Real Madrid had the celebratory jerseys ready as soon as its place in the Champions League final was secured. As the players raced to one another, exulting in yet another heart-stopping, nerve-shredding win, staff members sprinted onto the field after them, ensuring each star was correctly attired.

headline: Russian Missiles Hit Ukraine’s Energy System, Again
abstract: The large-scale air assault struck several sites in western Ukraine, including places near the borders with NATO member countries.
lead_paragraph: Russian forces struck several of Ukraine’s energy facilities with drones and missiles early Saturday, in a major air assault that targeted cities across the country, including some near the borders with NATO members.

headline: Worried About Youth Crime, Newark Revives an 11 P.M. Curfew
abstract: Newark has begun enforcing a longstanding law that prohibits people under 18 from being out late at night.
lead_paragraph: When officials in Newark noted a recent increase in violent crime in their city, they were especially concerned about teenagers, both as perpetrators and as victims.

headline: How Michael Rainey Jr. of ‘Power Book II: Ghost’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Rainey starts his day with tea, and then it’s time for fancy cars, making beats and Call of Duty with his friends.
lead_paragraph: Michael Rainey Jr. had looked up to the rapper 50 Cent since he was 8 years old. So when he landed the opportunity to work with him (real name: Curtis James Jackson III) on the Starz crime drama “Power,” he couldn’t have been more excited.

headline: Doctor-Assisted Death Is Legal in 10 States. Could New York Be No. 11?
abstract: Activists have renewed attention on legislation related to the emotional issue of so-called medical aid in dying that has long languished in Albany.
lead_paragraph: The sounds of protest came forcefully from the Assembly chamber gallery, the chants echoing the words emblazoned on handmade banners that were held aloft: “Stop the suffering, pass the bill!”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: New York, Once Trump’s Playground, Is Now the Scene of His Indignities
abstract: Donald J. Trump was for decades a creature of New York. But in recent years, the city that helped make him seems more eager to break him.
lead_paragraph: New York City was once Donald J. Trump’s playground, the place where he made his name and then plastered it everywhere he could.

headline: Trump Has Few Ways to Overturn His Conviction as a New York Felon
abstract: The judge in Donald J. Trump’s case closed off many avenues of appeal, experts said, though his lawyers might challenge the novel theory at the case’s center.
lead_paragraph: “This is long from over,” Donald J. Trump, the former president and current felon, declared on Thursday, moments after a Manhattan jury convicted him on 34 counts of falsifying records to cover up a sex scandal.

headline: The Wedding Singer Takes a Celebrity Turn
abstract: To delight their guests, couples are booking musical headliners to give surprise performances at their weddings.
lead_paragraph: Wendy Mazur said her “jaw hit the floor” when she saw her favorite pop singer, Goldford, walk out with his guitar during her first dance with Jerry Bedwell at their wedding in April 2022.

headline: She Dreamed of a New York Media Life. Would Her Soul Survive It?
abstract: In “Ambition Monster,” Jennifer Romolini recounts a rise from blue-collar dropout to “Corporate Barbie,” and what it cost her.
lead_paragraph: This spring, the website LitHub published an essay about the lack of financial particulars in contemporary fiction. That piece stayed in my head as I read Jennifer Romolini’s spirited memoir about her transformation from an angry and self-destructive child of teen parents in working-class Philadelphia to a hard-charging fashion magazine editor and, later, a “Corporate Barbie” at a Fortune 500 tech company.

headline: An Epidemic Hit These Farms Hard. Then Things Got Even Darker.
abstract: Scott Preston’s debut novel, “The Borrowed Hills,” unfolds during the 2001 outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in Britain.
lead_paragraph: Scott Preston’s debut novel, “The Borrowed Hills,” begins in the north of England during the outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease in 2001, when several million British farm animals were slaughtered to contain the deadly virus. Steve Elliman, a truck driver, has returned to his father’s sheep farm in the hilly, rainy, boulder-strewn region of Cumbria, also known as the fells. The Ellimans are tenant farmers, unlike their more successful neighbor, William Herne, who owns the land on which he grazes his much larger flock.

headline: He Could Be the Next Lionel Messi. If Anyone Can Find Him.
abstract: In Joseph O’Neill’s new novel, the search for an African sports prodigy is wrapped around a story of American workplace dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible that you have encountered someone like Mark Wolfe, a restive 40-something in Pittsburgh who has, in his own words, “not fully recovered from a decade spent as an active member of the American intelligentsia.” Maybe you’ve worked with this guy, slept with him, sparred with him on social media.

headline: The 7 Grueling Months to Reclaim the Bookstore Dream a Fire Stole
abstract: A fire left Lucy Yu’s literary hub in Chinatown gutted. She was determined to rebuild it.
lead_paragraph: Lucy Yu wasn’t sure if she had smoke in her lungs or was having an anxiety attack. She needed fresh air.

headline: In the West Bank, Guns and a Locked Gate Signal a Town’s New Residents
abstract: Since the war in Gaza began, armed Israeli settlers, often accompanied by the army, have stepped up seizures of land long used by Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: From the outskirts of his town in the West Bank, the mayor surveyed the rocky hills stretching toward the Dead Sea where Palestinians had long farmed and herded, and pointed out the new features of the landscape.

headline: Google’s A.I. Search Leaves Publishers Scrambling
abstract: Since Google overhauled its search engine, publishers have tried to assess the danger to their brittle business models while calling for government intervention.
lead_paragraph: When Frank Pine searched Google for a link to a news article two months ago, he encountered paragraphs generated by artificial intelligence about the topic at the top of his results. To see what he wanted, he had to scroll past them.

headline: He’s Obsessed With Sports and Politics. His Novels Are, Too.
abstract: Joseph O’Neill’s fiction incorporates his real-world interests in ways that can surprise even him. His latest novel, “Godwin,” is about an adrift hero searching for a soccer superstar.
lead_paragraph: The novelist Joseph O’Neill has a good idea of his daughter’s earliest memories: being driven through the northern swath of Benin in a jeep, in hot pursuit of a (fictional) story her father himself was only beginning to understand. This is remote terrain, even for visitors who aren’t American toddlers on their first trip to West Africa.

headline: They’re Asian. They’re American. But, They Wonder, Are They Asian American?
abstract: Bhutanese Americans are the newest citizens of Asian descent. But many do not identify strongly as Asian Americans, reflecting the complexity of the label.
lead_paragraph: When Dinesh Nepal first arrived in the United States in 2010, he had never heard of the term “Asian American.”

headline: Security Deposits: Your Landlord May Owe You More Than You Think
abstract: Landlords are required to put security deposits in interest-bearing bank accounts. How much of that interest goes to you?
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a large market-rate apartment building on the Upper West Side. My landlord placed my security deposit in an interest-bearing account, as required by law. The account only pays 1 percent and the bank sends the full interest earnings to my landlord each month as a fee permitted by New York state. However, at the end of the year, I received a 1099 for the interest earned even though I never received the funds. Is this legal? And isn’t the landlord obligated to put the deposit in a higher-earning account considering that any earnings above 1 percent go to me?

headline: She’s 98, and Walked Past Corpses to Escape Russian Attacks
abstract: “If only everything would stop,” said Lidiia Lomikovska, who walked to safety after her town was attacked. But for civilians in the Donetsk region of Ukraine, it is not stopping.
lead_paragraph: When a Russian soldier appeared outside 98-year-old Lidiia Lomikovska’s shattered home in eastern Ukraine in late April, the first thing he did was shoot and kill the family dog.

headline: The Very Online Afterlife of Franz Kafka
abstract: One hundred years after his death, the Czech writer circulates as a pop idol of digital alienation.
lead_paragraph: On TikTok, a collection of objects sits atop a stack of books: a string of pearls, a Diptyque candle, a Sylvanian Families rabbit figurine in a scallop-collared dress. A woman’s hand brushes them aside. She pages through the pile of books below. We see “My Year of Rest and Relaxation” by Ottessa Moshfegh and “The Bell Jar” by Sylvia Plath. Also, “The Metamorphosis” by Franz Kafka, a fat black bug on its cover. A question typed over the scene asks: What do you conclude about me?

headline: The History of Black Baseball Players, on Full Display
abstract: As the number of African American players dwindles, a new exhibit at the Hall of Fame traces 150 years of Black baseball feats, stars and obstacles.
lead_paragraph: Octavius Catto’s impact was mostly unknown here at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, amid the sport’s heroic feats of lore and legend, like Joe DiMaggio’s 56-game hit streak, Ted Williams’s .406 batting average and Hank Aaron’s 715th home run to break Babe Ruth’s record.

headline: ‘Sugar’ Actress Kirby on the Only Album She Really Needs
abstract: She co-starred in the Apple TV+ show with Colin Farrell after appearing in “Killing Eve” and “Barry.” Now when she does a red carpet, she knows to go with Doc Martens.
lead_paragraph: When Kirby accepted the role of Ruby — a Bondish M-meets-Q foil to a Los Angeles private detective played by Colin Farrell — in the Apple TV+ series “Sugar,” she found herself among kindred spirits.

headline: Bacon, Banter and the Business of a Diner
abstract: “I try to make people feel good.” How one New Jersey diner keeps the doors open.
lead_paragraph: Just after 5 a.m. on a recent Friday, Bendix Diner, a small, family-run business, began frying up eggs on the griddle to make the first of dozens of dishes it would serve to a steadily rotating cast of regulars.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, AMC+, Disney+, Hulu, and More in June
abstract: “The Boys,” “Orphan Black: Echoes,” “The Bear” and “The Acolyte” will be streaming.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of June’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Google Rolls Back A.I. Search Feature After Flubs and Flaws
abstract: Google appears to have turned off its new A.I. Overviews for a number of searches as it works to minimize errors.
lead_paragraph: When Sundar Pichai, Google’s chief executive, introduced a generative artificial intelligence feature for the company’s search engine last month, he and his colleagues demonstrated the new capability with six text-based queries that the public could try out.

headline: My Friend Asked for Clothing Donations and Then Sold Them on Poshmark. Do I Confront Her?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to handle deception by a friend.
lead_paragraph: My friend is a high school teacher in a low-income area. She always shares tearful stories of her students’ need for food, school supplies, professional clothes for job interviews and so on. Over the years, I’ve donated food, snacks and clothing for her to give to her students. A few months ago, my friend said there was a job fair coming up at the school and the students needed clothes; she would take anything we could donate. I went through my closet and gathered professional blazers, skirts, pants and blouses and gave them to her. Long story short: I decided to start an account on Poshmark to sell my family’s old clothes. When I looked up some of my friends’ closets on the site, I discovered my teacher friend had posted and sold all the items I gave her for her students! Not just one or two items — all 20! What’s the right thing to do? Do I confront her, or do I ignore the fact that those kids never got the donated items? Once a donation has been made, what is the ethical expectation?— Name Withheld

headline: Democrats Push Biden to Make Trump’s Felonies a Top 2024 Issue
abstract: Interviews with dozens of Democrats reveal a party hungry to tell voters that Donald Trump’s conviction makes him unfit for office, and hopeful that President Biden will lead the way.
lead_paragraph: Now that former President Donald J. Trump is a convicted criminal, the Democratic Party finds itself wrestling with a choice that will help define this year’s presidential race: Should it try to push his felonies to the center of the election?

headline: Elaine May, Ahead of Her Time
abstract: For the brilliant comedian, writer and director, Hollywood success was elusive. A new book offers perspective on the rocky career.

headline: Why Mexico May Elect a Female President Before the United States
abstract: Having a woman as president will be a milestone in a country where gender-based violence is so common. But how much will change remains unclear.
lead_paragraph: Mexico is poised to elect its first female president on Sunday, a historic leap in a country long known for its machismo — and a big moment for all of North America.

headline: A 9/11 Charity Provides a Financial Safety Net to a Giuliani Firm
abstract: Five months after filing for bankruptcy, the former New York City mayor disclosed his company’s income from a foundation established to honor a firefighter killed on Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: Because of his efforts to overturn the 2020 election, Rudolph W. Giuliani has been indicted in two states and hit with a $148 million defamation judgment that forced him to seek bankruptcy protection.

headline: Trump Verdict Hardens Many Views, but Changes Some, Too
abstract: For the remaining undecided voters, the decision to pick former President Donald J. Trump could be more difficult now that he is a felon.
lead_paragraph: As the nation’s electorate processed the felony convictions of Donald J. Trump, the partisan divide in the verdict’s wake did not look so much like opposing sides of a chasm but like two alternate universes, one where the former president had been hounded and persecuted by his corrupt political enemies, the other where justice had finally been served to a career criminal.

headline: Richard Linklater Sees the Killer Inside Us All
abstract: David Marchese talks to the acclaimed director about his new film, “Hit Man,” and life’s big questions.
lead_paragraph: Richard Linklater’s latest movie, “Hit Man,” is a bit of a departure for the director, who has made some of the most acclaimed and influential indie films of the last 30-plus years. The movie, which stars the ascendant Glen Powell, is about a mild-mannered college professor who has a side gig with the New Orleans Police Department, setting up stings by posing as different hit men. It’s a tight, stylish and sexy thriller, with some twisted romance added in, from a filmmaker better known for the ambling rhythms and gently existential tone of beloved classics like “Dazed and Confused,” “Boyhood” and “Before Sunrise” (not to mention his great comedy “School of Rock,” which exists in a category of its own).

headline: Notre-Dame Rises Again ... in Lego
abstract: With rose windows, bell towers and a central spire, this model of the famed Paris cathedral is all the hype among adult fans of Lego, known as AFOLs.
lead_paragraph: Arnaud Gaudillat, a history teacher in France, recalled bursting into tears as he watched television coverage of flames tearing through the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in 2019. “We couldn’t do anything but just watch it burn,” he said.

headline: South African Voters Reject the Party That Freed Them From Apartheid
abstract: The African National Congress received less than 50 percent of the national vote for the first time since gaining power 30 years ago, setting the nation on an uncharted course.
lead_paragraph: The African National Congress lost its political monopoly on South Africa after election results on Saturday showed that with almost all of the votes counted, the party had received only about 40 percent, falling short of winning an absolute majority for the first time since vanquishing Africa’s last white-led regime 30 years ago.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,079, June 2, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 357, June 2, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Warnings of Election Meddling by China Never Reached the Prime Minister
abstract: A watchdog agency found roadblocks to the flow of information both within the spy agency and the public service.
lead_paragraph: It can be a bit difficult to keep tabs on the various inquiries and examinations into foreign interference in Canadian elections, particularly by China.

headline: It’s June Again
abstract: Summer returns, and with it all the feelings and fantasies and fears we associate with the season.
lead_paragraph: June! Again! I know! Where has the time gone? It’s boring to even raise the issue — your subjective experience of the months and years passing so quickly, how it seems just yesterday you were doing something (making plans to see Barbenheimer, maybe? That was last summer!) and now here we are, doing this again.

headline: Mixed News About Opioid Overdoses
abstract: Readers discuss reports of a decline in deaths in the U.S. but a rise in Baltimore.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Oil and Gas Companies Are Trying to Rig the Marketplace
abstract: Fossil fuel interests are spreading misinformation that renewable energy is harmful, unreliable and worse for consumers.
lead_paragraph: Many of us focused on the problem of climate change have been waiting for the day when renewable energy would become cheaper than fossil fuels.

headline: How to Think Through the Moral Tangle in Gaza
abstract: It’s not a black-and-white morality tale.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been on a book tour for the last few weeks, speaking around the country, and one of the questions I get asked most often isn’t about my book at all but along the lines of: What should I think of the war in Gaza?

headline: Mexico’s Women Are Speaking. Will a Female President Listen?
abstract: Neither female front-runner in Mexico’s presidential race has proposed a strong agenda to serve the women who put them where they are today.
lead_paragraph: My mother was born in 1943 in a country where she was not allowed to vote. The Mexican government did not grant women the right to vote in national elections — or the right to hold public office on a national level — until Oct. 17, 1953. Now, almost 71 years later, for the first time two women are leading the race to be Mexico’s next president: Claudia Sheinbaum, who is the front-runner, and Xóchitl Gálvez. It is no small feat for a country with a longstanding and complex relationship with machismo, and where every day some 10 women or girls are killed on average.

headline: Holy Cow, 34 for 45!
abstract: But the real verdict comes on 11/5.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At Nativity grade school, we grew up steeped in the lore — and gore — of martyrs. For their brave deeds and words, these men and women were stoned, crucified, beheaded, stripped of all their skin, shot with arrows and cooked alive on a red-hot griddle.

headline: That Other Guy
abstract: People tethered to a particular someone else, whether they like it or not.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: South Africa Is Not a Metaphor
abstract: The country’s story of liberation has been both a symbol of hope and a burden. Now it’s time for reality.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand why the party that liberated South Africa from white rule lost its parliamentary majority in the election this week, you need to look no further than Beauty Mzingeli’s living room. The first time she cast a ballot, she could hardly sleep the night before.

headline: Scenes From a Historic Verdict
abstract: A photographer captured the crowds outside the courthouse during Trump’s trial — and as the historic verdict came down.
lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, the scene outside the criminal courthouse in Downtown Manhattan where former President Donald Trump was standing trial was one of relatively orderly anticipation.

headline: 2 Books to Help You Go Gray Gracefully
abstract: Ditch the dye; live with style.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Companies Counter Pushback on Price Increases With Promotions
abstract: “The consumer was a fat pig — now there’s nothing left, and they need to feed the pig again,” one banker told DealBook.
lead_paragraph: The president of McDonald’s USA, Joe Erlinger, pushed back on “inaccurate” reports this week that said the chain had more than doubled its prices on some items over the last decade. But his retort wasn’t exactly reassuring: The average price of a Big Mac is up 21 percent from 2019.

headline: As Voting Ends in India, Modi Awaits a Verdict on His 10 Years in Power
abstract: While a newly united opposition seemed to gain some traction, exit polls showed the popular and entrenched prime minister was winning a third term.
lead_paragraph: Voting in India’s general election, a six-week-long referendum on Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s decade in power, came to a close on Saturday as much of the country’s populous north was gripped by a deadly heat wave.

headline: Meet Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore, the NASA Astronauts Riding on Boeing’s Starliner
abstract: For Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, the wait for this trip on the Boeing Starliner has been longer than they expected.
lead_paragraph: For Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, the wait for this trip on the Boeing Starliner has been longer than they expected.

headline: What Donald Trump Didn’t Say After His Trial
abstract: In his post-verdict remarks, the former president sounded more like an aggrieved New York businessman than the political martyr his supporters believe him to be.
lead_paragraph: The way to evaluate a political speech — I mean as a literary critic, not as a pundit or a partisan — is to examine how the rhetoric rises to the occasion. Does the moment demand gravity or transcendence? Humility or defiance? Do the speaker’s words answer the call of history?

headline: ‘Everyone Sat Stunned After the First Bite’
abstract: Chez Panisse’s blueberry cobbler has that effect.
lead_paragraph: A confession: I almost always pull back the sugar in a dessert recipe. (I’m sharing this here because I don’t think I’m alone.) I do this because 1) I come from a home where “not too sweet” is the highest praise a dessert can get; 2) I get cavities just by thinking about sweets; and 3) I love, love, love fresh fruit, and the last thing I want to do to my perfect, beautiful, expensive farmers’ market finds is dull their bright personalities with heaps of sugar.

headline: Sam Butcher, Who Gave the World Precious Moments, Dies at 85
abstract: His childlike porcelain characters thrilled and inspired generations of collectors. They also made him a millionaire.
lead_paragraph: Sam Butcher, the soft-spoken artist whose doe-eyed, pastel-hued porcelain Precious Moments figurines ignited a global collecting frenzy and made him a wealthy man, and whose Christian faith spurred him to build his own version of the Sistine Chapel in Carthage, Mo., died on May 20 at his home there. He was 85.

headline: How a Retirement Withdrawal Can Lead to a Perjury Conviction
abstract: A prominent lawyer was recently sentenced to home confinement for falsely claiming hardship to withdraw funds. How desperate must you be to take money out?
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, it’s illegal to spend money that you set aside for yourself.

headline: Idaho Man in ‘Doomsday’ Killings Is Sentenced to Death
abstract: Chad Daybell was convicted on Thursday in the murders of his first wife and two children of his current spouse, Lori Vallow Daybell. The couple’s extreme beliefs drew attention to the case.
lead_paragraph: An Idaho judge on Saturday sentenced a man to death, two days after he was found guilty of first-degree murder and other charges in the 2019 killings of his first wife and two of his current wife’s children, capping a case that drew scrutiny because of the couple’s “doomsday” religious beliefs.

headline: Yael Dayan, Israeli Writer, Politician and Daughter of War Hero, Dies at 85
abstract: She was hailed for her books and admired for promoting women’s rights. But her support for a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict angered many.
lead_paragraph: Yael Dayan, a celebrated Israeli writer who, after the death of her father, the war hero and statesman Moshe Dayan, entered politics and became a proponent of women’s rights, L.G.B.T.Q. issues and a two-state solution to the Palestinian conflict, died on May 18 at her home in Tel Aviv. She was 85.

headline: After Biden’s Push for Truce, Netanyahu Calls Israel’s War Plans Unchanged
abstract: The timing of the remarks seemed to rebuff the president’s hopes for a speedy end to the war. But some analysts said the prime minister was aiming at domestic supporters, not the White House.
lead_paragraph: A day after President Biden called on Israel and Hamas to reach a truce, declaring that it was “time for this war to end,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Saturday reiterated that Israel would not agree to a permanent cease-fire in Gaza as long as Hamas still retains governing and military power.

headline: Protesters in Tel Aviv Call on Netanyahu to Accept Cease-Fire Proposal
abstract: Thousands of demonstrators rallied in Israel on Saturday evening in support of the proposal. Protesters also gathered in Rome, Paris and Jakarta.
lead_paragraph: Protesters in Tel Aviv and around the world Saturday called on Israeli leaders to accept the latest road map for a cease-fire and the return of hostages in Gaza, a day after President Biden said it was time for the war to end.

headline: ‘He’s Had Great Challenges’: Giuliani Holds 80th Birthday Amid Many Woes
abstract: The indicted and increasingly isolated former New York mayor celebrated his birthday over pasta and meatballs. Donald J. Trump sent a video.
lead_paragraph: Consider this Midtown split screen.

headline: Robert Pickton, Notorious Canadian Serial Killer, Dies at 74
abstract: Convicted in the murder of six women (though he boasted of killing many more), he died of unspecified injuries after being assaulted in prison.
lead_paragraph: Robert Pickton, one of Canada’s most notorious serial killers, whose crimes called attention to police and societal disregard for the violent deaths of Indigenous women, died on Friday after a fellow inmate attacked him in prison in Quebec, where he was serving a life sentence. He was 74.

headline: Typecasting
abstract: Luke W. Schreiber’s debut Sunday puzzle is full of character(s).
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: U Tin Oo, Embattled Pro-Democracy Leader in Myanmar, Dies at 97
abstract: A powerful figure in his country, he helped found its main opposition party. “I had to face up to the harm I did to people when I served in the army,” he said.
lead_paragraph: U Tin Oo, a former Burmese armed forces chief and minister of defense who turned against his country’s repressive government to become a leader of the pro-democracy movement there, died on Saturday in Yangon, Myanmar. He was 97.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Laborers Who Take Time Off in Pakistan’s Record Heat Risk Going Hungry
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This isn’t heat. It’s a punishment, maybe from God.”

headline: Corrections: June 2, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 2, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on June 2 about student protests at Columbia University misstates the date that the university’s president, Minouche Shafik, asked the New York City Police Department to clear a pro-Palestinian student encampment on the university’s lawn. It was April 18, not April 17. The article also misstates the position of the literary theorist and activist Edward Said on a two-state solution. He supported the proposal in the 1990s but changed his public stance to support a one-state solution later in that decade.

headline: After Pipes Burst in Atlanta, Many Residents Lose Water, Then Patience
abstract: Major main breaks resulted in closed businesses, canceled events and angry residents who were upset over a lack of updates.
lead_paragraph: A series of water main breaks in Atlanta caused widespread disruption on Saturday, as outages and severely reduced water pressure forced some businesses to close and infuriated residents who criticized city officials for failing to provide timely updates.

headline: A Pacific Island With Ties to Taiwan Was Hacked. Was It Political?
abstract: Palau’s claims that China orchestrated the attack remain unproven. But it’s clear that the breach presents a danger for another ally of Palau: the United States.
lead_paragraph: Palau, a clump of about 350 small islands in the Pacific Ocean, has become increasingly important to the United States as China tries to build clout in the Indo-Pacific. This year, Washington finalized a long-delayed plan to give Palau hundreds of millions of dollars in aid over two decades.

headline: How Internet Access Is Transforming Life in This Amazon Tribe
abstract: Since September, the Marubo, an isolated Amazon tribe, were connected to high-speed internet through Elon Musk’s Starlink. Jack Nicas, The New York Times’s Brazil bureau chief, visited the tribe’s remote Indigenous villages to see what the internet has changed for them.
lead_paragraph: Since September, the Marubo, an isolated Amazon tribe, were connected to high-speed internet through Elon Musk’s Starlink. Jack Nicas, The New York Times’s Brazil bureau chief, visited the tribe’s remote Indigenous villages to see what the internet has changed for them.

headline: The Internet’s Final Frontier: Remote Amazon Tribes
abstract: Elon Musk’s Starlink has connected an isolated tribe to the outside world — and divided it from within.
lead_paragraph: As the speeches dragged on, eyes drifted to screens. Teenagers scrolled Instagram. One man texted his girlfriend. And men crowded around a phone streaming a soccer match while the group’s first female leader spoke.

headline: As Challenges Pile Up, a Spate of Summitry Spotlights Western Resolve
abstract: Wars in Ukraine and Gaza, along with Donald J. Trump’s candidacy, are testing the Western alliance. But starting with the 80th anniversary of D-Day this week, leaders have a rare opportunity to showcase unity.
lead_paragraph: Western leaders are embarking on an extraordinary stretch of summitry this week, which could give them a chance to project unity to adversaries who increasingly view the West as something to be defied, disregarded or even repudiated.

headline: ‘A.N.C. Has Been Humbled’: a Couple’s Vote Explains Why
abstract: Some South African voters welcomed the defeat of the African National Congress in last week’s elections, even as they remain wary of the country’s political future.
lead_paragraph: A bell tolled on TV, signaling a shift in the results tallied so far. From their home in northern Johannesburg, the Mathivha family celebrated the latest update: with the majority of votes counted, the African National Congress had earned a mere 41 percent.

headline: In Singapore, China Warns U.S. While Zelensky Seeks Support
abstract: The annual Shangri-La Dialogue became a stage for competing demands on U.S. global power, including the war in Ukraine and tensions over Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: The competing strains on U.S. global power came into sharp focus at a security conference on Sunday, where China accused the United States of stoking tensions around Taiwan and the South China Sea, and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sought greater support for his embattled country.

headline: I Supervised New York City Judges. Juan Merchan Put On a Master Class in the Trump Trial.
abstract: This is how judges can remain pillars for the rule of law in America.
lead_paragraph: I spent almost 13 years as a judge in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. I supervised judges presiding over a wide spectrum of cases, dealing with complex legal issues, angry victims, difficult defendants and intense media scrutiny. The job can at times be thankless and frustrating.

headline: Yoav Gallant Has Shown Defiance. Will He Again?
abstract: Israel is facing a stark choice about its future. Defense Minister Yoav Gallant represents a critical role in the path it takes.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Yoav Gallant told Israelis that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was leading the nation astray. Mr. Gallant, the defense minister and a member of the war cabinet, accused him of letting the nation drift into a military and civilian occupation of Gaza, which would cost Israel “blood and many victims, with no aim.” He challenged Mr. Netanyahu to rule that option out.

headline: Congestion Pricing Ignites an Old Rift: Drivers vs. Transit Riders
abstract: As New York City prepares to roll out its tolling program on June 30, the divide between those who love their cars and those who embrace their subway lines has only grown.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, Filolaos Kefalas, an electrical engineer, drove a black Corvette into Manhattan for his first date with Lisa Daglian, a transit advocate. She was not impressed.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: ‘A Building Employee Greeted Us With a Broad Smile Every Day’
abstract: Recalling a first job, trading places in a crowded subway car and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: The Floating Traffic Jam That Freaked Us All Out
abstract: The coronavirus pandemic schooled the world in the essential role of global supply chains. Have we learned anything from it?
lead_paragraph: Southern California appeared to be under siege from a blockade.

headline: A Productive Chat on the Significance of ‘Slack’
abstract: Once referring to those prone to idle behavior, the word has come somewhat full circle.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, The New York Times published an article examining the assertion by some elders that millennials are “a generation of slackers.” Such assumptions about younger generations are nothing new. “Even Aristotle and Plato were said to have expressed similar feelings about the slacker youth of their times,” the article read. While we might use the word “slack” to refer to a certain messaging app today, “it appears in some of our earliest Old English written records,” the lexicographer Kory Stamper said.

headline: Archival Treasures ‘Hidden in Plain Sight’
abstract: The Times’s clippings library, with millions of pieces of reference material, can tell its own stories.
lead_paragraph: There are millions of newspaper articles, photographs and other archival materials in The New York Times’s clippings library, a repository known to employees as the morgue.

headline: Why North Korea Launched Another Salvo of Trash Balloons Toward the South
abstract: The unusual offensive, across the world’s most heavily fortified border, is a revival of a Cold War-era tactic. The South is responding by blasting K-pop.
lead_paragraph: Cold War-era tactics are in vogue again at the world’s most heavily armed border.

headline: Faith-Based Groups That Assist Migrants Become Targets of Extremists
abstract: Charities that feed, clothe and shelter border crossers fear for the safety of their employees and volunteers as the election nears and the vitriol over immigration intensifies.
lead_paragraph: A man posing as a pest exterminator tried to gain access to a San Diego hotel that operates as a shelter for migrant families. The next day, a woman showed up claiming to be an immigrant in need of help. Workers at the shelter, run by Catholic Charities, turned away both impostors.

headline: A Tribal Eviction, a Blood Secret and the Knotty Questions of Belonging
abstract: In “Fire Exit,” a white man raised on a reservation wrestles with whether he should reveal to his daughter the complications of her heritage.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lovely clarity to Morgan Talty’s debut novel, “Fire Exit.” He is especially bracing about the losses that can accrue with time. When we first meet Charles Lamosway, Talty’s middle-aged protagonist, he is at a crossroads: Mental illness and dementia threaten to engulf his mother; he has been evicted from the Native reservation where he has lived all his life; and, most painful of all, his daughter doesn’t know him. That last problem, at least, is within his power to change. He strongly feels “she needed to know that her blood was her blood,” to be aware of her “connection to a past time and people.”

headline: The Long Life of Yuppie Scum
abstract: In “Triumph of the Yuppies,” Tom McGrath revels in the stories of a generation that turned its back on protest and bought into consumer culture.
lead_paragraph: In 1967, a bushy-haired Jerry Rubin walked onto the balcony of the New York Stock Exchange with a few friends and flung dollar bills down to the trading floor. Rubin, a co-founder of the activist group the Yippies, was delighted when the traders on the floor piled on top of one another to grab the money.

headline: 46 Children Were Taken From Ukraine. Many Are Up for Adoption in Russia.
abstract: The New York Times traced how a web of officials and politicians aligned with President Vladimir V. Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
lead_paragraph: As news of Russia’s invasion spread through Ukraine on Feb. 24, 2022, Dr. Natalia Lukina was waiting for a taxi at her home.

headline: China Lands Spacecraft on Far Side of the Moon
abstract: The landing brings the Chang’e-6 mission a step closer to being the first to return a sample from the part of the moon that’s never seen from Earth.
lead_paragraph: China successfully landed a lunar lander on the far side of the moon on Sunday morning, the country’s space agency announced, taking the mission one step closer to bringing back the first sample from the part of the moon that earthlings never see.

headline: The Governor, the Wolf and the Warden: A Fresh Look at a Gianforte Hunt
abstract: Law enforcement officers say they were pressured to lie when Gov. Greg Gianforte of Montana killed a black wolf in 2021. He says the story is an election-year smear.
lead_paragraph: The game warden in Helena, Mont., received a phone call one morning in March 2021 with a request that he knew might not end well for him. His boss and friend at the Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks Department asked him to record officially the killing of a wolf, a fairly routine request save for one detail.

headline: Stuck in a Starter Home
abstract: Squeezed by high interest rates and record prices, homeowners are frozen in place. They can’t sell. So first-time buyers can’t buy.
lead_paragraph: If buying a home is an inexorable part of the American dream, so is the next step: eventually selling that home and using the equity to trade up to something bigger.

headline: Anatomy of a Success Story: How One Artist Broke Through
abstract: Hugo McCloud has gone from designing fountains and furniture to his fifth show with an established New York gallery.
lead_paragraph: Each year in the art world, lesser-known artists percolate into public consciousness — most obviously at auctions like those that recently concluded in New York, which saw prices exceeding estimates for up-and-comers like Jadé Fadojutimi, Lucy Bull and Michaela Yearwood-Dan.

headline: Is Nonviolent Resistance Past Its Prime?
abstract: In “We Refuse,” Kellie Carter Jackson explores the many forms of activism that oppressed people have resorted to and offers a more nuanced picture of their lives.
lead_paragraph: In his 1958 memoir “Stride Toward Freedom,” the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. laid out a series of principles — courage, friendship, spiritual transformation and so on — for combating racism and other forms of oppression. Inspired by Mahatma Gandhi and Jesus Christ, King urged that the acceptance of suffering, even violence, without retaliation put one in accord with the universe and armed just people with the power to defeat hate.

headline: They Spent Their Life Savings on Life Coaching
abstract: Some people who wanted to improve their lives and careers through coaching found themselves trapped in what they described as a pyramid scheme.
lead_paragraph: To an outsider, Billiejo Mullett is someone who has her head firmly screwed on. She’s smart and educated — a registered nurse who works for a medical insurance provider — and balances her career with a busy family life.

headline: N.H.L.’s Move to Salt Lake City Is Latest Sports Downsizing
abstract: Professional leagues are embracing smaller markets in their search for newer stadiums and arenas and the potential for more devoted fan bases.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, smaller is better.

headline: The Age of Brooke Shields
abstract: The model and actress has three new titles: Netflix rom-com star, union boss and C.E.O. of a beauty brand aimed at women over 40.
lead_paragraph: Some stories are so perfect and poignant that even if we suspect they are not true, we simply do not want to know.

headline: They Revolutionized Shopping, With Tea Sandwiches on the Side
abstract: In “When Women Ran Fifth Avenue,” Julie Satow celebrates the savvy leaders who made Bonwit, Bendel’s and Lord & Taylor into retail meccas of their moment.
lead_paragraph: In 1980, Donald J. Trump made the front page of The New York Times after assaulting a pair of scantily clad women at a Fifth Avenue department store.

headline: The Ghost Trees of Chicago
abstract: Residents have been covering their trees in mesh to protect them from the emerging broods, and the effect is pretty eerie.
lead_paragraph: In May, parts of Chicago were covered for the first time in 17 years by a brood of buzzing, mating, crawling red-eyed cicadas. The city’s tiniest trees were ready.

headline: How We Found 46 Ukrainian Children Taken by Russian Officials
abstract: The New York Times traced how a web of politicians aligned with President Vladimir Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times traced how a web of politicians aligned with President Vladimir Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.

headline: Is This Season of ‘Hacks’ Trolling Jerry Seinfeld?
abstract: The comedian’s philosophies about the audience and comedy are contradicted in characterizations and plot lines on the Max series.
lead_paragraph: So many movies and television series have shown us the misery of a stand-up comic bombing and the joy of a comedian killing. But skirting cliché, the entertaining third season of “Hacks,” which just concluded, dramatizes a more novel and pointed onstage moment: the crisis of success.

headline: As Hunter Biden’s Trial Nears, President Biden Pulls Him Close
abstract: President Biden has weathered years of scandals surrounding his son. But people close to both men say the president has refused to treat him as a political liability.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the verdict in Hunter Biden’s gun trial.

headline: Claudia Sheinbaum Makes History as First Woman Elected to Lead Mexico
abstract: A climate scientist and former mayor, Ms. Sheinbaum became the first woman and Jewish person elected as president of the country.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Sheinbaum, a climate scientist and former mayor of Mexico City, won her nation’s elections on Sunday in a landslide victory that brought a double milestone: She became the first woman, and the first Jewish person, to be elected president of Mexico.

headline: After Trump’s Conviction, a National Enquirer Editor Sends His Regrets
abstract: For Barry Levine, a former top journalist at the supermarket tabloid, the former president’s trial was its own kind of tear-jerker.
lead_paragraph: Even before former President Donald J. Trump was convicted on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records to conceal a sex scandal, a verdict was being delivered on The National Enquirer.

headline: Here’s Where Trump’s Other Cases Stand
abstract: After being convicted in a Manhattan courtroom, the former president still faces charges in three criminal prosecutions, all of which are tangled up in procedural delays.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan came to an end this week when a jury found him guilty of 34 counts of falsifying business records in an effort to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to upset his 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: A Felon in the Oval Office Would Test the American System
abstract: Some are wondering how the Constitution’s checks and balances, meant to hold presidents accountable, would work if the next president elected were already a felon.
lead_paragraph: The revolutionary hero Patrick Henry knew this day would come. He might not have anticipated all the particulars, such as the porn actress in the hotel room and the illicit payoff to keep her quiet. But he feared that eventually a criminal might occupy the presidency and use his powers to thwart anyone who sought to hold him accountable. “Away with your president,” he declared, “we shall have a king.”

headline: The Connections Companion No. 358, June 3, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Why the New Human Case of Bird Flu Is So Alarming
abstract: The virus is changing.
lead_paragraph: The third human case of H5N1, reported on Thursday in a farmworker in Michigan who was experiencing respiratory symptoms, tells us that the current bird flu situation is at a dangerous inflection point.

headline: Civil Liberties Make for Strange Bedfellows
abstract: Sonia Sotomayor helped protect the country from Donald Trump, and she did it in an unexpected way.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, Sonia Sotomayor helped protect the country from Donald Trump, and she did it in an unexpected way — by defending the National Rifle Association.

headline: Stuck at the Start
abstract: In the last few years, many Americans have gotten stuck in their starter house.
lead_paragraph: Buying your first home has long been a milestone of adulthood. So has selling your first home and moving into something bigger. But in the last few years, many Americans have gotten stuck in their starter house.

headline: Netanyahu may be forced to choose between a cease-fire and his government’s survival.
abstract: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against Hamas in Gaza, a reticence that his critics see as a political tactic. But he has been put on the spot this weekend by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
lead_paragraph: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against Hamas in Gaza, a reticence that his critics see as a political tactic. But he has been put on the spot this weekend by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.

headline: Give Yourself Permission to Not Have Sex
abstract: Intentional periods of sexual abstinence can help us better understand the nature of our desire. If we do Dry January, why not Dry Spell July?
lead_paragraph: In his first letter to the Corinthians, the apostle Paul issues one of Christianity’s better-known if lesser-observed dictates: It’s best to remain unmarried, full stop. But, he continues, if people “cannot control themselves, they should marry, for it is better to marry than to burn with passion.”

headline: Hunter Biden Should Take a Plea Deal. Quickly.
abstract: The case against him is strong.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted on three felony gun charges in a trial that is set to begin in Wilmington, Del., on Monday. In the meantime, his father is behind in many polls, his financial benefactor is reportedly “tapped out” and his best legal arguments require gutting federal gun control laws. An embarrassing trial that he is likely to lose will only make things worse.

headline: Should Trump Be Sentenced to Prison? Two Opposing Views.
abstract: Two legal experts weigh in.
lead_paragraph: Now that Donald Trump has been convicted on 34 felony counts, his sentencing hearing looms on July 11. Below are two legal experts weighing in on the critical question of whether Mr. Trump ought to receive a prison sentence.

headline: Wildfire Near San Francisco Burns About 14,000 Acres
abstract: The blaze, the Corral Fire, was 50 percent contained by Sunday evening. It was the largest so far in this year’s California wildfire season.
lead_paragraph: A fast-spreading wildfire east of San Francisco has burned about 14,000 acres, prompting an evacuation order and for a time shutting down major highways, according to public safety alerts and Cal Fire, California’s firefighting agency.

headline: South Africa Confronts Israel and Its Own Democracy
abstract: Lydia Polgreen reports from Cape Town about the myth of the country’s exceptionalism and its moral authority in the war on Gaza.
lead_paragraph: In a special intercontinental episode of “Matter of Opinion,” Lydia Polgreen reports from South Africa as the country challenges Israel for its attack on Rafah in southern Gaza.

headline: Grilled Soy-Basted Chicken With Spicy Cashews, a Five-Star Reader Favorite
abstract: “I would love to leave a review, but I’m so busy swooning and drooling, I’m not sure I can concentrate.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Julie Powell famously learned to cook by making her way through all of Julia Child’s “Mastering the Art of French Cooking,” an endeavor she chronicled in a blog that became a book and then a movie.

headline: The Widespread Harm of Nuclear Testing
abstract: Readers, including Christie Brinkley, discuss the dangers. Also: About apostrophes; oversight of legislative initiatives; congestion pricing.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Trump Joins TikTok, the App He Once Tried to Ban
abstract: The former president has recently embraced the platform as he seeks to reach younger voters.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has joined TikTok, the social media app that he tried to ban during his presidency but that he more recently has embraced as he and his campaign try to reach younger voters before November’s general election.

headline: 1 Dead and 24 Wounded in Akron Shooting, Police Say
abstract: The shooting happened at a large birthday party in Akron, Ohio, early on Sunday, officials said. At least two of those wounded were in critical condition.
lead_paragraph: Two dozen people were wounded and one person was killed in a shooting at a large birthday party in Akron, Ohio, early on Sunday morning, officials said.

headline: Hunter Biden to Go on Trial in Gun Case, Days After Trump Was Convicted
abstract: On Monday in Delaware, one of two trials will begin in which President Biden’s son will defend himself during a presidential election year.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of Hunter Biden’s trial in a gun case.

headline: Netanyahu May Face a Choice Between a Truce and His Government’s Survival
abstract: The Israeli prime minister has been put on the spot by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
lead_paragraph: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against Hamas in Gaza, a stance his critics see as a political tactic. But he has been put on the spot by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.

headline: OPEC Plans a Gradual Unwinding of Production Cuts
abstract: The group announced after its meeting on Sunday that it would be extending production cuts into 2025 and laid out plans for phasing out voluntary cuts. Whether the strategy will work remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: When officials from major oil-producing countries met on Sunday, they had a tricky task before them: To reassure shaky markets that they would continue to restrain oil supplies.

headline: After Verdict, Trump Revels in Embrace of His Most Avid Base: Male Fans
abstract: The former president’s appearance at a U.F.C. fight in Newark on Saturday night showcased his hypermasculine appeal, and his defiance.
lead_paragraph: Sixteen thousand people erupted into rapture when Donald J. Trump walked into the Prudential Center in Newark at 10 p.m. Saturday to attend an Ultimate Fighting Championship match. He stayed until the grisly end, at 1:15 a.m.

headline: What’s Next for South Africa After Voters Rebuked Its Reigning Party?
abstract: A look at the leaders who could shape the country’s future after the African National Congress’s poor showing in elections.
lead_paragraph: South Africa is headed for big change.

headline: Wildfire Near San Francisco Grows to Several Thousand Acres
abstract: The blaze, the fast-spreading Corral Fire, is California’s largest so far this wildfire season and has shut down major highways and prompted residents to flee their homes.
lead_paragraph: The blaze, the fast-spreading Corral Fire, is California’s largest so far this wildfire season and has shut down major highways and prompted residents to flee their homes.

headline: David Levy, Ex-Laborer Who Became a Top Israeli Leader, Dies at 86
abstract: A native of Morocco, he often embodied the resentment of North Africans and Middle Eastern Jews toward European Israelis.
lead_paragraph: David Levy, a Moroccan-born Israeli who rose from ditch digger to Israel’s political heights, often embodying the resentments of Jews of North African and Middle Eastern origin who felt ill-treated by Europe-rooted elites, died on Sunday at a hospital in Jerusalem. He was 86.

headline: Teacher Placed on Leave Over ‘Mock Slave Auction’ in Classroom
abstract: The teacher in Massachusetts, who has not been named, was placed on leave after also using a racial slur, the school superintendent said.
lead_paragraph: A fifth-grade teacher in Massachusetts who held a “mock slave auction” and used a racial slur in a classroom has been placed on paid administrative leave, the district superintendent said.

headline: Intense Security at Peaceful Parade for Israel in Manhattan
abstract: The annual parade focused this year on the hostages in Gaza. Thousands marched, and with many streets blocked off, there were few protesters.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of supporters of Israel marched along Fifth Avenue on Sunday during a heavily policed Israel Day parade that took on a more somber tone this year as the war in Gaza enters its eighth month.

headline: Rupert Murdoch Marries for the Fifth Time
abstract: Mr. Murdoch, the 93-year-old media mogul, married Elena Zhukova, a retired molecular biologist, Saturday at Moraga, his Bel Air vineyard estate in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch, who retired from the boards of Fox and News Corporation last year, walked down an outdoor aisle under blue skies to exchange vows on Saturday with Elena Zhukova, his fifth bride, at Moraga, his Tuscan-style vineyard estate in the hills of the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles.

headline: Lara Trump, R.N.C. Leader, Denounces Larry Hogan for Accepting Trump Verdict
abstract: Ms. Trump refused to say whether the Republicans should support Mr. Hogan, a prized recruit who gave the party a chance of picking up a Democratic Senate seat in Maryland.
lead_paragraph: Lara Trump, the co-chair of the Republican National Committee and former President Donald J. Trump’s daughter-in-law, on Sunday denounced Larry Hogan, the Republican Senate candidate in Maryland, for urging Americans to “respect the verdict” against Mr. Trump — criticizing a prized recruit who has given the party a chance of winning a seat that has reliably been held by Democrats.

headline: Mexico Election Results: Sheinbaum Wins
abstract: See results and maps for Mexico’s 2024 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: See results and maps for Mexico’s 2024 presidential election.

headline: Monday Briefing: What’s Next for South Africa
abstract: Also, India’s elections and internet in the Amazon.
lead_paragraph: The African National Congress has lost its political monopoly on South Africa. Election results on Saturday showed that the party had fallen short of winning an absolute majority for the first time since the end of apartheid in 1994.

headline: Hot Off the Presses
abstract: Alana Platt makes her New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Philadelphia’s University of the Arts Announces Sudden Closing
abstract: The institution’s financial woes were widely known, but the announcement surprised students and faculty members.
lead_paragraph: The nearly 150-year-old University of the Arts in Philadelphia will close its doors June 7. Many of its 1,149 students and about 700 faculty and staff members got the news from an article in the Philadelphia Inquirer on Friday or on social media, only later getting official word from the school.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,080, June 3, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: A Sticking Point in Paramount and Skydance Talks: Who Pays For a Lawsuit?
abstract: A special committee of Paramount’s board of directors supports a merger with Skydance, a studio that has increased its offer in recent days. But the deal isn’t done yet.
lead_paragraph: Paramount and Skydance have haggled for months over an ambitious merger that would usher in a new ruler of a sprawling media kingdom that includes CBS, MTV and the film studio behind “Top Gun.”

headline: Sally Buzbee, Washington Post Editor, to Leave Role
abstract: Matt Murray, the former editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, will take her place temporarily.
lead_paragraph: The executive editor of The Washington Post, Sally Buzbee, will leave her role, a major and sudden change at one of the nation’s pre-eminent news organizations.

headline: Prosecutor Drops Murder Charges Against Minnesota Trooper Amid Pushback
abstract: The prosecution of Ryan Londregan, a white Minnesota state trooper who fatally shot a Black motorist last year, sparked rare bipartisan outrage.
lead_paragraph: The top prosecutor in Minneapolis has dropped murder charges against a state trooper who fatally shot a motorist last year after a traffic stop, her office said on Sunday, a stunning turnaround in a case that ignited a political firestorm.

headline: Puerto Rico Governor Loses Primary to Former Ally
abstract: Representative Jenniffer González-Colón, the island’s nonvoting member of Congress, defeated Gov. Pedro R. Pierluisi four years after they appeared on the same ticket.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Pedro R. Pierluisi of Puerto Rico lost his bid for a second term on Sunday, suffering a rare defeat by a sitting governor on the island after a rancorous primary.

headline: Quote of the Day: Tired of Chaos and Leaving House by the Dozens
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 3, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “All they know is how to use social media to burn the place down.”

headline: Fake News Reports and Videos Seek to Undermine the Paris Olympics
abstract: Russian propagandists are spoofing broadcasters and mimicking French and U.S. intelligence agencies to stoke fear about security at the Games.
lead_paragraph: With its athletes barred from competing in the Summer Olympics under the country’s flag, Russia has turned its fury on the Games and this year’s host, Paris.

headline: A Surging Hard Right in Europe Stumbles Over Its Own Divisions
abstract: Elections starting this week for the European Parliament could leave far-right parties with more power than ever, but also expose the fissures among them.
lead_paragraph: Nationalists are surging and expected to make big gains when voters from 27 nations cast ballots starting this week for the European Parliament. But the prospect of success is already raising the question among far-right parties of how far is too far.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: South Africa rejects the party that ended apartheid.
lead_paragraph: The African National Congress lost its political monopoly in South Africa for the first time since vanquishing the country’s last white-led regime 30 years ago.

headline: My Country Shows What Europe Has Become
abstract: For all its singularity, Belgium tells a quintessentially European story.
lead_paragraph: He could have been anywhere. Delivering a speech to a group of Belgian businessmen this year, Barack Obama warned about the dangers of artificial intelligence, climate change and geopolitical conflict. More local matters were close at hand: Belgium was entering an election year, and its capital, Brussels, home to some of Europe’s most hallowed institutions, had weathered a year of geopolitical shocks. Yet Mr. Obama wouldn’t be drawn into questions about national politics. A visit to the Magritte Museum and the king was the extent of his engagement.

headline: First They Came for Sudan’s Future. Now They’re Destroying Its Past.
abstract: There was no place for rogue militias in the Sudan we dreamed of.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of April 14, 2023, I was at a concert in Khartoum. The end of Ramadan was near, and the audience listened to the ouds, tambours and kanoons of Bait Al Oud, an orchestra set up to preserve traditional Sudanese instruments. I sang along to songs made popular by the 2019 revolution and then floated home, my spirits high.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Lots of Bravo and ‘Fantasmas’
abstract: “Summer House” and “The Valley” wrap up as “Below Deck Mediterranean” starts a new season. HBO airs a new show from Julio Torres.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, June 3-9. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: introspection
abstract: This word has appeared in 75 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word introspection has appeared in 75 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 1 in “What’s ‘In’ for 2024? In-and-Out Lists, Apparently” by Jessica Roy:

headline: What to Know About Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s Newly Elected President
abstract: Here are five key insights into Mexico’s new president as people wonder whether she will diverge from Andrés Manuel López Obrador’s policies or focus on cementing his legacy.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has a Ph.D in energy engineering, participated in a United Nations panel of climate scientists awarded a Nobel Peace Prize and governed the capital, one of the largest cities in the hemisphere.

headline: New York Has a Week to Pass Bills on Social Media and Plastics. Will It?
abstract: Lawmakers in Albany are rushing to address various environmental and health-related initiatives, with just a week left in the 2024 legislative session.
lead_paragraph: In New York, the state legislative session runs for roughly 60 days spread out from January to early June, but most of the actual passing of bills occurs over two periods. The first is when the state passes its budget, a document so overstuffed with unrelated bills that it’s known around the State Capitol as the “big ugly.”

headline: Liberals Find a TV Prescription for Election Jitters: Monday Nights
abstract: Once a week, Rachel Maddow and Jon Stewart are luring viewers back to basic cable.
lead_paragraph: Liberal TV viewers have a new mantra: T.G.I.M.!

headline: New Yorkers Who Need Help With Rent Can (Finally) Join a List for Help
abstract: A waiting list for federal housing vouchers that has been closed for nearly 15 years is reopening, providing a lifeline for families struggling to afford the city’s high rent.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in 15 years, thousands of people who cannot afford to live in New York City may be able to get financial help through a highly sought-after federal program.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Where Do Those Painted White ‘Ghost Bikes’ Come From?
abstract: White bikes across the city serve as memorials — and calls for awareness about the dangers cyclists face.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: Arrest Threatens Nepal’s Standing as South Asia’s Model for Free Speech
abstract: A media executive was arrested after his company published critical reports about a powerful government minister.
lead_paragraph: In a region sliding toward authoritarianism one country after another, the small Himalayan nation of Nepal was a shining exception.

headline: The Make-or-Break Question for a New Roommate: Do You Drink?
abstract: A Brooklyn woman who has been sober for three years needed a roommate. But alcohol would not be allowed in the apartment. Some people thought that was a joke.
lead_paragraph: When Shelby Cohen posted advertisements on Facebook for a new roommate in her Brooklyn apartment, she noted the most important details. She listed the bedroom’s dimensions, mentioned that there was just one bathroom, and noted nearby subway stations. But there was an important caveat for any potential roommate — no alcohol was allowed in the apartment.

headline: Ford Rescues a Detroit Train Station as It Plots Its Own Future
abstract: The automaker paid $90 million for the ravaged Michigan Central Station in 2018, and will spend millions more to create a hub of businesses focused on transportation.
lead_paragraph: When he was growing up in Southwest Detroit, Cristian Rubio was never all that curious about the shuttered train station that loomed over his neighborhood. The building, a couple of miles west of downtown, was among the city’s most visible symbols of urban decay and a go-to for photographers who wanted to capture its decline.

headline: In This Experimental Grief Novel, You Choose Your Own Adventure
abstract: Gabriel Smith’s shape-shifting debut, “Brat,” cycles through a multiverse of strange possibilities.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of his father’s death and his mother’s move to a nursing facility, a 20-something British novelist named Gabriel (not to be confused with the 20-something British novelist Gabriel Smith, whose debut, “Brat,” he inhabits) returns home.  Ostensibly, he’s there to prepare his parents’ estate for sale, but he’s also hiding out from a multitude of problems. For starters, despite receiving a sizable advance for his second book, Gabriel hasn’t written a word yet.

headline: Abnormally Dry Canada Taps U.S. Energy, Reversing Usual Flow
abstract: Lower-than-normal rain and snow have reduced Canada’s hydropower production, raising worries in the industry about the effects of climate change.
lead_paragraph: In February, the United States did something that it had not done in many years — the country sent more electricity to Canada than it received from its northern neighbor. Then, in March, U.S. electricity exports to Canada climbed even more, reaching their highest level since at least 2010.

headline: Seniors in Baltimore Are Being Devastated by Drugs: 5 Takeaways
abstract: The city has become the U.S. overdose capital, and older Black men are dying at higher rates than anyone else.
lead_paragraph: Over the past six years, Baltimore has endured one of America’s deadliest drug epidemics. Fatal overdoses have fallen surprisingly hard on one group: Black men currently in their mid-50s to early 70s.

headline: The 25 Photos That Defined the Modern Age
abstract: A group of experts met to discuss the images that have best captured — and changed — the world since 1955.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get this out of the way first: Of the dozens of photographers not represented here that a reasonable person might expect to have been included, the most conspicuous absentees include Berenice Abbott, Ansel Adams, Robert Adams, Richard Avedon, Dawoud Bey, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Imogen Cunningham, Roy DeCarava, William Eggleston, Walker Evans, Robert Mapplethorpe, Helmut Newton and Irving Penn. Putting together a list of the 25 most significant photographs since 1955 — both fine art photos and reportage — proved a difficult task for the panelists (even the chosen time frame was controversial). They were: the Canadian conceptual photographer Stan Douglas, 63; the Vietnamese American photographer An-My Lê, 64; the acting chief curator of Photography at the Museum of Modern Art, Roxana Marcoci, 66; the American documentary photographer Susan Meiselas, 75; the American photographer Shikeith, 35; and Nadia Vellam, 51, T’s photo and video director. Each participant (including myself, the moderator, 36) submitted up to seven possible nominees for the list. We gathered at The New York Times Building on a morning last February (with Shikeith joining on video from a shoot in Los Angeles) to begin our deliberations.

headline: Can a Novel Tell Us How Ted Kaczynski Became the Unabomber?
abstract: Maxim Loskutoff’s “Old King” is set in the remote forests of Montana, where one resident began a campaign to destroy modern life as we know it.
lead_paragraph: Ted Kaczynski may already have been harboring considerable resentments by his second year at Harvard, where the awkward, 17-year-old math prodigy lived in a dorm for similarly gifted students. He was under a lot of pressure from his parents to succeed. He’d skipped grades and missed out on building relationships with peers. He was socially isolated.

headline: 7 Days in the Cultural Life of a MoMA Photography Curator
abstract: Oluremi Onabanjo fills her week with early morning writing sessions, a live show at the Village Vanguard, time with other Black scholars and art all around New York City.
lead_paragraph: As a curator in the photography department of the Museum of Modern Art, and a Ph.D. candidate in art history at Columbia, Oluremi C. Onabanjo squeezes as many exhibitions and talks as she can into an already packed schedule.

headline: 8 Comics to Read This Pride Month
abstract: These comics and graphic novels have superheroes and supervillains, and drama at theater camp. There is also a nonfiction guide to coming out.
