abstract: Nomad Tea Parlour offers dim sum and takes on Chinese American specialties, Veselka opens an outpost in Williamsburg and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: When post roads were horse and buggy interstates, the Bedford Post Inn, dating from 1762, was a rest stop. Its gracious restaurant is now reopening after renovations with the chef Sam Mason turning out tavern fare like oysters, onion tart, skirt steak and grilled chicken, not just his usual pastries. Like the rest of the inn, Sunday Hospitality, which also runs El Quijote and Cafe Chelsea in Manhattan, is managing it in partnership with the actor Richard Gere, an owner. Bedford Post Barn, a casual spot on the property for all-day fare and baked goods from BreadsNbakes nearby, is opening soon. (Opens Wednesday)

headline: Jez Butterworth’s ‘The Hills of California’ to Open on Broadway
abstract: The play, about a group of English sisters who reunite at their mother’s deathbed, plans to open in New York in September. It ends a London run this month.
lead_paragraph: “The Hills of California,” the latest darkly comedic drama from the acclaimed English playwright Jez Butterworth, will transfer to Broadway this fall after a well-received five-month run in London.

headline: Sean Combs Sells Stake in Revolt, the Media Company He Founded
abstract: After a wave of lawsuits accusing Mr. Combs of sexual assault, the two are “completely separated and dissociated from each other,” the company’s chief executive said.
lead_paragraph: Sean Combs, the hip-hop mogul who has been facing mounting legal scrutiny over allegations of sexual and physical abuse, has sold his majority stake in Revolt, the media company that he founded, the organization announced Tuesday.

headline: In Shift, Biden Issues Order Allowing Temporary Border Closure to Migrants
abstract: The move shows how drastically immigration politics have shifted in the United States. The American Civil Liberties Union said it planned to challenge the order in court.
lead_paragraph: President Biden issued an executive order on Tuesday that prevents migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border when crossings surge, a dramatic election-year move to ease pressure on the immigration system and address a major concern among voters.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in June
abstract: The final season of “Sweet Tooth” and a Richard Linklater rom-com highlight this month’s slate.
lead_paragraph: Every month, Netflix adds movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of June’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Psychiatry and the Dangerous Patient
abstract: Two psychiatrists respond to a Science Times article. Also: Dr. Fauci’s grilling in the House; a shortage of immigration lawyers; presidential rankings.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Big Hurdle Between R.F.K. Jr. and the Debate Stage (It’s Not a Poll)
abstract: The independent presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has said he’s confident he will qualify. But CNN’s rules have put an urgently ticking clock on his already-critical ballot access efforts.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s campaign has been clear: He will debate former President Donald J. Trump only one-on-one.

headline: PTSD Treatments Are Falling Short for Many Patients
abstract: Therapy and medication can help people recover from trauma, but many struggle to access the care they need.
lead_paragraph: Post-traumatic stress disorder closes people off. They withdraw — often reluctant to talk about what they’ve experienced and unable to trust others or themselves. But many leading treatments for the condition require just that.

headline: Needing Help to Stay in Power, Modi Loses His Aura of Invincibility
abstract: Though Narendra Modi will take up a third term as India’s leader, the election was closer than expected, forcing him to rely on coalition partners that don’t share his Hindu nationalist agenda.
lead_paragraph: Suddenly, the aura of invincibility around Narendra Modi has been shattered.

headline: Gizmodo Sold to European Media Company
abstract: The tech website’s publisher, G/O Media, sold Gizmodo to the digital media and tech company Keleops.
lead_paragraph: The tech website Gizmodo has been sold to a European media company, the latest brand from the publisher G/O Media to go out the door.

headline: When Hydropower Runs Dry
abstract: The struggle of the world’s largest source of renewable last year could have important implications for the fight against climate change.
lead_paragraph: Global pollution from electricity generation was set to fall last year, thanks to the growth of renewable energy. Then came the droughts.

headline: How We Tracked Every Damaged or Destroyed Building in Ukraine
abstract: This is the first comprehensive map showing the destruction of the war in Ukraine. Using detailed analysis of years of satellite data, it shows every building that has been damaged or destroyed since Russia attacked in 2022.
lead_paragraph: This is the first comprehensive map showing the destruction of the war in Ukraine. Using detailed analysis of years of satellite data, it shows every building that has been damaged or destroyed since Russia attacked in 2022.

headline: How Modi Courted India’s Youth
abstract: India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi tapped influencers and gamers to draw in young voters, many of whom are discontent with the economy and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi tapped influencers and gamers to draw in young voters, many of whom are discontent with the economy and unemployment.

headline: Key Primary Races to Watch: June 4
abstract: See results and maps for key races in the June 4 state and presidential primaries.
lead_paragraph: See results and maps for key races in the June 4 state and presidential primaries.

headline: Transplanted Pig Kidney Is Removed From Patient
abstract: The organ, from a genetically modified animal, failed because of a lack of blood flow, surgeons said, but did not appear to have been rejected by the body.
lead_paragraph: Surgeons removed the kidney of a genetically engineered pig from a critically ill patient last week after the organ was damaged by inadequate blood flow related to a heart pump that the woman had also received, according to officials at NYU Langone Transplant Institute.

headline: Students Want Charges Dropped. What Is the Right Price for Protests?
abstract: At pro-Palestinian demonstrations, students have broken codes of conduct and, sometimes, the law. But the question of whether and how to discipline them is vexing universities.
lead_paragraph: Youssef Hasweh expected to receive his diploma from the University of Chicago on Saturday.

headline: Wisconsin Charges 3 Trump Allies in Fake Electors Scheme
abstract: It is the fifth battleground state to prosecute former President Donald J. Trump’s supporters for trying to overturn his defeat in the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Wisconsin brought felony charges on Tuesday against three onetime advisers of former President Donald J. Trump in connection with a fake electors plot there in 2020, becoming the fifth battleground state to prosecute his allies for their attempts to overturn his defeat that year.

headline: Visiting Europe, Biden Will Find Both Solidarity and Isolation
abstract: The president arrived in France for a visit meant to mark the 80th anniversary of the D-Day invasion and showcase Western unity. But even as he rallies American allies in defense of Ukraine, he will defy them on the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden visits France this week, he will be rallying European leaders to his side and showcasing the resolve he has helped to foster on behalf of Ukraine.

headline: The Ultimate Charli XCX Primer
abstract: Prep for the arrival of her new album, “Brat,” with 11 songs from her catalog (and 10 bonus tracks!).
lead_paragraph: I don’t think there’s a single song I’ve listened to more over the past few weeks than “360,” the endlessly quotable, deliriously catchy synth-pop song by one of my favorite working pop stars, Charli XCX.

headline: A ‘House of the Dragon’ Party Without a Silvery Wig in Sight
abstract: At the Season 2 premiere of HBO’s “Game of Thrones” prequel, the cast mingled over cocktails as early clips from the series suggested that “war is coming.”
lead_paragraph: Where does the story pick up this season on HBO’s fantasy epic “House of the Dragon”?

headline: Ex-Agent Who Criticized F.B.I. to Congress Has Security Clearance Reinstated
abstract: Marcus Allen was also awarded back pay and resigned from the bureau after reaching a settlement agreement, his lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: A former F.B.I. agent who criticized the bureau in congressional testimony has been awarded back pay and had his security clearance reinstated, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

headline: Goodbye Inflation, Hello Recession?
abstract: The landing is almost here, but will it be soft?
lead_paragraph: Long ago I studied international economics with the great Charles Kindleberger, famous not just for his insights but also for his bon mots. One line I took to heart — he was talking about the balance of payments, but it applies equally well to many subjects in economics — was that people always want a single number, but what they really need is a story.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘We Met at a Gay Bar Called Woody’s’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: In a movie, a twangy guitar riff would have played. I was a longtime lone ranger with debilitating social anxiety after moving from New Jersey to Tokyo and back again. She was a sandy-haired palomino mare who had become a therapist for traumatized veterans. The kicker? She, herself, had suffered prolonged abuse, becoming averse to human touch. We stood tall, eyes locked. The more I wrangled for her to like me, the further she cantered away. Then, one night, I rested my forearms on the fence and she approached me for the first time, dipping her nose to my palm. — Saachi Subramaniam

headline: Alec and Hilaria Baldwin and Their 7 Children Get a Reality TV Series
abstract: “We’re inviting you into our home,” the actor, who is set to stand trial next month on an involuntary manslaughter charge, said as he announced a show about his family on TLC.
lead_paragraph: Speaking with Alec Baldwin on her podcast last year, the talk show host Kelly Ripa made a pitch for him and his wife: “When I think about you and Hilaria and your seven young kids — now, I know what you’re going to say, but just go with me — this has reality TV written all over it,” she said.

headline: Ukraine Strikes Into Russia With Western Weapons, Official Says
abstract: The official said Ukraine had destroyed missile launchers in the Russian region of Belgorod using an American-made rocket system.
lead_paragraph: Just days after the Biden administration granted permission for Ukraine to fire American weapons into Russia, Kyiv took advantage of its new latitude, striking a military facility over the border using a U.S.-made artillery system, according to a member of Ukraine’s Parliament.

headline: Biden Issues Order to Curb Immigration at Southern Border
abstract: President Biden’s executive order prevents migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border when crossings surge.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s executive order prevents migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border when crossings surge.

headline: We’re Entering a Joyful New Era of Lesbian Fashion
abstract: Pairing silky garments with butch suiting, women are pushing back against stereotypical ideas about dressing, on the red carpet and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, the actress Kristen Stewart appeared on the cover of Rolling Stone in a pocket-covered black leather vest that looked like it had been swiped from a 1980s lesbian bar. Bare-chested, her hair cut into a squirrelly mullet, she wore only one other garment: a white jock strap into which her hand plunged suggestively past the wrist. The 34-year-old former ingénue — who entered the public eye in 2008 as the teenage star of the “Twilight” movie franchise, before coming out in 2017 — seemed to be reclaiming pleasure exclusively for herself. For other appearances to promote “Love Lies Bleeding,” her A24-produced queer thriller, which was released in March, she channeled a similar spirit, showing up in a sea green Dickies bomber jacket over a stomach-baring crop top at the Sundance Film Festival and a structured black leather blazer with a fishnet bra on “Late Night With Seth Meyers.”

headline: Biden’s Crackdown on Migrants Reflects a New Reality for Democrats
abstract: Advocates of the right to asylum can’t defend the system when it’s broken.
lead_paragraph: There’s no denying that the executive order President Biden signed on Tuesday — significantly curtailing the number of asylum seekers allowed into the country — is a head-spinning reversal for a president who promised to undo Donald Trump’s policies at the border. It’s worth remembering that Biden wasn’t alone on that front. Eight out of 10 Democrats running in the presidential primaries said in 2019 that they would make walking across the border without permission a civil infraction, like a traffic ticket, instead of a criminal offense.

headline: Modi Struggles to Stay on Top: 4 Takeaways From India’s Election
abstract: The prime minister will keep his job, but his aura has been diminished and his leadership has fundamentally changed as the country’s multiparty democracy springs back to life.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi’s first decade as India’s prime minister came with its fair share of surprises. None, however, looked anything like what happened on Tuesday morning when he won his second re-election, but lost his party’s majority in Parliament.

headline: To Restrict Migrants, Biden Leans on Trump’s Favorite Immigration Law
abstract: President Biden’s executive action addresses one of his most serious political vulnerabilities ahead of the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Looking for a way to shut down the southern border in 2018, President Donald J. Trump found a 73-word provision in the asylum law that he said gave him “magical authorities” to keep migrants out of the country.

headline: ‘Bad Boys: Ride or Die’ Review: Older, but Never Wiser
abstract: In their latest buddy cop movie, Will Smith and Martin Lawrence are still speeding through Miami. The franchise has rarely felt so assured, relaxed and knowingly funny.
lead_paragraph: Two years after Will Smith slapped the comedian Chris Rock on the Academy Awards stage, it feels bizarre that he needs a franchise called “Bad Boys” to rekindle his star power. Smith and his co-star, Martin Lawrence, are two producers of “Bad Boys: Ride or Die,” the stylishly chaotic lark by the directors Adil El Arbi and Bilall Fallah, suggesting outsize roles as star-auteurs and the importance for this installment to be a hit. In their hands, “Bad Boys: Ride or Die” throws everything at the wall, and much of it sticks.

headline: A Year After Orange Skies Covered N.Y.C., Residents Get Another Air Quality Alert
abstract: This time ozone, not smoke, was to blame.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year after orange smoke from Canadian wildfires enveloped New York City, residents received text messages Tuesday morning about a different kind of air quality alert.

headline: University of the Arts President Resigns After School Announces Closure
abstract: Kerry Walk announced last week that the institution would close on June 7, leaving hundreds of students in academic limbo.
lead_paragraph: The University of the Arts president, Kerry Walk, has resigned only a few days after her administration said that the nearly 150-year-old institution in Philadelphia would close because of declining revenue and enrollment, union officials representing school employees told The New York Times on Tuesday.

headline: House Votes to Impose Sanctions on I.C.C. Officials Over Israel Prosecution
abstract: The Republican-written bill, which the White House strongly opposes, stands little chance of becoming law after lawmakers failed to reach a bipartisan deal on penalizing measures.
lead_paragraph: The House voted mostly along party lines on Tuesday to impose sweeping sanctions on officials at the International Criminal Court in a rebuke of efforts by the court’s top prosecutor to charge top Israeli leaders with war crimes in connection with the offensive against Hamas.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Modi’s Bruising Path to a Third Term
abstract: Also, a Times analysis of the destruction in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India claimed a third term in office yesterday. But early results suggest his party won by a far narrower margin than expected. The aura of invincibility around Modi has been shattered.

headline: Bringing a New York Street Scene to Life in ‘Robot Dreams’
abstract: The director Pablo Berger dissects a frame from his Oscar-nominated animated film about the friendship between a dog and a robot.
lead_paragraph: The director Pablo Berger dissects a frame from his Oscar-nominated animated film about the friendship between a dog and a robot.

headline: Wendell Pierce Claims Discrimination in Trying to Rent a Harlem Apartment
abstract: The renowned character actor, best known for playing Detective Bunk Moreland on HBO’s “The Wire,” says a white landlord rejected his rental application.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed actor Wendell Pierce says his rental application for an apartment in Harlem was denied by a white landlord, and he believes racism is the reason.

headline: Fingers Point as Biden Closes Border to Asylum Seekers
abstract: The president blamed Donald Trump and Republicans for the failure of a previous immigration plan. Mr. Trump called the new action too little, too late.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of his remarks from the White House on Tuesday announcing that he would prohibit migrants from seeking asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border, President Biden tried to make clear just whose fault it was that he was taking action by executive order.

headline: Nonny Hogrogian, 92, Honored Illustrator of Children’s Books, Dies
abstract: A two-time Caldecott Medal winner, she brought multiculturalism to children’s literature by evoking her Armenian heritage.
lead_paragraph: Nonny Hogrogian, an illustrator who mined her Armenian heritage to bring diversity and wonder to her woodcuts and watercolors — an approach that helped expand the world of children’s literature and made her a two-time Caldecott Medal winner — died on May 9 in Holyoke, Mass. She was 92.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Sam Rosenfeld and Daniel Schlozman
abstract: The June 4, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sam Rosenfeld and Daniel Schlozman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Muhammad Ali’s Childhood Home Goes on the Market
abstract: The boxing champion lived in the one-story house in Louisville, Ky., which in recent years became a museum. It’s listed for sale, along with two neighboring properties, for $1.5 million.
lead_paragraph: The childhood home where Muhammad Ali, the three-time world heavyweight boxing champion and activist, learned to box and that was along the route of his funeral procession in Louisville, Ky., is for sale.

headline: Both Democrats and Republicans Embrace Border Politics
abstract: Also, India’s election was closer than expected. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in Arizona voted this afternoon to put a measure on the state’s ballots in November that would make illegal immigration a state crime. If passed, the measure would give local authorities the power to arrest, jail and deport unauthorized migrants.

headline: Garland Says He ‘Will Not Be Intimidated’ by House Republicans
abstract: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, testifying before the House Judiciary Committee, defended the Justice Department against false accusations made by former President Donald J. Trump and his congressional allies.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, testifying before the House Judiciary Committee, defended the Justice Department against false accusations made by former President Donald J. Trump and his congressional allies.

headline: After Trump’s Conviction, House Republicans Vow Again to Target His Foes
abstract: Speaker Mike Johnson announced a “three-pronged approach” for how Republicans on Capitol Hill would push back against the prosecutions of the former president.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans have spent the past 18 months vowing to use their majority to attack what they claimed was a “weaponization” of government against conservatives, including the prosecutions of former President Donald J. Trump, but have made little headway in doing so.

headline: F.D.A. Panel Rejects MDMA-Aided Therapy for PTSD
abstract: An independent group of experts expressed concerns that the data from clinical trials did not outweigh risks for treatment of post-traumatic stress disorder.
lead_paragraph: An independent advisory panel of the Food and Drug Administration rejected the use of MDMA-assisted therapy for post-traumatic stress disorder on Tuesday, highlighting the unparalleled regulatory challenges of a novel therapy using the drug commonly known as Ecstasy.

headline: Gazans Pin Hopes on New Truce Proposal, but Remain Skeptical
abstract: A cease-fire plan described by President Biden has stirred cautious optimism after nearly eight months of war in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: After eight months of devastating bombardment by Israeli forces, some Gazans are urging Hamas to accept a cease-fire plan outlined by President Biden, but many remain deeply skeptical that the United States, as Israel’s chief ally, would truly bring an end to the war.

headline: Rob Burrow, Rugby Star and A.L.S. Campaigner, Dies at 41
abstract: The “Mighty Atom” enjoyed a glittering professional career in Britain before gaining more acclaim for his charity efforts after a diagnosis of motor neuron disease.
lead_paragraph: Rob Burrow, a rugby standout who overcame his diminutive stature with fleetness and ferocity to become an eight-time champion of Britain’s Super League and who was later hailed for raising awareness of motor neuron disease after being diagnosed with it in 2019, died on Sunday. He was 41.

headline: What to Know About Claudia Sheinbaum, Mexico’s President-Elect
abstract: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has earned a Ph.D. in energy engineering, participated in a United Nations panel of climate scientists awarded a Nobel Peace Prize and governed Mexico’s capital, one of the largest cities in the hemisphere. On Sunday, she added another achievement to her résumé by becoming the first woman elected president of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Claudia Sheinbaum’s list of accolades is long: She has earned a Ph.D. in energy engineering, participated in a United Nations panel of climate scientists awarded a Nobel Peace Prize and governed Mexico’s capital, one of the largest cities in the hemisphere. On Sunday, she added another achievement to her résumé by becoming the first woman elected president of Mexico.

headline: Halsey Reveals Illness in New Song, Saying They Are ‘Lucky to Be Alive’
abstract: The pop star shared that they had been diagnosed with lupus and a rare T-cell lymphoproliferative disorder.
lead_paragraph: An album, a new song and a medical diagnosis — the singer Halsey took to social media to announce them all.

headline: How Biden’s Asylum Order Works
abstract: The president issued an executive order that essentially blocks asylum claims at the southern border, a major shift in how the United States has handled claims for protection.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced an executive order on Tuesday to essentially block asylum at the southern border, a major shift in how the United States has historically handled claims for protection.

headline: This D-Day, Europe Needs to Resolve to Get Its Act Together
abstract: People, and nations, succeed or fail to the extent that they refuse to hand over responsibility for their fates to others.
lead_paragraph: Thursday’s D-Day anniversary — the 80th — is occasioning somber and anxious reflections about the fate of the Atlantic alliance. Somber because the last of the Greatest Generation will soon no longer be with us. Anxious because Donald Trump, and his evident disdain for that alliance, may soon be with us again.

headline: Ron Edmonds, 77, Whose Camera Captured the Shooting of Reagan, Dies
abstract: Working for The Associated Press, he won a Pulitzer Prize for his sequence of photos showing the president being struck by a bullet while three others fell wounded.
lead_paragraph: Ron Edmonds, a photographer for The Associated Press who won a Pulitzer Prize for a dramatic series of pictures of the attempted assassination of President Ronald Reagan and the takedown of the gunman outside a Washington hotel in 1981, died on Friday in Falls Church, Va. He was 77.

headline: Senator Menendez Enjoyed a Steakhouse Dinner, as the F.B.I. Watched
abstract: At Senator Robert Menendez’s bribery trial, an investigator described surveilling diners at a Washington restaurant. Among them were Mr. Menendez and an Egyptian official.
lead_paragraph: The man and the woman arrived at the Washington steakhouse one evening in May 2019 and took a table on the patio, near where five diners already were seated and seemed to be enjoying themselves. Jackets were off, laughter was heard and wine was being poured. A cigarette dangled from one man’s hand.

headline: Rival U.K. Political Leaders Clash in Bad-Tempered Election Debate
abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, fighting to narrow a substantial polling gap, adopted an aggressive approach against his Labour Party opponent, Keir Starmer.
lead_paragraph: The two contenders to become Britain’s next prime minister clashed angrily over tax, immigration and health policy on Tuesday in a televised debate that at times descended into ill-tempered exchanges as the political rivals talked over each other.

headline: D.A. Seeks to Overturn Texas Governor’s Pardon of Man Who Killed Protester
abstract: The prosecutor accused the governor of violating the constitutional separation of powers doctrine by intervening with the actions of a court.
lead_paragraph: A Texas prosecutor said on Tuesday that he would seek to have a court overturn Gov. Greg Abbott’s pardon of a man convicted of fatally shooting a Black Lives Matter protester in Austin in the summer of 2020.

headline: Parnelli Jones, Champion Auto Racer and Record Setter, Is Dead at 90
abstract: He was one of the greatest drivers of the 1960s and ’70s, winning six Indy races and four major NASCAR events while setting speed marks.
lead_paragraph: Parnelli Jones, who as a teenager traded in a horse for a hot rod and went on to become one of the biggest stars in auto racing and a storied figure at the Indianapolis 500, died on Tuesday in Torrance, Calif., where he had lived for many years. He was 90.

headline: Trump Asks Judge to Lift N.Y. Gag Order Following Conviction
abstract: Citing statements by Stormy Daniels and Michael Cohen, and an upcoming presidential debate, Donald J. Trump’s lawyers asked a judge to lift the order.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s lawyers on Tuesday asked the judge who oversaw the former president’s criminal trial to lift a gag order on their client as the presidential campaign intensifies.

headline: Andy Kim Wins Democratic Senate Primary in New Jersey
abstract: Mr. Kim jumped into the race shortly after the incumbent, Senator Robert Menendez, was indicted on federal corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: Representative Andy Kim won a decisive victory in the Democratic Senate primary in New Jersey on Tuesday, beating two other candidates and setting up what could be a lively general election campaign in the fall.

headline: Andy Kim Wins Democratic Senate Primary; Rob Menendez Survives Challenge
abstract: The victory makes Mr. Kim a favorite to replace Mr. Menendez’s father, Senator Robert Menendez, who is on trial, charged with corruption — a detail that became central to his son’s re-election race.
lead_paragraph: Representative Andy Kim, a lawmaker who has turned New Jersey politics on its head since entering the race to unseat Senator Robert Menendez, won the Democratic nomination for Senate on Tuesday after a campaign marked by a watershed ballot-access ruling.

headline: The President’s Son: A Routine Gun Case, but Abnormal in Every Way
abstract: At Hunter Biden’s trial, he listened with the jury to his own voice on the audio version of his memoir. “We’ve all been inside rooms we can’t afford to die in,’’ he heard himself say.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates of Hunter Biden’s trial in a gun case.

headline: Review: In ‘Breaking the Story,’ All’s Unfair in Love and War
abstract: Maggie Siff plays a war journalist facing the most dangerous assignment of her life: domesticity.
lead_paragraph: “If in the first act you have hung a pistol on the wall, then in the following one it should be fired.” So Chekhov instructed playwrights, and so they are taught in drama schools everywhere.

abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 New Jersey primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 New Jersey primary elections.

headline: Rob Menendez, a Senator’s Son, Staves Off a Primary Challenge
abstract: Rob Menendez, a freshman member of Congress, beat Ravi Bhalla, the mayor of Hoboken, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Representative Rob Menendez of New Jersey on Tuesday staved off a tough Democratic primary challenge from Ravi Bhalla, the mayor of Hoboken, N.J.

headline: Herb Conaway Wins House Primary in Andy Kim’s District
abstract: Mr. Kim, who represents District 3 in New Jersey, is running for the Senate seat held by Robert Menendez.
lead_paragraph: Herb Conaway, a member of the New Jersey General Assembly, won a five-way Democratic primary for a seat in the U.S. House representing communities in the central and southern part of the state.

headline: Call on the High Seas
abstract: David Rockow gets organized.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Columbia Law Review Website Is Taken Offline Over Article Criticizing Israel
abstract: The board of directors of the student-run publication said that the article, by a Palestinian human rights lawyer, had not been subject to sufficient review.
lead_paragraph: The website of the Columbia Law Review, one of the United States’ most prestigious student-edited law journals, was taken offline Monday by its board of directors after its editors published an article that argues Palestinians are living under a “brutally sophisticated structure of oppression” by Israel that amounts to a crime against humanity.

headline: Questions Dog a Case Involving a Suspended License and a Viral Video
abstract: Video of a man appearing behind the wheel via Zoom for a court hearing over a suspended license drew widespread attention. But there’s more to the story.
lead_paragraph: The irony was too much for the video not to go viral: A Michigan man charged with driving without a license shows up for a court hearing via video … while driving a vehicle.

headline: Tim Sheehy Wins G.O.P. Nod to Challenge Tester for Senate in Montana
abstract: Mr. Sheehy will face a formidable opponent in Senator Jon Tester, the Democratic incumbent who has survived past challenges in his red state by leaning on his farming roots and bipartisan brand.
lead_paragraph: Tim Sheehy, a businessman and former Navy SEAL, won the Republican primary for U.S. Senate in Montana on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, setting him up for a November showdown against Senator Jon Tester, the Democratic incumbent.

headline: Corrections: June 5, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Tuesday about Mexican President-elect Claudia Sheinbaum’s background in energy engineering misidentified the field in which Ms. Sheinbaum earned a doctorate. She holds a Ph.D. in energy engineering, not environmental engineering.

headline: Hochul Pushes for Congestion Pricing Delay in Last-Minute Reversal
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul wants to postpone a plan to charge motorists to enter Manhattan’s business district, citing fears that it will hurt the city’s economy.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul is quietly maneuvering to delay a plan to toll drivers entering Manhattan’s central business district, just weeks before it is slated to go into effect, according to two people familiar with the discussions.

headline: Quote of the Day: Marking 80 Years After D-Day With a ‘Last Hurrah’
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 5, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I made it.”

headline: E.C.B. Is Likely to Leapfrog the Fed on Interest Rate Cuts
abstract: With eurozone inflation falling, the European Central Bank has signaled it is ready to lower rates this week, diverging from the U.S. Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: European Central Bank officials are expected to cut interest rates this week for the first time in more than five years, drawing a line under the worst of the eurozone’s inflation crisis and easing the pressure on the region’s weak economy.

headline: Europe Has Fallen Behind the U.S. and China. Can It Catch Up?
abstract: A “competitiveness crisis” is raising alarms for officials and business leaders in the European Union, where investment, income and productivity are lagging.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s share of the global economy is shrinking, and fears are deepening that the continent can no longer keep up with the United States and China.

headline: Amanda Knox Convicted in Slander Retrial Over 2007 Killing
abstract: The American, who spent several years in jail but was exonerated in 2015 of the killing of her housemate in Italy, was defending herself against a charge related to the case.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Knox, an American who was convicted and then exonerated of murdering her housemate while they were studying in Italy, on Wednesday lost another trial in an Italian court against slander charges related to the 2007 killing.

headline: A Deadly Ambush, a Giant Manhunt and 3 Weeks With No Arrest
abstract: The aftermath of a brazen attack on a prison convoy has raised uncomfortable questions for France’s justice system.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of investigators scoured the crime scene in northern France. More than 450 police officers combed the countryside and the surrounding area. Interpol issued an alert.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Narendra Modi’s election setback in India.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India claimed a third term in office yesterday. But his party won by a far narrower margin than expected, and the aura of invincibility around Modi has been shattered.

headline: Word of the Day: sheepishly
abstract: This word has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word sheepishly has appeared in 37 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 8 in the guest essay “Anxious Parents Are the Ones Who Need Help” by Mathilde Ross:

headline: Indian Voters Have Finally Woken Up
abstract: Narendra Modi is a diminished figure after a disappointing election showing that could imperil his visions for an intolerant Hindu state.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, the announcement of India’s election results loomed as a moment of dread for millions of people who cherish the country’s commitment to secular democracy.

headline: Late Night Reacts to President Biden’s Border Closure Order
abstract: “The Daily Show” host Ronny Chieng joked that the president “has decided to start trying to win the election” with a temporary order affecting asylum seekers.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How Top N.Y. Officials Helped a Lobbyist Cash In on State Government
abstract: The acting budget director, Sandra Beattie, helped a friend and former lawmaker land lobbying and consulting deals, investigators said.
lead_paragraph: In the midst of the pandemic in early 2021, New York state officials were hashing out how to build a mobile app to display users’ vaccination status when an unfamiliar face suddenly started joining the conference calls.

headline: Gunman Opens Fire on U.S. Embassy in Lebanon
abstract: An attacker was wounded and arrested, the Lebanese Army said. An embassy security guard was injured.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire on the U.S. Embassy in Lebanon early Wednesday and was shot and captured by Lebanese security forces, adding to mounting tensions in a crisis-hit nation already on edge over months of cross-border strikes between Israel and the armed militant group Hezbollah.

headline: How a Comedian Burst Into the Celebrity Bubble
abstract: Druski began hobnobbing with star rappers and athletes after his Everyman sketches grew popular on social media.
lead_paragraph: Before Drew Desbordes appeared in a music video with Drake or lived with the N.F.L. star Odell Beckham Jr., his teary-eyed mother scolded him near the living room couch he had flipped upside down as a stage prop.

headline: A Girls’ Trip to Costa Rica. But With No Phones, Did It Happen?
abstract: Travelers are signing up for phone-free tours, to try to escape technology’s tether on daily life. But would it make for a better experience?
lead_paragraph: We were on a quintessential girl’s trip to Costa Rica. Together, we gulped icy drinks by the hotel pool, were battered by waves during a surf lesson, had our tarot cards read aboard a catamaran, and danced our hearts out, powered by espresso martinis, to early 2000s anthems on a rooftop.

headline: Read Your Way Through New Orleans
abstract: New Orleans is a thriving hub for festivals, music and Creole cuisine. Here, the novelist Maurice Carlos Ruffin shares books that capture its many cultural influences.
lead_paragraph: New Orleans is a tourist destination frequented as much for its local dishes (gumbo, jambalaya, among others) as for the spectacle that is Mardi Gras — where you may run into drunk college students on spring break, but could also bump into the Grammy Award-winning artist Jon Batiste. By some counts, it’s one of the most festive cities in America, with a party or two happening almost every week.

headline: The Jesus Lizard, Underground Rock Heroes, Surface With a New Album
abstract: The band known for its raucous early ’90s records made with Steve Albini is returning with fresh music in September: “Rack,” a new LP that amps up its legacy.
lead_paragraph: In May, following the death of Steve Albini, the engineer and tastemaker who helped define the aesthetics of independent rock in the early 1990s, a consensus about his past work started to emerge: Among the slew of albums that Albini recorded in those days, few encapsulated his signature sonic wallop — and the potency of the broader scene he championed — better than the early work of the Jesus Lizard.

headline: How to Strengthen Your Bones With Exercise
abstract: Women are at higher risk of bone loss than men. But a few simple workouts can help to keep your skeleton strong and resilient.
lead_paragraph: When Barbara Hannah Grufferman was in her early 50s, a bone density scan showed that she was on a path to developing osteoporosis. If she didn’t change her lifestyle, her bones would become increasingly brittle, putting her at high risk for spine, hip and other life-altering fractures.

headline: How Healthy Are Avocados?
abstract: Here’s a highlight reel of their biggest nutritional benefits, plus delicious recipes to help you enjoy them.
lead_paragraph: Ripe, creamy avocados are great on toast, salads and burgers, or just sprinkled with salt. Plus, they’re healthy — but how healthy?

headline: Surprising, Unsettling, Surreal: Roaming Through Saudi Arabia
abstract: To witness the kingdom’s profound transformation and assess its ambitious tourism projects, a Times journalist spent a month on the road there. Here’s what he saw.
lead_paragraph: Wandering alone along the southern fringes of Saudi Arabia’s mountainous Asir Province, some eight miles from the Yemeni border, in a nondescript town with a prominent sculpture of a rifle balanced on an ornately painted plinth, I met a man, Nawab Khan, who was building a palace out of mud.

headline: Salvadoran Sweet Bread to Brighten Up Your Morning
abstract: Earthy queso duro blando is at the heart of a Salvadoran quesadilla, which allows for interpretation.
lead_paragraph: One suitcase was never enough. Each time Karla Tatiana Vasquez’s grandmother prepared to make the trip from Los Angeles to El Salvador, the country of her birth, word got out, and people came knocking — tías and tíos, friends, neighbors, “everyone,” Vasquez says — bearing gifts for the folks back home. There was suspense when her grandmother trundled into the airport, two or three bags in tow. “You can’t take this one,” she might be told. “It weighs too much.”

headline: A War on the Nile Pushes Sudan Toward the Abyss
abstract: A year of fighting has turned the once proud capital, Khartoum, into a charred battleground. Millions have fled. Now a famine threatens in one of Africa’s biggest countries.
lead_paragraph: The gold market is a graveyard of rubble and dog-eaten corpses. The state TV station became a torture chamber. The national film archive was blown open in battle, its treasures now yellowing in the sun.

headline: Boys Get Everything, Except the Thing That’s Most Worth Having
abstract: Modern boyhood is an apprenticeship in loneliness.
lead_paragraph: The 20-year-old college student and gamer I met in Cedar City, Utah, didn’t seem particularly amused by his own joke that he was a cultural cliché. He lived in his grandma’s basement, and barely left the house except to go to classes. He spent the vast majority of his free time online — playing video games, watching porn and hanging out on Discord, the heavily male-skewed communication platform, where users gather in communities devoted to topics ranging from the innocuously nerdy to the utterly horrifying. By his own admission, he was brutally lonely.

headline: Their Florida ‘Paradise’ Keeps Flooding, but Some Can’t Afford a Solution
abstract: In the Shore Acres neighborhood of St. Petersburg, rising water has become a constant threat. Many residents cannot afford to elevate their homes or move.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Idalia came ashore last August some 200 miles north of Jennifer Connell-Wandstrat’s neighborhood in St. Petersburg, Fla., but her ranch-style home flooded with nine inches of water that ruined her appliances, doors, dry wall, floors and furniture. She still sleeps on a mattress on the living room floor with her youngest daughter.

headline: As Ukraine Rebuilds Its Identity, Folk Songs Are the New Cool
abstract: Faced with Russia’s efforts to erase Ukrainian culture, people have embraced traditional music as a way to reconnect with their past and affirm their identity.
lead_paragraph: At first sight, it looked like a typical party in a nightclub. It was mid-March in central Kyiv and a hundred or so people were wiggling on the dance floor of V’YAVA, one of the Ukrainian capital’s most popular live music venues. The hall was dark, lit only by bright blue and red spotlights. Bartenders were busy pouring gin and tonics.

headline: The D-Day Battle France Chose to Forget. Until Now.
abstract: Far from Normandy’s beaches, French paratroopers and resistance members fought a rear-guard action to keep the Nazis at bay. But its tragic end had made it a battle to forget.
lead_paragraph: Some 170 miles southwest of the celebrated landing beaches in Normandy, the remains of a D-Day site few visit peek out from behind trees in rural Brittany.

headline: Trump Super PAC Says It Took In Nearly $70 Million in May
abstract: In a memo for donors obtained by The New York Times, the group also said it viewed Pennsylvania as critical to the Trump campaign’s success in November.
lead_paragraph: The original super PAC supporting Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign plans to report that it raised nearly $70 million in May, and that it will spend a further $100 million through Labor Day, according to a memo written for the group’s donors.

headline: Will A.I. Be a Creator or a Destroyer of Worlds?
abstract: The implications for politics reach well beyond deep fakes.
lead_paragraph: The advent of A.I. — artificial intelligence — is spurring curiosity and fear. Will A.I. be a creator or a destroyer of worlds?

headline: The Truth of Trump Is Very Far From the Myth
abstract: It’s crazy to think Donald Trump wants to be a felon.
lead_paragraph: The myth of Donald Trump is that he is immune to scandal — that there’s nothing he could say or do that would undermine his political prospects. In this rendering of the Trump dynamic, his shamelessness helps him glide past controversy, and the unshakable devotion of his base keeps him afloat through the worst of storms.

headline: Israel Secretly Targets U.S. Lawmakers With Influence Campaign on Gaza War
abstract: Israel’s Ministry of Diaspora Affairs ordered the operation, which used fake social media accounts urging U.S. lawmakers to fund Israel’s military, according to officials and documents about the effort.
lead_paragraph: Israel organized and paid for an influence campaign last year targeting U.S. lawmakers and the American public with pro-Israel messaging, as it aimed to foster support for its actions in the war in Gaza, according to officials involved in the effort and documents related to the operation.

headline: She Was Told She Had an Untreatable Disease. But Did She?
abstract: The woman’s disorder was diagnosed when she was a child. Thirty years later, she decided to have more testing done.
lead_paragraph: The 40-year-old woman glared at the windows in her Lower Manhattan apartment. They were filthy. She wanted to wash them. God knows they needed it. But she couldn’t. She considered what it would take to do the job. First, she would have to be on her feet for maybe 20 minutes. Impossible. After standing for more than a few minutes, her legs would tremble with fatigue. She might have the strength in her arms to clean the lower half of a window — maybe one or two of them — but the top? Forget it. On her best day, she could lift her arms up over her head, but she couldn’t keep them up. Her muscles tired too quickly. No, if she wanted clean windows, she would have to hire someone. The thought was depressing. But it was that frustration that eventually led her back to the office of Dr. Mary Lynn Chu.

headline: How America Turned Stories Into Weapons of War
abstract: In a new book, the journalist and science fiction writer Annalee Newitz shows how we have used narrative to manipulate and coerce.
lead_paragraph: A story can entertain and inform; it can also deceive and manipulate. Perhaps few stories are as seductive as the ones we tell ourselves about ourselves — those reasonable, principled creatures so many of us presume ourselves to be.

headline: To Win on Immigration, Biden Must Move the Debate Beyond the Border
abstract: Biden can and should lead his party back to a time when fighting for the undocumented was a major policy priority.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, President Biden issued a proclamation that gives the Department of Homeland Security the authority to temporarily block migrants from seeking asylum between ports of entry at the United States-Mexico border. This means that the only people who are able to apply for asylum at the border are those who can secure an appointment through the government’s CBP One app, in flagrant violation of immigration law.

headline: Your Chance to Snoop: It’s ‘Open Days’ Season in the Garden
abstract: This year, more than 360 private gardens across the country are opening to visitors. Don’t miss your chance to learn from some of the best.
lead_paragraph: I was at my station, a folding table dressed up with a burlap cloth, checking in visitors at a Garden Conservancy Open Days event maybe 10 years ago and answering questions from those who had already explored my garden, when I saw someone across the yard taking a photograph.

headline: $700,000 Homes in Connecticut, New Jersey and Georgia
abstract: A three-bedroom condominium in a converted Gothic Revival church in New Haven, an 1873 rowhouse in Lambertville and a 1938 bungalow in Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: This Gothic Revival church was converted into 11 apartments in 2006. It overlooks Wooster Square Park, a green space with mature cherry trees and a seasonal farmers’ market, and is about a five-minute walk from a stretch of Wooster Street with several of the city’s most popular pizzerias. Yale University Art Gallery, the school’s library and Yale New Haven Hospital are all less than 10 minutes away by car.

headline: For Lauren Hutton, Modeling Was Never the Dream
abstract: At 80, the model and actress waves the flag for “full-grown women.”
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Lauren Hutton explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Paintings: Not Quite the Refuge He Sought
abstract: The president’s son started selling his artwork several years ago, drawing potential ethics concerns that were discussed in congressional testimony this year.
lead_paragraph: As Hunter Biden’s life and business dealings have come under increasing scrutiny in recent years, leading to this week’s trial on gun charges, the president’s son has said he hoped to keep one part of his life unscathed: his art.

headline: Donald Trump, Blocking Out the Sun
abstract: Trump sort of photosynthesizes any and all attention to grow bigger and stronger. What’s Biden to do?
lead_paragraph: Frank Bruni, a contributing Opinion writer, hosted a written online conversation with Josh Barro, who writes the newsletter Very Serious, and Olivia Nuzzi, the Washington correspondent for New York magazine, to banter and bicker about the potential political fallout of Donald Trump’s conviction. Below is a lightly edited transcript of their conversation.

headline: Students Walk Out Over Gun Violence That Is Close to Home
abstract: In Crown Heights, Brooklyn, middle-school students are protesting gun violence in partnership with a community group.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at a protest by middle-school students in Brooklyn. We’ll also find out about a settlement in a defamation lawsuit about a TV series on the Central Park Five case.

headline: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love South African Jazz
abstract: The country has a rich, original relationship to jazz, with American techniques layered into regional traditions and rhythms. Explore 50 years of recordings picked by musicians, poets and writers.
lead_paragraph: We’ve spent five minutes each with stars like Shirley Horn, Sarah Vaughan, Max Roach and John Coltrane. We’ve traveled together to New Orleans, and to the outskirts of the avant-garde. But we haven’t jumped past the boundaries of the United States. Let’s change that.

headline: The G.O.P. Push for Post-Verdict Payback: ‘Fight Fire With Fire’
abstract: Republican leaders in and out of government are publicly pushing to prosecute Democrats as legal retribution for Donald Trump’s felony conviction.
lead_paragraph: Republican allies of Donald J. Trump are calling for revenge prosecutions and other retaliatory measures against Democrats in response to his felony conviction in New York.

headline: Luther Vandross, Pop Perfectionist, Didn’t Want You to Hear These Albums
abstract: Early records reveal that his sumptuous voice and longing lyrics were there from the start. Out of print since 1977, “This Close to You” will be available Friday.
lead_paragraph: Nile Rodgers’s very first professional recording session, in the late 1970s, got off to a bumpy start. He wasn’t the only guitarist booked to work with Luther, a group fronted by Luther Vandross, but Rodgers was the youngest, making him an easy target when Paul Riser, the Motown veteran arranging the session, noted something he didn’t like.

headline: A Brooklyn Doughnut Shop Opens a Portal Into a Sweeter Past
abstract: Peter Pan, born in the 1950s in Greenpoint, conjures more than memories for the illustrator Rachelle Meyer.
lead_paragraph: Follow New York Times Cooking on Instagram, Facebook, YouTube, TikTok and Pinterest. Get regular updates from New York Times Cooking, with recipe suggestions, cooking tips and shopping advice.

headline: As Ukraine’s Summer Starts With Blackouts, Worries Over Winter Begin
abstract: Recent rolling power outages have raised alarm about what will happen when cold weather arrives and energy consumption goes even higher.
lead_paragraph: Skyscrapers are without electricity up to 12 hours a day. Neighborhoods are filled with the roar of gas generators installed by cafes and restaurants. And at night, streets are plunged into darkness for lack of lighting.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,083, June 6, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 361, June 6, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: It’s Wedding Season: Here Come the Owls
abstract: What better way to deliver the rings to the bride and groom?
lead_paragraph: Juliet has been to many weddings, and she’s a pro. While the happy couple are exchanging vows, she comes out of a dark box and hops onto the gloved arm of Duncan Blake, her handler. With a 270-degree turn of her head, she takes in her surroundings.

headline: Biden’s Push to End the War in Gaza
abstract: The American president revealed a secret cease-fire proposal that may force Israel’s leader to choose between the end of the war and his political survival.
lead_paragraph: In an unexpected speech last week, President Biden revealed the details of a secret proposal intended to end the war in Gaza. Perhaps the most surprising thing was where that proposal had come from.

headline: Israel Secretly Targets U.S. Lawmakers, and Biden Visits Europe
abstract: Plus, what our reporter witnessed in Sudan.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Biden Tries to Close a Loophole
abstract: We explore the story behind the president’s immigration order.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s latest executive actions on immigration are an attempt to shrink a loophole that has allowed many people to enter the country without legal permission. That loophole is the asylum system.

headline: Want to See Bison at Yellowstone? You’re Likely Not Prepared.
abstract: An 83-year-old woman was gored Saturday by a bison. Experts offered advice on how to avoid a similar situation.
lead_paragraph: In the deep green pastures of Yellowstone National Park, where the air is crisp and the tall grass dances in the breeze, lives the bison, a large, majestic animal with chocolate brown fur — and a delicate temperament that could turn from pleasant to dangerous in seconds.

headline: Alameda City Council Votes to Stop Cloud Brightening Test
abstract: City officials decided to block testing of an experimental technology to fight global warming, even though experts hired by the city found that it posed no health risk to residents.
lead_paragraph: The international debate over how much to interfere with nature to slow the planet’s warming was fought on a surprising stage this week: a City Council meeting in Alameda, on the eastern edge of San Francisco Bay.

headline: Europe’s Fed Problem
abstract: The European Central Bank is widely expected to cut interest rates on Thursday. But how low it can go may ultimately depend on the Federal Reserve.
lead_paragraph: Thursday is a big day for the European Central Bank. It is widely expected to lower interest rates by a quarter percentage point, its first cut since 2019 — and outpace the Fed in lowering borrowing costs. Investors will watch to see how that would influence monetary policy beyond Brussels, as well as its effect on global trade, stock markets and the dollar.

headline: Dollar Tree Explores Sale of Family Dollar
abstract: Family Dollar has struggled with its operations in recent years, and its owner, Dollar Tree, said in March that it would close nearly 1,000 of the stores.
lead_paragraph: Dollar Tree said on Wednesday that it was considering a sale or spinoff of Family Dollar, which has struggled with its operation for years.

headline: Far-Right Politician Attacked With Box Cutter in Germany
abstract: The authorities said the attack did not appear to be targeted. But it came days after members of an anti-Islam group were stabbed in the same city, raising fears about violence before E.U. elections.
lead_paragraph: A municipal candidate for the far-right Alternative for Germany party was slashed with a box cutter in the western German city of Mannheim, the authorities said on Wednesday.

headline: The New Kingmakers Who Could Make or Break Modi’s Government
abstract: Two veterans of bare-knuckled Indian politics have the Parliament votes the prime minister will need, but neither is aligned with his Hindu-first vision.
lead_paragraph: After his first two national election victories, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India easily set his own terms, with his Bharatiya Janata Party winning clear majorities.

headline: Is It Disrespectful to My Dead Father to Speak to His Estranged Brother?
abstract: A reader’s uncle and aunt were touched when she sent them a Christmas card, but her sister thinks the gesture was a betrayal of their father’s memory.
lead_paragraph: My father, who died seven years ago, was estranged from his brother for over 40 years. (I don’t know why.) So, I haven’t seen my uncle in decades. On a whim, when I was writing Christmas cards this year, I sent one to my uncle. On Valentine’s Day, I came home to find a dozen red roses and a box of candy on my doorstep with a note that read: “Your Christmas card meant the world to us!” It was signed, with love, from my uncle and aunt. I wasn’t sure what to do next, so I sent another note, sharing the details of my life — and eventually I received another dozen roses on my doorstep. My sister is appalled that I reached out to our uncle: Our father would not approve, she said, and it might upset our mother. So what should I do now: honor my dead father’s grievance or give my uncle a call?

headline: E.P.A. Moves to Limit Toxic Chemical Used in Hundreds of Products
abstract: The chemical, N-Methylpyrrolidone, or NMP, has been linked to miscarriages, reduced male fertility and other health problems.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency on Wednesday proposed limits on the use of N-Methylpyrrolidone, a solvent in many products used by both consumers and workers, ranging from arts and crafts supplies to paint remover, that is linked to serious health effects.

headline: Finding Your Roots With Help From Your Phone
abstract: Everyday tools and free apps on your mobile device can help you collect, translate and digitize new material for your family-tree files.
lead_paragraph: Spending time in graveyards and libraries may not be everyone’s idea of summer fun, but for those interested in finding their roots, collecting information about one’s ancestors is a “family” vacation. Sure, genealogy sites have made researching one’s ancestral history much easier with digitized document archives, family-tree-building software and community forums. But not everything is online.

headline: The Long, Difficult Road of Boeing’s Starliner Capsule
abstract: Here’s a timeline of the setbacks that proceeded the spacecraft’s first trip to orbit with astronauts on board.
lead_paragraph: In late 2019, Boeing appeared to have a good chance at beating SpaceX to become the first private U.S. company to take astronauts to orbit.

headline: Allies Warn Former Fighter Pilots Not to Train Chinese Military Members
abstract: A new bulletin says China is trying to step up recruitment of Western-trained fighter pilots to improve its air combat capability.
lead_paragraph: For years, U.S. officials have accused China of stealing American technology to design and build fighter planes. But while China learned how to build advanced fighters, its pilots could not fly them so well.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Former Partners Describe Toll of His Drug Abuse
abstract: His ex-wife and an ex-girlfriend painted a portrait of a family man who was falling into an abyss of addiction and living a lavish, party-hopping high life in New York and Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Two of Hunter Biden’s former romantic partners, his ex-wife and an ex-girlfriend, provided vivid and gut-wrenching testimony on Wednesday about his out-of-control addiction to crack in the weeks and months before he claimed to be drug-free on a federal firearms form.

headline: Larry Hogan Incurs Trump’s Wrath After Telling Americans to ‘Respect the Verdict’
abstract: When former Gov. Larry Hogan asked Americans to “respect the verdict,” the Trump team turned on his Senate candidacy, jeopardizing a potential Republican pickup opportunity.
lead_paragraph: With former President Donald J. Trump’s organization in full attack mode, former Gov. Larry Hogan’s path to the Senate in Maryland is getting considerably narrower.

headline: California City Leaders End Cloud-Brightening Test, Overruling Staff
abstract: The City Council in Alameda, Calif., voted to stop tests of a device that could one day cool the Earth. Scientists and city staff had previously concluded the tests posed no risk.
lead_paragraph: Elected leaders in Alameda, Calif., voted early on Wednesday to stop scientists from testing a device that might one day be used to artificially cool the planet, overruling city staff members who had found the experiment posed no danger.

headline: ‘Hanging by a Thread’: U.N. Chief Warns of Missing a Key Climate Target
abstract: His comments came as the world body’s weather agency said it expected Earth to soon surpass the record high temperatures experienced in 2023.
lead_paragraph: With the planet in the grips of its highest temperatures in more than 100,000 years, scientists with the United Nations weather agency have crunched the numbers and come to a stark conclusion: More record-hot years are all but inevitable.

headline: How Would Congestion Pricing Have Worked in New York City?
abstract: The tolling program aimed to diminish traffic while raising money for mass transit.
lead_paragraph: For decades, New York lawmakers, transit officials and environmental activists have been pushing to implement a plan to toll drivers who enter Manhattan’s core business district — a concept known as congestion pricing.

headline: How Electric Car Batteries Might Aid the Grid (and Win Over Drivers)
abstract: Automakers are exploring energy storage as a way to help utilities and save customers money, turning an expensive component into an industry asset.
lead_paragraph: Electric cars are more expensive than gasoline models largely because batteries cost so much. But new technology could turn those pricey devices into an asset, giving owners benefits like reduced utility bills, lower lease payments or free parking.

headline: Collectors Line Up in London as King Charles Bank Notes Are Released
abstract: A steady stream of people lined up at the Bank of England on Wednesday to get what they hoped would be collector’s items: the first bank notes featuring the portrait of King Charles III.
lead_paragraph: Bank notes can still be exciting in our increasingly cashless society.

headline: India Keeps Its Glorious, Messy Tradition Alive
abstract: The voters have spoken: They want to keep their democracy.
lead_paragraph: Back in January, when Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India looked all but unstoppable, he visited the small city of Ayodhya for the unofficial start of his campaign to win a third term. The location was freighted with symbolism. For decades, Hindu nationalists had sought to build a temple in Ayodhya, at a spot they believe to be the birthplace of the Hindu god Ram. The only problem was that there was already a house of worship on the spot, a mosque built by a Mughal emperor in 1528. A Hindu mob had dismantled the mosque in 1992, setting off riots that killed 2,000 people, most of them Muslims. The ruins were a flashpoint of religious tensions in India for decades.

headline: Narendra Modi Fell to Earth After Making It All About Himself
abstract: The Indian leader used his singular persona to lift his party to new heights. Then the opposition found a way to use his cult of personality against him.
lead_paragraph: When everything became about Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India, his party and its century-old Hindu-nationalist network were propelled to unimagined heights.

headline: New Report Underscores the Seriousness of Long Covid
abstract: The National Academies said the condition could involve up to 200 symptoms, make it difficult for people to work and last for months or years.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s premier medical advisory organizations has weighed in on long Covid with a 265-page report that recognizes the seriousness and persistence of the condition for millions of Americans.

headline: At the Tribeca Festival, Vision and Vibes
abstract: The festival favors abundance, which can make it easy for cinema fans (and critics) to miss the loveliest trees for the sheer breadth of forest.
lead_paragraph: Early in the animated film “Boys Go to Jupiter,” premiering at this year’s Tribeca Festival, an indie electronic beat kicks in. Like a music video rendered on Kid Pix, the sequence that follows finds the mulleted Rozebud (voiced by the singer Miya Folick) tending to neon citrus trees while crooning a melody as catchy as it is ethereal. The film, from the artist Julian Glander, belongs to a subset of Tribeca movies that use music in startling and adventurous ways. Their soundscapes conjure vision and feeling, as well as that ineffable thing sometimes called vibe.

headline: Blissfully Crunchy Hot Honey Chicken
abstract: A coating of crushed cornflakes gives these cutlets a shaggy golden crust, ready to trap a drizzling of hot honey.
lead_paragraph: Hello! Here’s something new: I took over the Well newsletter this week, creating a weekend-prep game plan to make weeknight cooking faster and easier. Think: Wash and cut up your sturdy veggies on Sunday so you’re all set for orzo salad on Monday and naan-o paneer-o sabzi on Tuesday. Sign up here to get my takeover in your inbox tomorrow!

headline: The Shyamalans: A Family That Scares Together
abstract: Saleka and Ishana Night Shyamalan are collaborating with their father, M. Night Shyamalan, on the thrillers “The Watchers” and “Trap.” The release dates are a happy coincidence.
lead_paragraph: The Shyamalan family is very close. How close? During a video interview with the sisters Saleka, 27, and Ishana Night Shyamalan, 24, their dad, the “Sixth Sense” director M. Night Shyamalan, called Ishana on the phone. The sound interrupted Ishana speaking about the differences between her and her father’s filmmaking process.

headline: Here’s a Closer Look at the Hurdles to a Cease-Fire Deal
abstract: Neither Israel or Hamas have said definitively whether they would accept or reject a proposal outlined by President Biden, but sizable gaps between the two sides appear to remain.
lead_paragraph: President Biden raised hopes last week when he endorsed a plan that he said could lead to a “cessation of hostilities permanently.” He said Israel had put forward the plan, but neither Israel nor Hamas has said definitively that they would accept or reject the proposal, and they appear to still be locked in disagreement over fundamental issues.

headline: Police Arrest 13 After Protesters Occupied Stanford President’s Office
abstract: Demonstrators had taken over the office at dawn and demanded that Stanford University trustees vote on divestment from companies said to support Israel’s military.
lead_paragraph: Police officers arrested 13 people on Wednesday after pro-Palestinian protesters barricaded themselves in the office of the president of Stanford University and demanded that administrators meet several demands, including a vote by the university trustees on whether to divest from companies that are said to support Israel's military.

headline: New Stock Exchange in Texas Takes Aim at N.Y.S.E. and Nasdaq
abstract: The Texas Stock Exchange, based in Dallas, has the backing of BlackRock and Citadel Securities. But challengers to the dominant New York markets have gained little traction.
lead_paragraph: A start-up stock exchange headquartered in Dallas and backed by the financial powerhouses BlackRock and Citadel Securities is set to challenge the dominance of the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq in the listing and trading of companies and funds.

headline: Rahul Gandhi, Long on the Ropes, Looks Set for an Unexpected Comeback
abstract: The Indian National Congress and its leader registered a far stronger showing in India’s elections than many expected.
lead_paragraph: Just last year, Rahul Gandhi and the once-powerful party he led, the Indian National Congress, seemed to be on the ropes and little threat to Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s consolidation of political power.

headline: Pro Skier and Partner Fall to Their Deaths in the Italian Alps
abstract: Jean Daniel Pession, a speed skier on the World Cup circuit, and his girlfriend, Elisa Arlian, fell more than 2,000 feet.
lead_paragraph: A professional skier and his girlfriend fell more than 2,000 feet to their deaths while mountain climbing in the Italian Alps, sports officials in the country said.

headline: London Hospitals Face Major Disruptions After Cyberattack
abstract: A system used by several major London hospitals was targeted in a ransomware cyberattack, forcing the cancellation of services and the diversion of patients.
lead_paragraph: Several major hospitals in London have been crippled by a cyberattack, Britain’s National Health Service said, causing surgical procedures to be canceled, disrupting blood transfusions and forcing patients to be diverted.

headline: How Will Trump’s Conviction Affect the Election?
abstract: Readers offer their analyses in response to various Opinion writers. Also: Foster children; free school meals.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: What Did Jenna Lyons Sell at Her Stoop Sale?
abstract: A garment she wore to Michelle Obama’s birthday party was just one of the things the former J. Crew president and reality television star added to the sale.
lead_paragraph: On the third floor of a building in SoHo, Jenna Lyons sat frantically scrubbing a pair of Lanvin shoes.

headline: It Was Legal Boilerplate. Trump Made It Sound Like a Threat to His Life.
abstract: The former president’s lies about the F.B.I. being prepared to kill him during the search of Mar-a-Lago took his attacks on the justice system and the rule of law to another level.
lead_paragraph: On the day before the F.B.I. obtained a search warrant almost two years ago to look for classified materials at former President Donald J. Trump’s private club and residence in Florida, one of the agents on the case sent a reassuring email to his bosses.

headline: ‘Hitler and the Nazis’ Review: Building a Case for Alarm
abstract: Joe Berlinger’s six-part documentary for Netflix asks whether we should see our future in Germany’s past.
lead_paragraph: Hitler’s project: “Making Germany great again.” The Nazis’ characterization of criticism from the media: “Fake news.” Hitler’s mountain retreat in Berchtesgaden: “It’s sort of like Hitler’s Mar-a-Lago, if you will.”

headline: Hochul Halts Congestion Pricing in a Stunning 11th-Hour Shift
abstract: Weeks before New York was to charge motorists to enter Manhattan’s business district, Gov. Kathy Hochul postponed the program, citing economic concerns.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced on Wednesday that she was shelving the long-awaited tolling plan known as congestion pricing, just weeks before it was to go into effect.

headline: Little Island Gets a Reboot, With a Rising Star at the Helm
abstract: Zack Winokur, an ambitious dancer-turned-director, now has a New York stage to call his own as the park’s artistic leader.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Zack Winokur stood at the top row of the amphitheater of Little Island. Hundreds of people had taken their seats for the first performance of the park’s summer season, but he didn’t feel like joining them. “I’m just going to pace,” he said.

headline: Court Strikes Down S.E.C.’s Fee Disclosure Rule for Funds
abstract: Private equity and hedge funds had appealed the regulator’s August ruling requiring them to disclose their fees and expenses to investors.
lead_paragraph: A federal appellate court on Wednesday struck down a Securities and Exchange Commission rule intended to provide investors in hedge funds, private equity funds and venture capital firms with more information about fees and expenses.

headline: U.S. Counterterrorism Chief Is Stepping Down
abstract: The official, Christine Abizaid, recently warned that the Hamas attacks in Israel, and the Gaza conflict, had energized terrorist threats worldwide.
lead_paragraph: The director of the National Counterterrorism Center will step down next month, Biden administration officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Why Children Are Missing More School Now
abstract: Norms on attendance have changed, but it’s about more than Covid-era school closings.
lead_paragraph: The raw data looks inarguably bad: The share of American children missing at least 10 percent of school days nearly doubled over the course of the pandemic, leaving perhaps more than six million more students “chronically absent” than had been in the 2018-19 school year.

headline: Gov. Hochul’s Unwarranted Retreat on Congestion Pricing
abstract: A vitally important public policy was derailed over political concerns.
lead_paragraph: Americans didn’t need a reason to feel more cynical about politics. But Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York has delivered one.

headline: Do I Tell the Woman With a Medical Condition She Can’t Swim With Us?
abstract: The magazine’s ethicist columnist on what to do when forced to play lifeguard.

headline: As Hunter Biden Stands Trial, a Republican Noise Machine Goes Silent
abstract: Republicans have gone after Hunter Biden for years, but his trial on gun charges undermines their views on gun rights and on a “weaponized” Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the verdict in Hunter Biden’s gun trial.

headline: Review: ‘What’s the Point?’ Oona Doherty’s Resonant Ambivalence
abstract: The choreographer’s “Navy Blue” is the rare work to express the emotions of life in pandemic lockdown.
lead_paragraph: Despite the enormous impact that the pandemic had on dance, few works have emerged that capture the experience. Plenty of pieces have been shaped by isolation and social-distancing rules, but not many have made something of the emotions of lockdown. Oona Doherty’s “Navy Blue,” from 2022, is one, and the feelings it effectively expresses are those of the lucky: dread, helplessness, guilt.

headline: Supporters of Congestion Pricing Are Furious at Hochul’s ‘Betrayal’
abstract: Advocates who have been fighting for decades for the program were shocked by the governor’s sudden move and lamented its impact on funding for the city’s subway.
lead_paragraph: With weeks to go before the launch of a plan to toll drivers in Manhattan’s core commercial district, advocates and organizers of congestion pricing had been celebrating a victory years in the making.

headline: The Bird Flu Virus Adapted to Sea Mammals. It May Not Be Done Yet.
abstract: Huge die-offs of elephant seals occurred after the virus gained nearly 20 troublesome new mutations, scientists found.
lead_paragraph: Elephant seals in South America died in massive numbers because the bird flu virus acquired mutations that allowed it to spread among mammals, according to a new study.

headline: Erich Anderson, Actor in ‘Friday the 13th’ and ‘Felicity,’ Dies at 67
abstract: Mr. Anderson had a breakout role in “Friday the 13th” and went on to appear in more than 300 TV episodes, including a recurring role as the father on “Felicity.”
lead_paragraph: Erich Anderson, an actor known for his breakout role in the “Friday the 13th” franchise and recurring appearances on television series like “Felicity” and “Thirtysomething,” died on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 67.

headline: Zoe Kestan, Hunter Biden’s Former Girlfriend, Describes Drug-Fueled Partying
abstract: Her testimony, like that of Mr. Biden’s other romantic partners, is intended to establish that he was a chronic drug abuser who lied when he claimed to be clean on an application for a handgun in October 2018.
lead_paragraph: The muted mood of Hunter Biden’s trial, which had focused on his struggle with addiction, shifted abruptly on Wednesday, with the appearance of Zoe Kestan, a former girlfriend who described him as a charming free-spender who loved the party-hopping high life in New York.

headline: Byron Donalds, Trump V.P. Contender, Suggests Jim Crow Era Had an Upside
abstract: The Republican congressman from Florida was visiting Philadelphia to persuade Black voters to support former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Representative Byron Donalds, a Florida Republican whom Donald J. Trump is said to be considering for his running mate, suggested on Tuesday that the Jim Crow era had some virtues for Black people while trying to persuade voters of color to back the former president.

headline: Getting a Cease-Fire in Gaza Has Been Hard. Fulfilling One Will Be Harder.
abstract: The proposal backed by President Biden is deeply political and aims at stopping the war at least for now. But Israel rejects a permanent cease-fire and Hamas has its own reasons for reluctance.
