lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken plans to visit Israel and three Arab states next week, as the U.S. presses for a cease-fire deal between Israel and Hamas to end the war in Gaza.

headline: YouTuber Who Had Lamborghini Shot With Fireworks From a Helicopter Is Arrested
abstract: Suk Min Choi, also known as Alex Choi, landed in trouble for directing the stunt recorded last year and posted to his YouTube channel, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A helicopter flying over what looks like arid land hovers near a blue Lamborghini, as the luxury sports car speeds in what could pass for a spectacular chase scene in an action film.

headline: 5 Convicted in Federal Fraud Trial Imperiled by a Gift Bag of Cash
abstract: Prosecutors accused the defendants of stealing millions of dollars from programs meant to feed children. A juror was replaced after officials said she was apparently offered a bribe of $120,000 to acquit.
lead_paragraph: A federal jury in Minneapolis on Friday convicted five people who had been accused of embezzling millions of government dollars from programs aimed at feeding hungry children during the pandemic. Two others accused in the case were acquitted.

headline: Can I Lie About How I Lost Weight?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what your friends have a right to know about your health.
lead_paragraph: My husband, who has struggled with his weight for decades, has decided under the recommendation of his doctor to begin taking Zepbound, an injectable specifically for weight loss. When he starts to lose weight, we know he will be congratulated and questioned by friends, co-workers and associates, as he has before when he has had significant weight loss. Are we obliged to tell people how he is losing weight? Would it be OK to be dishonest? — Name Withheld

headline: Are American Workers’ Wages Really Lagging Productivity?
abstract: The answer to this decades-old debate depends on which workers you’re talking about.
lead_paragraph: It’s become conventional wisdom in some circles that sometime in the 1970s, the link between pay and productivity broke. Workers’ productivity kept rising, but their inflation-adjusted pay did not. “The divergence between the two trends suggests that there may be forces suppressing the pay of workers relative to their productivity,” President Biden’s Council of Economic Advisers wrote in 2022.

headline: Elin Hilderbrand Says Goodbye to Nantucket Summers
abstract: The author discusses her new novel, “Swan Song,” which she says is the last beach read she intends to write.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Elin Hilderbrand’s name has been synonymous with summer reading. Her novels set among the misbehaving moneyed class on Nantucket Island juggle romance and crime and a sun-kissed beach vibe that her fans soak up like coconut oil, some of them so fervently that they even make pilgrimages to Nantucket in the off-season.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, June 8, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Can I Opt Out of Meta’s A.I. Scraping on Instagram and Facebook? Sort Of.
abstract: Social media users voiced worries about a move by Meta to use information from public Instagram and Facebook posts to train its A.I. But the scraping has already begun. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Meta announced that it was going to expand its artificial intelligence services around the world, and the company let users in Europe know that it would use their public information to train its A.I. services starting on June 26.

headline: U.S. Fund for Nuclear Radiation Victims Set to Expire Amid Impasse in Congress
abstract: Lawmakers are looking for a way to extend the program to compensate victims of government-caused nuclear contamination who fell ill, and some are seeking to expand it.
lead_paragraph: A law allowing victims of government-caused nuclear contamination who developed cancer and other illnesses to receive federal compensation was set to expire on Friday, amid an impasse in Congress over significantly expanding eligibility for the program.

headline: Senate Democrats Face Escalating Calls for Broader Investigation Into Supreme Court
abstract: They say their options are limited by the court’s status as a separate branch of government and deep Republican opposition.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats are facing intensifying pressure from the left for inquiries into ethical questions at the Supreme Court, but they say their options are limited given the court’s independent status and Republican opposition.

headline: Is New York’s Economy Too Fragile for Congestion Pricing? Many Say No.
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul said she halted the tolling plan because of New York City’s unstable economic recovery. Experts say the alternatives are worse.
lead_paragraph: In her abrupt decision on Wednesday to halt New York City’s congestion pricing plan, Gov. Kathy Hochul made a familiar argument: The city’s economic recovery from the coronavirus pandemic was still too “delicate.”

headline: How Media Outlets on the Left and Right Covered Biden’s Immigration Order
abstract: Conservative media outlets criticized the executive order as being too lenient, while the liberal outlets that covered it said it was harmful to migrants.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s immigration policies are a frequent target of conservative and liberal media outlets, often mirroring criticisms from Republican and Democratic elected officials. The reaction to his executive order on Tuesday, which limits asylum at the U.S.-Mexico border, was no different.

headline: Putin, at Economic Forum, Again Talks About Nuclear War
abstract: The Russian leader’s chatter about nuclear weapons has picked up since the U.S. allowed Ukraine to use its conventional weapons against military targets in Russia.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Friday that even the combined arsenals of Europe and the United States would be no match for Russia’s in a nuclear confrontation, but that “I hope this is never going to happen.”

headline: Alex Jones Seeks to Liquidate His Assets to Pay Damages to Sandy Hook Families
abstract: But money to the families would fall far short of the more than $1.4 billion they were awarded by juries for Mr. Jones’s lies about the 2012 school massacre.
lead_paragraph: The Infowars conspiracy theorist Alex Jones is seeking permission from a bankruptcy court to liquidate his personal assets and deliver the proceeds to the Sandy Hook families who are owed more than $1.4 billion in damages for his lies about the 2012 school shooting.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Limits of Tall Privilege
abstract: If you’re tall, can you put your hiking boots on the dining table?
lead_paragraph: Katie writes: Because he’s tall, my husband, Andrew, puts our backpacking gear on the dining table, including our shoes, which I don’t think should be on eating surfaces. He says that he wouldn’t do it if he had stepped in dog poop, and that the thousands of steps we take each day remove anything objectionable.

headline: Jeannette Charles, Who Doubled for the Queen, Is Dead at 96
abstract: She bore a startling resemblance to Elizabeth II. In “The Naked Gun” and other movies, and in comedy sketches on TV, she wore the crown lightly.
lead_paragraph: Jeannette Charles, who transformed a portrait rejected by a royal art show into a career as a Queen Elizabeth II look-alike in movies and on television, died on Tuesday in Great Baddow, England. She was 96 — the same age as the monarch when she died two years ago.

headline: $365 to Book a Table for 2 in New York? A New Law Could Stop That.
abstract: A bill passed by state lawmakers this week would prohibit third-party services from selling restaurant reservations without the restaurant’s approval.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that it can be difficult to reserve a table at many popular New York City restaurants, especially with some third-party services using computer bots to make reservations and then selling them at steep prices.

headline: U.S. Considers Expanded Nuclear Arsenal, a Reversal of Decades of Cuts
abstract: China’s expansion and Russia’s threats of using nuclear weapons in Ukraine and in space have changed a U.S. drive to reduce nuclear weapons.
lead_paragraph: A senior Biden administration official warned on Friday that “absent a change” in nuclear strategy by China and Russia, the United States may be forced to expand its nuclear arsenal, after decades of cutting back through now largely abandoned arms control agreements.

headline: Have You Applied for Federal Compensation for Nuclear Radiation Exposure? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: We’re hoping to speak to people who have filed a claim through the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act. We want to know what the experience was like.
lead_paragraph: We’ve been covering efforts on Capitol Hill to substantially expand the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act, a 1990 law allowing victims of government-caused nuclear contamination who developed cancer and other serious illnesses.

headline: Apple Watch in Stolen Luggage Leads to Airport Worker’s House, Police Say
abstract: The Sheriff’s Office in Broward County, Fla., said an airport worker had been charged with stealing a woman’s bag, which had her Apple Watch inside.
lead_paragraph: When a Florida woman’s pink hard-shell roller bag didn’t show up at the baggage carousel after her flight was canceled, she panicked.

headline: Latinos for Trump Rebrands to Add ‘Americans’ to Its Name
abstract: Trump’s Latino outreach effort aims to emphasize citizenship as he makes inroads with these voters, even as he ramps up inflammatory talk about immigrants.
lead_paragraph: “Latinos for Trump” is no more. Now, it is “Latino Americans for Trump.”

headline: New York Should Lead the Way on Congestion Pricing, Not Delay It
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul’s misguided decision would be a huge setback for the quality of life in the nation’s largest city.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen days ago, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York stood before an audience of world economic leaders in Ireland and promised to transform mobility in New York City with a first-in-the-nation congestion-pricing system. The concept, she said, had stalled for 60 years because leaders feared a backlash from drivers set in their ways. But, she said, “if we’re serious about making cities more livable, we must get over that.”

headline: What We Know About Israel’s Deadly Strike on U.N. School Complex in Gaza
abstract: Israel said it struck three classrooms used by 20 to 30 Palestinian militants. Gazan health authorities said that many women and children were among the dozens killed.
lead_paragraph: A day after Israeli forces bombed a U.N. school complex in central Gaza that had become a shelter for displaced Palestinians, some of the facts remain unclear or under contention.

headline: They Sang, They Cheered, They Bravo’ed: Italy Is Hailed as Home of Opera
abstract: A star-studded concert pulled out all the stops to celebrate one of the country’s most important art forms.
lead_paragraph: If there was ever any question of what a Three Tenors concert on steroids might look like, the hundreds of performers belting out operatic greatest hits at the Arena of Verona on Friday night could offer a good answer.

headline: Are These Really ‘the World’s 50 Best Restaurants’?
abstract: The places on this year’s “50 Best” list are endurance tests, theatrical spectacles, monuments to ego and — the two most frightening words in dining — “immersive experiences.”
lead_paragraph: To be media literate these days is to understand that no ranked list, whether it is the “100 Greatest Drummers of All Time” or the “35 Cutest Dog Breeds to Ever Exist,” should be taken too literally. We all know that the cuteness of the Maltipoo and the awesomeness of Keith Moon are matters of opinion.

headline: U.S. Hiring and Wages Rose More Than Expected
abstract: Also, Biden pushes for more E.V.s. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The labor market outperformed forecasts yet again in May, according to government data released today. Employers added 272,000 jobs, easily topping the average monthly gains over the previous year. Wages also rose 4.1 percent from a year ago, beating expectations.

headline: School and Police Officials in Vermont Apologize for Mock Shooting Drill
abstract: The exercise upset some high school students who were on a field trip to the Burlington Police Department this week.
lead_paragraph: School and police officials in Burlington, Vt., apologized on Friday after high school students on a field trip to the Police Department were exposed to a staged armed robbery that included a mock shooting — a training exercise that upset some students.

headline: Roaring Kitty Talked GameStop and Chugged Beer. Shares Plunged.
abstract: Keith Gill, the investor who spurred the meme stock mania in 2021, attracted a huge audience for his public return to livestreaming Friday. But his favorite buy dropped.
lead_paragraph: Around lunchtime Friday, on a YouTube livestream watched by half a million people, a bandanna-clad man in white sunglasses grinned into his webcam and teased: “I’m about to show it.”

headline: The Biden Family’s Public Reckoning With Addiction
abstract: President Biden is keeping his son close, and acknowledging his addiction, while he’s on trial.
lead_paragraph: This week, in a courtroom in Delaware, federal prosecutors presented a sordid story of drug use and a fateful gun purchase by President Biden’s son.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Officer Accused of Critically Wounding Man in Off-Duty Shooting
abstract: Prosecutors said Officer Hieu Tran shot the driver of a truck at a New Jersey intersection in an apparent road rage episode and then drove off. He has been charged with attempted murder.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer has been charged with attempted murder after shooting another motorist during an apparent road-rage episode in New Jersey and then driving off, prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: Israel Strikes Another School Building as It Pushes On in Gaza
abstract: The Israeli military said it killed militants in the central part of the enclave on Friday, a day after a strike on a former school, where Gazan officials say civilians were killed.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military pushed ahead with its offensive in central Gaza on Friday, saying it had killed dozens of militants, including some who had holed up in the premises of a former United Nations school that had been converted into a shelter in the area.

headline: Denmark’s Prime Minister Is Attacked in Copenhagen Square
abstract: Mette Frederiksen, who has led the country since 2019, was “beaten,” her office said. The police said an arrest had been made, but a motive was unclear.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark was attacked on Friday evening in a busy square in Copenhagen in an assault that left her “shaken,” her office said, though she was able to walk away. The police said they had made an arrest.

headline: If Trump Wins
abstract: Donald Trump and his closest allies are planning a radical reshaping of American government. Here are some of the policy stakes if he regains power in 2025.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and his closest allies are planning a radical reshaping of American government. Here are some of the policy stakes if he regains power in 2025.

headline: R.F.K. Jr. Will Be on the Ballot in Florida, His Campaign Says
abstract: The minor but storied Reform Party, which is backing Robert F. Kennedy Jr., had its ballot access restored, a significant boon for the independent candidate.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the independent presidential candidate, will be on the ballot in Florida this fall, his campaign said on Friday, after the minor party that nominated Mr. Kennedy as its presidential candidate had its ballot access reinstated this week.

headline: Alvin Bragg Agrees to Testify Before Congress About Trump Case
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney suggested to a Republican congressman that he would testify only after former President Donald J. Trump is sentenced in July.
lead_paragraph: Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney who prosecuted former President Donald J. Trump, agreed on Friday to testify before Congress as Republicans seek to discredit Mr. Trump’s conviction. But Mr. Bragg suggested his testimony would need to wait until after Mr. Trump is sentenced next month.

headline: Hunter Biden Is on Trial, but All Eyes Are on the Biden Women
abstract: The women called to testify have at different times tried to support a man whose history of addiction continues to hit them with shrapnel.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the verdict in Hunter Biden’s gun trial.

headline: Washington Post Leaders Look to Quell Anxiety
abstract: Will Lewis, the chief executive, pledged to employees to “improve how well I listen,” while Matt Murray, the new editor, tried to reassure staff members.
lead_paragraph: After a tumultuous week at The Washington Post, including the unexpected announcement of a new editor and reports that its chief executive objected to coverage of a news story involving him, leaders at the news organization spent Friday trying to reassure the staff.

headline: The Best Beach and Surf Gear
abstract: How to maximize your day at the beach.
lead_paragraph: How to maximize your day at the beach.

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Episode 6 Recap: A Charming Rogue
abstract: The Doctor and Ruby head back to Regency England in a meta meditation on cosplay and obsessive TV fandom.
lead_paragraph: For decades, cosplay has been a huge part of the “Doctor Who” fandom, with hardcore viewers rocking up to conventions or gathering to watch the show decked out in Tom Baker’s striped scarf or David Tennant’s slim suit.

headline: Washington Post Shake-Up Brings Fresh Eyes to an Old Scandal
abstract: The newspaper’s new publisher argued against coverage of British phone hacking. Instead, he has invited renewed scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, Rupert Murdoch’s media empire, News Corporation, faced a grave threat in Britain. Reporters at one of his tabloid newspapers were exposed for hacking the phones of celebrities, private citizens and, in one case, a murdered child for information.

headline: N.Y. Lawmakers End Session Without Replacing Congestion Pricing Revenue
abstract: State Senate Democrats rebuked Gov. Kathy Hochul over her decision to halt a long-developed plan to charge drivers tolls to enter Manhattan’s core.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul defended her decision to halt congestion pricing hours after State Senate Democrats said they would leave Albany without plugging the funding gap left in its absence.

headline: Weeks Before Prison, a Defiant Bannon Is Still Rallying MAGA World
abstract: The onetime adviser to former President Donald J. Trump has framed his impending imprisonment as an act of patriotism.
lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Bannon was sitting in the back seat of an S.U.V. on a pleasant Friday evening in Powhatan, Va., enjoying what could be his last weeks of freedom.

headline: William A. Anders, 90, Dies; Flew on First Manned Orbit of the Moon
abstract: During the 1968 Apollo 8 mission, his color photograph of an emerging Earth, known as “Earthrise,” became an icon and driving force for the environmental movement.
lead_paragraph: Maj. Gen. William A. Anders, who flew on the first manned space mission to orbit the moon, the Apollo 8 “Genesis flight” of Christmas Eve 1968, and took the color photograph “Earthrise,” which is credited with inspiring the modern environmental movement, died on Friday morning when a small plane he was piloting alone dived into the water northwest of Seattle. He was 90.

headline: ‘The Time Has Come to Say Goodbye’: Pat Sajak Bids Farewell to ‘Wheel of Fortune’
abstract: The host thanked the show’s viewers and had special words for his co-star, Vanna White, before he signed off for the final time.
lead_paragraph: On Friday night, Pat Sajak said goodbye to “Wheel of Fortune,” expressing gratitude to the countless viewers who had tuned in during his more than 40 years at the helm. “Thank you for allowing me into your lives,” he said.

headline: Stage Opening, Perhaps
abstract: Daniel Sheremeta makes a sweeping Saturday debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an excellent, twisty themeless puzzle that will please the solvers who pick up on subtleties and curious juxtapositions between entries. It’s Daniel Sheremeta’s second construction for The New York Times after a Friday debut in 2022; that one is another toughie that went over like gangbusters, so try it when you’ve recuperated from today’s challenge.

headline: Kari Lake Delivered a Speech in Front of a Confederate Flag
abstract: Appearing at a Trump-themed merchandise store in Show Low, Ariz., Ms. Lake repeated lies about the 2020 election’s having been stolen from former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Kari Lake, the leading Republican candidate for Senate in Arizona, delivered a speech in front of a Confederate flag at a Trump-themed merchandise store in Show Low, Ariz., last week.

headline: University of California Workers Ordered to End Strike Over Protest Grievances
abstract: An Orange County judge halted the labor action by academic workers after the university system said the walkout was causing students “irreparable harm.”
lead_paragraph: A strike by University of California academic workers over the treatment of pro-Palestinian demonstrators was temporarily halted by a Southern California judge on Friday after the university argued the walkout was causing students “irreparable harm.”

headline: George Clooney Complained to White House About Biden’s Criticism of I.C.C.
abstract: The actor contacted a top official to protest the president’s denunciation of the move to seek arrest warrants for top Israeli officials over the war in Gaza, a case his wife worked on.
lead_paragraph: George Clooney contacted a top White House official last month to complain after President Biden criticized the International Criminal Court’s decision to seek a warrant against top Israeli officials over the war in Gaza, a case the actor’s wife had worked on, according to two people familiar with the situation.

headline: Canadian Auto Parts Billionaire Faces Sexual Assault Charges
abstract: A police force outside Toronto said that charges against Frank Stronach, 91, relate to episodes from as long ago as the 1980s and as recent as last year.
lead_paragraph: Frank Stronach, the 91-year-old billionaire founder of one of the world’s largest auto parts companies, was arrested and charged on Friday in connection with a sexual assault investigation.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Affordable Housing Faces a Threat as Insurance Costs Soar
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It severely impacts your operating budget. You can only squeeze a dime so many times.”

headline: Corrections: June 8, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 8, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about the start of Hunter Biden’s gun trial case misstated the middle initial of a top deputy to the special counsel, David C. Weiss. He is Leo J. Wise, not Leo P. Wise.

headline: ‘The Bachelor,’ but Make It Belgian Politics
abstract: A reality show called “The Conclave” put Belgium’s political rivals together in a medieval château for a weekend. Can they put aside their differences and help keep the country from coming apart?
lead_paragraph: In the United States, Donald J. Trump and Joe Biden can barely agree to share a stage for a debate.

headline: Jordan Bardella, the New Face of France’s Surging Right
abstract: Charismatic and clean cut, shorn of the Le Pen name, the young National Rally leader took his party to its blockbuster showing in European elections on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: France has a taste for revolutions, and in the 28-year-old Jordan Bardella, it has found a mild-mannered, impeccably dressed insurgent who vows to upend the politics of the country in order to save it from “disappearance.”

headline: Macron Hosts Biden in Paris, Honoring a Not Always Easy Bond
abstract: The friendship between France and the U.S. endures. But tensions have mounted over the wars in Gaza and Ukraine, and how Europe can step out of America’s shadow.
lead_paragraph: In the sunlight of Normandy, before the surviving American veterans who eight decades ago helped turn the tide of the war against Hitler, President Emmanuel Macron of France spoke this past week of the “bond of blood shed for liberty” that ties his country to the United States.

headline: A member of Netanyahu’s war cabinet who threatened to quit postpones a planned address.
abstract: The decision comes as Israeli authorities announced that they had rescued four hostages who had been held in Gaza since Oct. 7.
lead_paragraph: A key member of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s Israeli war cabinet who has threatened to depart amid serious differences over the war in Gaza has indefinitely postponed an expected news conference planned for Saturday evening, citing “recent events.”

headline: Vietnam Arrests Prominent Journalist for Facebook Posts
abstract: Truong Huy San was accused of “abusing democratic freedoms,” a charge that rights groups say has been frequently used against critics of the government.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Vietnam have arrested one of the country’s most prominent journalists and accused him of “abusing democratic freedoms” by posting articles on Facebook that “infringed on the interests of the state and the legitimate rights and interests of organizations and individuals.”

headline: How Matt Williams, the Creator of ‘Roseanne,’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Williams loves people-watching and pasta with his wife. But when he’s writing on Sundays? No judgment allowed.
lead_paragraph: Over the past four decades, Matt Williams has been intimately involved in many of America’s most successful television programs.

headline: How an American Dream of Housing Became a Reality in Sweden
abstract: The U.S. once looked to modular construction as an efficient way to build lots of housing at scale, but Sweden picked up the idea and put it into practice.
lead_paragraph: As an architect, Ivan Rupnik thinks the solution to America’s affordable housing shortage is obvious: Build more houses. Start today. But the way homes are built in the United States makes speed impossible.

headline: Inside a Factory Where a Home Is Made Every 30 Minutes
abstract: The U.S. once looked to offsite construction as an efficient way to build lots of housing and drive down costs. Sweden has embraced the idea and put it into practice. Francesca Mari, a contributor to The New York Times, breaks down the process.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. once looked to offsite construction as an efficient way to build lots of housing and drive down costs. Sweden has embraced the idea and put it into practice. Francesca Mari, a contributor to The New York Times, breaks down the process.

headline: A Neighborhood Battles Illegal Weed Shops: ‘We’ve Been Begging for Help’
abstract: Alarmed by the proliferation of unlicensed stores, Lower East Side residents have banded together to track the shops and push for the authorities to shut them down.
lead_paragraph: Just before 11 p.m. on a recent Saturday, a young woman was buzzed into Flame Zone Convenience, an unlicensed weed store on Delancey Street in the Lower East Side displaying bags of potent gummies and multiple strains of marijuana, including one called Gunpowder.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: It Called Itself a Yoga School. Prosecutors Say It Was a Sex Cult.
abstract: The Buenos Aires Yoga School promised spiritual salvation, but former members and prosecutors say it pushed some female members into prostitution as it cultivated powerful friends.
lead_paragraph: Juan Percowicz was an accountant with an unusual side hobby: teaching self-help classes around Buenos Aires with a heavy dose of ancient philosophy and New Age spiritualism. He was a hit and, with donations from his followers, he built an organization known as Buenos Aires Yoga School, or BAYS.

headline: The Best Thrillers of the Year (So Far)
abstract: These twisty suspense novels will keep you on the edge of your seat.
lead_paragraph: We chose the 10 best thrillers of 2023. See the complete list.

headline: You Can Now Get Virtual Doula Care for Pregnancy. Does It Work?
abstract: Many doulas, relied upon for pregnancy and childbirth support, have started offering their services over text and video. Experts say that’s a good thing.
lead_paragraph: Kanwal Haq, a New York-based doula, was on a plane home from a vacation last September when she received a text from her client: “It’s game day here.”

headline: The Cats of Old San Juan Are Being Run Out of Town. Locals Can Empathize.
abstract: A federal plan to remove feral cats from a historic site in Puerto Rico’s capital has upset some residents, who are also feeling pushed out as housing costs soar.
lead_paragraph: Feral cats have roamed the blue cobblestone streets of Old San Juan for as long as anyone can remember. They meander around a historic fortress that looms over San Juan Bay, hiding from the hot sun under sea grape bushes.

headline: What Should You Wear to Our Wedding? Here’s a Mood Board.
abstract: Dress codes, color palettes and shopping guides: Wardrobe guidance for some weddings is getting increasingly specific.
lead_paragraph: When Lauren and Jackson England tied the knot with a safari wedding in Ranthambore, India, in January, they wanted the dress code to reflect the surroundings. The mood they communicated to their guests was “classic heritage Ralph Lauren.”

headline: The Napoleon of Your Living Room
abstract: Gary Friedman, who runs RH (formerly Restoration Hardware), is out to conquer the world, one luxurious sofa at a time. Next stop, Waterloo?
lead_paragraph: Gary Friedman hates meetings. A 66-year-old with apparently limitless energy and a perpetual tan, Mr. Friedman is the chief executive of RH, one of the country’s largest high-end furniture sellers, and he never holds meetings. Instead, he convenes “adventures.”

headline: An Essayist Who Revels in Glorious Chaos
abstract: In her third essay collection, the poet and critic Elisa Gabbert celebrates literature and life through a voracious engagement with the world.
lead_paragraph: “Any Person Is the Only Self,” the poet and critic Elisa Gabbert’s third collection of nonfiction, opens with an essay that should be, but isn’t quite, a mission statement. She starts by describing the Denver Public Library’s shelf for recent returns, a miscellaneous display of disconnected works she habitually browsed in the years she lived in Colorado. In part, Gabbert (who is also the Book Review’s poetry columnist) was drawn to the shelf for its “negative hype,” its opposition to the churn of literary publicity. But mainly, she enjoyed playing the odds. “Randomness is interesting,” she writes; “randomness looks beautiful to me.” At the essay’s end, she declares, “I need randomness to be happy.”

headline: A ‘Cursed Film’ Novel, Spiked With Venom and Fear
abstract: Lock the windows and bolt the doors before picking up Paul Tremblay’s “Horror Movie.”
lead_paragraph: In his listless post-college years, the unnamed narrator of “Horror Movie,” Paul Tremblay’s new novel, is recruited by an old classmate, Valentina, for a visionary amateur movie about a group of teenage outcasts who set out to create a monster. He has no acting experience; it’s his body type — lanky and attenuated — that they want for the silent, mysterious character known as the Thin Kid.

headline: Shrink the Economy, Save the World?
abstract: Economic growth has been ecologically costly — and so a movement in favor of ‘degrowth’ is growing.
lead_paragraph: A rising tide and a bigger pie: Economic growth has long been considered such an obvious boon that it’s pursued by governments across the world as a matter of course. But in 2016, when a London professor warned an audience in Newcastle that Brexit would lead to a precipitous drop in Britain’s gross domestic product, that well-worn measure of economic activity, one woman’s heckling caught him by surprise. “That’s your bloody G.D.P.,” she shouted, “not ours!”

headline: Trump Vows to Lower Prices. Some of His Policies May Raise Them.
abstract: Donald J. Trump has not released a detailed economic plan. But three of his key proposals would push prices up, economists say.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump routinely blames President Biden for higher prices at the grocery store and everywhere else Americans shop, and promises to “fix it.”

headline: Maya Hawke Doesn’t Want to Let the Vibe Die
abstract: She just finished playing Flannery O’Connor and released a new album. Next up: “Inside Out 2” and a new season of “Stranger Things.”
lead_paragraph: The actress and singer-songwriter Maya Hawke is on a self-awareness kick.

headline: Energy Drinks Boost Ukraine’s Soldiers, and Its Economy
abstract: Cans packed with caffeine and branded with patriotic machismo have become an essential antidote to the stresses of war.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny morning, deep in the forests of western Ukraine where the war barely reaches, 16,000 cans of a new energy drink, Volia, rolled off the assembly line every hour at the Morshynska beverage factory.

headline: When the Money Is Under the Mattress. Or in the Freezer. Or a Shoebox.
abstract: Older people who stash large sums of cash in their homes think it’s safer there than anyplace else. But they could be creating huge headaches for their heirs.
lead_paragraph: After their father died in 2021, Susan Camp and her brother cleaned out his home — and inadvertently threw out $5,000 in cash he had wrapped in aluminum foil and stashed in the freezer. (Luckily, they later retrieved it.)

headline: President Biden’s Action on Immigration Is a Tough Sell in This Border County
abstract: Republicans and Democrats alike in Cochise County, Ariz., a place where many have long felt their needs are ignored, eyed the executive order with skepticism.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats and Republicans in Washington negotiated legislation to overhaul the asylum system and tighten border security earlier this year, many in Cochise County, Ariz., a conservative stronghold, held their breath.

headline: Can Big Art Make It in Las Vegas? Urs Fischer Weighs In.
abstract: The desert entertainment mecca is “artificial, but in a good way,” says the Swiss artist. His 46-foot-tall, gold-leaf sculpture is the city’s latest addition.
lead_paragraph: The Swiss artist Urs Fischer suggests beginning our day together with coffee in the Village. Not the Manhattan neighborhood of Greenwich Village — on the edge of which he lived from the mid aughts until several years ago, commuting to giant studios in Red Hook, Brooklyn, and Long Island City, Queens — though if you squint, there’s a resemblance to its earlier era: the maze of disorienting lanes, lots of cobblestone (sort of), neon-marqueed Italian-suggestive stands that sell iced lattes (watery) and cannolis (soggy).

headline: I’m Choking on My Neighbor’s Smoke. But She’s Rent-Stabilized. What Can I Do?
abstract: When it comes to rent-stabilized tenants, legal claims against co-ops are tricky. Ultimately, it’s the apartment’s owner who must take action.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m a shareholder in a large co-op in Queens. The lease prohibits odors from traveling from one apartment to another, but doesn’t include a smoke-free policy. My elderly downstairs neighbor lives in a rent-stabilized apartment and can no longer go outside to smoke. My bedroom smells like her ashtray, and I have been sleeping on my couch. The co-op’s management has sent her notice after notice for four years, and recently reached a settlement with her after threatening to bring an eviction case. They agreed that the owner of her apartment would install a commercial smoke abatement machine, but it’s been 10 weeks with no installation. What do I do now?

headline: The British Aren’t Coming. They’re Here.
abstract: As a historic presidential election looms, several of America’s largest and most powerful newsrooms are now being led by English journalists. Why?
lead_paragraph: The news business is in upheaval. A presidential election is barreling down the pike. Facing financial challenges and political division, several of America’s largest news organizations have turned over the reins to editors who prize relentless reporting on a budget.

headline: The Best Way to Get a Refund When Your Airline’s Wi-Fi Is Terrible
abstract: We compiled shortcuts and links for every big U.S. carrier — and some little-known tips that should make it easier to get your money back.
lead_paragraph: When an airline sells you a service, you should be able to receive a refund if it doesn’t deliver. But when is it not worth your time to even bother asking for one?

headline: Pride Month 2024: An Abundance of Theater of All Stripes
abstract: From Broadway to the city’s smaller stages, a flurry of shows with wide-ranging appeal, familiar faces and rising talent.
lead_paragraph: American theater has long been more welcoming to queer lives and stories than Hollywood has been, so the abundance of shows during Pride Month is unsurprising. It’s also overwhelming — there is just so much to see.

headline: A Small American Bomb Killing Palestinians by the Dozen in Gaza
abstract: The GBU-39 is increasingly the weapon of choice for the Israeli military and was used in two recent mass-casualty events.
lead_paragraph: An American-made, precision guided bomb that homes in on specific targets and, ideally, limits civilian casualties, was used in airstrikes in Gaza that killed dozens of Palestinians, including women and children.

headline: Who Is a ‘Rodent Man’?
abstract: A new term has cropped up to describe the faces of certain Hollywood actors, prompting many conversations — especially among the Styles team.
lead_paragraph: “Rodent Men”: What are they? Tiny men? Men who eat garbage? Some kind of furry science experiment gone wrong?

headline: The Women Rethinking Marriage and Family Life Because of Miranda July
abstract: The author’s new novel, “All Fours,” has spurred a whisper network of women fantasizing about desire and freedom.
lead_paragraph: It’s the talk of every group text — at least every group text composed of women over 40.

headline: The Darker Side of Julia Louis-Dreyfus
abstract: The actress is taking on serious roles, trying to overcome self-doubt and sharing more about her personal life — but she’s not done being funny.
lead_paragraph: At some point in almost every performance she gives, Julia Louis-Dreyfus has this look. If you’ve watched “Seinfeld,” “The New Adventures of Old Christine” or “Veep,” you know it — the perfect mix of irritation and defiance. As if she were saying, Try me.

headline: Stand-Up Comics Are Divided Over the Growing Presence of Crowd Work
abstract: Crowd work has grown more common, with some comedians now focusing their acts on it and sharing clips of their exchanges with audience members. But some comics say it takes away from the craft.
lead_paragraph: After the comedian Joel Kim Booster performed recently at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., he posted about an interaction he had with a heckler, who was standing up and motioning a thumbs-down at Booster.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,086, June 9, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 364, June 9, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Did Politicians Break the Law by Aiding Foreign Influence Efforts?
abstract: A report by a parliamentary committee said that politicians, who were not named, had helped China, India and other countries meddle in Canadian politics.
lead_paragraph: After years of toiling away little noticed, the awkwardly named National Security and Intelligence Committee of Parliamentarians certainly caught the nation’s attention this week. The committee, which reviewed 4,000 classified documents totaling 32,000 pages and held closed briefings with officials, found that some federal politicians had been “‘semi-witting or witting’ participants in the efforts of foreign states to interfere in our politics.”

headline: Come Retribution
abstract: Donald Trump has a plan for his second term: retribution. We check in with the people who’ve crossed him to hear how they feel about that.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: How Will Employers Regard Today’s Student Activists?
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Pamela Paul about college protesters’ job prospects and future careers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: This Glorious Celebration Shows What Border Communities Can Be
abstract: As the country becomes increasingly divided, Brownsville comes together.
lead_paragraph: The sky was muddy gray when I arrived at the Sams Memorial Stadium parking lot on a cool February afternoon. As soon as I parked, a school police officer appeared in a golf cart to rush me to the front of the parade line. I clambered aboard, one hand holding my large white Mexican sombrero rimmed with gold embroidered roses, the other scooping my thick, long skirt.

headline: My Mom Had Alzheimer’s. Now I Do Too, but I Learned From Her Not to Despair.
abstract: A man reflects on his mother’s life with Alzheimer’s and what it has taught him as he faces his own diagnosis with the disease.
lead_paragraph: My mother spent the last three decades of her life afflicted by the loss of memory and control that comes with Alzheimer’s. I remember her panicking in the night, waking my father at 3 a.m. to search for her long-dead mother. He would often give in and drive her through the deserted streets of Los Angeles to lull her back to sleep.

headline: An Object Lesson From Covid on How to Destroy Public Trust
abstract: Officials should have told us what they knew, or at least leveled with us about what they didn’t know.
lead_paragraph: Big chunks of the history of the Covid pandemic were rewritten over the last month or so in a way that will have terrible consequences for many years to come.

headline: The Pandas Are Back
abstract: The return of pandas to our zoos means more to Americans than just a burst of fleeting joy.
lead_paragraph: Our interest in pandas has always brought out the best and the worst in us.

headline: Trump’s Most Dangerous Gift
abstract: For months now, he has been spinning his tale of tyranny and martyrdom, styling himself as the victim of an administration that plays dirty.
lead_paragraph: When a Manhattan jury found Donald J. Trump guilty, it should have sent shock waves through the nation. Yet, though the trial and conviction of a former president was unprecedented in American history, it seems most people couldn’t have cared less. As Michelle Goldberg recently noted, only 16 percent of respondents to a Yahoo News/YouGov poll said they had followed the first few weeks of the trial very closely, and when asked how they felt, many replied, “bored.”

headline: Why Biden Is Right to Curb Immigration
abstract: His executive order limiting asylum seekers may be political, but that doesn’t mean it’s wrong.
lead_paragraph: Many of us liberals now find ourselves in an awkward spot on immigration.

headline: Blank Screen
abstract: If you’ve been having trouble finding a show to watch, you’re not alone.
lead_paragraph: Blame it on the better weather and its privileging of being out over staying in, but I’ve been having a hard time getting into any streaming entertainment these days. I’ve started dozens of shows and abandoned them after an episode or two, never to return. Are recent shows just poor matches for my taste? Has TV become boringly mid, as my colleague James Poniewozik described? Or perhaps it’s more serious: Have I finally and irretrievably reached the outer limits of my own attention span?

headline: Scare Easily? These 2 Thrillers Are Worth It.
abstract: Complicated sisters; messy neighbors.
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Tesla Shareholders Will Vote on Elon Musk’s Big Payday. What Happens Then?
abstract: The company has lobbied to reinstate the package awarded to Musk six years ago — now worth about $56 billion — after a Delaware judge voided it.
lead_paragraph: After months of fighting over a pay package promised to Elon Musk six years ago — one that included stock grants now worth about $56 billion — matters are finally coming to a head.

headline: What Makes Katie Ledecky Swim?
abstract: As she prepares for the Paris Games, the seven-time Olympic gold medalist talks about the doping accusations against her competitors and how she stays focused while swimming 1,900 miles a year.
lead_paragraph: Long before Katie Ledecky was collecting gold medals and setting world records, she seemed nonchalant about making it across the pool.

headline: Biden’s Border Crackdown Could Disproportionately Affect Families
abstract: Parents with children represent 40 percent of migrants who crossed the southern border this year. Now, they will be turned back within days, according to a memo obtained by The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: A new border crackdown unveiled by the Biden administration this week is likely to disproportionately affect families, whose soaring numbers in the last decade have drastically changed the profile of the population crossing the southern border.

headline: Israeli news outlets break the quiet of the Sabbath to cover the release of four hostages.
abstract: The main Israeli television stations have switched to live coverage of the hostage rescue, breaking the customary quiet and prerecorded programming typical of the Sabbath.
lead_paragraph: The main Israeli television stations have switched to live coverage of the hostage rescue, breaking the customary quiet and prerecorded programming typical of the Sabbath.

headline: The last functioning hospitals in Gaza may soon be out of service, the health ministry warns.
abstract: The few overwhelmed hospitals still functioning across the Gaza Strip could be completely out of service if diesel generators needed to keep lights on and to run lifesaving medical equipment are not replaced or maintained soon, the Gaza Health Ministry warned on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The few overwhelmed hospitals still functioning across the Gaza Strip could be completely out of service if diesel generators needed to keep lights on and to run lifesaving medical equipment are not replaced or maintained soon, the Gaza Health Ministry warned on Saturday.

headline: As Trump Rallies in the Southwest, Extreme Heat Threatens MAGA Faithful
abstract: Eleven people were treated for heat exhaustion at a recent Trump event in Phoenix. Temperatures for a rally in Las Vegas on Sunday are expected to approach 105 degrees.
lead_paragraph: Political campaigns do their best to control as much as possible: their candidate, their messaging, their surrogates and their schedules. But what to do about the weather?

headline: Who Are the Four Hostages Rescued in Gaza?
abstract: Since the Hamas-led terrorist attack on Oct. 7, Israel has freed only a small number of hostages through military force.
lead_paragraph: Four hostages abducted from the Nova music festival and held by militants in Gaza for the last eight months were rescued by Israeli forces on Saturday.

headline: Spiced Chicken and Rice, Extremely Nice
abstract: And extremely fragrant and flavorful, thanks to turmeric and cardamom, nutty roasted pistachios and sweet golden raisins.
lead_paragraph: I will always, in any season, make a chicken-and-rice dish. It’s my favorite protein combined with my favorite carb, and I love it in any iteration: Hainanese chicken rice, arroz chaufa, arroz con pollo, iwuk edesi, chicken perloo, chicken cook-up rice, chicken doria, oyakodon. I don’t care if it’s hot outside; all are worth mopping my brow and doing that thing where I whap the sides of my T-shirt away from my body.

headline: A Gazan health official says scores are dead as Israel carries out intense bombardments.
abstract: Residents in central Gaza reported intense bombardments as Israel carried out an operation to rescue four hostages held since Oct. 7.
lead_paragraph: Residents in central Gaza reported intense bombardments as Israel carried out an operation to rescue four hostages held since Oct. 7.

headline: Jürgen Moltmann, Theologian Who Confronted Auschwitz, Is Dead at 98
abstract: He drew on his experiences as a German soldier during World War II to construct transformative ideas about God, Jesus and salvation.
lead_paragraph: Jürgen Moltmann, who drew on his searing experiences as a German soldier during World War II to construct transformative ideas about God, Jesus and salvation in a fallen world, making him one of the leading Protestant theologians of the 20th century, died on Monday at his home in Tübingen, in southwest Germany. He was 98.

headline: No, Byron Donalds, Jim Crow Didn’t Create Stronger Black Families
abstract: The era of Southern apartheid is inseparable from poverty, exploitation and violence.
lead_paragraph: At an event in Philadelphia promoting Donald Trump and the Republican Party on Tuesday, Representative Byron Donalds of Florida made the eyebrow-raising assertion that Black families were stronger, and Black people more conservative, under the Jim Crow regimes of the former Confederate states.

headline: U.S. Intelligence Helped Israel Rescue Four Hostages in Gaza
abstract: Intelligence collection and analysis teams from the U.S. and the U.K. have been in Israel throughout the war.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. provided intelligence on the hostages before Israel’s successful rescue operation Saturday, according to American and Israeli officials briefed on the assistance.

headline: Biden and Macron Talk Togetherness, With No Mention of Discord Over Gaza
abstract: The two presidents, in a brief appearance before reporters, declined to take questions, in a departure from tradition.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and President Emmanuel Macron of France stressed on Saturday how much they agreed with each other about world affairs, including the war in Ukraine, even as their countries have expressed sharply different views of the fighting in Gaza between Israel and Hamas.

headline: Saratoga’s Crowning Moment
abstract: The Belmont Stakes arrives at Saratoga Race Course.
lead_paragraph: Summer at the Spa — a ritual nearly 200 years strong — started early in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., with the third leg of the Triple Crown, the Belmont Stakes, being held on Saturday for the first time at Saratoga Race Course, a revered relic where the elite and otherwise mingle, but the horses rule.

headline: Scores Killed in Central Gaza After Israeli Strikes, Hospital Officials Say
abstract: Video footage showed people running for cover as a powerful airstrike exploded near them. The attack appeared to have hit a market.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli operation to rescue four hostages in the town of Nuseirat in central Gaza on Saturday unleashed a heavy aerial bombardment and ground operations that killed more than 200 people, according to two hospital officials in the area.

headline: Howard University Votes to Revoke Sean Combs’s Honorary Degree
abstract: In a unanimous decision, the university’s board of trustees also moved to disband a scholarship in Mr. Combs’s name amid investigations into abuse allegations.
lead_paragraph: Howard University announced on Friday that it would revoke an honorary degree that was awarded to the hip-hop mogul Sean “Diddy” Combs in 2014. The decision comes in the wake of Mr. Combs’s admission that he physically abused a former girlfriend, in addition to a slew of other allegations of abuse that have surfaced in recent months.

headline: In Final Analysis, N.Y. Legislative Session Is Defined by Its Omissions
abstract: The State Legislature passed a climate bill that would force polluters to pay into a “cost recovery” fund, but the focus of the session’s last days was on the collapse of congestion pricing.
lead_paragraph: After a final all-night session, the New York State Legislature ended its yearly business on Saturday morning, capping a nearly six-month slog that, in the end, was defined by what failed to happen.

headline: Here’s How Israel’s Mission to Rescue Four Hostages Unfolded
abstract: The operation required weeks of planning and received the final go-ahead just a few minutes before it began, according to Israeli officials.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military’s mission to rescue four hostages was a rare operation that required weeks of planning, and was given the final go-ahead just a few minutes before it commenced on Saturday morning, according to Israeli officials.

headline: ‘Cheaters Don’t Like Getting Caught’: Harris Blasts Trump in Michigan
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris argues that Donald J. Trump’s guilty verdict should disqualify him for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: In one of her first campaign appearances since former President Donald J. Trump was convicted of falsifying business records, Vice President Kamala Harris sharply criticized him on Saturday as a “cheater” who believes himself above the law and argued that he should be disqualified for the presidency.

headline: House Ethics Panel Looks Into Nancy Mace’s Use of Reimbursement Program
abstract: The committee will decide whether to open a formal investigation into expense reports filed by the South Carolina Republican.
lead_paragraph: The House Ethics Committee has begun reviewing Representative Nancy Mace’s use of a reimbursement program for lodging and other expenses of Congress members working in Washington, according to a committee member familiar with the preliminary inquiry.

headline: Sigmund Rolat, Who Used His Wealth to Memorialize Polish Jews, Dies at 93
abstract: A Holocaust survivor and a shipping financier, he returned to his home country, where his parents and brother perished, to help build a museum and other memorials.
lead_paragraph: Sigmund Rolat, a Polish Holocaust survivor who tapped the wealth he accumulated as a businessman in the United States to support cultural projects in his homeland, most notably a museum devoted to the history of Jews in Poland that stands on the grounds of the Warsaw Ghetto, died on May 19 at his home in Alpine, N.J. He was 93.

headline: Israel Rescues 4 Hostages in Assault That Killed Scores of Gazans
abstract: The news was met with jubilation in Israel, where tensions over the hostages’ safety have been rising in recent months.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers and special operations police rescued four hostages from Gaza on Saturday amid a heavy air and ground assault and flew them back to Israel by helicopter to be reunited with their families. The news was met with jubilation in Israel, where anxieties over the fate of the roughly 120 remaining captives have been rising after eight months of war.

headline: What to Know About the Hostages Still in Gaza
abstract: Israel’s military announced it had rescued four hostages who were held in Gaza. There are roughly 120 captives still in the enclave.
lead_paragraph: Israelis briefly breathed a collective sigh of relief on Saturday, when the military announced it had rescued four hostages who were held in Gaza for eight months after being captured in the Oct. 7 attack led by Hamas.

headline: Swimmer Trying to Make Olympic History Is Left Off the U.S. Team
abstract: When the sport of artistic swimming, formerly synchronized swimming, announced it would allow men to compete in the Paris Games, Bill May saw his chance. But the U.S. team chose only women.
lead_paragraph: Bill May, the 45-year-old artistic swimmer who was vying for a chance to be the first man to compete in the sport at the Olympics this summer, did not make the U.S. team’s final roster, the team announced on Saturday.

headline: Quiet Time
abstract: Zachary Schiff’s debut puzzle moves softly, but keeps us in suspense.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Days After Border Closes for Most Migrants, Manageable Crowds but More Anxiety
abstract: Shelters along the border were quieter on Friday and Saturday compared with previous months, but many hoping to cross into the U.S. felt stranded and fearful.
lead_paragraph: On a hot and humid morning in the Mexican border city of Reynosa, less than a mile from the Rio Grande, one question seemed to linger in the minds of hundreds of people who had arrived Saturday at a shelter for migrants.

headline: Stanford Becomes Latest School to Reinstate Test Scores Requirement
abstract: The university joins a small but growing number of elite colleges requiring SAT or ACT scores in applications once again.
lead_paragraph: Stanford University announced Friday that it was reinstating the requirement for standardized test scores in undergraduate admissions, becoming the latest of a small but growing number of elite colleges to go back to the practice after abandoning it during the pandemic.

headline: Israel Rescues Four Hostages in Operation That Palestinian Officials Say Killed Scores
abstract: Four hostages were rescued by Israeli forces after being held in Gaza since the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7, the Israeli military said. The rescue operation in the town of Nuseirat in central Gaza unleashed a heavy aerial bombardment that killed scores, according to hospital officials in the area.
lead_paragraph: Four hostages were rescued by Israeli forces after being held in Gaza since the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7, the Israeli military said. The rescue operation in the town of Nuseirat in central Gaza unleashed a heavy aerial bombardment that killed scores, according to hospital officials in the area.

headline: Kia Recalls Telluride SUV Over Fire Risk; Urging Owners to Park Outside
abstract: About 460,000 vehicles could be affected by the recall, which stems from a problem with the vehicle’s front power seat motor.
lead_paragraph: The automotive company Kia issued a recall on Friday of certain Telluride SUVs from the years 2020 through 2024 and urged the owners of the vehicles to park outside and away from structures because of a fire risk, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said.

headline: Protest Against Gaza War Draws Thousands to the White House
abstract: The demonstration included ringing the White House grounds with a red banner showing the names of the more than 36,000 Palestinians killed during the war.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: This article was updated on June 10 with a statement from the National Park Service.

headline: French-American Friendship in Four Courses
abstract: Under Emmanuel Macron, “culinary diplomacy” is back on the menu, with a lavish dinner fortifying an old alliance at a tense historical moment.
lead_paragraph: Beneath the crystal chandeliers of the gilded reception hall of the Élysée Palace, opened in 1889 with a party for 8,000 people, President Emmanuel Macron of France hosted President Biden on Saturday night at a state dinner intended to celebrate a very old alliance and demonstrate that the bond is greater than its intermittent frictions.

headline: Quote of the Day: A County Clerk’s Lonely Quest vs. Die-Hard Election Deniers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve given them every fact and document known to mankind, and none of it matters.”

headline: The E.U. Votes: What We’re Watching For
abstract: The main things to know as voters in 27 countries head to the ballot box to shape the next five years of European Union policies.
lead_paragraph: More than 300 million voters in the 27 countries that make up the European Union are heading to the polls to elect the new European Parliament’s 720 members. But in casting their ballots they’ll do more than that.

headline: A Promise to Grads With ‘No Promise’
abstract: No matter what seemingly hopeless mess you have made, everything can still work out.
lead_paragraph: It’s high school graduation season. Time to cheer the teenage achievers (especially the overachievers) and send them off to campus adventures and incipient adulthood. This year, though, I want to talk about the other graduates. The ones without honor society stoles or academic medals or college plans. The ones who still don’t know what they could or should do, who taste a tinny dread when the band strikes up “Pomp and Circumstance.”

headline: The Unabomber, Me and the Poisoned Myth of the American West
abstract: The Unabomber personified how we use the West as a mirror for the dark, untamed aspects of our national character.
lead_paragraph: On June 10 of last year, Ted Kaczynski, the homegrown terrorist known as the Unabomber, was found dead in his cell in Butner, N.C. Mr. Kaczynski, who had spent 25 years in federal prison for murdering three people and injuring 23 others with mail bombs, had reportedly died by suicide.

headline: Modi, Striking a Modest Tone, Is Sworn In for a Third Term
abstract: Forced into a coalition government, the prime minister faces the challenge of governing differently than he has so far in two decades in elected office.
lead_paragraph: As a humbled Narendra Modi was sworn in on Sunday for a third term as India’s prime minister, the political air in New Delhi appeared transformed.

headline: Corrections: June 9, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article this weekend about a Metropolitan Transportation Authority program that brings talented musicians to perform in the New York City subway system misstates the Iain S. Forrest’s stage name. It is Eyeglasses, not Eyeglass.

headline: Chet Walker, N.B.A. Champion and Movie Producer, Dies at 84
abstract: A vital member of the 1966-67 champion Philadelphia 76ers, he later produced a TV series based on the life on the point guard Isiah Thomas’s mother.
lead_paragraph: Chet Walker, one of the N.B.A.’s most understated stars of its developmental decades, who was a vital member of the 1966-67 champion Philadelphia 76ers and who later became an Emmy Award-winning movie producer, died on Saturday in Long Beach, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Where O.J. Simpson Found Acceptance, No Questions Asked
abstract: Las Vegas became a refuge that many believe Mr. Simpson did not deserve in his final years. There, he found an unlikely group of friends.
lead_paragraph: O.J. Simpson, even in his final years, was somewhat of a spectacle.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: This Old-School Pizzeria Stays Open by Playing Itself on TV
abstract: Sam’s Restaurant in Cobble Hill, run by 67-year-old Louis Migliaccio, has long been a go-to spot for film crews looking for a bit of Brooklyn charm.
lead_paragraph: Sam’s Restaurant, a 94-year-old red-sauce joint in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, was uncharacteristically full of life. Serious-looking women in peacoats and laminated badges typed frantically on laptops. Carhartt-clad carpenters straightened picture frames and other period-appropriate props, all jangling carabiners and nervous energy. For the past week, dozens of people had been working to turn Sam’s into a believable replica of an Italian American social club during the Great Depression.

headline: ‘Dragging a Small Roller Bag, I Found My Way to the Correct Subway Line’
abstract: A solo trip to the Upper West Side, a bonus at the shoe-repair place and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: How Governor Hochul Decided to Kill Congestion Pricing in New York
abstract: Although the governor said she long feared the program might hurt New York City’s economy, she never disclosed her reservations, leaving some feeling betrayed.
lead_paragraph: In the last few months, Gov. Kathy Hochul has privately exchanged anxieties about moving forward on congestion pricing with business leaders, political advisers and, in her telling, a great number of ordinary New Yorkers in diners.

headline: A Kinetic Piece of Art Will Stop Moving
abstract: “Moveable Type,” in which screens flash fragments from The Times’s news report, has been in the lobby of the company’s headquarters since 2007.
lead_paragraph: The Museum at The Times is a repository of artworks, furnishings, windows and even gargoyles that have adorned various headquarters of The New York Times.

headline: British TV Doctor Michael Mosley Found Dead in Greece
abstract: Dr. Mosley, a British medical journalist and documentary maker, disappeared last week while on a trip on the Greek island of Symi.
lead_paragraph: After a four-day search, Greek officials said on Sunday they had found the body of Dr. Michael Mosley, a British medical journalist and documentary maker who disappeared last week while on a trip on the Greek island of Symi.

headline: Adria Arjona on ‘Hit Man’ and How the Production Surprised Her
abstract: The actress, who stars with Glen Powell, said that with the contract-killer movie, her ideas were finally valued in a writers’ room.
lead_paragraph: Some spoilers follow.

headline: Ukrainian Activist Traces Roots of War in ‘Centuries of Russian Colonization’
abstract: One Ukrainian researcher and podcaster is a leading voice in efforts to rethink Ukrainian-Russian relations through the prism of colonialism.
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon in Kyiv, a professor of literature and a stand-up comedian ​got together to talk about Russian colonialism, a subject that has become ​a preoccupation among Ukrainian activists, cultural figures and bookstore owners.

headline: Is Your Driving Being Secretly Scored?
abstract: The insurance industry, hungry for insights into how people drive, has turned to automakers and smartphone apps like Life360.
lead_paragraph: You know you have a credit score. Did you know that you might also have a driver score?

headline: What Retail Apocalypse? Shopping Centers Are Making a Comeback.
abstract: Vacancy is the lowest it has been in two decades, at 5.4 percent, according to a recent report. The properties are thriving even as retailers like Macy’s and Express shutter many stores.
lead_paragraph: Shopping center landlords have found themselves in a wholly unfamiliar position: For the first time in 20 years, demand for retail space outstrips supply.

headline: Reality TV or Court TV? Lawsuits Test Limits of Outrageous Behavior
abstract: Popular shows including “Love Is Blind,” the “Real Housewives” universe and “Vanderpump Rules” are being challenged in court amid a changing legal landscape.
lead_paragraph: Tran Dang sued the makers of the Netflix dating series “Love Is Blind” over allegations of “false imprisonment,” saying it confined her and the rest of the cast to hotel rooms without their phones. She also accused a fellow cast member of groping her and exposing himself.

headline: Sign Right Here: The Parents Pledging to Keep Kids Phone-Free
abstract: By committing not to give their children smartphones until an agreed-upon age, parents are hoping for strength in numbers when schoolyard pressure starts to build.
lead_paragraph: Kiley DeMarco recently attended Safety Night at her children’s public elementary school on Long Island. As she walked around different booths learning about how to protect her children from accidentally taking a cannabis gummy, about a local violence-prevention program, about how police officers would respond to an emergency on campus, one station caught her eye: A parent was asking other parents to take a pledge not to give their children smartphones until the end of eighth grade.

headline: Dogged by Bad Health and Bad Reviews, Darwin Needed Friends Like These
abstract: In a new book, the medical historian Howard Markel homes in on Darwin’s physical and emotional travails — and the colleagues who rallied to his cause.
lead_paragraph: Charles Darwin was not a well man. He spent most of his adult life as a recluse, suffering from a whole host of symptoms: boils, rashes, ulcers, headaches, and bouts of vomiting and gas so painful that they often prostrated him. Modern doctors have retroactively diagnosed him with more than a dozen different ailments — lupus, narcolepsy, gout, pigeon allergies, etc. — without reaching any consensus. But one thing is clear: Darwin’s ups and downs correlated strongly with the stresses and joys of his scientific work, especially “On the Origin of Species,” which at different times proved both a soothing panacea and a veritable poison.

headline: Growing Up With Joan Didion and Dominick Dunne, in the Land of Make-Believe
abstract: In his memoir “The Friday Afternoon Club,” the Hollywood hyphenate Griffin Dunne, best known for his role in Martin Scorsese’s “After Hours,” recounts his privileged upbringing.
lead_paragraph: Dominick Dunne’s byline was one of the last to sell magazines. Reporting with elegance and tenacity on the trials of O.J. Simpson, the Menendez brothers and two Kennedy cousins for Vanity Fair in the go-go ’90s and early ’00s, Dunne was, as his son Griffin writes in a warm and perceptive new memoir, “an Irish terrier in a Turnbull & Asser shirt.”

headline: 25 Years Ago, ‘Hannibal’ Marked the Rise of a New Kind of Blockbuster
abstract: Thomas Harris’s book came at a pivotal moment: One of the last smash hits of the ’90s, it was also one of the first big releases of the hyper-speed, hyper-opinionated internet era.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1999, a veteran New York book editor got a surprise call from one of the world’s most elusive literary superstars: Thomas Harris.

headline: Biden Loves to Tell Tall Tales. We Cut Them Down to Size.
abstract: By President Biden’s account, he was a fierce civil rights activist in his youth, had an uncle who fell prey to cannibals and used to drive an 18-wheeler.
lead_paragraph: In President Biden’s telling, he was a teenage civil rights activist, a former trucker, the first in his family to go to college and the nephew of a cannibalism victim.

headline: For Trump, Doug Burgum Emerges as a Safe Option, and a Wild Card
abstract: Mr. Burgum, North Dakota’s governor, is a prime contender in the former president’s search for a running mate, but he remains untested on the national stage.
lead_paragraph: After taking his software company public in 1997, Doug Burgum gathered a few colleagues in his office and swore them to secrecy.

headline: Where New Tent Cities Are Rising in Central Gaza
abstract: Satellite imagery shows a dense community of tents going up in central Gaza, where Palestinians are once again seeking shelter from the fighting.
lead_paragraph: Satellite imagery shows a dense community of tents going up in central Gaza, where Palestinians are once again seeking shelter from the fighting.

headline: ‘Bad Boys’ Ticket Buyers Toss Will Smith a Career Lifeline
abstract: Mr. Smith’s first wide-release film since he slapped Chris Rock at the Oscars two years ago arrived to a hefty $56 million at the North American box office.
lead_paragraph: Moviegoers sent Will Smith a clear message over the weekend: We forgive you.

headline: Trump’s Energy Guy Talked a Green Game but Now Sells Big Oil Priorities
abstract: Doug Burgum, the Republican governor of North Dakota, has stepped into the spotlight as a cheerleader for oil and former President Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Doug Burgum, the Republican governor of North Dakota, has emerged as a key adviser on energy issues in Donald J. Trump’s campaign to retake the White House, acting as a liaison between Mr. Trump and the oil billionaires whom the former president has encouraged to fund his presidential bid.

headline: What’s Behind TikTok’s Beef With Chipotle?
abstract: A series of popular videos on the platform encourage users to protest the restaurant chain’s portion sizes by walking out without paying or filming workers.
lead_paragraph: When Chipotle Mexican Grill started rolling out across the United States over two decades ago, food writers were astonished at the restaurant’s portion sizes.

headline: Hey, Siri! Let’s Talk About How Apple Is Giving You an A.I. Makeover.
abstract: Apple, a latecomer to artificial intelligence, has struck a deal with OpenAI and developed tools to improve its Siri voice assistant, which it is set to showcase on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Each June, Apple unveils its newest software features for the iPhone at its futuristic Silicon Valley campus. But at its annual developer conference on Monday, the company will shine a spotlight on a feature that isn’t new: Siri, its talking assistant, which has been around for more than a decade.

headline: Personal Conflicts, Even Violence, Are Not Uncommon in Long-Term Care
abstract: Arguments, verbal abuse and aggression are not unusual in elder care settings. Better staffing and training can ease the tensions, experts say.
lead_paragraph: At an assisted living facility in New York State, a small crowd had gathered at the dining room entrance at lunchtime, waiting for the doors to open. As a researcher observed, one woman, growing tired and frustrated, asked the man in front of her to move; he didn’t appear to hear.

headline: Now Playing: The Press Tour (Shh, It’s Better Than the Movie)
abstract: For Jennifer Lopez, Sterling K. Brown, Dakota Johnson and others, the standard publicity push isn’t so standard anymore.
lead_paragraph: In the 1999 rom-com “Notting Hill,” the sheepish bookseller played by Hugh Grant goes to a hotel expecting a date with the megawatt star played by Julia Roberts. He is surprised to find he has arrived at a press junket and looks adorably flustered as he’s shuffled from room to room, pretending to be a reporter from Horse & Hound to interview the stars of her space movie.

headline: The audacious operation did little to resolve the many challenges facing Israel’s government.
abstract: For months, Israelis had heard only about hostages being killed or declared dead in Gaza. The “lucky” families were those whose loved ones’ remains were retrieved by soldiers, at great risk, and brought home to Israel for burial.
lead_paragraph: For months, Israelis had heard only about hostages being killed or declared dead in Gaza. The “lucky” families were those whose loved ones’ remains were retrieved by soldiers, at great risk, and brought home to Israel for burial.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,087, June 10, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 365, June 10, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Day My Old Church Canceled Me Was a Very Sad Day
abstract: There is a difference between peace and capitulation.
lead_paragraph: This week, the leaders of the Presbyterian Church in America are gathering in Richmond, Va., for their annual General Assembly. The Presbyterian Church in America is a small, theologically conservative Christian denomination that was my family’s church home for more than 15 years.

headline: Mountain Landslide Destroys Section of Highway to Jackson, Wyo.
abstract: The road, linking Idaho with Wyoming, is a key route to Jackson Hole, a tourism hub. It had been closed to traffic before the landslide.
lead_paragraph: A landslide in the Teton mountains destroyed part of a highway that links Idaho with Jackson, Wyo., forcing the authorities to close the road indefinitely on Saturday just as the area was entering its summer tourism season.

headline: Your Driving, Tracked
abstract: We explore the apps that are quietly tracking drivers’ habits.
lead_paragraph: You know you have a credit score. Did you know that you might also have a driving score?

headline: Our Fathers Marched With King. Here’s What They Would Say to Activists Today.
abstract: We are turning to the lessons of the interfaith leaders of the civil rights movement.
lead_paragraph: On March 9, 1965, at the foot of the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala., the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. chose two of the hundreds of men of faith present that day to deliver the prayer that began the march to Montgomery: the Rev. Dr. Ralph David Abernathy Sr., his dear friend and closest associate during the American civil rights movement of the 1950s and ’60s, and Rabbi Israel Dresner, one of Dr. King’s most trusted allies in the Jewish community.

headline: European Union 2024 Parliament Election Results
abstract: See totals and national results from the 2024 E.U. parliament elections.
lead_paragraph: See totals and national results from the 2024 E.U. parliament elections.

headline: Make Maangchi’s Bulgogi
abstract: I especially like it on Sundays, when I can slice the meat in the morning after breakfast and keep it in the garlicky, pear-sweetened soy marinade all day.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. I once spent an excellent summer day cooking in a Montauk condominium with the Korean cooking star Maangchi, who had rented the place for a vacation but still found time to help me understand the intricacies of cheese buldak, or fire chicken.

headline: ‘Music Speaks to Some Deep Need Among Humans’
abstract: Responses to a Science Times article about the evolution of music across cultures. Also: Accepting election results; honoring the dead; fear of crime.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Butterfly or Firefly: What’s Your Friendship Style?
abstract: We each connect with our social networks in our own way, though there are some universal threads. Take this quiz to find your friendship style, and sign up for Well’s 5-Day Friendship Challenge.
lead_paragraph: We each connect with our social networks in our own way, though there are some universal threads. Take this quiz to find your friendship style, and sign up for Well’s 5-Day Friendship Challenge.

headline: Israel’s Euphoria Over Hostage Rescue May Be Fleeting
