abstract: The operation conducted by Israel’s military to free four hostages resulted in a high death toll among Palestinians and has not resolved the challenges facing the Israeli government.
lead_paragraph: For months, Israelis had heard only about hostages being killed or declared dead in Gaza. The “lucky” families were those whose loved ones’ remains were retrieved by soldiers, at great risk, and brought home to Israel for burial.

headline: Gazans Recall ‘Unimaginably Intense’ Israeli Bombing Around Hostage Raid
abstract: As the Israeli military freed four hostages, the surrounding area came under heavy fire, generating chaos and panic, eyewitnesses said.
lead_paragraph: A day after the Israeli military rescued four hostages held by Hamas militants in Nuseirat, Gazans described an intense bombardment during the raid, followed by chaos in the streets from an operation that killed and wounded scores of Palestinians.

headline: After 50 Years and a Tornado Warning, an Oklahoma High School Class Graduates
abstract: In 1974, a high school commencement ceremony in Moore, Okla., was interrupted by a tornado warning. Decades later, students finally turned their tassels.
lead_paragraph: Members of the high school graduating class of 1974 in Moore, Okla., had taken their seats in the football stadium under darkening skies.

headline: Iran Names Six Candidates for President, Including Parliament Speaker
abstract: The June 28 election to succeed President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash last month, comes as the country faces acute domestic and international challenges.
lead_paragraph: Six candidates, including the speaker of Parliament, have been approved to run in the Iranian election this month to succeed President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash last month. The vote comes at a moment when the country faces acute domestic and international challenges, state media said on Sunday.

headline: Biden Visits a Military Cemetery in France That Trump Once Snubbed
abstract: President Biden wrapped up a five-day trip by visiting a cemetery for American soldiers killed in World War I that Donald J. Trump skipped during a similar trip in 2018.
lead_paragraph: There is trolling. And then there is presidential trolling.

headline: What Made New York Great? Leadership. Where Is It Now?
abstract: The city was built on bold ideas. Suddenly Gov. Kathy Hochul paused a game-changing plan to fight congestion. Can we still do big things in a polarized moment?
lead_paragraph: Have we lost the ability to do big things?

headline: Gantz Quits Israel Government in Dispute With Netanyahu Over Gaza
abstract: The move, though unlikely to force Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu from office, exposed the fractures within Israel’s leadership eight months into the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli politician Benny Gantz, a key member of the country’s war cabinet, quit the government on Sunday over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s handling of the war in Gaza.

headline: Suspect in Sacramento Mass Shooting in 2022 Dies in County Jail
abstract: The suspect, who faced murder and firearms charges in connection to the shooting that killed six people, was found unresponsive at the jail. Details of his death were unclear.
lead_paragraph: One of the suspects in the mass shooting in Sacramento that killed six people in 2022 died in a county jail on Saturday, his lawyer said.

headline: Review: ‘Inside Light’ Gives a Taste of Stockhausen’s Opera Epic
abstract: At the Park Avenue Armory, a five-hour selection of pieces from the 29-hour “Licht” cycle is best appreciated as a marathon performance.
lead_paragraph: How often can you describe five hours of excerpts from an opera as a drop in the bucket of the whole?

headline: In E.U. Elections, the Center Holds, but the Far Right Still Wreaks Havoc
abstract: Voters in the European Union delivered strong gains to anti-immigrant, nationalist parties, challenging leaders in Germany and France, and unsettling the political establishment.
lead_paragraph: Casting ballots in 27 countries, voters largely backed centrists in European Parliament elections, but far-right parties made serious inroads in France and Germany.

headline: A Friendship Forged by the Appeal of Being a ‘Bad Woman’
abstract: In Marcela Fuentes’s novel, “Malas,” a troubled teenager finds refuge in music and in a recluse with a dark history.
lead_paragraph: Selena, the “Queen of Tejano Music,” appears in an enthralling scene in Marcela Fuentes’s debut novel, “Malas.” At a show just weeks before she was murdered, the singer performs “¿Qué Creías?,” a mariachi ballad in which a wronged woman tells off a man who thinks she’ll stay with him. For the novel’s teenage protagonist, Lulu Muñoz, it’s a moment of perfect bliss and belonging that comes after her own defiance against the man looming over her life: her father, who forbids concerts and thinks teenage girls shouldn’t be “out running the streets.”

headline: Battered by Far Right in E.U. Vote, Macron Calls for New Elections in France
abstract: The president’s decision, on the eve of the summer Olympic Games that begin in Paris in July, ushered in a period of deep political uncertainty in France.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France, battered by a crushing defeat from the extreme right in European elections, dissolved the lower house of Parliament on Sunday and called for legislative elections beginning on June 30.

headline: In ‘Dark Noon,’ Hollywood Westerns Get a South African Reboot
abstract: At St. Ann’s Warehouse, a collaboration between a Danish director and a South African troupe that questions the tropes of Western films.
lead_paragraph: The saloon is there. So are the dusty cowboy hats, the freshly laid railroad tracks and the Native American headdresses.

headline: Flemish Nationalists Thwart Ascent of Secessionist Party in Belgian Elections
abstract: The New Flemish Alliance’s victory will bring relief to the country’s political establishment, which had long been bracing for a victory by the far-right party Vlaams Belang.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Belgium handed a victory to a conservative Flemish nationalist party, disproving polls that had predicted a sweep to first place by Flemish secessionists, preliminary results showed on Sunday.

headline: Trump and Biden Surrogates Go Toe-to-Toe on Sunday Shows
abstract: Governors and senators laid out the cases for their candidates, with questionable claims and contravening positions.
lead_paragraph: After two news-filled weeks in American politics — with former President Donald J. Trump convicted of 34 felonies, and President Biden issuing the most restrictive border policy of any modern Democrat — surrogates for the two campaigns flooded the morning news shows on Sunday to promote their candidates.

headline: Mexico’s Leftists Won Big. Investors Are Worried.
abstract: The peso had its worst week since the pandemic as markets reacted to fears that the government would pass constitutional changes seen as dismantling democratic checks and balances.
lead_paragraph: A final count of votes released over the weekend suggests Mexico’s leftist governing party and its allies would capture large majorities in Congress, potentially enabling the coalition to pass sweeping changes to the Constitution.

headline: Monday Briefing: Macron Calls New French Legislative Elections
abstract: Also, Benny Gantz leaves Israel’s government.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France, dealt a crushing defeat by the extreme right in European elections, dissolved the lower house of Parliament yesterday. He called for legislative elections beginning on June 30.

headline: Trump Will Have Virtual Interview With Probation Official on Monday
abstract: The former president, who was convicted of 34 felonies by a Manhattan jury, is required to have an interview as the city’s Probation Department prepares a pre-sentencing report.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, who was convicted last month on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records, is expected to have a virtual interview with a New York City Probation Department official on Monday, three people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: The Surprising Power of Texting a Friend
abstract: Welcome to the 5-Day Friendship Challenge! Today is a light lift — just pick up your phone.
lead_paragraph: I’m Catherine Pearson, and I cover families and relationships for The New York Times. Today, I’m making the case for something many of us have a love-hate relationship with: texting.

headline: Major Muddle
abstract: You’ll have to use all of your senses to solve Kareem Ayas’s crossword.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Biden Administration Considers Protection for Undocumented Spouses of U.S. Citizens
abstract: The steps under consideration include protecting them from deportation and providing access to work permits, according to three officials with knowledge of the discussions.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is considering a proposal to protect undocumented spouses of U.S. citizens from deportation and allow them to work in the country legally, according to four officials with knowledge of the discussions.

headline: The Other War: How Israel Scours Gaza for Clues About the Hostages
abstract: The rescue of four Israelis in Gaza in a ferocious assault over the weekend offered a glimpse into an ambitious intelligence operation aimed at bringing home those held by Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The hostages in Gaza are being moved around, with Hamas shuttling some from one apartment to another to obscure their whereabouts, while others are believed to be in tunnels underground.

headline: In Las Vegas, Trump Appeals to Local Workers and Avoids Talk of Conviction
abstract: At a rally on Sunday, former President Donald J. Trump promised to end taxes on tips for hospitality workers in a speech otherwise filled with familiar refrains.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump stood in blazing heat in a Las Vegas park on Sunday and directly appealed to working-class voters by promising to eliminate taxes on tips for hospitality workers.

headline: India-Pakistan Cricket World Cup Match Brings 34,000 Fans to Long Island
abstract: Security was tight, but the mood was jubilant in the temporary stadium in Nassau County, where India won a highly anticipated nail-biter.
lead_paragraph: Normally at this time of year, the grassy southeastern corner of Eisenhower Park in East Meadow, N.Y., is a place for softball games, family picnics and a few cricket players enjoying a warm weekend afternoon. On Sunday, that space was transformed into a stage for one of the most-watched global sporting events of the year.

headline: Jean-Philippe Allard, Jazz Producer and Musicians’ Advocate, Dies at 67
abstract: He called himself a “professional listener,” and he tended to develop lifelong relationships with the artists he worked with.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Philippe Allard, a French record executive and producer who helped revive the careers of jazz greats who had been all but forgotten in the United States, and who earned a reputation for uncommonly fierce advocacy on behalf of musicians, died on May 17 in Paris. He was 67.

headline: Debby Lee Cohen, Who Helped Prune Plastic From Schools, Dies at 64
abstract: Her successful campaign against foam lunch trays in New York City led to similar city and statewide bans — and taught a group of fifth graders how to take on City Hall.
lead_paragraph: As an artist who liked to play with scale, Debby Lee Cohen created monumental pieces, like the giant puppets she designed for Manhattan’s annual Village Halloween Parade, as well as miniatures, like the tiny forest she once made for a work by the interdisciplinary artist and composer Meredith Monk, with whom she often collaborated.

headline: Trump Endorses Sam Brown in Nevada’s Key Senate Race
abstract: Mr. Brown, a former Army captain, is the leading candidate in a crowded field of Republicans vying to take on Senator Jacky Rosen, a vulnerable Democratic incumbent in a presidential battleground.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday said he was endorsing Sam Brown, the Army veteran who is leading the crowded Republican primary field in Nevada’s U.S. Senate race.

headline: Landslide in Wyoming Causes Part of a Highway to Collapse
abstract: Aerial footage shows a section of the damaged road, which links Idaho with Jackson, Wyo.
lead_paragraph: Aerial footage shows a section of the damaged road, which links Idaho with Jackson, Wyo.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The French president calls for new elections.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France, who was dealt a crushing defeat by the extreme right in European elections, dissolved the lower house of Parliament yesterday. He called for legislative elections beginning on June 30.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: Celine Dion and the Stanley Cup Finals
abstract: The pop star does her first interview on NBC since her stiff person syndrome diagnosis. And the Oilers and the Panthers compete in the pro hockey championship.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, June 10 — 16. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Border Area Seeking Help Is Skeptical of Biden Order
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “On one hand, I am happy to get any help we can get. On the other, I wish they would just fix the problem.”

headline: No Corrections: June 10, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Word of the Day: disparate
abstract: This word has appeared in 255 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word disparate has appeared in 255 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 22 in “The Algebra Problem: How Middle School Math Became a National Flashpoint” by Troy Closson:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: First Female Leader in Centuries Returns a Tribal Nation to Its Roots
abstract: Lisa Goree took the helm of the Shinnecock Nation in April, as the Long Island tribe navigates disputes over burial grounds and projects to build a casino and a gas station.
lead_paragraph: Taking her new seat at the head of the tribal council table, Lisa Goree spied among some office items a desk nameplate that read “Chaos Coordinator.”

headline: Does New York City Really Need These Giant 5G Towers?
abstract: A 32-foot “smartpole” is coming to a block near you.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: The U.N. Security Council will vote on a U.S.-backed cease-fire resolution.
abstract: The United Nations Security Council was expected to vote on Monday on a resolution brought by the United States calling for a cease-fire in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council was expected to vote on Monday on a resolution brought by the United States calling for a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: Gantz quits Israel’s government in a dispute with Netanyahu over Gaza.
abstract: The resignation exposed the divisions at the top of the Israeli leadership over the future of the war and its aftermath.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli politician Benny Gantz, a key member of the country’s war cabinet, quit the government on Sunday over Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s handling of the war in Gaza.

headline: European Parliament Elections: Key Takeaways
abstract: The voting across 27 members of the European Union was a gauge of popular political sentiment at an unsettling moment on the continent. The right did well, but the center held.
lead_paragraph: Voters in the 27 European Union member states sent a stern warning to mainstream political powers, wreaking havoc on French and, to a lesser degree, German politics and rewarding hard-line nationalist parties in a number of countries.

headline: Strasbourg for Book Lovers
abstract: Bibliophiles will find plenty of centuries-old tomes, graphic novels, modern works and more in this French city, which also happens to be this year’s UNESCO World Book Capital.
lead_paragraph: Attention, bibliophiles: Put Strasbourg, the largest city in eastern France, on your radar. Once home to the godfather of publishing — the 15th-century printing-press pioneer Johannes Gutenberg — the city is the UNESCO World Book Capital for 2024. Through next April, more than 200 events and activities will take place in and around Strasbourg, a polyglot city on the German border whose half-timbered gingerbread houses, gabled roofs, picturesque canals and church spires seem to have sprung from a storybook of their own.

headline: He Said He Was Ashamed of Storming the Capitol. Now He’s Running for Office.
abstract: Elias Irizarry participated in the Jan. 6 riot, and now he’s running for the legislature in South Carolina. Will voters see it as a liability, or an asset?
lead_paragraph: More than two years after Elias Irizarry breached the U.S. Capitol with other Trump supporters, he wrote a letter to Judge Tanya S. Chutkan as he waited for her to determine his sentence.

headline: A Drug to Slow Alzheimer’s Is Finally Available. How Are Patients Faring?
abstract: As the F.D.A. considers a new Alzheimer’s medication, we asked experts how the rollout of a similar drug has gone.
lead_paragraph: Over the last three years, a new class of Alzheimer’s drug, the first to treat a root cause of the disease, has set off a roller coaster of hope and disappointment. But while these so-called anti-amyloid antibodies had a rough start, many patients and their doctors are feeling more optimistic now that one of the medications is finally being used more widely.

headline: She’s Fighting to Save America’s ‘Last Best Place’ From Suicide
abstract: Montana’s suicide rate has been the highest in the U.S. for the past three years. Most of the deaths involved firearms. But suicide rarely registers in the national debate over guns.
lead_paragraph: On a typical day, Ali Mullen races from her job at the county health department in Helena, Mont., to pick up dinner for her three children, heads home to feed them and then goes back out for a violin lesson or a school play, crisscrossing the small city in her aging S.U.V., with a rainbow bumper sticker that reads “You Are Loved.”

headline: I’m the Governor of Nevada. This Is Why Trump Is Doing So Well With Our Voters.
abstract: Nevadans’ unhappiness with the economy is driving Trump’s support in the state.
lead_paragraph: When Nevadans aren’t happy with the economy and their families’ ability to prosper, they often vote to make a change. In the 2022 elections, I was the only candidate in the country to unseat an incumbent governor of either party. What I heard most on the campaign trail from voters then was the importance of building a stronger economy, particularly the need for good-paying jobs and lower taxes.

headline: A Big Decision for Boeing’s Next C.E.O.: Is It Time for a New Plane?
abstract: Some analysts say building a new plane soon would help the company regain ground it has lost to Airbus. But doing so would be difficult and expensive.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade ago, executives at Boeing made a pivotal decision: To keep up with the company’s main rival, Airbus, they gave up on the idea of developing a new airplane and raced to update the 737, the company’s most popular jet.

headline: Their City Has a Plaque From Putin. They Want Zelensky to Tear It Down.
abstract: Some residents of Bari, Italy, hope Ukraine’s president will drop by while at a nearby summit to help rid them of a memento of links with Russia.
lead_paragraph: A small copper plaque mounted across the piazza from the Basilica of St. Nicholas in Bari, Italy, pledges “friendship and cooperation” between the city and the Russian people. It is signed by someone who, for the past two years in Europe, has pursued anything but: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: The Quiet Voice in R.F.K. Jr.’s Ear: A Former Aide to the Clintons
abstract: Jay Carson spent years as a Democratic insider. Disillusioned, he left politics for Hollywood and became friends with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — whose campaign he is now helping to steer.
lead_paragraph: In his outsider bid for the White House, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is flanked by a team of unlikely political characters: new age health gurus, anti-vaccine activists, social media influencers, veterans of fringe third-party campaigns, cryptocurrency evangelists and militant environmentalists.

headline: Where to Get the Most Bang for Your Buck
abstract: American travelers going abroad this summer will find their money buys more in some unexpected countries, including Japan and Australia.
lead_paragraph: It’s the backpacker’s call to India, the sunseeker’s attraction to Mexico, and the digital nomad’s drive to get to Thailand: Go where the dollar buys more.

headline: Don’t Say ‘Elite’: Corporate Firms’ New Pitch Is Meritocracy
abstract: McKinsey, Accenture and other big firms want to recruit with a wider net, focusing more on skills than on pedigree. It may be easier said than done.
lead_paragraph: If you ask a graduating M.B.A. student, a prep school guidance counselor or the internet how to be hired at the global consulting firm McKinsey, you’re likely to find a list of prestigious “target schools” where it has consistently aimed its recruiting efforts. You know the ones — Harvard, Yale, Stanford.

headline: $3.3 Million Homes in California
abstract: A hillside home in Tiburon, a ranch-style house in Calabasas and a midcentury retreat in Palm Springs.
lead_paragraph: Almost every room in this home has access to outdoor space, and the expansive deck offers views that stretch to the Golden Gate Bridge and Angel Island. The property is a five-minute drive from the Tiburon Peninsula Historical Trail, which winds along the water, and from a ferry terminal, waterfront restaurants and bakeries in the center of town. Paradise Beach Park, which has a fishing pier and a lawn for picnicking, is 10 minutes away.

headline: A Reporter’s Work Helped Topple Presidents. Now He Is Being Investigated.
abstract: Press freedom groups say the investigation of Gustavo Gorriti, a noted Peruvian journalist, is politically motivated and part of a growing campaign against the news media.
lead_paragraph: One of Latin America’s most celebrated journalists, whose work has toppled presidents and set off criminal investigations into government wrongdoing, was recovering from an aggressive bout of chemotherapy when he got more bad news: A Peruvian prosecutor was investigating him for bribery.

headline: Sunny Days in Moscow
abstract: A single image of a blustery day in wartime Moscow captures the feeling of triumph sweeping through the Russia.
lead_paragraph: The Russian invasion of Ukraine has not gone as quickly as the Kremlin once predicted, but a recent visit by a group of military students to a park in Moscow was a much speedier affair.

headline: The Renaissance of a Chinatown Bookshop
abstract: Yu & Me Books was nearly destroyed in a fire. Its owner reopened the shop with the community’s support.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll hear how a bookstore in Chinatown was brought back to life after a devastating fire. We’ll also meet the editor of a high school newspaper who became the subject of an article in the issue that came out last month.

headline: The Success Narratives of Liberal Life Leave Little Room for Having Children
abstract: Progressives need to stop thinking of family as a conservative hobbyhorse.
lead_paragraph: For young, secular, politically progressive men and women, having children has become something of an afterthought. Liberal conventional wisdom encourages people to spend their 20s on journeys of personal and professional self-discovery and self-fulfillment. Children are treated as a bonus round, something to get to only after completing a long list of achievements: getting a degree, forging a satisfying and well-established career, buying a house, cultivating the ideal romantic partnership.

headline: What Modi’s Dwindling Support Says About Democracy Worldwide
abstract: Lydia Polgreen on why Indian voters asked for change.
lead_paragraph: After a weekslong election, Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India and his party won a third term but lost their majority in Parliament.

headline: Susan Jaffe Wants to Build a New Era at American Ballet Theater
abstract: “We have to really become creative about everything we do,” said Jaffe, as the company works to address financial woes and carve a modern identity.
lead_paragraph: The red carpet was rolled out, the Champagne was flowing and the crowd of financiers, artists, philanthropists and socialites gathered in a Manhattan ballroom on a May evening began to cheer.

headline: We’re Good at Punishing #MeToo Men. Can We Ever Forgive Them?
abstract: When I met Morgan Spurlock, he was trying to make amends. What I saw changed how I think about #MeToo.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, I found myself in a coffee shop in downtown Manhattan sitting across a table from Morgan Spurlock, a man I’d never met and whom I knew only as the creator of the hit documentary “Super Size Me.” A colleague had brought us together, thinking we might be able to forge a mutually beneficial relationship. As I told a friend in the lead-up to the meeting, “I think I’m supposed to teach Morgan Spurlock how to apologize.”

headline: At 17, She Fell in Love With a 47-Year-Old. Now She Questions the Story.
abstract: Jill Ciment’s 1996 memoir “Half a Life” described her teenage affair with the man she eventually married. Her new memoir, “Consent,” dramatically revises some details.
lead_paragraph: In 1970, when Jill Ciment was a rebellious teenager, she did something shocking.

headline: The Artist Is Present (and Pretentious) in Rachel Cusk’s Latest
abstract: Her new novel, “Parade,” considers the perplexity and solipsism of the creative life.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Cusk, the author of the autobiographical Outline trilogy of novels, has written so well for so long that it’s almost a relief to discover that her new novel, “Parade,” is skippable for all but her most devoted tier of readers.

headline: The Mystery of the Disappearing Breast Pocket
abstract: Our fashion critic looks at a little swatch of fabric’s journey from practical adaptation to political signifier.
lead_paragraph: Pockets are one of those seemingly small details that provoke an outsize amount of opinions and unexpectedly strong feelings — whether about the fact that women’s clothing doesn’t have more of them or the incredible disappearing breast pocket.

headline: I’m an Appellate Lawyer in Manhattan. If Trump Appeals His Conviction, He Faces Long Odds.
abstract: Only one approach is likely to hold out anything more than the slimmest of hopes for the former president.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has vowed to appeal his conviction on 34 counts of falsifying business records. Some on the right have argued that the trial was a target-rich environment for an appeal. Others have said that the U.S. Supreme Court should step in and provide relief to Mr. Trump.

headline: Hunter Biden Gun Case Goes to Jury as Prosecutors Wrap Up Closing Arguments
abstract: Prosecutors connected dozens of evidentiary dots to try to show President Biden’s deeply troubled son willfully falsified a gun form.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the verdict in Hunter Biden’s gun trial.

headline: In Arizona, Life Sentences for Juveniles Test Supreme Court Precedents
abstract: The justices will soon decide whether to hear a case that could affect more than two dozen youths sentenced to die in prison.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Supreme Court has twice rebuked the Arizona Supreme Court for defying its precedents in capital cases.

headline: It’s a Trial a Minute Around Here
abstract: Here’s looking at you, Hunter.
lead_paragraph: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I know we’ll want to talk about the Hunter Biden trial. But I’d like to give kudos to The Times’s Edgar Sandoval for his terrific report last week from the Rio Grande Valley in South Texas. The long and short of it is that Texan Latinos, once reliably Democratic, are turning against Joe Biden on account of the border chaos.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 366, June 11, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Israeli Hostage Rescue Fallout, and Far Right Wreaks Havoc in Europe
abstract: Plus, Apple’s Siri gets an A.I. makeover.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: The Rise and Fall of Congestion Pricing in New York
abstract: The decision to shelve a long-awaited tolling plan was attributed to concerns about the city’s coronavirus pandemic recovery.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced that she was indefinitely halting a project that had been decades in the making: congestion pricing in Manhattan’s core business district.

headline: As His Political Alliance Breaks Up, Netanyahu Faces a Battle at Home
abstract: The Israeli prime minister is likely to become more dependent on the right-wing partners in his coalition government after the centrist Benny Gantz and his party pulled out of it.
lead_paragraph: Still fighting Israel’s outside enemies on multiple fronts, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu woke up on Monday to a new political battlefield at home.

headline: The Internet and the First Amendment
abstract: We explore the upcoming legal rulings that will shape online life.
lead_paragraph: Here is a puzzle at the center of online life: How should we balance freedom of speech with the flood of slanderous statements, extremist manifestoes and conspiracy theories that proliferate on the internet? The United States decided decades ago to let private companies solve that quandary themselves. The Supreme Court made this position official in three major rulings in the 1990s and early 2000s.

headline: Read a Judge’s Letter of Recommendation for Elias Irizarry
abstract: A letter of recommendation from Judge Tanya S. Chutkan to the Citadel for Elias Irizarry.
lead_paragraph: A letter of recommendation from Judge Tanya S. Chutkan to the Citadel for Elias Irizarry.

headline: Can Apple Think Different on A.I.?
abstract: Wall Street and Silicon Valley will be watching the company’s developers conference closely for signs of whether the iPhone maker can finally catch up on artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Heading into Apple’s Worldwide Developers Conference on Monday, big questions are hanging over the tech giant, from muted sales for its Vision Pro headset to growing competition in China and regulatory scrutiny on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: France’s Bold Election Gamble: Here Is What’s at Stake
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron’s surprise call for new elections in France’s lower house of Parliament is seen as a risky gamble.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron threw French politics into disarray this month when he unexpectedly called for snap elections.

headline: California’s New State Park Opens This Week
abstract: Dos Rios, near Modesto in the Central Valley, offers new green space in a part of the state that has little of it.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. California has a new state park. Plus, Stanford joins other elite schools in once again requiring standardized test scores from applicants.

headline: On Senator Menendez’s Patio, Businessman Says, He Asked Directly for Help
abstract: The businessman, Jose Uribe, testified at the senator’s corruption trial that Mr. Menendez asked him to write down the names of his friends who were under investigation.
lead_paragraph: Jose Uribe, the businessman who has said he bribed Senator Robert Menendez in return for his help in quashing a criminal investigation involving two people close to him, testified on Monday that he had asked the senator directly for his help and that Mr. Menendez had said he would “look into it.”

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,088, June 11, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Three Injured After Bull Jumps the Fence at an Oregon Rodeo
abstract: While the crowd sang “God Bless the U.S.A.,” the bull leaped across a barrier into the stands and raced through the grounds of the rodeo before being captured.
lead_paragraph: Three people were injured Saturday night in central Oregon after a large bull jumped over a barrier and into the crowd at a packed rodeo event, sending onlookers scrambling for safety before the animal could be captured, the authorities said.

headline: A Cave Explorer Died 99 Years Ago. Now His Story Is Broadway Bound.
abstract: “Floyd Collins,” a musical about a trapped spelunker and the media circus surrounding his failed rescue, had a brief Off Broadway run in 1996.
lead_paragraph: In 1925, a spelunker named Floyd Collins got trapped in a Kentucky cave and the unsuccessful efforts to rescue him became a media sensation, with print and radio reporters breathlessly tracking the endeavor.

headline: Fear for the Other
abstract: Small but mighty acts of empathy can help us assuage the feelings of isolation and divisiveness that followed the Covid pandemic.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Parts of Florida May See Up to a Foot of Rain This Week
abstract: Forecasters warned of flooding that could be severe by Friday.
lead_paragraph: The wet season will take hold of South Florida this week, with some areas of the state expected to receive up to a foot, or even more, of rain through Friday. This could cause flash flooding in urban areas — but it may also help ease the drought conditions across the region.

headline: Teamsters President Asks for Speaking Slot at Both Parties’ Conventions
abstract: Having Sean O’Brien at the Republican National Convention would be politically useful to former President Donald J. Trump, even absent an endorsement. The union has yet to back a candidate.
lead_paragraph: The president of the Teamsters union has asked for speaking slots at both the Republican and Democratic national conventions, at a time when President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have pressed for support from rank-and-file members of organized labor.

headline: Unwinding Wordle: Accelerating Your Solve
abstract: Tips for the game derived from our solver data, plus more from the game’s editor and its devoted community of solvers.
lead_paragraph: Wordle has captivated millions of players since it started gaining popularity at the end of 2021. While the game’s strategy seems straightforward, Wordle has a devoted community of daily solvers who have spent years developing techniques to improve their solve. No matter your reasons for solving, a little knowledge goes a long way when you’re trying to get better, so I, Isaac Aronow, an editor on the Games team, reached out to the game’s editor as well as some of its most dedicated fans for their best advice.

headline: In Calling Elections in France, Macron Makes a Huge Gamble
abstract: The president has challenged voters to test the sincerity of their support for the far right in European elections. Were the French letting off steam, or did they really mean it?
lead_paragraph: On the face of it, there is little logic in calling an election from a position of great weakness. But that is what President Emmanuel Macron has done by calling a snap parliamentary election in France on the back of a humiliation by the far right.

headline: Can You Find The 14 Book Titles Hidden in This Block of Text?
abstract: Try your hand at uncovering a reading list of thrillers in this Title Search puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Try your hand at uncovering a reading list of thrillers in this Title Search puzzle.

headline: Taylor Swift Bests K-Pop Band to Stay No. 1 for Seventh Week
abstract: Swift’s “The Tortured Poets Department” holds off Ateez’s “Golden Hour: Part.1.” The singer-songwriter Shaboozey opens at No. 5.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s “The Tortured Poets Department” is the No. 1 album once again, leading the Billboard 200 chart for a seventh straight time.

headline: How to Bake Wild Salmon
abstract: Lean fillets of wild Alaskan Pacific salmon turn tender and rich with Ali Slagle’s ingenious recipe.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written a lot about salmon farming for The New York Times in recent years, and what I’ve learned about salmon’s sustainability has persuaded me to use wild Pacific salmon from Alaska whenever possible. I buy it frozen in individual vacuum-sealed portions and stash it in the freezer. Submerged in a bowl of warm water, the slim fillets defrost in about 15 minutes and cook even faster. It makes a deluxe last-minute meal when the cupboard seems bare.

headline: Every Elephant Has Its Own Name, Study Suggests
abstract: An analysis of elephant calls using an artificial intelligence tool suggests that the animals may use and respond to individualized rumbles.
lead_paragraph: What’s in a name? It’s more than a sound people make to get your attention — it’s a seemingly universal hallmark of human society and language, the specifics of which set us apart from our fellow animals. Now, scientists say they have found evidence with the help of artificial-intelligence-powered tools that elephants call each other by names too.

headline: The Israeli Hostage Rescue, and the Cost
abstract: Responses to the military raid and the carnage in Gaza. Also: A Trump assessment; John Roberts’s legacy; abandoned oil wells; a grief memorial.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: States Take Up A.I. Regulation Amid Federal Standstill
abstract: California legislators have made the biggest push to pass new laws to rein in the technology. Colorado passed one protecting consumers.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in California last month advanced about 30 new measures on artificial intelligence aimed at protecting consumers and jobs, one of the biggest efforts yet to regulate the new technology.

headline: For an Older Homeless Population, a New Type of Care
abstract: Programs are sprouting across the country to provide nursing home and rehabilitation services to homeless people who would otherwise shuttle between hospitals and the street.
lead_paragraph: Five years on the Phoenix streets battered Vance Blair’s body. His vision dimmed, his speech slowed, and his hands began to twitch. A bulging pelvis revealed the need for hernia surgery, and the vacant lot where he slept was no place to keep dressings clean.

headline: High Interest Rates Are Hitting Poorer Americans the Hardest
abstract: The Federal Reserve is holding interest rates at a more than two-decade high in an attempt to wrestle inflation lower. That policy has proved especially painful for poorer families.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve is holding interest rates at a more than two-decade high in an attempt to wrestle inflation lower. That policy has proved especially painful for poorer families.

headline: A Democrat, Siding With the G.O.P., Is Removing Limits on Political Cash at ‘Breathtaking’ Speed
abstract: The Federal Election Commission has long done little more than reach deadlock, but an ascendant bloc of three Republicans and one Democrat has begun to unravel longstanding restraints.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, America’s campaign watchdog agency was a portrait of dysfunction. Divided equally between three Republicans and three Democrats, the Federal Election Commission deadlocked so often it became a political punchline as investigations languished, enforcement slowed and updated guidelines for the internet era stalled.

headline: The Constant Metamorphosis of Nona Hendryx
abstract: “Lady Marmalade,” her hit with Labelle, is turning 50. She’s nearing 80. But the singer, designer and technologist isn’t slowing down. She’s entering a new virtual world.
lead_paragraph: In a purple catsuit and spiky celestial headpiece, Nona Hendryx beckoned, with a wave. “I’m inside the tree!” she called. “In the forest of the ancestors.”

headline: The Rise of Bookstores With a Social Mission
abstract: The pandemic fueled a boom in social justice movements and indie bookstores. The two come together in these worker-owned shops.
lead_paragraph: On a recent rainy Saturday morning, eight organizers from All Power Books, a volunteer-run bookstore cooperative, gathered at the Church of Christ to distribute the leftover produce they had procured from a food bank. The day’s haul was unusually large: Crates of mini potatoes, frozen meat, green beans, apples and nectarines were stacked alongside snacks like fried spring rolls and Sour Patch Kids.

headline: Frightening Log From Titan Submersible’s Fatal Dive Declared a Fake
abstract: The federal team investigating the Titan disaster found that a detailed recounting of the craft’s descent was “made up.”
lead_paragraph: Last year, a purported transcript of communications between the Titan submersible and its mother ship circulated widely on the internet. Viewed millions of times, the so-called log suggested that a series of alarms had turned a dive to the resting place of the Titanic into a heart-pounding crisis in which the five voyagers struggled in vain to return to the surface.

headline: Suspect Shot Man and Set Fire That Engulfed Miami Apartment Complex, Officials Say
abstract: The authorities arrived to find the man, who had been shot inside the building. Several residents were evacuated, some from their balconies, Miami’s mayor said.
lead_paragraph: A person shot a man at a four-story apartment complex in Miami on Monday morning and set a fire there that engulfed the complex and sent dozens of residents fleeing, the authorities said.

headline: ‘Wedding Day at the Cro-Magnons’’ Review: A Bittersweet Premiere
abstract: An Arabic production of Wajdi Mouawad’s 1991 work, planned to open in Lebanon, was canceled because of his perceived ties to Israel. It found a home in France.
lead_paragraph: What happens when the roots you long for keep eluding you? This question has long been central to the work of the playwright and director Wajdi Mouawad, and never more so than in a new production of his 1991 work “Wedding Day at the Cro-Magnons’.”

headline: Environmental Group to Study Effects of Artificially Cooling Earth
abstract: The Environmental Defense Fund, entering controversial territory, will spend millions of dollars examining the impact of reflecting sunlight into space as global warming worsens.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Defense Fund will finance research into technologies that could artificially cool the planet, an idea that until recently was viewed as radical but is quickly gaining attention as global temperatures rise at alarming rates.

headline: One Thing Everyone Is Missing About Hunter Biden’s Case
abstract: It has nothing to do with law or politics.
lead_paragraph: Update: Hunter Biden has been found guilty of three felony counts of lying on a federal firearms application in 2018.

headline: Russia Releases Female Prison Inmates to Join Ukraine War
abstract: Tens of thousands of male convicts have been freed to fight in Ukraine. It is not clear if a small contingent of female volunteers released from a prison portends wider use of female soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Russia released a group of women from a prison in late May to join the fighting in Ukraine, according to two former inmates who maintain contact with those still there, potentially signaling a new phase in the Kremlin’s use of criminals in its war effort.

headline: Dog Runs 4 Miles to Get Help After Owner Crashes Truck in a Ravine
abstract: Brandon Garrett was stranded overnight in a ravine in Oregon after his truck crashed. One of the four dogs he was traveling with found help.
lead_paragraph: As Brandon Garrett lay stranded in a ravine in Oregon last week, his dog Blue was running through the densely wooded area, toward help.

headline: Law Enforcement Unit Is Formed to Crack Down on Illegal E-Cigarettes
abstract: Agents from various federal agencies will focus on unauthorized candy-flavored and nicotine-laden vapes that have flooded the U.S. market from overseas.
lead_paragraph: A multi-agency coalition of law enforcement agents will begin tackling the unruly market of illegal e-cigarettes, under pressure from antismoking groups, lawmakers and the tobacco industry urging federal authorities to stop the flood of vaping devices favored by adolescents.

headline: What Is the Best Way to Cut an Onion?
abstract: The cookbook author Kenji López-Alt dives deep into a question of his own, with computer models and all.
lead_paragraph: In this month’s column, the cookbook author Kenji López-Alt answers a question of his own: What’s the mathematically best way to cut an onion?

headline: In Germany, Far-Right Party Rises to 2nd Place in E.U. Election
abstract: The AfD’s gains were a sharp rebuke to Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s governing coalition and a sign of the rightward political shift across the continent.
lead_paragraph: The right-wing Alternative for Germany party won a record number of votes in European Parliament elections on Sunday, in a sharp rebuke to Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s governing three-party coalition in Germany and a sign of the rightward political shift across the continent.

headline: Aircraft Carrying Malawi’s Vice President Is Missing
abstract: A search is underway after the aircraft carrying Vice President Saulos Chilima and nine other people vanished.
lead_paragraph: A search is underway for a missing aircraft carrying the vice president of the southeastern African country of Malawi and nine other people, the country’s government said on Monday.

headline: Apple Jumps Into A.I. Fray With Apple Intelligence
abstract: The iPhone maker, which has been slow to embrace artificial intelligence, will weave it into the technology that runs on billions of devices.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two years after OpenAI ignited a race to add generative artificial intelligence into products, Apple jumped into the competition on Monday, as it revealed plans to bring the technology to more than a billion iPhone users around the world.

headline: Behind the Republican Effort to Win Over Black Men
abstract: The party is trying to make inroads with Black voters, a key demographic for Democrats, which could swing the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: Two Black Republican House members and Trump surrogates reserved a cigar bar near downtown Philadelphia last week and invited conservative organizers and Trump-curious Black voters to smoke and sip cognac.

headline: Israel’s Economy Is Not Invincible
abstract: The country’s leaders insist on its strength, but economists are warning of serious vulnerabilities.
lead_paragraph: Restaurants in Tel Aviv are full. High-tech exports remain strong. The shekel is holding its value. By some measures, Israel’s economy seems unscathed by the war in Gaza. But there is a financial strain, and the longer the war goes on, the worse it will become.

headline: Bowman Makes Amends With Democratic Socialists After Rift Over Israel
abstract: Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York told members of the socialist group that his views on Israel aligned with theirs, and insisted that he never quit the group, despite earlier claims.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, in the days after Hamas’s deadly Oct. 7 attack on Israel, Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York appeared ready to make a hard public break with the Democratic Socialists of America.

headline: Why the Head of One of New York’s Most Elite Schools Quit
abstract: The leader of Collegiate School in Manhattan stepped down after an internal report found “problems of religious and cultural bias.”
lead_paragraph: The leader of one of New York’s most elite schools has stepped down after a damning internal audit found “disquieting problems of religious and cultural bias” at the school.

headline: The Winners of Our Teen Photo Essay Contest Depict Community and Why It Matters
abstract: From 528 teen entries, we have chosen 10 extraordinary pieces. Take a look.
lead_paragraph: Our “Where We Are” photo essay contest asked a lot of students. First they had to choose and document an interesting local, offline community, both photographing and interviewing its members. Then, they had to weave it all together with an introduction and captions so that, whether they focused on a roller derby team in Los Angeles or nomadic reindeer herders in China, we viewers were taken inside.

headline: The L.A. Derby Dolls Take Up Space
abstract: Chloe Moon Flaherty, age 18, documents a community that “embraces the unconventional.”
lead_paragraph: In Vernon, Calif., past the meatpacking plants and product distribution centers, a lone warehouse door opens, and the noise of roller skates echoes into the surrounding streets.

headline: The Runners-Up of Our ‘Where We Are’ Photo Essay Contest
abstract: A glimpse into nine close-knit and compelling communities, as documented by teenagers.
lead_paragraph: A football team, an underground music scene, a dog park, a Native market, a rock climbing gym: In the photo essays below, the runners-up of our “Where We Are” contest introduce you to small but vibrant communities all over, and show you the places where they gather.

headline: No One Told the Cows Not to Lick the Artwork
abstract: The Basel Social Club is a rebellious alternative to the more buttoned-up art fair that descends on the Swiss city of Basel each year.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday morning, Roman Mathis, a farmer on the outskirts of the bucolic Swiss city of Basel, noted with concern that one of his cows was standing in a small wading pool filled with beans that had recently been installed next to his barn.

headline: Reconstruction Official Resigns, Highlighting Tensions in Ukraine
abstract: The departure of the official, who had pointed up mismanagement of funds, was a blow to government efforts to assuage allies’ concerns about how aid is spent.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian official with a long record of anti-corruption advocacy resigned on Monday from a government agency overseeing mostly Western-financed reconstruction work in Ukraine, citing poor management of funds. His departure highlights the tension inside the government of President Volodymyr Zelensky over the allocation of wartime aid.

headline: U.A.W. Reaches Accord on Pay and Safety at E.V. Battery Plant
abstract: The agreement, if ratified, will cover 1,600 workers making batteries for General Motors in Ohio. The union said it would be a model for efforts elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union on Monday announced a tentative contract agreement at an Ohio factory making batteries for electric vehicles, a step that it called a milestone in enhancing pay and safety in the E.V. supply chain.

headline: Judge Dismisses Case Against Couple Charged This Year in Boy’s 1989 Murder
abstract: A South Carolina judge cited the long delay in bringing criminal charges and ordered that the case against the boy’s father and stepmother be “forever ended.”
lead_paragraph: Citing the long delay in bringing criminal charges, a South Carolina judge on Friday dismissed murder counts that were filed earlier this year against a father and stepmother accused of killing the father’s 5-year-old son in 1989.

headline: Welcome to the Era of the A.I. Smartphone
abstract: Apple and Google are getting up close and personal with user data to craft memos, summarize documents and generate images.
lead_paragraph: Every year, Apple and Google announce major software updates that bring new features to our smartphones, like cosmetic overhauls to the home screen, stronger privacy protections and fun messaging tools. This year, the changes will feel more radical because the companies are focusing on reinventing our phones with artificial intelligence.

headline: Mushroom Edibles Recalled After Spate of Serious Illnesses
abstract: At least 39 people have fallen ill after eating Diamond Shruumz products. The F.D.A. said it had found the brand’s products contained toxic levels of a psychoactive chemical.
lead_paragraph: Diamond Shruumz-brand chocolate bars and other mushroom edibles have been recalled after dozens of people fell ill after consuming the products, the Food and Drug Administration said Friday.

headline: Amid Outcry, Academy Museum to Revise Exhibit on Hollywood’s Jewish Roots
abstract: When the museum first opened, it was criticized for omitting Hollywood’s Jewish pioneers. Now it is under fire for what its new exhibit says about them.
lead_paragraph: When the popular Academy Museum of Motion Pictures opened in 2021 with exhibits celebrating the diversity of the film industry, the museum was criticized for having largely omitted one group: the Jewish founders of Hollywood.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: U.N. Adopts U.S.-Backed Cease-Fire Resolution
abstract: Also, the center held in Europe and Apple unveiled new A.I. features.
lead_paragraph: With the U.S. seeking to put pressure on Hamas and Israel to agree to a cease-fire in Gaza, the U.N. Security Council voted to adopt a resolution, brought by the U.S., to call for an immediate truce. Secretary of State Antony Blinken was in Israel yesterday for talks.

headline: Advisory Panel of Experts Endorses F.D.A. Approval of New Alzheimer’s Drug
abstract: The modest benefits of the treatment, donanemab, made by Eli Lilly, outweigh the risks, the panel concluded unanimously.
lead_paragraph: A committee of independent advisers to the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously on Monday that the benefits outweigh the risks of the newest experimental drug for Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: James M. Lawson Jr., a Top Strategist for Dr. King, Is Dead at 95
abstract: After studying Gandhi’s principles of civil disobedience in India, he joined the 1960s civil rights movement and became an architect of it as a nonviolent struggle.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. James M. Lawson Jr., a civil rights strategist for the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. who taught protesters the painful techniques of nonviolence and confronted racial injustice in America for five decades, died on Sunday en route to a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 95 and lived in Los Angeles.

headline: Apple Entered the A.I. Fray
abstract: Also, the F.D.A.’s advisers endorsed a new Alzheimer’s drug. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: After lagging behind its rivals in the artificial intelligence race for the last two years, Apple today announced that its smartphones would soon feature several tools powered by generative A.I.

headline: Trump Pledged Support to an Organization That Wants Abortion ‘Eradicated Entirely’
abstract: The group, known as the Danbury Institute, opposes abortion in all cases and has asserted that life begins at the moment of fertilization.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump promised on Monday to join forces with the leaders of the Danbury Institute, a Christian coalition of churches, organizations and conservative activists that wants abortion “eradicated entirely” in the United States.

headline: The Secret to Refreshing a Friendship
abstract: Today’s challenge: ‘Repot’ a relationship and connect with an old friend in a new way.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 2 of the 5-Day Friendship Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: Chucky, Queer Icon?
abstract: A graphic on the Peacock home screen seemed to induct the killer doll into the gay pantheon. His creator, however, says Chucky’s queer credentials are well established.
lead_paragraph: During Pride Month, it can seem as if their faces are everywhere: Madonna, James Baldwin, Elton John, Judy Garland, Grace Jones, Bea Arthur. The well of queer icons is as deep as it is colorful. But how about Chucky, the homicidal redhead doll?

headline: Israel’s Military Says 3 Rescued Hostages Were Held in Hamas Member’s Home
abstract: The man’s death was confirmed by the Hamas-controlled Gaza media office, which identified him as an employee of the Hamas-affiliated news agency Palestine Now.
lead_paragraph: Following the Israeli rescue of four hostages in Gaza on Saturday, Israel’s military said that three of them had been held in the home of a member of Hamas, which it said showed that the armed group was using civilian homes to shield its activity.

headline: Trump’s Vegas Strategy: Run on Bad Luck
abstract: At his first rally since his conviction, Trump complained about the odds being stacked against him.
lead_paragraph: Keith Rose, a 64-year-old hot tub salesman, arrived at former President Donald Trump’s Las Vegas campaign rally yesterday wearing a necklace with a golden pendant shaped like a tiny horn.

headline: M.T.A.’s Goal Now: Make Sure ‘System Doesn’t Fall Apart’
abstract: Janno Lieber said the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was reining in its ambitions after Gov. Kathy Hochul moved to halt congestion pricing.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of the state agency that runs New York City’s subway and bus network said on Monday that the agency’s priority would be keeping the aging transit system operating safely now that an ambitious plan to improve it confronts a $15 billion shortfall.

headline: Obama Marks Milestone in Construction of Presidential Center
abstract: Nine years after selecting Chicago as the home for his presidential center, Barack Obama celebrated the structure reaching its full height.
lead_paragraph: As construction projects go, Barack Obama’s presidential center has not been the speediest or the simplest. Far from it.

headline: Freedom’s Just Another Word for Not Paying Taxes
abstract: Why America’s oligarchs are rallying around Trump.
lead_paragraph: After Donald Trump was convicted on 34 felony counts, the Heritage Foundation — a right-wing think tank that has, among other things, produced the Project 2025 agenda, a blueprint for policy if Trump wins — flew an upside-down American flag, which has become an emblem for support of MAGA in general and election denial in particular.

headline: U.N. Passes Gaza Cease-Fire Resolution as Blinken Presses Israel and Hamas
abstract: The Security Council endorsed a U.S.-backed plan, while Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken visited the Middle East to lobby for it, but Hamas and Israel were noncommittal.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Monday adopted a U.S.-backed cease-fire plan for the Gaza Strip with only Russia abstaining, a sign of the growing frustration among the world’s major powers over the war and the desire to bring it to an end.

headline: Bannon and Others on the Right Celebrate European Parliament Elections
abstract: A far-right wave did not fully materialize in Europe, but influential figures on the right nevertheless sought to tie the results to U.S. politics.
lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Bannon, the onetime adviser to former President Donald J. Trump who has been ordered to surrender by July 1 to begin serving a prison sentence, celebrated the performance of far-right candidates in the recent European Parliament elections.

headline: Judge Strikes One Element From Trump Indictment in Documents Case
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon threw out one basis for the case against the former president, involving a highly sensitive military map he showed an aide after leaving office.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday slightly narrowed the classified documents case against former President Donald J. Trump, saying prosecutors cannot charge him based on an episode in which he is said to have shown a highly sensitive military map to a political adviser months after leaving office.

headline: Critical Baltimore Shipping Channel Reopens 11 Weeks After Bridge Collapse
abstract: The 700-foot-wide section of the Patapsco River where the Dali slammed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge is open for business.
lead_paragraph: It took more than 2,000 people working for nearly 11 weeks, but the main shipping channel into the Port of Baltimore, which had been clogged by the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge, has fully reopened.

headline: The Gay-Bashing Email Splitting Colorado’s Republican Party
abstract: The MAGA movement tears another state Republican Party apart.
lead_paragraph: The Colorado Republican Party last week sent a mass email with the subject line, “God hates Pride.” The missive denounced Pride Month as a time when “godless groomers” attack what is “decent, holy and righteous.” It included a clip of a sermon by a famously misogynist pastor named Mark Driscoll, with thumbnail text proclaiming, in a nod to the slogan of the obscenely anti-gay Westboro Baptist Church, “God hates flags.” The party also posted on the social media platform X, “Burn all the #pride flags this June.”

headline: Israel’s Parliament Revives Bill on Drafting Ultra-Orthodox Men Into Military
abstract: The vote was aimed at keeping the divisive issue in the hands of legislators instead of judges, who have repeatedly determined that an exemption should not stand.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Parliament on Tuesday voted to revive a bill that would enable ultra-Orthodox men to be drafted into the military, a divisive issue that has become especially contentious since the war in Gaza began last October.

headline: Baltimore City Council to Hold Hearings on Drug Overdoses
abstract: The city’s overdose epidemic has killed nearly 6,000 people since 2018, a death rate never before seen in a major U.S. city.
lead_paragraph: Baltimore City Council members said Monday they would hold a series of hearings on the city government’s response to its overdose epidemic, following an examination by The New York Times and The Baltimore Banner.

headline: 4 Instructors From Iowa College Are Attacked in Public Park in China
abstract: A man, 55, was arrested after the episode, the police said. The Cornell College instructors were visiting as part of a partnership with a local university.
lead_paragraph: Four instructors from an Iowa college who were teaching in China as part of a partnership with a local university were attacked and injured in a public park there on Monday, according to Chinese and college officials.

headline: In Secret Recordings, Alito Endorses Nation of ‘Godliness.’ Roberts Talks of Pluralism.
abstract: The two justices were surreptitiously recorded at a Supreme Court gala last week by a woman posing as a Catholic conservative.
lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. told a woman posing as a Catholic conservative last week that compromise in America between the left and right might be impossible and then agreed with the view that the nation should return to a place of godliness.

headline: U.A.W. Monitor Investigates Accusations Against Union Leader
abstract: The court-appointed monitor is looking into allegations by two union officials that they were punished for raising questions on financial matters.
lead_paragraph: A court-appointed monitor overseeing the operations of the United Automobile Workers union is investigating disputes involving the union’s president, Shawn Fain, and two U.A.W. officials who say they were improperly stripped of duties.

headline: Chemical Makers Sue Over Rule to Rid Water of ‘Forever Chemicals’
abstract: Industry groups said the E.P.A. had exceeded its authority in requiring the drinking-water cleanup. The chemicals, known as PFAS, are linked to cancer and health risks.
lead_paragraph: Chemical and manufacturing groups sued the federal government late Monday over a landmark drinking-water standard that would require cleanup of so-called forever chemicals linked to cancer and other health risks.

headline: After Weeks of Planning, Seconds Made the Difference in Israel’s Hostage Rescue
abstract: When a truck carrying three of four rescued hostages broke down and came under fire, Israel says it called in an airstrike. Scores of Palestinians were killed, Gazan officials say.
lead_paragraph: When the four Israelis woke up in Gaza on Saturday, they had been held hostage by Hamas for 245 days. The buildings in which they were being kept, two low-rise, concrete apartment blocks, looked much like the other nearby residences in a civilian neighborhood full of Palestinian families.

headline: Trumpet Flourish
abstract: Chloe Revery never misses.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: The Full List of the 2024 James Beard Chef and Restaurant Award Winners
abstract: Restaurants and chefs from Washington, D.C., Portland, Ore., and New Orleans took home top honors.
lead_paragraph: The James Beard Foundation handed out its coveted culinary awards Monday evening in Chicago, showcasing an eclectic collection of winners from a range of restaurants in cities and towns across America.

headline: Justice Alito’s Wife, in Secretly Recorded Conversation, Complains About Pride Flag
abstract: In a conversation with a woman posing as a conservative supporter, Martha-Ann Alito appeared to push back against having to look at a symbol of L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr.’s wife, Martha-Ann, recently told a woman posing as a conservative supporter that she wanted to fly a Catholic flag at the couple’s Virginia home in response to a Pride flag in her neighborhood.

headline: Americans Push Biden to Help Their Undocumented Spouses
abstract: The White House is weighing relief for immigrants who crossed the border unlawfully but are eligible for green cards through marriage to U.S. citizens.
lead_paragraph: When Ashley de Azevedo married in 2012, she knew that her U.S. citizenship would make her husband, an immigrant from Brazil, eligible for a green card. What she didn’t realize was that to obtain permanent residency, he would need to return to Brazil for 10 years because he had entered the United States illegally.

headline: Biden, Honoring Juneteenth, Warns of Danger of ‘Old Ghosts in New Garments’
abstract: The president assailed attacks on Black history, and vowed that his administration was committed to protecting civil rights.
lead_paragraph: President Biden warned on Monday of “old ghosts in new garments trying to take us back” in remarks commemorating Juneteenth, the national holiday that marks the freedom of the last enslaved people in America, and vowed that his administration was committed to protecting Black history and civil rights.

headline: Buoyed by Election, Meloni Basks in Spotlight as Italy Hosts G7
abstract: The Italian prime minister was a rare leader to be fortified by the vote for the European Parliament. This week she has a chance to show her influence on an even broader stage.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, when her party won 6 percent of the vote in elections for the European Parliament, Giorgia Meloni tried to pop a bottle of sparkling wine, but the cork awkwardly flopped among some supporters.

headline: Nigeria Confronts Its Worst Economic Crisis in a Generation
abstract: People in Africa’s most populous nation are suffering as the price of food, fuel and medicine has skyrocketed out of reach for many.
lead_paragraph: Nigeria is facing its worst economic crisis in decades, with skyrocketing inflation, a national currency in free-fall and millions of people struggling to buy food. Only two years ago Africa’s biggest economy, Nigeria is projected to drop to fourth place this year.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: The U.N. passes a cease-fire resolution for Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. Security Council passed a resolution, brought by the U.S., to call for an immediate truce between Israel and Hamas in Gaza. The move was a sign of the growing frustration with the war among the world’s major powers and their desire to end it.

headline: Quotation of the Day:
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “He has given many French people the feeling of being inferior, and they detest that.”

headline: America Isn’t Leading the World
abstract: Never has the country looked less like a leader and more like the head of a faction.
lead_paragraph: After four years of Donald Trump, Joe Biden was supposed to restore the United States to a position of global leadership. By many conventional standards of Washington, he has delivered. He anticipated Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and adroitly rallied NATO to stand up to it. In Asia, he shored up old alliances, built new ones and fanned China’s economic headwinds. After Israel was attacked, he managed to support it while avoiding all-out regional war.

headline: Word of the Day: stamina
abstract: This word has appeared in 123 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word stamina has appeared in 123 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 24 in “‘So Far From Ukraine’: A Princely Dancer Finds a Home in Miami” by Marina Harss:

headline: Clashes Break Out at U.C.L.A.
abstract: Police arrested more than 20 pro-Palestinian demonstrators on U.C.L.A.’s campus after several physical confrontations with security guards.
lead_paragraph: Police arrested more than 20 pro-Palestinian demonstrators on U.C.L.A.’s campus after several physical confrontations with security guards.

headline: At U.C.L.A., Police Arrest More Than 20 Pro-Palestinian Protesters
abstract: Protesters marched through campus, pitched tents and occupied various quads in demonstrations that became confrontational at times.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators at the University of California, Los Angeles, clashed with law enforcement officers on Monday, sometimes physically, as they attempted to occupy outdoor areas and re-establish a protest encampment in the last days of the spring quarter.

headline: Foraging on Public Lands Is Becoming More Limited
abstract: Collecting wild mushrooms, berries and other foods from public forests and parks has become so popular that state and federal agencies are imposing more restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Beneath a row of fir trees River Shannon Aloia walks along a remote dirt road on national forest land, scanning the ground for morels.

headline: He Began With Sauce. Here’s Why This Brisket Sandwich Goes for $13.50.
abstract: Who has not dreamed of turning a side hustle into a full-time gig? Luis Rivera Jr., who sells barbecue on the weekends in the Bronx from his food truck, is trying.
lead_paragraph: The thing is, Mr. Rivera never had any intention of selling meat.

headline: The Mushroom Hunters Can’t Stop Finding Mysterious Fungi
abstract: For years, mycologists and hobbyists alike have been using DNA sequencing on foraged fungi.
lead_paragraph: Strange things appear in the forests and chaparral of California after a big rain. Invigorated by the damp, fungi living quietly in the soil sprout fruiting bodies. Some have the familiar mushroom shape of a stalk and a cap, but others resemble fluorescent corals, wads of clear brown jelly, brilliant yellow buttons — bizarre forms visible to the naked eye for only a brief window while the organisms release their spores.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: A Column in Which Age Takes Center Stage
abstract: For Paula Span, a columnist for The Times’s Health section, the subject of aging doesn’t age.
lead_paragraph: For about 15 years, Paula Span has dedicated much of her journalism career to covering one subject: aging, and the challenges that come with it.

headline: After the hostage rescue, the U.N. says actions by both Israel and Hamas may be war crimes, and other news.
abstract: Israel’s Parliament revived legislation that would allow ultra-Orthodox men to be drafted into the military

headline: A Champion Sherpa Died Guiding Foreigners. Is It Too Dangerous?
abstract: Tenjen Lama Sherpa was one of the most storied mountain guides of his generation. Now, he and two of his brothers are dead, and their youngest brother must keep climbing to make a living.
lead_paragraph: In July 2023, the mountaineer Tenjen Lama Sherpa guided a Norwegian climber to summit the world’s 14 highest peaks in record time. In a sport that demands an alchemy of sinewy resolve and high-altitude faith, Mr. Lama did everything his client did and more. But she received most of the money, fame and attention.

headline: ‘Hit Man’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: Richard Linklater, the director of “Hit Man,” narrates a pivotal sequence from his film, starring Glen Powell and Adria Arjona.
lead_paragraph: Richard Linklater, the director of “Hit Man,” narrates a pivotal sequence from his film, starring Glen Powell and Adria Arjona.

headline: Talking About Periods Is Taboo. So We Talked About Them.
abstract: From love and pride to discomfort and hate, ten people describe their feelings about their own periods.
lead_paragraph: From love and pride to discomfort and hate, ten people describe their feelings about their own periods.

headline: Palestinians in the West Bank Are Living in the Shadow of the War in Gaza
abstract: Since the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7, Israel has tightened its grip on the occupied West Bank. Two Palestinians describe how they have been impacted – and their worries for the future.
lead_paragraph: Since the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7, Israel has tightened its grip on the occupied West Bank. Two Palestinians describe how they have been impacted – and their worries for the future.

headline: As the War in Gaza Drags on, Palestinians in the West Bank Have ‘Reached Rock Bottom’
abstract: Since the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7, Israel has tightened its grip on the occupied West Bank. Two Palestinians describe how they have been impacted — and their worries for the future.
lead_paragraph: As the war in Gaza enters its eighth month, Palestinians living under Israeli occupation in the West Bank continue to face onerous restrictions, economic difficulties and an increased military presence — changes that some worry may become the new normal.

headline: A Rustic Cabin in the Woods Was His Dream. Not Hers.
abstract: It didn’t help that it was straight out of ‘Twin Peaks’: ‘Wood on wood on wood, in a very terrifying way.’ But now it’s bright and airy.
lead_paragraph: Natale Adgnot didn’t always see the appeal of owning a cabin in the woods.

headline: Is America Getting Interest Rates Wrong?
abstract: Why higher rates are replacing inflation as the thing to hate.
lead_paragraph: Update: In a unanimous vote on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged.

headline: Welcomed Into Joan Didion’s Home, if Not Her Inner Circle
abstract: In “The Uptown Local,” Cory Leadbeater describes his years as the late writer’s assistant and companion. Yet the fond portrait reveals more about him than her.
lead_paragraph: One of Joan Didion’s greatest talents was a bit of sorcery: She somehow became an icon of vulnerable self-revelation without being all that revealing. Her later memoirs, “The Year of Magical Thinking” and “Blue Nights,” are full of the vulnerability that age can afford. But her early work, in the collections “Slouching Towards Bethlehem” and “The White Album,” led her fans to believe she was just like them, that she could understand them. “A lot of people read these pieces,” she recalled in 2011. “People would come to me for, like, advice, and I hated it.”

headline: Is Serifos the Perfect Greek Island?
abstract: A writer’s checklist included ferry service, great beaches and good local restaurants. Add rich history, a welcoming population and proximity to other islands. The mythical cave of the Cyclops was gravy.
lead_paragraph: “I have analysis paralysis,” said my friend Maite, an Argentine who lives in Madrid. Maite is a world traveler but has always been stymied when it comes to Greece. “There are too many islands. How do you decide?”

headline: Can Apple Rescue the Vision Pro?
abstract: The $3,500 “spatial computing” device has gathered dust on my shelf. Can tweaks and upgrades save it from obsolescence?
lead_paragraph: When I first got my hands on an Apple Vision Pro early this year, it felt like magic.

headline: What My Father Taught Me About Texas Barbecue, and Being a Dad
abstract: Looking back on a family’s five-generation devotion to a historic smokehouse and restaurant.
lead_paragraph: In Lockhart, a small city just south of Austin, Texas, barbecue is still the feast of choice. Anywhere friends and family meet, butcher paper unfurls to reveal a mosaic of smoked meats and pickled jalapeños, juicy links of sausage that snap into a savory crumble, nestled between foam cups of potato salad, frijoles and baked mac — and always served with a stack of white bread and warm tortillas.

headline: She Moved Her Family to a Black Utopia. Then Things Got Weird.
abstract: In Nicola Yoon’s first novel for adults, “One of Our Kind,” a woman finds that a lush California suburb is not what it seems.
lead_paragraph: The new novel “One of Our Kind,” by Nicola Yoon, opens with a cozy description of an all-Black Los Angeles suburb called Liberty. There’s a Black History Museum with Roman columns and a grand staircase. A sculpture garden with statues of historic Black figures like W.E.B. Du Bois, Malcolm X and M.L.K. Expansive homes on both sides of a picturesque hill. And on that hill, a gleaming spa called the Wellness Center.

headline: Don’t Call It an ‘Ethnic’ Grocery Store
abstract: As Asian groceries like H Mart, Patel Brothers and 99 Ranch expand, they are reshaping American eating habits, and the American grocery market.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Americans bought half a billion packets of Shin Ramyun, the spicy, beefy Korean instant noodle. The bold red-and-black packaging feels inescapable: It’s a staple of college dorm rooms, bodegas, middle-of-the-country Walmarts and viral TikTok videos.

headline: Clare Sestanovich’s Characters Are Book-Smart and Bored
abstract: Her first novel, “Ask Me Again,” follows a young woman from high school in New York City to an elite university, to her early adulthood among the political class in Washington, D.C.
