lead_paragraph: Clare Sestanovich’s debut story collection, “Objects of Desire” (2021), introduced readers to a formally accomplished writer whose style calls to mind alienated, realist forebears such as Ann Beattie, Richard Yates and Mary Gaitskill.

headline: When Life Gives You Lemons, Get an Online Sex Account
abstract: Young, single and broke, a new mom finds creative ways to stay afloat in Rufi Thorpe’s deft comic novel “Margo’s Got Money Troubles.”
lead_paragraph: An earnest synopsis of “Margo’s Got Money Troubles,” Rufi Thorpe’s fourth novel, might give you the impression that it is overstuffed and, as a consequence, misshapen. Wrestling? OnlyFans? A young mother? Custody battles? Substance abuse? A touch of metafictional playfulness? Jokes about all of these things? But it is overstuffed only in the way a pillowcase is overstuffed on Christmas morning, if you’re lucky. You don’t see lumps; you see only gifts, and Thorpe is a generous, if unseasonal, Santa.

headline: Abortion Groups Say Tech Companies Suppress Posts and Accounts
abstract: The groups say they are increasingly confused and frustrated by how major technology platforms moderate posts about abortion services.
lead_paragraph: TikTok has briefly suspended the account of Hey Jane, a prominent telemedicine abortion service, four times without explanation. Instagram has suspended Mayday Health, a nonprofit that provides information about abortion pill access, without explanation as well. And the search engine Bing has erroneously flagged the website for Aid Access, a major seller of abortion pills online, as unsafe.

headline: You Lost Your Passport. Now What?
abstract: Summer travel season is upon us. Do you know where your passport is?
lead_paragraph: While just about every other document is accessible online, a lost passport is one of the last analog emergencies that can derail an international trip.

headline: The Tao of ‘Smooth,’ Rock’s Enduring, Inescapable Earworm
abstract: Santana’s track featuring Rob Thomas turns 25 this week. Why is it still a rock blockbuster?
lead_paragraph: “To really appreciate ‘Smooth,’ you have to embrace how cheesy ‘Smooth’ is,” Rob Thomas said. “It’s right in your face.”

headline: Nuclear Power Is Hard. A Climate-Minded Billionaire Wants to Make It Easier.
abstract: Work is starting in Wyoming coal country on a new type of reactor. Its main backer, Bill Gates, says he’s in it for the emissions-free electricity.
lead_paragraph: Outside a small coal town in southwest Wyoming, a multibillion-dollar effort to build the first in a new generation of American nuclear power plants is underway.

headline: I Have Incontinence. How Can I Avoid Accidents When I Leave Home?
abstract: Effective treatments and products can help manage this stressful condition.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m going on vacation soon and am worried about leaks from urinary incontinence. What should I do?

headline: On Broadway, ‘Suffs’ Has a New Tune (and 6 Tony Nominations)
abstract: A reworked opening number, less historical bulk and a general push to “have fun with these women” helped a musical find its way.
lead_paragraph: Two ambitious overhauls are on Broadway right now: the Palace Theater and the musical “Suffs.”

headline: Why NYC Audubon Changed Its Name
abstract: The birding group has rebranded as NYC Bird Alliance because of John James Audubon’s connections to slavery.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at a name change that has put a well-known birding organization on the right side of history. We’ll also see why the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority says “we’re behind the eight ball” now that Gov. Kathy Hochul has shelved congestion pricing.

headline: The Ecstasy of Humidity
abstract: Living in a place with seasons is overrated. There’s nothing like a sweaty Florida summer to bring you back to your body.
lead_paragraph: I long for sweat. Last year, I moved to upstate New York from Florida. All winter and spring I tried to sweat. I missed it terribly. I attended hot-yoga classes in heavy layers in an attempt to sweat as much as possible. As an amateur boxer, for years I have trusted coaches who extolled the benefits of heat, saying it can improve cardio endurance and strengthen immune systems. I realize now that this has all been an attempt to find a sense of home.

headline: Talking About Periods Is Taboo. So We Talked About Them.
abstract: From love and pride to discomfort and hate, 10 people describe their feelings about their own periods.
lead_paragraph: The Opinion video above dives headfirst into a topic that remains stubbornly taboo: menstruation.

headline: When Vienna’s Opera Tradition Got Too Traditional, They Stepped In
abstract: Bogdan Roscic and Lotte de Beer are shaking the dust off Vienna’s two biggest repertory companies.
lead_paragraph: In a rehearsal studio built on the grounds of old military barracks outside Vienna’s city center one recent morning, the director Barrie Kosky was asking for a touch of vaudeville.

headline: To Understand Elon Musk’s Descent, Look at His $46 Billion Pay Package
abstract: Tesla shareholders must reject the chief executive’s unorthodox compensation package to help turn him back into the visionary we need to fight climate change.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Fed Is in No Rush to Cut Rates as Economy Holds Up
abstract: Federal Reserve officials are expected to leave interest rates unchanged at their meeting this week. They will also release a fresh set of economic projections.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are entering an uncertain summer. They are not sure how quickly inflation will cool, how much the economy is likely to slow or just how long interest rates need to stay high in order to make sure that quick price increases are fully vanquished.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Thoroughly Iconic, Unsustainable City in the Desert
abstract: Success isn’t an Instagrammable skyline.
lead_paragraph: It may not feel like it, but we’re likely experiencing the largest construction booms in history. According to one estimate, the world will build the equivalent of a New York City every month from 2020 to 2060.

headline: First Came ‘Spam.’ Now, With A.I., We’ve Got ‘Slop’
abstract: A new term has emerged to describe dubious A.I.-generated material.
lead_paragraph: You may not know exactly what “slop” means in relation to artificial intelligence. But on some level you probably do.

headline: Torture Accusations Could Lead to Civil Rights Case in Mississippi
abstract: Federal authorities investigating the “Goon Squad” in a suburban sheriff’s office have widened their investigation, seeking out more victims of brutality.
lead_paragraph: More than two months after deputies were sentenced for torturing two Black men in central Mississippi, federal prosecutors have widened their investigation and may sue the Rankin County sheriff’s department for civil rights violations, a serious escalation that could lead to federal monitoring.

headline: Age Is on the Ballot in 2024, at Least in North Dakota
abstract: A vote on Tuesday on a proposed age limit for members of Congress is a rare chance to find out what voters actually believe about politicians and age.
lead_paragraph: For months, as the presidential election has drawn closer, a debate over the age of American politicians has swirled: Is there a point at which candidates should be deemed too old to run? Should age even matter?

headline: Watch Glen Powell and Adria Arjona Fight and Flirt in ‘Hit Man’
abstract: The director Richard Linklater narrates a pivotal sequence from his rom-com thriller.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Issues Affecting Women Take Center Stage as Southern Baptists Hold Annual Meeting
abstract: Delegates will vote on whether to tighten restrictions on women in pastoral leadership and whether to condemn the use of in vitro fertilization.
lead_paragraph: Southern Baptists are poised to vote at their annual meeting on whether to crack down on women in pastoral leadership and whether to condemn the use of in vitro fertilization, setting up a referendum on the role of women in the nation’s largest Protestant denomination and in American society.

headline: There’s a Reason Trump Has Friends in High Places
abstract: Even the weak regulatory grasp of capitalist democracy is too strong for, well, capitalists.
lead_paragraph: Among the features that distinguish capitalist society from its predecessors, the political theorist Ellen Meiksins Wood once observed, is “the differentiation of the economic and the political.”

headline: Malawi’s Vice President Is Killed in Plane Crash
abstract: After an overnight search, rescuers found the wreckage of the military aircraft that had been carrying Saulos Chilima and nine others.
lead_paragraph: The vice president of Malawi and nine other people were killed when their plane crashed in bad weather, the country’s president said on Tuesday.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 367, June 12, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Gaza Cease-Fire Plan, and Justice Alito Secretly Recorded
abstract: Plus, a dispatch from the U.S.-Mexico border.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Biden’s Hard-Line Effort to Close the Border
abstract: The order to suspend asylum when crossings surge shows how drastically immigration politics have shifted in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Last week, President Biden announced one of the most restrictive immigration policies by a Democratic incumbent in decades, effectively barring migrants crossing the southern border from seeking asylum in the United States.

headline: The Race for Running Mate
abstract: Donald Trump has tightened his V.P. list to dependable and loyal campaigners.
lead_paragraph: Discipline, experience and risk aversion are not traits typically associated with Donald Trump’s political brand. But his search for those values in a running mate has helped him narrow the field, for now, to a top tier of contenders, people in his orbit tell me.

headline: 4 Israeli Soldiers Are Killed in Rafah in Apparent Ambush
abstract: Israel said the soldiers were killed when Hamas militants detonated explosives in a three-story building. Some wounded soldiers were in critical condition.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said Tuesday that four Israeli soldiers had been killed and several more wounded after militants blew up a building where the troops were operating in the southern Gaza city of Rafah.

headline: Late Night Pounces on Trump’s First Meeting With Probation Officer
abstract: “Things got off to a rough start when Trump offered the probation officer $130,000,” Jimmy Fallon joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Apple’s Go-Slow A.I. Approach
abstract: The tech giant announced a slew of artificial intelligence-focused features, but also signaled it will be patient in rolling out the technology to users.
lead_paragraph: After months of anticipation, Apple finally introduced its plan to infuse its products with artificial intelligence: Meet Apple Intelligence, which weaves the technology into core features of iPhones, iPads and Macs.

headline: U.S. Bans Imports From 3 Chinese Companies Over Ties to Forced Labor
abstract: The government targeted companies involved in making seafood, aluminum and footwear, citing their links to labor programs affecting Chinese minorities.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Homeland Security on Tuesday added three Chinese companies to a list of firms whose products can no longer be exported to the United States, as part of what it described as an escalating crackdown on companies that aid in forced labor programs in Xinjiang.

headline: Seeking Safety in Cyprus, They’re Stuck in Island’s U.N. Buffer Zone
abstract: Nearly 30 people who hoped to seek refuge in the European Union nation are in limbo after trying to cross from the Turkish-occupied part of the island. Many are Syrians who left Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 asylum seekers are stuck in the United Nations-controlled buffer zone between the Turkish-occupied north of Cyprus and the internationally recognized south amid a crackdown by the Cypriot authorities on undocumented migration following a steep uptick in Syrians arriving from Lebanon.

headline: Hello, Dolley? Earliest Known Photograph of a First Lady Comes to Auction
abstract: Sotheby’s is offering a recently surfaced 1846 daguerreotype of Dolley Madison, who is credited with inventing the role of first lady.
lead_paragraph: Sometime around May 1846, Dolley Madison made her way from her home near the White House to the studio of an enterprising photographer who had begun a quixotic effort to create a daily publication featuring portraits of “interesting public characters.”

headline: How a Winter in California’s Gold Country Started Mark Twain’s Career
abstract: The young writer came across a tale in the Sierra Nevada foothills that would bring him national attention.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, you might think that Angels Camp, a small city in the verdant foothills of the Sierra Nevada, is famous for its frogs.

headline: What to Watch in Primaries in Maine, South Carolina, Nevada and North Dakota
abstract: A special House election will also be held in Ohio to replace a retiring Republican congressman.
lead_paragraph: The presidential primary season is over, but down-ballot primaries are still happening across the country. Candidates will be on the ballot on Tuesday in five states: South Carolina, Nevada, Maine, North Dakota and Ohio, where a special House race will take place.

headline: Memoir by Trump’s Nephew Will Shed Light Into ‘Darker Corner’ of Family
abstract: Fred C. Trump III’s “All in the Family: The Trumps and How We Got This Way” will hit shelves July 30.
lead_paragraph: Fred C. Trump III, the nephew of former President Donald J. Trump and the older brother of Mary Trump, will publish a memoir about the Trump family, according to his publisher, Simon & Schuster.

headline: World Bank Sees Rosier Growth Outlook
abstract: But rising trade barriers pose a long-term threat to global output as protectionist policies spread, the bank said.
lead_paragraph: The World Bank on Tuesday raised its outlook for the world economy this year but warned that the rise of new trade barriers and protectionist policies posed a long-term threat to global growth.

headline: Man Who Said He Bribed Menendez Is Called a ‘Sophisticated Liar’
abstract: Jose Uribe was cross-examined for hours on Tuesday during his third day of testimony at Senator Robert Menendez’s bribery trial.
lead_paragraph: For days, as the government’s star witness was testifying against him, Senator Robert Menendez offered much the same comment each time he exited his bribery trial in Manhattan: “Wait for the cross and find the truth.”

headline: Fate of Gaza Cease-Fire Proposal Is ‘on Hamas,’ Blinken Says
abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the world was waiting for Hamas to respond to a U.S.-backed cease-fire plan endorsed by the U.N. Security Council. Neither Israel nor Hamas has formally embraced it.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the world was waiting for Hamas to respond to a U.S.-backed cease-fire plan endorsed by the U.N. Security Council. Neither Israel nor Hamas has formally embraced it.

headline: France in Shock as Conservative Leader Embraces Far Right
abstract: The announcement by the head of the Republicans was a historic break with his party’s policy as dismay spread over a snap election.
lead_paragraph: The head of France’s conservative party on Tuesday called for an alliance with the far right in upcoming snap elections, breaking a longstanding taboo and throwing his party into deep turmoil as the shock waves from President Emmanuel Macron’s decision to dissolve the lower house of Parliament coursed through the country.

headline: What Scares a Master of Fear?
abstract: Feeling frightened isn’t always fun, but it can be a source of endless inspiration.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: At the Ojai Festival, a Star Pianist Keeps the Focus on Young Artists
abstract: Mitsuko Uchida appeared every night at her edition of the Ojai Music Festival. The rest of the time was given to other performers.
lead_paragraph: Mitsuko Uchida sat at the piano with her back to the audience.

headline: Alito No Longer Tries to Hide His Theocratic Worldview
abstract: Unlike Chief Justice Roberts, he wants to bring God onto the Supreme Court bench.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Supreme Court may bear Chief Justice John Roberts’s name, but it is not his court, nor has it been for many years.

headline: Police Identify Suspect Accused of Setting Fire to Miami Building
abstract: An arrest affidavit said the man shot a building employee and then started the worst fire in Miami in 25 years.
lead_paragraph: Moments before a Miami apartment complex was engulfed on Monday morning in what the mayor called the worst fire in the city in 25 years, residents of the building heard loud noises that sounded like gunshots.

headline: Trump to Meet With Republican Lawmakers in Washington
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump’s allies on Capitol Hill have been planning for a 2025 agenda, while Mr. Trump has put forth proposals for a radical reshaping of government.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump is expected to meet with a group of Republican senators and House members this week in Washington, where he will also sit down with business leaders, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Reflections on Gen Z and ‘Sellout Culture’
abstract: Responses to an article about a generation tugged in different directions. Also: Gun trafficking to Mexico; a strong leader; Joe Biden’s tall tales.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Bánh by Lauren Offers Pandan Coffee Cakes, Fried Sesame Balls and More
abstract: Veerays will serve tandoori food, Son del North has Northern Mexico-style burritos and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: The pastry chef Lauren Tran has put down roots in an airy corner bakery and cafe in the shadow of the Manhattan Bridge. She had baked at Gramercy Tavern until the pandemic, then began selling bánh (a general term in Vietnamese for cake) from home and at pop-ups. Now she’s turning out multilayered chiffon cakes, macarons, pandan coffee cakes, fried sesame rice balls filled with coconut and mung beans, and savory Chinese sausage, Cheddar and chive scones, many distinctively but subtly conveying Southeast Asian flavors, inspired by her Vietnamese heritage. A sleek quartz counter, an open kitchen and marble-topped tables define the space. Sidewalk seats are coming. (Opens Saturday)

headline: 5 Festive Recipes for a Juneteenth Feast
abstract: Make one, or make them all. Just make them yours.
lead_paragraph: On Kiva Williams’s Juneteenth table, pops of red — barbecue ribs and watermelon, a symbol of freedom — share the table with hot dogs, burgers, potato salad and baked beans. Sometimes, foods from her past, like fried fish and spaghetti, and coleslaw, “my favorite meal from back home” in Tennessee, also make an appearance.

headline: The Best Thing About Salad Is Croutons
abstract: They add craveable texture to summery dinners like Lidey Heuck’s chopped salad with chickpeas, feta and avocado.
lead_paragraph: Tell me honestly: Are you ever excited to have a green salad for dinner?

headline: Was This Sea Creature Our Ancestor? Scientists Turn a Famous Fossil on Its Head.
abstract: Researchers have long assumed that a tube in the famous Pikaia fossil ran along the animal’s back. But a new study turned the fossil upside down.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 500 million years, vertebrates have evolved into a staggering variety of forms, from hummingbirds to elephants, bullfrogs to hammerhead sharks, not to mention our peculiar species of upright ape. But underneath all that diversity, vertebrates share some key features.

headline: Mistral, a French A.I. Start-Up, Is Valued at $6.2 Billion
abstract: Created by alumni from Meta and Google, Mistral is just a year old and has already raised more than $1 billion in total from investors, leading to eye-popping valuations.
lead_paragraph: Mistral, a French artificial intelligence start-up, said on Tuesday that it had raised 600 million euros, or about $640 million, from investors, a sign of robust interest in a company seen as Europe’s most promising rival to OpenAI and other Silicon Valley A.I. developers.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Polling Surprisingly Well Among Latino Voters
abstract: Pollsters attribute the independent candidate’s strength to significant name recognition and to frustration with the top two contenders.
lead_paragraph: When Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Donald J. Trump faced off in the 2020 presidential election, Alexis Figueroa, a hospital worker in Phoenix, would have voted for Mr. Biden, he said, because he seemed like the least controversial of the two candidates.

headline: Biden Nears Pick for Next F.D.I.C. Chair
abstract: The front-runner for the bank regulatory job is Christy Goldsmith Romero, a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after President Biden vowed to pick a new leader for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the bank regulator shaken by a vast workplace abuse scandal, a front-runner has emerged: Christy Goldsmith Romero, who sits on the five-member Commodity Futures Trading Commission, according to two people with knowledge of the administration’s thinking.

headline: Grab Them. Then Stump Them.
abstract: Word puzzles on LinkedIn. Logic challenges in The Washington Post. For news publishers and tech sites looking to both entice and engage users, games are serious business.
lead_paragraph: What’s a five-letter word for an activity that media and technology companies are increasingly relying on to gain subscribers and keep them coming back?

headline: Dallas Pastor Tony Evans, Citing Undisclosed ‘Sin,’ Leaves Pulpit
abstract: Mr. Evans, who has built one of the largest predominantly African American evangelical churches in the United States, said in a statement that he was “stepping away from my pastoral duties.”
lead_paragraph: Tony Evans, a longtime pastor of a prominent evangelical megachurch in Dallas, stepped away from his position on Sunday citing an undisclosed “sin.”

headline: Government’s Case Against Hunter Biden Used His Own Words Against Him
abstract: Details from a 2021 memoir ended up being repeated in court testimony.
lead_paragraph: In his 2021 memoir, “Beautiful Things,” Hunter Biden took stock of his travails and wrote: “All my energy revolved around smoking drugs and making arrangements to buy drugs — feeding the beast.”

headline: Chiquita Held Liable for Deaths During Colombian Civil War
abstract: A South Florida jury found the company liable for killings committed by a paramilitary group that was on the banana producer’s payroll.
lead_paragraph: A jury in South Florida has ruled that Chiquita Brands is liable for eight killings carried out by a right-wing paramilitary group that the company helped finance in a fertile banana-growing region of Colombia during the country’s decades-long internal conflict.

headline: Black Disney Princess Ride Replaces Splash Mountain and Its Racist History
abstract: The ride was closed last year because of its connection to a racist film. Disney overhauled it to focus on Tiana, Disney’s first Black princess, drawing praise and backlash.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2020, as a reckoning on racial justice swept the country, Disney said it would rip out Splash Mountain, a wildly popular flume ride with a racist back story.

headline: Here’s What Hunter Biden Was Convicted Of
abstract: The president’s son was convicted of three felonies tied to his purchase of a gun in 2018.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, was convicted on Tuesday of three felonies: lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, which carries a maximum penalty of 10 years in jail; making a false claim on the federal firearms application used to screen applicants, with a sentence of up to five years; and possession of an illegally obtained gun  from Oct. 12-23, 2018, which carries a maximum punishment of 10 years.

headline: Rapid Verdict Took Biden Family by Surprise as They Rushed to the Courtroom
abstract: Jurors in Delaware reached their verdict on the charges against Hunter Biden, the president’s son, after just three hours and five minutes of deliberations.
lead_paragraph: The speed of the verdict took nearly everyone by surprise — including the first lady, Jill Biden.

headline: After Trump Endorses his Rival, a Nevada Senate Candidate Lashes Out
abstract: Jeff Gunter, who is competing in the Nevada Senate Republican primary, said without evidence that “a big check” swayed the former president.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Gunter, who is competing in Tuesday’s Nevada Republican primary for the Senate and described himself as “110 percent pro-Trump,” saw Donald J. Trump endorse one of his primary opponents, Sam Brown, over the weekend. He did not take it well.

headline: Here’s a Look at the U.N.-Backed Plan to Stop the War in Gaza.
abstract: The Security Council can’t force anyone to adopt the plan, but its passage of a resolution backing it increases pressure on both sides to make a deal.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Monday endorsed a cease-fire plan for the Gaza Strip that is backed by the United States, adding weight to an international effort to end the eight-month war. Neither Israel nor Hamas has publicly accepted the plan, but Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken on Tuesday held talks in the region to press for its adoption.

headline: Judge Strikes Down Florida’s Ban on Transgender Care for Minors
abstract: A federal judge ruled that Florida could not “prohibit transgender minors from receiving specific kinds of widely accepted gender-affirming medical care.”
lead_paragraph: Key parts of a Florida law that bans gender transition care for minors and imposes hurdles on adults seeking such care are unconstitutional, a federal judge ruled on Tuesday.

headline: ‘Presumed Innocent’ Review: Disorder in the Court
abstract: Jake Gyllenhaal steps in for Harrison Ford in a new, highly strung adaptation of Scott Turow’s legal thriller for Apple TV+.
lead_paragraph: Scott Turow’s first novel, the 1987 best seller “Presumed Innocent,” is a clever murder mystery and courtroom drama with an 11th-hour twist. Before that denouement, it throws out red herrings to distract us, paralleling the strategy of its protagonist, Rusty Sabich, a prosecutor accused of killing the female colleague with whom he was having an affair. The 1990 film adaptation starring Harrison Ford necessarily condensed Turow’s plot but stayed true to its outlines and to the identity of the killer, a closely guarded secret through most of the story.

headline: No, a Remote Amazon Tribe Did Not Get Addicted to Porn
abstract: A Times story about the arrival of high-speed internet in a remote Amazon tribe spiraled into its own cautionary tale on the dark side of the web.
lead_paragraph: In April, I hiked more than 50 miles through the Amazon rainforest to visit the remote villages of the Marubo people. The 2,000-member tribe had recently received high-speed internet, and I wanted to understand how it had affected their lives.

headline: David Boaz, a Leading Voice of Libertarianism, Dies at 70
abstract: At the Cato Institute, he argued against government interference in Americans’ lives, including policing their drug use, and supported legal equality for gay people.
lead_paragraph: David Boaz, an apostle of “reasonable, radical libertarianism” who argued that Americans are entitled to pursue life, liberty and happiness without government meddling in their bedrooms or boardrooms or with their cannabis, died on Friday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 70.

headline: Fake Donations Helped a Candidate Get $162,000 From Taxpayers
abstract: New York’s new matching-funds campaign system rewards candidates who raise money from small donors, but weak oversight may already have led to abuses.
lead_paragraph: In the heart of Flushing, Queens, a second-floor apartment seemed to be a modest hotbed of interest in a local State Assembly race, with three family members donating small amounts of cash to an obscure Democrat, according to campaign records.

headline: A Textile Company That Wants You to Feel at Home
abstract: For its first U.S. store, Nordic Knots is meant to feel like the opposite of a design studio.
lead_paragraph: Some families take their textiles very seriously.

headline: The Most Endangered Marine Mammal Still Exists. Here’s the Latest Count.
abstract: Scientists and officials spent days at sea searching for vaquitas, shy porpoises threatened by fishing gear.
lead_paragraph: During a few weeks each year or so, an international team of scientists spends long days at sea searching for the most endangered marine mammal on Earth: the vaquita porpoise. The species is teetering on the edge of extinction, with recent surveys estimating around 10 individuals in the area where they’ve been considered most likely to live.

headline: Rock Around the Clock: 8 Songs About Very Specific Times of Day
abstract: Hear tracks by the Strokes, beabadoobee, Normani and more.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, the R&B artist and former Fifth Harmony member Normani will finally release her debut album, “Dopamine” — a long (long) awaited, endlessly delayed release she has been teasing for nearly six years. Not that I’ve been watching the clock. Or at least I wasn’t until last month, when Normani dropped the album’s sultry lead single, “1:59.” That ode to not-quite-2-in-the-morning got me dreaming up a playlist of songs about incredibly specific times of day. Now that Normani is ready to share her opus with the world, so am I.

headline: Judge Who Will Sentence Hunter Biden Kept Trial Moving
abstract: Maryellen Noreika didn’t set a sentencing date, but she said that it typically takes place within 120 days of a verdict.
lead_paragraph: The judge who oversaw Hunter Biden’s federal firearms case — and will ultimately decide his sentence — is Maryellen Noreika, a no-nonsense Trump appointee who uncovered holes in an earlier plea agreement and is the main reason he stood trial.

headline: Four Tops Singer Sues Hospital Over Being Put in Restraints
abstract: The lawsuit by Alexander Morris, who joined the group six years ago, said the staff thought he was “delusional” when he told them he was in the Motown band.
lead_paragraph: A singer who joined the storied Motown group the Four Tops in 2018 sued a Michigan hospital on Monday, accusing its staff of placing him in restraints and ordering a psychological evaluation because they did not believe he was part of the band.

headline: Alvin Bragg Will Testify to Congress After Trump’s Sentencing
abstract: The Manhattan district attorney and another prosecutor will confront questions next month from G.O.P. lawmakers about the Trump case.
lead_paragraph: Alvin L. Bragg, the Manhattan district attorney who won conviction of former President Donald J. Trump on 34 felony counts, plans to testify before Congress next month, one day after Mr. Trump is scheduled to be sentenced.

headline: Another Sugar Substitute Is Called Out for Potential Heart Risks
abstract: New research suggests the sweetener xylitol is linked to health issues. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: A new study linking the low-calorie sugar substitute xylitol to an increased risk of heart attack or stroke has once again raised questions about the risks and benefits of sugar substitutes.

headline: Will Hunter Biden Go to Jail? Here’s What His Sentence Could Look Like
abstract: The president’s son is a first-time offender who was not accused of using the weapon in another crime.
lead_paragraph: When the judge presiding over Hunter Biden’s federal gun trial sentences him, she will have to weigh a number of unusual factors specific to his case.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,089, June 12, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Hunter Biden’s Conviction in a Gun Case
abstract: The president’s son, who was convicted of three felonies, could face a stiffer sentence if he is convicted in a separate tax case scheduled for September.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, was found guilty on three felony counts related to buying a gun while he was in the throes of drug addiction. On Oct. 12, 2018, he filled out the required federal background check form, marking “no” to a question about his drug use.

headline: A New Way to Talk About Heat
abstract: Record-breaking temperatures are pushing experts and public health officials to come up with a new vocabulary to warn the public about extreme heat.
lead_paragraph: Last month was not only the hottest May on record, it was the 12th month in a row to earn such a distinction. But was it “stickier”?

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Hated Myself Because of the Way I Looked’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: “How will I know?” I asked my father before he died. “Talk to me like we are now and listen,” he said. Months passed. I was scared to talk to him. What if I didn’t hear him? On Father’s Day, running barefoot on the beach, I called out, “Dad?” The sharp edge of a shell sliced my foot. My father’s father was a podiatrist. My father was a poet who wrote endlessly about feet. He believed, “The soul is rooted in the foot.” Seven stitches, a beautiful scar. I feel hollow with loss, but my father is still with me. — Hannah Sward

headline: Hunter Biden Is Guilty. That’s OK.
abstract: You break the law, you pay the price. Why is that so hard?
lead_paragraph: As a rule, it is not a good thing for your son to be convicted of a crime, and particularly not when you are the sitting president in the heat of a brutal re-election campaign.

headline: Young Thug Lawyer Clashes With Judge in Chaotic Gang Case
abstract: Brian Steel, a lawyer for the Atlanta rapper, was ordered to serve 10 weekends in jail after a dispute with the judge, further complicating a messy gang conspiracy trial.
lead_paragraph: A star witness jailed for refusing to testify. A change of heart after a weekend spent behind bars. And then, a lead defense lawyer taken into custody for implying that an improper secret meeting led to the witness’s about-face.

headline: U.S. to Send Another Patriot Missile Battery to Ukraine
abstract: The system is one of the best air-defense weapons, but the United States and its allies have a limited supply.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has approved the deployment of another Patriot missile system to Ukraine, senior administration and military officials said, as the country struggles to fend off Russian attacks on its cities, infrastructure and electrical grid.

headline: By a Stream in Vermont, a Glimpse of a Plant Last Seen a Century Ago
abstract: “Are you sitting down?” Vermont’s state botanist asked a fellow plant expert after spotting false mermaid-weed last month.
lead_paragraph: For those who rarely search for anything beyond a misplaced set of keys or a cellphone, the life of a botanist might look impossibly poetic: combing through fields of wildflowers or perusing mossy riverbanks in search of elusive plants with names like handsome sedge and rough false pennyroyal.

headline: Restaurant Review: Penny, a Seafood Counter That Knows What It’s About
abstract: Almost everything on the menu at this sibling of Claud contains seafood. You sit at a counter to eat it. The only surprise is how well it all works together.
lead_paragraph: Chefs tend to load their first restaurants with every hope, dream, vision and idea they’ve ever had. It may not all come together, but if it comes close and if the ideas are any good, we can respond to the originality and overlook the weak spots.

headline: Macron’s Call for Elections in France Adds to Fears of Financial Woes
abstract: Moody’s ratings agency warned of a downgrade on French debt, saying the move could worsen France’s finances by creating “a polarized political environment.”
lead_paragraph: Investors made clear on Tuesday the depth of their concerns over President Emmanuel Macron’s gamble to call for new elections in France, driving up the nation’s borrowing costs, pushing down stock prices and prompting the Moody’s ratings agency to warn it may downgrade French sovereign debt as risks of political instability rise.

headline: Biden Addresses Gun-Control Group Hours After Son’s Firearms Conviction
abstract: “More children are killed in America by guns than cancer and car accidents combined,” President Biden said in a speech in Washington.
lead_paragraph: President Biden told the nation’s largest gun-control group on Tuesday that he had secured extensive reforms on firearms safety but acknowledged that he had not achieved several of his priorities.

headline: $16 Billion Hudson River Tunnel Project Gets Final Green Light
abstract: An agreement for the federal government to pay for most of the $16 billion project means the long-delayed plan is “all systems go,” Senator Chuck Schumer of New York said.
lead_paragraph: The planners of the $16 billion rail tunnel project known as Gateway said they passed the “point of no return” on Tuesday when the federal government told Congress that it would provide an additional $6.88 billion to the project.

headline: Paramount’s Merger Talks With Skydance Fall Apart
abstract: There were several hitches in the last week as Skydance, Paramount and its parent company, National Amusements, reached the final stages of negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Skydance’s merger talks with Paramount were called off Tuesday after Paramount’s controlling shareholder scuttled the deal, ending a drama that has captivated Hollywood for months.

headline: Ben Potter, Who Voiced Popular Comic Books on YouTube, Dies at 40
abstract: Mr. Potter narrated the epic sagas of popular comic book heroes and villains on his channel Comicstorian.
lead_paragraph: Ben Potter, a YouTube personality who built a following of millions with his dramatic readings of comic books, died on Saturday. He was 40.

headline: Robert De Niro Doesn’t Mind Being Celebrated
abstract: Blake Lively, Jude Law, Selma Blair and many more turned out for the Tribeca Film Festival’s annual artists dinner, ahead of a weekend devoted to Mr. De Niro’s work.
lead_paragraph: Outside the Odeon in Lower Manhattan on Monday night, the bistro’s famed neon sign peeked above a tent shielding celebrities from onlookers trying to glimpse the red carpet at the Tribeca Film Festival’s 17th annual artists dinner.

headline: Morrie Markoff, Listed as Oldest Man in the U.S., Dies at 110
abstract: A rare supercentenarian, he remained remarkably lucid after 11 decades, even maintaining a blog. His brain has been donated for research on what’s known as super-aging.
lead_paragraph: Morrie Markoff, a supercentenarian blogger and scrap-metal sculptor who was believed to be the oldest man in the United States and whose brain has been donated for research on what is known as super-aging, died on June 3 at his home in downtown Los Angeles. He was 110.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Hunter Biden Found Guilty on Gun Charges
abstract: Also, pressure on Israel and Hamas to reach a deal.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, was found guilty on three felony counts of lying on a federal firearms application. The verdict is a personal blow to President Biden as he enters the final months of his re-election campaign.

headline: Philanthropist Gets 15 Years to Life in Hit-and-Run Murder of 2 Boys
abstract: Prosecutors said Rebecca Grossman was driving a sport utility vehicle at more than 80 miles an hour just before she struck and killed Mark Iskander, 11, and his brother, Jacob, 8, in a crosswalk.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Monday sentenced a California philanthropist to 15 years to life in prison for murdering two children in a hit-and-run collision in a crosswalk while she was driving a Mercedes sport utility vehicle at more than 80 miles an hour, prosecutors said.

headline: Hunter Biden Found Guilty on Charges Related to Gun Purchase in 2018
abstract: The president’s son was convicted of three felonies during a trial that made his struggles with drug addiction painfully public.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Wilmington, Del., on Tuesday found Hunter Biden, President Biden’s son, guilty of three felony counts for lying on a federal firearms application, a shattering blow for the Biden family in the middle of an unforgiving presidential election campaign.

headline: Biden Talks About Gun Safety Hours After Son’s Firearms Conviction
abstract: President Biden spoke to the nation’s largest gun control group shortly after his son Hunter Biden was convicted in Delaware of three felony counts of lying on a federal firearms application in 2018.
lead_paragraph: President Biden spoke to the nation’s largest gun control group shortly after his son Hunter Biden was convicted in Delaware of three felony counts of lying on a federal firearms application in 2018.

headline: In ‘Devastating’ Split, a Famous Hot Dog Gobbler and Nathan’s Part Ways
abstract: Joey Chestnut had long been the face of the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest. Then he signed up to endorse a rival brand’s vegan dogs.
lead_paragraph: The world of competitive hot dog eating was torn asunder on Tuesday by a divorce of almost unimaginable proportions. Major League Eating, the governing body of whatever sort of sport this is, said it had been forced to part ways with Joey Chestnut, the long-reigning champion of its marquee event, the Nathan’s Famous Hot Dog Eating Contest.

headline: In Taped Remarks at Supreme Court Gala, Revealing Glimpses of Roberts and Alito
abstract: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr., once close allies, have embraced starkly different conceptions of the judicial role.
lead_paragraph: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. and Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. have long been a jarring study in contrasts. The chief justice is guarded, embodying a cautious and conventional conception of the judicial role. Justice Alito, an eager combatant in the culture wars, tests the limits of that behavior.

headline: Rare White Grizzly Dies After Being Struck on Canadian Highway
abstract: Grizzly Bear 178, or Nakoda, as she was known to her fans on social media, was hit in Yoho National Park, hours after her cubs were struck and killed in a separate accident, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A white grizzly bear known as Nakoda became a popular presence on social media since she first appeared in public near Banff National Park in the Canadian Rockies in 2020. Her frequent roadside appearances endeared her to visitors, who were enchanted by her rare blonde coat and the black streak running up her back.

headline: The President’s Son Was Convicted of Three Felonies
abstract: Also, age is on the ballot in North Dakota. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A jury in Wilmington, Del., today found Hunter Biden, the president’s son, guilty of three felony counts of lying on a federal firearms application in 2018. He could face up to 25 years in prison, but first-time offenders typically receive no jail time.

headline: Officials Condemn Protest Outside Exhibit Memorializing Oct. 7 Victims
abstract: Anti-Israel demonstrators gathered outside the exhibition in New York that honors people at a music festival in Israel who were killed in the Hamas attack.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people protested against Israel on Monday night outside an exhibition in Lower Manhattan that commemorates the more than 360 people who were killed by Hamas on Oct. 7 at a rave in southern Israel, prompting strong condemnations from public officials.

headline: Is That Dog Actually a … Human?
abstract: TikTok is onto goldendoodles, the designer dog breed that is a cross between golden retriever and poodle, noting that they exhibit quite a few person-like qualities.
lead_paragraph: He sits forlornly on a floating staircase, his body slightly slumped and his limbs in his lap, gazing out floor-to-ceiling windows into the summer foliage beyond. He seems to be contemplating something — perhaps the meaning of life itself — as the camera shifts around to the front to reveal his true condition. He’s not a man; he’s a goldendoodle.

headline: Man Charged With Using Racist Messaging Channel to Sell Guns From Prison
abstract: Manhattan prosecutors say Hayden Espinosa operated through a white-supremacist channel on Telegram that they discovered after a racist massacre in Buffalo.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man was charged on Tuesday with selling firearms and parts through an online channel that promoted white-supremacist beliefs even as he was serving time in a Louisiana federal prison on previous gun charges.

headline: A Guilty Verdict for Hunter Biden Weighs on a Worried President Biden
abstract: The president, who is in the middle of a re-election fight, has grown more resigned and afraid about what the future might hold for his son, according to people close to them.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden was waiting for his father on the tarmac.

headline: You Need to Make Time for Your Friends. Here’s How.
abstract: Today’s challenge: Use your calendar to balance friendships and other priorities.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 3 of the 5-Day Friendship Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: At D-Day Ceremonies, Thinking of One Veteran Who Wouldn’t Return
abstract: While covering the 80th anniversary of the Allied invasion in northern France, a Times reporter remembers a family member.
lead_paragraph: I found myself getting emotional these past few weeks, covering the D-Day commemorations and celebrations in Normandy.

headline: Opponents of Hochul’s Move to Halt Congestion Pricing May Go to Court
abstract: The New York City comptroller, Brad Lander, and a group of stakeholders have developed a legal strategy to overturn Gov. Kathy Hochul’s shutdown of the Midtown toll program.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York may believe she has the power to unilaterally shut down the nation’s first congestion pricing scheme, which was slated to pump $1 billion a year into the coffers of the nation’s largest transit system.

headline: Elon Musk Withdraws His Lawsuit Against OpenAI and Sam Altman
abstract: The Tesla chief executive had claimed that the A.I. start-up put profits and commercial interests ahead of benefiting humanity.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk withdrew his lawsuit on Tuesday against OpenAI, the maker of the online chatbot ChatGPT, a day before a state judge in San Francisco was set to consider whether it should be dismissed.

headline: Hunter Biden Conviction Undercuts a Trump Narrative, and a Fund-Raising Pitch
abstract: Many allies of Donald J. Trump had secretly wanted an acquittal, which they predicted would have turbocharged fund-raising and fed their claims of a rigged justice system.
lead_paragraph: The moment had finally come. Late Tuesday morning, nearly five years after Republicans first went after Hunter Biden, the president’s son could finally be called a convicted felon.

headline: Norman Carol, Violinist in Historic Concert in China, Is Dead at 95
abstract: The concertmaster and first-chair violinist with the Philadelphia Orchestra for decades, he took part in a diplomatic breakthrough in 1973 with concerts in Mao Zedong’s Beijing.
lead_paragraph: Norman Carol, a former violin prodigy who was first chair and concertmaster for the acclaimed Philadelphia Orchestra for nearly three decades, accompanying it on a history-making trip to China under Mao Zedong in 1973, died on April 28. He was 95.

headline: Biden Proposes Dropping Medical Debt From Credit Reports
abstract: The move would offer relief to millions of Americans who need a better credit score to get an apartment or a car, but it would not wipe out their financial obligations.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Tuesday proposed removing medical debt from the credit reports of more than 15 million Americans, making it easier for them to qualify for car, home and small-business loans.

headline: The Most Courageous Thing That Joe Biden Can Do
abstract: Israel, Ukraine and American democracy are on the line.
lead_paragraph: In 1977, Ronald Reagan shared his thoughts on the Cold War with his aide Richard Allen. “My idea of American policy toward the Soviet Union is simple, and some would say simplistic,” the future president said. “It is this: We win, and they lose. What do you think of that?”

headline: Hamas and Israel Face Pressure to Embrace Cease-Fire Adopted by U.N.
abstract: Despite positive statements and international urging, neither of the warring parties accepted a U.S.-backed plan to halt the war in Gaza, let displaced Palestinians go home and free hostages.
lead_paragraph: A day after the United Nations Security Council endorsed a U.S.-backed cease-fire proposal for the Gaza Strip, the focus shifted on Tuesday to the willingness of Israel and Hamas, under growing international pressure to end the war, to make a deal.

headline: Alito’s ‘Godliness’ Comment Echoes a Broader Christian Movement
abstract: Justice Samuel Alito’s secretly recorded remarks come as many conservatives have openly embraced the view that American democracy must be grounded in a Christian worldview.
lead_paragraph: It’s a phrase not commonly associated with legal doctrine: returning America to “a place of godliness.”

headline: Convictions of Biden’s Son and Trump Put the Justice System on Trial
abstract: But despite the partisan roar, two juries appeared to seriously weigh the evidence and deliver verdicts. The system seemed to work as it is supposed to.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump and his Republican allies have sought to delegitimize criminal investigations into his actions by declaring that Democrats have “weaponized” the justice system. That claim only intensified after a jury convicted Mr. Trump last month of 34 felonies in a hush-money case.

headline: Charity Founder Embezzled Millions and Spent on Lavish Meals, U.S. Says
abstract: Prosecutors say that Keith Taylor, head of Modest Needs, crowdsourced donations for the poor but spent hundreds of thousands of dollars at high-end restaurants.
lead_paragraph: The head of a charity called Modest Needs was charged Tuesday with embezzling $2.5 million to rent a Columbus Circle high-rise, have cosmetic surgery and dine regularly at some of Manhattan’s most expensive restaurants.

headline: Pope Francis Is Accused of Using a Homophobic Slur Again
abstract: Two prominent Italian news agencies said the pontiff used the term on Tuesday during a meeting with priests, after he was accused of uttering the same word last month while speaking with Italian bishops.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis repeated an anti-gay slur during a meeting with priests in Rome on Tuesday, Italian news outlets reported, the same offensive term he was accused of using two weeks ago.

headline: Participant in Jan. 6 Riot Loses Primary Race in South Carolina
abstract: The defeat of Elias Irizarry is the latest in a number of losses that riot participants have suffered at the ballot box in recent months.
lead_paragraph: A 22-year-old who participated in the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol lost his bid to unseat a Republican incumbent in the South Carolina House of Representatives.

headline: Nancy Mace Defeats G.O.P. Challenger, Dealing Blow to McCarthy’s Revenge Tour
abstract: The South Carolina congresswoman turned back a primary challenger backed by former Speaker Kevin McCarthy, who has been trying to exact retribution against Republicans who voted to oust him.
lead_paragraph: Representative Nancy Mace, Republican of South Carolina, on Tuesday defeated a well-funded primary challenger, putting her on track to win a third term. Her resounding victory also dealt a major blow to former Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s efforts to exact political retribution against those who voted to oust him.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Laptop, Revealed by New York Post, Comes Back to Haunt Him
abstract: Many claims about the laptop’s contents have not been proved, but it played a role in the prosecution of Mr. Biden over a firearm purchase.
lead_paragraph: When The New York Post first reported in 2020 about a laptop once used by Hunter Biden — which the paper said contained incriminating evidence against him and his father, Joseph R. Biden Jr., who was running for president — it set off a firestorm.

headline: Congressman Wins G.O.P. Nomination for North Dakota Governor
abstract: Representative Kelly Armstrong will be a strong favorite to win the general election and succeed Gov. Doug Burgum, who did not seek a third term.
lead_paragraph: Representative Kelly Armstrong won the Republican nomination for governor of North Dakota, The Associated Press said on Tuesday, defeating the state’s lieutenant governor, Tammy Miller, and positioning himself as the strong favorite in the general election.

headline: Senior Hezbollah Commander Is Killed in Israeli Strike
abstract: The commander was among the highest-ranking Hezbollah fighters in Lebanon to have been killed in the eight-month-long conflict, a Lebanese official said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli forces killed a senior Hezbollah commander in a strike in southern Lebanon late Tuesday, stoking concerns about an escalation of the conflict on another Israeli front.

headline: Obstacle to Change
abstract: Simeon Seigel stoops to conquer.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: North Dakotans Approve Age Limit for Members of Congress
abstract: A ballot measure left voters to decide whether 81 is too old for some political jobs. It was one state’s answer to an issue that has been a focus of national debate this election cycle.
lead_paragraph: Voters in North Dakota approved a ballot measure that sets a maximum age for representing the state in Congress, The Associated Press said on Tuesday. Experts said they believed North Dakota was the first state to impose such a requirement on members of Congress, though they said the measure is likely to be challenged in court.

headline: BTS Fans Rejoice: Jin, Its Eldest Member, Completes Military Service
abstract: The K-pop group is still on hiatus until 2025, when the last of its members finish their mandatory enlistment in South Korea’s military. But the celebrating has begun.
lead_paragraph: The K-pop juggernaut BTS is one step closer to a reunion.

headline: Sam Brown Wins Nevada G.O.P. Senate Race, and Will Face Rosen in November
abstract: After losing in a Senate primary in 2022, Mr. Brown, an Army veteran, was the pick of establishment Republicans from the start of the 2024 race.
lead_paragraph: Sam Brown, an Army veteran who was the heavy favorite in the Nevada Republican primary race for Senate even before former President Donald J. Trump’s last-minute endorsement, won the nomination on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Dire Economy Brings Nigeria Vast Hardship
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “There’s still very little clarity — if any — on where the economy is headed, what the priorities are.”

headline: Corrections: June 12, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 12, 2024.
lead_paragraph: A quiz last Wednesday about food trademarks misstated the lawyer David Perry’s role in the Cronut trademark. He represents the owner of the trademark, but he did not help secure it. That was done by another lawyer, Candice Cook Simmons.

headline: One Dead After Rush-Hour Hijacking of Commuter Bus in Atlanta
abstract: A suspect, Joseph Grier, 39, was taken into custody. No other injuries were reported among the 17 people on the bus.
lead_paragraph: One person is dead after a gunman hijacked a commuter bus in Atlanta on Tuesday with 17 passengers aboard, leading police on a miles-long, rush-hour chase that spanned several counties, officials said.

headline: ‘Just Disillusioned’: How U.K. Conservatives Lost a New Heartland
abstract: At Britain’s last election, the Tories laid claim to a swath of postindustrial England. Now voters there are returning to Labour, and the insurgent Reform U.K. is also rising.
lead_paragraph: On a hilltop next to a vast limestone quarry in England’s East Midlands, a crowd of about 60 people gathered last Thursday evening to witness the lighting of a beacon to mark the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings. Amid the drab parkas and pullovers was a figure in a striking red coat: Natalie Fleet, the Labour Party’s candidate for Parliament, wearing her party’s campaign color.

headline: Every Dollar Counts. To Pay for the War, Ukraine Embraces Privatization
abstract: The government hopes to sell off a range of companies to fund the military and stabilize the economy as the grueling conflict with Russia drains its coffers.
lead_paragraph: Towering over Kyiv for six decades, Hotel Ukraine has witnessed some pivotal moments in Ukraine’s recent history.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Hunter Biden found guilty.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden, son of the president, was found guilty on three felony counts related to his lying about his illegal drug use when he bought a gun in 2018. The verdict is a shattering blow to the Biden family in the middle of an unforgiving presidential campaign.

headline: Muggings, Murders and Mob Justice: Violent Crime Roars Back in Karachi
abstract: A decade after militant and criminal groups were pushed out, Pakistan’s economic powerhouse and most populous city is facing a startling rise in deadly street crime.
lead_paragraph: The terrifying stories are sprawled across local newspapers and recounted in hushed tones at tea stalls and bus stands: another day, another brutal death during an armed robbery in Karachi, Pakistan’s largest city.

headline: Israel’s North Is Burning
abstract: A cease-fire deal in Gaza might halt a war between Israel and Hezbollah.
lead_paragraph: On the night of June 3, vast parts of northern Israel went up in flames after Hezbollah fired rockets on the area. The raging fires burned more than 3,000 acres.

headline: Word of the Day: haphazardly
abstract: This word has appeared in 54 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word haphazardly has appeared in 54 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 20 in “How to Clean Up After Thanksgiving Dinner Like a Pro” by Genevieve Ko:

headline: Late Night Riffs on Hunter Biden’s Guilty Verdict
abstract: “Wow, frankly, I’m shocked — we’re actually enforcing gun laws in America,” Jordan Klepper said on Tuesday’s “Daily Show.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: A Public Housing Playground Barred Outsiders. Neighbors Objected.
abstract: Signs put up at Wise Towers say the playground is only for residents. There have been tense encounters with some neighbors on the wealthy, liberal Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: At the new playground on the Upper West Side, children clamber over a rocket-shaped jungle gym, spin on a tire swing and splash and scream among water sprinklers.

headline: New York City Might Finally Curb Broker Fees for Renters
abstract: A majority of the City Council supports a bill that would transfer the cost of most broker fees from renters to landlords.
lead_paragraph: It is an expensive New York City rite of passage that greets generations of renters eager to find an apartment: the dreaded broker fee.

headline: In Nevada, an Exercise in Trust and Empathy
abstract: Eli Saslow reported from a tiny, remote county where a Republican election clerk and Donald J. Trump supporters are at odds.
lead_paragraph: The best part about my job as a reporter for The New York Times is that it pushes me far outside of my bubble and into the far-flung parts of the United States. Already this year, I have reported from a remote ice fishing cabin in Minnesota and a dusty border ranch in Arizona. But rarely have I been anywhere as remote as Esmeralda County, Nev., where I spent several days in April and May reporting an article about election denialism that was published online last week.

headline: U.N. Report Accuses Both Israel and Palestinian Groups of War Crimes
abstract: A commission produced the United Nations’ most detailed examination yet of the Oct. 7 attacks and the subsequent war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations commission investigating the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel and the subsequent conflict in Gaza has accused both Palestinian armed groups and Israel of committing war crimes, and the panel said that Israel’s conduct of the war included crimes against humanity.

headline: How an Officer’s Social Media Posts About Work Harassment Led to Her Firing
abstract: A Toronto police officer mounted a defiant social media campaign against her employer. The police ruled that she had tried to destroy the agency’s reputation.
lead_paragraph: Her 10th anniversary as a Toronto police officer was approaching, but Firouzeh Zarabi-Majd was in no mood to celebrate. Embittered by the years of sexual harassment she said that she and her fellow female officers had experienced at work, she was engaged in a one-woman campaign to make her case public across Canada.

headline: A 20-Minute Core Workout for Strength and Stability
abstract: This series of exercises focuses on important muscles in the legs and torso we use every day. No equipment (and very little space) necessary.
lead_paragraph: A good strength workout should check a lot of boxes. It should improve your metabolism, challenge your body and leave you feeling good. But it should also make you feel stable on your feet and able to move freely.

headline: The Miniature Secrets of Championship Rings
abstract: More diamonds isn’t enough. One jeweler is wowing sports teams with reversible faces and detachable compartments.
lead_paragraph: As sports fans enjoy the legacy-defining moments of this month’s N.B.A. finals and Stanley Cup finals, Jason Arasheben is studying like a college student before exams.

headline: A Dark, Eruptive Force Hides Within These Inviting Fables
abstract: Adam Ehrlich Sachs reveals a society on the verge of cataclysm in his new novel, “Gretel and the Great War.”
lead_paragraph: Interwar Austria — baroque, violent, demented, doomed — flickers into view in Adam Ehrlich Sachs’s new novel, “Gretel and the Great War.” No staid work of history, this. Sachs draws from the madcap, darkly comic tradition of postmodern European fiction to reimagine the continent’s catastrophic destiny.

headline: At the Ambani Wedding Celebrations, a Dazzling Display of Jewels
abstract: Emeralds almost the size of Popsicles, ropes of the rarest natural pearls and rani haar pieces studded with diamonds were throwbacks to the time of maharajahs.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India abruptly changed her country’s constitution in 1971 and abolished the Privy Purse, a government allowance for the country’s former princely rulers, she also moved to nationalize their storied treasuries. Among the maharajahs, nizams and nabobs that once ruled the subcontinent, this set off a frenzy as they scurried to bury the family jewels.

headline: New Historical Fiction: Witch Hunts, Wartime and Mysterious Murders
abstract: This trio of novels ushers readers into three different but equally mesmerizing long-ago worlds.
lead_paragraph: The island of Berggrund is only an hour’s sail from the mainland, but in 1825 its superstitious inhabitants are as detached from the larger currents of Swedish life as they were 150 years earlier, when the community’s priest ordered most of its women put to death for witchcraft. Anna Noyes’s haunting first novel, THE BLUE MAIDEN (Grove, 240 pp., $26), explores the sinister effects of this legacy on the two daughters of Silas, the island’s current pastor, a descendant of one of the few women to be spared.

headline: A Prodigy of Jazz Clubs Explores Other Stages
abstract: The multi-instrumentalist Julius Rodriguez hones a bigger, more audacious sound on his second album, “Evergreen.”
lead_paragraph: Sitting outside a bar in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn one recent Sunday afternoon, Julius Rodriguez spoke with characteristic straightforwardness describing music that is anything but. The composer and bandleader, who has played with the rapper ASAP Rocky and style-bending artists like Kassa Overall and Meshell Ndegeocello, articulated the central challenge of his work, an amorphous blend of jazz, funk, gospel and R&B he simply calls “the music.”

headline: No Cars, No Crowds: 100 Years of Solitude in the New Mexico Wilderness
abstract: The Gila Wilderness, home to wolves, mountain lions and other wildlife, marks a century as a ‘land lab,’ where nature thrives as far as the eye can see.
lead_paragraph: On a crisp spring morning, I trusted a horse — a bay named Sino — to show me the vast Gila Wilderness of southern New Mexico. Red rock walls rose beside us as we wove back and forth across a shallow creek separating ponderosa pine on the shady south side of Rocky Canyon from barrel cactus in the cliff crevasses on the desertlike north face. I leaned against his neck as Sino climbed a steep ridge that led to a hilltop savannah of pinyon, juniper and groves of tentacled cane cholla cactus tipped in faded yellow fruit. Surrounding them, forested mountains were unblemished by buildings or roads.

headline: The Perfect Cake Does Not Exi … Is That Buttermilk Tres Leches?
abstract: An Appalachian twist on a classic Latin American dessert connects cultures and identities for a pastry chef.
lead_paragraph: To make a stodgy cake is human. To soak that cake in sweet milk is divine.

headline: All in the Details: Tony-Nominated Set Designers on Getting It Right
abstract: For this year’s nominees, some of their most rewarding — and realistic — work was in the smaller details.
lead_paragraph: What are all those buttons for?

headline: The Best Dressed People in Hollywood Are Not the Actors
abstract: Cinephiles can’t seem to help obsessing over their favorite filmmakers’ personal style.
lead_paragraph: Last month, while perusing a copy of the book “How Directors Dress” — a collection newly published by the entertainment company A24 — I came across a striking full-page photograph of the filmmaker David Cronenberg. It was taken at the 2014 Cannes Film Festival, where Cronenberg accented an otherwise-formal outfit with a pair of oversize wraparound sunglasses designed for mountaineering. These white-framed, gogglelike shades have since become a signature accessory for the director, who has worn them at Cannes so often that audiences there sometimes applaud when he puts them on. In late May, one video making the rounds on social media captured the moment when a standing ovation for Cronenberg’s latest film was briefly hijacked by cheers for the sunglasses.

headline: Diplo’s Jamaica
abstract: The Grammy-winning D.J. and music producer recommends spots in a city he loves on Jamaica’s northeast coast. A dance party makes the cut.
lead_paragraph: Diplo, born Thomas Wesley Pentz, fell in love with Jamaica, particularly its Portland parish on the northeast coast, nearly 20 years ago. “I was D.J.ing on a cruise ship, got off in Ocho Rios, and drove through Port Antonio to get to Kingston,” said the  multiple-Grammy nominee and winner who has collaborated with Dua Lipa, Sturgill Simpson, Snoop Dogg, Shakira, Bad Bunny and countless other musicians. “Portland is sort of like Costa Rica, all jungly and waterfalls. And Port Antonio is this quaint little town where I’d go on a sort of retreat, “Mr. Pentz added. About eight years ago he bought some farmland and built a house there.

headline: Our Desire for Inexpensive Food Is Putting Us in Danger
abstract: Factory farming increases the risks for epidemics.
lead_paragraph: A dairy worker in Texas contracts H5N1 bird flu after contact with infected cows, and suffers eye inflammation. Weeks later, a dairy worker in Michigan begins to cough and then tests positive for the virus. A ferret in a cage (ferrets are often used as study proxies for humans) becomes infected with the virus by airborne transmission from a sick ferret in a nearby cage. These data and other recent cases of H5N1 suggest that the virus might be evolving to spread more easily to — and among — people.

headline: The 1990s Were Weirder Than You Think. We’re Feeling the Effects.
abstract: In “When the Clock Broke,” John Ganz shows how a decade remembered as one of placid consensus was roiled by resentment, unrest and the rise of the radical right.
lead_paragraph: Some truly strange stuff was afoot in the 1990s. Yes, the early part of the decade marked the end of the Cold War and the beginning of Clintonian “triangulation,” giving the impression of a bland consensus coalescing around a political middle. This smooth hum of stability stands in obvious contrast to our current plight of fracture and chaos.

headline: You Decided to Become a Mother. What Happened Next?
abstract: Times Opinion wants to hear about the challenges women face when they decide to become mothers.
lead_paragraph: Whether to become a mother, and how to go about it, can be one of the most consequential decisions a woman can make. Women today contend with personal, professional, biological and financial pressures that may constrain their choices.

headline: Buyers Snap Up Aging and Empty Office Buildings for Deep Discounts
abstract: Bargain hunters are getting deals of up to 70 percent, a sign of the pain in the commercial property market that could lead to large losses for banks and investors in real-estate-backed loans.
lead_paragraph: A perfect storm of plunging property values for aging buildings, weak tenant demand coming out of the pandemic and high interest rates for new loans and refinancing has left the $2.4 trillion office building sector wobbling.

headline: Who Am I Without My Voice?
abstract: I was a singer heading out on tour. Losing my voice was terrifying — but it ended up teaching me everything about myself.
lead_paragraph: The serious trouble started on Christmas Eve, upstate with family. The Puerto Rican side does not alternate talking and listening — each is done in spirited unison. I was speaking too loudly over other stories and my own glass of wine, fighting a head cold and getting gravelly. My boyfriend, Benjamin, caught my eye across the room, touched his hand to his throat and made his face into a question mark, What’s wrong with your voice? But we’d brought a homemade cake — he baked, I decorated — that people were freaking out about, and I didn’t want to leave before the compliments were over. I’m a professional touring musician, so I miss a fair share of the holiday gatherings, and this was the first meeting between the boyfriend and most of the assembled relatives. He’s 10 years older but boyish — tousled hair, slender, animated, a mess of bad tattoos — and I wanted to spin him around for all to see how clever and how kind.

headline: I’m a Conservative. We Need to Make the Environment Nonpartisan.
abstract: To save a warming planet, both parties must change.
lead_paragraph: Climate change is a deeply divisive issue in modern American politics, but that wasn’t always the case. Today, progressivism is often associated with environmental action, but not long ago the Republican Party equated conservatism with conservation.

headline: Jessica Lange and Paula Vogel on Breaking, and Keeping, the Family Contract
abstract: In the Tony-nominated “Mother Play,” the writer conjures warm memories and thorny ones, not to judge her mother, but to understand — and to forgive.
lead_paragraph: It is one of life’s great strokes of luck to have an excellent mother. The playwright Paula Vogel didn’t get one. The actress Jessica Lange did: sweet and nurturing, accepting of her children, the kind of mom the other kids wished was theirs.

headline: Losing a Bridge Upends Life in Baltimore (and It May Soon Get Worse)
abstract: Congestion has increased on other routes in the city and residents are worried that traffic will get worse as the port returns to more normal operations.
lead_paragraph: Frank’s Bay Tavern in the neighborhood of South Baltimore — house cocktail: the grain alcohol Bay Slinger — has been hit hard by the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge.

headline: From Protester to Joining Bill Murray in ‘Enemy of the People’
abstract: Nate Smith, an actor and activist, will have a role in a production organized by Theater of War Productions on the TKTS Times Square steps.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at a performance of “An Enemy of the People,” which will feature an actor who disrupted the actual Broadway production. We’ll also look at the green light for the Gateway project under the Hudson River.

headline: Pasta Nada: The Culinary Art of Making Something From Nothing
abstract: A quick spin through the pantry can produce a dinner to remember.
lead_paragraph: In John Guare’s play “Six Degrees of Separation,” there’s a scene in which a father asks a second-grade teacher, at parents’ night, why the art her students make is so especially brilliant. “Look at the first grade,” he says to her.

headline: The Fed Holds Rates Steady and Predicts Just One Reduction This Year
abstract: Federal Reserve officials signaled that interest rates could stay higher this year as policymakers pause to ensure they’ve stamped out inflation.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged at their June meeting on Wednesday and predicted that they will cut borrowing costs just once before the end of 2024, taking a cautious approach as they try to avoid declaring a premature victory over inflation.

headline: Brooklyn’s Best Vintage Bookstore Is in His Living Room
abstract: Bill Hall, the proprietor, has assembled a vast collection of hard-to-find fashion books and magazines coveted by designers and influencers.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Sunday, few moments passed when Bill Hall wasn’t answering his home’s buzzer. He led a succession of fashionable Brooklynites through his entryway and into his sunny living room, which is lined with vintage fashion magazines, photo books from Guy Bourdin and Ron Jude and obscure German design quarterlies.

headline: Trump Would Be Long Gone if Only We Could …
abstract: It was never going to be easy to get voters to abandon their hero.
lead_paragraph: A central predicament of President Biden’s campaign is how to persuade voters to abandon Donald Trump.

headline: A Big Whack That Made the Moon May Have Also Created Continents That Move
abstract: Computer simulations suggest that a collision with another planetary object early in Earth’s history may have provided the heat to set off plate tectonics.
lead_paragraph: Some 4.5 billion years ago, many scientists say, Earth had a meetup with Theia, another planetary object the size of Mars. When the two worlds collided in a big whack, the thinking goes, debris shot into space, got locked into the orbit of the young, damaged Earth and led to the formation of our moon.

headline: At the G7, Biden Will Push for Frozen Russian Assets to Help Ukraine
abstract: President Biden faces the hurdle of convincing his allies that the United States plans to stay in the fight with Ukraine, no matter what happens in November.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after President Biden reversed himself and approved firing American weapons into Russian territory, he and his closest allies are preparing a different kind of assault, using the proceeds from Russia’s own financial assets to aid the reconstruction of Ukraine.

headline: At Home With - Brian d’Arcy James
abstract: Where the Tony nominee takes refuge: a “sweet little house” on five bosky acres in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Where the Tony nominee takes refuge: a “sweet little house” on five bosky acres in Connecticut.

headline: Inflation Slowed in May, Good News for Consumers and the Fed
abstract: The latest data could help to restore policymakers’ conviction that inflation is in the process of returning to the Federal Reserve’s goal.
lead_paragraph: Just hours before the release of the Federal Reserve’s latest rate decision, fresh inflation data showed that price increases slowed notably in May.

headline: On Canal Street, Fake Bags That Are Not for Sale
abstract: A new exhibition that looks like a store is meant to draw attention to the prevalence of “superfake” handbags.
lead_paragraph: Peering through the windows of the storefront at the corner of Broadway and Canal Street, it might seem like just another upscale boutique. Inside, luxury handbags — Dior’s Lady D-lite, Louis Vuitton’s Loop, Loewe’s Puzzle bag, Telfar’s Shopping Bag, and several Hermès Birkins among them — are arranged on a grid of white shelves and lit like individual works of art.

headline: Republicans Push Through Contempt of Congress Citation Against Garland
abstract: The attorney general has refused Republican demands to turn over audio recordings by the special counsel who investigated the president’s handling of classified documents.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Wednesday muscled through a measure recommending that Attorney General Merrick B. Garland be held in contempt of Congress for failing to comply with a subpoena.

headline: Connections Quiz: Can you connect the art to the puzzle?
abstract: Every day, Calum Heath publishes a unique illustration inspired by that day’s Connections puzzle. Can you match the words to the art?
lead_paragraph: Every day, Calum Heath publishes a unique illustration inspired by that day’s Connections puzzle. Can you match the words to the art?
