headline: Young Women Are Fleeing Organized Religion. This Was Predictable.
abstract: They’re increasingly identifying as feminist at the same time that some denominations are drawing conservative lines in the sand.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Draut, 28, was raised Christian in Kentucky. Her parents took her and her sister to nondenominational megachurches that adhered to a lot of Baptist and Pentecostal ideals, she said. As a kid, she loved the way every service felt “like a concert,” filled with music and light, and she made loads of friends through church. She went to Berry College in rural Georgia, a place that she described as “steeped in Southern culture, where religion is incredibly important.”

headline: If Not in New York, Then Where?
abstract: The city was the best-case scenario for congestion pricing. What does it mean that the plan was shelved?
lead_paragraph: Here is what the indefinite pause on New York City’s congestion pricing program, if it sticks, will cost: 120,000 more cars daily clogging Lower Manhattan’s bumper-to-bumper streets, according to a New York State analysis, and perhaps $20 billion annually in additional lost productivity and fuel and operating costs, as well as health and environmental burdens and a practically unbridgeable budget shortfall for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that will straitjacket an already handicapped agency and imperil dozens of planned necessary capital improvement projects for the city’s aging subway system.

headline: ‘Bridgerton’ Is Back (Again). Here’s Where Things Left Off.
abstract: Colin Bridgerton and Penelope Featherington are on their way to a happy ending — but Lady Whistledown is still a huge barrier in this “friends to lovers” story.
lead_paragraph: The first half of “Bridgerton” Season 3 left viewers on a cliffhanger — and a little hot and bothered — with Colin Bridgerton and Penelope Featherington finally giving in to their desires in the very climactic Carriage Scene.

headline: How Do You Use Water to Stay Cool at Home During the Summer? We Want to Know.
abstract: Sprinklers? Kiddie pools? What’s your creative solution to find respite from sweltering heat?
lead_paragraph: Summer is almost in full swing and New York is heating up. As the temperatures rise, we want to know how New Yorkers are staying cool — specifically, with water.

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in Colorado, California and Massachusetts
abstract: A Craftsman bungalow in Denver, a midcentury-modern home in Riverside and an 1841 Cape Cod house in Newburyport.
lead_paragraph: This house is in Park Hill, a neighborhood known for its wide, tree-lined streets and well-maintained early 20th-century homes. It is next to a small park with a playground, and within a five-minute walk of a coffee shop, several restaurants and an Italian grocery store and deli. A public elementary school and a public library are within a 10-minute walk.

headline: Ben Carson as Trump’s Running Mate? Don’t Count Him Out Just Yet.
abstract: The retired neurosurgeon and former housing secretary is a wild card in the vice-presidential sweepstakes. His main advantage is that Donald Trump genuinely likes him.
lead_paragraph: Just about the only person who shows any interest in Ben Carson as the Republican vice-presidential nominee is the one whose opinion matters the most: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Ukraine Says It Shot Down Most of a Russian Missile and Drone Barrage
abstract: Drawing on replenished supplies, Ukraine used mostly Western-provided air defense systems to deter the overnight assault.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine said on Wednesday that it had drawn on stocks of antiaircraft missiles recently replenished by the United States and other allies to shoot down 29 of 30 missiles and exploding drones that Russia had fired at the country in an overnight barrage.

headline: A Palestinian Professor Spoke Out Against the Gaza War. Israel Detained Her.
abstract: The investigation of Prof. Nadera Shalhoub-Kevorkian of Hebrew University has prompted a debate inside Israel about the repression of free speech and academic freedoms since the war began.
lead_paragraph: Nadera Shalhoub-Kevorkian, a Palestinian professor at a prominent Israeli university, first waded into the debate over the Gaza war by joining academics worldwide in signing a letter that called for a cease-fire. It branded Israel’s assault on the territory a “genocide” and the leaders of her university responded by urging her to resign.

headline: European Union Hits E.V.s From China With Extra Tariffs Up to 38%
abstract: Leaders in Brussels, Washington and beyond are trying to curb China’s automobile ambitions amid rising trade tensions and fears of a glut of Chinese cars flooding global markets.
lead_paragraph: The European Union said on Wednesday that it would impose additional tariffs of up to 38 percent on electric vehicles imported from China into the bloc, in what E.U. leaders called an effort to protect the region’s manufacturers from unfair competition.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,090, June 13, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 368, June 13, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Criminal Conviction of Hunter Biden
abstract: The president’s son was found guilty of three felony counts for lying on a federal firearms application.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Tuesday found Hunter Biden, President Biden’s son, guilty of three felonies related to the purchase of a gun at one of the low points of his troubled life.

headline: New U.N. War Crimes Accusations, and the Fed’s Plan for Rates
abstract: Plus, a major split in the hot dog world.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: West Wilson of ‘Summer House’ Discusses His First Taste of Infamy
abstract: When Mr. Wilson was accused on the reunion of misleading Ciara Miller, his castmate and former romantic interest, fan backlash was swift.
lead_paragraph: When a 28-year-old unemployed journalist named Westling Wilson, who goes by West, was enthusiastically embraced by Bravo fans during his first season on the reality TV show “Summer House” this year, it made some wonder: Could he keep the good vibes going?

headline: The Force Shaping Western Politics
abstract: We cover immigration’s role in European and U.S. politics.
lead_paragraph: The recent elections for the European Parliament are the latest sign of the political potency of immigration. ​The elections’ biggest winners were right-wing parties that promised to reduce the flow of migration.

headline: Hezbollah Launches Rocket Barrage After Israeli Strike Kills a Commander
abstract: Around 215 rockets were launched from Lebanon into northern Israel in an apparent response to the strike, Israeli army radio said. There were no immediate reports of casualties.
lead_paragraph: The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah fired one of its heaviest rocket barrages yet into Israel on Wednesday, targeting military bases and an arms factory, in response to an overnight strike that killed one of its senior commanders as tensions rise further at the border.

headline: Why the Paramount Deal Talks Failed
abstract: After months of negotiations, Shari Redstone walked away from a tie-up with SkyDance. Here’s how a plan to reshape the media conglomerate broke apart.
lead_paragraph: For months, Skydance Media’s effort to merge with Paramount — the studio behind “Mission: Impossible” and “Top Gun” — was the most-discussed M.&A. matter on Wall Street and in Hollywood. Now it has fallen apart.

headline: Food Inflation Eased Again, Welcome News for Shoppers
abstract: Although food price gains have cooled, prices remain much higher than they were several years ago, squeezing consumers.
lead_paragraph: Food inflation continued to moderate on an annual basis in May, providing some welcome news for consumers who have been feeling the pinch at the grocery store.

headline: Fire in Kuwait Worker Housing Leaves at Least 49 Dead
abstract: The blaze struck a building that was home to scores of low-paid migrant workers, many of them from India.
lead_paragraph: At least 49 people were killed and dozens of others injured in the Persian Gulf country of Kuwait, the state news agency said, when a fire broke out on Wednesday in a building that housed scores of low-income workers, many of them Indian nationals.

headline: Rare Battlefield War Crimes Case Reaches Sentencing Phase at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: An Iraqi prisoner admitted to conspiring with Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda. But his case is an outlier at the Guantánamo court.
lead_paragraph: Twenty years ago, when the Eggers family of Cape Coral, Fla., got the devastating news that their eldest son had been killed in Afghanistan, they did what Gold Star families do.

headline: Why Did My Wife’s Sister Confess to Taking Her Clothes 50 Years Later?
abstract: Stung by the revelation that her sister frequently took her clothing without permission in their youth, a reader is baffled by the disclosure: Was it expressly to hurt?
lead_paragraph: My wife is the second of four children who were raised in a frugal, middle-class household. To supplement her wardrobe, she babysat as a girl to earn money to buy clothes. She also sewed many of her outfits. Out of the blue — 50 years later — her younger sister confessed that she and their mother had often conspired to take my wife’s clothing, without her permission, for the younger girl to wear. This disclosure unearthed memories in my wife of finding her things out of place. The statement came without an apology and created great heartache. The question, “Why tell me now?” begs to be asked, but since the disclosure seems intended to cause hurt, it’s hard to envision the conversation. Your thoughts?

headline: Readers Share This Year’s Highlights (So Far)
abstract: Big birthdays, new family members and spectacular adventures.
lead_paragraph: My partner and I traveled to Austin, Texas, from the Bay Area in April to see the total solar eclipse that stretched across North America. Like many people around the world, we camped out to watch the silver-ringed orb glow in the sky. It was mind-bending and magical, and certainly one of the best parts of my year.

headline: What to Know About Europe’s Extra Tariffs on Chinese Electric Cars
abstract: The tariffs had been expected for months, but many European automakers warned that they would drive up prices for consumers and set off a trade war with China.
lead_paragraph: The European Union said on Wednesday that it would impose additional tariffs of up to 38 percent on electric cars built in China, a move it said would help level the playing field for automakers in Europe.

headline: Corrections: June 11, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 11, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the emergence of Doug Burgum, the Republican governor of North Dakota, as a cheerleader for oil and gas production and former President Donald J. Trump, misquoted the governor’s statement on U.S. oil production. He said the country was producing 13 million barrels a day but should be producing “14, 15, 20 million barrels a day”; he did not say the country was producing 13 million gallons a day but should be producing 14,15, 20 million gallons a day.

headline: Denmark’s Prime Minister Says She’s ‘Not Quite Myself’ After Assault
abstract: Mette Frederiksen said she was working but still recovering, days after being punched in a busy square in Copenhagen.
lead_paragraph: Four days after being assaulted in a busy Copenhagen square, Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark said she was carrying out her duties as leader but still recovering, in her first interview since the assault.

headline: 3 Days in Space Were Enough to Change 4 Astronauts’ Bodies and Minds
abstract: An extensive examination of medical data gathered from the private Inspiration4 mission in 2021 revealed temporary cognitive declines and genetic changes in the crew.
lead_paragraph: Space changes you, even during short trips off the planet.

headline: Student Loan Bills Are Dropping Next Month for Many, but There’s a Hiccup
abstract: The Education Department has not finished recalculating payments for millions of borrowers enrolled in SAVE, forcing loan servicers to put many loans into forbearance.
lead_paragraph: On July 1, millions of federal student loan borrowers will see their monthly bills drop — some by as much as half — as the Biden administration’s new income-driven payment plan, known as SAVE, takes full effect.

headline: Cooling Inflation Revives Biden’s Hope of Rate Cuts
abstract: The chances of at least one pre-election cut appeared to be helped by a new inflation report.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his aides have already given up any expectation that the Federal Reserve could cut interest rates several times before the November election.

headline: Three Men Convicted in Murder of Dutch Journalist
abstract: A Dutch court sentenced the men to prison for more than 25 years on Wednesday in the killing of Peter R. de Vries, whose daylight murder in 2021 rattled Europe.
lead_paragraph: A Dutch court on Wednesday sentenced three men to decades in prison for the murder of the renowned crime journalist Peter R. de Vries, whose brazen killing in broad daylight on an Amsterdam street rattled journalists and others across the Netherlands and Europe.

headline: When We Fear Silence, We Abandon the Self
abstract: The constant distractions of modern life have become an excuse to avoid the search for meaning.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: The Rage, Secrecy and Pain of a Family Torn Apart by Addiction
abstract: A Delaware family sees itself in the Hunter Biden story.
lead_paragraph: Kim Jones lives in a neat house on a road lined with cattails and lilies near the Delaware River with three dogs, four cats, her new husband, her 19-year-old daughter, Hannah, and her father, Curt. Kim has planted blueberries in the backyard and plans to start keeping bees. A wooden sign in the window of her garage conveys her hope for the future: “Honey For Sale.”

headline: White House Announces Strategy to Keep Edible Food Out of Landfills
abstract: The government will look at ways to extend the shelf life of foods and to create more composting and other facilities, as well as urge companies to donate more food.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday issued, for the first time, a national strategy to combat a major national problem: food waste.

headline: Housing Costs Cool, but Remain a Source of Concern
abstract: Housing costs were up 5.4 percent in May from a year earlier, the smallest increase in more than two years. But monthly progress has slowed.
lead_paragraph: Overall inflation cooled sharply last month, but one of the most important categories of consumer prices — housing — remained stubborn.

headline: Hunter Biden’s Conviction, and a Family’s Pain
abstract: Readers discuss addiction, call for compassion and praise how the president has supported his son.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: No Tables for Anyone Under 30 at This St. Louis-Area Restaurant
abstract: Customers generally support Bliss Caribbean Restaurant’s ban on male customers under 35 and women under 30. But some legal experts say there may be a problem.
lead_paragraph: When Tina and Marvin Pate travel to Cancún or the Dominican Republic, they enjoy the bliss created by the good music, delicious food and the absence of children.

headline: Greece Closes Schools and Acropolis as Possible Record Heat Is Forecast
abstract: Concerns are also growing for two foreign hikers who have gone missing on Greek islands amid the soaring temperatures.
lead_paragraph: Intense heat in Greece prompted a mini lockdown for two days starting on Wednesday, with some schools closing and the Acropolis restricting visiting hours, as the authorities searched for two foreign hikers just a few days after a British medical journalist was found dead on the island of Symi after going for a walk in searing heat.

headline: Ethics Questions Raised by Secret Recordings of Justices
abstract: Readers discuss a woman’s conversations with Justice Samuel Alito and Chief Justice John Roberts under false pretenses.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jerry West, One of Basketball’s Greatest Players, Dies at 86
abstract: He was a sharpshooting, high-scoring Hall of Fame guard for the Lakers and later an executive with the team. His image became the N.B.A.’s logo.
lead_paragraph: Jerry West, who emerged from West Virginia coal country to become one of basketball’s greatest players, a signature figure in the history of the Los Angeles Lakers and a literal icon of the sport — his is the silhouette on the logo of the National Basketball Association — died on Wednesday. He was 86.

headline: Why Is Biden Going to Europe Twice in a Week?
abstract: President Biden made two back-to-back round trips to Europe, separated by about 60 hours on the ground at home.
lead_paragraph: Air Force One is plenty comfortable if you are its most privileged frequent flier, with a comfortable bedroom and a spacious office.

headline: Why Senate Democrats Are Outperforming Biden in Key States
abstract: Democratic candidates have leads in Wisconsin, Pennsylvania, Nevada, Michigan and Arizona — but strategists aligned with both parties caution that the battle for Senate control is just starting.
lead_paragraph: It was a Pride Weekend in Wisconsin, a natural time for the state’s pathbreaking, openly gay senator to rally her Democratic base, but on Sunday, Tammy Baldwin was far away from the parades and gatherings in Madison and Milwaukee — at a dairy farm in Republican Richland County.

headline: In Wake of Election Defeat, Germany’s Weakened Leader Will Slog On
abstract: Chancellor Olaf Scholz and his governing coalition emerged battered from the vote for the European Parliament. But a snap election seems unlikely.
lead_paragraph: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany heads to the Group of 7 summit meeting in Italy on Thursday as a diminished leader after Sunday’s battering in elections for the European Parliament.

headline: U.S. Expands Sanctions on Russia as G7 Leaders Gather
abstract: The Biden administration is taking new measures aimed at stopping China from helping the Kremlin sustain its war effort against Ukraine. U.S. officials hope European nations will take similar steps.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday announced a series of new financial sanctions aimed at interrupting the fast-growing technological links between China and Russia that American officials believe are a broad effort to rebuild and modernize Russia’s military during its war with Ukraine.

headline: Back From Vacation and Still Burned Out
abstract: Time away can make work stress even more apparent. Here’s what to do about it.
lead_paragraph: The email does not find you well.

headline: Ancient Genomes Reveal Which Children the Maya Selected for Sacrifice
abstract: Thousand-year-old DNA from Chichén Itzá offers eye-opening details of the religious rituals of ancient Maya.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 1967, workers building a small airport behind Chichén Itzá, the ancient Maya city in Mexico, ran into a problem: Their excavations had uncovered human remains in the pathway of the proposed runway. The airport was set to serve V.I.P.s who wanted to visit Chichén Itzá. But with the remains so close to a major archaeological site, the work had to be halted until the bones could be examined.

headline: Mmm, Migas
abstract: Made with fried leftover corn tortillas for heft and jalapeño and onion for lift, these are scrambled eggs with oomph.
lead_paragraph: The path to countless speedy meals starts with a few scrambled eggs. Pep them up with spices, cheeses or vegetables, or leave them simple and pure; they might be the fastest breakfast you can make that doesn’t come out of a box. And I like them even better for dinner.

headline: How Fed Rates Influence Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
abstract: Higher rates benefit those who can save, but for borrowers falling rates would reduce bills on credit cards, home equity loans and other forms of debt.
lead_paragraph: American households who are hoping interest rates will soon decline will have to wait a bit longer.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Next Billion-Dollar Sports Play: A Boxing Takeover
abstract: A proposal awaiting financing would attempt to bring together dozens of the world’s best boxers in a single, Saudi-run pro league.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has already launched a hostile takeover of professional golf. It has invested billions of dollars in world soccer. Now it wants to own professional boxing, too.

headline: Southern Baptists Reject Tighter Ban on Women in Pastoral Posts
abstract: The denomination voted against adding language to its constitution saying that “only men” could be affirmed or employed “as any kind of pastor or elder as qualified by Scripture.”
lead_paragraph: Southern Baptists rejected a move on Wednesday to crack down on congregations with women in pastoral leadership. The vote dealt an unexpected rebuke to a hard-right faction that has been jockeying for influence in the country’s largest Protestant denomination.

headline: Tesla Investors to Decide if Musk Deserves $45 Billion Payday
abstract: The vote is seen as a referendum on the limits of executive pay and the accountability of Silicon Valley billionaires.
lead_paragraph: Under Elon Musk’s leadership, Tesla popularized electric vehicles and became the most valuable auto company in the world. Mr. Musk became a billionaire many times over while generating huge profits for investors.

headline: Heavy Rain Floods Parts of Southern Florida
abstract: Vehicles waded through several inches of rain as flash flooding deluged cities along Florida’s coasts. Some areas of the state were expected to receive up to a foot or more of rain in the coming days.
lead_paragraph: Vehicles waded through several inches of rain as flash flooding deluged cities along Florida’s coasts. Some areas of the state were expected to receive up to a foot or more of rain in the coming days.

headline: Françoise Hardy, Moody French Pop Star, Dies at 80
abstract: With hit songs and an understated personality, she incarnated a 1960s cool still treasured by the French.
lead_paragraph: Françoise Hardy, an introspective pop singer who became a hero to French youth in the 1960s with her moody ballads, died on Tuesday. She was 80.

headline: Fumihiko Maki, Honored Architect of Understated Buildings, Dies at 95
abstract: A Pritzker Prize winner, he designed notable projects in his native Japan and in the U.S., including 4 World Trade Center and the M.I.T. Media Lab’s new home.
lead_paragraph: Fumihiko Maki, an architect who designed many notable, subtly detailed buildings in his native Japan and several in the United States, including a new home for M.I.T.’s renowned Media Lab, a university art museum in St. Louis and Tower 4 of the World Trade Center, died on June 6 at home in Tokyo. He was 95.

headline: Amtrak Pays Executives Six-Figure Bonuses as Losses Continue
abstract: Some executives received payments of nearly half a million dollars as the rail service remained $1.7 billion in the red and the new Acela program continued to face challenges.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen Amtrak executives received more than $200,000 each in incentive bonuses last year despite the service’s poor recent financial performance and struggles with its capital improvement projects, according to documents obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Miami President Named as Next U.C.L.A. Chancellor
abstract: Julio Frenk, a public health expert who has led the University of Miami since 2015, will take over the elite Los Angeles school that has been rocked by protests this spring.
lead_paragraph: Julio Frenk, a public health expert who has led the University of Miami since 2015, was named on Wednesday as the next permanent chancellor of the University of California, Los Angeles. He will oversee an elite public institution still reeling from intense protests and a violent attack on student demonstrators that occurred this spring.

headline: For These Games, a Release Date Is Just the Beginning
abstract: More and more video games are building player bases with perpetual updates and seasonal content. Fans of Destiny 2 just completed a 10-year story arc.
lead_paragraph: The release last week of The Final Shape, a long-awaited expansion to the multiplayer shooter Destiny 2, was billed as the epic conclusion to the “Light and Darkness” saga, a 10-year story arc that began with the release of the first Destiny. But the studio, Bungie, has made clear to the game’s fans that there are plenty of stand-alone stories to come.

headline: How to Read the Fed’s Projections Like a Pro
abstract: The Federal Reserve is expected to leave rates unchanged on Wednesday. But Wall Street is focused on what comes next.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are scheduled to release both an interest-rate decision and a fresh set of economic projections on Wednesday, and Wall Street has been eagerly awaiting those revised estimates for clues on when interest rate cuts may begin.

headline: My Son’s Ex-Girlfriend Wants to Keep Her Pregnancy. Is That Unfair to Him?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether a co-parent’s wishes should matter to a pregnant woman.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always supported a woman’s right to choose, not least because legal access to abortion once saved me from an untenable situation. I also believe that if a woman chooses to abort, her wish should supersede any opposition to it by the father. The physical, practical and emotional effects on a woman obliged to carry a child to term (and to care for it afterward) are, in my view, far more significant than they are for the father.

headline: Oklahoma Supreme Court Dismisses Tulsa Massacre Lawsuit
abstract: The last known remaining survivors of the 1921 attack by a white mob were hoping for their day in court.
lead_paragraph: A historic quest for justice by the last two known centenarian survivors of the Tulsa Race Massacre likely ended on Wednesday when the Oklahoma Supreme Court affirmed a lower court’s dismissal of a lawsuit that sought reparations.

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Stick Season (Forever)’ and More
abstract: I lead a global breaking news team with hubs on three continents. Here are some things I am enjoying.
lead_paragraph: I lead a global breaking news team with hubs on three continents. Here are some things I am enjoying.

headline: Defiant Macron Predicts Chaos if France Succumbs to Extremes
abstract: The French president called on people of good will to come together to defend the Republic in the snap election he decided to call.
lead_paragraph: Declaring himself an “incorrigible optimist,” President Emmanuel Macron of France appealed on Wednesday to all French people “who reject the extremes” to vote for centrist parties in snap elections and so save the Republic from the bigotry of the far right and the antisemitism of the extreme left.

headline: Listen to 8 Songs From the Bewitching Françoise Hardy
abstract: From her start in the yé-yé 1960s to the depths she plumbed as a singer-songwriter, Hardy, who died Tuesday, continued to entrance new generations of listeners.
lead_paragraph: When she first broke through in the early 1960s, the bewitching French pop star Françoise Hardy, who died on Tuesday at 80, was initially lumped in with the yé-yés, the commercially minded rocking and twisting French singers of the era.

headline: White House Aide Does Not Say if Biden Would Commute Son’s Sentence
abstract: The White House spokeswoman said she had not spoken with the president about the matter yet.
lead_paragraph: A White House spokeswoman did not rule out on Wednesday the possibility that President Biden might commute the sentence of his son Hunter Biden, who was convicted on three federal felony counts for illegally purchasing a handgun during his addiction to crack cocaine.

headline: Howard Fineman, Veteran Political Journalist and TV Pundit, Dies at 75
abstract: From his beginnings with a daily newspaper, he moved easily through Newsweek magazine to cable news and, later, to the frontiers of online journalism.
lead_paragraph: Howard Fineman, a witty, encyclopedic political reporter who dominated the fast-evolving world of Washington journalism for nearly 40 years, moving effortlessly from daily news coverage to the pages of Newsweek magazine to cable news punditry and later to the frontiers of online journalism, died on Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 75.

headline: Eric Adams Praised a Reporter’s Body. It Wasn’t His First Such Remark.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams told a journalist that it looked like he was working out and complimented his “summer body.”
lead_paragraph: When a young journalist tried recently to ask Mayor Eric Adams a question about pro-Palestinian demonstrations, Mr. Adams took the exchange in an unusual direction.

headline: Kathy Hochul, Usher and Babyface Turn Out for the Apollo
abstract: More than 1,000 musicians, politicians and philanthropists gathered in Harlem on Tuesday night to celebrate the theater’s 90th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Usher, an eight-time Grammy winner, has won many awards in his 30-year career. But the one he received on Tuesday night at the Apollo Theater in Harlem was special, he said.

headline: Vandals Splash Graffiti on Home of Jewish Director of Brooklyn Museum
abstract: The homes of the director and three other museum officials were vandalized with red paint, and a banner at the director’s building called her a “white supremacist” Zionist.
lead_paragraph: The homes of the Jewish director of the Brooklyn Museum and other museum leaders were vandalized early Wednesday morning in a coordinated attack, according to a museum spokeswoman.

headline: He’s Got Baby Fever: A Trans Choreographer’s Surrogacy Journey
abstract: Ashley R.T. Yergens’s “Surrogate,” premiering at New York Live Arts this week, explores how trans men experience pregnancy and I.V.F.
lead_paragraph: In “prettygirl264264” (2018), the choreographer Ashley R.T. Yergens threw himself a funeral.

headline: A Former Close Friend of Senator Menendez Testifies Against Him
abstract: Philip Sellinger, the U.S. attorney for the District of New Jersey, was a guest at Senator Robert Menendez’s wedding in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Philip R. Sellinger, New Jersey’s top federal prosecutor, testified on Wednesday that he had several conversations with Senator Robert Menendez about a bank fraud case Mr. Menendez is charged with trying to quash in exchange for bribes.

headline: The Importance of the Pinehurst Caddies
abstract: With their knowledge of the course, they can save players “several strokes a round.”
lead_paragraph: Willie McRae, a caddie who spent more than seven decades at the Pinehurst Resort & Country Club, the host of this week’s U.S. Open, was a beloved figure who did his utmost to help his players.

headline: Art Basel Opens to Safe Sales and Fears of a Weaker Market
abstract: At the prestigious fair, doing business at what one mega-dealer calls a “more human pace” can just mean “slower” for smaller galleries.
lead_paragraph: The international art trade faced a crunch moment in Switzerland this week. Art Basel, the world’s biggest and most prestigious fair for dealers in modern and contemporary works, opened to V.I.P.s on Tuesday against a backdrop of declining auction sales and gloomy talk of a market downturn.

headline: Southern Baptists Vote to Oppose Use of I.V.F.
abstract: With almost 13 million church members across the United States, the Southern Baptist Convention has long been a bellwether for American evangelicalism.
lead_paragraph: Southern Baptists, the country’s largest Protestant denomination, voted on Wednesday to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization. The vote was an indication that evangelicals are increasingly open to arguments that equate embryos with human life, and that two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade, “fetal personhood” may be the next front for the anti-abortion movement.

headline: ‘Inside Out 2’ Review: PUBERTY! OMG! LOL! IYKYK!
abstract: Anxiety meets Joy in Pixar’s eager, predictably charming sequel to its innovative 2015 hit. Sadness is still around, too, as are Fear and Disgust.
lead_paragraph: When a dumpling of an old lady toddles into the animated charmer “Inside Out 2,” she is quickly shooed away by some other characters. Wearing rose-tinted glasses, she has twinkling eyes and a helmet of white hair. Her name is Nostalgia, and those who wave her off — Joy and Sadness included — tell her it’s too soon for her to show up. I guess that they’ve never seen a Pixar movie, much less “Inside Out,” a wistful conceptual dazzler about a girl that is also a testament to one of the pleasures of movies: the engagement of our emotions.

headline: Don’t Run From Fear — Embrace It
abstract: Seeking out the scary and the spooky can be a fun and healthy way to build resilience and learn to cope with stress.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: As the U.A.W. Scores Wins in Red States, Tensions Emerge Over Gaza Protests
abstract: A tentative new contract at an Ohio battery maker on Monday was big for President Biden’s E.V. transition, but for some, the victory was upstaged by the U.A.W.’s activism on college campuses.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers has scored a remarkable string of victories — most recently, a landmark contract on Monday for electric vehicle battery workers — as its new leadership strives to restore the union’s image as the voice of an iconic segment of the American working class.

headline: As Nonprofit Theaters Struggle, Seattle Rep Cuts 12% of Staff
abstract: The institution, Seattle’s pre-eminent repertory theater, says it is making the cuts so it can focus its resources on productions.
lead_paragraph: As nonprofit theaters around the country grapple with continuing financial troubles and a changed post-pandemic theatergoing landscape, Seattle Rep announced this week that it would lay off 12 percent of its employees.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): What’s an Aging Rapper to Do?
abstract: New songs from Eminem, Drake and J. Cole — plus Will Smith’s post-Slap “Bad Boys” comeback — demonstrate different paths for maturing (or not).
lead_paragraph: The first segment of this week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes discussion of:

headline: A Rare Antelope Dies After Choking on a Plastic Cap at Tennessee Zoo
abstract: Lief, as the antelope was known, was comfortable with humans. A squeezable food pouch, which is among items banned at the zoo to protect the animals, was found in the exhibit.
lead_paragraph: An African antelope at a zoo in Tennessee died after choking on the plastic cap of a food pouch that had been discarded in its enclosure even though it was among items banned near the animal habitats, according to the zoo.

headline: Sony Pictures Acquires Alamo Drafthouse in Lifeline to Cinema Chain
abstract: The deal is a rare example of a traditional Hollywood studio owning a movie theater chain.
lead_paragraph: Sony Pictures Entertainment is acquiring Alamo Drafthouse Cinema and will manage its 35 locations, a rare example of a traditional Hollywood studio’s owning a theater chain.

headline: Accounts of Life in Hamas Captivity Emerge in Israel
abstract: The four hostages rescued in Gaza were described as malnourished and traumatized.
lead_paragraph: In the months after he was taken hostage in Israel and hidden in the Gaza Strip, Andrey Kozlov’s captors kept drumming in the same message: The world, they said, had given up on him. Even his family had moved on.

headline: Thursday Briefing: G7 Leaders Prepare to Debate Frozen Russian Assets
abstract: Also, an E.U. blow to China’s electric-vehicle ambitions.
lead_paragraph: For two years, Western allies have debated how to deal with $300 billion in frozen Russian assets. The G7 leaders, who will meet beginning today in Italy, seem on the brink of announcing a compromise.

headline: Harrison White, Groundbreaking (and Inscrutable) Sociologist, Dies at 94
abstract: A theoretical physicist-turned-sociologist, he upended his field by focusing on social networks to explain how society works. His writing was compared to James Joyce’s.
lead_paragraph: Harrison C. White, a theoretical physicist-turned-sociologist who upended the study of human relations and society by examining how social networks shape the unseen forces of everyday life, died on May 19 in Tucson, Ariz. He was 94.

headline: A.C.L.U. Sues to Stop Biden’s Asylum Ban on the U.S.-Mexico Border
abstract: The action is the first legal challenge to an order that President Biden hopes will decrease the number of illegal crossings and neutralize a major political vulnerability.
lead_paragraph: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit on Wednesday challenging President Biden’s decision to shut down the southern border to nearly all migrants seeking asylum in the United States.

headline: Françoise Hardy: A Life in Photos
abstract: The French pop star pulled listeners close and always struck the perfect pose.
lead_paragraph: The French pop star Françoise Hardy, who died on Tuesday at the age of 80, was celebrated for her beauty and style, always striking the perfect pose whether she was doing a fashion shoot or had gotten caught in a candid picture. Hardy’s self-possession could be intimidating, but her songs created a sense of intimacy, pulling listeners close by exploring emotional depths, and she earned the love and loyalty of pop aficionados, devoted aesthetes and lonely souls.

headline: Man Who Killed Philadelphia Journalist Gets Up to 30 Years in Prison
abstract: Robert Davis, 20, pleaded guilty to third-degree murder in the fatal shooting, which was domestic in nature, according to the authorities.
lead_paragraph: A man who fatally shot a Philadelphia freelance journalist with whom he had a relationship was sentenced on Monday to 15 to 30 years in prison.

headline: Did Jerry West Inspire the N.B.A.’s Logo? ‘There Was Never Any Doubt.’
abstract: After decades of the league having avoided the issue, Commissioner Adam Silver said what most people knew all along: It is Jerry West in the league’s iconic logo.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the announcement that Jerry West, the Hall of Fame basketball player and executive, had died at age 86 on Wednesday, the N.B.A. emailed a statement to the news media from Adam Silver, the league’s commissioner, extolling the virtues of Mr. West as “a basketball genius” who contributed to every facet of the league over a period of more than 60 years.

headline: Review: A Glorious ‘Titanic,’ Returned From the Depths
abstract: Maury Yeston’s score, stupendously played and sung, is the star of the final production of an excellent Encores! season at New York City Center.
lead_paragraph: Among the 1,500 people who died aboard R.M.S. Titanic on April 15, 1912, eight were musicians, playing through the ship’s last hours to solace themselves and their doomed companions. It seems only fitting, then, that among the many ways to love the splendid Encores! revival of “Titanic,” which opened on Tuesday at New York City Center, the best is as a tribute to the power of music to address the largest and gravest human emotions.

headline: Tony Lo Bianco, ‘French Connection’ Actor, Dies at 87
abstract: Once labeled a “natural-born heavy,” he shined onscreen and especially onstage, securing a Tony nomination and winning an Obie Award.
lead_paragraph: Tony Lo Bianco, an actor whose film roles included villains in “The French Connection” and “The Honeymoon Killers” and whose stage career earned him stellar reviews for an Arthur Miller tragedy and an Obie Award for a baseball drama, died on Tuesday at his home in Poolesville, Md. He was 87.

headline: Rains Continue Battering South Florida, Closing Roads and Grounding Flights
abstract: The deluge, which began Tuesday afternoon, dumped more than 10 inches in some areas and was expected to continue through Thursday, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains battered South Florida on Wednesday, closing major roads, stranding vehicles, forcing delays and cancellations at airports, and causing flash flooding in the Fort Lauderdale and Miami areas.

headline: Inflation Cooled, but the Fed Expects Just One Rate Cut This Year
abstract: Also, Southern Baptists voted to oppose I.V.F. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Consumer price increases slowed notably in May, according to data released today, suggesting that inflation is easing again after proving stubborn earlier this year. Gasoline prices fell, car insurance prices dropped and so-called core inflation, which strips out volatile food and fuel prices, eased to 3.4 percent, its lowest level since April 2021.

headline: Russian Warships Enter Havana Harbor as Part of Planned Exercises
abstract: Experts called the naval exercises routine but also a show of strength as Washington maintains military support for Ukraine in its war against Russia.
lead_paragraph: Russian warships arrived in Cuban waters on Wednesday as part of planned military exercises that experts say were a symbolic show of strength in reaction to continued U.S. support for Ukraine, and a reflection of growing ties between Russia and Cuba.

headline: The Secret to Deepening Friendships Is Hiding in Your Phone
abstract: Today’s challenge: Put that sprawling photo library to good use.
lead_paragraph: This is Day 4 of the 5-Day Friendship Challenge. To start at the beginning, click here.

headline: Blinken Calls Hamas Changes to Cease-Fire Proposal Unworkable
abstract: While the U.S. secretary of state kept up the pressure for a halt to the hostilities in Gaza, Israel and Hamas still appeared to be far from reaching a deal.
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Wednesday that he would continue to press urgently for a cease-fire deal between Israel and Hamas in the Gaza Strip despite a counterproposal from Hamas that he said included unacceptable demands.

headline: SpaceX Is Sued by Employees Fired After Criticizing Musk
abstract: The eight workers say they were wrongfully fired after circulating a memo raising concerns about sexual harassment at the rocket company led by Elon Musk.
lead_paragraph: Eight former employees of Elon Musk’s rocket company, SpaceX, sued the company and Mr. Musk on Wednesday, contending they were wrongfully fired for raising concerns about sexual harassment and discrimination in the workplace.

headline: Akira Endo, Scholar of Statins That Reduce Heart Disease, Dies at 90
abstract: The Japanese biochemist found in the 1970s that cholesterol-lowering drugs lowered the level of LDL, or “bad” cholesterol, in the blood.
lead_paragraph: Akira Endo, a Japanese biochemist whose research on fungi helped to lay the groundwork for widely prescribed drugs that lower a type of cholesterol that contributes to heart disease, died on June 5. He was 90.

headline: Democrats Plan to Turn Statehouses Blue by Dishing Out Green
abstract: The spending blitz showcases the importance of state legislatures in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Hi there. Today, my colleague Nick Corasaniti, who covers voting and elections, joins us with an exclusive look at the big money pouring into small races. Then, I ask whether a surprising election result last night in Ohio tells us anything about November. — Jess Bidgood

headline: Senate Republicans Block Supreme Court Ethics Measure Pushed by Democrats
abstract: Democrats made what they knew was a doomed attempt as they faced pressure from the left to do more to try to hold the court accountable.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans on Wednesday blocked an effort by Democrats to quickly pass Supreme Court ethics and transparency legislation they had pushed forward in the wake of disclosures about justices taking unreported gifts and travel and other ethical issues surrounding the high court.

headline: Houthis Attack Merchant Ship in Red Sea Off Yemen’s Coast
abstract: The Iran-backed militia has launched dozens of attacks on shipping vessels in the vital sea route in support of Palestinians in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Yemen’s Houthi rebels attacked a merchant ship in the Red Sea on Wednesday  in the latest escalation of the Iran-backed militia’s campaign against shipping in support of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.

headline: Western Governors Give Bipartisanship a Try. At Least for a Few Days.
abstract: The Western Governors’ Association celebrated its 40th anniversary with high hopes and low turnout.
lead_paragraph: The bipartisan boat ride on Lake Tahoe was scrapped because of scheduling issues. At least three of the participating Republicans were suing the administration of one of the Democrats.

headline: Christophe Deloire, Who Fought for Threatened Journalists, Dies at 53
abstract: As the leader and spokesman for Reporters Without Borders, he rescued some, sought refuge for others and lobbied for pluralism in the press.
lead_paragraph: Christophe Deloire, whose nonpartisan organization to protect journalists rescued dissidents from jail and championed a diversity of viewpoints in the profession around the world, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 53.

headline: Hunter Biden Is Expected to Appeal Conviction on Gun Charges
abstract: Lawyers for Mr. Biden are considering a number of challenges to the guilty verdict, including one based on the Second Amendment.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden is expected to appeal his felony conviction for falsifying a federal firearms application, likely arguing that the judge in the case violated his constitutional rights in her instructions to the jury, according to people in his orbit and legal experts.

headline: Disney and DeSantis Reach Agreement, Ending Protracted Fight
abstract: The deal locks in a 15-year expansion plan for Disney World and clears a path for Disney to restart in-kind political donations in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Disney and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida have finally ended their feud, clearing the way for $17 billion in planned development at Walt Disney World near Orlando.

headline: Light Craft Material
abstract: Kevin Curry offers a different read on things.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Corrections: June 13, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, June 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about Dao Yin, a candidate who may have exploited an oversight weakness in New York’s new matching-funds campaign system misattributed a quote from a supposed donor to Mr. Yin. The person quoted was Faaizah Abdul-Mani, not Fazia Butt.

headline: Quotation of the Day: For Even the Best Sherpas, There Is No Escaping the Danger
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 13, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I will keep climbing mountains. I have no other options.”

headline: China Is Testing More Driverless Cars Than Any Other Country
abstract: Assisted driving systems and robot taxis are becoming more popular with government help, as cities designate large areas for testing on public roads.
lead_paragraph: The world’s largest experiment in driverless cars is underway on the busy streets of Wuhan, a city in central China with 11 million people, 4.5 million cars, eight-lane expressways and towering bridges over the muddy waters of the Yangtze River.

headline: Montana Has More Cows Than People. Why Are Locals Eating Beef From Brazil?
abstract: Cole Mannix, of Old Salt Co-op, is trying to change local appetites and upend an industry controlled by multibillion-dollar meatpackers.
lead_paragraph: “Making It Work” is a series is about small-business owners striving to endure hard times.

headline: Tesla Share Price Is Its Own Referendum on Musk
abstract: A huge run-up in the stock’s value followed a 2018 vote on Elon Musk’s compensation package. But investors have recently become less enamored.
lead_paragraph: The Tesla shareholder vote over Elon Musk’s pay is in some ways a referendum on the performance of the company and its chief executive.

headline: Tesla’s Nordic Shareholders Seek to Promote Workers’ Rights in Vote
abstract: Tesla mechanics in Sweden have been striking for six months with little movement from their employer. Nordic shareholders hope to change that.
lead_paragraph: The fight over Elon Musk’s pay package and the vote over whether to move Tesla’s headquarters to Texas have been the main focus of attention ahead of the company’s shareholders meeting on Thursday, but not for investors from Nordic countries.

headline: What It’s Like to Ride a Robot Taxi in China
abstract: Wuhan, China, hosts the world’s largest driverless car experiment with hundreds of robot taxis that transport passengers through busy streets and highways.
lead_paragraph: Wuhan, China, hosts the world’s largest driverless car experiment with hundreds of robot taxis that transport passengers through busy streets and highways.

headline: How Safe Are Driverless Cars in China? I Rode in Some to See.
abstract: Computer-aided driving has official support and public acceptance, but state media seldom reports crashes or safety incidents, and online posts are censored.
lead_paragraph: Images of the burned vehicle flew through the Chinese internet: An Aito M7 Plus electric sport utility vehicle, operated by an advanced assisted driving system, had crashed on a highway in Shanxi Province on April 26.

headline: Weakened Leaders of the West Gather in Italy to Discuss an Unruly World
abstract: The Group of 7 gathers major industrialized countries, but its leaders are politically weak and Ukraine and Gaza remain unsolved.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy convenes the leaders of the Group of 7 countries on Thursday at a luxury resort hotel overlooking the Adriatic Sea, she might be forgiven for thinking her guests are seeking a refuge.

headline: In China’s Backyard, America Has Become a Humbler Superpower
abstract: The United States no longer towers over the Asia-Pacific, dictating terms to its allies. Instead, it’s offering to be a teammate and share responsibilities.
lead_paragraph: Far from Ukraine and Gaza, as the Group of 7 wealthy democracies gathers in Italy to discuss a range of old, entrenched challenges, the nature of American power is being transformed across the region that Washington sees as crucial for the century to come: the Asia-Pacific.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: The Group of 7 summit considers funding for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: For two years, Western allies have debated how to deal with $300 billion in frozen Russian assets. The G7 leaders, who will meet beginning today in Italy, seem to be on the brink of announcing a compromise.

headline: Janet Yellen: A New Way to Make Russia’s Assets Pay for Ukraine’s Defense and Rebuilding
abstract: The U.S. Treasury secretary explains why America and its allies should unlock the value of Russian capital immobilized at the start of the war to give Ukraine the financing it needs.
lead_paragraph: We are at a critical time in Russia’s brutal and illegal invasion of Ukraine. Russia’s continued assault on the country requires that we take bold and decisive action. It is time for the United States and our allies to unlock the value of immobilized Russian assets so that Ukraine can get the financial support it urgently needs.

headline: France Is on the Brink of Something Terrifying
abstract: In calling snap elections, Emmanuel Macron has taken a dangerous gamble.
lead_paragraph: Whatever happens next, it’ll go down as one of the wildest gambles in modern French history. President Emmanuel Macron’s decision to dissolve the National Assembly and hold snap legislative elections on June 30 and July 7 has given the far right its best shot at governing France for the first time since the Vichy regime of World War II.

headline: Outage Leaves About 350,000 Customers in Puerto Rico Without Power
abstract: The outage affected customers in the island’s capital and surrounding areas following planned maintenance work on transmission lines at power plants.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in Puerto Rico said they were working to restore electricity after an outage struck the island during maintenance on the electricity grid, leaving about 350,000 customers without power during a heat wave.

headline: Heavy Rain Causes Devastating Flooding in Florida
abstract: The deluge, which began Tuesday afternoon, dumped more than 10 inches in some areas, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: Several communities in southern Florida were inundated Wednesday by “life-threatening” flooding as heavy rains closed major roads, stranded vehicles and submerged streets, homes and parking lots.

headline: Word of the Day: boisterous
abstract: This word has appeared in 147 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word boisterous has appeared in 147  articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 6 in “Onstage in Chicago, Zach Bryan Howled, and the Crowd Found Its Voice” by Jon Caramanica:

headline: Jimmy Fallon Tracks Biden’s Summer Abroad
abstract: “Yeah, the president is in Italy for the G7 Summit, or as Fox News put it: ‘Biden Flees Country After Hunter Convicted,’” Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: What to Know About New Social Media Protections for Children in New York
abstract: New York State passed a bill that will restrict the use of algorithms on minors’ social media feeds, in hopes of addressing mental health concerns.
lead_paragraph: On websites like Facebook, X and TikTok, a complex set of algorithms helps create curated personalized feeds to keep users engaged on the platform for as long as possible.

headline: Living Out Loud, Headphones Nowhere to Be Found
abstract: Welcome to their conversation. (Or YouTube video. Or baseball game.) For people bothered by the liberal use of speakerphones, the public sphere can be a circle of hell.
lead_paragraph: Hang out anywhere there are people — Amtrak, Burger King, the I.C.U. — and it can feel as if there’s no escape from their noise. A Mets game, the Beyoncé discography, FaceTime conversations about nothing: Thanks to the unfettered use of speakerphones, other people’s business is now yours too, loudly.

headline: For Rogue Smoke Shops in New York, the ‘Party’s Over’
abstract: The city is flexing its new enforcement powers to close hundreds of unlicensed cannabis stores. Critics have likened some of the authorities’ tactics to those used during the war on drugs.
lead_paragraph: Gold balloons announcing the “GRAND OPENING” of Zaza City Convenience in southeast Queens were still floating in the shop last month when the authorities cleared its shelves of cannabis and tobacco products that were illegal to sell in New York. After the police officers had bagged and weighed the contraband and sent it off in an evidence van, a sheriff’s sergeant sealed the entrances to the store with padlocks.

headline: R.O. Kwon: ‘I Want More of People’s Bodies, Especially in Fiction’
abstract: To write “Exhibit,” the queer novelist says she had to pretend that no one would read it. “By writing things I’m afraid of saying, I might stand a chance of voicing what I, too, really need and long to see in words.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Angry Catholics Wanted to Burn the Church. He Came to Save It.
abstract: In a cold, remote corner of northern Quebec, a sexual abuse scandal pushed a church to the edge. The Rev. Gérard Tsatselam, from Cameroon, must comfort the afflicted to bring it back.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Gérard Tsatselam boarded the ferryboat and settled in his usual place, on a reclining seat, at the back of a cold, unlit room that would have been packed in summer. Uneasy, he sat shrouded in his large, black coat as high winter winds delayed the boat’s arrival in the village where he was trying to save the church.

headline: The Sweet Rewards of Bitter Melon
abstract: Asian American chefs are embracing the medicinal gourd anew.
lead_paragraph: On broad banana leaves, dishes of sweet soy dipping sauce, a creamy pork liver sauce, a bubbling pinakbet, some sticky rice and a raw salad of slivered bitter melon and red onion flank a crackling lechon like planets orbiting the sun. This is the final savory course of the kamayan dinner, a Filipino family-style meal, at Naks in the East Village of Manhattan. Small but mighty, raw and crisp, the vibrantly green bitter melon packs a fierce bitterness that effortlessly holds up against the other heady accouterments.

headline: What Really Happened Inside Miss USA?
abstract: Accusations of racism, sexual harassment and rigging have plagued the organization in recent years, but no reigning titleholder has ever quit. Then Miss USA and Miss Teen USA resigned in the same week.
lead_paragraph: Laylah Rose says she won her first pageant at the age of 2. With dark, glossy hair and a measured smile, she went on to enter many more. Yet, even as a girl, she dreamed of something bigger. Ms. Rose didn’t only want to wear a sash, as her mother and grandmother had done before her: She wanted to run Miss USA.

headline: A Basket Maker Keeping Alive, and Reinventing, an Ancestral Craft
abstract: Mary Jackson, who is featured in museums like the Smithsonian, works in the fiber-arts tradition of the Gullah Geechee of coastal South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Mary Jackson was 4 when she learned how to weave. Sitting at her mother’s knee in the late 1940s, she tied her first knots with nimble little fingers, binding coils of sea grasses. In the Gullah Geechee communities of coastal South Carolina, where basket making is a centuries-old tradition, young children often start the weave for their elders. Jackson grew up surrounded by expert needlewomen who elevated this style of weaving from a strictly domestic craft to culturally profound artistry.

headline: ‘Brats’ Review: Feeding St. Elmo’s Ire
abstract: In this documentary, Andrew McCarthy examines fame and disappointment as a member of the so-called Brat Pack of the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: A thread of vulnerability weaves through “Brats,” the actor-director Andrew McCarthy’s new documentary. In it, McCarthy, the star of ’80s hits like “St. Elmo’s Fire” and “Pretty in Pink,” tries to make peace with having been branded a member of the “Brat Pack” by the press.

headline: Do You Have a Tip About the Pageant World? We Want to Hear From You.
abstract: The Times has been covering the turmoil inside Miss USA, but our reporters want to learn about the pageant world more broadly, too. We’re interested in your stories.
lead_paragraph: When the reigning Miss USA and Miss Teen USA, Noelia Voigt and UmaSofia Srivastava, resigned last month, it rocked the pageant world.

headline: 43 Tony Nominees and the Shows That Shaped Them
abstract: The Tony Awards are Sunday. Each year we photograph nominated performers and talk to them about their craft. This time, we asked about early theater memories.

headline: Long in the Shadows, the Latimer House Museum Gets a Glow-Up
abstract: The Queens home of the Black inventor who contributed to the invention of the lightbulb gets an overdue makeover.
lead_paragraph: In an episode of HBO’s “The Gilded Age,” Peggy Scott, the budding journalist, and T. Thomas Fortune, her discerning editor, expectantly await the illumination of the New York Times building in Lower Manhattan.

headline: How Conservatives Plotted Roe’s Downfall for Years, in Plain Sight
abstract: In “The Fall of Roe,” Elizabeth Dias and Lisa Lerer explain exactly how Roe v. Wade was made — and unmade.
lead_paragraph: In 2020, a writer at the feminist website Jezebel pitched an article on abortion pills. Her editor liked the idea, but knew what those of us who have tried to write about reproductive access had long internalized: The piece would not do well.

headline: ‘Ghostlight’ Review: With Patient Ears, Attend
abstract: The film is a gentle, emotional drama about a family struggling to stay together. It’s also about the power of theater.
lead_paragraph: The therapeutic value of theater is no secret. Everything from role play to full-out drama can be part of the health practitioners’ toolbox. But even a young person who finds themselves sobbing onstage in a role in the high school play knows there’s something regenerative about stepping into someone else’s shoes for a while.

headline: A New Opera Mashes Up Monteverdi and W.E.B. Du Bois
abstract: “The Comet/Poppea” radically pares down a classic and blends it with a premiere by George E. Lewis for an original show that will travel widely.
lead_paragraph: Morality takes a hike in Claudio Monteverdi’s final opera, “L’Incoronazione di Poppea.” Bold in its satire and explicit in its sensuality, even more than 350 years after its creation, the work gives its ruthless lovers, Nero and Poppea, everything they desire.

headline: ‘Ride’ Review: Heists, Heifers and Hospital Bills
abstract: A father and son resort to desperate measures to save an ailing child in this Texas-set dramatic thriller.
lead_paragraph: Like many movies before it, including “John Q,” and “Ambulance,” the indie thriller “Ride” is about a well-meaning father who turns to crime in a desperate bid to cover his family’s medical bills. It’s a distinctly, bleakly American crisis, one with an inevitable political subtext: If a man is forced to choose between stealing and watching his daughter die of cancer, maybe it’s the system, not the man, that’s the problem.

headline: ‘Tiger Stripes’ Review: A Ferocious Change
abstract: Myth and the changes of puberty combine in Amanda Nell Eu’s fierce, funny debut feature.
lead_paragraph: Decades of storytellers have framed changes in the adolescent female body as somehow mysterious and dangerous, almost sorcery. That’s why horror films like “Carrie,” “The Witch,” “The Exorcist” and “Teeth” are so spine-chilling. The theme is so well-trodden that it’s a little hard to find a fresh spin on the subject. In her feature debut “Tiger Stripes,” the director Amanda Nell Eu pulls it off.

headline: What Are the Homes in ‘Bridgerton’ Worth?
abstract: As the third season of the Netflix hit resumes, we share some home-value estimates for the luxurious dwellings used as locations.
lead_paragraph: As the third season of Netflix’s period drama “Bridgerton” resumes Thursday, we find Penelope Featherington dizzy from Colin Bridgerton’s sudden marriage proposal. Will these old friends make it to the altar? Will Colin discover Penelope’s earth-shattering secret? And most important of all: Who’s their real estate agent?

headline: The Disturbing Truth About Hair Relaxers
abstract: They’ve been linked to reproductive disorders and cancers. Why are they still being marketed so aggressively to Black women?
lead_paragraph: The phone rang incessantly in Dr. Tamarra James-Todd’s office at Harvard’s T.H. Chan School of Public Health. “I’m sorry,” she said, excusing herself for the third time. “It’s happening a lot,” she explained after pausing to take another call, “with the F.D.A. thing.”

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are four-bedroom homes in Smithtown, N.Y., and Stamford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A four-bedroom, one-and-a-half-bath house built in 1900, with a circular driveway, an entry vestibule, a gas fireplace in the living room, a formal dining room, a sunroom, an updated kitchen, laundry on the main level, an unfinished basement and a two-stall barn and tack room, on 0.85 acres. Marianne Koke, Daniel Gale Sotheby’s International Realty, 631-335-7111; danielgale.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Queens
abstract: This week’s properties are on West End Avenue, in the East Village and in Jackson Heights.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, one-bath 1,027-square-foot apartment with an open floor plan, a breakfast bar, a primary suite with a walk-in closet, a den/home office, a washer/dryer, PTAC heating and air-conditioning, and a private terrace, on the second floor of a six-story building with a virtual intercom, a roof deck and a super. Krista Nickols and Noah Kollar, SERHANT, 312-788-7881; serhant.com

headline: What J.D. Vance Believes
abstract: In a long conversation, the first-term senator from Ohio talks about Trump, populism, the 2020 election, Ukraine and the Republican V.P. slot.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, J.D. Vance’s best-selling memoir, “Hillbilly Elegy,” made him one of America’s leading interpreters of Trumpism, offering a personal narrative of populism’s origins in working-class disarray.

headline: How an Artist Became the Queen of Baltimore
abstract: Joyce J. Scott’s 50-year retrospective at the Baltimore Museum of Art draws inspiration, beauty and humor from her hometown and its people.
lead_paragraph: Joyce J. Scott is not an easy woman to interview. It’s not that she is reticent. It’s just hard to get a word in edgewise because practically every person we passed during our day together in Baltimore stopped to talk to her, shouting out “The Queen!” or “Mama Joyce!” whenever we entered one of her local haunts.

headline: Republicans Seek Retribution After Trump Conviction
abstract: G.O.P. leaders are publicly calling for Democrats to be prosecuted in retribution for Donald Trump’s felony conviction. Jonathan Swan reports on how the verdict is fueling anger and vengeance in the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: G.O.P. leaders are publicly calling for Democrats to be prosecuted in retribution for Donald Trump’s felony conviction. Jonathan Swan reports on how the verdict is fueling anger and vengeance in the Republican Party.

headline: How Big Tech Is Killing Innovation
abstract: The leading companies are co-opting Silicon Valley’s traditional cycle of disruption.
lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley prides itself on disruption: Start-ups develop new technologies, upend existing markets and overtake incumbents. This cycle of creative destruction brought us the personal computer, the internet and the smartphone. But in recent years, a handful of incumbent tech companies have sustained their dominance. Why? We believe they have learned how to co-opt potentially disruptive start-ups before they can become competitive threats.

headline: A Royal Visit to the City That Was Once Called New Amsterdam
abstract: Among other stops in New York, King Willem-Alexander and Queen Máxima of the Netherlands will tour an exhibit focused on 400 years of Dutch history.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll get details of a royal visit to New York City. We’ll also find out what Mayor Eric Adams said when asked about pro-Palestinian demonstrations.

headline: The Last Picture Show for Fotografiska
abstract: It was not a picture-perfect ending for the ambitious private venue, whose building is for sale. The museum is looking for another, with room for pictures and parties.
lead_paragraph: “Vivian Maier: Unseen Work” will be the final show at the six-story Flemish Renaissance Revival building that Fotografiska New York has occupied since opening at the end of 2019.

headline: How Groundbreaking Is Vivian Maier’s Photography?
abstract: She was a supremely gifted chameleon. But even in her striking new exhibition at Fotografiska, Maier remains in the shadows.
lead_paragraph: Vivian Maier was a disappearance artist. Street photographers typically keep hidden when shooting, but Maier receded in every aspect of her life. Her now well-known story, which has contributed greatly to her posthumous fame, is that while she supported herself through employment as a nanny, her true vocation was photography. She worked primarily in black-and-white with a square-format Rolleiflex, the same camera used by many of the greats, including Diane Arbus, Richard Avedon and Bill Brandt.

headline: The Joys and Perils of Return Travel
abstract: You’ve changed, and the place has changed. It exists for you in the past and for a past version of yourself.
lead_paragraph: Last week I went to Venice, where I had been invited to participate in an arts conference. It was the first time I’d been back in 32 years.

headline: Elden Ring Raised Masochists, and They’re Back for More
abstract: Influencers who have guided players through an unforgiving world are powering anticipation for the video game’s next chapter, Shadow of the Erdtree.
lead_paragraph: Kai Cenat had died more than 430 times and was prepared to die again when one of the toughest adversaries in video game history, Malenia, Goddess of Rot, finally succumbed to his sword after a marathon battle in Elden Ring.

headline: Ukraine Stalled Russia Near the Border. This Town Has Paid the Price.
abstract: Faced with an assault from the northeast, Ukrainian forces made their stand in Vovchansk. The front line is still there, but little else is.
lead_paragraph: A month into Russia’s push across the border in northern Ukraine, Western weapons and Ukrainian reinforcements have largely stalled the attack. But they came too late to save one town, Vovchansk, where the city hall, a cultural center, countless apartment blocks and several riverside hotels are all now in ruins.

headline: 171,000 Traveled for Abortions Last Year. See Where They Went.
abstract: Out-of-state trips for abortions more than doubled in 2023, demonstrating the upheaval in access since the overturn of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: Out-of-state trips for abortions more than doubled in 2023, demonstrating the upheaval in access since the overturn of Roe v. Wade.

headline: For Lincoln Center’s West Side, A New Story
abstract: The formidable arts institution has hired a design team to reconsider its relationship with its neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: The formidable arts institution has hired a design team to reconsider its relationship with its neighborhood.

headline: Hunter Biden and the Sadness of Being Defined by Your Sins
abstract: President Ronald Reagan’s daughter Patti Davis on addiction and the political spotlight.
lead_paragraph: Hunter Biden’s conviction has led Patti Davis to consider her own years of addiction. In this audio essay, Davis argues that the world should have compassion for Biden. The political spotlight is so bright, she says, and “being held accountable under the judgmental eyes of the world means you’re defined by your sins, not by the person you’re trying to become.”

headline: Maybe It All Comes Down to Abortion
abstract: In the battleground state of Arizona, Democrats hope that anger over Dobbs and state-level restrictions will send people to the polls and keep Biden in the White House.
lead_paragraph: Arizona is a battleground state that both parties are desperate to win in November.

headline: They Wanted a Small House on a Quiet Brooklyn Street. Would Their Budget Cover It?
abstract: Seeking enough space for a music studio, a guest room and some outdoor space, a New York City couple searched south of Prospect Park for a house that fit their needs.
lead_paragraph: Seeking enough space for a music studio, a guest room and some outdoor space, a New York City couple searched south of Prospect Park for a house that fit their needs.

headline: HBO Could Use a Hit. Enter the Dragons.
abstract: The network has hit an unusually fallow period. Executives hope “House of the Dragon,” which returns Sunday, could be the start of a new winning streak.
lead_paragraph: The dragons are back. And not a moment too soon.

headline: How ‘Bridgerton’ Makes History
abstract: Described by its showrunner as “definitely a fantasy,” the hit series relies on a team of historical consultants. Does the show take their advice? Mostly.
lead_paragraph: When the first season of the Netflix series “Bridgerton” premiered on Christmas Day, Amanda Vickery sat at home with her three daughters and watched every episode. This was in 2020, in the midst of England’s lockdown, and Vickery remembers thinking, “Thank goodness for this escape.”

headline: The Writer Behind the Most-Nominated Play in Broadway History
abstract: David Adjmi discusses “Stereophonic.”
lead_paragraph: David Adjmi felt out of place in the Syrian Jewish community in Brooklyn, where he grew up. He felt uncomfortable at the Juilliard School, where he studied playwriting. Some of the earliest productions of his plays taught him that his theatrical style could be frustrating and alienating for his collaborators and his audiences. In a review of a 2013 Off Off Broadway production of Adjmi’s play “Marie Antoinette,” the Times theater critic Ben Brantley called Adjmi “a polarizing playwright who specializes in sounding the depths of shallowness.” Adjmi decided that mainstream success was out of reach for him. He considered giving up writing altogether.

headline: The Young Designers to Know at Pitti Uomo
abstract: Plus: a boutique hotel in Philadelphia’s Fishtown, a new line of English knitwear and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: I never really take my eye makeup off, and I don’t wear foundation or concealer. I just splash water on my face in the morning and I use Environ Retinol Serum 1. If I’m a good girl I use Garnier Vitamin C Daily UV Brightening Fluid and then I put more eye makeup on my already made-up eyes. I use any black eyeliner on my waterline. It’s always a pencil — you can smudge it way easier and I like my makeup looking a little bit effortless. Right now I’m using one from Givenchy, their Khôl Couture Waterproof pencil. I get eyelash extensions done every two or three weeks, so I don’t really use mascara. I used to wake up an hour before school started just to do my makeup. Now that I get eyelash extensions, I feel ready as soon as I wake up; I’ll never stop getting them. Sometimes I use a cheek tint from Jillian Dempsey that makes me look sun-kissed. I put it on my nose. Sometimes I’ll use Chanel Le Gel Sourcils on my brows. I naturally have pretty thin brows but I’ve thinned them out more recently because I saw a picture of my mom in the ’90s and she looked so good with thin brows. The only lipstick I use is by Kiko Milano — Powder Power Lipstick in shade 15. I put it on my nose, lips and cheeks. Sometimes I do my makeup before I get into the shower — it’s such a good hack. Your skin gets dewy. I know your T-zone is meant to look matte but I like it looking a little sweaty sometimes. My makeup artist uses a Chanel Baume Essentiel highlighter stick that’s so amazing. It’s completely clear.

headline: What Exactly Did Justice Alito Say That Was Wrong?
abstract: His remarks should not have been controversial.
lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel Alito has been widely criticized this week for remarks he made to a self-described documentary filmmaker who on two occasions engaged him at social events, secretly taped him under false pretenses and released the recordings. What did he say that was wrong?

headline: What to Know About the Southern Baptists’ Vote Opposing I.V.F.
abstract: Wednesday’s vote was not a ban on in vitro fertilization. But it suggested that ordinary evangelicals are increasingly open to seeing embryos as people.
lead_paragraph: Southern Baptists, the country’s largest denomination of Protestant Christians, voted at an annual gathering on Wednesday to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization.

headline: Trump Returns to Washington With Renewed Grip on the G.O.P.
abstract: Three and a half years after the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, Donald J. Trump made a visit to Capitol Hill, as his party’s wary establishment rallies around his possible return to power.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump returned to Capitol Hill on Thursday for a pair of celebratory meetings with congressional Republicans, more than three years after a violent mob of his supporters overran the House and the Senate as he pushed to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: The U.N. Report on Israeli and Palestinian War Crimes: What We Know
abstract: The findings cite acts such as sexual violence and the deliberate killing or abducting of civilians by Hamas. They also accuse Israel of collective punishment and crimes against humanity in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: A commission at the United Nations published a report on Wednesday detailing acts of violence in Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories, accusing both sides of war crimes and arguing that the immense loss of life in the Gaza Strip amounted to a crime against humanity.

headline: 36 Hours in Ljubljana, Slovenia
abstract: Stroll along the river, explore a contemporary art scene and admire panoramic views in this scenic Central European capital.
lead_paragraph: Stroll along the river, explore a contemporary art scene and admire panoramic views in this scenic Central European capital.

headline: ‘Oddly Satisfying’ Cow Pedicure Videos Are a Hit on TikTok
abstract: In one corner of the internet, professional trimmers grind and buff away at cow hooves to the delight of millions of spellbound social media users.
lead_paragraph: There are many paths to internet stardom, but there are only a few ways to correctly trim a cow hoof.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,091, June 14, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 369, June 14, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Inside Trump’s Search for a Vice President
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s list of potential running mates has focused on a set of loyal campaigners.
lead_paragraph: The makeup of the 2024 presidential race has felt inevitable from the start — with one notable exception: Donald J. Trump’s choice of a running mate.
