abstract: The Biden campaign is trying to work its way into social media feeds. But it is struggling to win over the young, left-leaning influencers who control the conversation online.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday afternoon in late April, President Biden brought celebrities and elite social media influencers together for a White House reception. Fran Drescher and David Cross mingled with Ilona Maher, a rugby star, and V from @underthedesknews, at a mixer meant to generate warm feelings and badly needed pro-Biden content.

headline: Sex, Money and Séances: This 1922 Murder Had It All
abstract: A scion of wealth claimed self-defense and invoked a sinister blackmailing ring. But, James Polchin asks, what did they have on him?
lead_paragraph: “Shadow Men” opens on a note of uncertainty: “We don’t know why Duncan Rose was late to work that May morning in 1922.” As it turns out, it doesn’t really matter what detained him; like a cold-opener on “Law & Order,” he’s just a device to get us to the main event — a dead body on the side of the road in Westchester County.

headline: Where There’s a Trump Highway but Not Many Trump Flags
abstract: In Cimarron County, Okla., the voters and the community have a lot more going on than just adherence to Trump.
lead_paragraph: In the center of the country, there’s a place that’s home to what is likely the world’s only President Donald J. Trump Highway. But don’t go looking for Trump flags there, because you’ll have a hard time finding any.

headline: The ‘Disdain’ of Justice Alito and the Supreme Court
abstract: Flags, financial disclosures and the fragility of SCOTUS.
lead_paragraph: Amid politically charged flag flying, secret recordings, and eyebrow-raising financial disclosures, there’s something fishy about the behavior of the nation’s top judges. Are they ruining faith in the Supreme Court? Or is that the partisan reaction to the decisions coming from on high?

headline: Why the Stock Market Has Risen Even With No Fed Rate Cuts
abstract: The S&P 500 has been buoyant mainly because of A.I. fever, while bonds are having another mediocre year. But as an investor, our columnist is staying the course.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve has disappointed investors this year, but no matter. The markets have adjusted.

headline: Charli XCX, Robert Plant and More Music for Your Weekend
abstract: Our critic’s favorite new songs
lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic for The New York Times, recommends the reinvention of a classic rock song, a genre-bending musical odyssey, a country revenge song and more:

headline: Justice Alito Is Right About One Thing
abstract: There cannot be compromise on the question of American democracy.
lead_paragraph: Justice Samuel Alito is right.

headline: Katie Holmes Doesn’t Get the Fascination With Her Style
abstract: The actress, who lent her name to a new line by A.P.C., cares mostly about dressing practically.
lead_paragraph: What is it about Katie Holmes that has professional style watchers breathlessly documenting her every fashion choice?

headline: The Chilling Reason You May Never See the New Trump Movie
abstract: Hollywood shouldn’t pre-emptively capitulate to the MAGA movement.
lead_paragraph: This week I finally got to see “The Apprentice,” an absorbing, disturbing movie about the relationship between the red-baiting mob lawyer Roy Cohn and a young Donald Trump. The film, which was received with an extended standing ovation and mostly appreciative reviews when it premiered at Cannes last month, is a classic story of a mentor and his protégé, chronicling how Trump first learned from and later surpassed his brutal, Machiavellian fixer.

headline: How ‘Inside Out 2’ Battles Anxiety
abstract: The director Kelsey Mann narrates a sequence from his film, which pits Joy (voiced by Amy Poehler) against Anxiety (Maya Hawke).
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 14, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Silvia Moreno-Garcia, Elliot Page, Binyavanga Wainaina and more.
lead_paragraph: Recommended reading from the Book Review, including titles by Silvia Moreno-Garcia, Elliot Page, Binyavanga Wainaina and more.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the Pixar sequel “Inside Out 2.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the Pixar sequel “Inside Out 2.”

headline: Apple Joins the A.I. Party, Elon’s Wild Week and HatGPT
abstract: “They really sort of make you feel like it’s Christmas and Coachella at the same time.”
lead_paragraph: This week we go to Cupertino, Calif., for Apple’s annual Worldwide Developers Conference and talk with Tripp Mickle, a New York Times reporter, about all of the new features Apple announced and the company’s giant leap into artificial intelligence. Then, we explore what was another tumultuous week for Elon Musk, who navigated a shareholders vote to re-approve his massive compensation package at Tesla, amid new claims that he had sex with subordinates at SpaceX. And finally — let’s play HatGPT.

headline: How to Create ‘Rooms Within a Room’ in 312 Square Feet
abstract: For a tiny apartment in London, the solution was a shape-shifting bank of custom cabinetry built on a tight budget.
lead_paragraph: When Helen Zhou began looking for an apartment to buy in London, she already liked the thought of living small.

headline: Israelis Are Not Watching the Same War You Are
abstract: The Israeli journalist Amit Segal discusses Benny Gantz’s departure from the war cabinet, Israel’s shift to the right and whether a new theory of security is emerging in Israeli politics.
lead_paragraph: [You can listen to this episode of “The Ezra Klein Show” on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube or wherever you get your podcasts.]

headline: Site of Parkland Shooting Is Being Torn Down
abstract: Demolition of the former freshman building at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School began on Friday and was expected to take a few weeks, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Six years after a gunman killed 17 people at a Parkland, Fla., high school in one of the deadliest school shootings in American history, the site of the attack is being torn down.

headline: Mississippi Opens the Playbook for Dismantling a Free Press
abstract: A politician’s defamation case against a small Pulitzer Prize-winning news organization is designed to drain its financial resources.
lead_paragraph: Slow-moving lawsuits intended to drain newsrooms of their limited financial resources and editorial bandwidth. Threats of jail time for journalists who expose political corruption and refuse to give up their sources and turn over their notes. Judges with close ties to the politicians who have attacked reporters and their coverage.

headline: Parisians on TikTok Plead: ‘Don’t Come’ to Paris for the Olympics
abstract: Parisians are using the social media app to vent their displeasure with hosting the Games — and to send warnings to tourists.
lead_paragraph: “This is a video for anyone that’s coming to Paris Olympics 2024,” a woman says in a clip posted to TikTok. She pauses briefly, and then continues: “Don’t come. Cancel everything.”

headline: ‘No Talent Involved’: How Bad TikToks Boosted a Curry House
abstract: Urban Tandoor, an Indian restaurant in southwest England, is using terrible music video parodies made by its staff to bring in new and younger guests.
lead_paragraph: The tables were filling up at Urban Tandoor, a British curry house wholesome enough for a family meal and elegant enough for a low-key first date. Painted flowers twist up its entrance and lights adorn the colorful walls inside, a homage to Bristol’s artistic reputation. The local haunt in southwest England promises an array of crowd-pleasers, from jalfrezi to moilee.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,092, June 15, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 370, June 15, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: How to Retire as Early as Humanly Possible
abstract: Meet the extreme savers obsessed with ending their careers as soon as they can.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans work their entire lives and end up retiring with nothing. But a group of frugal obsessives is challenging that.

headline: Major Supreme Court Rulings, and Counterfeit Titanium in Planes
abstract: Plus, New York targets rogue smoke shops.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Two Covid Theories
abstract: Was the pandemic started by a lab leak or by natural transmission? We look at the evidence.
lead_paragraph: The origin of the Covid virus remains the pandemic’s biggest mystery. Did the virus jump to human beings from animals being sold at a food market in Wuhan, China? Or did the virus leak from a laboratory in Wuhan?

headline: Stephen Colbert and Whoopi Goldberg Met the Pope in the Vatican. No Joke.
abstract: Francis hosted an audience with over 100 comic entertainers, also including Chris Rock, Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Conan O’Brien. He said there was much to learn from them.
lead_paragraph: A late-night television host, a stand-up comedian and a comic actress walk into the Vatican, and the pope says, “Is this some kind of joke?”

headline: Musk’s Tesla Pay Package Got Big Margin in Shareholder Vote
abstract: About 72 percent of shares in the balloting affirmed the chief executive’s lucrative stock award. The company hopes to get a court to reinstate it.
lead_paragraph: Tesla shareholders decisively backed a proposal to affirm Elon Musk’s multibillion-dollar pay package, according to details of the vote released on Friday.

headline: 9 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: In the sequel to the Pixar charmer “Inside Out,” Riley (voiced by Kensington Tallman) develops a new range of (anthropomorphized) emotions like Anxiety (Maya Hawke) and Envy (Ayo Edebiri) when she reaches puberty.

headline: What Elon Musk’s Convincing Win Means for Tesla
abstract: Investors voted overwhelmingly to reinstate the C.E.O.’s multibillion-dollar compensation package, inextricably tying the car maker’s future to the tech billionaire.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk got his way.

headline: Ukraine Welcomes Pledges of More Military Aid With Cautious Optimism
abstract: Kyiv signed security pacts with several Western allies this week. Whether they will fundamentally change the course of the war, or endure beyond looming elections elsewhere, is unclear.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine has in recent weeks faced the full force of Russia’s multifaceted attacks, with Moscow sending waves of troops to break through Ukrainian lines in the east and barrages of missiles to knock out the country’s energy system.

headline: Putin Makes Cease-Fire Offer With Sweeping Demands on Ukraine’s Territory
abstract: Ukraine denounced the offer, saying that Mr. Putin was “afraid of real peace.” The Russian leader made the remarks one day before a peace summit organized by Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin said on Friday that Russia would be ready to order a cease-fire in Ukraine and enter negotiations with its government if Kyiv were to withdraw troops from the four regions that Moscow has claimed as its own and drop its aspirations to join NATO.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 2: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by June 21 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced by July 3.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the second week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: First a Victim of Tax Return Identity Theft, Then a 2-Year Wait for a Refund
abstract: The I.R.S.’s Taxpayer Advocate Service found that many of those affected were lower-income people who depended on refunds to cover living costs. The wait is “ridiculous,” the head of the service said.
lead_paragraph: Federal income tax refunds usually appear in bank accounts less than three weeks after the government accepts a return — unless you’re the victim of tax return identity theft. In that case, it often takes about two years.

headline: A California Law Banning Hidden Fees Goes Into Effect Next Month
abstract: Some lawmakers are trying to carve out an exception for restaurant owners, who say simply raising prices without context would hurt their business.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom signed legislation last fall that would make it illegal for businesses in California to tack on fees beyond their listed prices, like a “resort fee” at a hotel or a service charge that inflates the cost of a concert ticket.

headline: A France in Turmoil Mourns Françoise Hardy, Its Voice of Melancholy Cool
abstract: An overwhelming outpouring of tributes felt like a quest for some anchor in shared memory.
lead_paragraph: It was like Françoise Hardy, the wistful singer and songwriter of a certain French melancholy and style, to slip away in the midst of a political storm, for it was never the clamor of power struggles that interested her, but rather an inner world of solitude, love betrayed and loss.

headline: Trump plans to celebrate his 78th birthday in Florida with a trusted group of supporters.
abstract: Republicans on Capitol Hill presented a cake to Donald J. Trump on Thursday and serenaded him for his 78th birthday. He is scheduled to spend Friday, his actual birthday, in Palm Beach, Fla., with a group of supporters, led by three Florida residents, called Club 47 USA.
lead_paragraph: Republicans on Capitol Hill presented a cake to Donald J. Trump on Thursday and serenaded him for his 78th birthday. He is scheduled to spend Friday, his actual birthday, in Palm Beach, Fla., with a group of supporters, led by three Florida residents, called Club 47 USA.

headline: $995,000 Homes in the Bahamas
abstract: A two-cottage compound on Lubbers Quarters Cay, a three-bedroom bungalow on Great Exuma island, and a two-bedroom condo on Paradise Island.
lead_paragraph: Two cottages connected by a walkway make up this peaceful residence on Lubbers Quarters Cay, a small island off the east coast of Great Abaco Island in the Bahamas. Each cottage has an en suite bedroom, and the larger of the two also has a kitchen, a living room and a sunroom overlooking the water. The property, sold furnished, has a new Westinghouse 7.5-kilowatt generator.

headline: Flooding Remains Possible on Fourth Day of Soaking Rains in South Florida
abstract: A flood watch was active until Saturday evening after hundreds of flights were canceled and states of emergency were declared in several counties. More rain was expected into the afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Steady rain showers were falling for the fourth consecutive day across South Florida on Friday morning, capping a week in which the soggy weather pattern caused major travel disruptions and flooded homes and roadways.

headline: Finding Strength Through Song
abstract: Writing music helps me create a space where subjugation and violence are far away.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Trump Is Thinking About His Debates. And His Running Mate’s, Too.
abstract: As he considers his vice-presidential pick, Donald J. Trump has sought advice on a few key factors, including who will match up best on the debate stage against Vice President Kamala Harris.
lead_paragraph: Soon after two overheated Ohio Republicans stood chest-to-chest trading taunts on the debate stage in 2022, Donald J. Trump watched a video of the viral clip and raised an eyebrow.

headline: How Tesla Shareholders Upheld Elon Musk’s Sky-High Pay
abstract: The vote on the compensation package, which helped make Mr. Musk one of the richest men in the world, served as a referendum on his performance running the automaker.
lead_paragraph: The vote on the compensation package, which helped make Mr. Musk one of the richest men in the world, served as a referendum on his performance running the automaker.

headline: G7 Agrees to $50 Billion Ukraine Loan Backed by Russian Assets. How Will It Work?
abstract: The United States and others plan to give the sum to Kyiv, with the interest from Moscow’s assets frozen in the West used to repay it. But many of the details about the arrangement are unclear.
lead_paragraph: The United States and the other large Group of 7 economies agreed on Thursday on a plan to give Ukraine a $50 billion loan to help it buy weapons and begin to rebuild damaged infrastructure. The move comes at a crucial moment in the war, when Russia has the momentum on the battlefield.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Trump-Era Ban on Gun Bump Stocks
abstract: The devices allow semiautomatic guns to fire more rapidly. They were banned after one of the deadliest mass shootings in modern U.S. history, at a Las Vegas concert in 2017.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday struck down a ban on bump stocks, which enable semiautomatic rifles to fire at speeds rivaling those of machine guns, erasing one of the government’s rare firearm regulations to result from a mass shooting.

headline: $29 Trillion: That’s How Much Debt Emerging Nations Are Facing
abstract: A decades-long crisis is getting worse, and now dozens of nations are spending more on interest payments than on health care or education.
lead_paragraph: The Vatican’s meeting on the global debt crisis last week was not quite as celebrity-studded as the one that Pope John Paul II presided over 25 years ago, when he donned sunglasses given to him by Bono, U2’s lead singer.

headline: It’s the Summer of ‘Brats’
abstract: Fans of the new Charli XCX album count themselves among them. But the term “brat” has cropped up elsewhere in culture lately, and it has subtly different meanings.
lead_paragraph: Sheer white tank tops. Skinny cigarettes (not vapes). Questionable 3 a.m. decisions.

headline: Millions of Americans Watched ‘The Apprentice.’ Now We Are Living It.
abstract: As a new book by Ramin Setoodeh shows, Donald Trump brought the vulgar theatrics he honed on TV to his life in politics.
lead_paragraph: In 2004, when the entertainment journalist Ramin Setoodeh was 22, Newsweek assigned him to cover a new reality show starring Donald Trump. The show’s mix of product-hawking and emotional volatility was a hit; and in the years since “The Apprentice” first aired on NBC, Setoodeh would go on to become the co-editor in chief of Variety and Trump, of course, would go on to become president — arguably in large part because American audiences bought the mirage of the successful, no-nonsense businessman that Trump played on TV.

headline: Fauci Speaks His Mind on Trump’s Rages and Their ‘Complicated’ Relationship
abstract: In a new book, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci recounts a career advising seven presidents. The chapter about Donald J. Trump is titled “He Loves Me, He Loves Me Not.”
lead_paragraph: Three months into the coronavirus pandemic, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci was at home in northwest Washington when he answered his cellphone to President Donald J. Trump screaming at him in an expletive-laden rant. He had incurred the president’s wrath by remarking that the vaccines under development might not provide long-lasting immunity.

headline: It’s Time to Sweat. The East Coast’s First Heat Wave Is on the Way.
abstract: The abrupt arrival of summer will bring stifling temperatures from Chicago to New York, with little relief overnight.
lead_paragraph: Prepare to sweat on the East Coast through next week. The first heat wave of the summer is coming.

headline: Erin Moriarty Is a Woman Among ‘The Boys’
abstract: The actress in the hit superhero satire mulled her role in an age of online bullying and token feminism: “Thank God there are characters like this.”
lead_paragraph: Erin Moriarty just stopped a stranger in his tracks. But it wasn’t because he recognized her as a star on one of TV’s most popular shows, or because he was taken by her charm.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Review: Waiting for the Fire Breathers
abstract: The second season of HBO’s very successful “Game of Thrones” prequel gets off to an earthbound start.
lead_paragraph: Diplomacy versus violence. Dignity versus unbridled passion. Duty versus the selfish desire for revenge.

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include bruised bodies and bruised male egos.
lead_paragraph: Manuel (Gianmarco Franchini) is in trouble. The corrupt police commissioner, Vasco (Adriano Giannini), is blackmailing Manuel, a 16-year-old, to infiltrate a drug-fueled party and engage in a sex act, on camera, with an attending politician. When the boy gets cold feet, abruptly fleeing from the party, he searches for protection; his father, Daytona (Toni Servillo), a former crime boss with dementia, provides some refuge. But it’s the terminally ill mobster Cammello (Pierfrancesco Favino) who really steps up.

headline: Four Takeaways From the Metropolitan Opera’s Risky Season
abstract: The company has bet that new operas will attract new, more diverse audiences and revitalize a stale repertory. Is the gamble paying off?
lead_paragraph: For years, the Metropolitan Opera — the nation’s largest performing arts institution, with a $300 million budget and 4,000-seat theater — was like an ocean liner, changing course slowly, if at all.

headline: A Smoked Prime Rib for the Ages
abstract: Serve with mac and cheese, coleslaw, pickled jalapeños and potato salad.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. My colleague Gabriel Sanchez brought us a fantastic recipe for Father’s Day this year: the smoked prime rib (above) that his father makes, a homage to the one he used to prepare when he was cooking at Kreuz Market in Lockhart, Texas, where Gabe’s great-grandfather tended the coals before him.

headline: Crisis Averted: Martha’s Vineyard Will Have Enough Pot This Summer After All
abstract: For the island’s cannabis dispensaries, a sudden change in regulations came just in time.
lead_paragraph: Until recently, Geoff Rose, the proprietor of a cannabis business on Martha’s Vineyard, believed he was in for a bleak summer.

headline: House G.O.P. Pushes Through Defense Bill Nixing Abortion Access Policy
abstract: The annual defense policy legislation emerged from a House committee with bipartisan backing, but Republicans loaded it with right-wing mandates targeting abortion, transgender care and diversity initiatives.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans banded together on Friday to narrowly pass an $895 billion defense policy bill that would restrict access to abortion and transgender medical care in the military and eliminate all positions and offices of diversity, equity and inclusion across the Pentagon.

headline: Trump Once Promised to Revive Coal. Now, He Rarely Mentions It.
abstract: In earlier races for the White House, he pledged to get miners back to work. Now, political and economic realities have shifted.
lead_paragraph: The first time Donald J. Trump ran for president, he slapped on a miner’s helmet and told coal workers they would be “winning, winning, winning” when he entered the White House.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Bump Stock Decision Will Prove Fatal
abstract: Machine guns on the street are now legal again.
lead_paragraph: There was nothing abstract about the 6-to-3 decision issued Friday morning by the Supreme Court to permit bump stocks to be used on semiautomatic rifles. It is one of the most astonishingly dangerous decisions ever issued by the court, and it will almost surely result in a loss of American lives in another mass shooting.

headline: Jelly Roll’s Anthem of Perseverance, and 9 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Zsela, the Decemberists, Khalid and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Trump Participates in His Form of Debate Prep, Readying to Face Biden
abstract: The former president is engaging in policy briefings — but no role playing, or other traditional aspects of debate preparations — ahead of the June 27 debate against President Biden.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s aides often downplay his preparations for events like debates.

headline: F.B.I. Director Makes Rare Visit to Africa as Terrorism Threat Grows
abstract: The Islamic State and Al Qaeda consider Africa ‘very fertile ground,’ said Christopher A. Wray, who is meeting with officials in Nigeria and Kenya.
lead_paragraph: Christopher A. Wray, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, paid a rare visit to sub-Saharan Africa this week to discuss counterterrorism strategies with regional partners at a time when both the Islamic State and Al Qaeda are gaining momentum on the continent.

headline: What ‘Inside Out 2’ Teaches Us About Anxiety
abstract: A new emotion has taken over Riley’s teenage mind. And she has lessons for us all.
lead_paragraph: At the end of “Inside Out,” the 2015 Pixar movie about the emotional life of a girl named Riley, a new button appears on the console used to control Riley’s mood. It’s emblazoned with one word: Puberty.

headline: 19 Nonfiction Books to Read This Summer
abstract: Memoirs from Anthony Fauci and Anna Marie Tendler, a reappraisal of Harriet Tubman, a history of reality TV from Emily Nussbaum — and plenty more.
lead_paragraph: Judy Garland, Sean Connery, Carrie Fisher: Celebrities abound in the actor’s new memoir. Dunne’s book is engaging as much for his fame-adjacent vignettes as for his frank exploration of his famous family’s complicated history — most notably that of his sister, Dominique Dunne, a rising star in Hollywood whose career was cut short when she was killed by her ex-boyfriend. His account of her death and the subsequent infamous trial is an illuminating perspective.

headline: 33 Novels Coming This Summer
abstract: Watch for new books by J. Courtney Sullivan, Kevin Barry and Casey McQuiston; re-immerse yourself in beloved worlds conjured by Walter Mosley, Elin Hilderbrand and Rebecca Roanhorse.
lead_paragraph: The latest in this best-selling mystery series about Easy Rawlins centers on a missing-persons case that takes the beloved private detective deep into his own past. Easy’s lost love asks for help finding her ex-husband — a forensic accountant who got mixed up in trouble — prompting a torrent of memories.

headline: ‘Good Days and Bad Days’: Princess of Wales Gives Update on Cancer
abstract: In a message to the public, Catherine said she would attend King Charles’s birthday parade this weekend and wrote candidly about “knowing I am not out of the woods yet.”
lead_paragraph: Catherine, the Princess of Wales, said on Friday that she planned to take part in a parade on Saturday marking the birthday of King Charles III, a tentative return to the public stage after confirming in March that she was being treated for cancer.

headline: Almost 20 Years After She Found Her Mother’s Body, a Cold Case Thaws
abstract: She was just a girl when her mother was stabbed to death in the Bronx. Now, an arrest based on DNA has brought her bittersweet relief.
lead_paragraph: Things were off that morning. Her mother always called out “I love you, baby,” before leaving for work; there was only silence. And she always left the bathroom light on; only darkness.

headline: Storms Inundate Parts of South Florida
abstract: Heavy rains flooded neighborhoods and submerged cars.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains flooded neighborhoods and submerged cars.

headline: Why Cover Saudi Arabia as a Travel Destination?
abstract: An editor on the Travel desk explains our decision to explore the Middle Eastern kingdom.
lead_paragraph: When my Travel story about Saudi Arabia was published online last week, some readers bristled.

headline: When Churches Cancel Their Own
abstract: Responses to a column by David French and his former church. Also: An extremist Supreme Court; a “failing candidacy”; help after prison.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Fetterman Has History of Driving Infractions, Records and Former Aides Say
abstract: The senator’s accident in Maryland last weekend did not come as a surprise to some of his former staff members, who said he was a notoriously distracted driver.
lead_paragraph: Senator John Fetterman, Democrat of Pennsylvania, was at fault in a car accident in Maryland on Sunday and has a record of distracted driving and infractions, according to police records and former aides.

abstract: The rate of inflation in May over the previous year.
lead_paragraph: The Consumer Price Index, released on Wednesday, found that prices in May increased 3.3 percent from a year earlier. That was lower than the 3.4 percent that economists had forecast and down from the April reading.

headline: The Ultimate Dad Rock Playlist
abstract: What is dad rock? You know it when you hear it, so listen to 10 songs from Wilco, the Grateful Dead, Steely Dan and more.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday is Father’s Day, and I would like to celebrate the only way I know how — with a playlist of dad rock.

headline: French Stocks Tumble to Worst Week in Two Years Over Election Fears
abstract: Investors worry about a possible debt crisis in the country as polls show the far right could be brought to the brink of power in less than a month.
lead_paragraph: A growing realization that President Emmanuel Macron’s decision to hold snap elections in France may backfire sent the French stock market tumbling on Friday to its lowest level in two years, and prompted warnings from the French finance minister that the economy risks stumbling into a financial crisis.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: There was a wealth of news to discuss this week, including former President Trump’s next steps after being convicted of 34 felonies and Hunter Biden’s guilty verdict on gun charges. Here’s what the hosts had to say.
lead_paragraph: There was a wealth of news to discuss this week, including former President Trump’s next steps after being convicted of 34 felonies and Hunter Biden’s guilty verdict on gun charges. Here’s what the hosts had to say.

headline: Chinese Swimmers Twice Tested Positive for Drugs. They Kept on Swimming.
abstract: Three athletes who failed drug tests before the 2021 Olympics had tested positive for a banned drug several years earlier. They were not suspended in either incident.
lead_paragraph: After the revelation in April that 23 elite Chinese swimmers had tested positive for a banned substance months before the last Summer Olympic Games, China and the global antidoping authority vigorously defended their decisions to allow them to compete in the Games in 2021. The swimmers, they insisted, had not been doping.

headline: Federal Judge Blocks Biden Administration’s Title IX Rules in 4 States
abstract: The ruling was an early salvo in a national legal battle over the new regulations, which extend stronger protections to L.G.B.T.Q. students.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration’s new Title IX regulations that expanded protections for L.G.B.T.Q. students have been temporarily blocked in four states after a federal judge ruled that the Education Department overstepped its authority.

headline: El Niño Is Over. What Does That Mean for Summer?
abstract: The NOAA Climate Prediction Center announced an end to the El Niño climate phenomenon on Thursday, and predicted that La Niña could start as early as next month.
lead_paragraph: El Niño, the natural climate pattern linked to warmer conditions in the tropical Pacific Ocean, has ended, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced on Thursday. The counterpart pattern known as La Niña, defined by cooler equatorial sea surface temperatures, is expected to develop soon.

headline: How Media Outlets on the Right and Left Covered the Latest Inflation Numbers
abstract: Conservative media outlets used the new inflation data, which was lower than expected, to criticize President Biden’s handling of the economy. Liberal media outlets celebrated it.
lead_paragraph: Prices rose 3.3 percent in May from a year earlier, according to data released Wednesday, a lower number than expected. Partisan media outlets covered that number very differently.

headline: The Ingenuity of Lowcountry’s Deviled Crab
abstract: Deviling bolsters smaller pieces of blue crab with mayonnaise, bread crumbs, sautéed aromatics, plus a kick of cayenne.
lead_paragraph: Growing up on Hilton Head Island, S.C., Andrew Carmines loved visiting nearby Singleton Beach for its promise of deviled crabs, a cousin to crab cakes that originated here in the South Carolina Lowcountry, served from a seaside shack.

headline: U.S. Catholic Bishops Apologize for Traumas of Indian Boarding Schools
abstract: The bishops acknowledged the church’s role in operating schools where Native American children faced abuses and forced assimilation.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops issued a formal apology on Friday for the church’s role in the mistreatment and trauma experienced by Native Americans in the United States, notably in church-operating boarding schools that sought to force the assimilation of Native children into American culture.

headline: At the G7, Biden Can’t Escape the Shadow of the Gaza War
abstract: The president was miffed when, expecting to talk about a security pact with Ukraine, he was asked for updates on the Gaza cease-fire plan.
lead_paragraph: Sharing the stage with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine at a sprawling seaside resort in Italy, President Biden was looking forward to talking about a security pact he had just signed to provide continued support to Ukraine in its battle with Russia.

headline: Google C.E.O. Testifies in Ozy Media Founder’s Fraud Trial
abstract: Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google, said he never discussed a potential acquisition of the digital media start-up.
lead_paragraph: Sundar Pichai, the chief executive of Google, said in a New York courtroom on Friday that he never discussed a possible takeover of Ozy Media.

headline: N.Y.P.D. Detective Wounded in Shootout That Ended With Suspect Dead
abstract: The New York officer was shot in the foot at a New Jersey hotel after the police and a man sought in an East Harlem shooting exchanged gunfire, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A man sought for questioning in an East Harlem shooting was killed early Thursday by police officers in New Jersey after he fired a gun at two of them, including a New York City police detective, officials said.

headline: Larry Summers Isn’t Second-Guessing the Government on Inflation
abstract: The C.P.I. has been criticized for excluding interest payments, but there’s a solid reason for that.
lead_paragraph: Interest payments aren’t counted in the inflation rate. This is a fact that a lot of readers find confusing, if not angering, especially now, when rates are high on mortgages, auto loans and credit cards. I get lots of mail from people saying the absence of interest rates from the Consumer Price Index seems like sleight of hand by the government, the economics profession or both.

headline: How Jeff Bezos Is Trying to Fix The Washington Post
abstract: The Amazon founder has expressed his support to Will Lewis, the C.E.O., who has faced widespread criticism this month.
lead_paragraph: When The Washington Post’s staff gathered in the newsroom in early May to celebrate winning three Pulitzer Prizes, one person was conspicuously absent: Will Lewis, the company’s publisher and chief executive.

headline: I Think My Husband Has Dementia. Can I Leave Him Before It Worsens?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what happens when the implications of marital vows to love “in sickness and in health” become increasingly urgent.
lead_paragraph: I strongly suspect that my husband is developing dementia. His doctors have found nothing wrong with him. I understand that ‘‘mini’’ cognition tests might not find anything amiss in the early stages of disease, and I imagine that what are now subtle changes will eventually become obvious. In the meantime, our decades-long relationship has eroded. My insistence that he engage with me in maintaining a quality relationship has led to endless fighting and brought me to the brink of divorce.

headline: Johnny Canales, Influential Mexican TV Host, Dies at 81
abstract: He was known for introducing new musical acts to a wide audience, including Selena Quintanilla, whose appearance on his show in 1985 was one of her first live TV performances.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Canales, a popular Mexican television host whose program introduced new musical acts to wide audiences — including, in the 1980s, a young Selena Quintanilla — died on Wednesday. He was 81.

headline: Girl, 13, Sexually Assaulted at Knifepoint in Queens Park, Police Say
abstract: The girl and a schoolmate, a 13-year-old boy, were forced into a secluded area by a man who later fled, the authorities said. Investigators combed the area for evidence Friday.
lead_paragraph: A man with a “machete-style knife” on Thursday afternoon forced a 13-year-old girl and 13-year-old boy into a wooded area of a Queens park where the girl was sexually assaulted, the police said.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, June 15, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Cuomo Faulted for Pandemic Leadership but Not for Nursing Home Deaths
abstract: An audit commissioned by his successor said former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s decision to centralize the state response to the pandemic in his office was a “significant” mistake.
lead_paragraph: A long-awaited review of New York State’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic under former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declined to fault him for the thousands of people who died of Covid-19 at nursing homes.

headline: For Gay Catholics and Supporters, a ‘Sense of Whiplash’ Over Pope’s Reported Use of Slur
abstract: Pope Francis, noted for his outreach to gay Catholics, has been described as using an offensive Italian expression for gay men twice in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: This was the pope who asked, “Who am I to judge?” in response to a question about gay priests in 2013. He announced last year that he would allow priests to bless same-sex couples, defying conservative critics in the Roman Catholic Church. And he apologized only weeks ago, in a statement from the Vatican, for using an offensive Italian term for gay men at a conference of bishops.

headline: An Eclectic Summer Book Preview
abstract: Three editors gather to discuss 10 books they’re looking forward to over the next several months.
lead_paragraph: Summer is upon us and you’re going to need a few books to read. Elisabeth Egan and Joumana Khatib, editors at the Book Review, join the host Gilbert Cruz on this week’s episode to talk about a few titles they’re looking forward to over the next several months, as well as some of their preferred reading locations. (Check out our summer fiction and nonfiction previews.)

headline: The Bump Stock Ban Stemmed From a Horrific Mass Shooting
abstract: A gunman used bump stocks to help kill 60 people at a concert in Las Vegas in 2017, leading to wide political agreement that they should be prohibited.
lead_paragraph: The ban on bump stocks overturned by the Supreme Court on Friday was a rarity in an era of deep division over gun violence: a restriction that won support from Democrats, Republicans and even the National Rifle Association.

headline: The Best Advice for Dads (According to Dads)
abstract: Trust your instincts, find the fun and don’t forget that nail clipper.
lead_paragraph: Trust your instincts, find the fun and don’t forget that nail clipper.

headline: Supreme Court’s Leisurely Pace Will Produce Pileup of Late June Rulings
abstract: Even as the size of its docket has shrunk, the court has deferred a larger share of its decisions to the very end of its term.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has been moving at a sluggish pace in issuing decisions this term, entering the second half of June with more than 20 left to go. That is not terribly different from the last two terms, when the pace at which the court issued decisions started to slow.

headline: A Tense Debate Erupts at the G7, This Time Over Abortion Rights
abstract: Wording in the summit’s final statement led to a diplomatic tug of war, primarily between the United States and Italy.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the G7 had plenty to discuss — and disagree about — at their annual meeting in Italy. Two major wars, in Gaza and Ukraine. One hefty loan for Ukraine. They navigated those.

headline: U.S. Designates Largest Neo-Nazi Group in Sweden as Terrorist Organization
abstract: The Nordic Resistance Movement and three of its leaders were labeled terrorists in a rare move by the State Department targeting white supremacists.
lead_paragraph: The State Department on Friday designated the largest neo-Nazi group in Sweden and its leaders as terrorists, only the second time it has applied the label to a white supremacist group known for a long history of violence.

headline: Another Summer to Remember? For Germany: So Far, So Great.
abstract: A 5-1 thrashing of Scotland in the opening game of Euro 2024 was a good omen for a host nation in search of one.
lead_paragraph: The arc of Philipp Lahm’s career had the rhythm of someone meticulously ticking items off a bucket list. He won eight German championships with Bayern Munich, the team he supported as a child. He served as its captain for six years. He led the club to a domestic and European treble. A year later, he captained Germany to World Cup glory.

headline: Justice Dept. Says It Won’t Prosecute Garland for Contempt
abstract: The decision was expected because President Biden had invoked executive privilege to shield recordings subpoenaed by G.O.P. lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Friday that it would not prosecute Attorney General Merrick B. Garland for declining to comply with a congressional subpoena for audio recordings of President Biden’s interview by a special counsel.

headline: The Best Father’s Day Gift Is a Book
abstract: It's a keepsake for generations.
lead_paragraph: It's a keepsake for generations.

headline: U.S. Investigating ‘Dutch Roll’ That Damaged a Boeing 737 During Flight
abstract: The Southwest Airlines flight experienced a rare oscillation in May that caused “substantial” damage to its tail section and prompted investigations from federal agencies.
lead_paragraph: A rare midair sway-and-wobble that caused “substantial” damage to the tail section of a Southwest Airlines plane during a flight last month has become the focus of an investigation by the Federal Aviation Administration and the National Transportation Safety Board, the agencies said this week.

headline: The Supreme Court Rejected the Ban on Bump Stocks
abstract: Plus, advice for dads, from dads.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court today struck down a ban on bump stocks, which enable semiautomatic rifles to fire rapidly like machine guns. The ban was enacted by the Trump administration after a deadly mass shooting in Las Vegas in 2017.

headline: It’s Donald Trump’s 78th Birthday. He Isn’t Happy About It.
abstract: As he vies to become the oldest person to be elected president of the United States, former President Donald J. Trump said this birthday was one he wanted to ignore.
lead_paragraph: “Donald hates his birthdays,” Ivana Trump once said of her former husband.

headline: Pope Francis Meets Stephen Colbert and Other Comedians at the Vatican
abstract: Chris Rock, Jimmy Fallon and Whoopi Goldberg were also among the more than 100 comics who were invited to meet with the pope.
lead_paragraph: Chris Rock, Jimmy Fallon and Whoopi Goldberg were also among the more than 100 comics who were invited to meet with the pope.

headline: Charges of Race-Baiting Rattle a Key Democratic House Primary
abstract: The accusations by Representative Jamaal Bowman infused an element of unpredictability into the final days of a contest that has largely been defined by differences over the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s most bitter House primaries took an even uglier turn this week, as an embattled Black Democrat repeatedly accused his white challenger of race-baiting in the New York City suburbs.

headline: Judge Orders Sale of Alex Jones’s Personal Assets but Keeps Infowars in Business
abstract: The ruling will allow the conspiracy theorist to continue broadcasting on Infowars, while the Sandy Hook families pursue payment of $1.4 billion in defamation damages.
lead_paragraph: A Houston bankruptcy judge on Friday ordered the personal assets of the Infowars conspiracy theorist Alex Jones to be liquidated and sold, with the proceeds distributed among the Sandy Hook families. But the judge spared Mr. Jones from having to shutter his Infowars business empire.

headline: Trump’s Anti-Vaccine Problem
abstract: The anti-vax sentiment coursing through his die-hards shows how Trump takes his cues from his base.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald Trump’s chaotic and denial-filled response to the Covid-19 pandemic turned off independent voters and arguably cost him the 2020 presidential election.

headline: A Veteran’s Obituary Shares a Secret: ‘I Was Gay All My Life’
abstract: Edward Thomas Ryan, who died at 85, wrote that he was “afraid of being ostracized.” The revelation set off a wave of online tributes.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Edward Thomas Ryan’s obituary, published in The Times Union of Albany, N.Y., seemed fairly straightforward.

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Migrants in Dispute Over Deportation Hearing Notices
abstract: A majority of the justices found that the government had fulfilled its duty to tell immigrants about their court dates, even when the information was incomplete.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court sided with the federal government on Friday in a dispute over what information immigration officials must provide migrants about their deportation hearings.

headline: Bad Bunny and Reggaeton Have Sparked a Puerto Rican Spanish Renaissance
abstract: As Bad Bunny and other Puerto Rican musical artists explode in popularity, language instructors say more people want to learn how to speak the island’s slick, swaggering version of Spanish.
lead_paragraph: As Bad Bunny and other Puerto Rican musical artists explode in popularity, language instructors say more people want to learn how to speak the island’s slick, swaggering version of Spanish.

headline: Martin Starger, Influential Shaper of TV and Movies, Dies at 92
abstract: In his decade at ABC, long the doormat network in prime time, he helped guide it toward the No. 1 spot. He later produced “Nashville” and won an Emmy for “Friendly Fire.”
lead_paragraph: Martin Starger, who as a senior executive at ABC in the 1970s helped bring “Happy Days,” “Roots,” “Rich Man, Poor Man” and other shows to the small screen — and the network nearly to the brink of No. 1 in prime time — before turning to producing movies, most notably Robert Altman’s “Nashville,” died on May 31 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 92.

headline: Sam Smith, With Guest Star Alicia Keys, Throws a Pride Party
abstract: The British singer selected Julius’, a Manhattan tavern with a storied past, as the place to celebrate the 10th anniversary of “In the Lonely Hour.”
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night in the West Village of Manhattan, the soulful British balladeer Sam Smith hosted a private party at Julius’, which is known as the oldest gay bar in New York. Friends and fans sweltered inside the tavern, sipping vodka tonics as they waited for a late-night performance by Smith and a rumored special guest, Alicia Keys.

headline: War Veterans and Family Testify at Al Qaeda Commander’s War Crimes Tribunal
abstract: Victims of insurgent attacks in wartime Afghanistan described their loss to a jury at Guantánamo Bay to give a human face to a written guilty plea.
lead_paragraph: A U.S. Army veteran spoke about being left blind by a sniper’s bullet in wartime Afghanistan. A Florida father said he lost his best friend when a roadside charge killed his eldest son, a Green Beret. A former bomb squad member described two decades of trauma and anxiety from dismantling a car bomb that could have killed him.

headline: Derek Jeter (Finally) Snags a Buyer for His New York Castle
abstract: The Yankees legend initially put the compound on the market in 2018 for $14.25 million. This time, the asking price was $6.3 million.
lead_paragraph: After years of swings and misses, Yankees legend Derek Jeter has finally found a buyer for his compound in Orange County, N.Y., after it was re-listed for less than half of its original asking price.

headline: John Wilmerding, Who Helped Give American Art an Identity, Dies at 86
abstract: American paintings were largely overlooked and undervalued until he came along. A scholar, curator and collector, he oversaw important exhibitions over the last 50 years.
lead_paragraph: John Wilmerding, a towering figure in American art whose eclectic career as a scholar, museum curator and collector was instrumental in elevating the cultural significance and market value of painters such as Winslow Homer, Thomas Eakins and Fitz Henry Lane, died on June 6 in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Alabama’s I.V.F. Shield Law Now Faces a Constitutional Challenge
abstract: The challenge, from two of the families who filed the initial lawsuit, raises the possibility that access to I.V.F. could once again be in jeopardy in the state.
lead_paragraph: Two Alabama families at the center of the wrongful-death lawsuit that led to the temporary suspension of in vitro fertilization procedures in the state have asked a judge to overturn a new law that shields clinics and doctors from civil and criminal liability.

headline: Israeli Defense Chief Rebuffs French Effort to End Israel-Hezbollah Fighting
abstract: The United States, France and other mediators have sought for months to reach an agreement that would stop the tit-for-tat missile strikes over Israel’s border with Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s defense minister on Friday rejected a diplomatic effort by France aimed at ending months of cross-border strikes between Israel and Hezbollah that have been intensifying this week and raising fears of a full-blown war.

headline: House Tour | Roberto Gerosa
abstract: The architect and designer shows off his home and studio in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The architect and designer shows off his home and studio in Milan.

headline: In Milan, a Maximalist Home With a Shower Shaped Like a Bird Cage
abstract: The Italian architect and designer Roberto Gerosa has converted a disused wood shop into a live-work space where his imagination can run wild.
lead_paragraph: With a hand-rolled cigarette pinched between his fingers, the architect and designer Roberto Gerosa, 71, is rushing around his house, a cavernous former lumber workshop in Milan’s residential Villapizzone district, pointing out his favorite objects. In the corner that serves as his office, he presents a 13-foot-tall gilded column that was once part of a 19th-century theater set. Against a nearby wall is a wooden bookcase heaving with bolts of vivid fabrics: glossy heirloom brocades, pinstriped cottons and his most recent acquisition, from a tour of markets in Provence, a 19th-century paisley cashmere shawl that he plans to repurpose for a client’s upholstered headboard. In the guest bathroom is a birdcage-shaped metal shower stall of his own design painted Yves Klein blue and crowned with a bouquet of ostrich feathers.

headline: Edward Stone, 88, Physicist Who Oversaw Voyager Missions, Is Dead
abstract: He helped send the twin spacecraft on their way in 1977. Decades and billions of miles later, they are still probing — “Earth’s ambassadors to the stars,” as he put it.
lead_paragraph: Edward C. Stone, the visionary physicist who dispatched NASA’s Voyager spacecraft to run rings around our solar system’s outer planets and, for the first time, to venture beyond to unravel interstellar mysteries, died on Sunday at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Prosecutors Won’t Bring Charges in Death of Airport Executive in A.T.F. Raid
abstract: The federal agent who fatally shot the executive director of Little Rock’s airport was justified in his use of force, a local prosecutor said on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The federal agent who fatally shot the executive director of Little Rock’s airport during an early morning raid in March was justified in his use of force, an Arkansas prosecutor said on Friday, ruling out any charges.

headline: One Week That Revealed the Struggles of the Anti-Abortion Movement
abstract: The movement looks for a path forward: “Is the goal the absolute abolition of abortion in our nation?”
lead_paragraph: The Southern Baptist Convention voted to condemn in vitro fertilization at its annual meeting in Indianapolis this week, over the objections of some members.

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Episode 7 Recap: God of All Gods
abstract: In the first part of the season finale, a terrifying enemy from the Doctor’s past returns, as mysteries start to be solved.
lead_paragraph: Over six decades, “Doctor Who” has introduced many villains — including big hitters like the Cybermen (first introduced in 1966) and memorable one-off monsters like the gas-mask wearing Empty Child (2005) — as the Doctor’s most fearsome enemy.

headline: Rough Seas Set Back U.S.-Made Gaza Pier Yet Again
abstract: The U.S. military said it would temporarily move a pier designed for aid deliveries to Gaza a week after announcing it had been repaired and reattached.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. military said on Friday that it would be temporarily moving a pier that was built off the coast of Gaza by the United States to deliver aid to the war-torn enclave, where world health authorities say there is “catastrophic hunger” and malnutrition, to keep it from being damaged in expected rough seas. Only a week ago, the military said that the pier had been repaired and reattached to the Gaza shore after breaking apart in turbulence.

headline: Trump Lawyers Argue Barring Attacks on F.B.I. Would Censor ‘Political Speech’
abstract: In a filing, the lawyers in the classified documents case made an aggressive, and at times misleading, argument against prosecutors’ request for the judge to curb his attacks on agents.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump pushed back on Friday night in an aggressive — and at times misleading — way against an effort to curb his public attacks on the F.B.I. agents working on his classified documents case in Florida.

headline: Noted Tempter
abstract: Just try to resist the allure of Ryan Judge’s striking themeless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Ryan Judge’s second Times puzzle, after a Friday debut last February. A couple of things jump out.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Biden Striving for a Foothold in a Viral Duel
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This is not a Greek play where God is going to come down and, deus ex machina, save us with Taylor Swift.”

headline: Corrections: June 15, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 15, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about Saudi Arabia’s investment in professional boxing misspelled the given name of a boxer. He is Terence Crawford, not Terrence.

headline: A Hungarian Rapper’s Bandwagon Gets an Unlikely New Rider
abstract: Azahriah, who has rapped about the joy of cannabis, has shot to fame in Hungary. That may explain why he has been applauded by the country’s conservative leader, Viktor Orban.
lead_paragraph: The 22-year-old rapper is so popular — he recently held three sold-out concerts at Hungary’s largest stadium — that even Prime Minister Viktor Orban, a stodgy champion of traditional values not known for being in tune with youth or its culture, claims he is a fan.

headline: How a Sauna Master Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Regina Rocke makes snowballs for her sauna classes, snuggles with her cats, works on her towel dances and texts with her fiancée nonstop.
lead_paragraph: Regina Rocke has been teaching New Yorkers how to live more comfortably in their bodies for more than 20 years: She’s a certified personal trainer, a yoga and group fitness instructor, an ayurveda wellness counselor and a certified breathwork facilitator.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Progressive Democrats Scramble to Save One of Their Stars From Defeat
abstract: Representative Jamaal Bowman’s views on Israel made him a top target. But his primary has become a flashpoint in a broader fight within the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez of New York has declared the race her most pressing electoral priority. Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont is slated to join her for a pre-election rally in the Bronx. And a powerful pro-Israel lobby working for the other side has already shattered spending records.

headline: On Trial, Trump Glowered and Menendez Sings. Does It Affect the Outcome?
abstract: It is unclear if Senator Robert Menendez’s comportment will affect the verdict in his case, but Donald Trump’s surly attitude certainly didn’t seem to help.
lead_paragraph: One politician grumbled in the courtroom, sounded off to the reporters who gathered outside and seemingly nodded off in full view of the jury. The other has followed the courtroom action avidly, his head twisting as if watching a tennis match, and occasionally broken into song in the hallway.

headline: Could New York Ban Face Masks on the Subway? Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul said she was exploring whether to reinstitute a partial ban on face coverings in New York City over concerns about their possible role in hate crimes.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul is exploring a ban on the wearing of face masks in New York City’s subway amid concerns that such coverings could shield the identities of those committing hate crimes.

headline: For Most Refugees in Canada, a Warm Embrace. For Others, Jail.
abstract: Human rights groups are urging Canada to stop holding migrants seeking asylum in jails, often with people accused of violent crimes.
lead_paragraph: His attempt to escape deportation from Germany by hiding on a westbound freighter — under the cargo cover of a new BMW — was desperate and ill conceived. With only 1.5 liters of water and some nuts and dates, Walid Kabil did not have enough supplies, heat or space to survive the April voyage.

headline: My Renter, My Friend
abstract: Looking out for a woman in trouble, from eight states away.
lead_paragraph: When I first read the reservation request, I was suspicious.

headline: When Is a Tiny House Too Small to Be a Home?
abstract: As the Supreme Court weighs whether cities can criminalize sleeping outdoors or in tents, Los Angeles is attempting to combat homelessness with tiny homes criticized by some as ‘inhumane.’
lead_paragraph: For two years, James Valdez lived in his S.U.V., so it was a relief when he moved into Branford Village, a community of tiny homes, in Los Angeles.

headline: Bobby Finger Pays Tribute to New York’s Gay Community, Then and Now
abstract: The second novel from the co-host of the “Who? Weekly” podcast follows a West Village writer in the early 1990s and today.
lead_paragraph: You know you’re old when a decade you consider the recent past is the historical setting of a new novel. That’s the reality check I received while reading “Four Squares,” the heartfelt and entertaining second novel by Bobby Finger, the co-host of the celebrity news podcast “Who? Weekly.”

headline: Dries Van Noten Takes His Exit
abstract: In an exclusive interview, the designer reveals why he is retiring, his fears and why fashion is “an addiction.”
lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the designer Dries Van Noten sat in the sprawling old warehouse that houses his Antwerp headquarters, with its bare concrete walls, vintage oak cupboards and views over the city’s harbor. He was altering a jacket for his coming men’s wear show: a nip here, a seam moved there. Then, Mr. Van Noten said, a member of his team pointed out that it was the last piece of the men’s collection this season.

headline: Life, Death and Life After Death in June’s Graphic Novels
abstract: Justice, feminism, freedom and cheap horror thrills make for an exciting month of reading.
lead_paragraph: Though it is customarily served cold, revenge is a surprisingly versatile dish. Take, for example, Garth Ennis and Jacen Burrows’s THE RIBBON QUEEN (194 pp., AWA Studios, $19.99), a grisly crime/horror hybrid with a lot on its mind. Our heroine, Amy Sun, is a detective for the New York Police Department and a reluctant investigator into the suspicious suicide of a young woman who had recently been rescued by the chauvinist leader of a decorated tactical unit.

headline: R.O. Kwon’s Jade Rings
abstract: The rings, passed down by her mother, remind the author of the connection she has to her ancestors.
lead_paragraph: R.O. Kwon asks her ancestors for help. Two jade rings in particular, passed down by her mother, serve as a direct line and source of comfort.

headline: Ukraine-Russia Peace Is as Elusive as Ever. But in 2022 They Were Talking.
abstract: Representatives from the warring nations held peace talks in the early weeks of the Russian invasion. They fizzled. Documents from those talks show why any new ones will face major obstacles.
lead_paragraph: Representatives from the warring nations held peace talks in the early weeks of the Russian invasion. They fizzled. Documents from those talks show why any new ones will face major obstacles.

headline: The Sticking Points That Kept Russia and Ukraine Apart
abstract: Documents from 2022 shed new light on what prevented Ukraine and Russia from ending the war — and what would complicate a future negotiation.
lead_paragraph: Documents from 2022 shed new light on what prevented Ukraine and Russia from ending the war — and what would complicate a future negotiation.

headline: Not Your Average Flea Market: At La Pulga de Alamo, Stars Are Born
abstract: Every weekend, a flea market in Alamo, Texas, transforms from a Latino shopping mecca into a dance floor. The locals’ colorful moves have drawn fans around the world.

headline: Cormac McCarthy Did Not Talk Craft, With One Surprising Exception
abstract: Notoriously reluctant to give advice, the author offered his views, and meticulous edits, to a lifelong friend: Roger Payne, the marine biologist who introduced the world to whale song.
lead_paragraph: By the time the marine biologist Roger Payne won the MacArthur genius grant in 1984, his fame was well-established: Credited with helping discover the song structure of humpback whales, he had popularized their mysterious groans and creaks with a series of field-recorded LPs that fueled the marine conservation movement.

headline: Who’s Who in ‘House of the Dragon’? Here’s a Refresher
abstract: They all have blond hair and the same name. Not really, but close. Behold, a rundown of the key players ahead of the Season 2 premiere.
lead_paragraph: It has been nearly two years since the shadow of dragons’ wings last darkened our screens. When “House of the Dragon,” HBO’s hit “Game of Thrones” prequel based on the book “Fire and Blood” by George R.R. Martin, returns this weekend, its sprawling cast of characters will be prepping for war, the sides distinguished by the color of the banners they fly.

headline: The 15th Doctor Will See You Now
abstract: In his first season leading “Doctor Who,” Ncuti Gatwa has brought charisma, emotion and even more camp to the long-running sci-fi show.
lead_paragraph: “Give-ING! That dress is giving!” said Ncuti Gatwa with a burst of unbridled laughter. The newest Doctor Who had been shooting the same scene for several hours in Cardiff, Wales, where hangar-like spaces were teeming with crew and filled with sets and equipment for the show. (Yes, Whovians, the TARDIS was parked nearby.) Now, at the director’s request, the new Doctor was improvising.

headline: The Wife Who Survived Henry VIII Finally Gets Her Big-Screen Due
abstract: “Firebrand” focuses on his sixth spouse as she tries to outlast the ailing king and his treacherous court. “I thought of it as a thriller,” the director says.
lead_paragraph: Midway through Karim Aïnouz’s “Firebrand,” King Henry VIII of England takes a break from playing bowls on the lawn to walk with his sixth wife, Katherine Parr. Gripping her arm tightly, limping heavily, the king, played with terrifying menace by Jude Law, offers a threat to those who betray him. “They know what would happen,” he says quietly, turning to face the queen. “We’d have to have their head cut off.” Alicia Vikander’s Queen Katherine smiles faintly. “I’m sure you would come up with something much more creative,” she says.

headline: How to Watch the Tony Awards
abstract: The main event will be broadcast on CBS and livestreamed for Paramount+ with Showtime subscribers. A simulcast will also air at Damrosch Park in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: OK, Broadway fans: It’s showtime.

headline: Ariana DeBose, Tonys Host, Just Might Be the Busiest Woman on Broadway
abstract: Back in New York City after filming a movie, the actress has been racing to shows while also rehearsing for Sunday night’s ceremony.
lead_paragraph: “Baby,” Ariana DeBose confided, “you are always on.”

headline: As War Drags On, Gazans More Willing to Speak Out Against Hamas
abstract: Ordinary Gazans are bearing the brunt of the 8-month Israeli military onslaught on the territory and many blame the Palestinian armed faction for starting the war.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, as the Hamas-led attack on Israel was unfolding, many Palestinians took to the streets of Gaza to celebrate what they likened to a prison break and saw as the sudden humiliation of an occupier.

headline: Medical Experts Alarmed by Out-of-Hospital Cesareans in Florida
abstract: A new state law will permit surgeons to perform cesarean deliveries in “advanced birth centers,” despite the risk of complications.
lead_paragraph: A new law in Florida allowing doctors to perform cesarean sections in outpatient birthing centers has raised serious safety concerns among medical experts, who say the procedures carry a small but real risk of life-threatening complications and should not be undertaken outside hospitals.

headline: If Everyone Voted, Would Biden Benefit? Not Anymore.
abstract: Inside the unusual dynamic shaping the 2024 campaign.

headline: How Can You Get a Closer Look at Your Co-op’s Expenses?
abstract: Shareholders have a right to know about the building’s expenses, and there are ways to look inside the books.
lead_paragraph: Q: I am a shareholder in a Brooklyn co-op. One year ago, the board suddenly fired our super, who had worked here for more than 21 years. He immediately began legal action against the co-op, and the matter was settled out of court with a payment to the super. We respectfully asked for more information during a shareholder meeting but were told that the matter was strictly confidential. All the board has said is that the final cost to the co-op was approximately $15,000. This seems low, considering a year of legal fees, mediation and the settlement itself. Our co-op documents imply that the board must account for its use of funds, but there is no specific language. Is the board required to explain how much this cost?

headline: Is That Drink Worth It to You?
abstract: Alcohol is riskier than previously thought, but weighing the trade-offs of health risks can be deeply personal.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, a friend of mine started evading my invitations to grab a drink. It was only when we caught up for a walk that she explained she wasn’t putting me off for any personal reason — it was just that she had stopped drinking. She wasn’t a heavy drinker — she had a glass of wine with dinner, the occasional Aperol spritz — but she’d been hearing on podcasts and reading in the news that even a small amount of alcohol was much worse for her health than had previously been understood.

headline: James Phoon, a New Face on ‘Bridgerton,’ Is Team Ariana Grande
abstract: “She seems to approach the world with kindness and understanding,” said the actor, who has joined the Netflix series for its latest season.
lead_paragraph: James Phoon couldn’t quite imagine himself cavorting among the 19th-century bon tons of “Bridgerton.” Then he read that the first Chinese person gained British citizenship in 1805.

headline: 7 Moments That Reigned in ‘House of the Dragon’
abstract: Need a reminder of all the events that went down in Season 1 between the Greens and the Blacks? We’ve got you.
lead_paragraph: The civil war known as the Dance of the Dragons is almost here after an explosive Season 1 of “House of the Dragon.” Now, nearly two years later, HBO’s other popular show about succession returns this weekend  as the (mostly) white-blond Targaryens from across the family tree harness alliances, resources and dragons toward an ever-escalating cycle of vengeance and cruelty.

headline: Goodbye, Work Friends
abstract: After four years, as she prepares to hand off to her successor, our workplace advice columnist reflects on the rewards and the frustrations of office life.
lead_paragraph: We spend a lot of our lives working, especially in the United States — 40, 50, 60 or more hours a week. We hold multiple jobs to make ends meet. The candle is perpetually burning at both ends. Hard work, we’re told, is a virtue. It allows us to contribute to society and support our families, serve our employers well. It makes sense, then, that for Work Friend — the column I have written for the past four years — the questions you asked reflected both practical and existential concerns.

headline: A Look at One Way California Is Tackling Homelessness
abstract: As the Supreme Court weighs whether cities can criminalize sleeping outdoors or in tents, Los Angeles is attempting to combat homelessness with tiny homes that some people criticize as inadequate and even ‘inhumane.’
lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court weighs whether cities can criminalize sleeping outdoors or in tents, Los Angeles is attempting to combat homelessness with tiny homes that some people criticize as inadequate and even ‘inhumane.’

headline: These Common Medications Can Make Heat Waves More Dangerous
abstract: Certain antidepressants, blood pressure pills and other drugs make you more susceptible to heat-related illness. Here’s what to know.
lead_paragraph: A major heat wave is expected to hit much of the eastern United States this week. And millions of people across the country are taking medications that may make them more susceptible to heat-related illnesses.

headline: A Memoir of Hot Sex, Hot Chocolate and Freedom — Not in That Order
abstract: In “I’m Mostly Here to Enjoy Myself,” Glynnis MacNicol ignores the pearl-clutchers and does just that.
lead_paragraph: In March of 2021, after a full year at home with my husband and children, I began buying dresses. I don’t mean shapeless caftans or comfy “nap dresses.” I mean dresses with a capital “D”: tulle ball gowns and fitted sequined sheaths and flowing chiffon confections. Beautiful and useless, they represented a portal to another world, another life, in which I traversed New York, meeting friends at glittering parties.

headline: The Momentous Decision New York Almost Made
abstract: Chicago reversed the flow of a river. Boston put a highway underground. And New York, well, came close to enacting congestion pricing.
lead_paragraph: American cities are shaped by the accumulation of many small choices across time: to put a park here, to lay a sewer there, to rezone this commercial strip or redesign that roadway.

headline: It’s Not Just Russia: China Joins the G7’s List of Adversaries
abstract: While not invited to the Group of 7 meeting, China was still a major presence, with the summit’s final communiqué referencing the country 28 times, almost always as a malign force.
lead_paragraph: President Biden was eager to get off the stage at the Group of 7 summit Thursday night, clearly a bit testy after answering questions about Hunter Biden’s conviction and the prospects of a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: Trump, Biden and CNN Prepare for a Hostile Debate (With Muted Mics)
abstract: With Donald Trump’s rampage at the first 2020 debate still fresh in the memories of both campaigns and the moderators, the candidates are preparing in sharply different ways.
lead_paragraph: There will be no opening statements. President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump will each have two minutes to answer questions — followed by one-minute rebuttals and responses to the rebuttals. Red lights visible to the candidates will flash when they have five seconds left, and turn solid red when time has expired. And each man’s microphone will be muted when it is not his turn to speak.

headline: Serena Williams’s Next Challenge? The Rest of Her Life.
abstract: The greatest women’s tennis player of all time is trying to find her new normal in retirement.
lead_paragraph: A lot of people reach middle age having achieved some career success and ask themselves: Well, now what? Apparently this happens even if you’re Serena Williams.

headline: New York City Removes Two Parents From School Councils Over Behavior
abstract: One parent led a push to review rules around transgender athletes. The other had encouraged pro-Palestinian student activism. The chancellor said their conduct at parent meetings crossed a line.
lead_paragraph: Two elected parent leaders in New York City were removed from their school council positions on Friday, a rare step by school officials that reflected the escalating fights over broader political and cultural issues in local schools.

headline: Princess of Wales Appears in Public for First Time Since Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: Catherine took part in a ceremonial parade to celebrate the birthday of her father-in-law, King Charles III.
lead_paragraph: Catherine, Princess of Wales, appeared in public on Saturday for the first time since her cancer diagnosis, smiling while riding in a carriage with her three children as she took part in a ceremonial parade to celebrate the birthday of her father-in-law, King Charles III.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,093, June 16, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 371, June 16, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Shattered by Montreal Mind-Control Experiments, but Undeterred in a Suit
abstract: Families of patients in a Cold War-era mind-control experiment in Montreal are pressing forward after a recent setback in their class-action lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: Every weekend was an adventure for Julie Tanny when she was a young girl.

headline: Ukraine Peace Talks Held in Switzerland, Though Russia Isn’t Invited
abstract: Kyiv hopes to garner nations’ support for three points in its peace proposal, but it’s a hard sell, with China and Brazil declining to send high-level delegations.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine played the starring role at a peace conference in Switzerland on Saturday aimed at shoring up support for Ukraine’s negotiating positions in its war with Russia with the backing of as many nations as possible.

headline: My Father’s Day Gift From the F.B.I.
abstract: A secret file kept on my dad is now a reminder of a man who, even under pressure, stayed true to his beliefs.
lead_paragraph: On an otherwise pleasant day in May 1957, my father received two unwelcome visitors at his tool-and-die factory. They were F.B.I. agents acting on years of informants’ tips that Dad had been a Communist Party member. The agents intended to use that information as leverage to turn my father, too, into a snitch.

headline: Growing Old, With Grace and Aches
abstract: Older readers offer a range of perspectives in response to a column by Charles M. Blow.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘We Have to Live Now’: Stories of a Home Out of Reach
abstract: “When you live in the past, the people around you hate you, don’t understand and don’t accept you,” Valentyna Odnoviu wrote.
lead_paragraph: For almost two years Tania Drobot, a 53-year-old math teacher from Kyiv, Ukraine, has lived in the home of Fiona and David Ion, in Moorhaven in Devon, on the southwest coast of England.

headline: Jan. 6, America’s Rupture and the Strange, Forgotten Power of Oblivion
abstract: After a profound national rupture, forgiveness may be impossible. But the long-overlooked act of oblivion could offer a solution.
lead_paragraph: On March 4, Judge Tanya Chutkan presided over jury selection for a criminal trial in a Jan. 6, 2021, case. That date had long been scheduled, though there was a different defendant seated before her from one who had been planned: In the place of Donald Trump sat a 57-year-old Pennsylvania man named Lynnwood Nester.

headline: Birding My Way Through Chemo
abstract: The future is uncertain. But it feels less scary surrounded by feathered friends.

headline: Learning to Love My Father as His Mind Unraveled
