abstract: The experience of living with my father’s dementia ranged from tragic to tragicomic to vaudevillian, often within the span of a few minutes.
lead_paragraph: When I was around 10 years old, my father started hiding bananas in our house.

headline: What Have We Liberals Done to the West Coast?
abstract: Infected with ideological purity, the West Coast is focused more on intentions than on oversight and outcomes.
lead_paragraph: As Democrats make their case to voters around the country this fall, one challenge is that some of the bluest parts of the country — cities on the West Coast — are a mess.

headline: The Supreme Court Ruling in the Starbucks Case Proves the Law Won’t Save Labor
abstract: To win a union campaign, workers need a strong organizing committee and a hammer to enforce the right to organize. The law is not that hammer.
lead_paragraph: In Starbucks Corp. v. McKinney, the Supreme Court ordered lower courts to apply a stricter test when deciding whether to grant the National Labor Relations Board’s petitions for emergency relief, like ordering the reinstatement of seven fired Starbucks workers in Memphis.

headline: Biden Team Set to Raise Record $28 Million at Hollywood Fund-Raiser
abstract: President Biden flew from a gathering of world leaders in Italy to Los Angeles to appear along with Barack Obama, George Clooney, Julia Roberts, Jimmy Kimmel and others.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s campaign expects to collect more than $28 million at a Los Angeles fund-raiser packed with celebrities on Saturday night in a Hollywood show of force.

headline: Your Summer Reading Guide
abstract: If you fantasize about reading your way from now until Labor Day but need help corralling your curiosity, we can help.
lead_paragraph: I wrote last week about how finding something interesting to watch has been a challenge in recent months. In these moments, I turn to books. If we can agree that streaming options have been lackluster lately, we can also agree that there’s really no excuse for griping when neither you nor I have even scratched the surface of all the books we’ve been meaning to read. But why, then, am I not living my truth, the truth of being lost rapturously in multiple books at once? I have some ideas.

headline: Yousef and the Fourth Move
abstract: A Palestinian man is forced into a move he is not sure he can make.
lead_paragraph: On This Week’s Episode:

headline: Sweden and Iran Exchange Prisoners in a Breakthrough Swap
abstract: Iran released an E.U. diplomat from Sweden and a dual Iranian-Swedish national, while Sweden released a former Iranian judiciary official serving a life sentence for war crimes.
lead_paragraph: Iran and Sweden exchanged prisoners on Saturday, breaking a logjam that brought relief to families but also raised concern about Sweden’s decision to release the first-ever Iranian official to be convicted of crimes against humanity.

headline: The Business of Being Lorne Michaels
abstract: For 50 years, Michaels has managed both the weekly circus of producing “Saturday Night Live” and the broader task of keeping it relevant. How does he do it?
lead_paragraph: It’s 1:01 a.m. on a Sunday morning in May, and Lorne Michaels, the creator and producer of “Saturday Night Live,” has just finished the final episode of the 49th season. He spent those 90 minutes pacing backstage, hands in pockets, surveying the actors, allowing himself only an occasional chuckle of satisfaction.

headline: Western Anxiety Makes for an Unexpectedly Smooth G7 Summit
abstract: Political weakness, intractable wars in Ukraine and in the Middle East, and challenges from Russia and China combined to create solidarity behind American leadership.
lead_paragraph: The Group of 7 summit that ended on Saturday went extraordinarily smoothly by the standards of a gathering where the leaders of major powers come together. That was a measure of the anxiety the leaders feel about deteriorating trends in Ukraine, in the Middle East, in China and in their own political futures.

headline: Princess of Wales Makes First Public Appearance Since Cancer Diagnosis
abstract: Catherine, the Princess of Wales, took part in a parade on Saturday marking the birthday of King Charles III of Britain.
lead_paragraph: Catherine, the Princess of Wales, took part in a parade on Saturday marking the birthday of King Charles III of Britain.

headline: Did You Buy a Disneyland ‘Dream Key’? Disney May Owe You Money.
abstract: Disney owes a total of $9.5 million to customers who bought a $1,400 Dream Key pass over the course of two months in 2021. The payments, about $67, are going out this month.
lead_paragraph: People who paid nearly $1,400 for an annual pass to Disneyland will begin receiving checks in the mail this month from a $9.5 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit that accused Disney of misleading customers into believing that the program carried “no blockout dates.”

headline: Have We Reached Peak Baby Name?
abstract: Tank? Afternoon? Flick? Orca?
lead_paragraph: After the birth this spring of her third child, a baby girl named Whimsy Lou, the lifestyle influencer Nara Smith posted a TikTok listing some of the names she and her husband liked but did not ultimately use. Among them were Tank, Clementine, Flick, Halo and Dew.

headline: Voyager 1, After Major Malfunction, Is Back From the Brink, NASA Says
abstract: The farthest man-made object in space had been feared lost forever after a computer problem in November effectively rendered the 46-year-old probe useless.
lead_paragraph: Several months after a grave computer problem seemed to spell the end for Voyager 1, which for nearly a half century had provided data on the outer planets and the far reaches of the solar system, NASA announced on Thursday that it had restored the spacecraft to working order.

headline: Biden’s Health Secretary Goes West With a Focus on Reproductive Rights
abstract: Xavier Becerra, the health and human services secretary, will travel to states with large Latino populations, including some with key races on the ballot in November.
lead_paragraph: Xavier Becerra, the secretary of health and human services, said on Friday that he would begin a national tour next week to promote the Biden administration’s efforts to preserve and expand access to abortion.

headline: J.D. Vance’s Strange Turn to 1876
abstract: A look at the senator’s defense of Donald Trump’s conduct after the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: The most favorable gloss you could give to Donald Trump’s effort to “Stop the Steal” is that it was an attempt to deal with real discrepancies in the 2020 presidential race as well as to satisfy those voters angry about the conduct of the election.

headline: ‘This Is So Enjoyable to Make’
abstract: Melissa Clark’s versatile fruit galette is an “easy and beautiful” five-star reader favorite.
lead_paragraph: The above note about Melissa Clark’s fruit galette from Walter, a reader, stuck with me. Making this adaptable recipe truly is a joy. You have the chilled, floured dough on your hands; a sculptor’s satisfaction of rolling the dough lump into a smooth sheet. Preparing the colorful fruit maybe leaves a soft fuchsia blush on your fingertips, an endearing souvenir from assertive plums or melting raspberries. Then out comes the pastry brush — always a small rush of pride to use those specific, dedicated cooking tools — to coat your dough folds in eggy cream, knowing they’ll bake into a burnished wabi-sabi crust. Eating the galette is great, too — it is Melissa, after all — but making it is a wonderful bit of summer arts and crafts, a dose of hands-on happiness.

headline: Catherine Reappears, in White
abstract: The Princess of Wales made her first public appearance since coming forward with her cancer diagnosis.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning Catherine, Princess of Wales, tiptoed back onto the public stage for the first time since announcing her cancer diagnosis this year in her signature color-coordinated way, joining the rest of the royal family on the balcony of Buckingham Palace for the traditional finale flyover of King Charles’ birthday parade. She wore a white knee-length Jenny Packham dress with a black-and-white striped belt and a jaunty bow at the neck, topped off with a Philip Treacy hat, angled just so.

headline: Geeking Out Over a Word’s History
abstract: A circus performer, an unsociable student or someone who is ahead of the curve? Over the decades, a “geek” has been all three.
lead_paragraph: A headline on a 2021 New York Times article made a bold claim: President Biden was a geek. A “Watch Geek in Chief,” to be exact. The president’s affinity for luxury timepieces — he wore a Rolex at his inauguration — had caught the eye of the Styles desk.

headline: Nick Mavar, Fisherman and ‘Deadliest Catch’ Star, Dies at 59
abstract: Mr. Mavar, who ran a fishing operation in Alaska, starred in the reality television show for 16 years and captained his own boat.
lead_paragraph: Nick Mavar, a commercial salmon fisherman known for his tenacity and resourcefulness who was also a deckhand on the Discovery Channel’s extreme fishing reality show “Deadliest Catch,” died on Thursday at a hospital in King Salmon, Alaska. He was 59.

headline: Unruly Passenger Who Was Restrained With Duct Tape Faces Record Fine
abstract: Federal regulators are seeking $81,950 from a Texas woman who acted erratically and was violent toward crew members during an American Airlines flight in 2021.
lead_paragraph: An American Airlines passenger who kicked and spat at flight attendants and passengers and attempted to open the cabin door before she was secured to a seat with duct tape has been sued by the Federal Aviation Administration for $81,950, the largest-ever fine assessed by the agency for unruly behavior.

headline: G.O.P.-Led States, Claiming ‘Invasion,’ Push to Expand Power to Curb Immigration
abstract: Republicans’ latest efforts capitalize on the issue’s prominence in the 2024 election. But the fate of their proposals is still being litigated.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year since Texas adopted a law empowering state and local police officers to arrest undocumented migrants who cross into its territory, Republican lawmakers in at least 11 states have tried to adopt similar measures, capitalizing on the prominence of immigration in the 2024 presidential election.

headline: ‘We Need to Unite’: Protests Against the Far Right Are Held Across France
abstract: A newly formed left-wing coalition called on demonstrators to stop Marine Le Pen’s National Rally party from taking power in upcoming elections.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of demonstrators crowded onto French streets on Saturday to denounce the rise of the country’s far-right political party and call on fellow citizens to block it from taking power in snap parliamentary elections set by President Emmanuel Macron.

headline: Overlooked No More: Lorenza Böttner, Transgender Artist Who Found Beauty in Disability
abstract: Böttner, whose specialty was self-portraiture, celebrated her armless body in paintings she created with her mouth and feet while dancing in public.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Ben Vautier, Artist Whose Specialty Was Provocation, Dies at 88
abstract: A core member of the anti-art movement Fluxus, he died by suicide hours after the death of his wife of 60 years.
lead_paragraph: Ben Vautier, a French artist and agitator who often worked under the moniker Ben, and who as a core member of the anti-art collective Fluxus blurred the boundaries of high and low, art and life, while adhering to the credo “Everything is art,” died on June 5 at his home in Nice, France. He was 88.

headline: Lynn Conway, Computing Pioneer and Transgender Advocate, Dies at 86
abstract: She made significant contributions at IBM, but she lost her job because of her conviction that she inhabited the wrong body. She later fought for transgender rights.
lead_paragraph: Lynn Conway, a pioneering computer scientist who was fired by IBM in the 1960s after telling managers that she was transgender, despite her significant technological innovations — and who received a rare formal apology from the company 52 years later — died on June 9 in Jackson, Mich. She was 86.

headline: Connections
abstract: Chandi Deitmer and Wyna Liu combine forces, and games, and produce a charming mash-up.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Washington Post Publisher and Incoming Editor Are Said to Have Used Stolen Records in Britain
abstract: Years before becoming The Post’s publisher, Will Lewis assigned an article based on stolen phone records, a former reporter said.
lead_paragraph: The publisher and the incoming editor of The Washington Post, when they worked as journalists in London two decades ago, used fraudulently obtained phone and company records in newspaper articles, according to a former colleague, a published account of a private investigator and an analysis of newspaper archives.

headline: How a ‘Committed Partisan Warrior’ Came to Rethink the Political Wars
abstract: Bob Bauer, the personal attorney for President Biden and former White House counsel for President Barack Obama, is now wrestling with the win-at-all-costs nature of American politics.
lead_paragraph: Once, after he executed a particularly tough-minded legal attack on Republicans, Bob Bauer remembers, a conservative magazine called him an “evil genius.” He took it as a compliment. “I was very proud of that,” he said. “I thought, That’s cool.”

headline: 9 Shot at Splash Park in Michigan, Police Say
abstract: The authorities said the shooting in Rochester Hills, Mich., appeared to be random, and that the presumed attacker was later found dead in a nearby home.
lead_paragraph: A gunman opened fire at a Michigan splash park on Saturday in what the authorities said was a random attack that left nine people injured, including two children, one of whom was in critical condition.

headline: Trump, in Pitch to Black Voters in Detroit, Casts Biden as Anti-Black
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump met with voters at a Black church in the critical battleground state, seeking to make a contrast with President Biden on the economy.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, courting Black voters at a church on the west side of Detroit on Saturday, sought to harness animus toward migrants crossing the border, sanitized his track record on race and sold himself as the best president for Black Americans since Abraham Lincoln.

headline: The Greens Are Dead. Long Live the Greens!
abstract: Europe’s climate change-minded parties performed poorly in the European Union elections. Is the once ambitious European green movement over, or could its electoral crash launch a rebirth?
lead_paragraph: There is no sugarcoating it: losing one-third of their seats in the European Parliament elections last week, the Greens tanked.

headline: The Tasty New Challenge to Venezuela’s Autocrats: ‘Freedom Empanadas’
abstract: After the Hernández sisters served breakfast to an opposition leader, the government shut down their restaurant. Then came an outpouring of support.
lead_paragraph: A car pulled up recently outside a modest restaurant in the state of Guárico in Venezuela’s sprawling savanna. The driver shouted from behind the wheel: “Are you the ones whose business was closed by the government? I want a picture with you!”

headline: Corrections: June 16, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, June 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about Gary Friedman, chief executive of RH (formerly Restoration Hardware), misquoted Mr. Friedman. He said that he pushed the brand to “climb the luxury mountain,” not “climb the luxury ladder.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: The Best Advice for Dads (According to These Dads)
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, June 16, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Don’t pass up on an opportunity to tell your kids that you are proud of them.”

headline: At Biden Fund-Raiser, Hollywood and Democrats Let the Trump Attacks Fly
abstract: The Biden campaign said it raised at least $28 million on Saturday, at a fund-raiser in Los Angeles, where entertainers, Barack Obama and even Jill Biden assailed Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: A Hollywood fund-raiser Saturday night intended to bolster President Biden’s war chest turned into a platform for some of the most concerted and toughest attacks to date on former President Donald J. Trump by the Biden campaign, as entertainers, Barack Obama and even Jill Biden assailed Mr. Trump’s ethics and his suitability to return to the White House.

headline: A Senseless Fire and the Stranger Who Put It Out
abstract: An unsettling crime brought out the hero in a passing New Yorker.
lead_paragraph: The firefighters were gone, the police were on their way, and all around was the aftermath of whatever had happened a couple hours ago. Sabrina Rudin and her father peered at a video on her phone’s screen for some clue.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In California, Tribal Members Are Reclaiming the ‘Land of the Flowing Water’
abstract: Several tribes in Owens Valley in the eastern Sierra Nevada see hope in small property transfers that have become part of a growing “Land Back” movement.
lead_paragraph: The vast territory known as the Owens Valley was home for centuries to Native Americans who lived along its rivers and creeks fed by snowmelt that cascaded down the eastern slopes of the Sierra Nevada.

headline: Congestion Pricing Delay in New York Ripples Across the Country
abstract: Even as transit systems nationwide struggle, New York City’s transportation network appeared to finally score a major win with the now-paused tolling program.
lead_paragraph: In a country where the car is still king, New York had stirred hope that an ambitious policy prioritizing mass transit was possible.

headline: The Resistance to a New Trump Administration Has Already Started
abstract: An emerging coalition that views Donald J. Trump’s agenda as a threat to democracy is laying the groundwork to push back if he wins in November, taking extraordinary pre-emptive actions.
lead_paragraph: Opponents of Donald J. Trump are drafting potential lawsuits in case he is elected in November and carries out mass deportations, as he has vowed. One group has hired a new auditor to withstand any attempt by a second Trump administration to unleash the Internal Revenue Service against them. Democratic-run state governments are even stockpiling abortion medication.

headline: ‘We Walked to the A Train at 14th Street, Where We Said Goodbye’
abstract: A trip to the Whitney Museum on a windy day, a stuck elevator and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: No Field, No Problem. An Academic Powerhouse Can Also Play Ball.
abstract: The elite Baccalaureate high school, housed in a former pocketbook factory in Queens, is known for its college-level courses. And now its undefeated softball team.
lead_paragraph: Housed in a former pocketbook factory in Astoria, Queens, the tiny Baccalaureate School for Global Education is an elite public high school with a rigorous academic curriculum. Founded in 2002, it has only about 400 students, no gym, no playing fields and no auditorium.

headline: On Eid al-Adha, Gazans Mark Another Somber Holiday Amid War
abstract: The Muslim holiday typically involves slaughtering an animal for food for loved ones and the needy, but many in Gaza are going hungry as Israel’s offensive continues.
lead_paragraph: After eight devastating months of war, Muslims in Gaza on Sunday will mark a somber Eid al-Adha, a major religious holiday usually celebrated by sharing meat among friends, family and the needy.

headline: For Campus Protesters in Brussels, Familiar Methods, but Different Outcomes
abstract: Pro-Palestinian student activists at one Belgian university have borrowed from the U.S. playbook of encampments and slogans. The results, however, have been starkly different.
lead_paragraph: On the leafy campus of a Dutch-speaking university, students have for months been demanding that their institution break ties with Israeli academia over the war in Gaza.

headline: Pregnant, Addicted and Fighting the Pull of Drugs
abstract: Many pregnant women who struggle with drugs put off prenatal care, feeling ashamed and judged. But as fatal overdoses rise, some clinics see pregnancy as an ideal time to help them confront addiction.
lead_paragraph: Kim Short waited in the doctor’s exam room on an icy day in February, exhausted from the first trimester of pregnancy and trembling in withdrawal from methamphetamine, alcohol, Xanax and Klonopin.

headline: What We Think About When We Think About Joni Mitchell
abstract: In her new book, “Traveling,” the music critic Ann Powers offers a highly personal, even confessional, meditation on Mitchell’s life, work and influence.
lead_paragraph: How many singers have I listened to, on repeat, for years before playing music “on repeat” required a single mouse click? Bob Dylan. Sly Stone. Nina Simone. Aretha Franklin. Joni Mitchell. I play James Brown’s music less than I did, but I love Prince’s more than ever, especially his cover of Mitchell’s “A Case of You.” There were times when the melancholy in Mitchell’s songs (even the “happy” ones) too closely echoed my own. But I’m over that now. My favorite of her albums, “Blue,” and Los Lobos doing “Nothing Can Be Done” and Lana Del Rey’s version of “For Free” still surprise and move me, no matter how often I hear them.

headline: It Was Supposed to Be a Fun Night Out. It Led to a Criminal Underworld.
abstract: In Akwaeke Emezi’s latest novel, “Little Rot,” two exes trying to recover after a breakup inadvertently stumble into a dark, disturbing and dangerous side of Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: There’s an art to depicting things going seriously wrong very quickly, and Akwaeke Emezi’s latest novel, “Little Rot,” is a masterwork of the form.

headline: Is the Partisan Divide Too Big to Be Bridged?
abstract: From the urban and rural divide to the partisan gulf, from religious groups to warring factions on campuses, organizations and funders are cropping up with hope for common ground.
lead_paragraph: Bernard Clay, a Black, middle-aged data analyst and poet from Louisville, Ky., was leery when he was thrown together with Shaelyn Bishop, a shy, white, young biologist who grew up on a family farm in rural Green County, Ky., 15 minutes from the closest town.

headline: File Thom Gunn’s Life Under the Tortured Poets Department
abstract: A comprehensive new biography, by Michael Nott, lays bare the tragic circumstances behind a brilliant iconoclast’s life and work.
lead_paragraph: One version of the life of Thom Gunn might go like this: After a childhood spent in an erratic orbit of Fleet Street journalism, Gunn developed into a remarkably assured young writer and had immediate success as a poet, first in Britain, then in the United States. Openly gay despite the dangers of that identification in the second half of the 20th century, he led a scruffy, cheerfully louche existence (loads of sex with dubious characters, piles of drugs, often with the same dubious characters) while writing poems of elegant astringency. Gunn taught at several universities with conscientiousness, he plunged into leather dive bars as if they were all about to close forever, and he earned a devoted battalion of advocates who viewed him as a world-class writer who, rare among world-class writers, didn’t court the favor of people who use descriptions like “world-class writer.” He died as a prize-bedecked iconoclast, a near contradiction that suited him down to his panther tattoo.

headline: China’s Lust for Durian Is Creating Fortunes in Southeast Asia
abstract: Demand for the fruit, known for its rich taste and intense smell, has reshaped parts of Southeast Asia, where it has long been a staple.
lead_paragraph: Before he started a company 15 years ago selling the world’s smelliest fruit, Eric Chan had a well-paying job writing code for satellites and robots. His family and friends were puzzled when he made the career change.

headline: Coming to a City Near You: A Cricket Stadium?
abstract: Backers of the sport are negotiating leases and approvals for venues across the United States.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, after officials in Grand Prairie, Texas, were pitched an idea to turn the city’s underused minor league ballpark into a stadium for cricket, the city’s manager, Bill Hills, thumbed through a copy of “Cricket for Dummies.”

headline: Why Are Tweens Buying a ‘Visibly Firming’ ‘Bum Bum’ Cream?
abstract: A scented lotion by the brand Sol de Janeiro is a hit among adolescents. Cue bafflement and concern from some adults.
lead_paragraph: One of the most coveted beauty products among teenagers is a creamy, fragrant lotion that comes in a tangerine-colored plastic tub.

headline: 5 Ways This Year’s Tony Awards Reveal That Theater Is Changing
abstract: As Broadway prepares to celebrate the best of the season, our theater reporter explores what the nominations tell us about the industry and the art form.
lead_paragraph: Tonight’s Tony Awards ceremony will celebrate the best work on Broadway. For those of us who spend a lot of time in and around theater, the event is also a prompt, encouraging us to reflect on what the current crop of shows tells us about how the industry and the art form are doing.

headline: House G.O.P.’s Spending Chief Faces a Primary from the Right
abstract: Representative Tom Cole of Oklahoma is fighting off a right-wing challenger who has tried to make the lawmaker’s influential perch a liability.
lead_paragraph: When Representative Tom Cole became chairman of the Appropriations Committee in April, it marked the first time an Oklahoman had ascended to one of Congress’s most powerful perches.

headline: In a Digital Age, High-End Outdoors Magazines Are Thriving in Print
abstract: Titles like Adventure Journal, Mountain Gazette, Summit Journal and Ori are aimed at “people who just don’t want to be on their phones anymore.”
lead_paragraph: In an ordinary industrial building off a busy Orange County street, a Seussian contraption, nearly 100 feet long, clattered to life. The room filled with the hum and squeaks of belts and machinery. There was the smell of hot glue.

headline: An American’s Desperate Effort to Save Her Family in Gaza
abstract: Following an Israeli airstrike on a camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah, Gaza, Rolla Alaydi, a Palestinian American, could not reach her family members in Rafah for days, leaving her unsure if they had survived the attack.
lead_paragraph: Following an Israeli airstrike on a camp for displaced Palestinians in Rafah, Gaza, Rolla Alaydi, a Palestinian American, could not reach her family members in Rafah for days, leaving her unsure if they had survived the attack.

headline: ‘Inside Out 2’ Returns Pixar to Box Office Heights
abstract: The sequel was expected to collect at least $155 million in the United States and Canada over the weekend, about 70 percent more than anticipated.
lead_paragraph: Pixar is finally back in fighting form.

headline: Assessing Trump’s and Biden’s Claims About Immigration and Border Security
abstract: We fact-checked claims about migrants and border security from both presidential candidates.
lead_paragraph: Large numbers of migrant apprehensions at the southern border have vaulted immigration and border security onto the list of top concerns for voters.

headline: Reimagining Bloomsday for Molly, and All Women
abstract: To help honor 100 years of James Joyce’s “Ulysses,” an all-women Irish festival refocuses the annual re-enactment of the novel’s wanderings around the character of Molly Bloom.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Derry gave a speech. The first and deputy ministers of Northern Ireland took to the stage. All were women, and all were in the city on Thursday to celebrate the opening of Yes festival, an ode to female artists and creativity that also rounds off a two-year celebration of the 100th anniversary of the publication of “Ulysses,” James Joyce’s sprawling, encyclopedic novel.

headline: June Is the Month When Olympic Dreams Die
abstract: There will be no shortage of drama when the Paris Olympics begin in July, but most hearts will be broken in the cutthroat qualifying trials this month.
lead_paragraph: Before the Olympics even begin, there is always heartbreak. And June may be the hardest month of all.

headline: 5 Numbers to Know About the Coming Heat Wave
abstract: Stifling conditions are forecast to spread this week over the eastern half of America — and linger for days.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans from Texas to Maine will face sweltering conditions this week as a heat wave takes hold in the eastern half of the United States, according to forecasters. Beginning Sunday, rising temperatures will hit the South, then stretch over the Midwest before spreading to the East Coast by midweek.

headline: Inside the Chechen Units Helping to Fight Russia’s War
abstract: After hundreds of years of enmity with Russia, Chechens are deploying to Ukraine to fight Moscow’s war.
lead_paragraph: A hulking military transport plane roared onto the tarmac at the main airfield in Grozny, the capital of the Chechen Republic in southeastern Russia, and a group of 120 volunteer fighters heading for Ukraine clambered aboard.

headline: A Brief History of Iran’s Hostage Swapping
abstract: Since the 1979 revolution, Iran has made detaining foreigners and dual citizens a centerpiece of its foreign policy, trading them for money and people.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Iran and Sweden exchanged prisoners. The swap had the appearance of any two countries engaged in diplomatic negotiations to free their citizens. Families were elated; governments were relieved.

headline: Dad Brain Is Real, and It’s a Good Thing
abstract: New science reveals parenting is transformative for men.
lead_paragraph: A father of three recently told me that if he could go back in time and give himself one piece of advice, it would be to have kids sooner. Fatherhood changed him; it gave his life purpose, he said. It turns out neuroscience agrees with him.

headline: Biden’s Love for His Son Is Beautiful — and It Hits Home for Me
abstract: Many parents see themselves in the president’s affection for his son.
lead_paragraph: When my son Nic was born, I was like other parents who hope that their children will be healthy and happy. But when Nic became addicted to heroin and methamphetamine as a teenager, my dreams shifted. I wanted him to get clean and stay clean. As his drug problem escalated — he used potentially lethal drugs in dangerous combinations for a decade — my hope for him became very simple: just to survive.

headline: How John Roberts Lost His Court
abstract: New challenges to the Supreme Court’s image of probity and detachment seem to keep coming.
lead_paragraph: A self-described documentary filmmaker, trolling a gala dinner for a gotcha moment by engaging Supreme Court justices in conversation and surreptitiously recording their words, arguably scored with Justice Samuel Alito when he told her he shared their stated goal of returning “our country to a place of godliness.”

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,094, June 17, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: In Southern California, a Wildfire That May Foreshadow a Hazardous Summer
abstract: The Post fire northwest of Los Angeles has burned over 14,000 acres and illustrates the danger of built-up vegetation after rainy winters.
lead_paragraph: A wildfire that quickly consumed more than 14,000 acres of grasslands and brush in a mountainous area northwest of Los Angeles over the weekend signaled the start of what experts warn could be a dangerous, prolonged fire season in the West.

headline: Broadway’s Pop Era
abstract: The Tonys are tonight. Many of the shows have a new sound.
lead_paragraph: Tonight is the one night of the year when millions of Americans are focused on Broadway. That’s because it’s the annual Tony Awards, which, by virtue of being televised, are often the first way that many people learn about what’s new onstage.

headline: Police Shoot Ax-Wielding Man Before Euro 2024 Match in Germany
abstract: The shooting took place in Hamburg, in an area packed with soccer fans, and hours before the Netherlands and Poland were set to play in the city.
lead_paragraph: A man wielding an ax on a street crowded with soccer fans was shot by the police on Sunday in Hamburg, Germany, only hours before the city was to host a game at the European Championship.

headline: Italians Respond to Pope’s Slur by Taking Francis to Pride
abstract: At Saturday’s celebration in Rome, Pope Francis’ image was on cardboard cutouts adorned with flower necklaces. People came dressed as the pope, wore papal hats and said that there was never too much “gayness.”
lead_paragraph: At Rome’s Pride celebration, bare-chested men in pink angel wings danced to Abba songs, women wrapped in rainbow flags kissed, and shimmering drag queens waved from parade floats. And then there was Pope Francis.

headline: What Is a ‘Zombie Mortgage’?
abstract: Has your mortgage come back from the dead? It probably wasn’t really gone, it was likely just hiding.
lead_paragraph: For most buyers, mortgages are the cornerstone of purchasing a home. Sometimes a second mortgage is necessary, too, to cover the down payment, for instance. But what happens if that second mortgage seems to have been forgiven but actually still exists? Introducing: the “zombie mortgage.”

headline: Nick Jonas and Adrienne Warren to Star in ‘Last Five Years’ on Broadway
abstract: Whitney White will direct the first Broadway production of Jason Robert Brown’s popular musical, which plans to open next spring.
lead_paragraph: Nick Jonas and Adrienne Warren are planning to star in a production of “The Last Five Years” on Broadway next spring.

headline: Deadly Toll in Greece as Heat Waves Sweep the Country
abstract: A New York man was among several foreigners to have gone missing or been found dead in recent days as temperatures in Greece have soared.
lead_paragraph: Heat waves that have swept across Greece this month continued to exact a deadly toll over the weekend, with the authorities on Sunday reporting the death of an American on a Greek island. At least five tourists remain missing across Greece.

headline: What Happens When You Knock on 8,000 Doors
abstract: Listening to the stories of voters on their thresholds, we felt their need to trust.
lead_paragraph: In 2018, the district judge for our area of south-central Montana was retiring and encouraged my husband, Ray, to run to fill his seat. Ray, a lawyer with 30 years of experience in civil and criminal practice, was new to politics. He expected to be the underdog. While all judicial races in the state are nonpartisan, we were not members of the dominant Republican Party. And we had lived in Montana for only 20 years, long enough to know we would still be considered newcomers.

headline: Russian Forces Quash Prison Mutiny Led by Terrorism Suspects, State Media Reports
abstract: The assailants had taken two guards hostage and were killed, the prison service said.
lead_paragraph: Russian special forces have quashed a short-lived mutiny at a provincial detention center on Sunday, killing detainees, some charged with terrorism, who had broken out of their cells earlier in the day, according to Russian state media.

headline: Man Plotted Mass Shooting in Atlanta to Incite ‘Race War,’ Officials Say
abstract: Prosecutors said Mark Adams Prieto of Arizona planned to target Black concertgoers at an Atlanta venue. He was indicted on hate crime and firearm charges.
lead_paragraph: An Arizona man who planned to commit a mass shooting at an Atlanta rap concert as a way of inciting a “race war” has been indicted by a federal grand jury on hate crime and firearm charges.

headline: John Everett Benson, Who Chiseled John F. Kennedy’s Grave, Dies at 84
abstract: A master of the ancient and exacting art of carving into rock, he was 25 when he began his first major commission, at Arlington National Cemetery.
lead_paragraph: John Everett Benson, a master stone carver, designer and calligrapher whose chisel marked the deaths of presidents, playwrights, authors and artists as well as generations of American families — and whose elegant inscriptions graced museums and universities, government buildings and houses of worship — died on Thursday in Newport, R.I. He was 84.

headline: Buttermilk Fried Chicken, a Dad’s Gift to Himself
abstract: My five-star recipe yields a crisp crust and luscious interior.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s been slow out here in the shallow water, looking for fish on pancakes of sand, by muddy banks, in rock piles where the tide sluices in and out, at spots with names known only to those who fish them: Cheney’s; Manny’s Place; Ethan Allen; Left Side; Derr’s Flat.

headline: Men and Women, Together and Solo
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Nicholas Kristof. Also: An arms competition with China; A.D.H.D. medication; Donald Trump’s divisive rhetoric.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Paul Pressler, Disgraced Christian Conservative Leader, Dies at 94
abstract: A former judge, he helped steer the Southern Baptist Convention to the right. But at least seven men accused him of sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: Paul Pressler, a former Houston appeals court judge who spent decades helping conservatives gain control of the Southern Baptist Convention, the country’s largest Protestant denomination, only to become an embarrassment to its leaders after as many as seven men accused him of sexual abuse, died on June 7. He was 94.

headline: A Met Orchestra of Mixed Quality Returns to Carnegie Hall
abstract: The tenure of Yannick Nézet-Séguin, the Metropolitan Opera’s music director, can be difficult to assess. That much was evident over two concerts.
lead_paragraph: So far, Yannick Nézet-Séguin’s tenure as the Metropolitan Opera’s music director has been mixed. That much was evident over two Met Orchestra concerts at Carnegie Hall last week that were by turns excellent and mystifying.

headline: Review: Camille A. Brown Still Holds the Harlem Stage
abstract: It was a sign of her generosity that her program this weekend was almost all work by her associates.
lead_paragraph: Camille A. Brown is not a choreographer lacking in opportunities to show her work. A current Tony nominee for “Hell’s Kitchen,” she has a premiere scheduled for the Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival later this summer and another Broadway show, a revival of “Gypsy” with Audra McDonald, opening in December.

headline: 14 Jordanians Die in Intense Heat During Hajj Pilgrimage
abstract: The pilgrims died as a result of exposure to extreme sun and heat, Jordan’s official news agency said, as hundreds of thousands poured into Mecca in Saudi Arabia for the Muslim holy trip.
lead_paragraph: Fourteen Jordanian pilgrims died as they performed rituals related to the hajj, a holy trip to Mecca in Saudi Arabia that Muslims are encouraged to take once in their lives, Jordan’s official news agency said on Sunday.

headline: Maine Accepting Designs for a New State Flag
abstract: Maine is seeking design ideas before voters in November determine whether to adopt a new, more distinctive flag.
lead_paragraph: Anyone with an idea for how the Maine state flag should look has a month to submit a design idea, though the contest rules limit just how much of a creative free-for-all will be allowed.

headline: More Than 80 Nations Back Talks to Ease Path to Peace in Ukraine
abstract: Meeting in Switzerland, world leaders backed a joint statement urging more diplomacy, but were divided on how to engage Russia.
lead_paragraph: Scores of countries at a two-day summit in Switzerland joined Ukraine on Sunday in calling for “dialogue between all parties” to end the war with Russia. But Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, said he remained steadfast in opposing any negotiations that could require his country to cede territory.

headline: As N.B.A. TV Deal Nears, Warner Bros. Discovery Is on the Outside
abstract: The company’s TNT channel and the N.B.A. have long been inextricably linked, but that may end after next season. Plus, Charles Barkley is retiring.
lead_paragraph: Warner Bros. Discovery executives thought they had given the National Basketball Association a proposal it would accept.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel Plans for a Daily Pause in Some Fighting
abstract: Also, an emerging plan to resist Donald Trump and an Iran-Sweden prisoner swap.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said yesterday that it would suspend daytime military operations near a border crossing in southern Gaza “until further notice.” The move is an effort to allow more humanitarian aid to enter the enclave, as aid groups make increasingly urgent warnings about the lack of food and other basic goods.

headline: Tony Award Winners 2024: The Full List
abstract: The Tony Awards were held on Sunday at Lincoln Center’s David H. Koch Theater in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Here are the highlights from this year’s Tony Awards.

headline: Red Carpet Looks From the 77th Annual Tony Awards
abstract: Broadway’s biggest stars made their grand entrance.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Paulson, Daniel Radcliffe, Eddie Redmayne and Rachel McAdams are a few of the celebrities nominated this year fueling the excitement for the 2024 Tony Awards.

headline: James Kent, Chef Who Was Building a Restaurant Empire, Dies at 45
abstract: He had opened two restaurants and a cocktail bar in downtown Manhattan, and he was preparing for a big expansion backed by LeBron James.
lead_paragraph: James Kent, a distinguished chef and successful Manhattan restaurateur who seemed poised to become a food-industry tycoon, died on Saturday in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. He was 45.

headline: Bit of Band Equipment
abstract: Kiran Pandey runs a tight ship.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: After Splash Park Shooting, Michigan Community Feels a Familiar Pain
abstract: The violence in the city of Rochester Hills, which injured nine people including children, comes three years after the shooting at Oxford High School in the same county.
lead_paragraph: One day after a shooting in a splash park in suburban Detroit injured nine people, including children, residents on Sunday were struggling to process what happened, with bafflement, fear and shock.

headline: ‘The Outsiders’ Wins Tony Award for Best Musical, ‘Stereophonic’ Best Play
abstract: Stephen Sondheim’s “Merrily We Roll Along,” long considered a flop, was named best musical revival, and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins’s “Appropriate” won best play revival.
lead_paragraph: “The Outsiders,” a muscular musical based on the classic young adult novel, was named best new musical at the Tony Awards on Sunday night, while “Stereophonic,” a behind-the music play about a band making an album, was named best new play.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe Conjures Up His First Tony
abstract: “Merrily We Roll Along” is Radcliffe’s fifth show on Broadway, but the first for which he was even nominated for a Tony Award.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Radcliffe is one of the world’s most famous actors. But he’s never won a major award. Until now.

headline: Chita Rivera’s Life and Career Are Honored at the Tonys
abstract: Rivera, who dazzled Broadway audiences for nearly seven decades, died in January at the age of 91.
lead_paragraph: Chita Rivera, who dazzled Broadway audiences for nearly seven decades, died in January at the age of 91. She “was a Broadway star as long as anyone — and maybe longer,” our chief theater critic, Jesse Green, wrote in an appraisal. Rivera, whose father was born in Puerto Rico, was best known for starring as Anita in “West Side Story” and Velma Kelly in “Chicago,” but had a long list of credits to her name. (She detailed her life in career in “Chita: A Memoir,” written with Patrick Pacheco, in 2023.)

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Season 2 Premiere: Killing in the Name Of
abstract: The second season of HBO’s “Game of Thrones” prequel opens with an illicit affair and a misguided act of revenge.
lead_paragraph: King Viserys is dead. Princess Rhaenyra (Emma D’Arcy) is deposed. Aegon Targaryen (Tom Glynn-Carney), the Second of His Name, sits the Iron Throne. Well, not so much sits as slouches — drunkenly, at that.

headline: ‘Stereophonic’ Wins the Tony Award for Best New Play
abstract: It was the fifth award of the night for the production, a meditation on the joy and torture of creative collaboration.
lead_paragraph: “Stereophonic,” which eavesdrops on a folk-rock quintet whose members make up and break up as they lay down tracks for what will become a smash LP, won the Tony Award for best new play on Sunday. Its 13 Tony nominations are the most a play has ever received.

headline: ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ Was a Flop in 1981. Now It’s a Tony Winner.
abstract: The musical by Stephen Sondheim follows the implosion of a three-way friendship in reverse chronological order.
lead_paragraph: “Merrily We Roll Along,” long considered one of the most storied flops in Broadway history, found redemption on Sunday when it won the Tony Award for best musical revival, belatedly establishing it in the pantheon of Stephen Sondheim masterpieces.

headline: Sarah Paulson Wins Her First Tony for Best Actress in a Play
abstract: In the searing family drama “Appropriate,” Paulson plays an elder sister intent on protecting her father’s legacy.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Paulson won the Tony Award for best actress in a play for her performance in the family drama “Appropriate.” This is Paulson’s first Tony.

headline: Wildfire Burns Across Southern California
abstract: Firefighting crews worked over the weekend to contain the Post fire, which was burning north of Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Firefighting crews worked over the weekend to contain the Post fire, which was burning north of Los Angeles.

headline: Jonathan Groff’s Star Turn in ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ Lands Him His First Tony
abstract: The gregarious performer who loves and is loved by Broadway picked up a trophy for best leading actor in a musical.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Groff, a gregarious performer who loves and is loved by Broadway, finally won his first Tony Award on Sunday night, picking up a trophy for best leading actor in a musical for his star turn in a transformational revival of “Merrily We Roll Along.”

headline: ‘The Outsiders,’ a Broadway Adaptation of the Classic Novel, Wins the Tony for Best Musical
abstract: The gritty, bloody and relentlessly youthful musical features some of the most effectively vivid violence seen on a Broadway stage.
lead_paragraph: “The Outsiders,” a muscular stage adaptation of the classic young adult novel about class conflict between a pair of high school gangs, won the coveted Tony Award for best musical on Sunday.

headline: Maleah Joi Moon Wins a Tony for Her First Professional Role
abstract: Moon, 21, made her Broadway debut in the Alicia Keys musical “Hell’s Kitchen.”
lead_paragraph: Maleah Joi Moon won the Tony Award for best leading actress in a musical on Sunday night for her Broadway debut in “Hell’s Kitchen,” a fictionalized remix of Alicia Keys’s childhood.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hatching Plans for Cricket Venues
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 17, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This makes Grand Prairie a destination, not just a little town between Dallas and Fort Worth.”

headline: No Corrections: June 17, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, June 17, 2021.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Toyota Investors Challenge Scion’s Grip at a ‘Critical Juncture’
abstract: Akio Toyoda ran Toyota for 14 years before handing the reins to a new C.E.O. last year, but some have grown concerned about the control he still wields.
lead_paragraph: During his long tenure as chief executive, Akio Toyoda led Toyota Motor to the top of the car industry.

headline: America’s Voice in Taiwan Has Some Parting Advice About China
abstract: Worries about Chinese belligerence rose during Sandra Oudkirk’s three years in Taipei. As she leaves, she is seeking to assure Taiwan of continued U.S. support.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of three years as the United States’ chief representative in Taiwan, Sandra Oudkirk has some parting advice: Avoid panic about China’s combative language and moves, but don’t grow numb to the risks.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: Israel plans to pause fighting at a Gaza border crossing.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said yesterday that it would suspend daytime military operations near a border crossing in southern Gaza “until further notice” to allow more humanitarian aid to enter the enclave. Aid groups have made increasingly urgent warnings about the lack of food and other basic goods.

headline: U.N. Humanitarian Chief: World Leaders Are Failing Us
abstract: They are breaking the compact between ordinary people and those in whom power is vested.
lead_paragraph: I have spent much of my career in or on the edges of war zones, but nothing quite prepared me for the breadth and depth of human suffering I have witnessed in my three years as the United Nations’ humanitarian chief.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Slave Play’ and ‘Orphan Black: Echoes’
abstract: HBO airs a documentary about the playwright Jeremy O. Harris. A new show starring Krysten Ritter premieres on AMC.
lead_paragraph: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, June 17-23. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: interminable
abstract: This word has appeared in 41 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word interminable has appeared in 41 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 8 in “Striking Actors and Hollywood Studios Agree to a Deal” by Brooks Barnes, John Koblin and Nicole Sperling:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The ‘Mad Men’ Era Is Long Over. Why Is Advertising Still So White?
abstract: Despite corporate promises and hiring campaigns, the ad industry is among New York City’s least diverse job sectors. It shows in the work, critics say.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, KFC ran advertisements in Canada featuring Black people eating fried chicken and licking their fingers, their faces reflected in unused silverware.

headline: Gilgo Suspect’s How-To Manual Reflects a Killer’s Mind, Prosecutors Say
abstract: Rex Heuermann assembled a document that prosecutors said was created to help him avoid detection. But it may be damning evidence, with one expert calling it a “blueprint for murder.”
lead_paragraph: When prosecutors indicted Rex Heuermann this month on two additional murders in the Gilgo Beach serial killings on Long Island, they also described a manual he kept as a “planning document.”

headline: Here’s What You Discover When You Walk Every Block in New York City
abstract: Also, New York politicians have been promising to ease traffic for a century.
lead_paragraph: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.

headline: Biden Adviser Visits Israel as Military Warns of ‘Wider Escalation’ With Hezbollah
abstract: The adviser, Amos Hochstein, met with Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu amid Hezbollah’s use of larger and more sophisticated weapons beyond the Israel-Lebanon border.
lead_paragraph: A White House adviser met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem on Monday as the Israeli military warned that the Lebanese militia Hezbollah was risking a wider confrontation with its cross-border strikes against Israel.

headline: Urban Draws and Sandy Feet: 5 Cities With Great Beaches
abstract: Already been to Miami, Honolulu and Sydney? These other coastal destinations are vibrant on land and on the water, reliably offering visitors great beaches and urban adventures.
lead_paragraph: While secluded, remote coastal destinations have enduring appeal, a great beach city provides travelers with top-notch hotels, restaurants and cultural attractions, as well as the requisite sandy feet, endless waves and ocean sunsets of a great beach vacation.

headline: More Women in Africa Are Using Long-Acting Contraception, Changing Lives
abstract: Methods such as hormonal implants and injections are reaching remote areas, providing more discretion and autonomy.
lead_paragraph: On a busy day at the Kwapong Health Centre in rural Ghana, Beatrice Nyamekye put contraceptive implants into the arms of a half-dozen women, and gave eight or nine more a three-month hormonal injection to prevent pregnancy. A few sought condoms or birth control pills, but most wanted something longer lasting.

headline: Surgeon General: Why I’m Calling for a Warning Label on Social Media Platforms
abstract: It’s time for decisive action to protect our young people.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important lessons I learned in medical school was that in an emergency, you don’t have the luxury to wait for perfect information. You assess the available facts, you use your best judgment, and you act quickly.

headline: Surgeon General Calls for Warning Labels on Social Media Platforms
abstract: Dr. Vivek Murthy said he would urge Congress to require a warning that social media use can harm teenagers’ mental health.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. surgeon general, Dr. Vivek Murthy, announced on Monday that he would push for a warning label on social media platforms advising parents that using the platforms might damage adolescents’ mental health.

headline: A Bird-Flu Pandemic in People? Here’s What It Might Look Like.
abstract: There is no guarantee that a person-to-person virus would be benign, scientists say, and vaccines and treatments at hand may not be sufficient.
lead_paragraph: The bird flu outbreak in dairy cattle has so far spilled over to just three farmworkers in the United States, as far as public health authorities know. All of them have had mostly mild symptoms.

headline: He’s an Emergency Medical Worker Fighting to Save People From His Own Life
abstract: Joseph Earl Thomas’s new novel, “God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer,” follows a health care worker on a tumultuous shift where every other patient seems to be someone from his past.
lead_paragraph: Early one morning my husband asked me if I was enjoying “God Bless You, Otis Spunkmeyer,” the book I’d spent the last few days reading around the house, sometimes with a look of delight, sometimes laughing or on the verge of tears, sometimes with a look of extreme frustration. “Ask me later today,” I told him, unable to process if “enjoyment” was what I was feeling as I made my way through Joseph Earl Thomas’s debut novel.

headline: A School With 7 Students: Inside the ‘Microschools’ Movement
abstract: Parents, desperate for help, are turning to private schools with a half-dozen or so students. And they are getting a financial boost from taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: When Nathanael was in kindergarten, he told his mother, Diana Lopez, that he did not want to return to school — ever. His teacher yelled at him, he said. And when Ms. Lopez picked him up from school, he would often immediately start to cry.

headline: A Proud Texan Reckons With Her State’s Complicated Past
abstract: In her new book, Jessica Goudeau confronts a history of racism and violence in Texas through an investigation of her ancestors’ stories.
lead_paragraph: I never knew my father’s father, a Texas preacher who died when my father was 2 years old. As a bookish kid growing up in San Antonio, a city swirling with Texas history and myth, I often thumbed through the pages of my grandfather’s sermons and personal library, which lined the walls of my childhood home. What, I wondered, could those books tell me about him, my history, and myself?

headline: Does Stress Cause Ulcers?
abstract: Here’s what the evidence suggests about this long-running claim.
lead_paragraph: Q: My family always says I’m going to give myself an ulcer if I don’t manage my stress. But is that really a thing?

headline: 8 Productivity Books Time-Management Experts Actually Use
abstract: These titles can help you achieve more with less stress.
lead_paragraph: It probably doesn’t come as a shock that productivity researchers are always looking for new ways to use their time wisely.

headline: How Long Does Rice Last in the Fridge? And Other Pressing Rice Questions, Answered
abstract: Don’t get sick this season.
lead_paragraph: If the social media rumors are true, your leftover rice may be trying to kill you. Experts on the matter, however, tell a somewhat different story.

headline: Looking for Friends? How About 23 Housemates?
abstract: An engineer who moved from London to New York was planning to live alone, but ended up doing just the opposite — and loving it.
lead_paragraph: A move across the Atlantic Ocean into the arms of nearly two dozen housemates was not what Ishan Abeysekera had envisioned for himself. But that’s his life now, and he’s embraced it.

headline: Black Farmers in Georgia Cool to Biden, Reflecting a Bigger Challenge
abstract: White farmers filed lawsuits to block a debt forgiveness initiative, but the Biden administration is still bearing the blame.
lead_paragraph: On a hot day in May, Andrew L. Smith Sr., a vegetable farmer from Ludowici, Ga., listened with skepticism as Tom Vilsack, the U.S. agriculture secretary, touted President Biden’s efforts to help Black farmers overcome decades of discrimination.

headline: The Queen Bee of Bidenomics
abstract: Jennifer Harris is the intellectual force driving the administration’s approach to trade and economic policies.
lead_paragraph: The best dinner party I’ve attended all year took place at a conference held at the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge, overlooking the San Francisco Bay. It was a family-style meal, arranged to make you ask the person sitting next to you to please pass the kale salad, at which point you might realize that to your left is a celebrated economist, and to your right, a top government official. Our host, Jennifer Harris, gave a speech about how economic ideas change to meet the needs of a new era.

headline: Recycling Is Broken. Should I Even Bother?
abstract: Every little bit helps. But doing it wrong can actually make matters worse.
lead_paragraph: Recycling can have big environmental benefits. For one thing, it keeps unwanted objects out of landfills or incinerators, where they can produce potent greenhouse gasses and potentially hazardous pollutants.

headline: 3 High-Octane Summer Thrillers
abstract: Our columnist on three twisty new tales of murder.
lead_paragraph: You’re not going to like Dr. Caroline Strange, the psychiatrist in Louisa Luna’s constantly surprising TELL ME WHO YOU ARE (MCD x FSG, 340 pp., $29), but you might admire her ingenuity and ruthless instinct for self-preservation. She needs both those qualities to deal with the chaos wrought by Nelson Schack, a new patient with two unwelcome pieces of news. “I think I’m going to kill someone,” he declares, “and I know who you really are.”

headline: How A.I. Is Revolutionizing Drug Development
abstract: In high-tech labs, workers are generating data to train A.I. algorithms to design better medicine, faster. But the transformation is just getting underway.
lead_paragraph: The laboratory at Terray Therapeutics is a symphony of miniaturized automation. Robots whir, shuttling tiny tubes of fluids to their stations. Scientists in blue coats, sterile gloves and protective glasses monitor the machines.

headline: Can A.I. Answer the Needs of Smaller Businesses? Some Push to Find Out.
abstract: Artificial intelligence tools like ChatGPT are finding widest use at big companies, but there is wide expectation that the impact will spread.
lead_paragraph: The Nashville Area Chamber of Commerce has convened an annual meeting of local business leaders since the 1800s, but the most recent gathering had a decidedly modern theme: artificial intelligence.

headline: In Virginia, Bob Good’s Republican Primary Has Split the MAGA Movement
abstract: A contest between the chairman of the ultraconservative House Freedom Caucus and another right-wing politician who has the backing of former President Donald J. Trump has splintered the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene of Georgia stepped off a tour bus wrapped in “Trump 2024” decals one afternoon this month in south-central Virginia with a simple message: Representative Bob Good of Virginia, the chairman of the hard-right House Freedom Caucus, was a traitor to former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Pregnant in Gaza With Nowhere to Go
abstract: As war killed all hope around her, Nevin Muhaisen fought to bring a new life into the world.
lead_paragraph: Before the leaflets fell from the sky telling her to evacuate, before all that was left of her home was its western wall, before the food shortages left her baking her own bread, before her daughters slept under a chalkboard in an abandoned kindergarten, before a sniper killed an in-law who was bringing back blankets because it was getting cold — that is, before the war came to Gaza and obliterated most of what she remembered of life there — Nevin Muhaisen, a middle-school teacher and mother of four, was listening to her doctor give her some good news. Nevin, he said, was pregnant.

headline: 5 Places to Explore L.G.B.T.Q. History in New York City
abstract: Discover the new Stonewall visitors’ center, a queer-friendly beach, a museum with works by a pioneering lesbian photographer and other sites, one in each borough.
lead_paragraph: For decades, visitors flocking to New York for Pride every June found plenty of packed bars and jubilant parties but no easy way to engage with the city’s rich L.G.B.T.Q. history.

headline: Even Doctors Like Me Are Falling Into This Medical Bill Trap
abstract: Hospital outpatient departments, or HOPDs, are encouraging a surprise scourge on medical costs. It’s patients who bear the burden.
lead_paragraph: Thank goodness for urgent care centers. Last July my daughter was still limping a week after a bike injury, and we needed a quick X-ray to rule out a fracture. As a doctor, I knew we didn’t need an expensive emergency room for something this straightforward. We found an urgent care at the end of a strip mall in Chicago, and 20 minutes later we received the good news that there was only a sprain.

headline: Blast Shelters and Radar Jamming: A Russian City Adapts to War
abstract: While in Moscow the fighting feels far away, residents of Belgorod, 25 miles from the border with Ukraine, have learned to duck for cover when the sirens wail.
lead_paragraph: As Alina waited for the bus that would take her to her family’s weekend house outside Belgorod, she made sure to wait deep inside the concrete shelter built early this year around the stop.

headline: Across or Up, Rock Climbers and Crossword Solvers Puzzle Alike
abstract: Climbers say they love the sport because of its similarity to puzzles, not only for the athletic feats.
lead_paragraph: It was the third time Emma Ricks had tried a certain route on this rock climbing wall in Newark. Before, she failed to make it to the top — or, as climbers would say, she had yet to “send” the climbing problem. On this third attempt, she was determined to make it.

headline: A Designer Turns His Passion for Mountaineering Into New Pursuits
abstract: Ramdane Touhami recently restyled a hotel in the Swiss Alps and opened a hiking supply store in Paris. He says they are only the beginning.
lead_paragraph: Many designers aspire to the label polymath, but no one polymaths as hard and relentlessly as Ramdane Touhami, whose latest pursuit meshes merchandising, marketing and selling his favorite thing: hiking.

headline: Best and Worst Moments From the 2024 Tony Awards
abstract: Alicia Keys and Jay-Z’s high-wattage performance was a highlight, as were first-time wins for Kecia Lewis, Jonathan Groff and David Adjmi.
lead_paragraph: Ariana DeBose ended her third turn as Tonys host with a mic drop. Otherwise, last night’s ceremony offered a first time for everything and very nearly everyone. All eight winners in the acting categories took home their first trophies. (How is it possible that this is Jonathan Groff’s inaugural win?) The playwright David Adjmi, in his Broadway debut, won for “Stereophonic,” as did its director Daniel Aukin, also a Tony-winning newbie. Danya Taymor took home the prize for best direction of a musical for “The Outsiders,” her initial win. (“The Outsiders” also won for best musical.) In a mellow, equitable night, the other awards were spread among many of the nominated shows, with “Stereophonic,” “The Outsiders,” “Appropriate” and an ingeniously reimagined “Merrily We Roll Along” carrying home the top prizes. Here are the highs and lows — and wait, is that Jay-Z on the stairs? — of the ceremony.

headline: Trump Isn’t Choosing a Running Mate. He’s Casting a Co-Star.
abstract: Everything Donald Trump knows about picking a running mate in 2024 he learned while hosting “The Apprentice.”
lead_paragraph: The public jockeying by various candidates to become Donald Trump’s running mate has taken on the air of a circus. At the Manhattan criminal courthouse where he was being tried for falsifying business records (and was found guilty on all 34 counts), a parade of acolytes appeared, often wearing Trump-red ties, in apparent hopes of impressing their potential future ticket mate: Senator J.D. Vance of Ohio, Senator Rick Scott of Florida, Senator Tommy Tuberville of Alabama, the businessman and former presidential candidate Vivek Ramaswamy and others.

headline: In Search of the Lost Fireflies
abstract: There were no trees. There was no road. I was the trees, and I was the road. That darkness was like no darkness I’ve ever known.
lead_paragraph: I first learned about blue ghosts last year from Jennifer Frick-Ruppert, a zoologist at Brevard College in western North Carolina. I was at Brevard for a writers’ conference, and Dr. Frick-Ruppert offered to take me to see the ethereal fireflies that glow without blinking. But it rained that night, and lightning bugs don’t fly in a hard rain. I was heartbroken. I was also determined to get back there this year and try again.

headline: Why the Subways Are Crucial to New York’s Future
abstract: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the ripple effects of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s decision to put congestion pricing on an indefinite hold.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the ripple effects of Gov. Kathy Hochul’s decision to put congestion pricing on an indefinite hold.

headline: Libertarian Candidates Can Change Presidential Outcomes. What Does the New Nominee Believe?
abstract: Jane Coaston interviews the new nominee, Chase Oliver, about his beliefs.
lead_paragraph: In 2016 the Libertarian Party presidential candidate, Gary Johnson, received more votes than any of the party’s other candidates in history and the most of any third-party candidate since Ross Perot — and arguably, the Libertarian Party has never recovered.

headline: From Ferrari to the Frozen Food Aisle
abstract: Charles Leclerc, one of the rising stars of the Formula 1, now has an ice cream on the market.
lead_paragraph: Charles Leclerc, one of the fastest drivers in Formula 1, looked a tad sleepy. Despite being between races and time zones — a rainy Circuit Gilles Villeneuve in Montreal last week and the Spanish Grand Prix two weeks after — he was up very early on a video call from Lake Como in Italy, to talk about his new business venture: LEC, a low-calorie ice cream.

headline: His Family Survived the Nazis by Living in a Chicken Coop
abstract: A new museum exhibit on the Holocaust focuses on eight narratives, including the account of a man whose family escaped death by hiding on a family farm.
lead_paragraph: In 1942, when Max Heppner was 8, his parents told him they were leaving Amsterdam to go on a family vacation. Instead, they went into hiding in a small farm town in the Netherlands, Zeilberg, where they lived out the war in a chicken coop.

headline: After 40 Years of Dance, What Happens to a Dream Fulfilled?
abstract: Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, who founded Urban Bush Women four decades ago, says goodbye to it with a final work.
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the early 1980s, the choreographer Jawole Willa Jo Zollar had a life-changing dream. Her dead parents, Dot and Al, appeared in it along with other ancestors. They all ate at a table in the middle of the ocean, and her father sang of his failure, cautioning against chasing after outside approval, repeating the phrase “Success is not the test.” A wave crashed over them, and Zollar knew what she had to do.

headline: $1.4 Million Homes in California
abstract: A 1949 cottage in Lake Arrowhead, a Spanish-style home in Los Angeles and a Craftsman house in Berkeley.
lead_paragraph: This house is in the Palisades neighborhood, near Cedar Glen Malt Shop, a popular spot for hamburgers and milkshakes, and the Cedar Glen Inn, a casual restaurant. It is less than a 10-minute drive from breweries, restaurants and shopping in Lake Arrowhead Village, and within a 15-minute drive of hiking trails offering views of the lake and surrounding mountains.

headline: Bird Flu Is Infecting Cats (and the Occasional Dog). Here’s What to Know.
abstract: A few “reasonable precautions” can help people keep their pets safe from the H5N1 virus, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few months, a bird flu outbreak has spread swiftly through dairy cows in the United States, infecting more than 90 herds in 12 states. Along the way, the virus has caused collateral damage in several other species, spreading from dairies to poultry farms and from cows into at least three farm workers, who developed symptoms of mild illness.

headline: I’m Moving to a New City. Do I Have to Change the Way I Dress?
abstract: A reader who is moving cross-country wonders how to adapt his wardrobe without compromising his sense of style.
lead_paragraph: Every major city has its style stereotypes, sometimes many at the same time. New York is dark colors and conceptual shreds, banker suiting and Park Avenue bouclé. Seattle is fleece. (So is San Francisco.) Dallas is cowboy boots and diamonds. Los Angeles is leggings and Erewhon cups. Paris is blazers and perfectly draped scarves. And so on.

headline: ‘House of the Dragon’ Season 2 Premiere: What Was That Ending About?
abstract: Fans of the George R.R. Martin books know there are two words for that tense and slightly ambiguous ending to the Season 2 premiere: “Blood and Cheese.”
lead_paragraph: This article contains major spoilers for the Season 2 premiere of HBO’s “House of the Dragon.”

headline: Democrats Announce a $10 Million Push for State Legislatures
abstract: An unusually early and large Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee investment is aimed at getting voters to pay more attention to state legislative races.
lead_paragraph: As the arm of the Democratic Party that works on state legislative races, it is the job of the Democratic Legislative Campaign Committee to care about the bottom of the ballot. With a $10 million campaign announced on Monday, it is trying to get more voters to care, too.

headline: Biden Campaign Ad Calls Attention to Trump’s Felon Status
abstract: Democrats have been urging the president to more forcefully attack Donald Trump after his felony conviction by a New York jury.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s campaign on Monday began its most aggressive effort to brand former President Donald J. Trump a felon, with the introduction of a new television advertisement that focuses on the presumptive Republican presidential nominee’s criminal conviction.

headline: ‘A Hellscape’: Dire Conditions in Gaza Leave a Multitude of Amputees
abstract: Access to medical care and even clean water is limited, and the risk of infection is high, making it difficult for patients to get follow-up surgeries, prosthetics and rehabilitation.
lead_paragraph: Bleeding and crying, Dr. Hani Bseso’s teenage niece Ahed called out for him as she slipped in and out of consciousness.

headline: Northeast Braces for First Severe Heat of the Year
abstract: The excessive heat was being felt in the Midwest on Monday as the heat index, a measure of how the temperature feels with humidity, hit 102 degrees in Cincinnati.
lead_paragraph: Follow our updates for the latest on the heat wave across the U.S.

headline: A Heat Wave Hits the U.S., and a ‘Pause’ in Gaza Fighting
abstract: Plus, the Tony Awards honor the best of Broadway.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,095, June 18, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Abortion United Evangelicals and Republicans. Now That Alliance Is Fraying.
abstract: The Southern Baptist Convention, long a bellwether for American evangelicalism, voted to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization.
lead_paragraph: The Southern Baptist Convention, the largest denomination of Protestant Christians in the United States, voted at an annual gathering last week to oppose the use of in vitro fertilization.

headline: Russia Sets Date for Start of Evan Gershkovich’s Trial
abstract: The announcement of a hearing next week is the most significant movement in the Wall Street Journal reporter’s case since his arrest in March 2023 on espionage charges.
lead_paragraph: A court in Russia said on Monday that the espionage trial of the imprisoned American journalist Evan Gershkovich would start next week and that the proceedings would be held behind closed doors.

headline: Netanyahu Dissolves War Cabinet After 2 Members Quit
abstract: The widely expected move came after two moderates resigned last week from the influential group, which made key decisions about the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has dissolved his war cabinet, an Israeli official said Monday, after the departures of two significant members prompted demands from far-right politicians for representation in the influential group.

headline: Facing E.V. Tariffs, China Threatens Pork Imports From Europe
abstract: Acting quickly after the European Union imposed extra tariffs of up to 38 percent on China’s electric cars, Beijing opened a trade case on Europe’s pork.
lead_paragraph: China on Monday threatened to impose tariffs on pork imports from Europe, in what appeared to be retaliation for the European Union’s decision last week to impose preliminary tariffs on electric cars imported from China.

headline: Public Funding, Private Education
abstract: We explain a major change in U.S. public education.
lead_paragraph: An overwhelming majority of American students attend public schools. But that number is falling. In part, that’s because in more than half of states, parents can now use public money to educate their kids — at home, online, in private schools. This year, a million students used some kind of private education voucher, more than double the figure from four years earlier, according to new research from EdChoice, a group that supports private-school choice and tracks the sector.

headline: In Need of Munitions, Putin to Visit North Korea
abstract: ​Seeking more weapons for the war in Ukraine, the Russian president plans to return to the country on Tuesday for the first time in nearly a quarter-century.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will visit North Korea this week for a meeting with its leader, Kim Jong-un, their second in nine months, as the two countries deepen military ties to support Mr. Putin’s war in Ukraine with North Korean weapons.

headline: Is Social Media the New Tobacco?
abstract: Vivek Murthy, the U.S. surgeon general, wants warning labels on the tech platforms, arguing that they are fueling a mental health crisis among teens.
lead_paragraph: Just in: The U.S. surgeon general, Vivek Murthy, called for a warning label for social media platforms in a Times Guest Essay, advising parents that the technology may be helping fuel a mental health crisis among adolescents.

headline: Train Crash in India Leaves at Least 8 Dead and Dozens Injured
abstract: The death toll was expected to rise after a passenger train and a freight train collided in the state of West Bengal.
lead_paragraph: A freight train collided with a passenger train in eastern India on Monday, killing at least eight people and injuring 50 others, officials said.

headline: ‘Inside! Inside!’: Sailors Recount Houthi Attack and U.S. Navy Rescue
abstract: The captain of a ship assaulted by the Yemen-based militia last week spoke at a news conference in Manila after the rescue.
lead_paragraph: The crew of the Tutor, a Greek-owned bulk carrier sailing across the Red Sea to India, were on the deck on a sunny morning last week when they spotted in the distance what looked like a fishing vessel with two people aboard. The crew members thought it was nothing unusual, but moments later, the ship captain said, they noticed a vessel rushing toward their ship.

headline: A Tale of Two Nearly Extinct Giant Salamanders
abstract: While trying to save large amphibians native to Japan, herpetologists in the country unexpectedly found a way to potentially save an even bigger species in China.
lead_paragraph: In Japanese rivers, if you’re very lucky, you might find unusual amphibians that grow up to five feet long and look like strange cartoon dinosaurs. They are giant salamanders.

headline: California May Ban Legacy Admissions at Universities
abstract: The State Assembly passed a bill banning colleges from considering family ties to donors or alumni in admissions decisions.
lead_paragraph: California could become the fourth state to ban legacy admissions preferences at universities under a bill making its way through the State Legislature.

headline: Cosmic Horror Awaits Aboard a Perilous Oil Rig
