abstract: The Chinese Room has long delivered unconventional game worlds. The metal offshore structure in Still Wakes the Deep might be its most evocatively realized yet.
lead_paragraph: Christmas, 1975: an oil rig off the east coast of Scotland. Inside over breakfast, the chatter of possible strikes and crew members wolfing down baked beans, fried eggs and mugs of tea. Outside, the briny tang of windswept sea air, the North Sea swirling tempestuously below.

headline: N.Y.C. Rent Board Sets Increases of 2.75% for One-Year Leases
abstract: The city panel that oversees rents for one million stabilized apartments also backed increases of 5.25 percent for two-year leases.
lead_paragraph: A New York City panel approved rent increases for almost one million stabilized apartments on Monday evening. The carefully watched annual vote highlighted the city’s affordability crisis, a core struggle in New York and other cities across the nation.

headline: Maryland Governor Pardons 175,000 Marijuana Convictions
abstract: The state legalized the use of recreational marijuana in 2022. Several other states and the federal government have also wiped out low-level convictions for marijuana possession.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Wes Moore of Maryland signed an executive order on Monday morning that forgives more than 175,000 convictions on low-level charges related to marijuana use.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Tortured Poets’ Logs an Eighth Straight Week at No. 1
abstract: Billie Eilish is No. 2, and Charli XCX debuts strong at No. 3.
lead_paragraph: Taylor, Taylor, Taylor, Taylor, Taylor, Taylor, Taylor, Taylor.

headline: Why Do We Fear Forgiveness?
abstract: Choosing to forgive can be frightening, but it’s a powerful tool for repairing the harm done by violence, oppression and other traumas.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: You’ve Seen the Movie — Now Name the Book That Inspired It
abstract: This quick quiz challenges you to identify a film’s source material based on a photo. Click here to play!
lead_paragraph: This quick quiz challenges you to identify a film’s source material based on a photo. Click here to play!

headline: Sweet Corn, Spicy Shishitos, Super Salad
abstract: Lidey Heuck’s jubilant, cumin-y combination of crunchy raw corn kernels and sautéed peppers is hearty and flavorful enough to be a light meal unto itself.
lead_paragraph: This week brings the official start of summer, and with it comes the kickoff, in my house at least, of salad-for-dinner season.

headline: ‘The Promised Land,’ ‘Biosphere’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: Speculative science fiction, period drama and sly thrillers are among this month’s off-the-beaten-path recommendations from your subscription streamers.
lead_paragraph: Mads Mikkelsen stars in this epic period drama as Capt. Ludvig Kahlen, described as “a presumptuous soldier in a flea-ridden uniform” — and that’s what they say to his face. The sneers and humiliation he is subjected to by the ruling class of mid-18th-century Denmark give the picture its juice; the potent narrative is as much a pointed class commentary as a historical drama, as the poor but dedicated Kahlen tries to build a workable manor out of a barren slab of heath, and discovers that his idealistic notions of honor and hard work won’t get him much of anywhere with these aristocrats. Chief among them is Simon Bennebjerg’s De Schinkel, the most loathsome movie villain in many a moon. And the director Nikolaj Arcel builds up a furious head of steam on the way to an utterly satisfying conclusion.

headline: A Warning on Social Media Is the Very Least We Can Do
abstract: It’s a mere Band-Aid on a suppurating wound.
lead_paragraph: You’re in the middle of a public health emergency involving a dangerously addictive substance — let’s say an epidemic of fentanyl or vaping among teens. Which of the following is the best response?

headline: What Weapons Is North Korea Accused of Supplying to Russia?
abstract: Moscow needs conventional arms like artillery shells and missiles that North Korea could provide to give it an edge in its war of attrition in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will travel to North Korea for a two-day visit starting Tuesday to meet with one of the main arms suppliers for his war against Ukraine.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 372, June 17, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: The Paths to Progress for Our Graduates
abstract: Responses to an essay about “no promise” graduates. Also: Justice Alito and “godliness”; Sudan’s tragedy; whistle-blower protections; dreading election night.

lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Several Injured After Mace and Fireworks Disrupt Pride Event in Baltimore
abstract: Multiple attendees were treated for injuries after a confrontation involving mace led to the event being shut down early, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Several people were injured on Saturday night after a Pride event in Baltimore was disrupted by fireworks and mace sprayed in a crowded area, the police said.

headline: Infidelity, Dysfunction, Secrets — This Family Novel Delivers
abstract: “Same as It Ever Was,” by Claire Lombardo, is a 500-page, multigenerational examination of the ties that bind.
lead_paragraph: For a certain Gen X elder, Talking Heads were the definitive ’80s band, sparking dorm-room debates over David Byrne’s nerdy mystique, the artistic merits of “Remain in Light” versus “More Songs About Buildings and Food” and whether or not the group sold out with “Little Creatures.”

headline: How Crypto Money Is Poised to Influence the Election
abstract: The industry’s political awakening — and enormous pool of cash — is already affecting high-profile races across the country.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Selkis, a cryptocurrency executive, was eating dinner at Mar-a-Lago last month when he got an unexpected invitation: Former President Donald J. Trump wanted him to come to the stage and say a few words.

headline: Top Democratic Power Broker Is Charged With Racketeering
abstract: New Jersey’s attorney general said George Norcross, who built a political empire from Camden, N.J., had been running a “criminal enterprise” for 12 years.
lead_paragraph: George E. Norcross III, an insurance executive who for decades has been one of New Jersey’s most powerful Democratic kingmakers, was charged on Monday with racketeering in what prosecutors say was a 12-year scheme that involved his brother, his lawyer and a former mayor of Camden, N.J.

headline: Who Is George Norcross?
abstract: One of the most powerful political figures in New Jersey, he was indicted on Monday on charges of racketeering.
lead_paragraph: George E. Norcross III, who was indicted on Monday on charges of racketeering, has never held elected office but has wielded immense political power in New Jersey for decades.

headline: Jay-Z’s Big Tonys Duet With Alicia Keys Was Pretaped
abstract: The two stars brought down the house with “Empire State of Mind,” their 2009 love song to New York City, which they had recorded earlier on a grand marble staircase outside the auditorium.
lead_paragraph: It drew one of the biggest roars of the night at the Tony Awards: Alicia Keys was performing a medley from her Broadway musical “Hell’s Kitchen” on Sunday when she walked out of the auditorium and was shown joining Jay-Z on a marble staircase for “Empire State of Mind,” their 2009 love song to New York City.

headline: Traveling During a Heat Wave: Tips and Precautions
abstract: It’s summer and the temperature is rising. Here’s what you need to know to protect yourself and your vacation dollars.
lead_paragraph: Follow our updates for the latest on the heat wave across the U.S.

headline: Gaza Is World’s Deadliest Place for Aid Workers, U.N. Says
abstract: The peril faced by humanitarian workers in Gaza has interrupted or obstructed the delivery of aid in a place where, aid groups have warned, hundreds of thousands of people are facing famine conditions.
lead_paragraph: Gaza has become the most dangerous place in the world for aid workers, the United Nations said on Monday.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe, Pete Townshend and Sarah Paulson Party for the Tonys
abstract: Spirited celebrations that included an official after-party at Lincoln Center and a gathering at the Carlyle Hotel, where revelers broke out in show tunes, continued until nearly 5 a.m.
lead_paragraph: The actress Kara Young stood surrounded by admirers inside David Geffen Hall at Lincoln Center around 1 a.m. on Monday morning, fielding a swarm of well-wishers after winning her first Tony Award, for featured actress in the comedy “Purlie Victorious.” Her older brother hovered close by and periodically fanned out the train of her lime chiffon dress.

headline: First-Time Tony Winners Talk About Their Victories
abstract: All of the actors who took home Tonys were first-time winners. Here’s what they had to say after their wins.
lead_paragraph: All of the performers who received Tony Awards last night have one thing in common: they were all first-time honorees. After accepting their prizes, the winners trekked across the Lincoln Center plaza to a press room where they answered questions from The New York Times and reporters from other news outlets. Here’s a sampling of what they said.

headline: Michigan and CUNY Mishandled Discrimination Complaints, Education Dept. Finds
abstract: The department concluded that both schools failed to appropriately respond to complaints that campus protests had veered into antisemitism and anti-Arab discrimination.
lead_paragraph: The University of Michigan and the City University of New York mishandled complaints of discrimination on campus during widespread protests over the war in Gaza, the Education Department announced on Monday.

headline: Elite Real Estate Broker and His Twin Face Sexual Assault Suits
abstract: A co-founder of a brokerage that caters to the ultrawealthy and his twin brother face accusations that they sexually assaulted women. They have denied wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: This story has been updated to include information about another lawsuit filed on Tuesday.

headline: The ‘Bling Bishop’ Is Sentenced to 9 Years for Fleecing His Flock
abstract: Lamor Whitehead, who prosecutors said was a career con man who ran a church, took in millions, which he spent on cars, clothes and jewels.
lead_paragraph: Lamor Whitehead, the flamboyant Brooklyn preacher who was convicted of defrauding a parishioner’s mother and attempting to commit extortion, was sentenced to nine years in prison by a federal judge in Manhattan on Monday.

headline: Oxtail Is Gaining Fans. Not Everyone Is Happy About That.
abstract: The tender-stewed cut is being pushed to the culinary forefront by creative chefs and home cooks, leading to higher prices.
lead_paragraph: When the chef Lerone Mullin opened the Jerk Grill, his fast-casual restaurant in Redlands, Calif., in 2021, customers told him they loved his Caribbean classics, like brown stew chicken, and his Caribbean-Mexican mash-ups, like a jerk chicken burrito. But they asked for one addition.

headline: How to Throw a Greek Summer Party
abstract: According to Maria Lemos, the founder of the Athens boutique Mouki Mou, it’s all about “philoxenia,” a love of one’s guest.
lead_paragraph: When guests arrived at the Mouki Mou store in Athens at 6 p.m. on the last weekend in May, they grabbed cool glasses of Greek rosé before retreating into the concrete-clad boutique. Its founder, Maria Lemos, who grew up in Greece, opened the shop in the city’s historic center, Plaka, in 2023, ten years after establishing Mouki Mou’s flagship on London’s Chiltern Street. In both places, she curates a roster of under-the-radar clothing and homeware brands that center craftsmanship with a tactile, wabi-sabi approach. On this particular evening, the brand in focus was Dosa, founded by the American-based Korean designer Christina Kim, 67, in 1983. The label is known for its roomy clothes in natural, hand-woven fabrics that nod to workwear such as shepherd jackets, kurtas (long, loose shirts common in Pakistan), cossack tops and dashikis (boxy tops worn in West Africa), as well as its no-waste approach to production.

headline: U.S. Sues Adobe Over Hard-to-Cancel Subscriptions
abstract: The maker of Photoshop and other popular design software hid details of expensive cancellation fees, according to a Justice Department lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: U.S. regulators sued Adobe on Monday over claims that the company made it difficult to cancel subscriptions to Photoshop and other software, an escalation by regulators in a crackdown against such practices.

headline: Emerging From Orban’s Shadow, a Former Ally Tries to Steal His Limelight
abstract: Peter Magyar, a conservative who was once a well-connected figure in the Fidesz party of Prime Minister Viktor Orban, has become an unexpected leader of the country’s opposition.
lead_paragraph: Railing against the right-wing government that until recently counted him as a trusted insider, Hungary’s most popular and improbable opposition leader stood on the back of a flatbed truck surrounded by cheering followers.

headline: 17 Unforgettable Looks at the Tony Awards
abstract: The event gave Broadway stars a chance to step out of their costumes and into outfits that showcased personal style.
lead_paragraph: Broadway’s biggest stars descended on Lincoln Center in Manhattan on Sunday for the Tony Awards, an annual celebration of all the people — casts, crews and creatives — who make live theater the spectacle that it is. Since many attendees spend most of the week in costumes, the Tonys was also a chance to get dressed up and showcase personal style.

headline: Philippines Says Sailor Was Injured in China Ship Collision
abstract: The clash is the latest in a string of confrontations that have increased tensions in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: A Philippine Navy sailor was “severely injured” after ships from China and the Philippines collided Monday morning near a disputed archipelago in the South China Sea, the Philippine military said on Tuesday, the latest in a series of maritime confrontations that have increased tensions in the vital waterway.

headline: A Battlefield Break to Cheer Ukraine’s Soccer Team in Euro 2024
abstract: Soldiers huddled in a bunker with soft drinks and chips to watch Ukraine face Romania, only to suffer heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: They had won one battle, and then sat to watch a battle of a different kind. Eight Ukrainian National Guard soldiers who had helped stall a Russian offensive in the northern Kharkiv region of Ukraine took the afternoon off on Monday to watch the men’s national soccer team play its first game of the European Championship.

headline: Effective Altruism Is Flawed. But What’s the Alternative?
abstract: The movement can’t answer our deepest moral questions, but it still has wisdom to offer.
lead_paragraph: You don’t hear so much about effective altruism now that one of its most famous exponents, Sam Bankman-Fried, was found guilty of stealing $8 billion from customers of his cryptocurrency exchange. (This spring, at age 32, he was sentenced to 25 years in prison.)

headline: Democrats See Glimmers of Hope in Florida. Are They Seeing Things?
abstract: They are veering from cautious optimism to complete pessimism about their long odds this year, with two liberal-leaning state ballot measures having the potential to lift turnout.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Ron DeSantis remade Florida into the red-hot center of the Republican universe, transforming the state into a bastion of power for their party.

headline: William H. Donaldson, Wall St. Lion Who Led the S.E.C., Dies at 93
abstract: He co-founded D.L.J., the first securities firm to offer shares to the public. As S.E.C. chairman, he pressed for a stronger watchdog role after a series of accounting scandals.
lead_paragraph: William H. Donaldson, who made an early fortune as a co-founder of the innovative securities firm Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and later pushed for tighter financial regulation as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom accounting scandals, died on Wednesday at his home in Westchester County, N.Y. He was 93.

headline: What to Know About This Week’s Heat Wave in New York
abstract: Temperatures are expected to climb into the high 90s in New York City this week. Cooling centers will open on Tuesday.

headline: Man Accused in Plot to Assassinate Sikh Separatist Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Prosecutors say that Nikhil Gupta, at the behest of an Indian government official, tried to engage a hit man to kill an American citizen who is a Sikh separatist.
lead_paragraph: An Indian man pleaded not guilty on Monday to charges of orchestrating a failed assassination plot against a Sikh separatist in New York, a plan that prosecutors say he devised on behalf of an unnamed official in India’s government.

headline: Biden Administration’s New Title IX Rules Are Blocked in Six More States
abstract: Conservative groups and Republican attorneys general have argued that the protections for transgender students come at the expense of others’ privacy and conflicts with a number of state laws.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday blocked the Biden administration’s new Title IX regulations in six more states as Republicans and conservative groups try to overturn a policy that expanded protections for L.G.B.T.Q. students.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Netanyahu Disbands His War Cabinet
abstract: Also, President Vladimir Putin’s state visit to North Korea.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, dissolved his war cabinet. The move was widely expected after two key members resigned.

headline: School’s Out. Time for a Social Media Reset.
abstract: The surgeon general wants more restrictions on social media to protect children’s health. Here’s how to help your kids cut down on screen time this summer.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. surgeon general, Dr. Vivek Murthy, announced on Monday that he would push for a warning label on social media sites that says the platforms can harm the mental health of young people.

headline: Dozens of Groups Push FEMA to Recognize Extreme Heat as a ‘Major Disaster’
abstract: The labor and environmental groups are pushing the change so relief funds can be used in more situations.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of environmental, labor and health care groups banded together on Monday to file a petition to push the Federal Emergency Management Agency to declare extreme heat and wildfire smoke as “major disasters,” like floods and tornadoes.

headline: The Washington Post Delves Into a Difficult Story: Itself
abstract: The newspaper has been reeling from successive revelations about Robert Winnett, its incoming editor, and Will Lewis, its chief executive.
lead_paragraph: The backyard goodbye party for Sally Buzbee, the recently departed executive editor of The Washington Post, was beginning to break up on Sunday evening when the newspaper published a critical investigation into her permanent successor.

headline: The A.I. Influencer Ads Are Coming
abstract: Look closely. Is that a real person?
lead_paragraph: If you are scrolling through TikTok and see an ad, it is likely that the person trying to sell you something in that ad is a real human being. In the near future, that might not be the case.

headline: An Early Heat Wave Is Sweeping the Country
abstract: Also, the Surgeon General called for warning labels on social media. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: The official start of summer is still days away, but the Midwest today was already enveloped in extreme levels of heat and humidity that could last throughout much of the week. The heat index — a measure of how the temperature feels — hit 102 degrees in Cincinnati.

headline: Chicago Braces for First Heat Wave of 2024
abstract: The excessive heat heading across the country this week is expected to be a dangerous weather system days before summer officially begins, forecasters said.
lead_paragraph: The excessive heat heading across the country this week is expected to be a dangerous weather system days before summer officially begins, forecasters said.

headline: Pressure Grows on Giuliani Over Incomplete Bankruptcy Filings
abstract: Creditors, the judge and a Justice Department official signaled that they were running out of patience with the former New York mayor’s accounts of his financial condition.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani’s creditors and the judge overseeing his bankruptcy case aired their frustrations with him in court on Monday after months in which he has provided incomplete information about his finances, missed filing deadlines or failed to have his lawyers respond at all.

headline: Tell Us: How Are You Feeling About the Presidential Debate?
abstract: Share your thoughts with the On Politics newsletter.
lead_paragraph: The first presidential debate of the general election is set for next Thursday, June 27 — a summertime showdown with rare potential to shake up the race for the White House.

headline: Juneteenth Weekend in Brooklyn? It’s an Easy Call.
abstract: Fort Greene Park is the move, just as it has been since 2020. The Lay Out, a series of summer gatherings intended “to center Black joy,” returned on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny Sunday afternoon at Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, just days before Juneteenth, large crowds of people were lounging on brightly colored picnic blankets and under tents atop the hill, making them hard to miss.

headline: Israeli Protesters Mass in Jerusalem to Call for Elections
abstract: The protesters demanded an end to the war and the release of hostages from Gaza, and also called for elections that many hoped would oust Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of Israelis took to the streets of Jerusalem on Monday to call for elections and the immediate return of hostages held in Gaza in a demonstration that followed Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s recent decision to dissolve his war cabinet.

headline: The Trump Rallying Cry That’s Also a Math Problem
abstract: His supporters can’t quite agree on whether to call him the 45th president or the 47th president.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump and his supporters can’t quite seem to agree: Should he be labeled the 45th president, the 47th president or both?

headline: Tony Awards’ Viewership Slips Lower
abstract: Sunday’s show had the second-lowest viewership for a Tonys telecast since records have been kept.
lead_paragraph: Sunday’s broadcast of the Tony Awards averaged 3.5 million viewers, a decline of about 15 percent from last year, according to preliminary ratings data from Nielsen.

headline: Man Charged as Lookout in Whitey Bulger Killing Admits to Lying to F.B.I.
abstract: Sean McKinnon, accused of conspiring to murder the aging mobster in prison, pleaded guilty to making false statements to investigators and was sentenced to time served.
lead_paragraph: One of three inmates charged in the death of James (Whitey) Bulger, the Boston underworld figure who was fatally bludgeoned within hours of his being transferred to a prison in West Virginia, pleaded guilty on Monday to a charge of lying to federal agents.

headline: Tropical Storm Alberto Could Bring 10 Inches of Rain to Texas Coast
abstract: The first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season could dump more than a foot of rain on parts of Texas and Mexico.
lead_paragraph: A rainstorm off the coast of Mexico became Tropical Storm Alberto on Wednesday, the first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season.

headline: George R. Nethercutt Jr., Who Ousted a House Speaker, Dies at 79
abstract: He defeated Thomas S. Foley of Washington State in the 1994 Republican midterm sweep. It was the first time since the Civil War-era that voters rejected a House speaker.
lead_paragraph: George R. Nethercutt Jr., who as a first-time candidate for Congress in 1994 defeated Thomas S. Foley of Washington State, making Mr. Foley the first House speaker to be ousted by voters since the Civil War era, died on Friday in Colorado. He was 79.

headline: Why the Covenant School Shooter’s Writings Have Not Yet Been Released
abstract: A Nashville judge indicated on Monday that she would soon rule on whether the writings left by the Nashville school shooter could be made public.
lead_paragraph: A Nashville judge said on Monday that she would soon rule on whether writings left by the assailant who killed six people at a private Christian school last year could be released.

headline: Judge Blocks Iowa’s Attempt to Enforce Its Own Immigration Law
abstract: The Justice Department sued the state over the Republican-backed law, which creates state-level criminal penalties for some unauthorized immigrants.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Monday temporarily blocked Iowa from enforcing its own immigration law, which makes it a state crime to enter Iowa after being deported or denied entry into the United States.

headline: U.S. Treasury Imposes New Sanctions to Cut Off Weapons to Houthis in Yemen
abstract: The Iranian-backed militia has in recent months launched dozens of attacks in the Red Sea, a crucial shipping route.
lead_paragraph: The United States imposed new sanctions on Monday aimed at cutting off weapons, supplies and funding to the Iranian-backed Houthis, who control much of Yemen and have been striking commercial ships in the Red Sea to show support for Palestinians in Gaza.

headline: Read the Federal Judge’s Ruling
abstract: A federal judge temporarily blocked Iowa from enforcing a new law that makes it a state crime for someone to enter Iowa after being deported or denied entry into the United States.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge temporarily blocked Iowa from enforcing a new law that makes it a state crime for someone to enter Iowa after being deported or denied entry into the United States.

headline: Israel Pauses Daytime Offensive in Part of Gaza, Raising Hopes for More Aid
abstract: The new policy, addressing concerns that combat made aid delivery too dangerous, took hold as an increasingly isolated Benjamin Netanyahu dissolved his war cabinet.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Monday that it had paused operations during daylight hours in parts of the southern Gaza Strip, as a new policy announced a day earlier appeared to take hold, along with cautious hopes that it would allow more food and other goods to reach desperate civilians.

headline: Chicago Mayor Orders Task Force on Reparations for Black Residents
abstract: Once the panel is established, it will have about a year to determine what reparations should look like in the city.
lead_paragraph: The mayor of Chicago signed an executive order on Monday to establish a task force that will make recommendations for reparations to address policies that have harmed Black residents over the decades.

headline: But It’s Only June: An Early Blast of Heat Grips Much of the U.S.
abstract: Heat overwhelmed cities across the Midwest and was headed to the Northeast. High temperatures are expected to linger for days.
lead_paragraph: Larry White was thrown a little off-kilter by the soupy, 93-degree temperature in Chicago on Monday morning. It’s only mid-June, he said with annoyance, and until this week he barely needed the air-conditioning in his high-rise apartment on the city’s North Side. When he stopped at McDonald’s, he ordered a large hot coffee out of habit.

headline: In Indiana, the MAGA Revolution Eats Its Own
abstract: A Christian nationalist upset causes Republican angst.
lead_paragraph: The Indiana governor’s race should not, under normal circumstances, be remotely competitive. In 2020, Donald Trump won the state by 16 percentage points, and the current governor, Eric Holcomb, a Republican, won by more than 20. All the state’s leading officials are Republicans, and the party has supermajorities in both legislative chambers.

headline: Record Number of NATO Allies Hit Military Spending Targets
abstract: President Biden and the NATO secretary general sought to present a robust and united front against Russia as the alliance prepares for its annual meeting next month.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and the NATO secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg, announced on Monday that a record number of allies were meeting their military spending commitments as the two leaders sought to present a robust and unwavering response to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

headline: More Cities Feel Strain as Migrants Move In Seeking Better Prospects
abstract: After aid runs out elsewhere, some migrants relocate to places like Salt Lake City, where they find help but hurdles, too. “Consider another state,” says a flier distributed by Utah.
lead_paragraph: The bright orange fliers from the State of Utah were blunt.

headline: War Crimes Hearing Gives Public Virtual Look Inside a Secret C.I.A. Prison
abstract: Years after the agency’s “black site” program was shut down, details are slowly emerging during trials at Guantánamo Bay.
lead_paragraph: The public on Monday got its first view of a C.I.A. “black site,” including a windowless, closet-size cell where a former Qaeda commander was held during what he described as the most humiliating experience of his time in U.S. custody.

headline: Angela Bofill, R&B Hitmaker With a Silky Voice, Dies at 70
abstract: Starting in the late 1970s, she scored multiple hit singles, including “This Time I’ll Be Sweeter” and “I Try,” but a pair of strokes in the 2000s ended her career.
lead_paragraph: Angela Bofill, a New York-bred singer whose sultry alto propelled a string of R&B hits in the late 1970s and early ’80s before strokes derailed her career in the 2000s, died on Thursday in Vallejo, Calif. She was 70.

headline: Judge Orders Rail Operator to Pay $400 Million to Tribe for Trespassing
abstract: BNSF Railway broke its agreement with the Swinomish Indian Tribal Community when it ran hundreds of train cars a week containing crude oil through the tribe’s land in Washington State, according to a federal judge.
lead_paragraph: A judge has ordered a railway company to pay nearly $400 million for trespassing on Native American land by far exceeding the number of train cars carrying crude oil that it was allowed to run through a tribe’s land, according to documents filed Monday in federal court in Washington State.

headline: Exxon Suit Over Activist Investor’s Climate Proposal Is Dismissed
abstract: A federal judge ruled that the case was moot after the investor, Arjuna Capital, withdrew the proposal with a promise not to try again.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Texas on Monday dismissed a lawsuit that Exxon Mobil had filed against an activist investor, Arjuna Capital, over a shareholder proposal that called for cuts in the oil giant’s greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Lopsided Contest
abstract: Aaron M. Rosenberg compares and contrasts.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: After Delay, Top Democrats in Congress Sign Off on Sale of F-15 Jets to Israel
abstract: Senior Democrats who had taken the unusual step of holding out relented to pressure from the Biden administration and allowed a multibillion-dollar sale of weapons to move ahead.
lead_paragraph: A Biden administration plan to sell $18 billion worth of F-15 fighter jets to Israel is moving forward after two top Democratic holdouts in Congress signed off on the deal, according to multiple people familiar with the sale.

headline: Biden to Give Legal Protections to Undocumented Spouses of U.S. Citizens
abstract: Undocumented spouses of American citizens will be shielded from deportation, provided work permits and given a pathway to citizenship, according to officials briefed on the plan.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday will announce sweeping new protections for hundreds of thousands of immigrants who have been living in the United States illegally for years but are married to American citizens, officials familiar with the plan said.

headline: U.S.D.A. Suspends Avocado Inspections in Mexico, Citing Security Concerns
abstract: The move, prompted by fears for agency workers’ safety, could eventually affect U.S. avocado supplies if the inspections are not resumed.
lead_paragraph: Security concerns for agency workers have led the United States Agriculture Department to suspend its inspections of avocados and mangos imported from Mexico “until further notice,” the U.S.D.A. said on Monday.

headline: Corrections: June 18, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 18, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about a review of New York State’s handling of the coronavirus pandemic under former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo misattributed a statement responding to a state audit of Mr. Cuomo’s performance during the crisis. The statement was from Mr. Cuomo’s spokesman, Richard Azzopardi, not Mr. Cuomo himself. The article also referred incorrectly to the source of a requirement that nursing homes accept Covid-19 patients from hospitals. It was a Health Department directive, not an executive order by Mr. Cuomo.

headline: A Korean Secret to Keeping Friendships Strong: Savings Groups
abstract: In South Korea, it’s common for friends to form what are known as gyemoim to save for vacations, meals and other social activities.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Jina Kim and two of her friends splurged on a two-night stay at the Ananti at Busan Cove, a luxury resort in Busan, South Korea.

headline: Why These Chinese Working Mothers Don’t Want More Babies
abstract: We spoke to three women who have rejected the government’s drive for bigger families and asked them to document their daily lives as they juggle home and the workplace.
lead_paragraph: We spoke to three women who have rejected the government’s drive for bigger families and asked them to document their daily lives as they juggle home and the workplace.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Israel’s prime minister dissolved his war cabinet.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, dissolved his war cabinet. The move was widely expected after two key members, Benny Gantz and Gadi Eisenkot, resigned last week over disagreements about the direction of the fighting in Gaza.

headline: An Israeli Hostage’s Parent: This Is Not the Holocaust
abstract: Invoking Nazis and pogroms in discussing the Hamas attacks is wrong and offensive and helps the Israeli government avoid responsibility for its failures.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 7, Hamas terrorists invaded southern Israel, murdered approximately 1,200 people and abducted more than 240 others. One of those kidnapped was my 35-year-old son, Sagui, who lived on Nir Oz, the kibbutz I’ve called home for most of my adult life and which was destroyed during the attack. Sagui is among the 120 hostages still held by Hamas.

headline: Secret Service Agent Robbed at Gunpoint on Night of Biden’s L.A. Gala
abstract: The agent’s bag was stolen on Saturday night in a residential community in Southern California, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A United States Secret Service agent was robbed at gunpoint in Southern California over the weekend, on the same night that President Joe Biden was in Los Angeles for a re-election fund-raiser, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: More Doctors Walk Off the Job in South Korea
abstract: Physicians across the country staged a one-day strike, the latest escalation in a months-old protest against the government’s plan to train more doctors.
lead_paragraph: Doctors at medical facilities across South Korea walked off the job in a one-day strike on Tuesday, dramatically if briefly expanding a months-old protest against the government’s health care policies that began when residents and interns at major hospitals stopped working in February.

headline: Word of the Day: gregarious
abstract: This word has appeared in 66 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word gregarious has appeared in 66 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 3 in “How a Snake Uses Its Sense of Smell” by Asher Elbein:

headline: Doctors Test the Limits of What Obesity Drugs Can Fix
abstract: “Obesity first” doctors say they start with one medication, to treat obesity, and often find other chronic diseases, like rheumatoid arthritis, simply vanish.
lead_paragraph: Lesa Walton suffered for years with rheumatoid arthritis. “It was awful,” said Ms. Walton, 57, who lives in Wenatchee, Wash. “I kept getting sicker and sicker.”

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: As Misconduct Complaints Rise in N.Y.C. Schools, Investigations Decline
abstract: Budget constraints and staff shortages reduced capacity at the agency that investigates criminal behavior in public schools, according to the City Council.
lead_paragraph: The New York City office responsible for investigating complaints about sexual misconduct, corruption and other potential wrongdoing in public schools has lost staff even as it faces a record spike in complaints, according to a new City Council report.

headline: The Gun Lobby’s Hidden Hand in the 2nd Amendment Battle
abstract: Case after case challenging gun restrictions cites the same Georgetown professor. His seemingly independent work has undisclosed ties to pro-gun interests.
lead_paragraph: In the battle to dismantle gun restrictions, raging in America’s courts even as mass shootings become commonplace, one name keeps turning up in the legal briefs and judges’ rulings: William English, Ph.D.

headline: Late Night Latches Onto Donald Trump’s ‘Johnson’ Mix-Up
abstract: “The sad thing is under MAGA law, his name is now Ronny Johnson,” Jon Stewart said after Trump referred to his former doctor, Ronny Jackson, by the wrong name.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Thaksin, Former Thai Premier, Indicted on Charges of Insulting Monarchy
abstract: The case against Thaksin Shinawatra was a reminder that the levers of power in Thailand remain firmly in the hands of the royalist-military establishment.
lead_paragraph: Thaksin Shinawatra, a former prime minister of Thailand who is also a powerful behind-the-scenes player in the current government, was indicted on Tuesday on a criminal charge of insulting the monarchy, ushering in a period of uncertainty that could plunge the country into a political crisis.

headline: Toyota Chairman, Re-elected by Investors, Defends His Hands-On Role
abstract: Akio Toyoda, who stepped down as chief executive last year, had been criticized by some shareholders for continuing to dominate decision making at the automaker.
lead_paragraph: Toyota Motor’s longtime leader, Akio Toyoda, defended his continued deep involvement in the company’s operations on Tuesday, responding to calls by some big investors that he step back after having resigned as chief executive more than a year ago.

headline: Thailand’s Legislature Approves Same-Sex Marriage
abstract: The bill, which needs the king’s endorsement to become law, underscores Thailand’s status as a relative haven in Asia for L.G.B.T.Q. people.
lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Thailand voted on Tuesday to approve a marriage equality bill, a move that puts the country on a clear path to becoming the first in Southeast Asia to legalize same-sex marriage.

headline: North Korea Has Lost ‘Many’ Troops to Mines in DMZ, South Says
abstract: North Korean soldiers have been sent into the mine-strewn buffer zone to do construction work since November, the South Korean military said on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: A number of North Korean soldiers have been killed or injured by land mines in the Demilitarized Zone that divides the Koreas since late last year, when the North began sending them into the buffer zone to do construction work, the South Korean military said on Tuesday.

headline: Deadly Landslides and Floods Hit Southern China
abstract: Chinese state media footage showed landslides that tore through mountain roads as heavy rains washed away a bridge and flooded villages.
lead_paragraph: Chinese state media footage showed landslides that tore through mountain roads as heavy rains washed away a bridge and flooded villages.

headline: Contractions
abstract: In Memphis, a doctor and a volunteer driver contemplate the discontinuation of abortion services at a women’s health clinic two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: In Memphis, a doctor and a volunteer driver contemplate the discontinuation of abortion services at a women’s health clinic two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.

headline: Biking Through Southern France, and History
abstract: The Canal du Midi traverses the Occitanie region and gives cyclists of all skill levels access to parts of France that are rich in lore, yet sometimes passed over by visitors.
lead_paragraph: The Canal du Midi, entirely hand-dug and hailed as an engineering marvel on completion in 1681, offers a refreshing alternate take on French travel: a bikeable path through the towns and landscapes of the country’s south. Traversing Occitanie, the canal gives cyclists of all skill levels access to parts of France that are rich in history, yet sometimes passed over by visitors with (only) Paris on their mind.

headline: How Lesbians Found One Another, From the Softball Field to the Sex-Toy Shop
abstract: In “A Place of Our Own,” June Thomas considers “six spaces that shaped queer women’s culture.”
lead_paragraph: June Thomas’s ability to resurrect the past in “A Place of Our Own: Six Spaces That Shaped Queer Women’s Culture” is a testament to her meticulous research. But it’s her voice — charming, irreverent, tender — that makes the journey through lesbian history so worthwhile.

headline: Tennessee Abortion Clinic Workers Speak Out About the State’s Near-Total Ban
abstract: In Memphis, a doctor and a volunteer driver contemplate the discontinuation of abortion services at a women’s health clinic two years after the overturning of Roe v. Wade.
lead_paragraph: I remember the hollowing sensation I felt on June 24, 2022, the day that the Supreme Court deemed that abortion was not a protected right under the U.S. Constitution. Everyone — on both sides of this debate — knew that women’s lives across the country were going to be drastically transformed. Since then, a lot of attention has been paid to the most heart-wrenching cases, but this decision affects all women’s bodily autonomy across the country.

headline: The Surprising Link Between Your Sense of Smell and Brain Health
abstract: Experts say a loss of smell can negatively impact mental health. But training your nose can fight off the decline.
lead_paragraph: Your grandma’s brownies, the scent of rain on a pine forest, a whiff of cardamom — smells can be powerful time machines, unlocking memories almost like magic and transporting you to specific moments more vividly than vision or hearing.

headline: A Hot, Fraught Cape Cod Family Drama
abstract: In her new novel, “Sandwich,” Catherine Newman explores the aches and joys of midlife via one family’s summer week at the beach.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally a writer comes along who seems able to turn every domestic triumph and tear, every dinner concocted, co-sleep endured and I.P.A. swallowed (or not) — in other words, the ordinary stuff of first-world life — into material rife with wit, humor and soul-bearing openness.

headline: Film Crew Veteran, Injured in an Accident, Faults Amazon for His Pain
abstract: The visual effects supervisor, hurt in one of three recent accidents on Amazon film sets, has sued, but the company says it is not to blame.
lead_paragraph: In March 2023, the producers of Amazon’s holiday movie “Candy Cane Lane,” starring Eddie Murphy, were determined to set a 15-foot fir aflame for a scene, according to court papers filed in a recent lawsuit.

headline: Anthony Fauci, a Hero to Some and a Villain to Others, Keeps His Cool
abstract: In a frank but measured memoir, “On Call,” the physician looks back at a career bookended by two public health crises: AIDS and Covid-19.
lead_paragraph: In his new memoir, Dr. Anthony Fauci bares all. After he’s unthinkingly opened a typewritten letter containing a mysterious white powder that could be anthrax (treatable with Cipro), ricin (almost certainly fatal in an Agatha Christie kind of way) or perhaps confectioner’s sugar, guys in hazmat suits arrive and order him to strip.

headline: Secrets of a Perfect Desk Lunch
abstract: The ideal meal will strike the right balance of protein, healthy fats and complex carbohydrates. Here’s how to make it happen.
lead_paragraph: Trying to make time for a nutritious lunch during the workday can feel like a losing battle.

headline: Hozier Was Never a One-Hit Wonder. But Now He Has a Second Smash.
abstract: He broke out in 2014 with “Take Me to Church.” Then listeners on TikTok found his passionate, dramatic songs and a new single made its way to No. 1.
lead_paragraph: A decade ago, the Irish singer-songwriter Andrew Hozier-Byrne, who performs as Hozier, scored a surprise global hit with his debut single, “Take Me to Church,” thanks in large part to its black-and-white music video depicting an intimate relationship between two gay men, one of whom is attacked by a masked mob. The soulful, octave-hopping track, written as a rebuke to the Catholic Church’s stance on homosexuality, established Hozier as a serious, socially conscious artist. It peaked at No. 2 on the Billboard Hot 100 and earned a Grammy nomination for song of the year.

headline: The Biggest Political Divide Is Not Left vs. Right
abstract: Yanna Krupnikov probes the motivations of Americans who avoid politics — but often vote.
lead_paragraph: The biggest divide in our politics isn’t between Democrats and Republicans, or even left and right. It’s between people who follow politics closely, and those who pay almost no attention to it. If you’re in the former camp — and if you’re reading this, you probably are — the latter camp can seem inscrutable. These people hardly ever look at political news. They hate discussing politics. But they do care about issues and candidates, and they often vote.

headline: How Did We Learn to Talk? We Can’t Say for Sure.
abstract: In “The Language Puzzle,” the archaeologist Steven Mithen asks exactly how our species started speaking.
lead_paragraph: If you stand on the rock of Edinburgh Castle on a clear day and look due north toward the Firth of Forth, you can make out the small island of Inchkeith, about three miles out to sea. It was to this island, in 1493, that James IV banished two infant children, with only a mute nurse for company, to be raised in silent isolation. The king hoped that, when the children came of age, this experiment would reveal the original, Edenic language of Adam and Eve, uncontaminated by modern chatter.

headline: Trump’s ‘Wartime Consigliere’ Now Faces Legal Peril of His Own
abstract: Boris Epshteyn routinely surfaces as a lesser character in Trump-related indictments. In a case in Arizona, he pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to nine felony charges.
lead_paragraph: Boris Epshteyn, who was arraigned Tuesday on election interference charges in Arizona, has played many roles for former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: What Can’t You Say These Days?
abstract: In “The Indispensable Right,” Jonathan Turley argues that the First Amendment has been deeply compromised from the start.
lead_paragraph: Conservative voices are being silenced. We know this because conservative voices are telling us so, insistently, on social media and cable news programs, in speeches by Supreme Court justices and on the grounds of the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse. Casual observation might suggest otherwise — as does the data — but it has become an article of faith on the right that conservative viewpoints are being systematically suppressed, even criminalized.

headline: Bob Eckstein Has the Perfect Museum for You
abstract: Is the Mob Museum on your list? The writer and illustrator sees his new guide to North America’s museums as a way to help families plan their summer vacations.
lead_paragraph: “When they first go to museums, the first two things people want to know is, where’s the gift shop and where’s the bathroom?” said the writer and illustrator Bob Eckstein, 61, whose new book, “Footnotes From the Most Fascinating Museums,” is an illustrated field guide to North America’s cultural and historical repositories.

headline: Biden’s Stimulus Juiced the Economy, but Its Political Effects Are Muddled
abstract: Some voters blame the American Rescue Plan for fueling price increases. But the growth it unleashed may be helping the president stay more popular than counterparts in Europe.
lead_paragraph: The $1.9 trillion economic stimulus package that President Biden signed shortly after taking office has become both an anchor and a buoy for his re-election campaign.

headline: ‘Outstanding: A Comedy Revolution’ Review: Beyond the Punchline
abstract: A new Netflix documentary showcases comedy as a source of queer liberation, featuring Margaret Cho, Tig Notaro, Joel Kim Booster and more.
lead_paragraph: The director Page Hurwitz examines comedy’s place in the L.G.B.T.Q. movement in the new Netflix documentary “Outstanding: A Comedy Revolution,” creating a rich, century-long timeline full of archival footage, behind-the-scenes glimpses and candid interviews with comedians. A standout subject is the 82-year-old trailblazer Robin Tyler, the first out lesbian on national TV.

headline: Writers, the Wretched of the Earth
abstract: In Munir Hachemi’s novel “Living Things,” four young men seek adventure for “literary capital” and find exploitation.
lead_paragraph: First published in Spanish in 2018, “Living Things” is the debut novel by Munir Hachemi, who, we are told in the author bio, started out selling his stories in Madrid bars and was eventually named one of Granta’s best young Spanish-language novelists. That impetuous, upstart spirit infuses this short and spunky tale about young, would-be literary men who hit the road in search of adventure but find bleakness and exploitation.

headline: It Could Soon Cost More to Take a Shower. Here’s Why.
abstract: The city has approved rent increases for tenants and has raised the rent for its own water board. In response, the board is charging property owners more for water.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out why it’s going to cost more to take a shower in New York — and to renew a lease on a rent-stabilized apartment. We’ll also get details on a prison sentence for the Brooklyn preacher known as the bling bishop.

headline: Grab a Matchbook From Your Favorite Spot and Thank Me Later
abstract: Collecting these small keepsakes can help keep the places you love alive.
lead_paragraph: When the legendary Jazz Standard club closed, in late 2020, I mourned the loss of yet another New York cultural institution. My favorite spots were shutting down one after another, sinking me and the city further into a collective depression. I texted the news to my parents; it was there, when my parents were in town,  that they introduced me to the Mingus Big Band and to the music of Joni Mitchell, whose songs I fell in love with after we saw a cover singer perform. I never considered that something might kill a venue that had been so central to my youth.

headline: Can You Retire if You Never Had a Job? NOFX Will Try.
abstract: The punk rock pioneers chose freedom — and chaos — over major labels. Pulling the plug while things are still working is one final act of rebellion.
lead_paragraph: “It’s like going to your own wake.”

headline: ‘Cats’ Returns, Ditching the Junkyard for Queer Ballroom
abstract: As part of a wave of reimagined Andrew Lloyd Webber musicals, a new revival of “Cats” unfolds as a ballroom competition.
lead_paragraph: Things seemed to change when the video came out.

headline: Review: In ‘Dark Noon,’ American History Is a Shoot-’Em-Up Western
abstract: A play from Denmark, with a South African cast, turns the heroic tropes of horse operas into the tools of tragedy at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The building boom in Dumbo, Brooklyn, may be waning, but onstage at St. Ann’s Warehouse it flourishes. There, the hard-working seven-person cast of “Dark Noon,” which opened on Monday, spends much of the production’s 105 minutes assembling the edifices of westward-creeping American civilization, from home to brothel to church to jail. By the end, the playing space, like the once pristine frontier, is so overbuilt you can see little else.

headline: Is It Storage or Art? If It’s Hard to Tell, You’re Doing It Right.
abstract: The best open storage adds personality to a room. Here’s how it’s done.
lead_paragraph: What to do when you have too much stuff and not enough storage space? Celebrate it. Storing some of that overflow out in the open can be a good solution when you’ve got a small space with few closets.

headline: What Donald Trump Learned From Don King
abstract: The decades-long friendship of two men who never especially changed.
lead_paragraph: For more than three decades, the boxing promoter Don King and Donald J. Trump have shared an enduring friendship and some defining surface similarities: an unmissable hairdo and a self-regarding gumption that became a kind of superpower, a trail of beleaguered creditors and an unswerving conviction that more is more.

headline: Biden Gives Legal Protections to Undocumented Spouses of U.S. Citizens
abstract: The new policy is one of the most significant actions to protect immigrants in years. It affects about 500,000 people who have been living in the United States for more than a decade.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday granted far-reaching new protections for hundreds of thousands of immigrants who have been living in the United States illegally for years but are married to American citizens.

headline: How the Teamsters and a Homegrown Union Plan to Take On Amazon
abstract: An affiliation agreement between the Amazon Labor Union and the 1.3 million-member Teamsters signals an escalation in challenging the online retailer.
lead_paragraph: After years of organizing Amazon workers and pressuring the company to bargain over wages and working conditions, two prominent unions are teaming up to challenge the online retailer.

headline: The System Isn’t Built for Jan. 6, and Neither Are We
abstract: It’s not as if anybody needs a trial to form an opinion about the events of that day.
lead_paragraph: There won’t be a trial anytime soon — or maybe ever — for Donald Trump on charges related to Jan. 6. No matter the Supreme Court presidential immunity decision, even if the court rules that a trial can proceed, there almost certainly won’t be enough time before the election. If Mr. Trump is elected, there might not be a trial at all.

headline: 57 Sandwiches That Define New York City
abstract: A portrait of the five boroughs between two slices of bread.
lead_paragraph: A portrait of the five boroughs between two slices of bread.

headline: On Juneteenth, Freedom Came With Strings Attached
abstract: The best way to think of the holiday is not as the moment Black people attained freedom but as a moment in the struggle to realize freedom.
lead_paragraph: Last week at a Juneteenth concert on the South Lawn of the White House, Vice President Kamala Harris said that on June 19, 1865, after Union troops arrived in Galveston, Texas, “The enslaved people of Texas learned they were free.” On that day, she said, “they claimed their freedom.”

headline: American Leaders Should Stop Debasing Themselves on Israel
abstract: You have to wonder if American “friends” of Israel have any clue about the nature of Israel’s government.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 4, 2022, just after the current far-right Israeli government coalition won election, I wrote a column with this headline: “The Israel We Knew Is Gone.” It was meant to be a warning flare about just how radical this coalition is. Many people disagreed. I believe events have proved them wrong — and the situation is now even worse: The Israel we knew is gone, and today’s Israel is in existential danger.

headline: A Heat Wave Is Coming: Here’s How Paramedics Are Preparing
abstract: Wet towels and body bags filled with ice water are being used to quickly cool victims, which is essential to saving lives.
lead_paragraph: A heat wave is bearing down on large parts of America, forcing emergency workers to prepare for what could be record-breaking numbers of people in heat distress.

headline: A Democratic Brawl in Virginia May Put a House Seat in Play
abstract: The Democratic contest in Virginia’s 10th House district will end what may be the ugliest fight of the 2024 primary season — and start an unexpected general election battle.
lead_paragraph: Virginia’s 10th Congressional District, in the suburbs of Washington, was never meant to be a linchpin in the battle for control of the House. But with the ugliest Democratic primary campaign of 2024 finally ending, national Democrats may be nervously watching as the results roll in on Tuesday night.

headline: Protests Erupt in Kenya Over Tax Hike Proposals
abstract: The government is trying to pass a finance bill in Parliament that would involve increasing taxes. Critics say it will raise the cost of living for Kenyans who are already struggling economically.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the protests in Kenya.

headline: ‘A Big Step Back’: In Ukraine, Concerns Mount Over Narrowing Press Freedoms
abstract: Journalists say they are subject to increasing restrictions and pressure from the government of President Volodymyr Zelensky, adding that the measures go beyond wartime security needs.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian reporter who revealed that a state news agency tried to bar interviews with opposition politicians said he received a draft notification the next day.

headline: Heavy Rains Lash Southern China, Killing at Least 9
abstract: Rains set off landslides and inundated villages in the south, forcing thousands to evacuate. In the north, residents sweltered through a drought.
lead_paragraph: Heavy rains battered southern China over the weekend and into Tuesday, setting off landslides and causing roads and homes to collapse as rivers overran their banks.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,096, June 19, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 374, June 19, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Novel Legal Strategy for Mass Shooting Victims’ Families
abstract: Families in Uvalde, Texas, have sued a video game, a gun maker and Instagram, claiming they helped to groom and equip the shooter.
lead_paragraph: As mass shootings plague the United States, victims’ families continue to search for accountability. To that end, a pair of lawsuits by the families of victims of the Uvalde school shooting will try a new tactic.

headline: U.S. Protections for Undocumented Spouses, and Putin’s North Korea Visit
abstract: Plus, trouble in the avocado supply.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: We Want to Know: What’s Your Favorite Sandwich in New York City?
abstract: The New York Times Food staff crisscrossed the city in search of its most noteworthy sandwiches and now we want to hear from readers.
lead_paragraph: This week, the Food team at The New York Times shared an in-depth look at “57 Sandwiches that Define New York City.” And while there are tons of fun details and a mixture of different sandwich styles throughout, there are always more great sandwiches to be enjoyed.

headline: President Biden’s Distrust Challenge
abstract: We explain how one set of voters may decide the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: The voters likely to decide the Biden-Trump rematch don’t participate in most elections. They are irregular voters who tend to skip primaries and midterm elections but do often turn out for the country’s highest-profile campaign — a presidential election.

headline: How to Make Thrilling Theater About Climate Change Negotiations
abstract: A new play from the writers of “The Jungle” dramatizes the 1997 Kyoto Protocol, a landmark climate agreement preceded by years of arguments over its wording.
lead_paragraph: When the playwrights Joe Murphy and Joe Robertson were looking for ideas for a new production, they stumbled upon a radio show about the negotiations that led to the 1997 Kyoto Protocol.

headline: Ian McKellen Is in ‘Good Spirits’ After Falling Off the Stage During a Play
abstract: The English actor was injured during a performance of “Player Kings,” and the show was abruptly canceled. He is expected to perform again on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: The actor Ian McKellen was hospitalized but expected to recover quickly after falling off the stage during a performance of “Player Kings” at a theater in the West End in London on Monday night, the producers of the play said.

headline: Israel and Hezbollah Play a Risky Tit-for-Tat, Leaving Region on Edge
abstract: A full-scale war could devastate both Israel and Lebanon, where the Hezbollah militia is a far better trained and equipped adversary than Hamas.
lead_paragraph: As the war has raged in Gaza, another battle has unfurled in parallel along Israel’s northern border with Lebanon — a risky game of tit-for-tat that has intensified in recent weeks, with a far stronger foe.

headline: Boeing’s Bumpy Ride Isn’t Over
abstract: Dave Calhoun, the embattled company’s C.E.O., heads to Capitol Hill amid new whistle-blower accusations and questions over succession.
lead_paragraph: Boeing’s boss, Dave Calhoun, will testify before a Senate panel on Tuesday, as yet another whistle-blower has come forward, alleging the planemaker was negligent in tracking hundreds of faulty parts.

headline: Boeing C.E.O. Apologizes for Quality and Safety Issues at Senate Hearing
abstract: Confronted by families of those killed on two flights, Dave Calhoun, Boeing’s chief executive, apologized for “the grief that we have caused.”
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Boeing’s chief executive, Dave Calhoun, took his seat, families who lost relatives in the 2018 and 2019 crashes of the company’s 737 Max 8 planes called out to him, demanding that he turn around and acknowledge them and the photos of their loved ones.

headline: Ralph Lauren Unveils the Team USA Olympic Uniforms
abstract: Navy blazers for the win.
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to dress to represent the United States?

headline: A Relic of Los Angeles’s Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Past Comes Down
abstract: The strange “no U-turn” signs along Griffith Park Boulevard in Silver Lake were erected in the 1990s to ward off gay men.
lead_paragraph: For many Angelenos, the road signs that have been posted in the Silver Lake neighborhood over the last two decades forbidding U-turns from midnight to 6 a.m. were just another example of the city’s seemingly arbitrary and extremely specific traffic regulations.

headline: The T-Shirt’s Message Is Simple: ‘Everyone Watches Women’s Sports.’
abstract: A black-and-white shirt by the brand Togethxr has become the unofficial uniform of a breakthrough moment for women’s basketball.
lead_paragraph: The black T-shirt spells it out in capital letters: “Everyone Watches Women’s Sports.”

headline: French Court Strikes Down Ban on Israeli Companies at Weapons Show
abstract: A court ruled that France’s order to bar Israeli exhibitors from the Eurosatory arms show was discriminatory, as the French government’s criticism over the war in Gaza mounts.
lead_paragraph: A court in Paris ruled on Tuesday that France’s decision to bar Israeli companies from one of the world’s largest weapons shows was discriminatory and ordered the ban to be rescinded.

headline: Anouk Aimée, Enigmatic Star of ‘A Man and a Woman,’ Dies at 92
abstract: The French actress had already made an impression in international film when she appeared in Claude Lelouch’s 1966 romance, a role that earned her an Oscar nomination.
lead_paragraph: Anouk Aimée, the French film actress who became an international sex symbol as the aloof, enigmatic and sensual star of Claude Lelouch’s 1966 romance “A Man and a Woman,” died on Tuesday at her home in Paris. She was 92.

headline: More Than 1,000 Birds Died One Night in Chicago. Will It Happen Again?
abstract: A mass of birds died in Chicago in October after striking one building, adding to the push for more protections in one of the most dangerous cities for avian migration.
lead_paragraph: One night in October, an enormous swirl of birds flew over Chicago, astounding those who had their binoculars trained on the flashes of yellow, white and brown speckling the sky above. It seemed like an incredible moment for birders, but the next day ended with nearly a thousand dead birds outside one building along Lake Michigan and even more scattered across the city’s streets.

headline: Hidden Under George Washington’s Home: 35 Glass Bottles of Cherries
abstract: Archaeologists discovered the glass bottles in the cellar during a restoration project.
lead_paragraph: There it was, in the cellar of Mount Vernon, a relic of the last decades of colonial America: the top of a glass bottle, standing vertically and holding some kind of liquid. The contents suggested the bottle was intact, unlike the fragments commonly found on the estate.

headline: Putin Arrives in North Korea as Ukraine War Redefines Ties With Kim
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin’s military needs have prompted the Kremlin to strengthen ties with the authoritarian government of Kim Jong-un, which is well stocked in munitions.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has arrived in North Korea, according to Russian state media, visiting for the first time in 24 years after vowing to bring ties with Pyongyang to new heights and jointly rebuff what he called the “global neocolonial dictatorship” of the United States.

headline: Rush-Hour Commute Disrupted for Many by Disabled Train at Penn Station
abstract: New Jersey Transit service into and out of the Midtown Manhattan transit hub was suspended and commuters were rerouted to buses and the PATH train. Amtrak reported 90-minute delays.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey Transit service into and out of New York’s Pennsylvania Station was suspended Tuesday morning for about an hour and all Amtrak trains passing through the station were delayed because of overhead wire issues and a disabled commuter train on the tracks, train officials said.

headline: Justin Timberlake Is Charged With Drunken Driving in Sag Harbor
abstract: The 43-year-old singer and actor told the police he had one martini after an officer said he saw him go through a stop sign and weave in a lane.
lead_paragraph: It was shortly after midnight on Tuesday when a Sag Harbor police officer noticed a gray 2025 BMW weave out of a lane and go through a stop sign.

headline: Nothing to Fear but Me
abstract: Being you can be a painful and scary thing. And that’s OK.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Elden Ring: Shadow of the Erdtree Review: Faith, Meet Futility
abstract: A new tier of knights, monsters and freaks often exceeds the most demanding late-game adversaries of Elden Ring. Belief in yourself will be stretched to its limit.
lead_paragraph: One of the first landmarks you’ll come across in Shadow of the Erdtree is a tall, brilliantly shining cross. Intersected at its peak by a thin crescent — most likely a representation of the Golden Order, the dark fantasy world’s ruling theocracy — it feels bluntly referential to saints and prophets and resurrections.

headline: Titan Disaster Forces Global Rethinking of Deep Sea Exploration
abstract: A year after the first deaths of divers who ventured into the ocean’s sunless depths, an industry wrestles with new challenges for piloted submersibles and robotic explorers.
lead_paragraph: When five men died on June 18, 2023, in the implosion of the Titan submersible during a dive to the Titanic’s resting place, the knowledge of Paul-Henri Nargeolet was lost too. It was Mr. Nargeolet’s 38th dive to the sunken liner. Known as Mr. Titanic, he helped retrieve thousands of artifacts that have been displayed in museums and at events around the world.

headline: Huey Lewis Musical to Close on Broadway as New Shows Struggle
abstract: “The Heart of Rock and Roll” is the first new Broadway musical to announce a closing plan following Sunday’s Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: “The Heart of Rock and Roll,” a new jukebox musical powered by the songs of Huey Lewis and the News, will close on Broadway on Sunday.

headline: Unlikely World Cup Victories Raise Cricket’s Profile in U.S.
abstract: Cricket faces notable obstacles before it can obtain widespread popularity in America, but its most passionate supporters feel positive about its future.
lead_paragraph: When Harmeet Singh left India in 2020, he was looking for a fresh start. His career as a cricket player had stagnated, and his dream of making the Indian national team — and playing in the World Cup, the sport’s biggest stage — was fading.

headline: Should Hundreds of Millions in Seized Assets Go to ISIS Victims?
abstract: The State and Justice Departments disagree about what to do with more than half a billion dollars after a French company pleaded guilty to aiding militants in war-torn Syria.
lead_paragraph: Biden administration officials are divided over what to do with $687 million in assets a French company forfeited after pleading guilty to aiding terrorist groups like the Islamic State, according to people familiar with internal deliberations.

headline: How to Stay Cool Indoors During the Heat Wave
abstract: With temperatures climbing this week, here’s how to be comfortable in your home — with or without air-conditioning.
lead_paragraph: Summer officially starts on Thursday, and this season is predicted to be hotter than normal — a heat wave across the country this week is expected to affect millions of Americans. In New York, the temperature is forecast to reach 96 degrees by Friday. On Monday, Chicago hit a record-breaking 97 degrees.

headline: How Biden’s New Immigration Policy Works
abstract: The new policy will give some 500,000 people a pathway to citizenship.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s new immigration policy protects some 500,000 people who are married to U.S. citizens from deportation and gives them a pathway to citizenship.

headline: Why All the Thighs?
abstract: Don’t worry, we’ve got plenty of excellent chicken breast recipes, too: honey garlic chicken, chicken piccata and green masala chicken, to name a few.
lead_paragraph: I’ve gotten a bunch of emails from readers lately asking why New York Times Cooking chicken recipes don’t often call for boneless, skinless breasts. “Why is it always chicken thighs? I don’t know anyone, except my sister, who prefers dark meat,” someone wrote, in a truly excellent email with a subject line that simply said “Again?”

headline: Why Longer Heat Waves Are So Dangerous
abstract: Researchers have found that longer-lasting heat waves can be deadlier and can pose unique health risks.
lead_paragraph: For tens of millions of Americans this week, summer is starting with a multiday blast of fierce heat. Temperatures in parts of the country are likely to be well into the 90s through the weekend. The National Weather Service has warned that the heat wave could be the longest one some places have experienced in decades.

headline: E.V. Maker Fisker Files for Bankruptcy as Cash Runs Short
abstract: The company became the latest electric vehicle start-up to fail to meet investors’ expectations after a high-profile public debut.
lead_paragraph: Fisker filed for bankruptcy protection late on Monday, the latest start-up in the electric vehicle industry to fall short after raising large amounts of money from investors with lofty expectations.

headline: Yellowstone Tourist Sentenced to Jail for ‘Thermal Trespass’
abstract: Viktor Pyshniuk, 21, was sentenced to a week in jail after a park employee saw him walk off a path near Steamboat Geyser, which can shoot hot water more than 300 feet in the air.
lead_paragraph: A Yellowstone National Park tourist who walked off a designated path and came within 15 to 20 feet of a steam vent belonging to the world’s tallest active geyser was sentenced this month to seven days in jail and banned from the park for two years, the Justice Department said.

headline: Campania Is the Next Move for the Man Behind Rezdôra
abstract: Stefano Secchi is opening Massara in the Flatiron district, ice creams inspired by appetizing and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: Striding through his restaurant’s beautifully paved dining room, Stefano Secchi marveled at the space. His lanky wingspan might reach wall to wall at Rezdôra, where he made his name, but not here where a bar and an open kitchen with a wood-fueled pizza oven frame the main floor tables. Upstairs there’s a larger dining room. He’s putting Campania, where he spent time in his youth, on the plate with seafood; stews; grilled meats, including goat; and pasta, both fresh and dried. “Food in 2024 has to be regional,” he said. The Neapolitan pizzettes depend on sourdough starter he’s nurtured for years, and Italian wines go no further north than Tuscany.

headline: You Talkin’ Like Him? A Convention Lets De Niro Fans Get In on the Act.
abstract: Participants at De Niro Con in Tribeca could talk like Travis Bickle, shadowbox like Jake LaMotta or get a tattoo like Max Cady. Yes, a real tattoo.
lead_paragraph: Amy Cakes has dozens of tattoos, but the one she got on Friday would stand out simply because the ink was applied amid a celebration of all things Robert De Niro.

headline: Neil Goldschmidt, Portland Mayor Who Abused Teenager, Dies at 83
abstract: While he was reviving Portland, Ore., as a vibrant, pedestrian-friendly city, he was also sexually abusing a teenage girl over three years, he later admitted.
lead_paragraph: Neil Goldschmidt, a transformative figure in Oregon politics who as mayor of Portland in the 1970s reshaped the city into a vibrant, progressive, pedestrian-friendly urban area — a period when he was sexually abusing a teenage girl, he later admitted — died on Wednesday at his home in Portland. He was 83.

headline: Planning the Resistance to Trump
abstract: Readers discuss preparations by progressive activists and others. Also: A nuclear threat; geoengineering; Gaza protests in Belgium; a tribe’s whale hunt.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Sisters Who Turned a Sondheim Flop Into a Tony Winner
abstract: Maria and Sonia Friedman discussed their long history with “Merrily We Roll Along,” after a bittersweet Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: The Friedman sisters have been making art together since they were little girls. Their London childhood was chaotic — they were often left to their own devices — but the family’s four children found solace in storytelling.

headline: Trump’s Legal Advisers Plead Not Guilty in Arizona Election Case
abstract: Boris Epshteyn, who oversees Donald J. Trump’s legal team, was arraigned on nine felony charges on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Boris Epshteyn, who oversees Donald J. Trump’s sprawling legal team, pleaded not guilty to nine felony charges on Tuesday in Arizona’s election interference case, highlighting the legal risks for the advisers and allies who attempted to keep Mr. Trump in power after he lost the 2020 presidential election.

headline: Colorado L.G.B.T.Q. Club Shooter Pleads Guilty to Federal Hate Crimes
abstract: The assailant in the 2022 attack that killed five people will avoid the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: The shooter convicted of killing five people at a Colorado Springs L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub in 2022 pleaded guilty on Tuesday to federal hate crimes and was sentenced to 55 life terms in prison on those charges.

headline: Glitz and Grimness Cross Paths on London’s ‘Caledonian Road’
abstract: Andrew O’Hagan’s ambitious state-of-England novel finds a cosseted academic facing up to the hard lives and ethical shortcuts he’d prefer to ignore.
lead_paragraph: London’s Caledonian Road runs through the borough of Islington, past Pentonville Prison, postwar public housing estates and rows and rows of highly coveted Georgian terraces. Prices can reach multiple millions for houses in leafy squares, while poorer residents can spend years on waiting lists for council flats. If you want to write about inequality in London — or in the United Kingdom — “the Cally,” to locals, is a good place to start.

headline: Garlicky Chicken Sandwiches With Red Cabbage Slaw, Gorgeous and Glossy Strawberry Pretzel Bars
abstract: Bold and bright recipes for a Juneteenth feast.
lead_paragraph: Millie Peartree — the brilliant mind behind these beloved recipes for rasta pasta, jerk chicken meatballs and brown-butter chocolate chip cookies — has shared with us five new recipes for a Juneteenth feast. They’re bold and bright, in both color and flavor: garlicky chicken sandwiches with red cabbage slaw; robust roasted shrimp jambalaya; and a flushed, fiery strawberry-ginger limeade.

headline: On Immigration, Biden Attempts to Replicate a Powerful Obama Moment
abstract: The president’s announcement to expand legal protections for some undocumented spouses of American citizens evoked Barack Obama’s move to help young immigrants in 2012.
lead_paragraph: In the summer before a tough re-election contest in 2012, President Barack Obama was losing support from Latino voters who called him “deporter in chief.” Then he signed a sweeping executive order to shield hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants from deportation.

headline: U.S. Pier for Gaza Aid Is Failing, and Could Be Dismantled Early
abstract: Officials hope a looming deadline will pressure Israel to open more land routes into the territory, which is facing extreme levels of hunger.
