lead_paragraph: The $230 million temporary pier that the U.S. military built on short notice to rush humanitarian aid to Gaza has largely failed in its mission, aid organizations say, and will probably end operations weeks earlier than originally expected.

headline: Stop-and-Shop the Runways
abstract: If you’re just looking (but not buying), there’s pleasure in creating an imaginary wardrobe from the men’s wear catwalks at Gucci, Fendi, JW Anderson, Ralph Lauren and Tod’s.
lead_paragraph: Wanting what we do not need (and what, in a biblical sense, is not ours) is at the core of luxury-goods consumption. And want, more than anything more evolved or cerebral, was the emotion stimulated by the men’s wear shows in Milan this season. Does the world require a linen field jacket with Breton stripes or a navy blazer made from terry cloth piped in white or a safari jacket styled as evening wear and worn with Gurkha trousers and a slightly ludicrous shawl collar waistcoat? It does not.

headline: The Fiery Sounds of the Monterey International Pop Festival
abstract: Revisiting the event’s memorable set list, 57 years later.
lead_paragraph: Fifty-seven years ago today, the Monterey International Pop Festival — the three-day event that arguably invented the modern music festival — concluded in a blaze of glory. That Sunday boasted quite a bill: Ravi Shankar mesmerized the crowd with a set of ragas that lasted more than three hours. The Who obliterated the calm with a proto-punk set which ended when Pete Townshend smashed his guitar. Jimi Hendrix attempted a one-up by lighting his on fire. The headliners the Mamas & the Papas had the unenviable task of following all that.

headline: Israel’s Daily Combat Pause in Part of Gaza: How Is It Working?
abstract: The new practice is supposed to make it easier and safer to distribute desperately needed aid around Gaza. Aid groups are hopeful, but say more is needed.
lead_paragraph: Israel has said that the partial daily suspension of its military activity in a part of southern Gaza, which began over the weekend, is aimed at making it safer for humanitarian groups to deliver aid in the territory.

headline: U.S. Debt on Pace to Top $56 Trillion Over Next 10 Years
abstract: Congressional Budget Office projections released on Tuesday show a grim fiscal backdrop ahead of tax and debt limit fights.
lead_paragraph: The United States is on a pace to add trillions of dollars to its national debt over the next decade, borrowing money more quickly than previously expected, at a time when big legislative fights loom over taxes and spending.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Yanna Krupnikov
abstract: The June 18, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Yanna Krupnikov. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Two Wildfires in New Mexico Burn Out of Control and Force Evacuations
abstract: Thousands were evacuated from the village of Ruidoso and nearby areas. About 1,400 buildings had been destroyed by Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Two wildfires in Southern New Mexico that destroyed 1,400 structures, consumed over 20,000 acres and forced the evacuations of thousands of people were still burning out of control on Tuesday night as firefighters struggled to contain them, the authorities said.

headline: Biden Courts Some Liberal Love on Immigration
abstract: For thousands of families, Biden’s plan will be a game-changer.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after President Biden abruptly cracked down on asylum seekers at the southern border — angering some progressives — he announced a new program on Tuesday to protect from deportation the undocumented spouses and stepchildren of American citizens.

headline: Bob Schul, a Singular U.S. Olympian in the 5,000-Meter Race, Dies at 86
abstract: His remarkable sprint in the final yards on a muddy track in the 1964 Games in Tokyo made him the only American ever to win the gold medal in that event.
lead_paragraph: Growing up on an Ohio farm, Bob Schul battled asthma and allergies. But he loved to run.

headline: A Mysterious Monolith Appears Near Las Vegas. Why? It’s Anyone’s Guess.
abstract: A volunteer search-and-rescue organization reported finding the monolith over the weekend near the Gass Peak trail, which is north of Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: It looks like something out of a sci-fi movie. A tall, vertical column mirroring everything around it, with no explanation of its purpose and origin.

headline: Virginia Exonerates Man Who Spent 45 Years in Prison for Death of 3-Year-Old
abstract: On Tuesday, a Virginia appeals court fully absolved Marvin Grimm Jr. of the 1975 crime, saying that new evidence had dismantled the state’s original case against him.
lead_paragraph: On a Saturday afternoon in 1975, a 3-year-old boy wandered into the woods behind the apartment complex where he lived in Richmond, Va.

headline: Sarah Mandel, Therapist Who Told Her ‘Trauma Narrative,’ Dies at 42
abstract: She received a diagnosis of Stage 4 breast cancer late in her second pregnancy and described her experience in a book, “Little Earthquakes: A Memoir.”
lead_paragraph: On June 1, a short, emotional video popped up on TikTok with news about Sarah Mandel, a 42-year-old psychologist, wife and mother of two young daughters.

headline: There Is No Magical Way to Overcome Fear
abstract: After being paralyzed on the set of a ‘Harry Potter’ movie, I rediscovered what fearlessness really meant.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: The Celtics Have 18 Championships. The Lakers? 17. (And Maybe One More.)
abstract: The Celtics won their record-breaking 18th championship this week, breaking a tie with the Los Angeles Lakers. But what if they’re still tied?
lead_paragraph: The Duck Boats are being gassed up for the Boston Celtics championship parade. The clam chowders are on the stove. I’m already being insufferable to other basketball fans — the poor souls who, unlike me, aren’t Celtics fans.

headline: Massachusetts Emergency 911 System Temporarily Goes Down Statewide
abstract: The system was down for nearly two hours, when officials urged residents to call local police or fire stations to seek help. It was not clear what caused the outage.
lead_paragraph: Massachusetts’s statewide 911 emergency system was paralyzed for nearly two hours on Tuesday afternoon, prompting officials to urge residents to call local police stations and firehouses and even revert to pulling red fire call boxes on street corners if necessary.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘To Die with Perfect Abs’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I love my husband, Igael, and like to show him attention, but what can I say? I’m busy! I’m a practicing physician and the president and chief executive of NYC Health & Hospitals, the nation’s largest municipal health care system. I also have two children and a futile desire to die with perfect abs. So there’s little time to be affectionate. That’s where our microwave comes in. In the 90 seconds it takes to warm coffee or the three minutes to heat dinner, I find my husband, then hug and kiss him. In our family this is known as “microaffection.” — Mitchell Katz

headline: Queens Residents Capture Suspect in Rape of 13-Year-Old Girl
abstract: The police said the suspect, Christian Inga, was recognized after a public campaign to identify him. Investigators said he forced the girl into the woods of a park and bound her with a shoelace.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a dozen Queens residents stopped a man on the street after he was recognized as the person wanted in connection with the sexual assault of a 13-year-old girl last week, according to the police. The residents then held the man until officers arrived, the authorities said.

headline: Trump Wasn’t Going to Stay in Milwaukee. Then Reporters Asked.
abstract: The Republican convention will be held in swing-state Wisconsin’s largest city. The nominee, however, had planned to stay in his own hotel in Chicago, before members of the media began inquiring.
lead_paragraph: When Republicans gather in Milwaukee next month to nominate him for president, Donald J. Trump planned to stay not in the convention’s host city but at a Trump hotel in Chicago, some 90 miles away, according to three people briefed on the former president’s logistics.

headline: Attack Ads Hit John Avlon in His House Primary Bid in New York
abstract: Nancy Goroff, who has contributed $1.2 million of her own money to her campaign, has recently run a string of attacks against John Avlon
lead_paragraph: For months, the Democratic contest on eastern Long Island to choose a candidate most capable of unseating Representative Nick LaLota, the Republican incumbent, has been cordial, if not overly polite.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty in Chinatown Killing of Young Woman in Her Apartment
abstract: Assamad Nash followed Christina Yuna Lee into her home and fatally stabbed her. The killing raised fears at a time of anti-Asian attacks.
lead_paragraph: A man pleaded guilty in Manhattan Criminal Court on Tuesday to killing a 35-year old woman in her Chinatown apartment in 2022 in an episode that intensified fears over anti-Asian attacks.

headline: Nvidia Becomes Most Valuable Public Company, Topping Microsoft
abstract: The chip maker’s stock price has jumped over the last year thanks to its stranglehold on the market for the chips needed to build A.I. systems.
lead_paragraph: Move over, Microsoft and Apple. The stock market has a new king.

headline: Split by Politics and Protests, Georgia Lets Soccer Carry the Flag
abstract: The opposition in Georgia accused the government of cozying up to Russia. Can playing in the Euros make the nation feel more like a part of Europe?
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s road to its first game in the European soccer championship had been a long one, more than 30 years in the making. So when it finally arrived on Tuesday, no one wanted to miss out.

headline: More Black and Latino Students Admitted to New York’s Elite High Schools
abstract: The percentage of Black and Latino students in the eight schools increased modestly to 12 percent, the highest since 2013, but still far below the overall percentage of those students in schools.
lead_paragraph: More than 12 percent of offers to New York City’s most prestigious high schools went to Black and Latino students this year, education officials announced on Tuesday, the highest number since 2013.

headline: Wednesday Briefing: Biden’s Plan to Help 500,000 Immigrants
abstract: Also, Thailand’s vote to legalize same-sex marriage.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced sweeping new legal protections yesterday for undocumented immigrants who have been living in the U.S. for years and are married to Americans. It is one of the most expansive presidential actions to protect immigrants in more than a decade.

headline: Elinor Fuchs, a Leading Scholar of the American Stage, Is Dead at 91
abstract: As a journalist and later as a Yale professor, she provided the intellectual tools to help actors, directors and audiences understand challenging theatrical work.
lead_paragraph: Elinor Fuchs, whose impassioned insights into contemporary theater — first as a critic prowling the avant-garde scene in New York, and later as a professor at Yale — made her one of the leading scholars of the modern American stage, died on May 28 at her home in the West Village of Manhattan. She was 91.

headline: California Joins Growing National Effort to Ban Smartphone Use in Schools
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom called for a statewide ban as states and large school districts have pursued similar prohibitions to prevent disruption and cyberbullying.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom called on Tuesday for a statewide ban on smartphone use in California schools, joining a growing national effort to curb cyberbullying and classroom distraction by limiting access to the devices.

headline: Senate Republicans Block Bump-Stock Ban
abstract: Democrats failed in their effort to override last week’s Supreme Court ruling with legislation, but saw some political benefits to the clash.
lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats failed on Tuesday to overcome Republican opposition to quick passage of legislation that would outlaw gun bump stocks, falling short in their bid to reverse last week’s Supreme Court ruling invalidating a Trump administration ban on devices that allow semiautomatic weapons to fire more rapidly.

headline: Biden Granted Protections for Undocumented Spouses
abstract: Also, the U.S. pier for Gaza aid is failing. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden today announced sweeping new protections for undocumented immigrants who have been living illegally in the U.S. for at least a decade and are married to American citizens.

headline: Texas Border and Pittsburgh Swelter Under Triple-Digit Heat
abstract: Though people in Texas are used to sweltering summer temperatures, residents in Pittsburgh are less acclimated.
lead_paragraph: Some of the hottest spots in the nation on Tuesday were in very different locations: Texas’s border region, which is used to sweltering summer temperatures in the triple digits, and much farther north in Pittsburgh, Pa., which … is generally not.

headline: Georgia 2nd Congressional District Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Georgia runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Georgia runoff election.

headline: Oklahoma 2nd Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary election.

headline: Oklahoma 3rd Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary election.

headline: Oklahoma 4th Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary election.

headline: Georgia 3rd Congressional District Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Georgia runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Georgia runoff election.

headline: Georgia 14th Congressional District Runoff Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Georgia runoff election.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Georgia runoff election.

headline: Oklahoma 1st Congressional District Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary election.

lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Oklahoma primary elections.

headline: Small Step Could Bring Big Relief to Young Undocumented Immigrants
abstract: A new Biden administration measure enables “Dreamers” to get work visas that could free them from relying on the DACA program, whose survival is in doubt.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Tuesday announced an initiative that could be life-changing for hundreds of thousands of undocumented young adults, known as Dreamers, whose ability to live and work in the United States has long been tied to a temporary immigration program that has been on life support.

headline: In the History of United States Heat Waves, 1936 Stands Out
abstract: Thousands died and people slept on roofs to cope with the early heat wave, which was supercharged by agricultural practices.
lead_paragraph: By the time cool air from Canada’s Hudson Bay arrived to relieve the baking Upper Midwest in July 1936, the United States had sweat through a torrid heat spell that stretched to New York.

headline: In Legal Peril, Seattle’s ‘Belltown Hellcat’ Is Ordered to Yield
abstract: A driver whose roaring Dodge Charger has plagued Seattle residents said he was working to modify the car. Still, city officials won an $83,000 judgment against him.
lead_paragraph: A man whose thundering Dodge Charger has tormented Seattle residents for months was ordered Tuesday to pay a fine of more than $83,000, the most serious penalty the city has imposed in months of enforcement efforts that have, until now, been largely ineffective.

headline: Amazon Is Fined Nearly $6 Million Over Warehouse Work Quotas
abstract: California officials cited failures to disclose productivity requirements at two locations. The company said it would appeal.
lead_paragraph: A California labor regulator said on Tuesday that it had fined Amazon nearly $6 million for thousands of violations of a safety law that took effect in 2022.

headline: She Walked in Beauty: The Subtle Seductiveness of Anouk Aimée
abstract: The French star created characters who could be fantasies or enigmas, but they always intrigued, even when she was miscast in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: These days it’s dicey to refer to a female performer as “a thinking man’s sex symbol,” but back in the ’60s and ’70s, when such phrases were dispensed profligately, the French actress Anouk Aimée, who died on Tuesday in Paris at 92, fit the category most beautifully. A willowy brunette with high sculpted cheekbones and penetrating eyes that seemed capable of looking right through you, she was a screen goddess who wielded a thoughtfulness that held the world at arm’s length, or farther.

headline: How Capitalism Went Off the Rails
abstract: Easy money destroyed the basis for productive, competitive markets.
lead_paragraph: The Group of 7 countries might have set a record when they met in Italy last week. Has there ever been a less popular assemblage of leaders of the free world? Approval ratings ranged from Giorgia Meloni of Italy’s about 40 percent to Emmanuel Macron of France’s 21 percent to Fumio Kishida of Japan’s 13 percent. Last year the Edelman Trust Barometer found that only 20 percent of people in the G7 countries thought that they and their families would be better off in five years. Another Edelman survey, from 2020, uncovered a broad distrust of capitalism in countries across the world, “driven by a growing sense of inequity and unfairness in the system.”

headline: Home Collapses in Syracuse, Injuring 11, Officials Say
abstract: An explosion was reported, and an occupied car was found buried under the rubble. It was not clear if it had crashed into the house.
lead_paragraph: A house collapsed in Syracuse, N.Y., on Tuesday afternoon, injuring 11 people, including children.

headline: California Moves to Modify Law Letting Workers Sue Employers
abstract: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced a deal with business and labor leaders heading off a ballot measure to repeal the law, which has cost companies billions.
lead_paragraph: A last-minute political compromise has headed off an effort to repeal a California law allowing workers to sue employers for workplace violations — a legal tool that has cost companies billions of dollars.

headline: Debris From Destruction Adds to Health Crisis in Gaza, U.N. Says
abstract: After eight months of fighting between Israel and Hamas, Gaza is littered with more than 39 million tons of debris, according to an initial assessment.
lead_paragraph: More than eight months of fighting between Israel and Hamas has destroyed buildings and infrastructure across the Gaza Strip, leaving more than 39 million tons of debris and exacerbating an already dire health crisis there, according to a preliminary assessment of the environmental impact of the conflict released by the United Nations on Tuesday.

headline: Trump Whistle-Blower Wins House Primary in Virginia
abstract: Yevgeny Vindman, who raised alarms about then-President Donald J. Trump’s conduct toward Ukraine, will stand for Abigail Spanberger’s seat in Congress as a Democrat.
lead_paragraph: Yevgeny Vindman, who along with his twin brother helped expose then-President Donald J. Trump’s attempts to strong-arm Ukraine into digging up dirt on Joseph R. Biden Jr., won his Democratic primary on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press. He will run in the fall to represent the Virginia district of Representative Abigail Spanberger, who is retiring.

headline: Tom Cole, House G.O.P. Spending Chief, Prevails Against Right-Wing Challenger
abstract: The veteran Republican faced a right-wing challenger who sought to make his powerful post on the committee that controls federal spending into a political liability.
lead_paragraph: Representative Tom Cole, the veteran Oklahoma Republican and chairman of the powerful Appropriations Committee, fended off a primary challenge on Tuesday from a well-funded right-wing businessman, putting him on track to win a 12th term.

headline: Willie Mays, Baseball’s Electrifying Player of Power and Grace, Is Dead at 93
abstract: Mays, the Say Hey Kid, was the game’s exuberant embodiment of the complete player. Some say he was the greatest of them all.
lead_paragraph: Willie Mays, the spirited center fielder whose brilliance at the plate, in the field and on the basepaths for the Giants led many to call him the greatest all-around player in baseball history, died on Tuesday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 93.

headline: How Well Do You Know the N.Y.C. Subway?
abstract: The New York City subway is arguably the most famous transit network in America. How well do you know it? Take our quiz to find out.
lead_paragraph: The New York City subway is arguably the most famous transit network in America. How well do you know it? Take our quiz to find out.

headline: Remembering Willie Mays as Both Untouchable and Human
abstract: Mays, who died on Tuesday at 93, had been perfect for so long that the shock of seeing baseball get the best of him was the shock of seeing a god become mortal.
lead_paragraph: At the end, the Say Hey Kid looked nothing like the extraordinary force who had been at the center of the American imagination for much of the 20th century.

headline: Democratic State Senator Emerges From Nasty House Primary in Virginia
abstract: Suhas Subramanyam had the endorsement of Representative Jennifer Wexton, who is retiring.
lead_paragraph: Suhas Subramanyam, a state senator in suburban Loudoun County, Va., narrowly won the Democratic primary in a House district in Northern Virginia on Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, after perhaps the ugliest primary of the 2024 election season so far.

headline: Read the Ruling by the Virginia Court of Appeals
abstract: Marvin Leon Grimm Jr., who confessed to the 1975 murder of a 3-year-old boy and spent 45 years in prison, was granted a writ of actual innocence by the Virginia appeals court, fully absolving him of the crime.
lead_paragraph: Marvin Leon Grimm Jr., who confessed to the 1975 murder of a 3-year-old boy and spent 45 years in prison, was granted a writ of actual innocence by the Virginia appeals court, fully absolving him of the crime.

headline: Race and Israel Take Center Stage in Final Bowman-Latimer Debate
abstract: Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York sought to portray his challenger, George Latimer, as a pawn of a major pro-Israel lobby.
lead_paragraph: Fighting for his political life ahead of next week’s New York primary, Representative Jamaal Bowman took broad swipes on Tuesday at his opponent in the contest’s final debate, accusing him of failing Black constituents and selling his campaign out to a pro-Israel super PAC.

headline: Targets of Pull-Down Exercises, in Brief
abstract: Brad Wiegmann has new takes on old wisdom.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Nancy Pelosi Meets With Dalai Lama, Despite China’s Criticism
abstract: The former House speaker joined a congressional delegation that met with the Tibetan spiritual leader at his home in India. China calls him a separatist.
lead_paragraph: A high-level U.S. congressional delegation, including the former House speaker Nancy Pelosi, met with the Dalai Lama at his Indian home on Wednesday, a visit that was condemned in advance by China’s government, which considers the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist.

headline: Federal Dams Harm Native American Communities, U.S. Acknowledges
abstract: In a report released Tuesday, the Biden administration said that federal dams in the Columbia River Basin had inflicted damage on local communities, and committed to restoring native fish to the ecosystem.
lead_paragraph: The federal government has released a report that for the first time acknowledges the harms that dams in the Pacific Northwest have “inflicted and continue to inflict” on Native American tribes, it said.

headline: Texas Megachurch Pastor Resigns After Sexual Abuse Allegations
abstract: Robert Morris, a faith adviser to the Trump White House, resigned from Gateway Church after he was accused of abusing a child in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Robert Morris, the founder of a Texas megachurch and a faith adviser to the Trump White House, has resigned from his job as its senior pastor, the church said on Tuesday, days after he was accused of sexually abusing a child in the 1980s.

headline: Kandinsky Cut Ties With Russia. So Did This Museum.
abstract: The first major exhibition at H’Art, a former satellite of the Hermitage, explores how war and nationalism shaped the painter’s career.
lead_paragraph: When the Hermitage Amsterdam cut ties with the State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg in 2022, after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, it could have seemed like the Dutch museum was turning away from Russian culture, or even Russian artists.

headline: Who Owns Alexander the Great? It’s a Diplomatic Minefield.
abstract: North Macedonia has claimed historical figures as part of a drive to build a national identity. That has ruffled the feathers of the Balkan nation’s neighbors.
lead_paragraph: The center of Skopje, the capital of North Macedonia, a Balkan country born just 33 years ago as an independent state, is awash in history.

headline: Putin and Kim Sign Pact Pledging Mutual Support Against ‘Aggression’
abstract: A need for munitions to use against Ukraine is pushing Russia’s leader to deepen his ties with North Korea, raising alarms in the West. The text of the agreement was not immediately released.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, revived a Cold War-era mutual defense pledge between their nations on Wednesday, as the Kremlin deepened its security relationship with North Korea and vowed solidarity in challenging the United States.

headline: Wednesday Briefing
abstract: Biden’s new protections for undocumented spouses.
lead_paragraph: President Biden announced sweeping new legal protections yesterday for undocumented immigrants who have been living in the U.S. for years and are married to Americans. It is one of the most expansive presidential actions to protect immigrants in more than a decade.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Politics Still Rile Georgia, but Soccer Unites Nation
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, June 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “This is the closest we’ve been to unity in a very long time. Everyone had this common thing that they were happy about.”

headline: Corrections: June 19, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, June 19, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Sunday about the treatment of migrants seeking asylum in Canada misstated the number of migrants who sought asylum there last year. The number of asylum seekers was 29,455 in 2023, not roughly 32,000 in the most recent fiscal year.

headline: Britain Election Winner’s First Problem: Fix a Stagnant Economy
abstract: After more than a decade of deep budget cuts, slow growth and weak productivity, the country has struggled to overcome years of uncertainty and underinvestment.
lead_paragraph: “Our economy has truly turned a corner,” Rishi Sunak, Britain’s prime minister, said last week as he introduced his party’s election manifesto, buoyed by recent data showing that Britain’s economy had exited from a recession more strongly than expected in the beginning of the year and that inflation had slowed substantially.

headline: As President Takes Oath, 4 Challenges for South Africa’s New Government
abstract: For the first time since the fall of apartheid, the nation must rely on a coalition of rival parties to govern. Can they get along enough to pull the country out of its crises?
lead_paragraph: With a humility stemming from his party’s electoral disappointment, President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa was sworn in for a second term on Wednesday, conceding bluntly to the government’s failure to cure a nation that remains deeply divided and economically fraught in the three decades since the end of apartheid.

headline: Late Night Trolls Trump After Report of ‘Severe Memory Issues’
abstract: “I’m starting to think Trump writes his name on buildings just so he can remember where he lives,” Jimmy Fallon said.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: In Rare Rebuke, Toyota Chairman’s Investor Support Tumbles
abstract: A relatively low 71.9 percent of shareholders supported Akio Toyoda, who has faced scrutiny over governance issues, in his bid to remain chairman.
lead_paragraph: Investor support for Toyota Motor’s longtime leader, Akio Toyoda, sank to its lowest level since he took the helm as shareholders challenged the extent of control he exerts over the company.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: In a State Notorious for Political Scandal, Signs of Change Emerge
abstract: New Jersey’s senior senator is on trial, charged with taking bribes. A political power broker is accused of racketeering. A judge has declared the election system unfair.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s senior U.S. senator is on trial, charged with taking bribes in exchange for political favors. A federal judge has declared the state’s method of conducting primary elections fundamentally unfair. And on Monday New Jersey’s attorney general charged one of the state’s most formidable Democratic power brokers with racketeering.

headline: A Palestinian American Choreographer’s Intimate, Epic ‘Gathering’
abstract: Samar Haddad King’s premiere at the Shed tells a layered story of trauma, dislocation and resilience.
lead_paragraph: For the Palestinian American choreographer Samar Haddad King, the orange is more than a prop in her latest show. It’s an entry point into her culture.

headline: How Cage the Elephant’s Frontman Nearly Lost It All
abstract: Matt Shultz is a rock ’n’ roll ringmaster known for pushing himself to the brink. After a period of psychosis and an arrest, he had to put his reality back together again.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2020 as the pandemic cut a terrifying path across the globe, touring bands packed up and went home, unsure how they’d survive. At the same time, Matt Shultz, the frontman of Cage the Elephant — the rare arena-scale rock act to emerge within the past two decades — was facing a different crisis in his own head.

headline: This Veterinarian Makes House — and Penthouse — Calls
abstract: In her memoir, “Pets and the City,” Amy Attas reflects on three decades of caring for animals (and, by extension, humans) right in their own homes.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever tried to wrangle a hissing, scratching, flailing, selectively incontinent beast into a cat carrier, you’ll appreciate the way Amy Attas practices veterinary medicine: She makes house calls.

headline: How One Couple Turned Their Backyard Into an Arboretum
abstract: Their passion for fruit you’ve never heard of started small. Now they have a botanical garden that’s open to the public.
lead_paragraph: This is what happens if you stay put, and keep digging holes: An effort that begins innocently enough — planting a garden at home — may grow on you. And it could morph into an arboretum.

headline: Was Global Trade a Mistake?
abstract: Across two new books, the ideal of a global free market buckles under pressure from protesters, politicians of all stripes and the Covid pandemic.
lead_paragraph: On a cold November morning in 1999, Harold Linde, a member of the Rainforest Action Network, was trying to hang an enormous sign from a construction crane hundreds of feet in the air over downtown Seattle. Loosely attached to a rope, he rappelled off the crane, lost control and began to plummet.

headline: The Careful Crafting of Austin Butler
abstract: “Elvis” and “Dune” established him as a chameleonic movie star. Now, with “The Bikeriders,” something closer to the real Butler is being revealed.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene early on in the new film “The Bikeriders” that functions like a stress test for stardom.

headline: My Favorite Way to Make Salmon Even Better
abstract: Dried limes can take your weeknight meal to the next level.
lead_paragraph: Much can be said about salmon. Its life cycle is so remarkable that its sheer survival seems to invoke some odds-defying metaphors. Tenacity, audacity, resilience: If anyone wants to anthropomorphize salmon, its heroic qualities are there for the taking. To get through life’s upstream struggles, we all just need to be a bit “more salmon.”

headline: The Good News About a Bad G.P.A.
abstract: A mediocre high school record doesn’t have to define your life.
lead_paragraph: The Opinion contributing writer Megan Stack has a gift for high school graduates who struggled academically or who feel like life is passing them by. In this audio essay, Stack lays out an optimistic vision for the late bloomers and poor performers, arguing that this stage of life doesn’t have to define a person’s future and that there are many paths to happiness and success.

headline: New York’s First Black Librarians Changed the Way We Read
abstract: How the women who ran libraries during the Harlem Renaissance built collections and, just as important, communities of writers and readers.
lead_paragraph: It was a banner day in the history of American libraries — and in Black history. On May 25, 1926, the New York Public Library announced that it had acquired the celebrated Afro-Latino bibliophile Arturo Schomburg’s collection of more than 4,000 books, manuscripts and other artifacts.

headline: What Your Heart Rate Can Tell You About Your Fitness
abstract: Most fitness trackers offer a wealth of heart-rate data. Here’s how to make sense of it.
lead_paragraph: If you wear a smartwatch or fitness tracker, you likely already have access to a steady stream of data about your heart health.

headline: A Massacre Threatens Darfur — Again
abstract: Darfur, the region of Sudan once synonymous with genocide, may be on the brink of a new chapter of horror.
lead_paragraph: Darfur, the region of Sudan once synonymous with genocide, may be on the brink of a new chapter of horror.

headline: Exposing the Designer Behind the Curtain
abstract: Dior, Chanel, Lagerfeld — a rash of new streaming biopics have tried to humanize fashion’s most famous names. Is that a good thing?
lead_paragraph: There is a scene late in “Becoming Karl Lagerfeld,” the six-part streaming series on Hulu about the early Paris career of the famed German designer, that features a youngish Karl talking to his mother, who has just had a stroke and whom he has installed in an elaborate château in the French countryside. He is in despair. Without her, Mr. Lagerfeld says, there will be no one who knows the real him.

headline: He Memorized the World With Google Maps. Now He’s Exploring It.
abstract: Few people are better than Trevor Rainbolt at identifying  obscure locations online — but there’s even more joy in watching him visit them IRL.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2021, a 22-year-old from Arkansas named Trevor Rainbolt shuttered himself in his Los Angeles apartment to memorize the world. For months, he spent his time studying Google Street View from his desk chair. Delivery drivers handed over his meals; a barber came to style his hair. After a while, his memory grew planetary. When you see cabbage-like plants thriving along the sides of a Russian country road, he learned, you’re most likely looking at Sakhalin Island. On a bridge lined with pea-green pavement? You’re above a river in Indonesia’s Central Kalimantan province. If your vista, but for the sweep of golden grasslands, screams South Africa, you’ll be in Eswatini.

headline: The Eternal Pull of the Fascinating, Deadly Volcano
abstract: In “Adventures in Volcanoland,” the geologist Tamsin Mather takes us on a global and historical investigation of her life’s passion.
lead_paragraph: I live on a hump of pink granite, part of a geological formation that stretches across southern Connecticut, lurching out of the ground here and there like a pod of surfacing whales.

headline: In California, Hotels and Rentals Must Reveal Fees Upfront. What Does That Mean for You?
abstract: Two new laws target surprise charges like resort fees, cleaning fees and service fees, forcing companies to tell you about them before you book, even if you live elsewhere. Here’s what you need to know.
lead_paragraph: Last May, Samir Bhavnani, a 47-year-old tech executive from San Diego, was planning a trip to Palm Springs, Calif., where he planned to propose to his girlfriend. He found the perfect spot on Vrbo: It offered a “spa in a grotto,” a slide and a swim-up bar and had plenty of five-star reviews.

headline: Land Art in Malibu Gets a Second Chance
abstract: Lita Albuquerque redraws her “Malibu Line,” an ultra-vivid blue earthwork that connects earth, ocean and sky.
lead_paragraph: Lita Albuquerque made a strange sort of painting in 1978 that changed her course as an artist. An abstract painter at the time, she had felt the urge to get out of her studio and work directly on the land where she lived, an artist’s colony on the bluffs of Malibu. She dug a narrow, shallow, 41-foot-long trench in the ground, running perpendicular to the Pacific Ocean, and poured powdered ultramarine pigment into it. From some viewpoints the bright blue color appeared to run into the sea, visually connecting that strip of earth to the ocean and horizon.

headline: South Africa Runs Out of Insulin Pens as Global Supply Shifts to Weight-Loss Drugs
abstract: The shortage highlights a widening gulf in the standard of care for people with diabetes, most of whom live in low-income countries.
lead_paragraph: South Africa’s public health care system has run out of the human insulin pens that it provides to people with diabetes, as the pharmaceutical industry shifts production priorities to blockbuster weight-loss drugs that use a similar device for delivery.

headline: How Scared Should You Be of Bird Flu?
abstract: Here’s who needs to worry right now.
lead_paragraph: How worried you should be about H5N1, the bird flu virus spreading on dairy farms in the United States, depends on who you are.

headline: What My Cancer Surgery Taught Me About Immigration
abstract: Glenn Kramon discusses the coincidences that led him to realize how critical immigration was to his recent cancer battle.
lead_paragraph: Wheeled into the operating room last January, staring up at the massive arms of the robot with which a surgeon would remove my cancerous gland, I was hit with an unusual realization: I owe a debt of gratitude to President Lyndon Johnson and the Immigration and Nationality Act of 1965.

headline: A Disaster of the U.S. Military’s Own Making
abstract: Austin Valley’s death exposed the Army’s most urgent challenge: a suicide crisis among soldiers in peacetime.
lead_paragraph: Austin Valley had just arrived at his Army base in Poland, last March, when he knocked on his buddy Adrian Sly’s door to borrow a knife. The base plate of his helmet was loose and needed fixing, he told Sly. The soldiers had spent most of their day on a bus, traveling from their former base to this new outpost in Nowa Deba, near the border with Ukraine. It had been a monotonous 12-hour journey with no stops and nothing to eat but military rations. Sly thought his friend looked exhausted, but then so did everyone else. He handed Valley an old hunting knife, and Valley offered an earnest smile. “Really appreciate it, man,” he said. Then he disappeared.

headline: End Legal Slavery in the United States
abstract: Compulsory labor with little or no compensation should be unthinkable.
lead_paragraph: Today we celebrate Juneteenth, the day when word of the Emancipation Proclamation reached the farthest outpost in America. Many people do not realize that Emancipation did not legally end slavery in the United States, however. The 13th Amendment — the culmination of centuries of resistance by enslaved people, a lifetime of abolitionist campaigning and a bloody civil war — prohibited involuntary servitude “except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted.”

headline: How Does Democracy Die? Maybe by Laser Vision.
abstract: “The Boys” and other TV series imagine fascism coming to America, whether wrapped in the flag or in a superhero’s tights.
lead_paragraph: What would fascism look like in America? A quote long misattributed to Sinclair Lewis says that it would come “wrapped in the flag and carrying a cross.” The comedian George Carlin said that it would come not “with jackboots” but “Nike sneakers and smiley shirts.”

headline: 5 Minutes to Love Max Roach
abstract: A look at one of the jazz icon’s most provocative albums.
lead_paragraph: Max Roach would have been 100 this year. Roach, an American music pioneer who died at 83 in 2007, was a jazz drummer, composer and band leader. His percussive rhythms laid the foundation for the bebop era. He was also an activist who used his music as a platform for his political beliefs. Nowhere was this more evident than in his 1960 landmark avant-garde album, “We Insist!”. The music reporter Marcus J. Moore takes a look at the album’s impact and reflects on Roach’s lasting legacy.

headline: $400,000 Homes in New York, Mississippi and Maryland
abstract: An 1860 rowhouse in Catskill, a Queen Anne Revival home in Holly Springs and a 19th-century farmhouse in Westminster.
lead_paragraph: This house is a block from Main Street, putting it within easy walking distance of the village’s restaurants, bakeries and art studios. It is a 10-minute walk from the Avalon Lounge, a popular music venue, and from Catskill Marina, on Catskill Creek. Dutchman’s Landing Park, which has a playground, picnic areas and walking trails along the Hudson River, is about 15 minutes away on foot.

headline: Grace Coddington on the Secrets of Reinventing Yourself
abstract: At 83, the longtime Vogue editor, stylist and artist says that “listening” is one of the most important things you can do.
lead_paragraph: The Unstoppables is a series about people whose ambition is undimmed by time. Below, Grace Coddington explains, in her own words, what continues to motivate her.

headline: What to Know About Suicides in the U.S. Army
abstract: A Times investigation reveals a crisis of the military’s own making.
lead_paragraph: Soldiers are more likely than their civilian peers to die by suicide. Many people wrongly believe this is because of combat trauma, but in fact the most vulnerable group are soldiers who have never deployed. The Army’s suicide rate has risen steadily even in peacetime, and the numbers now exceed total combat deaths in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. A Times investigation into the death of Specialist Austin Valley, stationed at Fort Riley in Kansas, found that mental-health care providers in the Army are beholden to brigade leadership and often fail to act in the best interest of soldiers.

headline: Researchers Say Social Media Warning Is Too Broad
abstract: Some scientists who study youth mental health say the evidence does not support the notion that social media is harmful per se.
lead_paragraph: When the U.S. surgeon general, Dr. Vivek Murthy, announced on Monday that he was planning to push for a mental health warning label on social media platforms, he was met with cheers from many parents and teachers, who described a long, lonely struggle to wrench children away from a habit that was hurting them.

headline: ‘We Just Always Expect It to Work’: 911 Outage Shows System’s Perils
abstract: The failure of the Massachusetts 911 system on Tuesday was the latest reminder of the potential problems faced by an emergency network that many say needs to be upgraded.
lead_paragraph: The abrupt failure of Massachusetts’ 911 system on Tuesday was a stark example of the disastrous consequences that can occur when an emergency network that is supposed to be reliable is, without warning, suddenly unreliable.

headline: Political Scientists Want to Know Why We Hate One Another This Much
abstract: What does the rise of partisan sectarians portend for the rest of us?
lead_paragraph: Who among us are the most willing to jettison democratic elections? Which voters not only detest their political adversaries but also long for their destruction?

headline: The Gay Comedians Who Showed the Way Even if They Weren’t Exactly Out
abstract: Paul Lynde, Charles Nelson Reilly and Rip Taylor get a cursory mention in a new documentary about queer stand-up, but they were groundbreaking.
lead_paragraph: In 1987, David Letterman was taping his late-night show in Las Vegas before rowdy audiences of mostly young men in preppy pullovers and muscle shirts — prototypical bros raised on “Porky’s.”

headline: Something’s Rotten About the Justices Taking So Long on Trump’s Immunity Case
abstract: It shouldn’t take so long for the justices to consider an outlandish claim.
lead_paragraph: For those looking for the hidden hand of politics in what the Supreme Court does, there’s plenty of reason for suspicion on Donald Trump’s as-yet-undecided immunity case given its urgency. There are, of course, explanations that have nothing to do with politics for why a ruling still hasn’t been issued. But the reasons to think something is rotten at the court are impossible to ignore.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling on Bump Stocks Could Open Door to More Lethal Weapons
abstract: The court’s decision has the potential to undercut President Biden’s efforts to restrict other gun accessories that enable semiautomatic rifles to fire at speeds rivaling those of machine guns.
lead_paragraph: After a gunman in Las Vegas killed 60 people at a concert in 2017, officials focused on a gun accessory known as a bump stock, a device that allows a rifle to fire at nearly the rate of a machine gun. Bump stocks were banned by the Trump administration after that mass shooting.

headline: Today Is the Longest Day of the Year in the Northern Hemisphere
abstract: We have Earth’s off-kilter tilt to thank for the summer solstice, as well as the different seasons.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, everyone in the northern half of our planet will experience the summer solstice. It’ll be the longest day of the year north of the Equator, and it is the scientific start of summer.

headline: Why Darfur Again Faces the Risk of Ethnic Slaughter
abstract: Satellite and video evidence shows that thousands of homes have been razed and tens of thousands of people forced to flee a city in Sudan.
lead_paragraph: Overshadowed by the fighting in Ukraine and Gaza, Sudan’s brutal civil war has been spreading for months across the western Darfur region, where atrocities were seared into international consciousness 20 years ago.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,097, June 20, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 375, June 20, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Netanyahu Lashes Out at U.S., and the Stock Market’s New King
abstract: Plus, baseball legend Willie Mays dies at 93.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Getting Aid Into Gaza
abstract: We explain why it has been such a challenge.
lead_paragraph: Humanitarian groups have thousands of tons of food, fuel and medicine ready to send to Gaza. That aid is sitting in Egypt, Jordan and Cyprus, just hours away, or less, from the people who need it. But much of it can’t get in.

headline: ‘Black Barbie: A Documentary’ Review: Becoming the Main Character
abstract: A new Netflix documentary explores what led to the release of Black Barbie in 1980, both celebrating her existence and recognizing her limitations.
lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, Lagueria Davis’s aunt, Beulah Mae Mitchell, worked at Mattel. Davis, the director of the new Netflix documentary “Black Barbie,” was not a fan of dolls, but was drawn to the subject by her aunt, who is a devoted collector.

headline: Anarchy Hinders Gaza Aid Efforts, Despite Daily Combat Pause
abstract: Thousands of tons of aid stockpiled in southern Gaza cannot be distributed because the roads are too dangerous, relief groups say.
lead_paragraph: The extreme anarchy that has gripped the Gaza Strip is making it too dangerous and difficult to distribute desperately needed aid in the south, relief groups and others say, despite a daily pause in fighting that Israel is observing along a key road there.

headline: 2 Are Killed in ‘Devastating’ New Mexico Wildfires
abstract: The state’s governor declared a regional state of emergency as thousands evacuated. Wind and rain could affect firefighting efforts.
lead_paragraph: Two fast-moving wildfires in Southern New Mexico that have killed two people, prompted the evacuation of thousands of people and scorched more than 23,000 acres continued to burn out of control on Wednesday, officials said, and it was unclear when firefighters might gain some control.

headline: Russia Sentences U.S. Soldier to 4 Years in Prison
abstract: Staff Sgt. Gordon Black was accused of making death threats against, and stealing money from, a woman with whom he was romantically involved.
lead_paragraph: A Russian court sentenced a U.S. Army sergeant to nearly four years in jail on Wednesday for stealing the equivalent of about $100 from a woman with whom he was romantically involved and for making death threats against her.

headline: Why Are My Parents Handling College Costs So Differently for My Sibling?
abstract: A reader who was made to choose a college based on price is struggling to understand her parents’ support of her younger sister at an expensive private school.
lead_paragraph: My younger sister has decided to attend an expensive private college. This surprised me: She was accepted at prestigious state schools with scholarships, which would be more affordable for our parents, who are footing the bill. When my brother and I went to college several years ago, such an expensive school would have been out of the question. We also had to take out small loans, which my parents are not asking our sister to do. Their financial situation hasn’t changed, and I feel frustrated. I had to select a college based on price and take out loans; she doesn’t have to do either. Should I raise this with my parents? They are kind and generous people, and I don’t want to seem ungrateful. But I am still paying off the loans.

headline: Getting Real With the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders
abstract: Kelli Finglass, the director of the dance squad, sits down for a discussion of the new Netflix series “America’s Sweethearts.”
lead_paragraph: They are famous for their jump splits and Rockette-style leg lifts; their big hair, blue sleeves and star-embroidered vests; and their white boots and bedazzled shorts. Their uniform is so iconic that it hangs in the Smithsonian.

headline: It’s Time to Ban Pharmaceutical Advertising
abstract: There are too many drug ads on social media to ever regulate them properly, and ads drive up prescription costs.
lead_paragraph: “Zofran girlies rise up.”

headline: Most New York City Pools Are Still Closed as Temperatures Soar
abstract: New Yorkers are sweating through an early heat wave, but the city’s outdoor public pools won’t open until June 27.
lead_paragraph: Outdoor public pools in New York City won’t open until June 27, leaving residents with fewer options to find refuge from this week’s heat wave.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s Conspiracy of Ravens
abstract: The presidential candidate keeps two of the free-minded birds as wild pets. They’re much better behaved than his old emu, Toby, who would attack his wife, Cheryl Hines.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was getting annoyed, fingers tapping on his lawn chair. As a reporter and a photographer crouched expectantly in the bushes behind his Los Angeles home, his two wild ravens were refusing to cooperate with a photo shoot.

headline: Intense Heat Grips Saudi Arabia, Killing Dozens at Hajj
abstract: Reports from official media in Europe, the Middle East and Africa suggest that dozens of people died during this year’s pilgrimage as temperatures soared.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of people have died amid scorching temperatures during the annual hajj pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca in Saudi Arabia, according to reports from official media in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

headline: It’s Unanimous: In the Senate, Neither Party Consents to the Other’s Ideas
abstract: Democrats sought to quickly reinstate a ban on gun bump stocks after a Supreme Court ruling. It was the latest Senate floor fight to end in a predictable stalemate.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the term “U.C.” stands for “unanimous consent” — usually verbal shorthand for an agreement by all senators to quickly take up and pass a bill. But with the November elections just months away, it might as well stand for: “You see? Our political opponents are dead wrong on this issue.”

headline: Chasing Five Rings to Escape Destiny
abstract: An Olympian realizes she has agency over her future — and her fears.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: Is Murray Hill’s Showbiz Dream Finally Coming True?
abstract: For years he wowed ’em in the clubs with his drag-king lounge act. Now, against all odds, he’s breaking out.
lead_paragraph: The almost famous drag king comedian Murray Hill struts through Melvyn’s Restaurant & Lounge, an old school steakhouse in Palm Springs, Calif.

headline: My Date Recorded Us Having Sex Without My Consent. Should I Report Them?
abstract: The Magazine’s Ethicist columnist on boundaries in friendship and other intimate relationships.

headline: E.U. Warns France Over ‘Excessive’ Deficit, Adding to Political Risks
abstract: The rebuke for breaking European Union rules that require strict financial discipline comes two weeks before French voters head to the polls for parliamentary elections.
lead_paragraph: Add an entry to the list of troubles facing President Emmanuel Macron of France less than two weeks before pivotal legislative elections: potential financial penalties by the European Union for failure to rein in the nation’s ballooning deficit and debt.

headline: Are Planes Safe Right Now? Here’s What the Experts Say.
abstract: You should expect the unexpected while flying, but few disruptions should provoke serious concern, aviation experts say.
lead_paragraph: Smoke in the cabin. A tire blowout. A cracked windshield. No shortage of problems can affect a flight, fueling traveler anxiety and contributing to thousands of daily delays and cancellations around the world.

headline: Group of Austrians Picks 77 Charities to Receive Heiress’s Fortune
abstract: Marlene Engelhorn, a descendant of the founder of one of the world’s largest chemical companies, decided to give away most of her inheritance.
lead_paragraph: After six weekends of deliberating, a group of Austrian citizens this week decided how to divvy up the riches of the heiress Marlene Engelhorn, who is donating the bulk of her inheritance to charity in an attempt to challenge a system that allowed her to accumulate millions of euros.

headline: Why Is Everyone on TikTok Suddenly Going to the Chiropractor?
abstract: Neck cracks and spine adjustments have become a potent social media trend, but some chiropractors fear the videos send the wrong message about the profession.
lead_paragraph: Snap. Crack. Pop. These sounds, once used to sell a popular breakfast cereal, are now enticing people to visit the doctor thanks to a wave of chiropractic videos sweeping social media.

headline: Do We Need Language to Think?
abstract: A group of neuroscientists argue that our words are primarily for communicating, not for reasoning.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of years, philosophers have argued about the purpose of language. Plato believed it was essential for thinking. Thought “is a silent inner conversation of the soul with itself,” he wrote.

headline: With the Help of Whales, a Choreographer Falls Into an Abyss
abstract: Mayfield Brooks explores grief and decomposition in the hull of a 19th-century cargo ship.
lead_paragraph: Whales, Black bodies, the ocean, climate change, protest movements — over the past few years, they have all made their way into work by Mayfield Brooks, a choreographer, dancer and vocalist.

headline: Colorful, Cooling Country Panzanella With Watermelon Dressing
abstract: Toasted bread, tomatoes and watermelon are tossed with a piquant dressing that’s made from both the sweet watermelon flesh and tangy rind.
lead_paragraph: It’s Juneteenth, a day traditionally celebrated with brightly hued red foods. If you’re searching for some summery inspiration, look no further than Gabrielle E.W. Carter’s recipe for country panzanella with watermelon dressing, adapted by Nicole Taylor and Yewande Komolafe.

headline: Life With Alzheimer’s: Families’ Stories
abstract: Readers recount their experiences coping with the disease. Also: A mother’s dementia; the B.D.S. movement; dangers of factory farms.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tracking the Remnants of Alberto
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Alberto.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Alberto.

headline: Maine Takes Precautions for Heat, Including Changes to Juneteenth Event
abstract: Around the state, cooling centers are opening in libraries, town halls, civic centers, Y.M.C.A.s, fire departments and other public buildings to give people a chance to escape the heat.
lead_paragraph: In Lewiston, Maine, organizers of a Juneteenth celebration on Wednesday made changes to prepare for the heat, including moving events indoors, shortening a parade and providing extra water, as precautions were enacted all over the state amid soaring temperatures.

headline: Putin Once Tried to Curb North Korea’s Nuclear Program. That’s Now Over.
abstract: Vladimir Putin promised unspecified technological help to North Korea, which could allow it to advance its nuclear weapons program.
lead_paragraph: As Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia and Xi Jinping’s China deepened their confrontation with the West over the past decade, they were always united with the United States on at least one geopolitical project: dismantling or at least containing North Korea’s nuclear arsenal.

headline: 176 Writing Prompts to Spark Discussion and Reflection
abstract: Here are all of our Student Opinion questions from the 2023-24 school year. Each question is based on a different New York Times article, interactive feature or video.
lead_paragraph: Each day of the school year we publish a Student Opinion question inviting students to share their own opinions and experiences in response to New York Times stories on the news of the day. To introduce each question, we provide an excerpt from a related Times article, interactive or video as well as a free link to that piece.

headline: ‘Pre-Existing Condition’ Review: Recovering From a Traumatic Relationship
abstract: Marin Ireland’s play opens with Tatiana Maslany in a rotating cast of stars, and “What Became of Us” continues its own experiment with changing casts.
lead_paragraph: Marin Ireland’s new play, “Pre-Existing Condition,” doesn’t come with trigger warnings; it barely even comes with a marketing description. The show’s website says that it’s about the aftermath of “a life-altering, harmful relationship,” but doesn’t explicitly mention domestic violence.

headline: Ricardo M. Urbina, Trailblazing Latino Judge in Capital, Dies at 78
abstract: Before being appointed to the bench in Washington, he was a track star who became a symbol of discrimination against Black athletes.
lead_paragraph: Ricardo M. Urbina, a trailblazing Latino lawyer who scored victories for civil liberties as an empathetic federal judge and for civil rights as a record-breaking track star — helping to fuel an epochal protest at the 1968 Olympics — died on Monday in Washington. He was 78.

headline: Crews Rush to Restore Power in Pittsburgh as Temperatures Soar
abstract: With heat indexes forecast to reach 110 degrees in western Pennsylvania, about 6,700 people were still without power after damaging wind and rain storms earlier this week.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of people in the greater Pittsburgh area were without power on Wednesday as the city was set to experience some of the hottest conditions in the United States.

headline: Congress Debates Expanded Draft Amid Military Recruitment Challenges
abstract: Republicans and Democrats are weighing proposals to expand military conscription to women and make registration automatic. Both proposals face an uphill path to becoming law.
lead_paragraph: The United States military has not activated a draft in more than 50 years, but Congress is weighing proposals to update mandatory conscription, including by expanding it to women for the first time and automatically registering those eligible to be called up.

headline: How Has a Ban on Smartphones in Schools Affected You?
abstract: We want to hear from you — students, parents and teachers — about a growing push to limit smartphone usage in schools.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California on Tuesday became the latest state leader to back a ban on smartphones in schools, joining a growing, bipartisan call to limit them in the classroom.

headline: How Heat Affects the Brain
abstract: High temperatures can make us miserable. Research shows they also make us aggressive, impulsive and dull.
lead_paragraph: In July 2016, a heat wave hit Boston, with daytime temperatures averaging 92 degrees for five days in a row. Some local university students who were staying in town for the summer got lucky and were living in dorms with central air-conditioning. Other students, not so much — they were stuck in older dorms without A.C.

headline: After His Arrest, Justin Timberlake Is the Talk of Sag Harbor
abstract: As the serene Hamptons village is overrun with news vans, the locals eat oysters and engage in some light media criticism.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday afternoon in Sag Harbor, Janice Yu of WABC-TV was sitting in the passenger seat of a Nissan news van, eating from a bag of Smart Food popcorn. It was as close as she would come to getting to a kernel of news.

headline: Willie Mays, ‘Poetry on the Diamond’
abstract: Readers pay tribute to the beloved Giants great, who died on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: OpenAI Co-Founder, Who Helped Oust Sam Altman, Starts His Own Company
abstract: Ilya Sutskever’s new start-up, Safe Superintelligence, aims to build A.I. technologies that are smarter than a human but not dangerous.
lead_paragraph: Ilya Sutskever, the OpenAI co-founder and chief scientist who in November joined other board members to force out Sam Altman, the company’s high-profile chief executive, has helped found a new artificial intelligence company.

headline: Louisiana Requires All Public Classrooms to Display Ten Commandments
abstract: A law signed by Gov. Jeff Landry on Wednesday makes the state the only one with such a mandate. Critics have vowed to mount a constitutional challenge.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jeff Landry signed legislation on Wednesday requiring the display of the Ten Commandments in every public classroom in Louisiana, making the state the only one with such a mandate and reigniting the debate over how porous the boundary between church and state should be.

headline: Trump Tries to Set Expectations, and Floats Excuses, for His Debate With Biden
abstract: The former president has set a low bar for President Biden’s performance at next week’s matchup. Now, he is preparing supporters for the possibility that Mr. Biden clears it.
lead_paragraph: A few minutes into his speech at a campaign rally on Tuesday, Donald J. Trump asked a question of the few thousand who’d turned up to hear him speak. “Is anybody going to watch the debate?”

headline: What’s in Our Queue? ‘Hacks’ and More
abstract: I’m a politics reporter covering the Southeast for The New York Times. Here are a few things I’m reading, watching and listening to in regular rotation.
lead_paragraph: I’m a politics reporter covering the Southeast for The New York Times. Here are a few things I’m reading, watching and listening to in regular rotation.

headline: Biden’s Strategy: Help Immigrants in the U.S., but Stop Others From Arriving
abstract: President Biden’s recent actions on immigration put his approach to one of the most divisive issues in the 2024 election into focus.
lead_paragraph: There are hundreds of thousands of immigrants in the United States who have been living in the country illegally for years, working and making a living, starting families and sending their children to school. President Biden says they can stay.

headline: How Two Beluga Whales Made It to Safety From Ukraine
abstract: A pair of  whales were extricated from the besieged city of Kharkiv and taken to an aquarium in Spain with help from experts around the world.
lead_paragraph: It was a whale of an evacuation. Actually, two.

headline: Hezbollah’s Leader Says It Will Fight Without ‘Limits’ if Israel Attacks
abstract: Hassan Nasrallah, head of the Lebanese militia, also threatened Cyprus if it helped Israel in an all-out war. The Cypriot president responded that his nation was “not involved in any way.”
lead_paragraph: After days of intensified clashes between Hezbollah and Israel, Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militia, warned on Wednesday that “there will be no place safe from our missiles and our drones” if all-out war breaks out. He also threatened Cyprus if it allows Israel to use its airports and bases in a full-scale conflict.

headline: Why Is Putin in Vietnam?
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin is keen to maintain the longstanding military ties between Russia and Vietnam, as Hanoi has developed deeper bonds with Washington.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia wrapped up a state visit to one ally, North Korea, and moved on to another, Vietnam, arriving early Thursday hoping to shore up crucial partnerships in the region as he wages a protracted war in Ukraine.

headline: Ask The Morning Anything
abstract: Do you have questions about The Morning newsletter? Or about the news? We want to hear them.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a busy news year, and our team at The Morning newsletter wants to know what questions are on our readers’ minds. Maybe you’ve got questions about how we write each day’s newsletter — we’re happy to answer those, too.

headline: U.K. Conservatives Hit by New Gambling Allegations Two Weeks Before Election
abstract: The governing party’s director of campaigning has taken a leave of absence after reports his wife, a Conservative candidate, was being investigated by Britain’s gambling regulator.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s embattled Conservative Party suffered a fresh blow after its director of campaigning took a leave of absence just two weeks before the election, following reports that his wife, one of the party’s candidates, was being investigated over allegedly placing a bet on the timing of the vote.

headline: Thursday Briefing: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pledge
abstract: Also, the challenges of getting aid into Gaza.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un revived a Cold War-era mutual defense pledge between Russia and North Korea yesterday.

headline: At ‘Playgrounds of Privilege,’ a Reporter Takes the Pulse of Power
abstract: Jacob Bernstein, a reporter on the Styles desk, writes about philanthropists, media magnates and other social connectors in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Jacob Bernstein is fascinated by power, privilege and the people who wield both.

headline: For a Story on Disney, a Writer Tests New Waters
abstract: When Walt Disney World replaced a ride that was based on a racist film with a new attraction, Brooks Barnes, who covers entertainment, was first in line.
lead_paragraph: I suppose I qualify as a Disney Adult, the pejorative term for grown-ups who visit Disney theme parks without children in tow.

headline: Ecuador Hit by Nationwide Blackout
abstract: The public works minister said the power outage had been caused by the failure of a key transmission line. Within hours, power had begun to be restored to the nation of 18 million.
lead_paragraph: Ecuador was plunged into a nationwide blackout on Wednesday afternoon, and the country’s public works minister blamed the emergency on the failure of a key transmission line.

headline: Willie Mays, Birmingham and Rickwood Field: Baseball Honors a Legend in His Hometown
abstract: Major League Baseball is in Birmingham to honor the legacy of the Negro Leagues. With Mays’s death, the celebration at ancient Rickwood Field takes on new meaning.
lead_paragraph: In the late innings of a minor league game on Tuesday night at Rickwood Field in Birmingham, Ala., fans throughout the grandstand, suddenly and almost in unison, began staring at the news on their phones: The great Willie Mays had died, at 93, in California.

headline: Battlefield Commander’s Case Goes to Guantánamo Jury
abstract: The panel is deciding a sentence for a prisoner who pleaded guilty to commanding Qaeda and Taliban forces in Afghanistan that carried out war crimes.
lead_paragraph: A military jury on Wednesday began deliberating a sentence for an admitted war criminal at Guantánamo Bay after prosecution and defense lawyers portrayed the prisoner as, alternately, a senior member of a global Qaeda conspiracy or a battlefield commander defending Afghanistan from the U.S. invasion.

headline: Putin’s Presidential Planes: What We Know
abstract: The Kremlin clings to Soviet-designed aircraft even as Russia’s commercial carriers opt for Western planes.
lead_paragraph: When President Vladimir V. Putin travels abroad — as he did this week to North Korea and Vietnam to bolster alliances and nurture security ties amid Russia’s war in Ukraine — he typically flies in dated, Soviet-designed Ilyushin Il-96 series jets.

headline: Kennedy Raises Just $2.6 Million, a Sign of Reliance on His Running Mate
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s campaign has depended heavily on contributions from Nicole Shanahan, his vice-presidential pick, who did not make major new donations in May.
lead_paragraph: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential campaign raised just $2.6 million in May, a paltry sum that speaks to how reliant his bid has become on his running mate, the wealthy Silicon Valley lawyer Nicole Shanahan.

headline: Unrelenting Heat Stifles Millions of Americans for 3rd Consecutive Day
abstract: As the heat wave moved east, the Northeast felt the brunt of the conditions. But forecasters provided a glimmer of relief, saying “conditions should improve over New England” this weekend.
lead_paragraph: From the Midwest to the northern tip of Maine, millions of Americans sweltered under a springtime heat wave on Wednesday that stifled the Eastern portion of the United States for a third consecutive day.

headline: At Least 4 Dead After Tropical Storm Alberto Drenches Mexico
abstract: No longer a tropical cyclone after making landfall on Thursday, Alberto still threatened flooding and mudslides in Mexico and dangerous surf on the Texas coast.
lead_paragraph: Alberto, the first named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, made landfall on the northeastern coast of Mexico as a tropical storm early on Thursday, unleashing heavy rain, flooding and gusty winds, forecasters said. At least four people died in events related to the storm, which later weakened into a depression, officials and forecasters said.

headline: Dancer’s Haul
abstract: Ella Dershowitz calls us by (some of) our names — or does she?
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Is Hamas Bound by International Law? What to Know.
abstract: The armed Islamist group committed war crimes on Oct. 7, experts say, and continues to do so by holding hostages.
lead_paragraph: Since the attacks of Oct. 7, every legal expert I have asked has shared one conclusion: Hamas’s attacks on civilians that day, including killing, torture, and hostage-taking, were war crimes. And because many hostages are still being held, that crime remains ongoing.

headline: Spicy Noodles and Pickled Fish: Chinese Eateries Move Into Hong Kong
abstract: As the cultural lines between Hong Kong and China blur, restaurants from the mainland are finding opportunities in the city. But not everyone is happy.
lead_paragraph: The ravenous came for a taste of home in a dish of spicy fried beef or steamed fish head. Waiters, speaking in Mandarin, delivered plates heated with green and red chiles.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Russia and North Korea pledge mutual defense.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un, the leaders of Russia and of North Korea, revived a Cold War-era mutual defense pledge between their two countries yesterday.

headline: Ancient Shipwreck Preserves a Deep Bronze Age Time Capsule
abstract: About a mile beneath the sea, the ship suggests that trade in the eastern Mediterranean Sea traveled much farther from the safety of land.
lead_paragraph: Remains of the oldest shipwreck ever discovered in deep water, and perhaps the oldest complete wreck in any water, have been located in the Mediterranean Sea about 56 miles off the coast of northern Israel.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Is It Possible to Desegregate the Nation’s Biggest School System?
abstract: A major lawsuit against racial inequality in New York City’s public schools is moving forward. Already, local districts in the city were trying different measures to diversify schools.
lead_paragraph: It is the story of many American cities. Despite decades of efforts, school districts have made little progress on desegregation.

headline: What Happened When Brooklyn Tried to Integrate Its Middle Schools
abstract: A new report found that many schools enrolled more racially and socioeconomically diverse groups of students without sparking a major exodus of families from public schools.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to solve a problem that has vexed public schools around the country for decades, one progressive section of New York undertook an ambitious plan to better integrate middle schools that were among the most homogenous in the city.

headline: Jimmy Fallon Mocks Kim Jong-un and Putin for Making Things Official
abstract: “Then they got a text from Trump that said, ‘Throuple?’” Fallon joked on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Quotation of the Day: When a Giant of the Game Became Mortal
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, June 20, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t know that Willie Mays ever got booed, even in the opposition ballpark. That is how loved he was.”

headline: No Corrections: June 20, 2024
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Thursday, June 20, 2024.

headline: Putin and Kim Deepen Their Friendship During State Visit
abstract: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, and Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, played up their growing bond as they agreed to a mutual-defense pledge.
lead_paragraph: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, and Russia’s president, Vladimir V. Putin, played up their growing bond as they agreed to a mutual-defense pledge.

headline: How to Give Yourself a Salon-Like Manicure at Home
abstract: Everything you need to know to take care of your nails like a professional — polish optional.
lead_paragraph: Giving yourself a good manicure isn’t just a question of clipping and filing your nails; for starters, the rest of your hands need love, too. With the right tools and gentle care, you can get salon-like results at home (which might also mean saving some money). Here’s what the experts recommend for nails that look healthy and polished, even if they’re not painted.

headline: Reimagining a Retirement Fit for Boomers, and Those Who Are Next in Line
abstract: The people who grew up with the Mouseketeers are now becoming re-imagineers. A Q. and A. with Michael Clinton, author of a book about second acts.
lead_paragraph: Michael Clinton is all about practicing what he preaches. His recent accomplishments include hiking to Mount Everest’s base camp; running marathons; earning a master’s degree at Columbia University in nonprofit management; becoming a first-time entrepreneur; and writing the best-seller “Roar: Into the Second Half of Your Life (Before It’s Too Late).”

headline: 36 Hours in Portland, Maine
abstract: Find your favorite lobster shack, take a ferry to an island and linger in bookstores over a weekend in this classic New England destination.
lead_paragraph: Find your favorite lobster shack, take a ferry to an island and linger in bookstores over a weekend in this classic New England destination.

headline: People Are Coming Out Younger and Younger. Then There Are People Like Me.
abstract: A collection of stories on the challenges and joys of coming out later in life.
lead_paragraph: This Pride Month, the Opinion columnist Charles Blow dives into the stories of people who embraced fluid sexual identities later in life.
