lead_paragraph: The best part about watching professional cornhole on TV may be listening to it. As aural A.S.M.R. goes, it ranks right up there with golf. First comes the satisfying plunk of the bag landing on the board’s slanted 18-millimeter grade-A Baltic birch surface, followed by a whispery thhhnnn as it slides upward toward the hole. And then if the shot is true, the polymer-resin pellets inside the bag rustle — shh-chh — as it drops through. Cornhole bags are the scalp massager of sports equipment.

headline: A Love Letter to Cricket, the Bookish Child’s Bible
abstract: For young magazine readers with literary pretensions, it wasn’t just our best option; it was our only option.
lead_paragraph: I first encountered Cricket, the literary magazine for children, at the home of my best friend, Elaine. Elaine was the most sophisticated child I knew. She always chose coffee ice cream. The tooth fairy brought her not crumpled dollar bills but smooth stones painted with miniature landscapes. She had traveled a lot, visiting family, and the Inwood apartment where she lived with her parents was filled with art and books and the smells of the elaborate meals her father cooked — the fact that he worked nights, and so was available to take us to museums after school, was itself glamorous. Even the apple juice they served us, in vividly painted Turkish tea glasses, tasted richer and finer than any I had ever tasted.

headline: His Photos Exposed a Bloody Crackdown, but His Identity Was a Secret
abstract: Na Kyung Taek’s photos bore witness — and helped bring international attention — to the military junta’s brutal suppression of a pro-democracy uprising in Gwangju, South Korea, in 1980.
lead_paragraph: It is an iconic image — a black-and-white photo of a blood-splattered student being clubbed by a paratrooper medic. It was the first photo to slip through the military cordon around Gwangju, South Korea, in 1980, exposing the brutal suppression of what would be known as the Gwangju Democratization Movement.

headline: A Universe of Inspirations Swirls Within ‘Janet Planet’
abstract: The playwright Annie Baker shares the artistic influences behind her feature film debut.
lead_paragraph: Annie Baker has amassed multiple awards for her idiosyncratic and deeply observed plays, including the Pulitzer Prize for her 2013 drama “The Flick.” Baker has always loved the movies — “The Flick,” about three young workers sweeping up popcorn and discussing movies in a broken-down central Massachusetts theater, is something of an ode to the cinema — but has never directed a film before now.

headline: The Opaque Industry Secretly Inflating Prices for Prescription Drugs
abstract: Pharmacy benefit managers are driving up drug costs for millions of people, employers and the government.
lead_paragraph: Americans are paying too much for prescription drugs.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in Prague
abstract: A three-bedroom loft in an revamped factory, a two-bedroom apartment in a 16th-century house, and a detached villa in a leafy residential area.
lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom loft-style apartment is on the ninth floor of a 14-story former aircraft parts factory built in 1925. The industrial building, in Prague’s southern Modrany district, has been renovated and transformed into the Vanguard, a luxury loft complex with a car lift, concierge services, a rooftop terrace with a sauna, and a wellness center with a glass pool in a revamped nuclear bunker.

headline: Smiles Away From Home: Acts of Kindness That Saved the Trip
abstract: It can be easy to get caught up in the inevitable frustrations that travel brings. But appreciating the small things, like the help of strangers, can have outsized impacts.
lead_paragraph: Because of a rental car mishap, it was well after dark by the time Catherine Dupree and her father arrived in Canakkale, a city in northwestern Turkey, during a vacation in 2006. As they drove around the city, trying in vain to navigate to their hotel (this was well before the days of reliable mapping apps, like Waze), Ms. Dupree’s father spotted a man walking his dog and asked him for help.

headline: On Saturday, Mermaids Will Reign on Surf Avenue in Coney Island
abstract: The annual Mermaid Parade in Brooklyn is a tacky yet spectacular extravaganza.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.

headline: What J.D. Vance’s Transformation Tells Us About the Future of Democracy
abstract: Can populist leaders actually fix the world’s unsolvable problems?
lead_paragraph: Populism, offered as a solution to economic and cultural woes, has gained ground in Europe following a slew of recent elections. Across the pond, the Ohio senator and potential Trump running mate J.D. Vance is championing an American version of populist politics that is also gaining traction. On this week’s episode, the hosts discuss Vance’s embrace of the ideology and consider why many voters find it so appealing.

headline: An Ode to Gardens That’s Also a Bouquet of Ideas
abstract: In her latest book, Olivia Laing makes an impassioned case for the garden — as repository of natural beauty, as democratic ideal, as writerly inspiration.
lead_paragraph: Unlike Olivia Laing, I don’t much care for gardening. Like her, however, I’m very fond of gardens, provided my allergies are under control and there aren’t too many bugs around. What I love even more — and I suspect she feels the same way — is reading about gardens. I don’t know hellebore from hogweed, but an artfully arranged list of plant names is among my favorite poetic genres.

headline: 7 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: This crime drama follows the rise and fall of a fictional motorcycle club in the 1960s.

headline: The Trump Running Mate Who Would Threaten the Blue Wall
abstract: Rubio would offer Latinos the chance to vote for one of their own to be a heartbeat away from the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania has been political ground zero in presidential elections for nearly a quarter-century, and 2024 will be no different. Joe Biden carried his birth state by almost 82,000 votes in 2020 and will need to win it again this year.

headline: Well Beyond the U.S., Heat and Climate Extremes Are Hitting Billions
abstract: People all over the world are facing severe heat, floods and fire, aggravated by the use of fossil fuels. The year isn’t halfway done.
lead_paragraph: Poll workers. Pilgrims. Tourists on a hike.

headline: Workers Shouldn’t Have to Risk Their Lives in Heat Waves
abstract: Laws aren’t keeping pace with the risks climate change poses to workers laboring under sweltering conditions.
lead_paragraph: A record-breaking heat wave is cresting across the United States, with about 100 million people under extreme heat alerts. Local TV news stations, governors and health officials advise to plan accordingly, drink water, go to cooling centers if needed and above all, refrain from excess outdoor exertion.

headline: School Cellphone Bans Have Buzz, but May Be Hard to Enforce
abstract: California is the latest state to try to regulate the devices. But how far should the ban go? And will parents sign on?
lead_paragraph: When it comes to banning cellphones in schools, success could be determined by the details.

headline: Trump’s Bold Vision for America: Higher Prices!
abstract: Inflation is Biden’s weak spot. Matthew Yglesias argues that it may also be Trump’s.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has made inflation a central part of his campaign message. At his rallies, he rails against “the Biden inflation tax” and “crooked Joe’s inflation nightmare,” and promises that in a second Trump term, “inflation will be in full retreat.”

headline: How Media Outlets on the Left and Right Have Covered Fauci’s Book Tour
abstract: Progressive publications have quoted extensively from Dr. Fauci’s new book, heralding him as a hero for his work during the pandemic. Conservative outlets have cast him as a villain.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the former government scientist, has been on something of a media spree in recent weeks, and liberal and conservative media outlets have used very different tones to cover his appearances.

headline: Pharrell Williams Wants You to Smell Like Photosynthesis
abstract: The process influenced a new scent developed by the “Happy” singer for Louis Vuitton. Plus, a surprise at Valentino and a punk doyenne’s wardrobe at auction.
lead_paragraph: What does Pharrell Williams smell like? Something like sunshine in a bottle — or so he would have you believe.

headline: Trump’s Allies Say They’ll Enforce the Comstock Act. Believe Them.
abstract: Democrats should rally around a bill to overhaul the 1873 anti-vice law.
lead_paragraph: Until the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in 2022, it was hard for feminists to get Americans to take the threat of losing the constitutional right to abortion seriously. Describing Hillary Clinton’s inability, in 2016, to shake pro-choice voters out of their complacency, The New York Times’s Lisa Lerer and Elizabeth Dias wrote, “Internal campaign polling and focus groups showed that the issue did not resonate strongly with key groups of voters, because they did not believe Roe was truly at risk.”

headline: A Surgeon General Warning, The Disinformation Battle and The Rise of CryptoPACs
abstract: Will a social media warning really help children’s mental health?
lead_paragraph: The Surgeon General is calling for warning labels on social media platforms: Should Congress give his proposal a like? Then, former Stanford researcher Renée DiResta joins us to talk about her new book on modern propaganda and whether we are losing the war against disinformation. And finally, the Times reporter David Yaffe-Bellany stops by to tell us how crypto could reshape the 2024 elections.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 21, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the film “The Bikeriders.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the film “The Bikeriders.”

headline: The Lazy Authoritarianism of Donald Trump
abstract: The former president is no more prepared for a second term than he was for a first. He may even be less prepared.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump went to Capitol Hill last week to visit with House Republicans. According to most reports of the meeting, he rambled.

headline: 5 Things You Do That Keep Dentists in Business
abstract: These habits can cause a surprising amount of damage to your teeth, experts say.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I booked an emergency visit with my dentist for a cracked molar.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: This week's selection includes titles by Gabrielle Zevin, Peace Adzo Medie, Patrick Mackie and more.
lead_paragraph: This week's selection includes titles by Gabrielle Zevin, Peace Adzo Medie, Patrick Mackie and more.

headline: The Epitome of French Cool
abstract: Remembering pop icon Françoise Hardy.
lead_paragraph: Beloved pop star Françoise Hardy, who died last week, got her start in 1960s yé-yé music and became an icon of French cool. She was a talented songwriter and “a beast in the studio,” says Elisabeth Vincentelli, recording albums into her 70s despite a long battle with cancer. Vincentelli remembers Hardy’s voice and singular persona through her music.

headline: Dutch Fashion Designer Iris van Herpen Moves Into Art
abstract: “There’s more to me than only couture,” she said, previewing her first exhibition of sculpture. Catch it while you can: The show will last only 45 minutes.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch fashion designer Iris van Herpen, who counts Beyoncé, Björk and Tilda Swinton among her regular clients, is known for dazzling haute couture pieces that resemble sculpture.

headline: Our Reporter on How Pharmacy Benefit Managers Work
abstract: Pharmacy benefit managers are driving up drug costs for millions of people, employers and the government. New York Times pharmaceutical reporter, Rebecca Robbins, explains how.
lead_paragraph: Pharmacy benefit managers are driving up drug costs for millions of people, employers and the government. New York Times pharmaceutical reporter, Rebecca Robbins, explains how.

headline: In Iran Election, a New Target for Conservatives: The Government
abstract: A special presidential election campaign is featuring blistering attacks on the status quo by conservatives and the lone reformer alike.
lead_paragraph: The campaign billboards adorning the streets of Iran for the coming presidential election make grand promises: economic prosperity, an end to corruption, a free press, the reversal of a brain drain and a pledge from one candidate to “save the citizens” from all the woes afflicting the country.

headline: A Stuffed Pepper Recipe That Goes Hard on Spiced Chickpeas
abstract: Blanketed with cheese, this filling recipe is perfect for summer and surprisingly light.
lead_paragraph: Of all the vegetables you can stuff, sweet bell peppers are among the most amenable. Unlike eggplant, onions or zucchini, which need their guts scooped to make room, or cabbage or grape leaves, which first have to be blanched, bell peppers are ready to go. Just slice them in half, shake out the seeds (or don’t; they’re harmless), and they’re all set for any savory mixture you can think of.

headline: U.K.’s Richest Family Is Found Guilty of Exploiting Workers at Luxury Villa
abstract: A Swiss criminal court handed prison sentences to members of the Hinduja family for exploiting domestic workers at their villa in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: A Swiss court on Friday found members of Britain’s wealthiest family guilty of exploiting domestic workers at a luxury villa in Geneva, but acquitted them of the more serious charge of human trafficking.

headline: ‘Tiny Crime Fighters With Wings’: Bees Go to Work on a Virginia ‘Body Farm’
abstract: By studying bees and their honey near decomposing human tissue, researchers at George Mason University hope to give crime scene investigators a new tool for finding the hidden dead.
lead_paragraph: Deep in the woods in Northern Virginia last month, two human bodies were carried to a remote spot among the trees and left to decompose. As nature takes its course, the bodies will exude organic compounds into the air and soil. Flowers growing nearby will absorb traces of the decay, which pollinating bees will carry to hives.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 377, June 22, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: A Rubens Returns to a German Castle, 80 Years After It Was Stolen
abstract: The oil painting of a saint, looted from the castle in the closing weeks of World War II by the ducal family that once owned it, is being returned by a Buffalo museum.
lead_paragraph: Among the most valuable art treasures once held at Friedenstein Castle, a vast baroque palace in eastern Germany, was a series of five oil sketches depicting saints by Peter Paul Rubens that disappeared at the end of World War II.

headline: Trump Narrows Biden’s Cash Lead, and Heat Shatters Records
abstract: Plus, the Taylor Swift inflation effect.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: America’s Top Doctor on Why He Wants Warning Labels on Social Media
abstract: The surgeon general says parents should be aware that using the platforms might harm adolescents’ mental health.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains mentions of bullying and suicide.

headline: Overpaying for Medicine
abstract: Who is driving up drug costs for millions of people?
lead_paragraph: You probably already know some of the reasons prescription drugs are so expensive. Drugmakers charge as much as the market will bear. Health insurers and the government haven’t reined in prices.

headline: Amid Gaza War, Netanyahu Feuds With Military, His Coalition and Washington
abstract: As the Israeli prime minister’s allies pull him in multiple, contradictory directions, he has publicly focused on his conflict with the Biden administration.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu this week engaged in increasingly public spats with his military brass, his right-wing coalition partners and his most powerful supporter, the White House. The cascading conflicts — all with allies who are on his side in the battle against Hamas — have renewed difficult questions about the future of the war and about the Israeli leader’s own political survival.

headline: Editor Tapped to Lead Washington Post Won’t Take the Job
abstract: Robert Winnett will stay at The Daily Telegraph, after reports raised questions about his ties to unethical news gathering practices.
lead_paragraph: Robert Winnett, the editor selected to run The Washington Post, will not take up that position, after reports raised questions about his ties to unethical news gathering practices in Britain.

headline: How Billionaires Are Reshaping the Presidential Race
abstract: Wealthy donors including Timothy Mellon helped Donald Trump’s campaign out-raise President Biden’s last month, but Democratic supporters are still spending.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has rapidly erased his cash disadvantage against President Biden, out-raising his Democratic rival for a second straight month. Powering that fund-raising haul was a coterie of well-heeled supporters who donated millions shortly after the former president was convicted of 34 felony counts in New York.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 3: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by June 28 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced by July 10.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the third week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: Tips for Renting an E.V. for Your Summer Vacation
abstract: Even with more fast-charging stations available, having a smooth electric vehicle experience still takes planning, our columnist found.
lead_paragraph: Are you curious about electric vehicles but not ready to buy one? Renting one can help you see what it’s like — and some car rental companies are offering discounts.

headline: So Much for California’s Big November Anti-Tax Initiative
abstract: Businesses are fuming and cities are exhaling after the State Supreme Court blocked a ballot measure at the heart of a big fight in Sacramento.
lead_paragraph: Californians are used to big political fights over ballot measures, but the fights don’t usually end like this. On Thursday, the California Supreme Court unexpectedly cut short a gathering war over one of the most sweeping anti-tax proposals since the 1970s, before voters could even consider it.

headline: As Ukraine Expands Military Draft, Some Men Go Into Hiding
abstract: Fearful that conscription is a one-way ticket to bloody trench warfare, the men spend their days holed up at home to avoid draft officers who roam the streets.
lead_paragraph: First, Vladyslav stopped going into Kyiv’s city center to avoid draft officers checking papers. Then he stopped exercising at the gym because of patrols in his neighborhood. Now, he spends most of his days holed up in his apartment, often using his binoculars to watch officers serving draft notices to commuters leaving a nearby subway station.

headline: A Ride in a Chemical-Sniffing Van Shows How Heat Amps Up Pollution
abstract: In heat waves, chemicals like formaldehyde and ozone can form more readily in the air, according to researchers driving mobile labs in New York City this week.
lead_paragraph: Two vans loaded with precision instruments trundled along the streets of New York and New Jersey in the heat earlier this week, sniffing for toxic chemicals in the air.

headline: In Russia, Fear of the Past Is Ever-Present
abstract: The trauma Russians endured during the transition from communism to capitalism in the 1990s helps explain why Vladimir Putin remains in power.
lead_paragraph: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What do we fear? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.

headline: 260 McNuggets? McDonald’s Ends A.I. Drive-Through Tests Amid Errors
abstract: Ordering mistakes frustrated customers during nearly three years of tests. But competitors like White Castle and Wendy’s say their A.I. ordering systems have been highly accurate.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly three years since McDonald’s announced that it was partnering with IBM to develop a drive-through order taker powered by artificial intelligence, videos popped up on social media showing confused and frustrated customers trying to correct comically inaccurate meals.

headline: 1924: Trial Trip Date Set for Zeppelin
abstract: The giant airship was scheduled to fly across Germany to Denmark, Sweden and back. A flight across the Atlantic to the United States was tentatively planned to follow.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The giant Zeppelin ZR-3 probably will make its first big trial trip about July 5, it was announced at Friedrichshafen today. The ship will carry several American naval officers and will fly across Germany to Copenhagen and Stockholm, returning to Friedrichshafen by way of Berlin, but without landing here.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Law Disarming Domestic Abusers
abstract: The decision amounted to a retreat from what had been an unbroken series of major decisions expanding gun rights that started in 2008.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that the government can take guns away from people subject to restraining orders for domestic violence, limiting the sweep of a blockbuster decision in 2022 that had vastly expanded Second Amendment rights.

headline: Finally, a Euros for a Whole Continent
abstract: Eastern European countries who have in recent years lagged behind their continent’s bigger names are having their day in the sun in Germany.
lead_paragraph: Edi Rama’s best friend during the World Cup summer of 1982 just so happened to be the one person he knew who owned a color television. So every evening, Rama would find himself crammed into his kitchen with countless others, desperately hoping that the fuzzy, flickering signal would hold.

headline: Bragg Asks Judge to Extend Trump’s Gag Order, Citing Deluge of Threats
abstract: Donald J. Trump claims the order has unfairly restricted his free speech rights ahead of his sentencing on 34 felony counts. He has nonetheless attacked the judge, prosecutor and justice system.
lead_paragraph: Manhattan prosecutors said Friday that a judge should keep in place major elements of the gag order imposed on Donald J. Trump before his criminal trial, citing dozens of threats that have been made against officials connected to the case.

headline: Why Was Maine Sweltering?
abstract: A shifting weather front and climate change temporarily turned the temperate state subtropical.
lead_paragraph: Typically, Maine is a summer destination for people who want to cool off.

headline: Conan O’Brien Doesn’t Matter*
abstract: *That’s his opinion. And yet he’s setting a new standard for what life after late-night can look like. (Hint: It’s a lot like what he did on talk shows.)
lead_paragraph: After hosting talk shows for nearly three decades, Conan O’Brien has come to believe that longevity is overrated. The first time he made this point to me was in April at a restaurant in New York, when he proposed that all statues and monuments should be made with durable soap that dissolves in seven years. One month later, in his office in Los Angeles, down the hall from his podcast studio, he went further, declaring himself anti-graveyard.

headline: At the Royal Ballet, Taking the Measure of Ashton’s Genius
abstract: Many remarkable performances fueled the Royal’s mini-festival of ballets by Frederick Ashton, the company’s founding choreographer.
lead_paragraph: Dance, people like to say, is a universal language. But ballet isn’t. Rather, it’s a language with many sharply contrasting dialects. Tradition, training and temperament all shape distinctive styles, and the English style of classical dance, embodied by the Royal Ballet, was largely shaped by Frederick Ashton (1904-1988), the company’s founding choreographer.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include demon baby, a cursed chef and all kinds of people trapped in hellish situations.
lead_paragraph: Arkasha Stevenson’s prequel to “The Omen” smashes and remixes genres — body and pregnancy horror, nunsploitation, Gothic melodrama — to tell a terrifying and visually striking origin story about an ungodly little boy named Damien.

headline: Students Kissed Her Feet for Good Luck. Now She’s Missing Her Head.
abstract: A replica of the Athena Giustiniani that greeted students at Wells College for more than 150 years was accidentally decapitated in the scramble to close the institution forever.
lead_paragraph: A marble statue of the Roman goddess of wisdom that presided over Wells College for 156 years, surviving both a devastating fire in 1888 and an attempted kidnapping in 1975, was embraced by students as a symbol of resilience for generations.

headline: Time to Make, and Eat, Some Seriously Good Sandwiches
abstract: Halloumi with lettuce and tomato, spiced lamb on an English muffin and a Scuttlebutt.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. What’s your favorite store-bought sandwich? In New York, I’m partial to the hot roast beef from Defonte’s in Brooklyn, the Carmine’s Special at Del Fiore’s in Patchogue and the Reuben with coleslaw at the Country Store in Orient.

headline: 15 Great Donald Sutherland Performances to Stream
abstract: Whether in the lead or a supporting role, the actor’s immense talent and range were apparent in six decades of performances.
lead_paragraph: A lithe and seductively charming actor who worked consistently for more than six decades in Hollywood, often as a leading man, Donald Sutherland died on Thursday at 88. As a thinking man’s sex symbol whose versatility made him equally persuasive in irreverent comedies and heart-rending dramas, Sutherland worked with major directors across multiple eras, including Robert Altman, Federico Fellini and Clint Eastwood and looked comfortable in both modern dress and period garb. His unusual height — he was 6-foot-4 — and sonorous voice gave Sutherland an authoritative gait, but he was given more toward gentle-giant sensitivity than masculine swagger. Narrowing his great performances down to 15 films is no easy task — there’s at least another 15 where these came from — but this selection of streamable titles is a testament to his immense talent and range.

headline: Is Missouri About to Execute an Innocent Man?
abstract: The case against Marcellus Williams is far from settled.
lead_paragraph: On June 4, the Missouri Supreme Court set a September execution date for a man named Marcellus Williams. There’s a profound problem with this ruling, however. Williams is most likely innocent of the charges against him.

headline: Boeing May Evade Criminal Charges for Violating Settlement
abstract: The Justice Department could require the aircraft maker to install an independent federal monitor to oversee safety and quality issues. Prosecutors have not made a final call on bringing charges.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department is considering allowing Boeing to avoid criminal prosecution for violating the terms of a 2021 settlement related to problems with the company’s 737 Max 8 model that led to two deadly plane crashes in 2018 and 2019, according to people familiar with the discussions.

headline: Israel says it struck a missile launch site in a Gaza ‘humanitarian zone.’
abstract: The Israeli military said on Friday that it had struck a missile launch site belonging to the Palestinian Islamic Jihad militant group that had been embedded in a shelter for displaced people in a “humanitarian zone” of Khan Younis, in southern Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said on Friday that it had struck a missile launch site belonging to the Palestinian Islamic Jihad militant group that had been embedded in a shelter for displaced people in a “humanitarian zone” of Khan Younis, in southern Gaza.

headline: Israeli Official Describes Secret Government Bid to Cement Control of West Bank
abstract: Israeli judges have long ruled that Israel’s control of the territory is a temporary military occupation and complies with international law. A powerful minister’s recent speech, caught on tape, suggested the government is trying to change that.
lead_paragraph: An influential member of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition told settlers in the Israeli-occupied West Bank that the government is engaged in a stealthy effort to irreversibly change the way the territory is governed, to cement Israel’s control over it without being accused of formally annexing it.

headline: Looking Ahead to the Biden-Trump Debate
abstract: Readers make their wishes known about the debate. Also: The Ten Commandments in public classrooms; asylum seekers; Black women’s health; Justice Alito’s wife.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Folger Library Wants to Reintroduce You to Shakespeare
abstract: After an $80 million expansion, the Folger Shakespeare Library is reopening with a more welcoming approach — and all 82 of its First Folios on view.
lead_paragraph: Social media is awash with pictures of jaw-dropping libraries, elaborately styled home bookshelves and all manner of drool-worthy Library Porn. But for understated dazzle, it’s hard to compete with a wall in the new basement galleries of the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, D.C.

headline: Oil Projects Must Consider Full Climate Impact, Top U.K. Court Rules
abstract: Previously, local council and planning groups in Britain had to weigh only the planet-warming emissions from their own operations.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s highest court has ruled that local councils and planning groups must consider the full environmental impact of new fossil fuel projects when deciding whether to approve them, a decision that could have far-reaching consequences and that climate activists hailed as a major victory.

headline: Cyberattacks Disrupt Car Sales by Dealers in U.S. and Canada
abstract: The attacks on a software provider, CDK Global, affect systems that store customer records and automate paperwork and data for sales and service.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of auto dealers across the United States and Canada are suffering disruptions to their operations as a result of cyberattacks on a provider of critical software and data services used in auto retailing.

headline: It’s the Summer of Powell and Pressburger in New York
abstract: The British filmmaking team were maestros of Technicolor and so much more. If you don’t know their work, your favorite directors do.
lead_paragraph: Toward the end of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s “Black Narcissus” (1947), set at a convent high in the Himalayas, the crazed Sister Ruth sneaks up behind her perceived nemesis, Sister Clodagh, who is ringing the convent’s cliffside bell, and gives her a good shove.

headline: Trump Media Stock Down 46% Since Former President’s Conviction
abstract: The parent of Truth Social has come under pressure this month, most recently after early investors were given approval to sell a fresh chunk of shares.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s stake in his social media company is worth about half of what it was before his conviction on charges of falsifying business records to cover up a sex scandal during the 2016 presidential campaign

headline: Tracking a Single Day at the National Domestic Violence Hotline
abstract: Some major Supreme Court decisions this term, including a ruling that allowed the government to prohibit people subject to restraining orders from having guns, have underscored the pervasiveness of domestic violence.
lead_paragraph: Some major Supreme Court decisions this term, including a ruling that allowed the government to prohibit people subject to restraining orders from having guns, have underscored the pervasiveness of domestic violence.

headline: The Supreme Court Dials Down the Chaos on Guns
abstract: Previous attempts to broaden the Second Amendment don’t apply to a domestic abuser, eight justices ruled.
lead_paragraph: Violent people who pose a clear and immediate threat to the physical safety of others should not be allowed to possess firearms. That seems like a statement any reasonable person living in a self-governing society can readily agree with. And yet on Friday morning, it took the United States Supreme Court 103 pages of opinions, concurrences and dissent to work it all out.

headline: Swimming Moves to an N.F.L. Stadium for the 2028 Olympics
abstract: Organizers of the Los Angeles Olympic Games hope that a huge venue for swimming, a marquee event, will draw crowds and generate much-needed revenue.
lead_paragraph: The organizers of the 2028 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles have promised to have the most ambitious sports program ever and sell more tickets than any other Games.

headline: On the House Floor, Republicans Gag Mentions of Trump’s Conviction
abstract: During official proceedings of the G.O.P.-controlled chamber, speaking about former President Donald J. Trump’s felony conviction has been forbidden, while disparaging President Biden and Democrats is routine.
lead_paragraph: The floor of the United States House of Representatives is supposed to be a dignified place, where lawmakers refer to each other as “gentleman” or “gentle lady,” speak only to the presiding officer, and never engage in personally disparaging remarks against rivals, an offense known as “engaging in personalities.”

headline: Ángeles Flórez Peón, Spanish Civil War’s Last Militiawoman, Dies at 105
abstract: She was revered as an essential guardian of the country’s memory of war and repression long after the Franco dictatorship.
lead_paragraph: Ángeles Flórez Peón was 17 when she braved mortar and artillery fire to bring food to her fellow Republican volunteers in the trenches of northern Spain during the Spanish Civil War.

headline: The Everything Guide to Partying (Without Regrets)
abstract: Forty-three highly sociable people, from Ivy Getty to Rufus Wainwright, offer tips on how to be a stellar guest and a gracious host. Read this before you say yes to the next invitation.
lead_paragraph: Forty-three highly sociable people, from Ivy Getty to Rufus Wainwright, offer tips on how to be a stellar guest and a gracious host. Read this before you say yes to the next invitation.

headline: $3.34 Trillion
abstract: The market value on Tuesday of Nvidia, whose chips have made it possible to create A.I. systems.
lead_paragraph: It’s a number that kept going up, with few signs of slowing down.

headline: Hawaii Settles With Young Plaintiffs in Climate Case
abstract: The state agreed to take steps to cut greenhouse gas emissions from transportation. It’s the latest of several victories for youth-led climate lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: The government of Hawaii on Thursday settled a lawsuit with a group of young people who had sued the state’s Department of Transportation over its use of fossil fuels. It was the latest in a series of victories around the world in cases filed by young plaintiffs.

headline: Kevin Costner Announces That He Is Done With ‘Yellowstone’
abstract: The actor and director is turning his attention to his ambitious film series about post-Civil War America.
lead_paragraph: It’s official: Kevin Costner will not be returning to television’s hit neo-western “Yellowstone” for its final episodes or for any future “Yellowstone” offshoot, ending speculation about his involvement with one of TV’s biggest hits in recent years.

headline: Southwest Plane Begins Descent Too Early Over Oklahoma City
abstract: Its low altitude had triggered an automated warning and startled some residents near Oklahoma City, where it eventually landed safely.
lead_paragraph: A Southwest Airlines plane descended prematurely on Wednesday over Oklahoma City, startling residents miles from the airport, before regaining altitude and then landing safely.

headline: American Express Buys Tock Dining Reservation Service
abstract: The credit card company acquired Tock, a restaurant reservation company, after buying its rival, Resy, in 2019. Its cardholders spent $100 billion in restaurants in 2023, the company said.
lead_paragraph: The credit card giant American Express has acquired Tock, a restaurant reservation and event management company, from the digital commerce platform Squarespace for $400 million, American Express said on Friday.

headline: Griffin Dunne on His Joyful and Tragic Family Memoir
abstract: In “The Friday Afternoon Club,” the actor and director recalls his years growing up around performers, writers and the Hollywood set.
lead_paragraph: Every family has its stories, and every family has its drama — and some families, like the one the actor and director Griffin Dunne was born into, have an excess of both. His uncle was the writer John Gregory Dunne, his aunt was Joan Didion and his father was Dominick Dunne, who became famous for his Vanity Fair dispatches from the trial of the man who killed his daughter (and Griffin’s sister) Dominique.

headline: Nathan Hare, 91, Forceful Founder of First Black Studies Program, Dies
abstract: Seeking to bring the ideas of Black power into the classroom — and coining the term “ethnic studies” — he clashed with a university as well as allies on the left.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Hare, a sociologist who helped lead a five-month strike by faculty members and students at what is now San Francisco State University, resulting in an agreement in 1969 to create the country’s first program in Black studies, with him as its director, died at a hospital in San Francisco on June 10. He was 91.

headline: Anthony O’Reilly, Flashy Irish Tycoon Who Led Unflashy Heinz, Dies at 88
abstract: He had success on the rugby pitch and in boardrooms, building a media empire and boosting Heinz’s profits, but his fortunes buckled in the global financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: Anthony J.F. O’Reilly, a charming, high-flying, Irish-born former chairman of the H.J. Heinz Company, who also owned newspapers, luxury brands and trophy homes in France and the Bahamas, only to lose nearly everything in his eighth decade, died on May 18 in Dublin. He was 88.

headline: How Misleading Videos Are Trailing Biden as He Battles Age Doubts
abstract: A flurry of recent clips, many of them edited or lacking context, laid bare a major challenge for the president as he tries to persuade voters he has the energy for a second term.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has many adversaries in this year’s election. There are his Republican opponent, former President Donald J. Trump, and the independent candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

headline: 10 Standout R.E.M. Deep Cuts
abstract: Hear a pick from each of the band’s first 10 albums.
lead_paragraph: Last week R.E.M. was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame, an event that sparked a lot of FOMO from me, your guest newsletter writer (the band briefly reunited in New York; I was out of town) and text conversations with my fellow R.E.M. devotees. (Does this fandom have a name? The Sleepyheads?)

headline: Where Parisians Escape to for Secret Beaches and Oyster Cabanas
abstract: A guide to France’s Cap Ferret, with insider tips from Philippe Starck and three other locals.
lead_paragraph: A sandy, 15-mile spit that reaches across Arcachon Bay like a protective arm, Lège-Cap Ferret, on France’s western coast, is that country’s answer to New York’s Montauk, albeit dialed back a decade or two. Cap Ferret — not to be confused with Cap Ferrat, the glitzy, southeastern French peninsula with almost the same name — is a 30-minute ferry ride from the seaside town of Arcachon and features a varied, contrary, landscape: oyster farms on the tranquil lagoon, or bassin side, and a broad surf beach on the Atlantic side (“When there are waves, they are gigantic,” says the designer and architect Philippe Starck), which has attracted Parisians since the 1950s.

headline: This Easy Brunch Dish Feels Like a Trip to Italy
abstract: Crisp on the outside, tender on the inside, savory farinata brings a taste of the Mediterranean coast to your kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Rogers, a founder of the famed River Cafe in London, brought cash to a parking lot in Pisa, Italy, to meet a vendor she had connected with through a Ligurian acquaintance.

headline: The Cottage Industry Spawned From a Video Game
abstract: The masochistic gameplay loop of Elden Ring — live, die, die and die again — sprouted a cottage industry of streamers displaying their misery to audiences all over the world. Zachary Small, a culture reporter for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: The masochistic gameplay loop of Elden Ring — live, die, die and die again — sprouted a cottage industry of streamers displaying their misery to audiences all over the world. Zachary Small, a culture reporter for The New York Times, explains.

headline: U.S. Moves Ahead With Plan to Restrict Chinese Technology Investments
abstract: The Treasury Department unveiled rules to curb financing of Chinese semiconductors, quantum computers and artificial intelligence systems.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Friday outlined its plans to curb new American investment in critical Chinese technology industries that could be used to enhance China’s military, further straining economic ties with Beijing at a time when trade tensions are rising.

headline: Gracie Abrams and Taylor Swift’s Tortured Duet, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Mavis Staples, Jamie xx featuring Robyn, Rakim and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: F.D.A. Authorizes First Menthol-Flavored E-Cigarettes
abstract: The decision came less than two months after the Biden administration delayed a decision on whether to ban traditional menthol-flavored cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said on Friday that it had approved the first menthol-flavored e-cigarettes in the United States, less than two months after the Biden administration delayed a fiercely contested decision on whether to ban traditional menthol cigarettes.

headline: Sure, Knowledge Is Power, but Ignorance Is Underrated
abstract: The human tendency to ignore the truth is often seen as a flaw, but it can be useful, too.
lead_paragraph: We crave knowledge. Only ostriches stick their heads in the sand. Right? Well, then, how can we explain the following?

headline: Is It OK to Secretly Medicate Your Manic Husband?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on marital deception.
lead_paragraph: A woman I know often complains about her “manic” husband. He is a war veteran in his late 50s who owns a very successful business and is the primary breadwinner for their family. (They have no children.) The wife, a woman in her early 60s who works part time and is dependent on his income, recently told me she dissolves melatonin in the water he takes with him to work in order to “calm him down.” She said, “I told him it was a nutritional supplement, something to help him because he sometimes doesn’t eat lunch.” I looked a bit shocked at her confession, and she immediately justified her actions by saying: “You don’t have to live with him. He doesn’t take his medications. Now he’s calmer.” She did not ask his permission to add melatonin to his drinking water.

headline: Review: ‘Orphan Black: Echoes’ Revisits a Sci-Fi Favorite
abstract: The new sequel to “Orphan Black” raises interesting questions about the nature of memory but misses the charm of that show’s star, Tatiana Maslany.
lead_paragraph: Congratulations to the ominous vat of goo community and its ever-expanding sci-fi reign. Where else might human-seeming characters emerge if not from an ominous vat of goo? They gasp and look around frantically. Ah yes, a star covered in goo — that’s how you know the bad guys are up to something.

headline: Charli XCX and Lorde End the Rumors on a Refreshing Remix
abstract: Lorde adds guest vocals to Charli XCX’s “Girl, So Confusing,” a song that muses on the complexities of female friendship, and helps create something revelatory.
lead_paragraph: To a lot of people these days, “ambivalent pop music” is an oxymoron. Catchy hooks tend to streamline complex emotions into universal, legible sentiments, temporarily dividing the world into teams: the heartbreakers vs. the victims, the happy vs. the sad, the boys vs. the girls. Infectious as they are, many of the songs on Charli XCX’s incisive sixth album, “Brat,” refuse to take sides, making them difficult to discuss in the explainer-generating, SEO-baiting grammar of modern pop standom. How refreshing.

headline: 3 Dead and 11 Injured in Shooting at Arkansas Grocery Store
abstract: Two police officers were injured in the attack at the Mad Butcher store in Fordyce, and the shooter was injured, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed and 11 others injured in a shooting on Friday morning at a grocery store in Central Arkansas, the police said.

headline: Louisiana’s Ten Commandments Law Signals a Broader Christian Agenda
abstract: Gov. Jeff Landry wants his state to be at the forefront of a national movement to advance legislation with a Christian worldview.
lead_paragraph: The crowd at Our Lady of Fatima Catholic School in Lafayette, La., applauded Gov. Jeff Landry as he signed bill after bill this week on public education in the state, making it clear he believed God was guiding his hand.

headline: A New Option to Treat Sleep Apnea: Weight-Loss Drugs
abstract: New research showed that tirzepatide, the compound in Zepbound, improved symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea.
lead_paragraph: Sue Clasen kept trying to manage her sleep apnea. She knew a CPAP machine would help her breathe through the night, but none of the masks she wore with it were comfortable enough to actually fall asleep. She bought a special hanger to hold the machine’s hose so she wouldn’t get tangled up in it. She found a pillow with cutouts to cradle the mask. Some nights, she woke up feeling as if she were drowning in the air that streamed out of the machine.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: This week, the hosts riffed on the heat wave that pummeled the U.S. as well as Trump trying to argue that he’s more mentally fit to lead than President Biden. Here’s what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: This week, the hosts riffed on the heat wave that pummeled the U.S. as well as Trump trying to argue that he’s more mentally fit to lead than President Biden. Here’s what they had to say.

headline: Nevada Judge Throws Out State’s Case Against Fake Electors
abstract: The judge said the state chose the wrong venue to file a case against the Republicans who tried to declare Donald J. Trump the winner of the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: A Nevada judge on Friday threw out the state’s case against the six Republicans who claimed to be presidential electors and tried to declare Donald J. Trump the winner of the 2020 election. The judge, Mary Kay Holthus, said that state prosecutors had chosen the wrong venue to file the case.

headline: Investing in Employee Happiness, One Benefit at a Time
abstract: How Humana helps employers gain a competitive edge.
lead_paragraph: How Humana helps employers gain a competitive edge.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Matthew Yglesias
abstract: The June 21, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Matthew Yglesias. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: DeSantis Vetoes All Arts Grants in Florida
abstract: Gov. Ron DeSantis gave no explanation for zeroing out the $32 million in grants that were approved by state lawmakers.
lead_paragraph: For the past 10 days, Richard Russell has been rattled, poring over budgets and working the phones in an attempt to limit the consequences of Gov. Ron DeSantis’s veto pen.

headline: What You Need to Know About the Power Grid During the Latest Heat Wave
abstract: So far, aided by growing solar capacity, heat-related outages have been limited.
lead_paragraph: The heat wave has broken temperature records across the Midwest and Northeast and put 100 million people under heat advisories. But there’s a silver lining, at least so far: Experts say the energy grid has held up well, thanks in part to increased solar capacity — a promising indicator of its resilience this summer.

headline: Official Death Toll From Hajj Pilgrimage Climbs Into the Hundreds
abstract: Searing heat in Saudi Arabia appeared to at least contribute to many of the deaths.
lead_paragraph: During the annual hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia, one of the most important events on the Muslim calendar, at least 450 people died under a scorching sun as they prayed at sacred sites around the holy city of Mecca.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, June 22, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: The Supreme Court Upheld a Law Disarming Domestic Abusers
abstract: Also, dangerous heat is rising around the world. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court, in an 8-to-1 decision, ruled today that the government can take guns away from people subject to restraining orders for domestic violence.

headline: In Montana, Abortion Rights Groups Submit Signatures for Ballot Measure in November
abstract: The measure would affirm the right to abortion in the State Constitution. Democrats hope that it will help Senator Jon Tester in his bid for re-election.
lead_paragraph: A coalition of abortion rights groups in Montana announced Friday that it had submitted enough signatures to put a measure on the November ballot that would ask voters to affirm a right to reproductive freedom in the State Constitution.

headline: Trump’s PAC, Which Pays His Legal Bills, Is Nearly Out of Cash
abstract: A fund-raising pact with the Republican Party is expected to replenish the money Donald J. Trump paid his lawyers as he faced three indictments and finished a criminal trial in New York.
lead_paragraph: The political account that former President Donald J. Trump has been using to pay his sizable legal bills has dwindled to less than $4 million in the bank, after accounting for its debt, according to new federal election filings.

headline: Putin Shows He Can Antagonize the U.S. Far Afield From Ukraine
abstract: His support for North Korea’s military ambitions showed he can inflict pain on the U.S. and its NATO allies in ways beyond aggression in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: When the United States and its Western allies declared that Ukraine could strike Russian territory with their weapons, President Vladimir V. Putin began ratcheting up the threats.

headline: U.N. Chief Warns Israel and Hezbollah of the Risk of a Wider War
abstract: “The people of the region and the people of the world cannot afford Lebanon to become another Gaza,” he said.
lead_paragraph: After months of escalating violence along Israel’s northern border with Lebanon, the chief of the United Nations warned on Friday that “the risk for the conflict in the Middle East to widen is real — and must be avoided.”

headline: Taylor Wily, ‘Hawaii Five-0’ and ‘Forgetting Sarah Marshall’ Actor, Dies at 55
abstract: He spent his early career as a professional sumo wrestler.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Wily, who played a shrimp truck vendor and a police informant on the television reboot of “Hawaii Five-0,” and who had earlier been an acclaimed professional sumo wrestler, died on Thursday in Hurricane, Utah. He was 55.

headline: The Other Showdown to Watch Next Week
abstract: A New York Democratic primary sheds light on the split over Gaza and the party’s leftward shift.
lead_paragraph: Hi there! Today, we’re looking at a political brawl that’s become a high-stakes battle for the future of the Democratic Party. Then I’ll take you behind the scenes of a photo shoot featuring Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s ravens. My colleague Nicholas Fandos, who covers New York politics, starts us off. — Jess Bidgood

headline: New Drug Provides Total Protection From H.I.V. in Trial of Young African Women
abstract: An injection given just twice a year could herald a breakthrough in protecting the population that has the highest infection rates.
lead_paragraph: Researchers and activists in the trenches of the long fight against H.I.V. got a rare piece of exciting news this week: Results from a large clinical trial in Africa showed that a twice-yearly injection of a new antiviral drug gave young women total protection from the virus.

headline: A Presidential Death Sends Iranians to the Polls. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Iran will hold a special election on Friday to replace former President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash in May.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s election for its next president will take place a year early, on June 28, after President Ebrahim Raisi died in a helicopter crash last month. The vote will usher the Islamic republic into new leadership amid domestic discontent, voter apathy and regional turmoil.

headline: Judge in Trump Documents Case Hears Arguments Over Special Counsel
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon held a hearing to consider a question that has been quickly dismissed in other cases: whether there is a constitutional basis for the appointment of a special counsel.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s defense team tried on Friday to persuade the judge overseeing the national security documents case to dismiss the indictment, pushing a long-shot argument that the special counsel, Jack Smith, was not properly appointed.

headline: Travis Scott Wasted No Time Putting His Mug Shot on a T-Shirt
abstract: A commemoration of the rapper’s brief arrest in Miami Beach, the shirt reinforced the idea that for some celebrities, a brush with the law can be good for business.
lead_paragraph: After a night of partying in South Florida, the superstar rapper Travis Scott ended his Thursday with two more charges on his record and one more product on his website than he started with.

headline: Man Who Attacked Nancy Pelosi’s Husband Is Convicted in California Trial
abstract: In 2022, David DePape broke into Ms. Pelosi’s San Francisco home and eventually beat her husband with a hammer.
lead_paragraph: David DePape was convicted on Friday of five charges, brought by the state of California, for breaking into Nancy Pelosi’s home in 2022 and beating her husband with a hammer.

headline: Trump Allies Begin First Line of Attack Against Arizona Election Case
abstract: The challenges from defendants charged with trying to overturn the 2020 election will be a test case for a new but little-known state law aimed at curbing political prosecutions.
lead_paragraph: Allies of former President Donald J. Trump charged in a sweeping Arizona election case on Friday began filing what is expected to be a series of challenges, seizing on a new state law aimed at curbing litigation and prosecutions involving political figures.

headline: Florida to Pay Millions to Victims of Abuses at Notorious Reform School
abstract: A $20 million program will give financial restitution to students who endured abuse and neglect at the hands of the state.
lead_paragraph: The horrors inflicted on hundreds of boys at a notorious reform school in the Florida Panhandle remain excruciating for survivors to recount, all these years later. Forced labor. Brutal floggings. Sexual abuse.

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Finale Recap: Answers Through the Tears
abstract: Ncuti’s Gatwa’s first season as the Doctor closes with a typically ambitious episode.
lead_paragraph: If Ncuti Gatwa’s first full run of episodes manning the TARDIS has been characterized by anything, it’s big swings.

headline: The Culture Wars Came to a California Suburb. A Leader Has Been Ousted.
abstract: Voters recalled a Southern California school board president after his conservative majority approved policies on critical race theory and transgender issues.
lead_paragraph: From the start, the three conservative board members of the Temecula Valley Unified School District made clear where they stood. On the same night in December 2022 that they were sworn in as a majority, they passed a resolution banning critical race theory from classrooms in their Southern California district.

headline: Trading Card Enthusiasts?
abstract: Hoang-Kim Vu’s latest themeless puzzle will have you singing while you solve.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an elegant, bustling grid from Hoang-Kim Vu, his third Saturday construction and 11th overall for The New York Times. A lot of the middle-length terms are exceptionally odd, new or unusual, and the marquee entries at 20- and 51-Across are debuts with terrific clues. Of course, the moment I laid eyes on the second across clue, I got “Kokomo” stuck in my head and had to solve the rest of the puzzle with half of my brain droning “da-da-da, da-da-da, daaaaa da-da-da-da-da.” Fortunately, the half that knows other stuff was available.

headline: Man Charged With Murder in Stabbing at Manhattan Subway Station
abstract: The killing occurred during a dispute between two men just before 6 p.m. Friday at the West 175th Street A train station.
lead_paragraph: A Manhattan man was arrested early Saturday and charged with murder in a fatal stabbing the night before at an Upper Manhattan subway station, the police said.

headline: It’s Fine if Investing Bores You. Some Money Pros Feel the Same Way.
abstract: For many financial professionals, investing is just a tool to help people achieve their meaningful life goals.
lead_paragraph: For a certain type of money professional, there is a particular question that is decidedly unwelcome, and it tends to come up in a variety of social settings: Got any hot investment tips?

headline: Slur by Francis Lays Bare the Church’s Contradictions on Homosexuality
abstract: The pope used homophobic slang and cautioned prelates about admitting gay men into seminaries. But ordination has also long been a refuge for gay faithful.
lead_paragraph: When reports spread that Pope Francis had used an offensive anti-gay slur while speaking to Italian bishops at a conference last month, many Catholics were both shocked and baffled. How could a pope known for his openness to and acceptance of L.G.B.T.Q. people use homophobic slang and caution prelates about admitting gay men into seminaries?

headline: For Turkish Germans, Heart Overrules Home at Euro 2024
abstract: A soccer championship has doubled as a test of identity for millions of Germans with Turkish roots. For many, picking one team to support was an easy decision.
lead_paragraph: Erkan Aykan does not require a second invitation to share his claim to fame. He grew up in a Turkish family in Gelsenkirchen, an industrial city nestled in the heart of Germany’s Ruhr valley. Somewhat more famously, so did Ilkay Gundogan, the captain of the country’s soccer team. “I know his cousins,” he said, proudly.

headline: Putin Came to Asia to Disrupt, and He Succeeded
abstract: His embrace of North Korea and deal making with Vietnam injected more potential threats into a region already strained by Taiwan tensions and South China Sea clashes.
lead_paragraph: Four days in Asia. That’s all President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia needed to anger Washington, undermine Beijing and rattle a collection of Indo-Pacific nations already scrambling to cope with a jumbled world order.

headline: U.S.D.A. Avocado Inspectors Will Start Returning to Mexican Packing Plants
abstract: The inspections in Michoacán, the Mexican state responsible for most avocado exports to the U.S., were suspended last weekend because of security concerns.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. ambassador to Mexico, Ken Salazar, announced on Friday that inspections of avocados and mangos made by U.S. Agriculture Department workers in Michoacán, a state in western Mexico, would “gradually” resume.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Heart Overrules Home for Turkish Germans Picking a Euros Team
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Having two hearts in one chest is not unusual for migrants anywhere in the world.”

headline: Corrections: June 22, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 22, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on June 16 about Chinese swimmers who participated in the Olympics despite having tested positive for drugs years earlier misstated the nature of clenbuterol, a drug banned by the World Anti-Doping Agency. It is an anabolic agent, not a steroid.

headline: 2 Teenagers Missing in Waters Off Beach in Queens in Suspected Drownings
abstract: Authorities suspended their search Saturday for the boys, 16 and 17, who were last seen on Friday being overtaken by a large wave in the waters off Jacob Riis Park.
lead_paragraph: Authorities on Saturday afternoon suspended their search for two teenagers who were reported missing in the waters off Jacob Riis Park in Queens, a shoreline notorious for rip currents that prove deadly year after year.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How an Eco-Conscious ‘Roller Disco Fanatic’ Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Lynn Bodnar Kelly, executive director of Bette Midler’s New York Restoration Project, e-bikes through Brooklyn and roller skates to the beat of Beyoncé.
lead_paragraph: For the past four years, Lynn Bodnar Kelly has been the executive director of the New York Restoration Project, a nonprofit that Bette Midler founded in 1995 to help make clean, open, green spaces more accessible. The organization, which owns and operates 52 community gardens, also plants trees, renovates gardens and restores parks in communities.

headline: The Gaza War Is Dividing the L.G.B.T.Q. Community
abstract: Conflicts over the war have played out in protests, social media battles and a fight over flags on Fire Island during a time usually reserved for solidarity and celebration.
lead_paragraph: In the upscale gay resort town of Fire Island Pines, colorful flags honor L.G.B.T.Q. history makers like the actress Wanda Sykes and the drag queen RuPaul in a small park near the harbor. For a few hours this month, one flag also honored Representative Ritchie Torres, the first openly gay Afro-Latino member of Congress.

headline: Fatal Shooting Robs a Neighborhood of a Longtime Friendly Face
abstract: Alejandro Ramirez was one of two men killed in Upper Manhattan on Father’s Day. A 16-year-old has been charged in the deaths.
lead_paragraph: He worked his shift at Pizza Palace in Manhattan’s Inwood neighborhood late Sunday. He baked pies, took orders and chatted with customers. At closing time, he bid his co-workers farewell and headed for his home in the Bronx, walking several blocks to the Bx12 bus stop, passing bright bodegas and clumps of litter on the way.

headline: Bowman, in Fight for His Political Life, Embraces the Left’s Star Power
abstract: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and Senator Bernie Sanders rallied with Jamaal Bowman on Saturday, three days before the primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: He cracked jokes on “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert,” spit verses with the rapper Cash Cobain and spent the weekend rallying with two of the left’s biggest names: Senator Bernie Sanders and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.

headline: How Mark Zuckerberg’s Meta Failed Children on Safety, States Say
abstract: The C.E.O. and his team drove Meta’s efforts to capture young users and misled the public about the risks, lawsuits by state attorneys general say.
lead_paragraph: In April 2019, David Ginsberg, a Meta executive, emailed his boss, Mark Zuckerberg, with a proposal to research and reduce loneliness and compulsive use on Instagram and Facebook.

headline: Are We Loving Our Pets to Death?
abstract: Pet owners are treating their animal charges ever more like humans. But that isn’t good for pets, or for us, many experts argue.
lead_paragraph: Pets are more popular than ever. Roughly two-thirds of American homes have at least one pet, up from 56 percent in 1988, according to the American Pet Products Association, and Americans spent $136.8 billion on their pets in 2022, up from $123.6 billion in 2021. An estimated 91 million households in Europe own at least one pet, an increase of 20 million over the past decade. The pet population in India hit 31 million in 2021, up from 10 million in 2011.

headline: The Insiders: The 3 Men at the Core of Biden’s Brain Trust
abstract: President Biden has a diverse group of advisers, but few have the influence of three men in his inner circle during his final campaign.
lead_paragraph: Multiple times each day, President Biden dials up Mike Donilon, a close adviser since the 1980s, to chew on the latest polls and headlines.

headline: Drag Goes Mainstream in the Philippines, a Bastion of Christianity
abstract: For many performers, drag is not only a cultural phenomenon, but also a political statement promoting social justice and gay rights.
lead_paragraph: Before he put on the glittery neon yellow tasseled jumpsuit, donned the yellow wig, and lip synced and danced onstage under colorful spotlights, Paul Hidacan went through his preshow routine in a busy dressing room. He pulled out a small white Bible from his bag, sat down and read a verse.

headline: He’s a Queer Colombian, Lost in His Mind, Dreaming of Home
abstract: Santiago Jose Sanchez’ debut novel, “Hombrecito,” follows a young immigrant as he grows up in the United States, struggling to identify with a masculinity he’s never felt and a country he never knew.
lead_paragraph: Migration is an act of constant ruptures, an uprooting that’s compounded by the gradual fraying of bonds, language and culture. For the characters in Santiago Jose Sanchez’ debut novel, “Hombrecito,” migration also induces a metaphysical fracture — it cleaves space from time, suspends a country in a nostalgic yesterday, freezes home in memory.

headline: How to Alienate a Colleague, One Coffee at a Time
abstract: Introducing your new Work Friend: Anna Holmes.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: The Vexing Problem of the ‘Medium Friend’
abstract: They’re not our besties, but they’re more than just acquaintances. How much of ourselves do we owe them?
lead_paragraph: Most of us maintain an informal mental inventory of our friendships, sorting those closest to us, our intimates, from our acquaintances. My friend R. once went a step further. He ranked his friends on a document on his computer. (R. asked that I use his first initial here out of a sense of propriety, knowing it’s taboo to acknowledge even the existence of such a list, let alone to disclose to friends their positions on it.)

headline: Like Shakespeare’s Sonnets, ‘Practice’ Finds Beauty in Digression
abstract: Starring an undergraduate student at Oxford, Rosalind Brown’s debut novel is exquisitely attuned to the thrill and boredom of academic life.
lead_paragraph: A novel that is mostly about the deskbound drama of study: The heart quickens, no? Not for all readers, I suppose. In search of larger stakes, novels of student life have generally scanted the slow labor of scholarship as such, or the reckless midnight dash to the term-paper deadline.

headline: The Future of Streaming (According to the Moguls Figuring It Out)
abstract: Who will survive? Die? Thrive? And how? We talked to nearly a dozen top media executives and asked them to predict what lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: When the media titans Brian Roberts, John Malone and Barry Diller cast off in early February on Mr. Diller’s 156-foot, two-masted yacht, named Arriva, the waters off the coast of Jupiter, Fla., were placid.

headline: De la Torre Brothers Are Making the Most of Maximalism
abstract: Working and living on both sides of the U.S.-Mexico border, they shatter entrenched ideas about beauty and good taste.
lead_paragraph: The wallpapered-room is filled with antiques and a menagerie of blinged-out taxidermy. A 24-foot-long banquet table has been laid out, but the dinner guests seem to have disappeared, leaving their coats behind. On the table: nucleated eyeballs nestling in golden spoons, miniature torsos propped up on cake stands, and baby Kewpie dolls trapped in red goo, like candied desserts. A glass “Capitalist Pig,” one of several profane centerpieces, grins as it defecates gold coins.

headline: At Royal Ascot, the Hats ‘Err on the Side of Extravagance’
abstract: Fascinators are banned at a storied British horse racing event that has a strict dress code codifying what it means to be a hat.
lead_paragraph: Piles of books, an entire topiary, a block of Stilton cheese, a pink flamingo — all these and more have appeared on the heads of attendees at Royal Ascot, the five-day British racing event that is as famous for its outrageous millinery as its stallions. Hats may follow horses around the world, from the Kentucky Derby to the Dubai World Cup and the Hong Kong Cup, but nothing tops the … well, toppers at Ascot, founded in 1711 by Queen Anne. They go together like strawberries and cream. Pimm’s and cucumber. Champagne and finger sandwiches.

headline: Piping Up at the Gates of Dawn
abstract: Astronomers have found the earliest and most distant galaxy yet.
lead_paragraph: Since the James Webb Space Telescope began operating two years ago, astronomers have been using it to leapfrog one another millions of years into the past, back toward the moment they call cosmic dawn, when the first stars and galaxies were formed.

headline: Getting Acquainted With Our New Workplace Columnist
abstract: Anna Holmes, the incoming writer of Work Friend, shares what to expect from the column now that so many of our relationships with the office have changed.
lead_paragraph: Some writers aim to develop one area of expertise over the course of their careers. Anna Holmes has done the opposite, following her curiosity wherever it leads: politics, relationships, sex, women and gender issues, race, culture and children’s books.

headline: On ‘Couples Therapy,’ They Discuss Intimacy Like Nobody’s Watching
abstract: The Showtime series gives audiences an intimate look inside real relationships. Its couples are still navigating the aftermath.
lead_paragraph: One night after a blowout fight with his fiancée, Josh Perez was lying in bed, typing silently on his phone.

headline: How a Boston Physician Conquered the Thriller Genre
abstract: After getting her start by self-publishing, Freida McFadden is now the fastest selling thriller writer in the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Freida McFadden self-published her first novel, “The Devil Wears Scrubs,” more than a decade ago, she figured it would mark both the start and the end of her literary career.

headline: Tree of Life Synagogue to Break Ground on New Sanctuary, and New Mission
abstract: A museum on the history of antisemitism will be part of the new building, alongside a memorial to the 11 worshipers killed in the 2018 attack in Pittsburgh.
lead_paragraph: Debates over antisemitism have flared for months on college campuses, in local government meetings and in Congress, in many cases boiling down to bitter disagreements over what is, and what is not, antisemitism.

headline: These Grieving Parents Want Congress to Protect Children Online
abstract: A group is using the Mothers Against Drunk Driving playbook, sharing personal tragedies, to lobby for the Kids Online Safety Act.
lead_paragraph: Deb Schmill has become a fixture on Capitol Hill. Last week alone, she visited the offices of 13 lawmakers, one of more than a dozen trips she has made from her home near Boston over the past two years.

headline: Listening Through the Life of George Crumb
abstract: In a rarity for contemporary music, the entire catalog of Crumb, who died two years ago, has been recorded and released in 21 volumes.
lead_paragraph: It’s rare for a composer to quickly find a broad audience. It usually takes years, or even decades, and sometimes doesn’t happen at all.

headline: Kevin Kwan’s Art Deco Heirloom
abstract: The author, who received the ring from his favorite aunt, described himself as its custodian “for this generation.”
lead_paragraph: Kevin Kwan used to do some of his best napping in jewelry stores.

headline: What Is a Flip Tax, and Who Has to Pay It?
abstract: Flip taxes, also known as transfer fees, help co-op buildings raise money for repairs and improvements, and they must be described in your governing documents.
lead_paragraph: Q: A month before I sold my Upper Manhattan co-op, I discovered that I would have to pay a flip tax of 2 percent of the sale price at the closing. It’s a significant amount! When my wife and I bought the apartment in 2013, the seller paid $20 per co-op share for the flip tax. I asked the co-op board for evidence that they have the right to collect this tax. The board sent me documents about how the co-op operates, which included nothing about the flip tax. Are they allowed by law to demand this tax? Can I fight it?

headline: Anjana Vasan Just Wants Stanley Tucci to Cook for Her
abstract: “Maybe I can engineer it where I work with him, and then he makes me a drink and a bowl of pasta,” the “We Are Lady Parts” actress said.
lead_paragraph: The past three years have been good to Amina, the introverted scientist in London with rock-star dreams played by Anjana Vasan on the Peacock series “We Are Lady Parts.”

headline: What if an Earthling and Someone From Outer Space Became Pen Pals?
abstract: After a chance encounter, an extragalactic being and a citizen of Earth strike up a friendship and decide to keep in touch.

headline: Sheinbaum’s American Experience Offers Clues to Her Approach to U.S. Relations
abstract: The next Mexican president’s years of living in California provide insight into how she will handle key issues in Mexico-Washington ties.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1990s, a young scientist named Claudia Sheinbaum moved with her family from Mexico City to Northern California, where she studied at the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory.

headline: Gretchen Whitmer Wants a Gen X President — in 2028
abstract: The governor of Michigan isn’t saying it should be her, but she’s not saying it shouldn’t be, either.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the result of this year’s election, it will most likely be the end of an era. Because of their ages — not to mention the law for whoever wins — it’s hard to imagine President Biden or former President Donald Trump running again in 2028, opening the door to a new generation of political leaders. And for Democrats, there are few politicians talked about more than Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan.

headline: Hezbollah Has Threatened Cyprus. Here’s Why.
abstract: Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s chief, warned that the armed group would punish the small island nation if it allowed Israel to use its airports and bases to target Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Cyprus found itself at the center of the world’s attention this week when the leader of Hezbollah threatened to target the small island nation if it supported Israel in potential war efforts.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 378, June 23, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Amid the Stanley Cup Excitement, Edmonton’s Downtown Struggles
abstract: Edmonton’s mayor says that the issues behind homelessness, opioid overdoses and mental health crises cannot be fixed by cities.
lead_paragraph: By the time this newsletter is published, the Edmonton Oilers will be either one game away from winning the Stanley Cup or out of the competition.

headline: Consider the Beach
abstract: With much of the U.S. experiencing a heat wave, let us consider the beach and all its promises and pitfalls.
lead_paragraph: A friend and I like to send each other photos of the corniest beach house signs we encounter, those punny plaques that declare a Margaritaville state of mind rules in this house. The signs are made of painted driftwood and say stuff like “Sand by Me” and “It’s Always 5 O’Clock Here” and “If You’re Not Barefoot, You’re Overdressed.” These are all variations on the overarching theme, the through line of summer vacation: Life is a beach. You are hereby commanded to put on a brightly colored swimsuit, sip a frosty cocktail garnished with a slice of pineapple and relax.

headline: The Rise of Progressivism Among the Educated Elite
abstract: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks about “The Sins of the Educated Class.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sean Penn, Rebel With Many Causes
abstract: He’s just as intense, but a bit more mellow. Or is he?
lead_paragraph: Don’t mellow my harsh, dude.

headline: Finding Freedom 30 Feet in the Air
abstract: Olympic hopefuls are a group of exceptional people held together by athletic tape and hope, who leap without sight of where they will land.
lead_paragraph: I’ve dreamed of competing in the Olympics for as long as I can remember. I would practice my salute in front of the bathroom mirror, pretending I was about to begin my routine. I imagined what it would look like, what it would feel like, how it would finish in triumph and joy.

headline: Why Netanyahu Doesn’t Take Biden Seriously
abstract: By averting his eyes as his red lines are ignored, Biden is wasting his leverage over Israel.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, President Biden seemed so fed up as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel ignored his calls for restraint in Gaza that he finally sounded tough.

headline: The Ten Commandments Are Trump’s Favorite of All the Commandments
abstract: Imagining what comes next in the Republican effort to spread the Christian word.
