abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday that the conflict is about to enter a new stage. Here are four ways that may play out, both in Gaza and at Israel’s northern border.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s prime minister says the war in the Gaza Strip will soon enter a new phase.

headline: Mabe Fratti, a Spark in Mexico City’s Experimental Music Scene
abstract: The singer, cellist and composer has found inspiration in the city’s flourishing avant-garde. Her new LP, “Sentir Que No Sabes,” wrestles with the idea of progress.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, the cellist and experimental composer Mabe Fratti came across a strange painting by Paul Klee. “Angelus Novus” depicts an angel, wings splayed, eyes wide open, who looks as though he is about to flutter away from whatever he is looking at. “It’s a metaphor for history,” she said, video calling from her friend’s living room couch in Berlin. “The philosopher Walter Benjamin wrote about it: this idea that we’re looking forwards, but also always looking back.”

headline: The Voters Watching the Debate With a Hand Over Their Eyes
abstract: “This is the most apprehensive I’ve felt about a presidential debate,” said one voter who usually supports Democrats. “I sense a disaster in the making where neither will look presidential.”
lead_paragraph: Jay Bodenstein, a lifelong Democrat who lives in the Villages retirement community in Florida, plans to sit down this week for a night of television he regards with terror.

headline: France’s Far-Right Leader Says the National Rally Is Ready to Govern
abstract: If he becomes prime minister after snap elections, Jordan Bardella, the party’s president, said he would represent all. But he also said dual citizens should not hold some “sensitive” jobs.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Bardella, the president of France’s far-right National Rally, insisted at a news conference on Monday that he would be a prime minister for all French people if his party won the country’s upcoming snap elections, even as he defended his party’s proposal to bar French citizens with dual nationalities from certain “sensitive” jobs.

headline: Taylor Swift Notches a Ninth Week at No. 1 With New CD Versions
abstract: The singer’s latest album, “The Tortured Poets Department,” now has the second-most weeks at No. 1 of any Swift album.
lead_paragraph: The spring of Taylor Swift has become the summer of Taylor Swift as the singer’s latest album, “The Tortured Poets Department,” holds for a ninth straight week at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart.

headline: Film Academy Chief Gets a Sequel: Bill Kramer’s Contract Is Renewed
abstract: Amid challenges in Hollywood, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences renewed its chief executive’s contract a year early.
lead_paragraph: In a time of flux in Hollywood, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the organization that oversees the Oscars, placed a bet on continuity, announcing Monday that it would extend Bill Kramer’s tenure as chief executive through July 2028.

headline: The Governor’s Race You Cannot Ignore
abstract: North Carolina has a chance to overcome tribalism and hate in November.
lead_paragraph: Partisan hit jobs. Left-wing smears. That’s how Mark Robinson’s aides characterize any attention to his diatribes against Jewish people, gay people, women. They want voters in North Carolina, where he is the Republican nominee for governor, to see him as just another conservative whose straight talk and religiousness come under predictable fire from the ambassadors of wokeness. Nothing to see here, folks, nothing but the usual disdain for MAGA might.

headline: ‘Arctic Blast’ of Leaky Water Halts Spacewalk by NASA Astronauts
abstract: It was the second scheduled spacewalk by NASA astronauts aboard the space station that faced an interruption this month.
lead_paragraph: A spacewalk by two NASA astronauts at the International Space Station ended almost as soon as it began on Monday morning when water started squirting from one of the spacesuits into the airlock.

headline: Man Pleads Guilty in Home Invasion Using Fake Deadly Virus
abstract: Stefan Alexandru Barabas, 38, pleaded guilty to extortion after threatening a multimillionaire in her Connecticut home in 2007.
lead_paragraph: One of three masked intruders who told a Connecticut multimillionaire and her partner that they had been injected with a lethal virus and would receive the antidote only if they paid $8.5 million has pleaded guilty in the 2007 home invasion, prosecutors said.

headline: Tamayo Perry, Professional Surfer, Dies After Shark Attack Off Oahu
abstract: Mr. Perry also appeared in television and movies, including roles in “Blue Crush,” “Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides” and “Hawaii Five-0.”
lead_paragraph: A lifeguard and professional surfer who grew up on the beaches of Oahu, Hawaii, cementing himself as a local celebrity both in the water and in film and television appearances, died on Sunday after he was attacked by a shark while surfing, the authorities said.

headline: What Works for Golf Works for Life
abstract: In the long run, consistency and skill tend to win out over luck.
lead_paragraph: Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland, one of the greatest golfers of his generation, suffered a crushing loss at the U.S. Open this month when he missed short putts on two of the last three holes.

headline: ‘The Lion King’ at 30: Jason Weaver Sang for Simba but Few Knew It
abstract: The actor was playing a young Michael Jackson when Elton John spotted him. Three decades later, the new attention to his legacy is “gratifying.”
lead_paragraph: When Jason Weaver arrived at his middle school in Chicago wearing a sweatshirt emblazoned with “The Lion King” logo in 1993, his classmates sneered. The apparel had been a gift from Disney when Weaver recorded the singing voice of young Simba, but the blockbuster animated film had yet to be released.

headline: They Came to See Trump. First They Heard a Pitch to Buy Gold and Silver.
abstract: At a recent campaign speech, one of Donald Trump’s warm-up acts was a precious metals salesman being sued by federal regulators for fraud.
lead_paragraph: At a conference this month put on by Turning Point Action, a rising conservative activist group, 8,000 people packed into a Detroit convention hall to hear directly from Republicans’ presumptive nominee for president, Donald J. Trump.

headline: Why Do We Love ‘The Bear’ So Much?
abstract: The grit, the merch, the biceps. Charting the cultural phenomenon that sparked new interest in the people behind the scenes at restaurants — or at least, in their stuff.
lead_paragraph: The first time I heard a stranger say “corner” outside a kitchen, I was taken by surprise, but pretty soon, I lost count. After the FX show “The Bear” began streaming on Hulu in 2022, shouting out phrases that bounce around professional kitchens became something of a national bit.

headline: Inside Biden’s Camp David Debate Prep
abstract: President Biden’s aides are working to position him as a campaign-season fighter who can counterpunch on the fly and combat voters’ concerns about his age.
lead_paragraph: At Camp David, a movie theater and an airplane hangar have been outfitted with lights and production equipment to create a mock debate stage. At least 16 current and former aides, summoned from Washington and Wilmington, whiz back and forth on golf carts to join President Biden in strategy sessions.

headline: Washington Post Publisher Says He Aided Hack Inquiry. Scotland Yard Had Doubts.
abstract: Will Lewis gave a “green light” to delete emails during a major journalism scandal engulfing Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp.
lead_paragraph: Will Lewis, now the publisher of the Washington Post, was in full crisis mode in 2011. Then an executive at a subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation, he was an intermediary to the police detectives investigating a British phone-hacking scandal that had placed the company’s journalists and top leaders in legal peril.

headline: Hamas Skimmed $1 Billion in U.N. Aid for Weapons and Tunnels, Suit Says
abstract: About 100 Israelis sued the United Nations Relief and Works Agency, saying it pays local employees in dollars that buoy the terrorist group. But the case faces high legal hurdles.
lead_paragraph: For years, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency sent millions of dollars each month to Gaza to pay employees and support hospitals, schools and other infrastructure, according to a new lawsuit. The money was wired from New York, where the agency has an office, to the West Bank, where financial institutions loaded some of that cash onto trucks to be driven across Israel to Gaza.

headline: Frederick Crews, Withering Critic of Freud’s Legacy, Dies at 91
abstract: A literary critic, essayist and author, he was a leading voice among revisionist skeptics who saw Freud as a charlatan and psychoanalysis as a pseudoscience.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Crews, a literary critic and a leading skeptic in the contentious scholarly debate over the achievements and legacy of Sigmund Freud, died on Friday in Oakland, Calif. He was 91.

headline: Former Officer Pleads Guilty to Killing Woman in Ex-Girlfriend’s Home
abstract: Yvonne Wu was waiting inside her ex-girlfriend’s apartment in Brooklyn when she came home with a friend. Ms. Wu turned her service gun on the two women.
lead_paragraph: A former New York City police officer pleaded guilty on Thursday to killing a woman she had found in her ex-girlfriend’s apartment and trying to kill the ex-girlfriend as well.

headline: More Than 1,300 Die During Extremely Hot Hajj Pilgrimage
abstract: A Saudi official said most of the deaths involved unregistered pilgrims who lacked access to certain amenities available to those with permits, such as air-conditioned buses and tents.
lead_paragraph: A Saudi official said most of the deaths involved unregistered pilgrims who lacked access to certain amenities available to those with permits, such as air-conditioned buses and tents.

headline: F1 on the Water? Yachts Race at the Statue of Liberty.
abstract: Thousands of spectators turned out over the weekend for SailGP, which brought a high-speed competition, and lots of champagne, to the New York Harbor.
lead_paragraph: At 11:30 a.m. Sunday morning, with New York City under a heat advisory, a gaggle of sailing enthusiasts, dressed in polo shirts and summer dresses, boarded a ferry for Governors Island to watch towering F50 catamarans race along the skyline of Lower Manhattan and in front of the Statue of Liberty.

headline: Roger Federer’s Graduation Speech Becomes an Online Hit
abstract: At Dartmouth College, the retired tennis champion offered his thoughts on winning and losing.
lead_paragraph: There are thousands of commencement addresses on college campuses each spring. Most are unremarkable and go unremarked upon. But occasionally one gets people talking and gains traction online. That was the case with the speech given by the retired tennis champion Roger Federer at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., on June 9.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Dagestan Attack Revives Terrorism Fears in Russia
abstract: Also, a shift in Israel’s focus and extreme heat in Mecca.
lead_paragraph: At least 20 people were killed on Sunday in a seemingly coordinated assault in the Dagestan region of southern Russia. It was the deadliest attack in the area in 14 years.

headline: Louisiana Parents Sue to Block Display of Ten Commandments in Schools
abstract: A law enacted last week requires the display of the commandments in every public classroom. The parents argued it “pressures students into religious observance.”
lead_paragraph: A group of parents in Louisiana filed a federal lawsuit on Monday seeking to block a new state law requiring that the Ten Commandments be posted in every public school classroom.

headline: Covid Changed Everything, Including How We Cover the Bird Flu
abstract: The Times’s science and global health reporter shared how the pandemic shaped her current reporting on viruses, including bird flu, which is seeing an uptick in cases.
lead_paragraph: Many of the scientists Apoorva Mandavilli spoke to seemed convinced of the same thing: The bird flu virus, called H5N1, could cause the world’s next pandemic.

headline: Attacks in Russia’s Dagestan Region: What to Know
abstract: Gunmen killed at least 20 people in attacks in two Dagestan cities. No suspects or motives have been identified, but the region has long been rocked by ethnic and religious violence.
lead_paragraph: Two bloody attacks in Dagestan, in southern Russia, on Sunday ignited fears of extremist violence on the home front, as the Kremlin pours resources and bodies into its sprawling war in Ukraine.

headline: Biden Is Prepping for the First Debate
abstract: Also, an N.H.L. final for the ages. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has spent the last five days at Camp David, the presidential retreat in the woods of northern Maryland, sparring with a man pretending to be Donald Trump and working with his closest advisers to prepare for this week’s debate.

headline: Will the Debate Be ‘Rah-Rah’ or ‘Ruh-Roh?’
abstract: I asked how you’re feeling about the debate. Hundreds of you responded with worries and hopes.
lead_paragraph: Good evening. It’s debate week!

headline: Israeli Strike Kills Health Official, Gazans Say, as Gallant Visits U.S.
abstract: Israel’s defense minister, Yoav Gallant, was meeting with the C.I.A. director and the secretary of state on Monday as Israel signaled a potential shift in its military campaign in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli strike killed a top official in charge of ambulance services in the Gaza Strip, local health officials said on Monday, as the Israeli defense minister met with top American officials in Washington about a possible new phase in the Israeli offensive.

headline: Judge Skeptical About Request to Limit Trump Statements on F.B.I.
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon posed tough questions to prosecutors who want to bar the former president from making inflammatory remarks about the agents who searched Mar-a-Lago in the documents case.
lead_paragraph: The federal judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s classified documents case posed tough questions on Monday to prosecutors who have asked her to bar him from making inflammatory statements that might endanger any F.B.I. agents involved in the case.

headline: Assange Agrees to Plead Guilty in Exchange for Release, Ending Standoff With U.S.
abstract: Barring last-minute snags, the deal would bring to an end a prolonged battle that began after the WikiLeaks founder became alternately celebrated and reviled for revealing state secrets in the 2010s.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, agreed to plead guilty on Monday to a single felony count of illegally obtaining and disclosing national security material in exchange for his release from a British prison, ending his long and bitter standoff with the United States.

headline: County Legislature in N.Y. Suburbs Passes Transgender Athlete Ban
abstract: The majority-Republican Nassau County Legislature approved a bill that bars transgender athletes from playing at county-owned facilities on teams that match their gender identity.
lead_paragraph: A county legislature in New York voted on Monday to bar transgender athletes from playing at county-owned facilities unless they compete on teams matching the gender they were assigned at birth or on coed teams.

headline: A Timeline of Julian Assange’s Legal Saga
abstract: A plea deal brought an abrupt end to an extraordinary legal saga that has raised novel issues of national security, press freedoms, politics and diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder who has long fought extradition from Britain to the United States, agreed on Monday to plead guilty to one count of violating the Espionage Act in exchange for a five-year prison sentence.

headline: Election 2024 Polls: Biden vs. Trump
abstract: Our polling averages track the latest trends in the presidential race, using data from national and battleground state polls.
lead_paragraph: Our polling averages track the latest trends in the presidential race, using data from national and battleground state polls.

headline: Methodology: How The Times Calculates 2024 Polling Averages
abstract: An average of surveys may sound straightforward, but even a simple approach faces a series of choices.
lead_paragraph: The idea behind a poll average is simple: Just average the most recent polls together.

headline: Oakland’s Mayor Had Enough Troubles. Then the F.B.I. Came Knocking.
abstract: Sheng Thao was already facing a recall election as residents remain frustrated over crime and homelessness. She said on Monday that she had committed no crimes.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Oakland, Calif., were already frustrated. Violent crime and burglaries had become enough of a problem that getting an In-N-Out burger and fueling up near the airport was considered a risky endeavor.

headline: Hoping for a Glimpse of Hailey Bieber, Hundreds Turn Out for Her Makeup
abstract: After braving a line that snaked through SoHo, fans snapped selfies and rubbed blush on their cheeks inside a tiny pop-up shop for Mrs. Bieber’s makeup brand, Rhode.
lead_paragraph: The line of Hailey Bieber fans snaked up Greene Street in Manhattan and wrapped around the block, but many were never going to get what they really wanted: a selfie with Mrs. Bieber.

headline: Ex-Haitian Gang Leader Is Sentenced to 35 Years in Prison in Gunrunning Scheme
abstract: Prosecutors said Joly Germine, 31, who had led the 400 Mawozo gang, was involved in a conspiracy that used ransom money that had been paid for the release of American hostages to buy and smuggle guns into Haiti.
lead_paragraph: The former leader of a Haitian street gang was sentenced on Monday to 35 years in prison for his role in directing a gunrunning scheme that smuggled guns to Haiti using ransom money that had been paid for the release of American hostages, prosecutors said.

headline: The Most Important Primary Election of the Year Is Also a Heartbreaker
abstract: The high stakes of Bowman’s primary make his carelessness especially frustrating.
lead_paragraph: Update: George Latimer defeated Jamaal Bowman in the Democratic congressional primary on Tuesday.

headline: Judges Block Parts of Biden’s Student Loan Repayment Plan
abstract: A part of the SAVE plan that would have cut monthly bills for millions of borrowers starting on July 1 was put on hold.
lead_paragraph: Two federal judges in Kansas and Missouri temporarily blocked pieces of the Biden administration’s new student loan repayment plan on Monday in rulings that will have implications for millions of federal borrowers.

headline: With Virginia Primary Undecided, Rep. Bob Good Seeks Funds for Recount
abstract: The margin between the congressman and his Trump-backed challenger is just slightly above the threshold for a state-funded recount. His opponent has already declared victory, and both are election deniers.
lead_paragraph: The Republican primary between Representative Bob Good of Virginia, the chairman of the ultraconservative House Freedom Caucus, and his Trump-backed challenger was still undecided on Monday almost a week after the balloting, as the two election deniers settled in for a lengthy and ugly fight over who was the true winner.

headline: New Jersey Transit Service Disrupted for Third Time in Less Than a Week
abstract: Rush-hour commuters at Penn Station faced a shutdown of close to an hour, followed by extensive delays, after Amtrak investigated a report of a problem with overhead wires.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey Transit service was disrupted once again on Monday evening, with travel suspended in and out of Pennsylvania Station for nearly an hour because of a report of a problem with Amtrak overhead wires in one of the Hudson River tunnels.

headline: Where Joe Biden and Donald Trump Stand on the Issues
abstract: Here’s what President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have done and want to do on abortion, democracy, the economy, immigration, Israel and Gaza, and Social Security and Medicare.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have done and want to do on abortion, democracy, the economy, immigration, Israel and Gaza, and Social Security and Medicare.

headline: Zelensky Removes a Top General Amid Criticism of Excessive Casualties
abstract: The announcement by Ukraine’s president on Monday came hours after a scathing social media post implicitly accused the general of “killing more Ukrainian soldiers than any Russian general.”
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine removed one of his top generals from his post on Monday amid public criticism that the commander’s decisions had led to excessive casualties.

headline: A User’s Guide to Midlife
abstract: Experts weigh in on the most vexing issues and changes — and how to deal with them.
lead_paragraph: Experts weigh in on the most vexing issues and changes — and how to deal with them.

headline: ‘Is There Any Chance He Can Sit on a Camel?’ A Senator’s Wife Wanted to Know.
abstract: An aide to Senator Robert Menendez testified that she had been asked to consult with an Egyptian intelligence officer who had befriended Nadine Menendez.
lead_paragraph: In March 2019, an aide to Senator Robert Menendez drafted a letter that used strong language to criticize the president of Egypt and the country’s human rights record. Mr. Menendez declined to sign it.

headline: ‘Let’s Do This Thing!’
abstract: Seth Bisen-Hersh and Jeff Chen game the system.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: He Stole From His Tech Boss and Killed Him to Conceal the Crime
abstract: Tyrese Haspil, 25, was convicted of murdering his former boss, the entrepreneur Fahim Saleh, and dismembering his body in 2020.
lead_paragraph: Just days after the body of Fahim Saleh, a successful tech entrepreneur, was found dismembered in his luxury condominium in Manhattan in July 2020, his former personal assistant, Tyrese Haspil, made a series of unsettling web searches.

headline: Corrections: June 25, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Saturday about The Washington Post’s leadership group misstated Scott Higham’s current status at company. He left The Post in March. He is not currently a reporter there.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Realities of Abortion Bans Shift the Terms of the Issue
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 25, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “It’s profoundly personal to a majority of the public.”

headline: Where Have All the Chinese I.P.O.s Gone?
abstract: Chinese companies’ stock market listings once flooded Wall Street. These days, China’s initial public offerings are in a drought.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when a Chinese internet company’s initial public offering was the hottest thing on Wall Street.

headline: How to Watch the Biden-Trump Presidential Debate
abstract: The debate will be hosted by CNN from its Atlanta studios starting at 9 p.m. Eastern time on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The moment has been four years in the making: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump on a debate stage, another flashpoint in their long-running hostilities.

headline: 2 Russian Women Put on a Play. Then the State Came for Them.
abstract: The prosecution of a prominent playwright and a director in Russia over their work is a chilling sign of increased repression, cultural figures say.
lead_paragraph: They wrote and staged their play as an indictment of terrorism, examining the deception and depravity of violent extremists and the people whose lives they ruin.

headline: China Becomes First Country to Retrieve Rocks From the Moon’s Far Side
abstract: The Chang’e-6 mission’s sample, which might hold clues about the origins of the moon and Earth, is the latest achievement of China’s lunar exploration program.
lead_paragraph: China brought a capsule full of lunar soil from the far side of the moon down to Earth on Tuesday, achieving the latest success in an ambitious schedule to explore the moon and other parts of the solar system.

headline: What to See on London Stages This Summer
abstract: British theater recommendations for visitors and residents of all ages — and inclinations.
lead_paragraph: London’s theaters offer something for everyone. Whether in big West End venues or on stages tucked away above a pub, the city’s shows include the classics, new plays and some productions that defy classification. Open air playhouses attract audiences willing to brave the unpredictable summer weather, and venues spread throughout the city make for an accessible theater landscape that extends far beyond the heavily trafficked tourist hot spots.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: An attack in Dagestan rekindled Russian fears of terrorism.
lead_paragraph: At least 20 people were killed on Sunday in a seemingly coordinated assault in the Dagestan region of southern Russia, the deadliest attack in the area in 14 years.

headline: What Is It About Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Anyway? 12 Voters Explain His Appeal.
abstract: The participants talk about their frustrations with the two-party system, the appeal of third-party candidates and the issues most important to them in voting for president.
lead_paragraph: The participants talk about their frustrations with the two-party system, the appeal of third-party candidates and the issues most important to them in voting for president.

headline: Hillary Clinton: I’ve Debated Trump and Biden. Here’s What I’m Watching For.
abstract: Going head-to-head with the former president is like juggling nonsense, blather and bluster.
lead_paragraph: Last week I had the time of my life at the Tony Awards introducing a song from “Suffs,” the Broadway musical I co-produced about the suffragists who won women the right to vote. I was thrilled when the show took home the awards for best original score and best book.

headline: An Israeli panel warns Netanyahu over corruption case, and other news.
Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Is New York Prepared for a Bird Flu Pandemic?
abstract: The health care system has stockpiles of medicine and has worked out “a lot of the kinks” since the Covid pandemic. But experts still have some concerns about a bird flu outbreak.
lead_paragraph: Four years after a new coronavirus swept through New York in what was called a once-in-a-century event, public health officials are beginning to prepare for the possibility that a far worse pandemic is on its way.

headline: It’s Primary Day in New York. Here’s What to Know.
abstract: Representative Jamaal Bowman faces George Latimer in the state’s most-watched race, a costly contest that may speak to the Democratic Party’s direction.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday is Primary Day in New York.

headline: China’s Lunar Craft Returns to Earth
abstract: Chang’e-6 parachuted down to an area of Inner Mongolia, carrying with it soil samples from the far side of the moon.
lead_paragraph: Chang’e-6 parachuted down to an area of Inner Mongolia, carrying with it soil samples from the far side of the moon.

headline: Gold Medal Looks in Paris
abstract: Dior and Thom Browne get Olympic fever.
lead_paragraph: The question of inspiration has always been a little cringey when it comes to fashion: Designers offering up “mood board” collages backstage to turn even the genesis of their collections into content and connect them to some deeper meaning that can often seem either ridiculously convoluted or drippingly banal. Hence Miranda Priestley’s famous “Florals? For spring? Groundbreaking” moment in “The Devil Wears Prada.”

headline: Israeli Military Must Draft Ultra-Orthodox Jews, Supreme Court Rules
abstract: The court ruled there was no legal justification for the ultra-Orthodox exemption from service, a decision that threatened to split Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s wartime government.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s Supreme Court on Tuesday ruled that the military must begin drafting ultra-Orthodox Jewish men, a decision that threatened to split Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition government amid the war in Gaza.

headline: Two Sisters, Joined in Hardship and Separated by a Bear
abstract: A massive, mysterious grizzly takes on symbolic weight in Julia Phillips’s moody and affecting second novel.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, a black bear swam out to the San Juan Islands, the lush, lovely archipelago in Washington’s north Puget Sound. The adult male was spotted on six islands before moving on, apparently discouraged by the paucity of mates (or perhaps by the high price of real estate). More than a year later, when I visited the San Juans, the bear was still the talk of the float plane.

headline: Year After Failed Mutiny, Russia Tightens Grip on Wagner Units in Africa
abstract: Moscow has largely taken over the African operations of the paramilitary group, once led by Yevgeny Prigozhin, who was killed after leading an insurrection against Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: For years, Russia covertly propped up authoritarian leaders, exploited natural resources and fought extremists in a number of African countries.

headline: The Pet ‘Superheroes’ Who Donate Their Blood
abstract: Transfusions have become an important part of veterinary medicine, but cat and dog blood is not always easy to come by.
lead_paragraph: At first, it was hard to tell whether something was really wrong with Rover. The 10-year-old yellow Lab had always been a bit of a loafer, so when he refused to get up from the rug last February, it was not entirely out of character. But then he declined a treat.

headline: An Orcas Island Home Was the Dream. Here’s How They Made It a Reality.
abstract: The small house in Washington was designed to sit lightly on the land: It touches the ground in only six places, and they didn’t cut down a single tree.
lead_paragraph: A home should be a place where you can welcome your extended family — at least that’s what Leah Martin and Vikram Prakash thought. But while they loved entertaining at the house they shared with their three children, the experience wasn’t quite what they had in mind.

headline: Do You Have Food Allergies? Here’s How to Travel Safely.
abstract: Airlines, restaurants and hotels are all making travel easier for people with sensitivities to foods like peanuts, wheat and milk, but it’s still critical to be your own advocate.
lead_paragraph: For the 33 million Americans managing any of the most common nine food allergies — including milk, eggs, nuts, wheat, soy, sesame and different types of fish — traveling safely can be challenging, but it’s becoming easier.

headline: Kevin Costner Is Pursuing His Western Dream. Will Audiences Follow?
abstract: To make “Horizon,” he put his own money on the line and left “Yellowstone,” the series that revived his career — all with little Hollywood support.
lead_paragraph: Oh, to have the self-confidence of Kevin Costner.

headline: The Ballot Measures Aim to Reduce Partisanship. Can They Fix American Politics?
abstract: Eight states are certain or likely to field election initiatives that would overhaul redistricting or give voters a greater voice in choosing candidates.
lead_paragraph: Americans of both parties routinely express deep concern about the state of the country’s democracy. This fall, many voters may have a chance to do something about it, by voting on state ballot measures related to the nuts and bolts of elections and governance.

headline: What Happened to the Well-Mannered Cat Burglar?
abstract: In “A Gentleman and a Thief,” Dean Jobb vividly recounts the life and times of the notorious criminal — and tabloid fixture — Arthur Barry.
lead_paragraph: As the rich got richer in the boom years of the 1920s, many of them fled New York City noise for the newly fashionable suburbs. But in these tranquil enclaves, they found something else to keep them up at night: a mysterious jewel thief known only as “the phantom.”

headline: Léopold Sédar Senghor’s Library Heading to Senegal
abstract: Two decades after his death, a collection of over 800 works that the first president of Senegal owned is moving from France to Dakar.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years after the death of Léopold Sédar Senghor — the writer, poet and first president of Senegal after the country’s independence from France — his name is still generating headlines.

headline: Is It a Bad Idea to Drink Alcohol on an Airplane?
abstract: Experts suggest caution before ordering an in-air beverage. Here’s what to keep in mind.
lead_paragraph: Q: A cocktail or glass of wine helps me fall asleep on long flights. But are there downsides to drinking on a plane?

headline: 13 of Our Readers’ Favorite New York City Sandwiches
abstract: We asked, you answered: Here are the sandwiches our readers live for, including turkey leg, beef tongue and a crab BLT.
lead_paragraph: Last week we published a project we’ve been working on for quite a while: a list of 57 sandwiches that define New York City. (Someone named Dave in the comments generously suggested we rename the list, “Making Everyone Who Ever Left NYC Regret Their Choices.”)

headline: How America Became the Capital of Great Pizza
abstract: Since the early 2000s, the variety and quality of pizza made by ambitious chefs all over the country have only gotten better.
lead_paragraph: Marisol Doyle wasn’t bothered by the frozen dough and canned mushrooms common in the pizzas she ate as a kid growing up in Sonora, Mexico. It was comfort food.

headline: Mavis Staples Is an American Institution. She’s Not Done Singing Yet.
abstract: After more than seven decades onstage, the gospel and soul great decided last year that it was time to retire. Then she realized she still had work to do.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy April day in Chicago, Mavis Staples sat in the restaurant of the towering downtown Chicago building where she’s lived for the past four years. For two hours, she talked about the civil rights movement and faith. And finally, she mentioned her old flame Bob Dylan.

headline: Can a New Leader Make the Boston Symphony Innovative Again?
abstract: Chad Smith, the orchestra’s new chief executive, hopes to return the storied ensemble to its groundbreaking roots while moving it forward.
lead_paragraph: “I’m going to sound like such a dork,” Chad Smith said as he drove a golf cart around the grounds of Tanglewood, the Boston Symphony Orchestra’s pastoral summer home in the Berkshires. “I love Tanglewood so much.”

headline: In Defense of Wine
abstract: Sales are down, and health concerns are up. But wine’s history of providing beauty, joy and affirmation should not be forgotten.
lead_paragraph: Around the globe, much of the wine world is feeling besieged and stigmatized.

headline: The Diabolical PBS Show That’ll Restore Your Faith in Reality TV
abstract: Producers selected three families to mimic late-19th-century homesteaders over five months. The resulting quarrels make the “Real Housewives” seem tame.
lead_paragraph: Reality TV has become the victim of its own domination. Today it is all but impossible to find participants unlearned in the folkways of reality television. A “Real Housewives” viewer understands the show as not a documentary about women’s lives but an improvisatory melodrama whose characters strive to be depicted favorably in a documentary about women’s lives. They watch because it is funny, infuriating and at times harrowing to observe people, consumed with awareness of being filmed, trying to give the impression that they are not thinking almost exclusively about being filmed.

headline: 22 of the Best Pizza Places in the United States
abstract: From Southern California to the Mississippi Delta to the Pacific Northwest, the bounty of great pies has never been bigger.
lead_paragraph: Pizza in America has never been better. The wood-fire Neapolitan pizzerias that took off in the early 2000s, and have been spreading ever since, taught Americans to ask more of a dish they already loved.

headline: Scientists Find First Evidence That Butterflies Crossed an Ocean
abstract: Researchers discovered painted ladies on a South American beach and then built a case that they started their journey in Europe or Africa.
lead_paragraph: Early one morning in late October 2013, Gerard Talavera, an entomologist, saw something highly unusual — a flock of painted lady butterflies stranded on a beach in French Guiana.

headline: Surgeon General Declares Gun Violence a Public Health Crisis
abstract: Dr. Vivek Murthy is calling for a multipronged effort to reduce gun deaths, modeled on campaigns against smoking and traffic fatalities.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. surgeon general, Dr. Vivek Murthy, on Tuesday declared gun violence in America a public health crisis, recommending an array of preventive measures that he compared to past campaigns against smoking and traffic safety.

headline: A Day-Glo New York Where Artists Could Afford the Rent
abstract: In his beautiful memoir, “Do Something,” Guy Trebay paints a picture of a vanished, pre-AIDS Gotham that’s both gritty and dazzling.
lead_paragraph: Among the skills that can get a writer out of trouble, a sense of smell should not be underestimated. Stuck for an escape, cornered by the rats of cliché and sentimentality, today’s autofictionists are wont to brandish their anxiety, consort with their inner demons, flash their self-loathing and blame late capitalism — yet a nimbler response might simply be to sniff for fresh air and head for the door.

headline: A Brooklyn School District Finds a Path Toward Integration
abstract: Breaking with segregation does not have to involve bitterness and decades of delays.
lead_paragraph: Elected officials who prefer not to discuss the fact that New York City has one of the most segregated school systems in the United States could soon have no choice. A state appellate court has said that an anti-discrimination lawsuit can move forward.

headline: The Urgent Need to Blow Off Swing Voters
abstract: Thursday’s debate is time to preach to the choir.
lead_paragraph: In a presidential election where both leading candidates are unpopular, there’s much talk about what each candidate can say to swing voters in Thursday’s debate. But true swing voters are disengaged from political news; in fact, many avoid it with a determination normally reserved for toxic exes, ticks and food poisoning. To the extent they learn what’s said on Thursday, it’ll be via repackaged clips on social media.

headline: Introducing Our 2024 Poll Tracker
abstract: It starts by showing a very close race nationally and in critical battleground states.
lead_paragraph: What do the polls say about the race for the White House?

headline: Why Republicans Are Talking About Biden’s ‘Dictatorship’
abstract: The breathless catastrophizing of Trump and his allies is not an expression of ignorance as much as it is a statement of intent.
lead_paragraph: The United States under President Biden is a “dictatorship,” according to Doug Burgum, governor of North Dakota.

headline: ‘I Am: Celine Dion’ Review: You Saw the Best in Me
abstract: Dion’s voice made her a star. A new documentary on Amazon Prime Video brings her back to Earth, showing her intimate struggles with stiff person syndrome.
lead_paragraph: Illness shows no regard for even the most revered figures in pop music.

headline: Three Ideas to Beat the Heat, and the People Who Made Them Happen
abstract: As temperatures soar around the world, practical experiments are emerging to protect people.
lead_paragraph: An app that helps people find relief from the heat.

headline: How Venezuela’s Leader Could Stay in Power, No Matter What Voters Want
abstract: Four former officials in the government of President Nicolás Maduro describe his options between now and an election that could remove him from power — or solidify his grip.
lead_paragraph: Venezuela’s authoritarian president, Nicolás Maduro, faces a watershed moment that will determine the fate of his rule and the course of his troubled country.

headline: Age and the Image of Capacity
abstract: President Biden’s toughest opponent may not be his predecessor. It is the cultural meaning, built up through centuries, that we assign to being old.
lead_paragraph: “Watch me,” President Biden likes to say when he’s asked — he’s asked a lot, these days — whether he is too old to serve a second term. He is getting his wish.

headline: London’s Kew Gardens Has Long Links to Japan. Now the Emperor Is Set to Visit.
abstract: Emperor Naruhito is touring the famous botanic gardens this week as part of a state visit to Britain with his wife, Empress Masako.
lead_paragraph: When Emperor Naruhito of Japan will visit Kew Gardens on Thursday as part of a state visit to Britain, the links between his island nation and the famed London landmark will be on full display.

headline: ‘Doctor Who’ Season in Review: The Doctor Might Be on a New Path
abstract: Ncuti Gatwa shined as the 15th Doctor. But the long-running show feels at a crossroads as it concludes its latest season.
lead_paragraph: “Doctor Who” is a show of paradoxes. At its best, it’s a show about a time-traveling, space-venturing alien who ceaselessly untangles the mysteries of the universe, and often invites his own. At its worst, it’s plagued by its contradictions — incoherent or unintelligible narrative logic, inconsistent writing, uneven tone.

headline: What Happened to Stanford Spells Trouble for the Election
abstract: Universities that cataloged election lies and disinformation are being targeted with the same tactics they sought to uncover.
lead_paragraph: In 2020 the Stanford Internet Observatory, where I was until recently the research director, helped lead a project that studied election rumors and disinformation. As part of that work, we frequently encountered conspiratorial thinking from Americans who had been told the 2020 presidential election was going to be stolen.

headline: ‘Babylon Berlin’ Review: Dancing While the World Begins to Burn
abstract: The long-awaited fourth season of the cult-favorite German thriller takes place in 1931, with the Nazis not quite in power.
lead_paragraph: Far from the eyes of Emmy voters or the digital gremlins compiling streaming Top 10 lists, there is a series — a German period drama, of all things — that a small core of aficionados would argue is the world’s best television show.

headline: Today’s Teenagers Have Invented a Language That Captures the World Perfectly
abstract: Our kids’ lingo is not only better than any we used; it’s a useful window into the way they think.
lead_paragraph: My son just completed high school and when he leaves for college in the fall my life will change in ways I’m still struggling to contemplate. Among the things I’ll miss most are his lessons in teenage slang. My son has always been generous with me, and I’ve found the slang of his generation to be so much better and more useful than any that I’ve ever used. His slang has also offered me an accidental and useful portrait of how he and his generation see the world.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 381, June 26, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,103, June 26, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Plan to Defeat Critics of Israel in Congress
abstract: A pro-Israel political group has spent millions to defeat Representative Jamaal Bowman of New York.
lead_paragraph: A powerful group supporting Israel is trying to defeat sitting members of Congress who have criticized the country’s deadly war against Hamas.

headline: Assange Agrees to Plea Deal, and Israel-Lebanon Border Strikes Intensify
abstract: Plus, China’s extraordinary moon mission.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: Deadly Fire Exposes Harsh Conditions Migrant Workers Face in South Korea
abstract: Activists say the blaze that killed 23 laborers at a battery plant, most of them from China, shows that such workers need better protection.
lead_paragraph: They were descendants of Koreans who ​moved to Northeast China​, fleeing Japan’s brutal colonial rule ​in the early 20th century. In a twist of history,​ many like them have come to South Korea in recent decades,​ looking for better-paying jobs in their forebears’ homeland, ​now one of the world’s richest countries.

headline: Biden’s Polling Progress
abstract: The president has narrowed the gap with Donald Trump, but Trump still holds a small lead.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has narrowed the gap with Donald Trump in the past few months, but Trump still holds a small lead in the race for the presidency.

headline: E.U. Charges Microsoft With Antitrust Violations Over Teams Bundling
abstract: The tech giant has been accused of stifling competition by packaging its video conferencing app with other tools like Word and Excel.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators on Tuesday charged Microsoft with breaking antitrust rules by bundling its Teams video conferencing and collaboration software with a suite of other productivity tools, giving it an unfair advantage over rivals.

headline: ‘Babylon Berlin’ Is Back. Here’s What You Need to Know.
abstract: Season 4 of the epic crime drama has finally come to streaming in the United States, via MHz Choice. Here’s a refresher on where we left off.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, the lavish German noir detective series “Babylon Berlin” has required patience from its American viewers.

headline: What Is a Famine and Who Determines That One Exists?
abstract: A group of global experts said that Gaza is at high risk of famine, but stopped short of saying that one had begun. Here’s a closer look at how famine is defined.
lead_paragraph: A group of global experts said on Tuesday that Gaza is at high risk of famine, but it stopped short of saying that one had begun.

headline: I.C.C. Issues Arrest Warrants for 2 Senior Russian Security Officials
abstract: Sergei K. Shoigu, a former defense minister, and Gen. Valery V. Gerasimov, the country’s highest-ranking military officer, were accused of directing attacks against civilians in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The International Criminal Court said on Tuesday that it had issued arrest warrants for two top Russian security officials over strikes against civilian targets, delivering a stinging, if largely symbolic, condemnation of the Kremlin’s invasion of neighboring Ukraine.

headline: Turning 26 and Struggling to Find Health Insurance? Tell Us About It.
abstract: The New York Times and KFF Health News are looking into a dreaded “adulting” milestone: finding your own medical insurance at 26.
lead_paragraph: A hard-won provision of the Affordable Care Act allows young adults to stay on their family’s insurance until age 26. But after that, those without employer-based insurance face an array of complicated choices, including whether to shop on the insurance plan exchanges, apply for Medicaid or roll the dice and go uninsured.

headline: Strike Kills Sister of Hamas’s Political Leader
abstract: Hamas confirmed the death of a sister of Ismail Haniyeh and her family. The Israeli military said it was aware of the reports but could not “currently confirm” that it had struck the Haniyeh family home.
lead_paragraph: A strike in the northern Gaza Strip killed a sister of Ismail Haniyeh, the political leader of Hamas, and her family on Tuesday, the armed group and a Gazan rescue official said.

headline: Inside Nvidia’s $500 Billion Wipeout
abstract: The chipmaker’s stock has tumbled in recent days, a reminder that the artificial intelligence stock boom could be tough to sustain.
lead_paragraph: It looks like another volatile day for Nvidia shareholders. And given the company’s enormous influence on the entire S&P 500, they may not be the only investors facing big swings.

headline: Word of the Day: academe
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word academe has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 4 in the guest essay “The Problems Only Start With Plagiarism” by Charles Seife:

headline: How a Brooklyn District Tackled School Segregation
abstract: District 15 dropped selective admissions for middle schools, and the schools are now more integrated than they were.
lead_paragraph: Today we’ll find out what happened when a school district in Brooklyn began an ambitious effort to better integrate its middle schools. We’ll also find out about a decision throwing out an attempt by the city to ban foie gras.

headline: Readers Share Their Favorite Parts of 2024 So Far
abstract: New hobbies, graduation ceremonies and more.
lead_paragraph: Believe it or not, we’re nearly halfway through 2024. As a midweek pick-me-up, today I’m sharing some of the lovely notes readers have sent me about their favorite parts of this year: new hobbies, graduation ceremonies and more. Send your own tales to CAtoday@nytimes.com.

headline: Foreign Police Officers Land on the Ground in Haiti
abstract: The arrival of 400 Kenyan officers came on a day of deadly violence in Kenya. The international force was sent to try to restore order in the gang-plagued Caribbean nation.
lead_paragraph: Foreign law enforcement officers began arriving in Haiti on Tuesday, more than a year and a half after the prime minister there issued a plea to other countries for help to stop the rampant gang violence that has upended the Caribbean nation.

headline: Russia Committed Human Rights Violations in Crimea, European Court Finds
abstract: The European Court of Human Rights listed multiple violations. Its findings paint a grim picture of life under a decade of Russian occupation.
lead_paragraph: The European Court of Human Rights ruled on Tuesday that Russia and its proxy security forces in Crimea have committed multiple human rights violations during its decade-long occupation of the Ukrainian territory.

headline: Leslye Headland’s ‘Cult of Love’ to Open on Broadway in the Fall
abstract: The play will be produced by Second Stage, which is also planning an Off Broadway production of a two-character drama by Donald Margulies.
lead_paragraph: “Cult of Love,” a play about a fractious holiday gathering of a Christian family, will come to Broadway this fall via Second Stage Theater, one of the four nonprofits with Broadway houses.

headline: In States That Won’t Pay for Obesity Drugs, ‘They May as Well Have Never Been Created’
abstract: Public employees in West Virginia who took the drugs lost weight and were healthier, and some are despondent that the state is canceling a program to help pay for them.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Bailey, a family physician and obesity specialist, doesn’t want to tell her patients that they can’t take Wegovy, but she has gotten used to it.

headline: The Four Issues Trump and Biden Will Clash Over at the Debate
abstract: Immigration, the economy, democracy and abortion rights: Here are the main ways each candidate is likely to slam the other at Thursday’s high-stakes confrontation.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump have sparred for months on the campaign trail, in interviews with reporters and through paid advertisements, creating phantom likenesses of each other to thrash and tear down.

headline: When the Runways Are a Personal Playlist
abstract: Theater and dance critics can’t own the subjects they cover, but a fashion critic can — at least imaginarily — by making a hits compilation as the clothes go by.
lead_paragraph: If fashion is a storytelling business, it should follow that runway shows are narratives.

headline: France’s Far-Right National Rally Rebranded Itself. Here’s How.
abstract: Many long considered Marine Le Pen’s party too extreme to be anywhere close to power. Now, the party could win a parliamentary election — and fill the prime minister’s seat.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the National Rally was the pariah of French politics — deemed so dangerous that politicians from other parties refused to engage with its members.

headline: It’s Called the Best Gazpacho Because It Is the Best Gazpacho
abstract: Julia Moskin’s five-star recipe is simple, salty, thick and smooth — a coolly satisfying remedy for summer’s sluggish heat.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for our annual reminder that gazpacho is the queen of summer cooking, a coolly satisfying remedy for intense, sluggish heat. Our recipe is called best gazpacho, and it delivers on that promise. It’s simple, salty, thick and smooth, with no bobbing cubes of cucumber in sight. (I never liked those.)

headline: ‘White Chicks’ at 20: Comedy Beyond the Pale
abstract: The Wayans brothers’ subversive comedy is smarter than you remember.
lead_paragraph: When the oversexed basketball player Latrell Spencer (Terry Crews) turns to his date to sing Vanessa Carlton’s “A Thousand Miles,” he does so to prove his total love of all things white. Spencer is the stereotypical embodiment of the lascivious muscular Black man intent on procuring a white woman to prove his own masculinity. “Once you go Black, you’re gonna need a wheelchair,” he says. And yet, despite the broadness of his carnal desires, his performativity is the comedic soul to the director Keenen Ivory Wayans’s astute racial passing satire “White Chicks.”

headline: Jonathan Majors Is Cast in First Movie Role Since Assault Conviction
abstract: Mr. Majors, who was sentenced to a year of domestic violence programming and was dropped by Marvel, is set to star in the independent thriller “Merciless.”
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Majors will lead a feature film for the first time since he was found guilty of assaulting and harassing his girlfriend, a conviction that doomed a lucrative contract with Marvel Studios and imperiled his status as one of the fastest-rising stars in Hollywood.

headline: The Pro-Israel Donor With a $100 Million Plan to Elect Trump
abstract: Miriam Adelson long operated in the shadow of her powerful husband, Sheldon Adelson. Now, after his death, she is playing in politics as a solo practitioner for the first time.
lead_paragraph: As the Nevada caucuses drew to a close in February, Donald J. Trump and several top aides gathered for a quick dinner in a suite atop his hotel in Las Vegas before he descended and declared victory.

headline: Patients Stunned by Their Medical Bills
abstract: Responses to an essay about facility fees added by hospital-affiliated practices. Also: The border; North Korea’s weapons; Justin Timberlake’s arrest.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Jamaal Bowman Deserved to Lose
abstract: He is out of sync with his district and with the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Update: George Latimer defeated Jamaal Bowman in the Democratic congressional primary on Tuesday.

headline: How a Cake Became a National Obsession
abstract: For many Jamaicans, lychee cake is the taste of celebration. Its origin tells the history of Chinese immigration to the Caribbean island.
lead_paragraph: During the Lunar New Year of 1988, Selena Wong wanted to create a special dessert for her family in Kingston, Jamaica. Ms. Wong, whose ancestors came to the island from China in the 19th century, was a self-taught baker who occasionally sold goods from her home.

headline: Heat Is Killing Thousands, and Big Events Have Not Adjusted
abstract: The deaths of at least 1,300 pilgrims during the hajj point to the growing threat that climate change poses to beloved gatherings.
lead_paragraph: At large events all over the world, the scenes of extreme heat stress are starting to look familiar. Older men, shirts undone, lying down with their eyes closed. Aid tents packed with the unconscious. And lines of the faithful — whether they seek religion, music, ballot boxes or sport — sweating under slivers of shade.

headline: Review: In ‘Find Me Here,’ Sisters Grapple With a Father’s Will, and His Legacy
abstract: A family gathering fuels Crystal Finn’s new play, in which an excellent cast teases out the many complications of inheritance.
lead_paragraph: Weddings, anniversaries, holidays: The family get-together is a dramatic gift that keeps on giving to both screen and stage. Crystal Finn’s new play, “Find Me Here,” at Wild Project, falls into a subcategory of the funerals subgenre — the opening of a will. In this case, a patriarch’s last wishes are discovered by his three daughters and their families. Truths and conflicts emerge gingerly, almost tentatively, because Finn is less interested in confrontation than in gentle poking and prodding.

headline: At Montpellier Danse, Leaning Into New Work as the Void Looms
abstract: The festival, the final one for its longtime director, started with a bravura work by Wayne McGregor that was at once otherworldly and deeply human.
lead_paragraph: The abyss, the womb, the fathomless depths of sea and space. These are the settings for Wayne McGregor’s new “Deepstaria,” in which nine dancers float and spin, buckle and collapse, regenerate and reform, in a protean display of technical virtuosity and human fragility.

headline: Oklahoma Supreme Court Says No to State Funding for a Religious Charter School
abstract: In a closely watched case, Oklahoma’s highest court blocked what was set to become the nation’s first religious charter school. An appeal is likely.
lead_paragraph: The Oklahoma Supreme Court blocked on Tuesday what would have been the nation’s first religious charter school, delivering a setback to a conservative movement that has increasingly fought for public dollars to go toward religious education.

headline: Seth Binzer, Crazy Town’s Lead Singer, ‘Shifty Shellshock,’ Dies at 49
abstract: He was the frontman for the rap-rock band Crazy Town, which was most known for the hit song “Butterfly.”
lead_paragraph: Shifty Shellshock, the lead singer of the late-1990s rap-rock band Crazy Town known for the hit song “Butterfly,” whose legal name was Seth Binzer, died at his home in Los Angeles on Thursday. He was 49.

headline: Kraam Dresses in Indigo to Serve Seasonal, Contemporary Thai
abstract: Sendo has a new counter for sushi, Nordic fare in a rustic setting at Kabin and more restaurant news.
lead_paragraph: A sleek white, gold and blue room (kraam means indigo) is the setting for a vibrant, distinctive Thai menu.Instead of the fierce attention to regional cuisines as at beloved Thai spots in Queens, the chef and owner, Pongsathorn Thinnuch, who worked at JoJo and Hutong, and his team of Thai chefs, favor seasonality and contemporary flair. Khao soi curry is made with chicken confit, there are sautéed razor clams with Thai-adjacent chimichurri, and strips of rib-eye heavily strewn with black peppercorns make a stir-fry. The inevitable green papaya salad includes sweet corn and long beans, and you can bet that Giovanni Bellini never tasted his namesake drink with lychee and guava.

headline: ‘Costco, Don’t Give Up on America As a Nation of Readers’: The Week 1 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
abstract: Read the work of the winning writer, Daphne Nguyen, 16 — and take a look at three favorite video responses, too.
lead_paragraph: For 15 years, our Summer Reading Contest has been inviting teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. Up until now, students could only enter by posting short written comments, but this year we’re also allowing 90-second video responses.

headline: Deadly Protests Leave Kenya Shocked by Violence
abstract: Across the country, outrage over proposed tax increases drove Kenyans to the streets.
lead_paragraph: A day after demonstrators clashed with the police and stormed the national Parliament building in Kenya to protest passage of a finance bill that would increase taxes, President William Ruto announced on Wednesday that he was changing course and would not sign the legislation.

headline: Review: A ‘Ulysses’ That Squeezes Bloomsday Into 2 Hours, 40 Minutes
abstract: Elevator Repair Service’s staged reading of the huge James Joyce novel retains much of its humor, pathos and bawdiness.
lead_paragraph: Looking at the stage as you enter the Luma theater, the smaller of the auditoriums at Bard College’s Fisher Center, you might think your ticket had been switched with one for a zoning board meeting. Enjoy the splendor of chairs lined up behind three conjoined conference tables! Admire the care with which pens, stacks of paper and wee bottles of water have been laid like dinner settings! Warily consult the large clock on the upstage wall that offers the real time — at least at first.

headline: The Heat Crisis Is a Housing Crisis
abstract: A lack of affordable housing and high energy costs are making Americans more vulnerable to record-breaking heat, public health experts say.
lead_paragraph: Air-conditioning was long considered a luxury in much of the world. Not anymore.

headline: Boeing Is Said to Offer Stock to Buy Spirit, Preserving Cash Amid Struggles
abstract: The plane maker is expected to soon strike a deal to acquire most of the operations of Spirit AeroSystems, a troubled supplier that makes the bodies of the 737 Max.
lead_paragraph: In a bid to acquire a key supplier, Boeing has shifted how it plans to pay for the deal, according to two people familiar with the negotiations, a move that could help the plane maker preserve money as it addresses safety and quality problems.

headline: Obama’s Half Sister Is Among Those Tear-Gassed During Protests in Kenya
abstract: Auma Obama, a sociologist and community activist, was being interviewed live on CNN when clouds of tear gas lobbed by the police overwhelmed her.
lead_paragraph: Auma Obama, an older half sister of former President Barack Obama, was tear-gassed on Tuesday while being interviewed live on CNN during protests in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital. The protests were against the passage of a finance bill that raises taxes on many basic goods.

headline: Safety Agency Faults Norfolk Southern for ‘Vent and Burn’ After 2023 Derailment
abstract: The National Transportation Safety Board said the decision to release and incinerate toxic chemicals in the wake of a train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, was misguided.
lead_paragraph: The National Transportation Safety Board issued a series of recommendations on Tuesday aimed at preventing the type of freight train derailment that occurred last year in East Palestine, Ohio, when 38 rail cars operated by Norfolk Southern came off the tracks.

headline: Why the N.F.L. Put a $7 Billion Antitrust Case in the Hands of an Unpredictable Jury
abstract: A class-action lawsuit over the cost of Sunday Ticket subscriptions underscored how valuable broadcast deals have been for the league’s success.
lead_paragraph: A pillar of the N.F.L.’s meteoric rise over the past six decades has been its strategy of making nearly all games available mostly free to fans on national networks. The league has stuck to this approach even as Major League Baseball, the N.B.A. and other leagues moved more of their games onto cable and satellite broadcasters and subscription streaming services.

headline: Assange’s Plea Deal Sets a Chilling Precedent, but It Could Have Been Worse
abstract: The deal brings an ambiguous end to a legal saga that has jeopardized the ability of journalists to report on military, intelligence or diplomatic information that officials deem secret.
lead_paragraph: The plea deal Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, has reached with prosecutors is bad for American press freedoms. But the outcome also could have been worse.

headline: 7 New Songs You Should Hear Now
abstract: Listen to Lorde tell her side of the story on a surprise remix with Charli XCX and more new songs.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, when the British pop musician Charli XCX released her raw, prismatic sixth album, “Brat,” I had some difficulty choosing just one of its tracks for our Friday Playlist. I ultimately went with “Girl, So Confusing,” a dance floor confessional that aired mixed feelings about a certain musical peer. “People say we’re alike, they say we’ve got the same hair,” Charli sang, before admitting that the few times they had hung out felt stilted: “We talk about making music, but I don’t know if it’s honest.”

headline: The Southern Border, Terrorism Fears and the Arrests of 8 Tajik Men
abstract: The men were arrested after the F.B.I. quietly began an investigation that stretched across the country and involved scores of bureau personnel.
lead_paragraph: When eight Tajik men sought asylum at the southwestern U.S. border months ago, federal authorities had no reason to doubt that they were desperate migrants fleeing a poor country in war-torn Central Asia.

headline: Trump Can Now Criticize Witnesses Who Testified Against Him, Judge Rules
abstract: The judge who oversaw Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial loosened the rules governing what Mr. Trump can say about it, and said his gag order would be lifted after his July 11 sentencing.
lead_paragraph: A judge on Tuesday loosened a gag order on Donald J. Trump in his Manhattan criminal case, allowing the former president to criticize witnesses who took the stand against him as well as others involved in the trial that led to his conviction.

lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Colorado primary election.

lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 New York primary election.

headline: U.S. Swimming Stars Assail Antidoping Agency Ahead of Olympics
abstract: Lawmakers expressed openness to withholding funding from the agency after reports that Chinese swimmers were allowed to compete in the 2021 Games after testing positive for a banned drug.
lead_paragraph: Faced with demands from two decorated Olympic swimmers, members of Congress expressed an openness on Tuesday to withholding funding from the global regulator assigned to ensure an even Olympic playing field over its refusal to hold accountable Chinese swimmers who tested positive for a banned drug.

headline: Kenyan Police, a Force With a Bloody History, Confront Protesters at Home and Gangs in Haiti
abstract: The combination of a bloody clash with protesters in Nairobi and the arrival of Kenyan officers in gang-ravaged Haiti draws new scrutiny to the Kenyan police.
lead_paragraph: Excessive force. Extrajudicial killings. A long history of brutality and impunity.

headline: Colorado Primary Election Results
abstract: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Colorado primary elections.
lead_paragraph: Get live results and maps from the 2024 Colorado primary elections.

headline: What to Know About Julian Assange and His Plea Deal
abstract: The deal ends a period of confinement that lasted about a dozen years, first in the self-exile of the Ecuadorean embassy in London, then in prison.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange spent his youth in Australia during the 1980s in a state of chaotic, perpetual motion. He moved more than two dozen times, bounced from school to school and was thrust, for a time, into what he called a New Age cult, before settling in Melbourne.

headline: Kenya Protests Are a Blow to Biden’s Embrace of President Ruto
abstract: Just a day earlier, President Biden had formally named Kenya a major non-NATO ally.
lead_paragraph: The street turmoil that swept Kenya’s capital on Tuesday represented a blow to the Biden administration’s tight embrace of President William Ruto, a strong U.S. ally on a continent where American influence is rapidly waning.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘That Was My First Inkling’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: When I was 7, my grandmother told me she saw Halley’s comet in 1910. As a young woman in rural Tennessee, she was amazed. She explained it would return in 1986, when she’d be in heaven and I’d be a grown man. That was my first inkling, lovingly and mysteriously rendered, that all things change — and people we love pass away, though the stars appear to stay the same. In Seattle, 1986, I watched the comet scar the darkness, my grandmother’s memory burning bright within me. By the time Halley returns in 2061, I will have joined her in infinity. — T.S. Davis

headline: He Monitors Solar Flares. Here’s What Keeps Him Up at Night.
abstract: Mike Bettwy, a government meteorologist who focuses on potential threats from space weather, says that we are more prepared than ever — and that forecasting is only getting better.
lead_paragraph: In May, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration issued a watch for a possible solar storm. A gigantic cluster of spots on the sun was flaring and expelling material headed straight toward Earth.

headline: ‘I Might Be Real-Life Good at This’: Shooting for Broadway at the Jimmy Awards
abstract: The awards, which celebrated excellence in high school musical theater on Monday, have become a launchpad for future stars and Tony nominees.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Damson Chola Jr. sang the powerful “Ragtime” anthem “Make Them Hear You,” in a commanding performance that drove the Minskoff Theater to delirium on Monday night, the young singer accepted the Jimmy Award for best actor. He gave an equally poised acceptance speech, expressing gratitude with a calm cadence and the occasional wry chuckle of someone who’s seen and heard it all.

headline: How Much Blush Is Too Much?
abstract: If you’re not sure, you might have what some people on TikTok are calling “blush blindness.”
lead_paragraph: Jennie Suk, 27, has gotten really into wearing blush in recent months, inspired by videos from TikTok influencers and celebrities, like the singer Sabrina Carpenter, whose dewy, flushed cheeks have become her calling card.

headline: Bringing Up Drugs? Undermining the Debate? These Are Old Trump Tactics.
abstract: Ahead of a high-stakes debate, former President Donald J. Trump is trying to reset the low expectations he set for President Biden.
lead_paragraph: To spend time on former President Donald J. Trump’s corner of social media is to witness any number of contradictory, unproven or outright conspiratorial ideas blooming, all at once. The approaching presidential debate has apparently sent him into overdrive.

headline: New Jersey Gamer Flew to Florida to Attack Rival With a Hammer, Police Say
abstract: The man went to the house of another player of the fantasy online game ArcheAge to confront him, the Nassau County sheriff’s office in Florida said. He is charged with attempted murder.
lead_paragraph: A New Jersey man who the police said had flown to Florida and attacked a fellow gamer with a hammer over an online dispute was charged with attempted second-degree murder on Sunday.

headline: Austin and Russia’s New Defense Minister Speak via Phone for the First Time
abstract: Communications between Washington and Moscow have become rare since Russia invaded Ukraine more than two years ago.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III spoke by phone on Tuesday with Russia’s new defense minister, Andrei Belousov, the Pentagon said, in a rare conversation between the Biden administration and Moscow.

headline: Another Real Estate Broker Steps Down in the Face of Sex Assault Suits
abstract: Tal Alexander, who rose to fame in the luxury housing market with his younger brother Oren, will take a leave from the firm he helped to create. Oren left earlier in June.
lead_paragraph: Tal Alexander, whose portfolio of luxury real estate transactions includes some of New York and Miami’s most eye-popping sales, is stepping down from the high-end brokerage he co-founded in the wake of mounting allegations of sexual assault.
