abstract: Across Asia and Europe, the event stoked concerns about American stability, both domestically and on crucial foreign policy issues like Washington’s commitment to alliances.
lead_paragraph: Amid a faltering performance by President Biden in the presidential debate Thursday night, former President Donald J. Trump caused anxiety among America’s allies with a simple shrug.

headline: Time Traveling Through London With an Impressionist Painter
abstract: A writer used Camille Pissarro’s paintings of suburban London and a ‘lost’ railway as a lens for exploring the city’s history — and settling an arcane mystery.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1870s, an émigré painter watched from a railway footbridge as a steam engine left a station on London’s suburban fringe. His name was Camille Pissarro and he was developing a style of plein-air painting that would soon be called “Impressionism.”

headline: For an Aquatic Veterinarian, It’s Never ‘Just a Fish’
abstract: Stress, ovarian cancer, buoyancy disorders: Every pet has its troubles, and needs a good doctor who makes house calls.
lead_paragraph: Many students begin veterinary school with career aspirations that date back to childhood, when they fell in love with the idea of ministering to cats and dogs, or horses, or the exotic animals at the zoo. Jessie Sanders arrived at veterinary school with a more particular passion. “I was the one weird fish kid,” she said.

headline: Three People in a One-Bedroom Apartment? They Found a Clever Solution.
abstract: Co-op rules meant they couldn’t add a second bedroom, so they came up with an elegant workaround.
lead_paragraph: Hardwood floors, beamed ceilings, exposed brick walls, working fireplaces — for many New Yorkers, the elements of a classic rowhouse are as toothsome as a dessert buffet at a wedding.

headline: How Fast Food Is Getting Faster
abstract: Retailers like Chick-fil-A are opening smaller, takeout-focused outposts with little or no seating to complement their traditional locations.
lead_paragraph: Chick-fil-A’s new location in New York City has everything you’d expect from the chicken shop: friendly servers, crispy waffle fries and a line of hungry customers. It’s missing just one thing: seats.

headline: Hoot, Howl and Sneeze: 6 Picture Books for Maximum Read-Aloud Joy
abstract: From silly rhymes to lively sound effects to stealthily-building suspense, these old standbys and new classics have something for everyone.
lead_paragraph: There are two kinds of story time: the one where listeners’ heads drop sleepily onto your shoulders and the one that feels, refreshingly, like a table read for the theater of the absurd. The former is sweet and cozy. The latter sparks audience participation and requests for an encore. If you’re going for this vibe and in the mood to strut your stuff as a raconteur, start here.

headline: Choosing Love and Marriage During the Holocaust
abstract: Natalie Mandelbaum, a coordinator and researcher of Yad Vashem’s online photo exhibit “Weddings During the Holocaust,” describes highlighting 11 Jewish couples who married during that perilous time.
lead_paragraph: “Weddings During the Holocaust” is one of 70 ongoing online exhibits depicting the Holocaust that was conceived, organized and produced by Yad Vashem, the World Holocaust Remembrance Center, Israel’s largest Holocaust memorial and museum. Intentionally debuting on Feb. 14, 2024, it is the only retrospective illustrating couples who married during World War II, at a time when millions of Jews were killed at the hands of the German Nazis and their allies.

headline: Money Dysmorphia
abstract: A nagging insecurity about one’s finances — even when one is on solid footing — that is most prevalent among Gen Z and millennials.
lead_paragraph: Flashy cars. Five-figure handbags. Island vacations.

headline: Ghosts, Haunted Dreams and the Devil Himself in 4 New Horror Books
abstract: Our columnist reviews June’s horror releases.
lead_paragraph: Riley Sager’s MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT (Dutton, 376 pp., $30) is a creepy and unnerving thriller that flirts with the supernatural.

headline: Why Can’t New York Make a Proper Monument to Gay History?
abstract: Fifty-five years after Stonewall, a new tourist center suggests that what the riots stood for is old history. But is everything now OK?
lead_paragraph: During this NYC Pride Week, the name of the place and event that gave it birth, Stonewall, has been more than usually in the air, and efforts to monumentalize it continue. News has come that a local subway station will be rechristened in its honor (new name: Christopher Street-Stonewall National Monument Station), and a brand-new cultural space called Stonewall National Monument Visitor Center opens today in the neighborhood.

headline: 16 New Books Coming in July
abstract: New novels from J. Courtney Sullivan and Liz Moore, a memoir by a “hacktivist” member of Anonymous — and more.
lead_paragraph: A dilapidated lavender mansion, perched high on a craggy bluff in Maine, turns out to be more than a home: It’s the key to a century of hopes, misdeeds and family ghosts.

headline: Is Biden Too Old? America Got Its Answer.
abstract: Three Opinion writers weigh in on the first presidential debate of 2024.
lead_paragraph: On the “Matter of Opinion” post-debate episode, the hosts Ross Douthat and Michelle Cottle are joined by Ezra Klein, who says, “At some point Democrats have to decide if they want to try to win this election or it is simply too uncomfortable for them to do anything but be on this train as it derails.”

headline: $1.3 Million Homes in Belgium
abstract: A four-bedroom house with a thatched roof, a turn-of-the-century rowhouse and a three-bedroom duplex in a converted grain distillery.
lead_paragraph: Built in 1938 on about half an acre, this four-bedroom villa with a thatched roof is in Brasschaat, a municipality in northern Belgium about nine miles north of Antwerp and 10 miles south of the border with the Netherlands. Luxury homes, villas, and estates dot the landscape in Brasschaat, which has a town park with a restored castle, hiking and biking trails, playgrounds, tennis, an indoor swimming pool and a lake with paddle boats. The Gunfire Museum, an international military museum, displays tanks, artillery and other war artifacts from the last century. Thermal spas abound. Restaurant Maurice, which received a 2024 Michelin mention, serves carpaccio langoustine and oxtail.

headline: Remembering Norman Mailer and His Thorny Legacy
abstract: “How to Come Alive With Norman Mailer” hits on an ingenious structure that avoids hagiography even as it includes friends and family.
lead_paragraph: Given the hagiographic bias of most celebrity documentaries, “How to Come Alive With Norman Mailer” (in theaters) sails into choppy waters. The director Jeff Zimbalist had to figure out a way to sum up one of the 20th century’s most admired, and most notorious, cultural figures. Mailer’s legacy as a novelist, speaker, filmmaker and pop culture icon — the movie reminded me how often he’s mentioned in “Gilmore Girls” — is full of bad behavior and also brilliant work, and making a film about such a person seems nearly impossible in our nuance-averse climate.

headline: A Suitcase, 10 Countries, One School: A Migrant Family’s Search for Home
abstract: Schools ground migrant children and their families when everything else — the language, the city, the culture, the people — is brand-new.
lead_paragraph: Mary Lauri and Roberto Rodríguez, asylum seekers from Venezuela, heard about Public School 46, in Fort Greene in Brooklyn, from a mother at Hall Street, the emergency shelter where their family had been placed. It was five blocks away and had a Spanish dual-language program.

headline: At Olympic Team Trials, U.S.A. Gymnastics Gets Warm and Fuzzy
abstract: Beacon, a golden retriever, began working with U.S.A. Gymnastics last year as part of the organization’s efforts to transform the sport’s toxic culture. More dogs quickly followed.
lead_paragraph: Just before this week’s United States Olympic gymnastics team trials, a very eager worker flew to the host city of Minneapolis with protein treats, a collection of colorful bandannas and a stuffed turtle. Upon his arrival he was given a U.S.A. Gymnastics badge to wear around his neck, identifying him as “Goodest Boy.”

headline: ‘My Lady Jane’ Asks: ‘What if History Were Different?’
abstract: A fantastical series about the very short-term 16th century queen Lady Jane Grey takes historical liberties in the name of reclamation — and fun.
lead_paragraph: Lady Jane Grey is generally considered a tragic heroine, the teen queen of England and Ireland for nine days in 1553 before her foes manipulated her into an early death by execution. As the cheeky narrator of the Amazon series “My Lady Jane” puts it, “History remembers her as the ultimate damsel in distress.”

headline: Experimental Films Fuel ‘Slave Play’ Documentary
abstract: The playwright Jeremy O. Harris’s “Slave Play. Not a Movie. A Play.” wears its intellectual references on its sleeve.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy O. Harris’s new documentary — titled “Slave Play. Not A Movie. A Play.” — is ostensibly focused on acting students rehearsing scenes from his provocative “Slave Play,” which was nominated in 2020 for 12 Tony Awards.

headline: 10 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
abstract: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
lead_paragraph: The first film in Kevin Costner’s projected four-film cycle collects various depictions of the Old West starting in the Civil War.

headline: Napoleon’s Loot: When the World Decided Stolen Art Should Go Back
abstract: As museums encounter increasing claims on their collections, experts say much of the debate hearkens back to 1815, when the Louvre was forced to surrender the spoils of war.
lead_paragraph: In September 1815, Karl von Müffling, the Prussian governor of Paris, presented himself at the doors of the Louvre and ordered its French guards to step aside.

headline: The Secret to Khruangbin’s Ultracool Vibe
abstract: Sounds and influences that shape the band’s music.
lead_paragraph: The Houston trio Khruangbin seems to be everywhere right now. You’ve probably heard their music on a TV show or a TikTok video or in your local coffee shop. The band has a signature sound that many musicians are chasing but can’t seem to replicate. What makes their sound so distinct and easy to listen to? Ryan Bradley digs into the band’s influences and unmistakable vibe.

headline: How to Strengthen Your Strands Game
abstract: The newest New York Times game has confounded and enthralled solvers. Here are some tips to help you improve your skills.
lead_paragraph: Strands, the newest game from The New York Times, is part Spelling Bee, part Mini Crossword and part word search puzzle. The objective is to use every letter on the board exactly once to create words that relate to the day’s theme, which is hinted at in the puzzle’s title.

headline: The Voices of A.I. Are Telling Us a Lot
abstract: Even as the technology advances, stubborn stereotypes about women are re-encoded again and again.
lead_paragraph: What does artificial intelligence sound like? Hollywood has been imagining it for decades. Now A.I. developers are cribbing from the movies, crafting voices for real machines based on dated cinematic fantasies of how machines should talk.

headline: Amid Challenges, Small New York City Museums Are Closing Their Doors
abstract: One quarter of all cultural institutions are dipping into their reserves or endowments to cover operating expenses. Mergers may be on the horizon.
lead_paragraph: Small museums that have helped define the unique character of New York City’s artistic scene are moving, changing or calling it quits, citing a challenging economic climate.

headline: On Pride Weekend, the Stonewall Visitor Center Opens
abstract: The center marks the history of the Stonewall Inn and the uprising there in 1969 that inspired a new era of gay activism.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today, and on Fridays through the summer, we’ll focus on things to do in New York over the weekend.

headline: Are You Screaming for This Whipped Cream Sunscreen?
abstract: A few viral products aim to put fun in the sun(screen).
lead_paragraph: Last week, on a family vacation at a resort in Scottsdale, Ariz., Alexa Johnson grabbed a canister containing a substance that looked like whipped cream, felt like whipped cream and made the same whooshing sound as whipped cream. But it wasn’t whipped cream at all. It was sunscreen.

headline: After That Debate, the Risk of Biden Is Clear
abstract: I joined my Times Opinion colleagues Ross Douthat and Michelle Cottle to discuss the debate — and what Democrats might do next.
lead_paragraph: I joined my Times Opinion colleagues Ross Douthat and Michelle Cottle to discuss the debate — and what Democrats might do next.

headline: Volcanoes, Vines, Freedom: Exploring Gay-Friendly Lanzarote
abstract: A place of windswept, austere beauty, this corner of the Canary Islands is a growing L.G.B.T.Q. destination as well as a perfect place to clear the mind.
lead_paragraph: “Lanzarote is a place of secrets and mysteries,” the Spanish filmmaker Pedro Almodóvar once said of the place he used as a backdrop for his 2009 film “Broken Embraces.” “After I set foot on the island, the tensions I bring from Madrid disappear, as if this land had healing qualities.”

headline: Wall Street Seems Calm. A Closer Look Shows Something Else.
abstract: The S&P 500 has climbed sharply this year, with few big swings. Below the surface, though, there’s a great deal of turmoil
lead_paragraph: In the stock market, all is not quite as it seems.

headline: Couture Fit for a ‘Lion King’
abstract: A new Balmain collection pays homage to the Disney film on a milestone anniversary. Plus, a preppy designer makes a comeback.
lead_paragraph: For Olivier Rousteing, the creative director of Balmain, the Parisian luxury house, South Africa is a long way from home. But the country is close to his heart.

headline: Make Something With Your Hands (Even if It’s Hideous)
abstract: Creating stuff is good for your brain.
lead_paragraph: I once decorated a mirror with shells, but I keep it in a closet. I’m fond of it, even though it looks a little sloppy. Sometimes I’ll debate whether to toss it, and then gently put it back on the shelf.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, June 27, 2024
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Season 3 of “The Bear.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including Season 3 of “The Bear.”

headline: Supreme Court’s Abortion Rulings May Set the Stage for More Restrictions
abstract: The court’s strategy of avoidance and delay cannot last and may have been shaped by a desire to avoid controversy in an election year.
lead_paragraph: Superficially, abortion rights had a good run at the Supreme Court this term. Two weeks ago, the justices unanimously let an abortion pill remain widely available. On Thursday, the court dismissed a case about Idaho’s strict abortion ban, which had the effect of letting emergency rooms in the state perform the procedure when the patient’s health is at risk.

headline: Biden Administration Denies Mining and Drilling Access to Alaskan Wilderness
abstract: The Interior Department rejected a proposed industrial road through pristine land in Alaska that was needed to reach an estimated $7.5 billion copper deposit.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration denied permission on Friday for an Alaska agency to build a 211-mile industrial road that would have cut through Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve to reach copper and zinc deposits beneath untouched wilderness.

headline: Record Labels Sue A.I. Music Generators, Inside the Pentagon’s Tech Upgrade and HatGPT
abstract: A little something for everyone: lawsuits, fighter jets and Casey in a bucket hat.
lead_paragraph: Record labels — including Sony, Universal and Warner — are suing two leading A.I. music generation companies, accusing them of copyright infringement. Mitch Glazier, chief executive of the Recording Industry Association of America, the industry group representing the music labels, talks with us about the argument they are advancing. Then, we take a look at defense technology and discuss why Silicon Valley seems to be changing its tune about working with the military. Chris Kirchhoff, who ran a special Pentagon office in Silicon Valley, explains what he thinks is behind the shift. And finally, we play another round of HatGPT.

headline: The Mess in Atlanta
abstract: The two Americans who most want this presidential rematch were the ones standing onstage.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was ugly.

headline: Stream These 9 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in July
abstract: A bunch of major titles are leaving for U.S. subscribers this month, including films by George Lucas and Ang Lee. See them while you can.
lead_paragraph: Two of the biggest movies of the 1970s and one of the biggest of the ’80s are among the movies leaving Netflix in the United States in July; other highlights include a family favorite, a comic book oddity and an unconventional biopic. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

headline: Israeli Minister Will Release Palestinian Funds if Settlements Are Legalized, Officials Say
abstract: Under a tentative deal, Israel’s far-right finance minister, Bezalel Smotrich, would help the Palestinian Authority stave off financial collapse if five illegal West Bank outposts are authorized.
lead_paragraph: With the Israeli-occupied West Bank facing deepening economic woes, Israeli officials said on Friday that a far-right minister had tentatively agreed to release some frozen funds to the financially embattled Palestinian Authority in exchange for strengthening Israeli settlements in the territory.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 384, June 29, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Key Debate Moments: A Night of Stumbles and Falsehoods, and More
abstract: Plus, Bronny James joins his dad at the Lakers.
lead_paragraph: On Today’s Episode:

headline: A Brutal Debate for Biden
abstract: The president’s shaky performance in his first 2024 debate against Donald Trump has deepened concerns about his age.
lead_paragraph: In the first debate of the 2024 race, President Biden hoped to make the case that Donald J. Trump was unfit to return to the White House. Instead, Mr. Biden’s weak performance deepened doubts about his own fitness for the job.

headline: Brittany Was Once Barren Ground for France’s Far Right. No More.
abstract: The region along the northwest coast has few immigrants and little crime or unemployment, but the far-right National Rally has made inroads saying that all three are coming.
lead_paragraph: So many locals over so many decades have left Gourin in rural Brittany for the United States that Air France awarded the town a miniature Statue of Liberty.

headline: A Halting Performance
abstract: Both candidates affirmed voter fears — about President Biden’s age and Donald Trump’s character.
lead_paragraph: After last night, many Democrats are panicked.

headline: Deaths Linked to Japanese Supplement Suddenly Rise to 80
abstract: The case, involving a supplement intended to reduce cholesterol, has put attention on how companies are allowed to self-report claims about their products.
lead_paragraph: A Japanese pharmaceutical company is investigating 80 deaths possibly linked to a yeast-containing supplement it sells in Japan, the country’s health ministry said Friday, in a shocking increase from an earlier revelation that is focusing attention on how supplements are regulated.

headline: Princess Anne Returns Home From the Hospital
abstract: Anne, the younger sister of King Charles III, suffered a concussion and other injuries in an accident at her country residence, palace officials said.
lead_paragraph: Princess Anne, the younger sister of King Charles III, was released from a hospital on Friday, five days after suffering a concussion and other injuries in an accident at her country residence, northeast of Bristol, England.

headline: Wife’s Ex-Boyfriend and Fear of Poverty at Center of Menendez’s Defense
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez’s lawyers are expected to call witnesses who will describe his childhood and the rocky start to his relationship with his wife.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez’s lawyers have cast him as a man who was duped by his dazzling wife, Nadine Menendez, and unaware of the gold bars and cash she kept in her locked bedroom closet — or the deals she made to get them.

headline: Democratic Donors’ Big Question: What’s Plan B?
abstract: An unsteady debate performance by President Biden has scrambled the thinking among some donors about whether the party needs to find an alternative.
lead_paragraph: After a bruising 90-minute debate that underscored President Biden’s single-biggest weakness — concern about his age — Democratic donors exchanged panicked texts and emails with one question: What’s Plan B?

headline: She Wants to Save the Arts in Britain (if She Can Get Elected)
abstract: The Labour lawmaker Thangam Debbonaire has a plan to turn Britain’s ailing cultural sector around. Will she get to implement it?
lead_paragraph: For the past 14 years, Conservative-led governments in Britain said they wanted to maintain the country’s status as a cultural powerhouse, to foster new talent and to keep the home of the Beatles and Harry Potter in the global spotlight.

headline: The Fed’s Preferred Inflation Measure Cools, Welcome News
abstract: The economy appears to be downshifting and price gains are moderating, as Federal Reserve officials creep closer to beating inflation.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve’s preferred inflation measure continued to cool as consumer spending grew only moderately, good news for central bankers who have been trying to weigh down demand and wrestle price increases under control.

headline: Summer Reading Contest, Week 4: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
abstract: To participate, submit your response here by July 5 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced by July 17.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the fourth week of our 15th Annual Summer Reading Contest.

headline: L.A. County Aims to Eliminate Medical Debt for 150,000 Residents
abstract: The county is investing $5 million to partner with a nonprofit and wipe out $500 million in debt for residents. The program is expected to start later this year.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-six percent of Californians have medical debt, owed to a doctor’s office, a hospital, a collections agency or a credit card company. That financial burden can lead people to delay or forgo necessary medical care.

headline: Why Some People Don’t Talk About Money With Their Partner
abstract: A new report finds that people stressed about their finances are often worried that discussing it will lead to an argument. But experts say conversations can help.
lead_paragraph: People who are stressed about their finances are often wary of talking about money with their romantic partners, even though it may be beneficial to their relationship, new research finds.

headline: Maps: 7.2-Magnitude Earthquake Shakes Peru
abstract: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
lead_paragraph: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.

headline: The Winners of Our 7th Annual Student Podcast Contest
abstract: We invited teenagers to create an original five-minute podcast about almost anything. Here are the finalists selected from over 1,100 submissions.
lead_paragraph: An intimate look at foster families, a moving account of navigating different worlds as a first-generation American teenager, and an exploration of why women — and not men — are called witches.

headline: Iowa Supreme Court Allows Six-Week Abortion Ban to Take Effect
abstract: Republican lawmakers passed the restrictions last year, but a lower court blocked enforcement of the law.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa Supreme Court ruled on Friday that the state’s six-week abortion ban could be enforced, a decision that sharply limits access to the procedure and fulfills a longstanding aim of the state’s Republican leaders.

headline: This Debate, We Could Hear Biden Speak. There His Troubles Began.
abstract: The CNN presidential debate kept the volume down, for a change. That didn’t make it more intelligible.
lead_paragraph: With the plans for the 2024 presidential debates, President Biden’s campaign appeared to get much of what it wanted. It got its preferred timeline, with Thursday night’s debate in Atlanta far earlier on the calendar than usual. It got the live audience removed. It got, above all, an agreement to mute the microphone on the candidate who wasn’t speaking, to avoid the cross-talk that made his first 2020 debate with Donald J. Trump a cacophonous mess.

headline: Read the document: What the Iowa Supreme Court said
abstract: The Iowa Supreme Court ruled that the state’s six-week abortion ban could be enforced. Read its ruling here.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa Supreme Court ruled that the state’s six-week abortion ban could be enforced. Read its ruling here.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Ban on Sleeping Outdoors in Homelessness Case
abstract: The case is likely to have broad ramifications for how cities across the country respond to homelessness.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday upheld an Oregon city’s ban on homeless residents sleeping outdoors, a decision likely to reverberate far beyond the West Coast as cities across the country grapple with a growing homelessness crisis.

headline: What I’m Reading: Tunneling to the Past
abstract: Looking for answers, or an escape, in a fraught world.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a while since I did a “what I’m reading” roundup. (After the newsletter went to once a week, it became harder to slot them in.) But today I wonder if you’re feeling like I am, worried about the state of the world and eager to find answers — or at least a way to escape searching for them — in books.

headline: Justices Limit Power of Federal Agencies, Imperiling an Array of Regulations
abstract: A foundational 1984 decision had required courts to defer to agencies’ reasonable interpretations of ambiguous statutes, underpinning regulations on health care, safety and the environment.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday reduced the power of executive agencies by sweeping aside a longstanding legal precedent, endangering countless regulations and transferring power from the executive branch to Congress and the courts.

headline: At Euro 2024, a Very England Fight Misses the Point
abstract: A back and forth over the pundit’s one-word analysis of his country’s performances rests on a misconception about the media’s role.
lead_paragraph: The problem, really, boils down to a single word. Unfortunately, that word — the key word in all of this — is not one that can be used here. But you know it. It is an adjective, a noun, a verb and most often an exclamation. You might say it when you stub your toe, or spill a cup of coffee, or realize that you have accidentally hit reply all.

headline: Read the Court’s Decision to Overrule the Chevron Doctrine
abstract: The ruling sweeps aside a legal precedent that required courts to defer to the expertise of federal administrators in carrying out laws passed by Congress.
lead_paragraph: The ruling sweeps aside a legal precedent that required courts to defer to the expertise of federal administrators in carrying out laws passed by Congress.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,106, June 29, 2024
abstract: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Wrist Weights Are Back. But Do They Work?
abstract: We asked fitness experts what wearable weights, which are popular on TikTok, can really do for your health.
lead_paragraph: Wearable wrist weights, which once seemed relegated to the dustbin of fitness history, are seeing a resounding resurgence on social media.

headline: Overlooked No More: Otto Lucas, ‘God in the Hat World’
abstract: His designs made it onto the covers of fashion magazines and onto the heads of celebrities like Greta Garbo. His business closed after he died in a plane crash.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s selections include a Japanese serial-killer thriller, a Pride Month pick from Sri Lanka, a Malaysian drama about undocumented street hustlers and more.
lead_paragraph: Part of the Criterion Channel’s ongoing Queersighted series, this debut feature by the Pakistani Canadian artist Sharlene Bamboat deploys cinema as a kind of metaphysical ferry: It moves irreverently across the boundaries between countries, languages and genres, and between image and text. Filmed in Batticaloa in Sri Lanka, scored in the Isle of Skye in Scotland, and edited in Montreal, Canada, the movie is in part a portrait of a lesbian poet, Ponni, shot intimately on video by her partner, Sarala.

headline: Mikhail Baryshnikov on Leaving Everything Behind
abstract: Fifty years ago, Baryshnikov defected from the Soviet Union. He discusses that day, the war in Ukraine and the challenges facing Russian artists today.
lead_paragraph: On the night of June 29, 1974, after a performance with a touring Bolshoi Ballet troupe in downtown Toronto, Mikhail Baryshnikov made his way out a stage door, past a throng of fans and began to run.

headline: Dress Your Chicken in Mustard and Mayonnaise
abstract: The cloaked breast meat is insulated from the heat of the grill and made tender by the acidity of the mustard.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. When there are snapper bluefish running in the bays nearby, I like to catch a couple and break them down into chunks and fillets — the chunks for a freestyle ceviche with mango, jalapeño, red onion and tons of lime, and the fillets for slathering with mayonnaise and mustard and roasting into excellence, just as my grandparents did, just as my parents did and, hopefully, just as my children will, down the generations. Mustard and mayonnaise are a phenomenal combination.

headline: Read the Court’s Ruling on Jan. 6 Obstruction
abstract: The court ruled in favor of a former police officer seeking to throw out an obstruction charge for participating in the riot on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: The court ruled in favor of a former police officer seeking to throw out an obstruction charge for participating in the riot on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Supreme Court Says Prosecutors Overstepped With Jan. 6 Charge
abstract: The ruling that the Justice Department misused a 2002 law in charging a pro-Trump rioter who entered the Capitol could have an impact on hundreds of other cases, including one against Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that federal prosecutors had improperly used an obstruction law to prosecute some members of the pro-Trump mob that stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Where Can Sondheim’s Operatic Musicals Find a Home?
abstract: Jonathan Tunick, Stephen Sondheim’s longtime collaborator, unveiled a grand orchestration of “A Little Night Music” that deserves more than a concert.
lead_paragraph: Near the end of Stephen Sondheim’s musical “A Little Night Music,” the orchestra swells to what he is said to have called his Max Steiner moment, something out of “Casablanca” or “Gone With the Wind.”

headline: Join Us to Hear About the Loopholes of Hawaii’s Pay-to-Play Law
abstract: A joint investigation examined the role money plays in politics in Hawaii. Hear how journalists put the story together in a livestreamed event on July 10.
lead_paragraph: Hawaii is reeling from one of the largest corruption scandals in its history. Former State Senator J. Kalani English and former State Representative Ty Cullen pleaded guilty in February 2022 to accepting tens of thousands of dollars in bribes during their time in office. Starting as early as 2014, and continuing until at least 2020, state and local politicians raked in campaign contributions at late-night fund-raising parties.

headline: A Woman Sleeping With Her Stepson? This Director Knows It May Shock.
abstract: The French filmmaker Catherine Breillat has been exploring relationships between girls and older men since the 1970s. Her latest, “Last Summer,” flips the script.
lead_paragraph: When the French director Catherine Breillat was 40, her then-husband and the father of her first child ended their relationship to be with a much younger woman. Soon after, Breillat started dating a man 12 years her junior.

headline: Yes … Who? Here Are the Chefs Who Appear in ‘The Bear.’
abstract: Last season, the FX series featured a parade of Hollywood celebrities. In the new one, it’s showing off its food-world credibility with a series of cameos from star chefs.
lead_paragraph: This article includes spoilers from Season 3 of “The Bear.”

headline: Here’s What the Court’s Chevron Ruling Could Mean in Everyday Terms
abstract: The decision is expected to prompt a rush of litigation challenging regulations across the entire federal government, from food safety to the environment.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday to limit the broad regulatory authority of federal agencies could lead to the elimination or weakening of thousands of rules on the environment, health care, worker protection, food and drug safety, telecommunications, the financial sector and more.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Could Put the F.D.A. in the Cross Hairs of Its Critics
abstract: Challenges could range from whether tainted spinach can be traced back to a farm to a decision on whether drugs are safe and effective enough to be sold in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration, which oversees a vast swath of items people use every day, is expected to see an increase — perhaps an onslaught — of lawsuits following the Supreme Court’s decision on Friday.

headline: She Thought She Caught a Man Cheating, So She Posted on TikTok
abstract: A woman took a sneaky video of a man and woman on a plane, claiming that she was witnessing an extramarital affair.
lead_paragraph: Nowhere is safe. Not a cafe, not a train and not a plane.

headline: Justices Thomas and Alito Ignored Calls for Recusal in Jan. 6 Case
abstract: Experts in legal ethics have said that the activities of the justices’ wives raised serious questions about their impartiality.
lead_paragraph: Justices Clarence Thomas and Samuel A. Alito Jr., rejecting calls for their disqualification, participated in the case, siding with a member of the mob that stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Dutch Olympic Organizers Defend Participation of Athlete Convicted of Rape
abstract: Steven van de Velde, a beach volleyball player, spent time in prison for the 2014 rape of a 12-year-old girl. His inclusion on the Olympic team has caused a stir in the international news media.
lead_paragraph: The Dutch Volleyball Association and Dutch Olympic organizers are standing by their decision to send a man convicted of rape to the Paris Olympics this summer to represent the Netherlands in beach volleyball.

headline: U.S. Presses to Avert Wider War Between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon
abstract: A recent flurry of diplomacy aims to head off a conflict that could pit the United States directly against Iran.
lead_paragraph: The United States is in the midst of an intense diplomatic push to prevent full-on war between Israel and Hezbollah forces in Lebanon, as the risks rise that either side could initiate a broader regional fight.

headline: Banks Stand to Benefit From the Supreme Court Decision on the Chevron Doctrine
abstract: The ruling will amplify a shift already underway in the lower courts, which have in recent years been receptive to lawsuits challenging financial regulators’ actions.
lead_paragraph: The end of Chevron deference is a boon for banking lobbyists, who have in recent years intensified their pushback against the agencies that oversee them — especially the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, one of the industry’s most aggressive regulators.

headline: A Visual History of the Harlem Renaissance
abstract: The Harlem Renaissance changed the world. We’ve gathered dozens of images, many that we’ve never published, showing the people and the art that they created.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem Renaissance changed the world. We’ve gathered dozens of images, many that we’ve never published, showing the people and the art that they created.

headline: 5 International Shows Worth Watching, From Kafka to a Human Kaiju
abstract: The return of “Babylon Berlin” was the international TV news of the week, but here are five other recent series to check out.
lead_paragraph: The long-awaited American premiere of a new season of the German hit “Babylon Berlin” was the big news this week in the realm of international television series. But interesting shows from other countries arrive on an almost daily basis. Here are five recent series to check out.

headline: Democrats, anticipating Chevron’s demise, gave E.P.A. more power in recent climate law.
abstract: The Biden administration has been preparing for the overturn of Chevron, knowing that conservative activists have pushed cases like this, and that the majority of justices on the Supreme Court were expected to look favorably on it.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has been preparing for the overturn of Chevron, knowing that conservative activists have pushed cases like this, and that the majority of justices on the Supreme Court were expected to look favorably on it.

headline: Social Conservatives Push Trump on the G.O.P.’s Anti-Abortion Platform
abstract: Leaders of the anti-abortion movement sent a letter to Donald J. Trump amid worries he may try to weaken the anti-abortion language in the party platform.
lead_paragraph: A group of some of the most powerful social conservatives in the country, fearful that Donald J. Trump may push to water down the Republican Party’s official position on abortion, sent a pointed letter to the former president this month imploring him to keep strong anti-abortion language in the party platform.

headline: Conservative Christian Activists See Opportunity in Supreme Court Ruling
abstract: The decision overturning a precedent known as Chevron deference was celebrated by those who would target medication abortion and rights for transgender people.
lead_paragraph: Conservative Christian activists and lawyers are celebrating the Chevron decision as a significant win for their ambitions to target medication abortion and rights for transgender people.

headline: Kamala Harris Could Win This Election. Let Her.
abstract: The vice president is the obvious path out of the mess Joe Biden has created.
lead_paragraph: Like many Americans who watched the presidential debate on Thursday night, I knew when it was over that there was no way I was going to sleep. So I did something I almost never do: tuned in to the pundit commentary on cable news. I’m glad I did. Not long after the debate, Vice President Kamala Harris appeared on CNN with Anderson Cooper. Watching her calmly and methodically respond to a battering ram of questions from Cooper, it occurred to me: The obvious, logical path out of the mess President Biden created with his disastrous debate performance is for him to bow out with honor and endorse his young, vigorous and talented vice president to stand in his stead.

headline: One by One, Biden’s Closest Media Allies Defect After the Debate
abstract: The MSNBC host Joe Scarborough urged him to consider dropping out. So did other pundits the president had long viewed as his strongest allies in the news media.
lead_paragraph: Joe Scarborough pursed his lips and jotted down a few notes at his desk. It was 6 a.m. on Friday, seven and a half hours after a diminished President Biden had gingerly stepped off the debate stage, and the host of “Morning Joe” on MSNBC was about to deliver a painful message to viewers of television’s most reliable redoubt of Biden support.

headline: Biden vs. Trump: A Wrenching Debate
abstract: Readers are disturbed by “problematic performances” by both candidates, and some urge the president to bow out.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Big Number: $5 Billion
abstract: The amount Volkswagen said it planned to invest in the electric vehicle maker Rivian.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen, the German car company, said this week that it would invest up to $5 billion in Rivian, the American electric vehicle manufacturer that makes electric pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and delivery vans.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Could Undermine Treasury Department and I.R.S.
abstract: The decision overturning a longstanding precedent is likely to spawn challenges to dozens of tax regulations.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s knockdown of Chevron deference could complicate the ability of the Treasury Department and the Internal Revenue Service to craft federal regulations that are central to President Biden’s economic agenda.

headline: House G.O.P. Begins Push on Hard-Right Spending Bills, Teeing Up Future Battles
abstract: The Republican-led House loaded its funding measures with provisions that have no chance of becoming law, as both parties look toward a bigger fight later this year, most likely after the elections.
lead_paragraph: The Republican-led House voted on Friday to strip President Biden’s homeland security secretary and secretary of state of their salaries. It approved measures banning military installations from having drag queen story hours for children. And it passed legislation prohibiting paid leave for Pentagon employees who get an abortion.

headline: Towa Bird’s Bouncy Revenge Rock, and 10 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Camila Cabello, Wilco, Xavi and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: Prosecutors in Menendez Bribery Trial Rest Their Case
abstract: After seven weeks of trial, lawyers for Senator Robert Menendez are expected to begin calling witnesses on Monday to rebut the government’s case.
lead_paragraph: After seven weeks of trial, federal prosecutors rested their case on Friday against Senator Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat accused of conspiring to take hundreds of thousands of dollars in gold, cash and other bribes in return for the senator’s willingness to dispense political favors at home and abroad.

headline: Los Angeles Homeless Count Drops for the First Time in 6 Years
abstract: The reduction was a sign of progress for Mayor Karen Bass, who started an aggressive new program to move people off the streets in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles residents, long exhausted by homelessness, were optimistic when Mayor Karen Bass started an aggressive effort to move people from encampments into motel rooms in late 2022, soon after she took office. Piles of belongings were removed from freeway underpasses. Sidewalks that had been blocked by lines of tents were cleared.

headline: Leading Democrats Vouch for Biden, but Concede a ‘Bad Night’
abstract: The president’s surrogates acknowledged his struggles in the debate but said that one night did not reflect his successes, or the dangers of a second Trump term.
lead_paragraph: Democratic Party leaders swiftly and unequivocally ruled out the idea that President Biden would or should step aside after his shaky performance at the first presidential debate. But there was a palpable sense of anxiety on Capitol Hill on Friday morning about what it would mean for his campaign and their own re-election chances.

headline: Learn the Secrets to Perfect Pasta Every Time
abstract: In the latest installment of her YouTube series, the cookbook author and chef Sohla El-Waylly will teach you how to tame that pantry workhorse.
lead_paragraph: Pasta — that pantry workhorse, a staple of easy weeknight meals — can take on just about any ingredient thrown at it. But it also comes with its share of pitfalls: clumping, oversalting, over- or undercooking. Worry not. In her latest installment of Cooking 101, Sohla El-Waylly will walk you through the secrets to making perfect pasta.

headline: Girl Groupers Gone (Successfully!) Solo
abstract: With two new albums from members of Fifth Harmony out now, a look back at other pop singers who took off on their own.
lead_paragraph: This is not exactly a boom time for American girl groups*. The last high-profile one to have any chart success was Fifth Harmony, who formed on the 2012 season of “The X Factor” and went on an indefinite hiatus in 2018. I bring this up because, strikingly, two former members of Fifth Harmony have released solo albums in the past two weeks: The R&B chanteuse Normani put out her long-gestating “Dopamine” on June 14, and today the Cuban-born pop star Camila Cabello is unleashing her bold, outré fourth solo album, “C, XOXO.”

headline: ‘I Know I’m Not a Young Man’: Biden Confronts Doubts During Forceful Rally
abstract: President Biden tried to minimize concerns about his fitness for office, saying he would not be running if he didn’t think he was up to the job.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday tried to beat back doubts about his fitness following a disjointed debate performance the night before, firing up a crowd of supporters with an energetic speech that accused former President Donald J. Trump of being a “one-man crime wave.”

headline: Young People Demand Change Ahead of Britain’s Election
abstract: Many young people feel disillusioned by politics in the United Kingdom, as the country readies for a pivotal general election after 14 years of Conservative governments. Megan Specia, an international correspondent for The New York Times based in London, spoke with young voters in the northern English cities of Liverpool and Manchester to hear their perspectives on the election.
lead_paragraph: Many young people feel disillusioned by politics in the United Kingdom, as the country readies for a pivotal general election after 14 years of Conservative governments. Megan Specia, an international correspondent for The New York Times based in London, spoke with young voters in the northern English cities of Liverpool and Manchester to hear their perspectives on the election.

headline: Regulatory Agencies Suffered Their Latest Blow in Chevron Ruling
abstract: The Supreme Court’s conservative majority has made it easier to sue agencies and get their rules struck down.
lead_paragraph: Overturning the Chevron deference precedent is just the latest in a series of ringing blows the Supreme Court’s Republican-appointed conservative bloc has delivered to the ability of regulatory agencies to impose rules on powerful business interests, advancing a longstanding goal of the conservative legal movement and the donors who have funded its rise.

headline: New Jersey Tells Trump’s Golf Clubs to Show They Deserve Liquor Licenses
abstract: The state said that former President Donald J. Trump’s felony convictions may mean he does not have the moral character to serve drinks.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey alcoholic beverage regulators on Friday ordered two of former President Donald J. Trump’s golf clubs to demonstrate why their liquor licenses should be renewed after he was found guilty of falsifying business records.

headline: The Supreme Court Thinks That by Arguing More, We Can Be Less Divided
abstract: Everyone in our system, including judges and members of Congress, will be nudged to do their proper constitutional work.
lead_paragraph: With its decision in Loper Bright Enterprises v. Raimondo on Friday, the Supreme Court has put new limits on how government regulators can interpret the law.

headline: Fearful and Doubting Biden, Democrats Face an Uncertain Path Forward
abstract: A range of despairing Democrats began to reconsider their nominee after his rough debate showing, but there was no agreement on how, or whether, to urge him to step off the ticket.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party faced a brewing crisis on Friday as a wide range of lawmakers, party officials and activists began to actively consider what had previously been a pipe dream for pundits and worried voters: the prospect of replacing President Biden on the ticket roughly four months before Election Day.

headline: On Immigration, Biden Offers a Muted, Muddled Message
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump continued to spread fear of immigrants, while the president did not define any broader strategy on the issue.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump repeated his hard-line message on immigration at the debate on Thursday, casting undocumented immigrants as a threat to American jobs, national security and the social safety net. President Biden offered little in the way of rebuttal.

headline: Racist and Homophobic Comments Unsettle U.K. Election Campaign
abstract: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak denounced a slur used against him by a man campaigning for Reform U.K., the anti-immigration party led by Nigel Farage.
lead_paragraph: Last year, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said in a speech that he was proud to be Britain’s first prime minister of Asian heritage, but “even prouder that it’s just not a big deal.”

headline: Why Conservatives Shouldn’t Be Doomers
abstract: A late-Soviet debate night doesn’t mean we’re in late-Soviet America.
lead_paragraph: Along with Donald Trump, a big winner in Thursday night’s presidential debate was the distinguished historian Niall Ferguson, who recently stirred up a lot of debate with a column for The Free Press comparing contemporary America with the later stages of the Soviet Union.

headline: One Way to Make Russia Pay for Ukraine? Take Its Money.
abstract: U.S. and E.U. leaders are divided over how far to go in the economic war against Vladimir Putin.
lead_paragraph: “To modern eyes, 19th-century wars protected commerce and finance to a degree that is almost unbelievably generous,” the Cornell historian Nicholas Mulder wrote in his 2022 book, “The Economic Weapon: The Rise of Sanctions as a Tool of Modern War.”

headline: Biden’s ‘Hard Night’ at Debate Surprises Voters Who Had High Expectations
abstract: Poll respondents who had thought the president would perform well expressed disappointment. ‘His communication fell down,’ one voter said.
lead_paragraph: Before Thursday, voters were nearly evenly split on how President Biden would perform during the first presidential debate: 46 percent of registered voters said Mr. Biden would do well, and 49 percent predicted he would not, in a recent Times/Siena poll. More registered voters — 60 percent — said they thought former President Donald J. Trump would do well, and 34 percent said he would not.

headline: Could Democrats Replace Biden at the Top of the Presidential Ticket?
abstract: While it is possible, it would most likely lead to political upheaval in the party unless the president decides to step aside on his own terms.
lead_paragraph: A once politically far-fetched question — can President Biden be replaced at the top of the Democratic Party presidential ticket — has taken on new urgency after Mr. Biden’s halting debate performance against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Reopen N.Y.C. Libraries on Sundays? Yes. Free 3-K for All? Not Quite.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams and the City Council reached a $112 billion budget deal that restored some unpopular cuts to key programs.
lead_paragraph: After months of tense and protracted negotiations, Mayor Eric Adams and City Council leaders announced on Friday that they had reached agreement on a $112.4 billion budget for New York City that restored many of the mayor’s proposed cuts, including to libraries and cultural institutions.

headline: First the Debate, Then a Supreme Court Ruling: Trump’s Big 24 Hours
abstract: Successive successes reinvigorated Donald Trump’s campaign a month after he became the first major party nominee convicted of a felony.
lead_paragraph: When Donald J. Trump returned to the green room after Thursday night’s debate, he flashed two thumbs up to waiting advisers who greeted him with a standing ovation for his performance against President Biden.

headline: Diplo, D.J. and Music Producer, Is Accused in Lawsuit of ‘Revenge Porn’
abstract: A woman accused Diplo of distributing intimate images and videos of her without her consent; his lawyer likened her suit to others “in search of a meritless payday.”
lead_paragraph: Diplo, the Grammy-winning electronic dance music D.J. and producer, was accused in a lawsuit filed on Thursday of sharing sexually explicit images and videos of a woman without her consent.

headline: Michael Jackson Died With $500 Million in Debt
abstract: Jackson owed about $40 million to the tour promoter A.E.G. in 2009, his estate’s executors said in a court filing. They said all the debts have been eliminated.
lead_paragraph: Michael Jackson’s debts and creditor’s claims at the time of his death in 2009 totaled more than $500 million, according to a court filing by the pop superstar’s estate that provides details of his financial woes toward the end of his life.

headline: Leaders in Their Prime Debate Substance in Detail (No, Not in the U.S.)
abstract: The debates between contenders to be U.K. prime minister showed that Britain’s political culture, and the leaders who have emerged from it, are far removed from those across the ocean.
lead_paragraph: Forty-eight hours before President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump clashed onstage in Atlanta on Thursday, the leaders of Britain’s two major parties, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and Keir Starmer, went head-to-head in Nottingham, England.

headline: Texas Supreme Court Upholds Ban on Gender Transition Care for Minors
abstract: The all-Republican court voted 8 to 1 to leave in effect a law enacted last year during a wave of legislation targeting transgender rights.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Supreme Court upheld a state law on Friday that bans gender-transition medical treatment for minors, overturning a lower-court ruling that had temporarily blocked the law and dealing a blow to parents of transgender children.

headline: Book Club: Let’s Talk About ‘Headshot,’ by Rita Bullwinkel
abstract: Bullwinkel’s debut novel sheds light on the culture of youth women’s boxing through an ensemble cast of complicated characters. It packs a punch.
lead_paragraph: Rita Bullwinkel’s debut novel, “Headshot,” follows eight teenagers fighting in the Daughters of America Cup, a youth women’s boxing tournament staged in a dilapidated gym in Reno. Each chapter details a match between fighters, bout after bout, until finally a champion is declared.

headline: ‘Is It Too Late?’ Four Writers on What Democrats Should Do About Biden.
abstract: None of the options ensure victory against Trump — and some of them could badly split the party.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Healy: I’ve been deluged with texts and emails from senior Democrats in a panic over President Biden’s debate performance and describing scenarios in which he might get out of the race, Vice President Kamala Harris becomes the nominee, or the Democratic National Convention in August becomes an open competition for the nomination. Biden addressed his debate problem briefly at a rally Friday afternoon: “I don’t debate as well as I used to,” he said, “but I know how to tell the truth.” So there are intense but also mixed emotions among Democrats right now. What do they do about their candidate for president, and their campaign to beat Donald Trump? Michelle?

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, June 29, 2024
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: My Mom Failed to Warn Me About an Abuser. Should I Tell My Dad?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on cycles of abuse and a heartbreaking family secret.
lead_paragraph: I worked part time for my granduncle’s business when I was 13 and 14. There were many times when we were alone, and he sexually abused me. I never raised it with my parents in those early years; I doubted I would be believed, and my granduncle was a ‘‘kind old man’’ who was very generous to my financially strained family.

headline: Texas Driver Is Sentenced to 60 Years in Prison for Crash That Killed 8
abstract: A jury convicted the driver of eight counts of intoxication manslaughter after he plowed into a crowd of migrants in Brownsville, Texas, last year.
lead_paragraph: A Texas man who drove into a crowd of migrants outside a shelter in the border city of Brownsville last year, killing eight people, was convicted on Friday of eight counts of intoxication manslaughter and sentenced to 60 years in prison, a prosecutor said.

headline: Before LeBron and Bronny, These Fathers and Sons Made Sports History
abstract: The Los Angeles Lakers are poised to have the first father-son N.B.A. duo in league history. But other dads and sons have played pro sports together as well.
lead_paragraph: When the Los Angeles Lakers selected Bronny James, 19, in the second round of the N.B.A. draft on Thursday night, the team set up an intriguing story line. Next season, he could play in the same lineup as his father, the 39-year-old superstar LeBron James.

headline: The Best Engagement Gifts
abstract: Take the guesswork out of the present.
lead_paragraph: Take the guesswork out of the present.

headline: Paul Sperry, Tenor Who Specialized in American Song, Dies at 90
abstract: He carved out a niche by singing the music of living composers from his own country. He was praised by critics at home and abroad.
lead_paragraph: Paul Sperry, a tenor who championed little-known American art song and spiky contemporary works, and who was praised for his incisive performances of the classics, died on June 13 in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: A Dark Day for Democrats
abstract: The combination of President Biden’s debate performance and adverse Supreme Court rulings left Democrats reeling and in despair with elections not far off.
lead_paragraph: Democrats confronted a nightmare scenario on Friday as they surveyed the wreckage of major political, policy and legal disasters piled atop one another with elections for control of the White House and Congress less than five months away.

headline: Supreme Court Rejects Bannon’s Appeal to Delay Prison Sentence
abstract: Stephen Bannon will have to begin serving four months in prison on Monday, after the court turned aside his request to remain free while he appeals his conviction for contempt of Congress.
lead_paragraph: Stephen K. Bannon, the longtime ally of former President Donald J. Trump, will have to report to federal prison on Monday after the Supreme Court rejected his final effort to stave off a four-month sentence for contempt of Congress.

headline: 6 Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Darrin Bell, Maggie Smith, David Friend and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Darrin Bell, Maggie Smith, David Friend and more.

headline: Weakening Regulatory Agencies Will Be a Key Legacy of the Roberts Court
abstract: Two rulings this week by the Republican-appointed majority add to its steady pursuit of enfeebling the ability of the administrative state to impose rules on powerful business interests.
lead_paragraph: Twice in two days, the Supreme Court’s conservative supermajority has issued sweeping rulings that cut against established precedents and will hamstring the ability of regulatory agencies to impose rules on powerful business interests.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Speaking Like a Local While Traveling
abstract: Should this father be trying to communicate in the language of the places he visits if it’s embarrassing his son?
lead_paragraph: Harry writes: My 21-year-old son and I occasionally go on vacation to places where English is not the native language. I like to tap into some basic words,  like ciao, grazie, arrivederci. My son thinks that my accent and pronunciation are insulting and an affront to the locals. I am seeking a ruling that allows me to continue using small amounts of non-English languages if, in my heart, I am being sincere. My son would like you to rule that I only ever speak English.

headline: After Biden’s Debate Disaster, an Uncertain Path
abstract: Also, the Supreme Court ruled that prosecutors overstepped in Jan. 6 case. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Party is facing a growing crisis after President Biden’s struggles in his debate against Donald Trump last night. A wide range of lawmakers, advisers and activists mulled a shocking scenario: replacing him on the ticket roughly four months before Election Day.

headline: Student Loan Payments Paused for 3 Million in SAVE Program
abstract: The Education Department said it would put the borrowers in forbearance while it recalculated their payments to comply with recent court rulings.
lead_paragraph: Roughly three million borrowers with federal student loans will see their monthly payments paused in the coming days, as the Biden administration tries to recalculate their bills to comply with a federal court order in Kansas.

headline: Downballot Republicans Seize on Biden’s Halting Debate Performance
abstract: Facing resilient Democratic incumbents, G.O.P. House and Senate nominees highlighted their opponents’ support for President Biden after he faltered in the presidential debate.
lead_paragraph: Republicans running for the U.S. Senate and House gleefully seized on President Biden’s stumbles in Thursday’s debate, betting they could use his performance to drag down their Democratic opponents.

headline: To Serve His Country, President Biden Should Leave the Race
abstract: The president’s inadequate performance in the debate made it clear he is not the man he was four years ago.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has repeatedly and rightfully described the stakes in this November’s presidential election as nothing less than the future of American democracy.

headline: Doris Allen, Analyst Who Saw the Tet Offensive Coming, Is Dead at 97
abstract: Her warning of a big buildup of enemy troops poised to attack South Vietnam in 1968 was ignored, a major U.S. Army intelligence failure during the war.
lead_paragraph: Doris Allen, an Army intelligence analyst during the Vietnam War whose warning in early 1968 about the impending attacks by North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces that became known as the Tet offensive was ignored by higher-ups, died on June 11 in Oakland, Calif. She was 97.

headline: Embattled Alzheimer’s Researcher Is Charged With Fraud
abstract: Hoau-Yan Wang, a professor at City College, published studies supporting simufilam, now in advanced clinical trials.
lead_paragraph: A scientist whose research has been at the center of controversy over an Alzheimer’s drug candidate has been charged with fraud.

headline: An ‘Extremely Dangerous’ Hurricane Beryl Grows to a Category 4
abstract: Beryl became the earliest in a season a storm has strengthened to a Category 4 hurricane in the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Beryl, an unusual early-season storm that formed late Friday, intensified into a Category 4 storm on Sunday, with forecasters warning it would continue to rapidly gain strength as it moved west toward the Caribbean Sea.

headline: The Bible in Public Schools? Oklahoma Pushes Limits of Long Tradition.
abstract: The Bible has a deep history in American classrooms, but the state’s provocative superintendent wants to broadly expand its influence.
lead_paragraph: The Bible has been a presence in American classrooms to at least some degree since before the origins of the country’s public school system in the 19th century.

headline: She Needed an Emergency Abortion. Doctors in Idaho Put Her on a Plane.
abstract: In states that have banned abortion, hospitals have struggled to treat pregnant women facing health risks. A Supreme Court decision this week did not help.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Miller had gone to the emergency room in Boise, Idaho, after waking up with heavy bleeding in her 20th week of pregnancy. By afternoon, she was still leaking amniotic fluid and hemorrhaging and, now in a panic, struggling to understand why the doctor was telling her that she needed to leave the state to be treated.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Reflects Challenges of Jan. 6 Prosecutions
abstract: In finding that prosecutors misused an obstruction law to charge rioters, the justices highlighted the lack of an established legal blueprint for addressing an attack on the foundations of democracy.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision on Friday that prosecutors had misused an obstruction law in charging hundreds of rioters who attacked the Capitol is the latest example of the persistent challenges the Justice Department has faced in grappling with the consequences of Jan. 6, 2021.

headline: Jill Biden’s Dress Makes a Post-Debate Statement
abstract: At a rally in North Carolina, the first lady’s frock said it all.
lead_paragraph: To the political strategy that might in the future be called “transparent efforts to change the narrative and repair the damage done to Joe Biden in the first presidential debate,” add the dress that Jill Biden wore to accompany her husband to his next-day rally in Raleigh, N.C.

headline: In An Unpredictable Debate, a Tussle Over Golf Was Par for the Course
abstract: Bickering about their golf handicaps in Thursday’s presidential debate was panned as a petty exercise between two aging men trying vainly to outdo one another.
lead_paragraph: It was a surreal detour during a presidential debate already filled with peculiar exchanges and meandering remarks. On Thursday night, after squabbles about the economy, abortion and the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol riot, President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump tussled over … golf.

headline: Astronauts Are Not Stuck on the I.S.S., NASA and Boeing Officials Say
abstract: Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams will spend additional weeks in orbit as teams on the ground study malfunctioning thrusters on the Starliner spacecraft.
lead_paragraph: Two NASA astronauts who traveled at the start of June to the International Space Station were originally scheduled to return home a couple of weeks ago, completing a test flight of Boeing’s Starliner spacecraft.

headline: Putin Vows to Make New Nuclear Missiles and to Weigh Placing Them Near NATO Nations
abstract: The announcement appeared to be the Russian leader’s latest attempt to raise the stakes in his conflict with the West, coming less than two weeks after his visit to North Korea.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin declared on Friday that Russia would produce new intermediate-range nuclear-capable missiles and then decide whether to deploy them within range of NATO nations in Europe and American allies in Asia.

headline: What to Know About Israel’s Plan to Legalize 5 West Bank Settlements
abstract: Israel says it will legalize five West Bank settlements previously considered illegal, as the government accelerates what critics call a slow-motion annexation of land meant for a Palestinian state.
lead_paragraph: Israeli officials have tentatively agreed to legalize five Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, a move that could further inflame tensions between Israelis and Palestinians and draw the ire of the international community, but one that advances the expansionist agenda of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s right-wing government.

headline: Obama Defends Biden: ‘Bad Debate Nights Happen’
abstract: The former president faced a similar crisis of confidence in his re-election campaign after a bad debate performance in 2012, and he defended his former running mate in a social media post.
lead_paragraph: Former President Barack Obama, who recovered from a disastrous debate performance to win re-election in 2012, publicly backed President Biden after his poor performance in Thursday’s debate against former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: There Are ‘No Conversations’ About Replacing Biden, Campaign Official Says
abstract: The official also said President Biden was committed to attending the next presidential debate in September.
lead_paragraph: There have been no discussions among President Biden’s campaign advisers about whether the president should step down as the Democratic nominee following his disastrous performance in Thursday’s debate, a senior Biden campaign official said on Friday.

headline: For Trump, the Debate Was Another Chapter in the Rewriting of Jan. 6
abstract: It was the biggest stage yet for his effort to rewrite the story of Jan. 6, 2021.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through Thursday night’s presidential debate, the moderators asked former President Donald Trump about Jan. 6.

headline: Two Appearances, Two Starkly Different Bidens
abstract: A day after a shaky debate performance that led to talk of a new Democratic candidate, President Biden was forceful and confident while speaking to supporters.
lead_paragraph: Millions of Americans saw one Joe Biden on Thursday night: halting, hesitant, meandering and looking burdened by every one of his 81 years. Democrats were aghast.

headline: 4 Killed After Minivan Crashes Into Long Island Nail Salon
abstract: Officials did not immediately say what caused the crash, in Deer Park. Nine people were also injured.
lead_paragraph: Four people were killed and nine were injured after a minivan crashed into a nail salon on Long Island Friday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Biden’s Debate Rattles Even the Most Faithful Democrats
abstract: The most loyal, longstanding Democratic voters were perhaps the most shaken by President Biden’s performance. Some blamed the national party.
lead_paragraph: Mary Riche, 76, is a devoted member of the Democratic Party faithful. She isn’t an elected politician or a highly paid party operative, but a loyal part of the rank and file who has supported state and national Democrats since the 1970s, hosted fund-raisers in her Iowa home and enthusiastically knocked on doors for candidates.

headline: 51.3 Million Viewers Tuned In for Shaky Biden and Boisterous Trump
abstract: It was the smallest TV audience for a presidential debate since 2004, but CNN’s telecast was still among the highest-rated programs of the year.
lead_paragraph: The numbers are in: 51.3 million Americans tuned in live to watch Thursday night’s televised debate between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Biden Administration Opposes Surgery for Transgender Minors
abstract: The statement followed a report in The Times that a federal health official had urged the removal of age minimums from treatment guidelines for transgender minors.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said this week that it opposed gender-affirming surgery for minors, the most explicit statement to date on the subject from a president who has been a staunch supporter of transgender rights.

headline: How a Trump-Beating, #MeToo Legal Legend Lost Her Firm
abstract: Roberta Kaplan’s work as a lawyer made her a hero to the left. But behind the scenes, she was known for her poor treatment of colleagues.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, senior partners at Kaplan Hecker & Fink, a New York law firm known for championing liberal causes, made a fateful decision: They were going to sideline their hard-charging and crusading founder, Roberta A. Kaplan.

headline: What’s a ‘Black Job’? Trump’s Anti-Immigration Remarks Are Met With Derision
abstract: Donald J. Trump accused immigrants of stealing “Black jobs” and “Hispanic jobs” during Thursday’s debate, prompting criticism from Democrats and other social media users.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump claimed during the presidential debate on Thursday that immigrants entering the United States illegally were taking “Black jobs” and “Hispanic jobs,” a claim with little basis that Democrats immediately seized on as evidence that Mr. Trump and Republicans were not serious about cultivating support from voters of color.

headline: In Her Crisp Defense of Biden, Harris Builds a Case for Herself
abstract: Vice President Kamala Harris tried to calm Democratic fears as her allies wondered what could be next for her.
lead_paragraph: Less than 24 hours after President Biden’s faltering performance at a debate in Atlanta, Vice President Kamala Harris was standing before a crowd of supporters in a crucial battleground state on Friday, defending his record and his fitness for office.

headline: The White House Brushed Off Questions About Biden’s Age. Then the Debate Happened.
abstract: President Biden’s allies can no longer wave away concerns about his capacity after his unsteady performance at Thursday’s debate as worries among Democrats grow.
lead_paragraph: Ever since President Biden announced last year that he would run again, those in his inner circle closed ranks and brushed off the obvious question: No, they insisted, he was not too old to seek re-election.

headline: A Gleeful Trump, Fresh From the Debate, Rallies in Virginia
abstract: A day after his falsehoods largely went unchecked amid an unsteady debate performance by President Biden, former President Donald J. Trump argued that the president was unfit for office.
lead_paragraph: The day after a presidential debate in which his opponent’s stumbles took the focus, former President Donald J. Trump returned to the campaign trail on Friday afternoon, clearly gleeful as he strode onstage in front of thousands of people in a field in Virginia and gloated about his performance.

headline: Martin Mull, Comic Actor Who Rose to Fame on ‘Mary Hartman,’ Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Mull, who was also an artist and a musician, had a long list of credits that included the sitcoms “Roseanne” and “Veep.”
lead_paragraph: Martin Mull, the deadpan comic actor, singer-songwriter and artist who won widespread attention in the 1970s on television shows like “Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman” and “Fernwood 2-Night” and remained active in television and film over the next half-century, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 80.

headline: 4 Missouri Prison Guards Charged With Murder in Death of a Black Prisoner
abstract: The man, Othel Moore Jr., died of positional asphyxiation on Dec. 8 of last year at the Jefferson City Correctional Center in what the medical examiner’s office called a homicide.
lead_paragraph: Four Missouri prison guards were charged with murder on Friday and a fifth with involuntary manslaughter for their roles in the death of a Black man who died last year after they pepper sprayed him, covered his face with a mask and left him in a restraint chair, the authorities said.

headline: Down During Difficult Times?
abstract: Adrian Johnson and Rafael Musa collaborate on an uplifting themeless crossword.
lead_paragraph: Note to readers: In the past, Wordplay indicated crossword clues with quotation marks. In crossword construction and editing, though, clues are typically indicated by brackets, a practice Wordplay is now following.

headline: Jill Biden Could Make or Break Biden’s Campaign. She Says She’s All In.
abstract: If President Biden seriously considered departing the race, the first lady would be the most important figure other than Mr. Biden himself in reaching that decision.
lead_paragraph: President Biden knew immediately after stepping off the stage in Atlanta on Thursday night that the debate had gone wrong. In those first stricken moments after a raspy, rambling and at times incoherent performance, he turned to his wife, Jill Biden.

headline: Who Might Replace Biden on the Top of the Ticket?
abstract: President Biden’s stumbling performance at the debate has spurred interest in replacements. Here’s a roster of some possible backup candidates.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s stumbling performance in the debate against former President Donald J. Trump has some Democrats raising the possibility of nominating an alternative candidate and mulling over a roster of names. High on the list is, of course, Vice President Kamala Harris, whose status as Mr. Biden’s running mate might make her an easy candidate for delegates to turn to during a difficult moment. But a crop of Democratic governors and other figures are often mentioned, too.

headline: Tracking Hurricane Beryl
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Beryl.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Beryl.

headline: Corrections: June 29, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about The Episcopal Church electing its youngest leader referred incorrectly to plans for Bishop Sean Rowe’s installation ceremony. Washington National Cathedral has not been confirmed as the venue. The venue was still being decided.

headline: Quote of the Day: The Vanishing Islands That Failed to Vanish
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 29, 2024.
lead_paragraph: “Basically, it’s a forensic exercise.”

headline: ‘The Whole Country Is Falling to Bits’: Britain’s Young Voters Are Frustrated
abstract: Many young people in the northern English cities of Liverpool and Manchester say they feel disillusioned by politics.
lead_paragraph: As the flag of a British workers union flapped behind him on a blustery June morning, Liam Kehoe was on strike with colleagues outside Royal Liverpool University Hospital, demanding better pay for porters, cleaners and catering staff. Their wages have failed to keep up with the surge in the cost of living, and many said they were living paycheck to paycheck.

headline: Years Later, Philippines Reckons With Duterte’s Brutal Drug War
abstract: A president’s vow to fight drugs unleashed violence and fostered a culture of impunity. But the crimes are finally getting a look, including from the International Criminal Court.
lead_paragraph: When Rodrigo Duterte was running for president eight years ago, he vowed to order the police and the military to find drug users and traffickers to kill them, promising immunity for such killings. In the months after, police officers and vigilantes mercilessly gunned down tens of thousands of people in summary executions.
